DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 1, or the 29th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some like It Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: British Honduras changes its name to Belize.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1974: Mahmoud Talba, deputy minister of the Saudi Arabian Ministry of Commerce and Industry, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: US President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1997: French President Jacques Chirac is forced to share power with a left-wing government under Socialist Party chief Lionel Jospin.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CANADA BUSINESS CONFERENCE OPENS
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, May 31 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The annual joint conference of the Canada-Taiwan Business Council and its Taiwan counterpart, the Canadian Committee of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC), is scheduled to open on Thursday in Vancouver.

The conference, the 14th of its kind, will be jointly presided over by Doug Young, chairman of the Canada-Taiwan Business Council, and Theodore Cheng, chairman of the Canadian Committee of the CNAIC, business sources here said on Wednesday.

Unlike previous occasions when prominent officials from both sides attended the conference in order to increase its influence, this year's event shows an absence of major officials. Some observers attributed the phenomenon to tenser cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the inauguration of the Republic of China's opposition leader-turned-president Chen Shui-bian.

However, Doug Young, a heavyweight in Canada's Liberal Party, discounted such speculation, pointing out that the absence of major officials indicates that bilateral business and trade relations between Canada and Taiwan have matured.

The absence of higher level political officials, as well as major business and industrial leaders from both sides, means the bilateral Canada-Taiwan trade relationship is now mature enough to not necessarily require the guidance and assistance of the government, Young noted.

He added that after Taiwan is formally admitted into the World Trade Organization, business and trade exchanges between Canada and Taiwan will be further bolstered and the method in which they are conducted will also be different, indicating that the relationship will mature even more.

Young stressed that most Canadians are aware of Taiwan's economic prowess, particularly the island's ability to remain relatively unscathed by the Asian economic crisis that began to hit the region in mid-1997.
He said the Canadian business and industrial sectors have a high level of confidence in Taiwan's economic ability, private leadership, and skilled labor force.
Overcoming trying times such as the devastating earthquake that hit last Sept. 21, Taiwan has become even stronger and more able to face any serious challenges that may arise, Young said.
Taiwan is Canada's eighth largest trading partner, with two-way commodity trade totaling some C$5.7 billion and service trade reaching C$400 million last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FORMULA REQUIRES CONSENT OF TAIWAN: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The United States should not back any formula for resolving cross-Taiwan Strait disputes that is unacceptable to the people of Taiwan, and any solution to the issue cannot work without Taiwan's consent, emphasized an American Asia specialist.

Ralph A. Cossa, the executive director of Pacific Forum at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, wrote in the latest issue of the forum's PacNet Newsletter that the root of Communist China's concerns about the US-Japan alliance is how the guidelines of a security treaty between the two might apply to Taiwan.

He said that while China views such alliances and the forward basing of US troops as vestiges of the Cold War, many Chinese acknowledge that in the near term the US-Japan alliance, if not aimed at mainland China, generally contributes to stability in the region.
"What Beijing fails to recognize fully is that its own future deeds, not its complaints, will have the greatest influence over how close the US-Japan link is or needs to be," Cossa added.

In the current situation, "nothing short of assurances by Tokyo and Washington that neither will interfere in a cross-strait conflict is likely to seriously diminish Beijing's criticism about the revitalized US-Japan alliance. It is equally clear that such an assurance would be politically impossible and strategically irresponsible for either to give," he noted.

The only thing less likely to be accepted than Chinese demands for "no-interference" assurances from Washington is the US demand for a "no use of force" pledge from Beijing vis-a-vis Taiwan, he continued.

Washington does not want to do anything that might appear to encourage Taiwan to dramatically alter the current status quo, and Beijing desires and prefers a peaceful solution, albeit on its terms. "Nonetheless, each would do well to accept that the other intends to keep its strategic options open," he wrote.

As Americans and Chinese discuss cross-strait issues, Cossa said, "it is important to recognize that their search for common ground is secondary to the need for common ground between both sides of the Taiwan Straits."

"The election and inauguration of Chen Shui-bian as Taiwan's first opposition party president adds to the challenge but also presents an opportunity for fresh thinking. Beijing must be prepared to recognize and respond positively to Chen's overtures, rather than just demand the impossible," he added.

The Asian specialist said that "there appears to be no substitute for genuine cross-strait dialogue, which itself appears possible only if both sides are willing to go back to their 1992 understanding to agree to disagree over what `one China' means. Attempts to put a deadline either on reunification or on cross-strait negotiations are likely to backfire."

"A Sino-American Cold War is possible but not inevitable. A true strategic partnership also seems unlikely, given differing world views and long-term objectives. Perhaps the best that can be hoped for is `apprehensive engagement' -- cooperation in areas where objectives clearly overlap and a commitment to talk about and manage the many differences and lingering suspicions that continue to challenge the relationship," he said.
"This will require serious strategic dialogue, not only between the US and China, but among the four major powers and with North and South Korea and Taiwan as well," concluded Cossa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MALAYSIA INCREASES 13-FOLD IN 1ST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Investment made in Malaysia by Taiwanese businesses surged 13-fold in the first quarter of this year over the same period last year, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Thursday.

Malaysia attracted US$94 million worth of investment from Taiwan in the first three months of this year, up 1333 percent over the level a year earlier, making it the fastest-growing country in Southeast Asia in terms of soliciting Taiwanese investment, said officials from the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC).

Taiwan's private sector channeled a total of US$407.51 million into Southeast Asia for 108 investment projects in the first quarter. The amount was an increase of 106.5 percent over the level a year earlier, IDIC officials noted.
IDIC officials attributed the surge in Taiwanese investment in Malaysia mainly to the fact that more Taiwanese high-technology companies have relocated their manufacturing operations to Malaysia.
Taiwanese investment in Singapore during the same three-month period also soared, increasing a whopping 301 percent over the level a year earlier, the officials added.

Investments in Vietnam and Thailand also increased significantly, up 120 percent and 28 percent, respectively. IDIC officials said more traditional, labor-intensive Taiwanese manufacturers have relocated their operations to Vietnam, taking advantage of that country's cheap labor, inexpensive real estate costs, as well as its imminent signing of a trade agreement with the United States.
As of the end of March, Taiwan was the largest source of foreign capital in both Malaysia and Vietnam, the officials said.
Thailand, meanwhile, was the country that absorbed the largest amount of Taiwanese investment capital, a total of US$145 million, in the first three months, they added.
However, Taiwanese investment in Indonesia and the Philippines showed negative growth in the first quarter of this year, down 37 percent and 73 percent, respectively.

The officials attributed the diminished amount of Taiwanese investment in Indonesia to such factors as political instability and anti-Chinese hostility harbored by some Indonesian citizens. Factors involved in the decreased amount of investment in the Philippines included unstable government policies, government inefficiency, as well as the suspension of direct Taiwan-Philippine air links, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NATIONAL CONGRESS TO DECIDE FATE OF 'INDEPENDENCE' PLANK

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is almost certain to be the next chairman of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Thursday that the DPP can consider showing goodwill to mainland China.

Hsieh was responding to a Hong Kong newspaper report which quoted mainland Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs as having said that so long as the DPP revises its pro-Taiwan independence party charter, the Chinese Communist Party will consider embarking on party-to-party contact with the DPP.
Hsieh, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician, said it's up to the DPP's national congress to decide whether to revise, shelve or scrap the so-called pro-independence plank in the party's charter.
The DPP, which has emerged as Taiwan's ruling party following Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration as the Republic of China's new president, is scheduled to hold its biennial party congress in July.

Hsieh, who had been a Taipei city councilor, legislator and the DPP's vice presidential candidate for the 1996 presidential election before assuming his current post, announced his bid to run for the DPP chairmanship on Wednesday. Without a major heavyweight challenger, Hsieh is in line to be next DPP chairman. The party will hold the chairmanship election on June 25.

Hsieh said although he has his own views on issues related to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, it's not suitable for him to publicly expressed too many opinions on the sensitive topic before the opening of the party's national congress.
In his own view, Hsieh said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should observe each other and learn from each other while avoiding provoking tension and unease.
"Constructive cross-strait interaction is conducive to people on both sides of the strait," Hsieh noted.
Mainland Chinese authorities have so far ruled out any contact with the DPP because of the party's pro-independence stance.
Hsieh said since President Chen, a DPP stalwart, has extended olive branch to Beijing, the DPP itself can follow suit.

Hsieh further said he believes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to overcome many technical problems concerning cross-strait engagement so long as they show goodwill and sincerity toward each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO COMPLETE QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION WITHIN 4 YEARS
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, central Taiwan, June 1 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday reassured the Taiwan public that earthquake reconstruction in central Taiwan will be completed within four years.

Chen has required that the Executive Yuan push for a four-year timetable for the rehabilitation of quake-battered areas so that economic prosperity can return to the areas and the people there can once again have happy homes.

The president made the remarks at a ceremony marking the establishment of the Post-Earthquake Reconstruction Promotion Committee under the Executive Yuan. The committee formally became operational on Thursday in Chung Hsing New Village, where the Taiwan provincial government is located.

Chen said the establishment of the committee marks a brand new start in post-quake rehabilitation engineering, adding that it also symbolizes the government's sincerity in delivering on its promises to the people.

Chen urged the relevant reconstruction officials and workers of the reconstruction committee to become good neighbors in the quake-affected communities, offering assistance and services with heartfelt compassion similar to that of the Goddess of the Sea, Matsu.

Chen said that over the next four years, the committee will heed the voices of the people, widely adopt suggestions from specialists, provide barrier-free communication channels, and conduct useful dialogue with the people and all private groups and organizations.
Pointing out that no government can run dynamically without a powerful and capable partner, Chen said the government needs the private sector to pitch in with the reconstruction work.

The magnitude 7.3 earthquake that struck on Sep. 21 was one of the deadliest worldwide this century and the biggest ever recorded on the tremor-plagued island. It claimed the lives of at least 2,400 people, injured some 84,000, and left 100,000 others temporarily homeless.
The tremor also leveled more than 6000 buildings and partially ruined another 5,600 buildings, including 140 schools, mostly in counties in central Taiwan.

The killer quake caused more than NT$300 billion (US$9.49 billion) worth of property damage islandwide, which represented a 3.3 percent reduction in the country's gross national product (GNP) for 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG'S ENTRY INTO OIL MARKET TO SPOIL PARTY FOR EX-MONOPOLY CPC

TEXT.P: The entrance of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) into Taiwan's fuel oil market may cause money-making Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to suffer financial losses ranging from NT$10 billion to NT$60 billion a year, CPC Chairman Chen Chao-wei said on Thursday.

Addressing some 600 CPC staff members during a ceremony marking the state-run corporation's 54th founding anniversary, Chen urged employees of CPC and affiliated firms to make concerted efforts to lower costs and sharpen their competitive edge in the face of cutthroat competition from FPG.

In an effort to streamline operations and cut corruption, Chen said the company has cooperated with the government's discipline agencies and has uncovered 295 cases of suspected corruption and irregularities involving CPC staff over the past two-and-a-half years. The crackdown has helped save some NT$15.4 billion for the company, he added.

CPC, one of Taiwan's most profitable government-owned enterprises, posted annual sales of NT$380 billion in fiscal year 1999, Chen noted. He added that after accounting for pension fund deductions, the company had a pre-tax net profit of NT$29.5 billion, exceeding the firm's official target of NT$22.4 billion.

Nevertheless, Chen pointed out, with FPG's imminent entry into the fuel market, CPC will face an immediate price war in oil products, with losses likely to reach NT$10 billion to NT$60 billion a year.
Meanwhile, CPC President Pan Wen-yen said that as of April 30 this year, there were a total of 603 CPC-run gas stations islandwide, compared with 1,341 privately-own service stations.

At present, total sales of gasoline and diesel fuel by private filling stations exceed sales by CPC-run gas stations. CPC's market share is doomed to shrink even further if FPG enters the fuel oil market, Pan noted.
FPG-produced gasoline and diesel oil are expected to be put on the market later this year, formally ending CPC's decades-old monopoly on the oil processing and distribution market in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD WILLING TO MEDIATE CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said on Thursday that if necessary, he will not hesitate to help mediate relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The head of the Republic of China's highest research body made the offer during a Legislative Yuan Budget Committee meeting.

Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry, originally intended to explain Academia Sinica's budget plans for the next fiscal year. However, legislators asked him a variety of questions, ranging from cross-strait relations and educational reforms to the performance of the ROC's newly inaugurated government.

Lee came out shortly before the March 18 presidential election to back pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate Chen Shui-bian. Lee's endorsement was believed to have contributed to Chen's election victory. His action enraged mainland Chinese leaders who said Lee has lost qualifications for mediating cross-strait talks by taking side with Chen.

Lee told lawmakers that he believes mainland leaders have by now come to understand that their judgment of his role might be wrong. "There are signs that mainland leaders are revising their views about me, and if necessary, I'm still willing to serve as a mediator to help seek a breakthrough to the current cross-strait logjam," he noted.

Lee, a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, further said he thinks that a supraparty task force will be inaugurated within a month to forge a national consensus on sensitive cross-strait issues.

Nevertheless, Lee said since the new government has been formed, many affairs, including cross-strait issues, should be dealt with within the official framework. "Take mainland affairs as an example. The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation should play the crucial role in handling related affairs," he said.
Lee further said he himself has never intended to serve as premier, although both incumbent President Chen and former President Lee Teng-hui had offered the job to him.

Meanwhile, the widely respected scholar said as Taiwan just completed its first democratic transfer of power from the Kuomintang to the DPP, lawmakers should give the new government "more time and room" to resolve many problems left by the previous administration.

Lee said he believes that the island's first transition of power between different political parties in 55 years has had a positive impact on local society. "Nevertheless, now is still a transitional period. We should give the new administration a longer period of time to implement its new policies and reform measures."

Lee, who headed Chen's national affairs advisory group during the final stage of campaigning for the presidency, also said he doesn't think that the new administration should indiscriminately deliver on all of Chen's campaign promises or "checks."
"I doubt the wisdom to turn all of the campaign checks into government policies. The new administration should not hesitate to revise or drop impractical or unrealistic campaign checks," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO ATTEND MINISTERIAL-LEVEL APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Yi-hsin will head an ROC delegation to attend the June 6-7 ministerial-level trade meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Council to be held in Australia, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on Thursday.
Other members of the delegation will include Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long and Liu Po-lun, the ROC's representative in Australia.
Topics will be centered on how APEC can support the international trade system, regional economic cooperation, trade and investment liberalization and facilitation, and biochemical technology.
This will be the first foreign trip for Lin since assuming the post of economics minister on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION PROMOTES PRODUCTS IN POLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Warsaw, June 1, (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Year 2000 East European Trade Mission, a 70-member delegation to promote Taiwan commercial interests, held on Wednesday a symposium on Taiwan trading opportunities for Polish businesses. More than 200 local business and industrial representatives participated in the meeting.

A senior official of Poland's economics ministry and the ROC representative in Poland, Huang Hsin-pi, jointly presided over the seminar. A Polish official in charge of trade promotion briefed the Taiwan trade mission on economic and trade development in Poland.
The trade mission was sponsored by China External Trade and Development (CETRA). It arrived in Poland Tuesday night, having traveled from Hungary.

Members of the mission hold a trade exhibition on Thursday, where they will exhibit samples of their products. More than 200 local buyers are expected to attend the exhibition, which is expected to generate orders worth US$10 million.

Twelve traders will leave the group and proceed to Macedonia to research that country's climate for private investment after the mission ends its tour of Eastern Europe. The government of Macedonia established official ties with the ROC last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WILL NOT MEDIATE CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: PERRY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, May 31 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Secretary William Perry reiterated on Wednesday that the United States will not play a role as a mediator in talks between Taiwan and mainland China.
Perry made the statement while meeting with James Soong, chairman of Taiwan's People First Party (PFP).

While expressing his grave concern over the future development across the Taiwan Strait, Perry told Soong that the United States will never seek to mediate in negotiations between Taiwan and mainland China.

Both Soong and Perry have maintained a low profile following their hour-long meeting at Stanford University, which was focused on Taiwan's democratization and the future of Taiwan-mainland ties. But Perry reportedly gave high praise to the performance of the Taiwan people in the island's March 18 presidential election.

Perry reportedly took the initiative by asking to meet with Soong upon the PFP chairman's arrival in San Francisco. The former US defense secretary is slated to lead a delegation to Taiwan and the mainland in mid-June.
Soong, currently on a trip to the US, arrived in the United States on May 18.

While here, he has met with former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, US officials in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs and members of local think tanks. He also received an honorary doctorate from the University of Maryland on May 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TALK WITH 11 MEMBER STATES IN APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi will leave for Australia on Saturday to attend a ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for June 6-7 in Darwin.

Lin will hold bilateral talks with 11 APEC member states -- the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Burma -- on the meeting's theme of creating prosperity for the region through the APEC mechanism.
Lin will also meet with World Trade Organization (WTO) Secretary-General Mike Moore to seek his support for Taiwan's membership in the world trade regulatory body.

According to Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruei-long, Lin will talk with Moore as part of his efforts to ensure Taiwan's smooth entry into the WTO by the end of this year. A Republic of China delegation composed of 16 officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Council on Agriculture will travel with Lin to Australia for the APEC meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CISCO CEO TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: John Chambers, chairman and CEO of Cisco System, the world's largest manufacturer of internet system equipment, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei next week to attend a high-tech education summit and to deliver a lecture, sources from Cisco Taiwan said on Friday.

Cisco, under the leadership of Chambers, has recently become the corporation with the highest market value in the world. The company's rise has also given new fame to Chambers, who has been called "Top CEO in America,"
Other titles that Chambers has earned include "the greatest leader in America," "one of the world's 10 most influential figures in science and technology innovation," and "Mr. Internet."

Chambers, who was recently awarded the title of "2000 Internet Leader" by the American Internet Convention, will deliver a keynote speech entitled "The Network Effect: Productivity in the New Economy" to the World Congress of Information Technology (WCIT), scheduled to kick off on June 11 at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Chambers will also take part in the Educational Summit on the Internet Era being co-sponsored by Academia Sinica and the Ministry of Education, said company sources. During the summit, Chambers will join Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and Education Minister Ovid J.L. Tzeng for discussions.
During his short stay in Taipei, Chambers will also meet with ranking officials of the new ROC government to exchange views on technology exchanges, the sources said.

Chambers, who regards Taiwan as a lifelong business partner, was last in Taipei in April, 1999 for discussions on cooperative projects with Taiwan. One of those projects was one that Cisco is now cooperating with Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry (III) to carry out. It involves establishing a cable modem laboratory to further develop Taiwan's internet hardware technologies.

Cisco previously helped the III establish a laboratory in Taiwan to develop asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL) technology. ADSL modems provide instant high-speed data communication connections for internet access, video conferencing, remote access, and multimedia applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Friday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved up 5 points to close at 8,920, with 3,570 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July increased 45 points to finish at 8,960, with 87 contract transactions; September futures gained 36 points to close at 9,100, with 17 contract transactions; and December futures moved down 7 points to close at 9,253, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 8,915 for June; 8,915 for July; 9,064 for September; 9,260 for December; and 9,145 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchanged-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
June TE futures moved up 3.5 points to close at 487, with 1,315 contract transactions, while July TE futures increased 5.2 points to finish at 486.7, with 21 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

June TF futures decreased 12.4 points to close at 938, with 566 contract transactions, while July TF futures lost 5 points to finish at 945, with 50 contract transactions, and September TF futures moved down 3 points to close at 949.4, with 23 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 2, or the first day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1780: Lord George Gordon foments riots to protest against the ending of penalties against Roman Catholics in the Roman Catholic Relief Act of 1778.
1868: Britain crushes the Marathas in India and annexes their lands.
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1899: Spain cedes the Carolinas, Pelews, Marianne and Ladrones to Germany.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and US Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1946: Italy becomes a republic after its monarchy is abolished.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The coronation is televised for the first time.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Malaysia and Indonesia agree to end five years of hostilities.
1966: Surveyor I, a US automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the US destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo service to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1976: Alberto Santofimio Botero, president of the Colombian Chamber of Representatives, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by British fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He was best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage, and in the film version of 1964, and for which he won not only a Tony but also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST AMERICANS THINK CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD POOR: POLL

TEXT.P: A large majority of Americans think that mainland China's government does a bad job respecting human rights, according to a recent Gallup poll.

As the 11th anniversary of the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing's Tiananmen Square approaches, the poll found that 67 percent of the respondents feel Communist China has a poor record of respecting the human rights of its citizens, with 36 percent describing the record as "very bad."
Only 18 percent of those Americans surveyed between May 23-24 believe Beijing is doing a good job in this respect.
At the same time, however, 54 percent of those surveyed said it is more important to maintain good relations with China than to take a strong stand on Beijing's poor human rights record.

Another recent Gallup poll, conducted between May 18-21, showed that Americans are split on their view of the state of US-PRC relations, with 51 percent considering China as either an ally or as a friendly nation and 43 percent considering it as unfriendly or as an enemy.

Meanwhile, the poll, which was conducted prior to the US House of Representatives' passage of legislation for granting PNTR status for China, found that 62 percent of the respondents felt the US should not increase trade with China until Beijing gives more economic, political, and religious freedom to its citizens, while 56 percent favored normalizing trade relations with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOM CRUISE IN TOWN TO PROMOTE `MISSION: IMPOSSIBLE II'

TEXT.P: Actor Tom Cruise and action film director John Woo arrived in Taipei from Hong Kong on a private plane Friday to promote their new picture "Mission: Impossible II."
Dressed in black and wearing dark sunglasses, Cruise displayed his trademark charming smile amidst throngs of security guards and a large crowd of shrieking fans at the CKS International Airport.
Cruise, who will be in Taiwan for less than 24 hours, is on a tight schedule while here. He is expected to take part in a press conference at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel at 3 p.m.
In the evening, fans will get a chance to get up close when Cruise walks the red carpet rolled out especially for the Taiwan premier of "Mission: Impossible II" at a film complex in eastern Taipei.
This movie was the first time Cruise and Woo collaborated on a project together, and they became good friends during the production of the film.
Woo said in Hong Kong on Thursday that the only complaint he had about the movie star was his love of danger.
"He wanted to do everything by himself and that made me very worried and nervous," he said.
"Mission: Impossible 2" is scheduled to open in Taiwan on June 17. The picture scored big at the box office in its opening weekend in the United States, raking in US$70.8 million over three days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT SOUTH AFRICA IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to leave for South Africa in October to co-chair an international women's meeting, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

A MOFA spokesman told a routine news conference that as Lu is one of the seven female vice presidents in 192 countries around the world today, organizers of the Seventh Global Summit of Women to be held in Johannesburg have invited Lu to co-chair the summit with six other women deputy heads of state.

The first Global Summit of Women was held in 1988, and Lu organized the fourth conference in Taipei in 1994 with the participation of more than 400 outstanding female politicians from 70-plus countries.
As the ROC does not have formal diplomatic ties with South Africa, the MOFA spokesman said it remains uncertain in which capacity or form Lu will visit South Africa.

Mainland China has never hesitated to try to block the ROC's engagement with other countries, particularly those with which it maintains official ties. South Africa switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1998.
Nevertheless, the MOFA spokesman said the ministry is now actively arranging for Lu to realize her overseas travel plan. The 2000 world summit on women's affairs is scheduled for Oct. 5-7.

Lu, the ROC's first female vice president, has been a democracy and women's rights activist. She was jailed for more than five years in the 1980s for her role in a pro-democracy demonstration during Taiwan's martial law era. She had been a legislator and Taoyuan County magistrate before assuming her current post on May 20.
Meanwhile, the MOFA spokesman said the Dominican Republic, one of the ROC diplomatic allies in the Caribbean, has invited President Chen Shui-bian to make a state visit later this year.

"The MOFA has sent a Dominican Republic travel plan to the Presidential Office," the spokesman said, adding that it's up to the Presidential Office to make a final decision on the exact visiting time and relevant itinerary.
