DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER CHILD SUCCUMBS TO KILLER ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: Another child died after being infected with enterovirus (EV), bringing the total number of child deaths caused by the viral disease in Taiwan to five this year, disease control officials said on Friday.
As of Thursday, 18 other young children have also died this year of suspected EV infections.
The latest victim, a four-month-old baby boy from the eastern city of Ilan, died Thursday of encephalitis and acute inflammation of the heart muscle in a Taipei hospital.
The child was sent to an Ilan hospital Monday after getting serious ulcers and blisters in his mouth and throat, typical complications caused by EV type-71, doctors said.

According to Chen Kuo-dong, a division head at the Center for Disease Control (CDC), the victim was an only child living in a neighborhood with no other young children. Doctors suspect that the child's mother, a working woman, might be the source of the baby's fatal illness. The mother has been asked to have her blood tested as part of the clinical investigation.
So far this year, there have been 98 suspected cases of serious EV infection, including the 23 fatal cases, all of them children under the age of three, said Chen.

Most of the 98 suspected EV infection cases were reported in northern Taiwan. Laboratory examination results showed that the suspected cases included EV type-71, coxsackievirus type A-16, and coxsackievirus type B-3, Chen noted.

Children younger than five are most susceptible to EV. Early symptoms of the infection resemble the flu, with fever, headache and vomiting. Ulcers or blisters in the mouth and rashes on the palms and feet can also develop. Later, possible deadly complications include encephalitis, meningitis, and acute inflammation of the heart muscle.
This year's epidemic appears to be a little more serious than last year's, said Chen, adding that there were 35 serious cases and nine deaths reported last year.
Meanwhile, a preschool class in Paiho Township, Tainan County was ordered to close Friday after two children in the class were rushed to a hospital in Chiayi.

Although the children were not clinically diagnosed as having contracted EV, they are receiving further tests due to their sudden blurred vision. EV infection, which can cause meningitis and encephalitis, may also cause blurred vision, doctors said.
So far this year, there have been 1,300 cases of suspected EV infection reported in Tainan County alone, although most of them were not serious cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS PREPARING TO EXPAND OPERATIONS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taipei-based TransAsia Airways, the third local airline company to operate international flight services, is preparing to open a liaison office in Beijing in June, company sources said on Friday.

A company spokesman said the move is aimed at bolstering services to Taiwan passengers who transfer from Macau to mainland Chinese cities, as well as paving the way for the much-discussed "three direct links" between Taiwan and mainland China.

With its current fleet of 10 Airbus A320 and A321 aircraft and nine ATR 72-500/200 jets, TransAsia operates 144 domestic flights, as well as 12 international daily flights on the Taipei-Macao, Kaohsiung-Macao, Taipei-Phuket and Taipei-Kinabalu routes.

Although ticket sales for domestic flights have fallen as a result of a price hike, TransAsia still managed to post a monthly business turnover of NT$555 million (US$18 million) in May, up 24 percent over the same month of last year. The company attributed the growth mainly to brisk sales of its international flight tickets.
TransAsia sold 3.8 million domestic seats last year, representing 27 percent of Taiwan's domestic flight market, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TPEC PITCHER TO BE SIGNED TO NY YANKEES

TEXT.P: Ace baseball pitcher C.M. Wang of the Taipei Physical Education College (TPEC) is scheduled to sign a US$2.01 million contract with the New York Yankees next week, TPEC sources reported on Friday.
The signing of the contract will make Wang the first Taiwanese college student to join any professional baseball team in the United States, the sources said.

If all goes smoothly, Wang is expected to leave for the United States later this month to begin his career by pitching in the minor leagues, which serve as training grounds for major league baseball players.
Wang has been watched by American baseball teams, including the Mariners and Dodgers, for the last five years, according to his coach at TPEC.

With a 148 km-per-hour pitch, Wang has a variety of pitches in his arsenal, including curve ball, slider, screwball, sinker and knuckle ball, but the Yankees scout was most impressed by his fork ball, the coach said.

Wang is expected to spend his first nine months in the United States receiving pitching training and playing in the minor leagues. Later, he will study baseball theory and English at a sister college of TPEC before returning to TPEC to continue his studies for three months before heading back to the United States to continue his professional career.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOY ASKS TO DISOWN MOTHER

TEXT.P: A 10-year-old boy went on his own to the Chiayi District Court on Thursday to ask to disown his mother because he is afraid of being beaten again.
The boy, surnamed Chiu, took a taxi after school directly to the district court to ask judges to place him under his father's custody rather than his mother's.
Chiu has been living with his mother since his parents divorced a couple of years ago.
He told the judges that he was beaten by his mother every time she found out that he had visited his father, who lives in another township in suburban Chiayi.

Police called both the boy's parents, whereupon the father rushed to the district court. He said he could no longer stand to see the child so abused, and added that it was unfair that judges granted custody of the child to his mother at the divorce hearing simply because the mother said he was not financially capable of raising the child.

The father said his ex-wife is a gambler, insensitive to the child's needs and unfit to be a mother. The mother did not show up at the court, but told reporters over the telephone that both the boy and his father are liars.
The police allowed Chiu to go home with his father and the judges agreed that they will look into the case and will possibly grant custody to the father.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD HOPING CROSS-STRAIT TALKS CAN RESUME SOON

TEXT.P: The government hopes high-level talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can be held as soon as possible, an official in charge of the nation's mainland policy said on Friday.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), expressed the hope that the mainland feels the same way, and stressed that the desire to move cross-strait relations toward positive development is not just "empty words."

She also said the timing of talks will have to take into consideration the physical fitness of the two top negotiators -- Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Tsai said that "stark December doesn't seem a suitable time for the two octogenarians to meet," while the possibility of an October meeting will depend on efforts by both sides.

She stressed that the long-established communication channel between the SEF and ARATS should not be scrapped, noting that it is still "the most important communication mechanism." The alternative "track II" or "track III" dialogue channels can only serve as "supplementary mechanisms," she added.

Talks between the SEF and ARATS have been stalled since last July following former President Lee Teng-hui's statement that cross-strait ties should be regarded as "a special state-to-state relationship," drawing Beijing's ire.

Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin pointed out that the 1992 talks between SEF and ARATS didn't reach a conclusion on the "one China" issue, other than to "agree to disagree" on the interpretation of "one China."

Lin was responding to remarks made a day earlier by ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei that Taiwan has reversed the agreement reached in 1992 and that it is due to Taiwan's "troublemaking" that relations between the two sides are stalled.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar remained unchanged against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at NT$30.831.
The local currency opened at NT$30.854 and was traded between NT$30.783 and NT$30.854.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$446.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOLD MEMORIAL CONCERT TO MARK TIANANMEN SQUARE MASSACRE

TEXT.P: A memorial concert will be held in Taipei on the evening of June 4 to mark the 11th anniversary of the bloody mainland Chinese suppression of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Organizers of the event include Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh, Kuomintang Vice Secretary-General Shaw Yu-ming and Taipei City Councilman Pan Chien-kuo of the People First Party.
Ma told the media on Friday that the memorial concert is designed to transform the June 4 pro-democracy spirit into a positive action for the future.
It will be held at the assembly hall of the Taipei City Council and will feature silent prayer, memorial documentary films and videotaped remarks by pro-democracy leaders Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is also expected to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT URGED TO TAKE ACTION AGAINST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 2 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A Philippine labor broker organization on Friday called on President Joseph Estrada to take "appropriate measures" on Taiwan's three-month ban on the importation of new Filipino laborers.

A spokesman for Filipino Agencies Accredited to Taiwan (FAAT) said that Taiwan's new labor policy will cut some 10,000 job opportunities for Filipino laborers, representing a total loss of earnings of 150 million pesos.

Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs imposed the ban from June 1 on the import of Filipino laborers for big construction projects in retaliation for interference by the Philippines in labor disputes in Taiwan involving foreign laborers over the years.
FAAT President Raul de Vera Jr. blamed former Philippine officials in charge of labor affairs for failing to reach an agreement with the ROC agencies concerned.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN LAUNCHES 15TH U-TYPE SHIP

TEXT.P: Evergreen Group christened and launched its 15th post-Panama U-type vessel in a ceremony held at the Kobe, Japan, shipyard of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries on Friday.

Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa named the new ship "Ever Unicorn," while Panamanian Governor Irlena Brown Villalobos broke the traditional champagne bottle across the ship's bows, watched by scores of guests and top Evergreen executives.

"Ever Unicorn" is scheduled to go into service immediately after her delivery in September. The ship has a capacity of 5,652 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent containers). She is 285 meters long, 40 meters wide and has a draft of 12.7 meters, with a cruising speed of 25 knots.
The U-type ship is presently the fastest and largest vessel in the Evergreen fleet.
The group has ordered 18 of the giant ships, 13 of which have been delivered. The other five are scheduled for delivery before mid-2001.
Evergreen officials said that building large-sized container ships, expanding strategic alliances and offering customers timely and precise e-service is the new market trend in the shipping industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AMERICAN TRIP FOR PRESIDENT STILL ON DRAWING BOARD: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's plan to visit Republic of China diplomatic allies in Latin American is still in the planning stages, a ranking presidential aide said on Friday.

Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chung-hsiung said that while Chen does indeed have plans for such a visit, the matter must wait until full arrangements have been made by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA). "It would be premature at this time to talk about which countries Chen will visit," he added.
It has been speculated that the president could visit several Central American countries, including the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua, as soon as mid-August.

However, MOFA said it has in fact completed the relevant plans for the trip, and that the Presidential Office has been studying them, although it noted that the feasibility of the visit is dependent on a number of additional factors.

In an unrelated development, meanwhile, Chang said the question of whether he will represent Chen at a memorial service for late Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi had not yet been decided, as he had yet to receive word from the Japanese government in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO TURN `GOODWILL INTO ACTION' TO IMPROVE TIES WITH BEIJING (I)

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said on Friday that the Republic of China is willing to turn "goodwill into action" and promote exchanges and cooperation with mainland China on the basis of mutual respect.
Tang, who is still recovering from surgery carried out in April to remove a chest tumor, made the pledge in his first administrative report to the Legislative Yuan.
He told lawmakers that since he was appointed premier of the ROC's new administration, he has been thinking of the kind of administration he wants to establish.

"In my mind, public well-being should be the administration's priority concern and all administrative programs should contribute to ensuring national security," said the four-star general-turned-premier.

Tang outlined six major categories of his administrative plan -- improving cross-strait relations; declaring war on "black gold" politics; accelerating economic development; substantiating educational reforms and boosting cultural development; rejuvenating government structure and upgrading administrative efficiency; and speeding up reconstruction of the 921 earthquake-stricken areas.

Noting that pursuing peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is critical to the nation's national security, Tang said the ROC is willing to hold comprehensive dialogue, including discussion of political issues with mainland China, on the basis of mutual respect.

Beijing froze semi-official talks with Taipei last July after then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined bilateral ties as a "special state-to-state relationship," and the communist regime has been pressuring the new ROC administration to embrace its cherished "one China" policy -- that there is only one China, of which Taiwan is a part -- in order to allow bilateral talks to resume.
The government has balked at the demand thus far because the policy downgrades the ROC to a local government under the People's Republic of China.

In his report, Tang, a former ROC Air Force commander-in-chief, chief of the General Staff and defense minister, stressed the importance of continuing to beef up the nation's defense capabilities in order to ensure national security, sovereignty and dignity.
He also called for the establishment of a cross-strait military mutual trust mechanism to avoid any possible conflict resulting from miscalculation or misinformation on either side.
Tang said his Cabinet will also conduct an overall review of the ROC's decades-old ban on direct trade, transportation and postal links with mainland China.

"And we regard Taipei's and Beijing's expected accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) later this year as an additional opportunity to improve bilateral ties," the premier said, adding he is hopeful that the other side of the strait will reciprocate "goodwill with goodwill."

On the diplomatic front, Tang said the new government will continue carrying out the previous administration's "pragmatic diplomacy" to reach out to the world and break Taiwan out of its Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation.

"We'll also push for the establishment of a national human rights commission and reinforce contact with international human rights organizations in order to bring the ROC back into the world human rights system," he said.

Turning to domestic issues, Tang declared an all-out war on "black gold" politics, saying his Cabinet will integrate the strength and resources of police, investigation, prosecution and other relevant law-enforcement authorities to stamp out irregularities in public works bidding procedures, cut out money-linked politics, wipe out official corruption, eradicate the involvement of organized crime in politics, draw a clear line between political and business interests and crack down on manipulation of the local bourse by underworld criminal rings. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO TURN 'GOODWILL INTO ACTION' (II)

TEXT.P: Tang further said the government will set up a special supervisory and management commission to oversee restructuring of troubled financial institutions, resolve the bad debt and overdue loan problems and ensure domestic financial and market stability.

In addition to boosting the development of high-tech industries to build Taiwan into a "green silicon island," Tang said the Cabinet will continue helping traditional industries upgrade production, management and competitiveness and assisting local farmers to cope with the challenges sure to arise from the ROC's forthcoming WTO entry and the global trend toward farming trade liberalization.

Tang, a Kuomintang stalwart, was named by President Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party to head the Cabinet partly because the KMT still dominates the legislature. His premiership was also designed to placate old-guard military generals who are vehemently opposed to any move toward Taiwan independence.

Tang's first administrative report drew mixed reactions from legislators from the various political parties. While DPP lawmakers generally gave a thumbs-up to Tang's administrative plans, their counterparts from the opposition parties, including the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party, criticized him for failing to present any innovative, forward-looking policy goals or concrete measures to deliver on President Chen's campaign promises.

Most of the opposition also expressed disappointment at Tang's failure to explain his Cabinet's stance on several controversial but very important issues, such as how the government plans to handle the fourth nuclear power plant project.
New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao said Tang's administrative report lacks vision and shows no innovative thinking.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY CELEBRATES ARRIVAL OF LEASED DOCK LANDING SHIP

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy on Friday celebrated the arrival at the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan of an Anchorage-class dock landing ship (LSD) leased from the United States.

ROC Fleet Vice Commodore Huang Cheng-yun said at a welcoming ceremony that after the 30-year-old vessel, renamed Hsuhai (Radiant Sea), has completed combat readiness training in mid-June, it will replace the 50-year-old LSD Chungcheng.

Anchorage-class ships, which are still in active service in the US Navy, are fast and have large troop transport capacities, two qualities that will greatly enhance the ROC Navy's amphibious operational strength, Huang added.

Formerly named the USS Pensacola (LSD-38), the Hsuhai will join the navy's Newport-class tank landing ships (LST) Chungho and Chungping to form a high-speed amphibious flotilla for rapid response missions.

The Hsuhai is one of just five vessels of its class. It is 171 meters long and 25 meters wide with a full displacement tonnage of 13,700 tons. It was constructed by General Dynamics at their Quincy, Massachusetts, facility and was commissioned by the US Navy in 1971.

The LSD has a maximum speed of 22 knots and can sail for 14,800 nautical miles without refueling. Armed with a Phalanx air defense system, it can accommodate 360 fully equipped infantrymen in addition to light LST's and amphibious tanks.

Hsuhai is the first of two Anchorage-class LSD's that the ROC Navy has leased from the United States through the foreign military sales (FMS) program. The only other decommissioned US vessel in its class is the USS Fort Fisher (LSD-40), currently berthed in Benecia, California, according to the US Navy's Naval Vessel Register.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOSTON UNIVERSITY INVITES ROC PRESIDENT TO VISIT

TEXT.P: Visiting Boston University Chancellor Jon Westling on Friday invited ROC President Chen Shui-bian to visit and deliver a speech at his school.
Westling extended his invitation during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Chen, who at 49 is the Republic of China's youngest president.

Chen said he appreciates Westling's invitation. "I'm more than willing to accept your invitation. The problem lies in whether the US government will issue a visa for me to realize the travel plan," the president said, adding: "But anyway, I'm grateful for your invitation. And this indicates that Boston really is the cradle of US freedom and democracy."

Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in 1995 to deliver a speech at his alma mater -- Cornell University. Lee's trip enraged Beijing which viewed it as a move to promote Taiwan independence. The communist regime retaliated by unilaterally suspending semi-official dialogue with Taipei and further vented its spleen by conducting live-fire war games and missile testing on Taiwan's doorstep.

Beijing has spared no effort to block the ROC's engagement with other countries and its presence in the international arena, which has made it very difficult for senior ROC leaders to visit countries which diplomatically recognize Beijing instead of Taipei.
Westling and several other senior Boston University executives arrived in Taipei earlier this week to take part in a meeting of the school's Taiwan alumni.

Chen said he admires Boston University for its liberal education tradition and its outstanding academic achievements. The 159-year-old school is one of the top-notch US universities and boasts the second largest enrollment of foreign students in the United States. The school currently has 300 students from Taiwan.
Later in the day, President Chen also met with a delegation of senior executives from the Barry Goldwater Research Institute, an Arizona State-based think tank.
The think tank was founded in 1988 in memory of the late US Senator Barry Goldwater, a staunch supporter of the ROC.
Chen, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician, said he admires Sen. Goldwater for his lifelong promotion of the concepts of "limited government, economic freedom and individual responsibility."
Chen also expressed his gratitude for the institute's contribution to promoting cooperation between Taiwan and US think tanks over past years.

The president said he hopes private think tanks in both countries will strengthen cooperation in research on topics related to Taiwan's development, relations across the Taiwan Strait and Asia-Pacific peace and stability to help boost regional peace and prosperity.
The delegation was led by Tracy R. Thomas, head of the Barry Goldwater Research Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND: BEIJING INCAPABLE OF BLOCKING TAIWAN PORTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ministry of National Defense officials said on Friday that the ministry doesn't know about any Beijing plan to block the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung, and added that Beijing lacks the capability of doing so.

A CNA corespondent in Canberra quoted the Sydney Morning Herald as reporting that mainland Chinese submarines have recently been detected in waters off Taiwan, a development that the paper said signals that Beijing intends to enforce a blockade aimed at forcing Taiwan to the negotiating table.
The officials said that the MND knows nothing about the report, and added that Beijing did not have the capacity to carry out a blockade of Taiwan sea ports.
They stressed that MND will announce any military actions by mainland China to the public, and urged the mass media to report the event in accordance with MND announcements.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES SEEKS A LIFT ON TAIWAN'S BAN ON NEW FILIPINO WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs is seeking a lift on the ban on Filipino workers imposed by Taiwan government, branding the policy as unfair since it applies only to Filipinos.

"We have a large number of skilled Filipinos and besides, if it is close to us, why is it open to other countries? We need the jobs there and Taiwan also needs us. Do not think that they don't need us," Foreign Affairs Undersecretary for Migrant Workers Benjamin Domingo said.
Domingo disclosed Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei Representative Rodolfo Reyes has started negotiations to remove the hiring freeze on Filipino workers.
"We are not begging, we have a position and our workers have skills that other nationalities do not have. They should not limit the entrance of Filipino workers,?" Domingo said.
He expressed optimism that things would "turn out well in the next month or so," as the government would also address the concerns of the Taiwanese side.
Taiwanese officials had cited long-standing labor issues such as the government's blacklisting of certain Taiwanese employers and recruitment agencies as reasons for the ban.

They also cited the high rate of Filipino workers who run away from their sponsoring employers, and said that the Philippine government's intervention in labor disputes between Taiwanese employers and their Filipino workers was "unfair treatment."
The ban will cover new applicants and not Filipinos already employed in Taiwan.

Domingo said that some problems between the two sides are caused by cultural differences, as some Filipinos bring their workplace habits abroad. For example, Domingo explained that Taiwanese do not stage sit-down strikes, a common form of labor protest in the Philippines.

In the meantime, Domingo said the Filipinos would still be able to find jobs in Taiwan. Construction-related jobs are plentiful, because of ongoing restructuring after last year's earthquake, he said, adding that no other nationalities could take the place of Filipino health care and related service workers.
The undersecretary expressed his suspicion that the ban on new workers was related to the ongoing dispute over air rights between the two nations, and added that the two issues should not be linked.

"Taiwan is very important to us because its state of industrialization... It not only provides jobs for our people but also a place to learn about industries. The air agreement should be treated as an isolated case," Domingo said.
Manila unilaterally canceled its air agreement with Taipei in October of last year due to several violations committed by the Taiwanese carriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN NORMALIZE ECON. TIES WITH M'LAND AFTER WTO ENTRY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO) will not only provide Taiwan with the benefit of freer global trade, but also increase the possibility of normalizing economic relations with China, a leading Taiwanese economist said here Friday.

"If both Taiwan and China join in the WTO, a considerable amount of disputes over investment and trade will be hopefully resolved under the institutional framework and the international organization," said Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

Wu's comments were made during a lunch meeting of the eighth conference on Pacific Basin Finance, Economics, and Accounting, which ran concurrently with a meeting of the Association of Deans of Southeast Asian Gradate Schools of Management. Some 200 scholars from around the world, including mainland China, were in attendance.

The new Republic of China government of President Chen Shui-bian has shown a willingness to improve cross-strait relations, Wu said, adding that only reciprocal good will from China will result in any progress.

He noted that the current climate of uneasiness among Taiwan investors in the mainland stems from China's deliberation over re-starting political negotiations with Taiwan, a situation that has left Taiwanese lives and interests insecure.

Therefore, the Taiwanese economist urged Beijing to show a more reasonable attitude, so that the public on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can see that there is no imminent crisis. This will result in increased confidence among Taiwan investors in the mainland, he added.

"If China is serious about its saber-rattling tactics and carries out its threats, it is not unlikely that the Taiwanese investors may diversify their foreign investment activities from China," Wu said.
China has encouraged the Taiwanese investors to invest in China ever since its open-door policy of 1978. But Taiwan's government has been very careful not to get too close to its menacing neighbor.
Trade activities are conducted via a third destination, as no direct links are allowed. Typically, each individual investment project is limited to less than US$50 million.

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and China grew from US$4 billion to US$25.9 billion from 1989 to 1999, while Taiwan's accumulated direct investment in China soared from less than US$1 billion in 1991 to US$14.5 billion in 1999, according to Taiwan's official figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF AGREES TO HEAD CROSS-STRAIT TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh on Friday accepted President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

But the 1986 Nobel prize winner for chemistry turned down Chen's offer to serve as chief senior presidential advisor when Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung brought the letter of appointment to him.
Before the March 18 president election, Lee agreed to head Chen's national policy advisors if Chen won the election.
But he told Chang that Academia Sinica is a subordinate institution under the Presidential Office, and he can present any proposals to the president in his current position.

As a result, he said, there is no need for him to serve as senior advisor to the president, and added that it remains unclear whether it is legal to concurrently serve as Academia Sinica president and senior advisor to the nation's president.
However, Lee accepted the post as head of the cross-strait task force which will work out concrete consensus on the development of cross-strait relations for the president's reference.
He said that the task force will be established in one month, after hearing the views of various people.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CLAIMS PUBLIC WANTED BAN ON TAIWAN POP SINGER 'A-MEI'

TEXT.P: According to Beijing's state-run Xinhua News Agency, mainland Chinese radio and television stations boycotted Taiwan pop singer Chang Huei-mei because the public audience urged them to do so.

In a brief news report on Friday, Xinhua claimed that "some listeners and viewers demanded the stations stop airing shows featuring Chang Huei-mei," who is known affectionately as "A-Mei" by her fans in both Taiwan and mainland China.

Quoting managers at the Central People's Broadcasting Station and the Central Television Station, Xinhua claimed that state-run radio and television stations imposed the "temporary ban" in consideration of strong negative feedback from their "vast listening and viewing audience."

According to the report, the managers also said that their stations will continue to promote cross-strait cultural exchanges. They praised Chang as an influential young singer from Taiwan, adding that this incident will not affect her future participation in cross-strait cultural exchanges, the news agency said.
This was Beijing's first official explanation on the ban imposed on Chang after she sang the Republic of China's national anthem at the May 20 ROC presidential inauguration ceremonies.

A soft drink commercial featuring Chang was banned from mainland Chinese television stations soon after the inauguration, a move that drew widespread local and international criticism. She has also reportedly been banned from entering mainland China for three years, and a ban has also been imposed on sales of her CDs and tapes in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGED TO STICK TO BOTTOM LINE OF INAUGURAL SPEECH

TEXT.P: ROC lawmakers planning to visit mainland China should stick to Taiwan's bottom line on "one China" as revealed in President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural speech.

Kuomintang lawmakers quoted Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen as saying that she hopes the lawmakers will stand firm on Taiwan's stance regarding the "one China" issue while visiting the mainland.

Members of the "E-Generation Alliance," a sub-group of Kuomintang lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan who have been invited by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to visit the mainland next week, made the remarks to reporters following a meeting with Tsai.

According to the "E-Generation" lawmakers, they also exchanged opinions with Tsai on the proposed "direct religious voyage" across the Taiwan Strait to facilitate an annual religious journey by Taiwan Buddhists to Meizhou in mainland China's Fujian province.

According to Legislator Chen Chieh-ju, the MAC head agreed to make efforts on this front, as long as technical issues, such as a registration of participants in the pilgrimage, can be confirmed prior to their departure.
According to Legislator Lin Chin-chia, Tsai also asked them to tell relevant mainland Chinese authorities that she will try to communicate with Vice President Annette Lu on the "one China" issue.

As Lu is not a member of the ROC government body in charge of drawing Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, Tsai was quoted as saying that "I will listen to Tang, not to her," if Lu makes any pro-independence suggestions.

Lin cited Tsai as saying that President Chen, Premier Tang Fei and she have jointly worked out common ground on Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and that they will continue seeking to patch up differences with Lu on the "one China" question.

Lu is viewed by Beijing as a hard-line pro-Taiwan independence activist, while Chen, a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, softened his stance toward mainland China in his May 20 inaugural address by declaring the "five noes," as long as the Beijing regime has no intention of using military force against Taiwan during his four-year tenure.

The "five noes" are: no declaration of Taiwan independence, no change of the national title, no inclusion of the "two-states" theory in the Constitution, no referendum to change the status-quo of the issue of Taiwan independence or unification with the mainland, and no abolition of the National Reunification Council or the National Reunification Guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATORS COMMENT ON PREMIER'S ADMINISTRATIVE REPORT

TEXT.P: Several Kuomintang legislators said on Friday that Premier Tang Fei's first administrative report to the Legislative Yuan "lacks fresh content."

Hung Yu-chin, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Coordination Committee, said that he found nothing special in Tang's report, faulting it for its failure to mention the timetable for implementation of the new pension system.
He said that the new government should not forget the promises President Chen Shui-bian made during the election campaign, and should not cheat the voters.
Another KMT legislator, Chu Feng-chih, said that Tang's report did not touch on the issue of whether the construction of the fourth nuclear power generating unit will be suspended or not.
On the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, she said that she was disappointed over the report, as it failed to present any formula to break the current stalemate.
Because of Tang's health problems, the legislators agreed to put off the interpellation session on the administrative report until July 4.

Meanwhile, before Tang delivered his report, several KMT legislators criticized the new government for failing to consolidate its policies on some important issues, including the legal status of Taiwan.
They criticized Vice President Annette Lu for her recent remarks that Taiwan's legal status remains up in the air.

Some directed their criticism at Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh for his remarks that the new government need not honor all its promises made during the campaign for the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY ONE CANDIDATE RUNNING FOR DEMOCRATIC PROGRESSIVE PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman, as the official registration deadline ended Friday.
Hsieh is almost certain to win by default because DPP by-laws governing elections do not have provisions on the percentage of party member votes needed for a win in such a case.
Of the three people who picked up the forms, Hsieh was the only person to complete the registration process for the June 25 election of the ninth DPP party chairmanship.
The DPP will review the candidate's qualifications on June 7, announce the number of candidates on June 12, organize a policy debate on June 16, and hold the election on June 25.

The direct election of DPP chairman by party members began with the previous term, in which four candidates vied for the position. Because only one candidate is registered to run this time, the DPP's central standing committee will decide whether or not to change the June 16 policy debate to a campaign speech-delivering session.

Hsieh is a graduate of National Taiwan University Law School and earned juris master and juris doctor degrees from Japan's Kyoto University. He is a qualified judge and placed first in the national bar exam. Hsieh is also a founding member of the DPP who served as a Taipei city councilman and a legislator before he took his current post in 1998.

Hsieh's campaign platform includes vows to consolidate intra-party consensus, serve as a stabilizing force for Taiwan, recast the party's place in the political landscape, and minimize differences between public and party opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOURMETS CONSUME 300 MILLION CHICKEN TESTICLES A YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan diners annually consume about 300 million chicken testicles, making the island the world biggest market for the Epicurean delight, said an agricultural official on Friday.

The demand for chicken testicles -- considered a delicacy by many Taiwanese -- is so great that the local poultry industry cannot meet it. Chen Ching-chang, a poultry production official at the Council of Agriculture (COA) estimates that two thirds of last year's consumption was smuggled in.

Taiwanese enthusiasm for chicken testicles is so feverish that it has brought about a thriving new trade -- scouting the poultry markets of mainland China and the United States to find new sources, and smuggled the product into Taiwan en masse.
The scouts have done such a good job that mainland China has almost been completely depleted of chicken testicles, said Chen.
The COA confiscated 21,000 kg of chicken testicles in the first four months of this year, compared with 23,000 kg of livestock offal. Most of the contraband originated in mainland China.

Testicles of almost any animal are prized by Taiwanese as an natural aphrodisiac. Chicken testicles, known as "chifu" in Taiwan, are also popular among Taiwan women, who think that eating the organ can help keep them beautiful. Usually the dish is prepared by boiling.
Of course, some people eat the dish because of its delicious taste. Like peanuts or pretzels, Chifus are often accompanied by pints of beer.

Taiwan farms usually slaughter chickens for their meat when the chickens are at the tender age of six to twelve weeks old, not old enough for their testicles to be fully developed. Only a few free-range chickens, which are brought to the market at a relatively advanced age of 14 to 16 weeks, have full-sized testicles, said Chen.
Most of mainland chickens are raised on open ranches, and have bigger testicles than those of Taiwan chickens.

This makes it easy to differentiate between the underdeveloped testicles from Taiwan chickens and those smuggled in from mainland China, not to mention those brought in from the United States. Some of the American chifus are actually taken from turkeys and are as big and hard as golf balls.
A pair of chicken testicles sells here for about NT$20 (US$0.66), or NT$600 to NT$1,000 (US$20-30) a kilogram, which makes it the most valuable part of a chicken.

In mainland China, the product costs about renminbi 10 yen (about US$1.40) a kilogram. In the United States, chicken testicles are folded into animal feed or simply disposed of as waste, which are far less profitable than selling them to Taiwan's gourmets.
Although the prices of chicken eggs and meat has fluctuated violently in past years, chicken testicles, riding on the back of strong market demand, have always sold at a premium in Taiwan.

Agricultural officials estimate that the chicken testicles smuggled in from mainalnd China and the United States are two to three times greater than Taiwan's domestic production, or 200 million testicles a year.
With local gourmands evincing such strong euphoria for chifus, many local chicken farmers are likely wishing that their chickens would develop more than one pair of testicles per head.

Agricultural officials warned, however, that the coastline area of mainland China has been declared an area plagued by bird flu which is passed over to humans from poultry. Chicken products from mainland China could transmit the epidemic to the island.
They called the public to be vigilant against the smuggled poultry, as it could carry the bird flu virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 3, or the second day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1657: William Harvey, English physician, anatomist and physiologist, dies at the age of 79. He discovered the circulation of blood in the human body in 1628.
1808: Jefferson Davis, the American soldier and president of the Confederate states, is born. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years, and although he was indicted for treason in 1866, he was never prosecuted.
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King," and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium at Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories and novels, including "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus," and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American bride, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The US Navy launches offensive against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships, as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treson. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed the late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for US Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: Earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: Train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being froward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENVOY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US Ambassador to mainland China Joseph Prueher said on Friday he is optimistic about prospects for relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait once both of them enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Prueher, who returned to Washington earlier this week, made the remarks in a question-and-answer session following his speech at a seminar sponsored by the Asia Society.
Prueher said he found that the People's Liberation Army's (PLA's) tough talks on Taiwan-related issues are partly backlash triggered by Beijing's move to cut its influence in the mainland society.

The US navy pilot-turned-diplomat pointed out that the mainland leadership ordered the PLA to stop any profit-making enterprises two years ago and tried to arrange for a civilian official to head mainland China's Central Military Commission. "All these moves have drawn some backlash from the PLA," Prueher noted.

He went on to say that Taiwan is almost the only topic that entire mainland China can reach a unanimous view. Therefore, he said, the PLA has often used this topic to highlight the value of its existence.
Many recent articles carried in the PLA-run newspapers featured hard-line rhetoric on cross-strait problems, Prueher said, adding that these articles reflected the PLA's official stance.
Nevertheless, Prueher said different opinions about Taiwan-related problems still exist within the ranks of the PLA.

Prueher said he got an impression through talks with mainland Chinese military leaders that they all attach great importance to national security and want to beef up mainland China's military might. "But I didn't feel that its top military brass hold an especially harsh attitude toward Taiwan," he added.

In his speech, Prueher said he believes that dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China can resume if the US Senate can smoothly pass the bill granting permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) to mainland China and global economic integration proceeds satisfactorily following mainland China's WTO accession.

As for Washington-Beijing relations, Prueher said mainland China has agreed to resume talks with the United States on prevention of arms proliferation and that the two sides may also open human rights dialogue for resolving some practical issues.

In conclusion, Prueher said he is optimistic about the prospects for future US-mainland China relations and Taipei-Beijing engagement. He added that mainland China must prepare for WTO entry and should also seek innovative, flexible and constructive measures to resolve cross-strait problems.
