DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 52.19 points to close at 8,935.64.
Encouraged by a strong hike in US stock prices, the bourse opened at 9,017.03 and fluctuated between 9,059.88 and 8,911.89 during trading.

A total of 1.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.24 billion (US$3.74 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.99 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$122.45 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers 274 to 228, with 111 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only bank and insurance shares remained unchanged.

All the other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 2.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1 percent, construction stocks at 0.8 percent, electrical shares at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent, and textile issues at 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS SATISFIED WITH PRESIDENT'S HANDLING OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The majority of local university students are satisfied with new ROC President Chen Shui-bian's handling of issues related to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Saturday.

The survey was conducted by the Chinese Culture Association from May 23 through June 1 on randomly chose students at 10 universities in northern Taiwan, four each in central and southern Taiwan, and two in eastern Taiwan. The association sent out 1,200 copies of questionnaires and collected 862 valid replies.

Survey results show that most university students want the two sides of the Taiwan Strait increase exchanges and consultation to boost mutual understanding. The majority of the respondents also want to maintain peace and the status quo while would neither like to see de jure Taiwan independence nor an eruption of cross-strait military conflict.

The poll found that 79.3 percent of those interviewed said they are satisfied with President Chen's handling of cross-strait problems and only 11.8 percent gave a thumbs-down to Chen's performance in this regard.
According to the survey, 51.1 percent said they think Chen's inaugural speech will help improve cross-strait relations while 36.4 percent said they think otherwise.

Meanwhile, 75.4 percent said they are confident in Chen's handling of cross-strait relations in the future, but 18.6 percent said they have no confidence in Chen's ability in dealing with such sensitive issues.

Another noteworthy finding was that 72.9 percent of the respondents said they think they are both Taiwanese and Chinese, three times the number of those who identify themselves as Taiwanese but not Chinese.
While 57.4 percent of those interviewed said they think that mainland China does not understand Taiwan's current situation, 38.9 percent said they don't think so.

As much as 62.8 percent said they don't think that a cross-strait war would break out during President Chen's tenure, and only 25.5 percent said they are worried about the possibility of the eruption of a cross-strait military confrontation over the next four years.

If a cross-strait war were to erupt, 71.1 percent said they think that the United States might send troops to assist Taiwan, but 23.5 percent said they don't think so. The finding indicates that local youths hold a strong reliance on the US military assistance.

Asked how the cross-strait issues should be resolved, 45.5 percent said the two sides should settle disputes through negotiations and consultations; 40.1 percent said they think that time will naturally resolve the problems; 7.2 percent said they hope to see the holding of a plebiscite to decide Taiwan's future; and only 3.5 percent said they are hopeful that the United States will mediate a solution to the thorn issue.

The survey also found that 40.5 percent of those interviewed said they think the status quo will continue to maintain in the long run; 20.5 percent said they believe that the two sides will eventually form either a confederation or a federation; 19 percent said they guess that the two sides will unify under a "one country, two systems" formula; only 5.7 percent said they think the two sides will unify through the use of military means; while 14.3 percent said they still don't know how the current cross-strait deadlock will be resolved.

An in-depth analysis of the survey results further found that most of the supporters of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said they don't think a cross-strait war will erupt during Chen's presidency. Chen is a DPP stalwart, but he has soft-pedaled his pro-independence stand since he won the March 18 presidential election.

Poll results also show that the number of northern and central Taiwan university students who support peaceful unification was 1.7 fold the number of those who prefer to see Taiwan move toward independence.
In contrast, southern Taiwan university students who support Taiwan independence outnumbered those who back peaceful unification by 3 percent, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market showed positive results on Saturday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved up 113 points to close at 9,033, with 3,366 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July increased 76 points to finish at 9,036, with 69 contract transactions, and September futures gained 50 points to close at 9,150, with seven contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were: 8,920 for June; 8,960 for July; 9,100 for September; 9,290 for December; and 9,150 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported positive results.

June TE futures moved up 6 points to close at 493, with 1,018 contract transactions, while July futures increased 6.4 points to finish at 493, with eight contract transactions. TE futures for next March gained 1.5 points to close at 520, with 11 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December TE futures.

June TF futures increased 7 points to close at 945, with 383 contract transactions, while July TF futures gained 3 points to close at 048, with 40 contract transactions. September TF futures moved down 0.6 points to finish at 948.8, with 24 contract transactions, and December TF futures decreased 10.6 points to close at 959, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTIAN VISION TO BROADCAST IN SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to risk tension in its relations with Asian countries following its leasing of a powerful short-wave radio transmitter in Darwin to the British charity broadcaster Christian Vision.

The Australian newspaper said on Saturday that Christian Vision will use the facility to broadcast in English across Southeast Asia, including Indonesia, where the population is more than 90 percent Muslim, and mainland China, where freedom of religious belief is restricted.

Australia's ties with Indonesia have been strained due to its leading role in the UN peacekeeping force in East Timor between October 1999 and February 2000, which led to the end of Jakarta's 24-year rule on the former Portuguese colony, the daily reported.
Beijing has previously lobbied the Australian government against allowing Christian broadcasts to mainland China from Darwin, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATE URGED TO CONSIDER PROPOSALS ON BEIJING PNTR

TEXT.P: The United States Senate has been urged to consider legislative proposals that would address such concerns as mainland China's proliferation activities as it considers the bill that would grant the mainland permanent normal trade relations.

Larry M. Wortzel, director of the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation said on Friday that while the House Resolution 4444 passed last week is the first step toward granting PNTR to mainland China, "it will not resolve either the specific and important differences that remain between the United States and China on democratic values and individual liberties, or serious concerns over China's proliferation activities."

Indeed, he pointed out, granting PNTR will help make American businesses more competitive in mainland China and increase trade, help the mainland Chinese develop a system based on free enterprise, and promote the development of a middle class in mainland China.

"But these benefits of trade and the fact that Resolution 4444 deals with other issues must not overshadow the serious concerns that continue to be expressed throughout America on China's proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and other activities that undermine regional stability and threaten US national security," said the specialist.

Wortzel added that the debate over PNTR highlighted the fact that in the view of many Americans, not enough attention has been given to Beijing's activities in other areas, such as religious freedoms, democratic reforms, human rights, labor standards, and proliferation activities.

Until recently, he said, little parallel legislation had been introduced in Congress to address mainland China's proliferation or Beijing's habit of misusing controlled goods, services and "dual-use" technology. Yet the evidence is growing that Beijing is using civilian technology for military purposes or for purposes other than that for which it had been purchased, he said.

As Sen. Fred Thompson (R-Tenn.) noted when introducing as parallel legislation the China Proliferation Act together with Sen. Robert Torricelli (D-N.J.) on May 25, "if China is going to be one of our trading partners, it's not too much to require them to stop providing weapons of mass destruction to countries who might someday use them against us."

Under the bill, any persons, groups or companies within mainland China, including US persons doing business in mainland China, would face immediate penalties if they violated international nonproliferation treaties or agreements or US export control laws in any way that contributes to proliferation.

"While there is no perfect means either to detect cheating or to deter noncompliance with agreements (by mainland China), the Thompson-Torricelli bill would give the president the lever to press when the United States does detect China's noncompliance or the diversion of technology to inappropriate agents or uses," emphasized Wortzel.

In the past, he said, mainland China's leaders have managed to dodge measures that were designed to address noncompliance. "This bill is an attempt to resolve that problem. More important, its non-trade punitive measures are consistent with the terms of the WTO agreement that the Clinton administration recently signed with China."

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADCAST, COMMUNICATIONS EXPO TO OPEN IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Singapore will host the Broadcast Asia 2000 from June 6-9, with more than 800 companies taking part from over 40 countries.

With visitors expected from over 70 countries, Broadcast Asia 2000 will be Singapore's largest-ever indoor trade show and reinforces Singapore's position as "the regional broadcast and communications hub of Asia", according to a press release.
The show will include conferences, seminars and tutorials on items such as multimedia, computer animation and computer graphics, digital TV (DTV) applications and mobile TV.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN FOR DIRECT FUJIAN-TAIWAN LINK FOR PILGRIMS TO BE WORKED OUT

TEXT.P: The head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) promised on Friday to come up with a detailed plan within a month for direct maritime links between Taiwan and mainland China's Fujian Province for local pilgrims.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen told a group of Kuomintang legislators from the "E-Generation Alliance" in the Legislative Yuan that the council will consider an application from Taiwan pilgrims for direct maritime links between the ports of Taichung, central Taiwan, and Meizhou in Fujian Province, on a case-by-case basis.

In light of the bad weather which usually sweeps into the Taiwan Strait after September, Tsai agreed to the legislators' demand to put forward detailed plans for regulating such voyages within a month to allow for a pilgrimage before the weather deteriorates.
Tsai said the regulations will be designed to ensure that such direct crossings are for purely religious purposes and do not compromise Taiwan's security in any way.
Taiwan forbids direct transportation links with mainland China and travelers between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait currently have to travel via a third country or area.

This restriction has been challenged in recent years by local followers of Matsu, a Chinese folk goddess enshrined by many temples as a guardian of fishermen. Matsu followers, especial those affiliated to Taichung's Chenlan Temple make an annual pilgrimage to the traditional home of the goddess in Meizhou, and have long demanded the right to travel directly across the strait to observe the religious ritual.

Their demands won favorable responses from candidates of various political parties during the presidential election campaign earlier this year, prompted the government to review its long-standing policy of prohibiting direct trade, postal and transportation links with mainland China.
In Friday's meeting, Tsai also agreed to put forward in six months a draft plan to exempt the Taiwan-controlled frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu from the ban on direct links.

A statue allowing Kinmen and Matsu to open direct trade and shipping links with mainland China is already in place -- an attempt to boost the sagging economy on the islands -- but detailed arrangements to prevent the two islands from becoming a gateway for Taiwan goods and passengers to and from mainland China is taking time to hammer out.

Tsai assured the legislators of the government's commitment to direct links between the two frontline islands and the mainland, but she cautioned that they cannot be opened without Beijing's cooperation.

She also asked the E-Generation Alliance members, who are slated to visit mainland China on Wednesday, to rally behind the government's mainland policy outlined by President Chen Shui-bian in his inaugural speech that Taiwan is willing to work with mainland China to sort out the issue of "one China."
Instead of being bound by ideology, Tsai said, Chen's policy is squarely based on pragmatism, which is also the principle that will dictate the new administration's future policy toward the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN CRITIC PRAISES ROC FILM DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: Hou Hsiao-hsien is as essential to understanding the world of film as Bergman once was, as Abbas Kiarostami is, and as Spike Jonze might be some day, a Canadian critic said on Friday.

Mark Peranson, Toronto-based editor and publisher of Cinema Scope magazine, said the ROC movie director "is more important, though less well-known, than such mainland Chinese directors as Zhang Yimou and Chen Kaige."
Writing in the Globe and Mail newspaper, the critic noted that 52-year-old Hou is not known to Canadian moviegoers because not one of his films has been released theatrically in North America.

From Friday, however, a retrospective of his work will be touring Canada, beginning in Toronto and Ottawa, and reaching Vancouver on June 15. The film festival is sponsored by the Canadian Film Institute and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTION PLAN TO ROOT OUT `BLACK GOLD' TO BE UNVEILED

TEXT.P: An action plan to eradicate "black gold" politics -- government links with organized crime -- will be sent to the Executive Yuan on Wednesday, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said on Saturday.
Chen made the remarks when he presided over a meeting of related government agencies on the eradication of black gold politics.

According to the plan, the Ministry of Justice will push for sunshine bills -- laws governing political donations, lobbying activities and the avoidance of conflicts of interests among civil servants -- so as to root out the practice of kickbacks and sever government links with conglomerates.

The Justice Ministry will also take reference from Hong Kong to revise anti-graft regulations, which will require civil servants to register their assets and subject them to punishment if they are unable to give a plausible explanation of how they acquired suspicious assets.
The Justice Ministry will also take reference from the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development and punish local manufacturers who bribe foreign civil servants.
The ministry will also learn from Hong Kong's success in setting up an anti-corruption administration to coordinate the fight against graft and corruption.

The participants in Saturday's meeting, which included representatives of the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of the Transportation and Communications, reached consensus on the crackdown on organized crime, consistent efforts to eradicate graft, and the establishment of anti-corruption administration.
However, they remained divided on the issues of the national registration of assets and the prevention of money-laundering.

Yen Ta-ho, director of the Department of Prosecutorial Affairs, said that participants have said that they hope to speed up the work on the avoidance of conflicts of interests and the compulsory entrustment of bonds and securities belonging to civil servants.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOVIE STAR SAYS GOODBYE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Hollywood movie star Tom Cruise left Taiwan for South Korea on Saturday after a 24-hour visit to promote his new action film -- Mission Impossible 2.
Cruise, who enjoys wide popularity in Taiwan, said at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport before his departure that he hopes to be able to visit the island again next year.
Cruise and John Woo, director of "Mission Impossible 2," flew into Taipei from Hong Kong aboard Cruise's private plane on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING ROC REPRESENTATIVE BIDS FAREWELL TO US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China nationals residing in Washington hosted a dinner party on Friday for outgoing ROC representative to the US Stephen Chen, attended by more than 500 people.
American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush and his predecessor Natale Bellocchi were also present on the occasion.

Bush said he was impressed by Chen's sacrifices and diligence and hailed his contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties while serving as the de-facto ROC ambassador to the United States in the absence of formal relations between the two countries.

Chen, who quit the post after Chen Shui-bian was elected president of the ROC on March 18, began hosting a string of parties on June 1 to bid farewell to his friends from all walks of life in the United States.
Meanwhile, it was reported that US opinion leaders at both the Senate and the House of Representatives will sponsor a farewell party for Chen on June 8 on Capitol Hill.
Former ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen will take over the post from Chen in late June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi left for Darwin, Australia, on Saturday to attend trade talks with senior officials from Asia-Pacific countries.
The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum ministerial-level meeting will take place from June 6-7.
Lin, who was accompanied by Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long, said that he hopes to solicit the support of the APEC members for the early entry of Taiwan into the World Trade Organization.

He will also hold bilateral talks with 11 APEC member states -- the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Burma -- on the meeting's theme of creating prosperity for the region through the APEC mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO VINDICATE 1989 PRO-DEMOCRACY MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Eight mainland Chinese dissidents in northeastern Jilin province jointly sent an open letter to Beijing leaders Jiang Zemin and Zhu Rongji Saturday, urging them to vindicate the 1989 pro-democracy protests in Beijing as soon as possible.

The eight dissidents, all of whom were imprisoned once for their part in the protests, said in the letter that the student-led demonstrations on Tiananmen Square in Beijing was a popular pro-democracy movement against government corruption, and that the government was totally wrong to label it as a "counter-revolutionary rebellion" and send troops to suppress it.

In the letter released through the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, the dissidents said that the government should make compensations to the families of those killed in the incident and those imprisoned in the subsequent crackdown on the movement. The government should also release all political prisoners, and begin to introduce political reforms and democratic systems, they added.
The letter to the Beijing leaders was made public on the eve of the 11th anniversary of the Tiananmen massacre on June 4, 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: US `SHUTTLING BETWEEN TWO SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT' MORE ACTIVELY: MAC

TEXT.P: An official in charge of the Republic of China's mainland China policy said on Saturday that the United States has been shuttling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait more actively than it did four years ago.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks when he spoke at a seminar titled: "Mainland China and the Asia-Pacific region: Interchanges and Trends" at National Sun Yat-Sen University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
The United States has been shuttling back and forth across the Taiwan Strait more actively that it did four years ago, Lin said. He did not elaborate on his statement.

He said that although the MAC has continued to send conciliatory gestures of goodwill to the mainland since before Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration as president, Beijing has yet to respond positively.

However, he added that the mainland leadership seems to be adopting a less-tough stance toward Taiwan, and noted that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in recent hotline talks with US President Bill Clinton said that he has "no intention" of invading Taiwan.
Lin expressed the hope that Jiang's words were spoken in good faith.

He noted that political, economic and social changes in the mainland have been faster than most people would have imagined. The rapid growth in the number of mainland Internet users has also increased the speed of the transformation process and has pushed the mainland toward a more pluralistic society, pitting the authoritarian communist regime against a never-before-encountered challenge, he said.

Lin said that although the mainland has censored news reports about President Chen, the growing popularity of the Internet has generated heated online debate about Taiwan in the mainland, with some chat-room users asking why the mainland cannot follow Taiwan's lead by holding democratic elections.

He said that as a spate of problems has emerged in the mainland, such as continued economic decline, growing social unrest, and growing disagreement with the Beijing leadership, Beijing can be expected to tighten its control of the people, step up its crackdown on religious freedom, media and the democratic movement, and toughen its stance toward Taiwan in the short term.
But in the long term, he went on, these moves will only facilitate the transformation of the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMES `SECOND-HIGHEST AMOUNT' OF NATURAL RESOURCES: EPA

TEXT.P: The new head of Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Saturday urged his fellow countrymen to practice thrift to preserve the island's environment.

Citing a 1998 Living Planet Report by the global conservation organization Worldwide Fund for Nature (WWF), Lin said the people of Taiwan consumed 3.4 times more natural resources than the world average, second only behind Norway among 151 countries surveyed.

Although the people in industrialized countries used 5.5 times more natural resources in general than those in the developing countries, Taiwan's per capita consumption was well ahead of the United States, who came in sixth, with 2.74 times the worldwide average. Japan was twelfth with 2.35 times the world's average per capita consumption, and Germany was 34th. Mainland China was 60th, and India ranked 87th, according to the report.

The WWF Living Planet Report, which ranked the pressure the 151 countries created on their environments through consumption of grain, fish, wood, water, cement and the emission of carbon dioxide, was the first ever of its kind, said Lin.
Compared with the world per capita average, Taiwan consumed 7.8 times more fish and 5.21 times more cement in 1998, and 3.16 times more fish and 4.37 times more cement in 1999.

Warning that Taiwan's excessive consumption has stretched its natural resources to the limit, Lin said an economy which pursues development without caring for the environment will undermine its economic development because of the deterioration of its environment.
Touting thrift as the key to conservation, Lin called on his countrymen to pursue sustained economic development by taking into account the need for environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RESOLUTION REQUIRES TIME AND WISDOM

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Saturday that a cross-Taiwan Strait resolution will require time, patience and wisdom.
He made the remarks while speaking at a ceremony to mark the establishment of a private educational foundation.
Chen encouraged young people not to afraid of failure, frustration or criticism by other people, stating that as long as one has confidence in himself, his future will be limitless.

He added that overcoming difficulties requires endeavor, perseverance and endurance, and pointed out that a cross-strait resolution also requires time, patience and endurance, together with wisdom and creativity.

Several ranking government officials were also present at the ceremony, including Senior Presidential Advisor Yao Chia-wen, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya and National Youth Commission Chairman Lin Fang-mei.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS OPPOSED TO `NATIONAL SECURITY TAX' PLAN

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers on Saturday warned the government not to rashly levy a proposed "national security tax" on Taiwan businessmen with operations in mainland China amid current tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Kuomintang legislative whip Lin Chien-jung said he was strongly opposed to such a proposal, and he reminded the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led administration of adverse political implications which may arise from the move at a time when relations between Taiwan and mainland China are facing a crucial change.

Although he agreed that the implementation of such a tax might have its benefits, Lin said the government must not make a reckless decision on the issue but should first discuss the issue with the legislature and obtain its approval before implementing any new measures.

Amid the present strained relations between Taiwan and the mainland, the KMT lawmaker said levying such a tax would be very likely to stir up unnecessary political pressure on Taiwan businessmen in the mainland, and would further cast a shadow of uncertainty over the future of bilateral ties.

"Such a situation will not be good for Taiwan, which is keen to pursue stable progress," he stressed. He urged the government to carefully and thoroughly study the issue, because "many Taiwan businessmen are being squeezed by the governments on both sides of the strait."

Lin made the remarks after government spokeswoman Chung Chin said earlier the same day that the government will not rule out the possibility of drawing up a formal government policy based on a proposal by S.M. Chen, designated vice governor for the Central Bank of China, as part of its efforts to regulate Taiwan-mainland economic activities.
Lawmaker Chiu Chuang-liang, the People First Party (PFP) whip, called on government officials to assess the issue within relevant government systems.

Pointing out that the proposed plan is in effect a move aimed at increasing taxes, Chiu contended that the issue must be dealt with from a viewpoint of national finance, national security and the cross-strait relationship.

According to Chiu, such an important national policy should be first fully discussed by government policy-making authorities, and public comments made rashly by government officials not directly involved in the issue will only damage the mechanism of government.

The PFP legislator also reminded the administration that the implementation of such a highly sensitive policy would very probably further undermine mutual trust and put Taiwan businessmen with mainland operations in an even more difficult situation.

Criticizing Chung and Chen for setting a bad example in publicly commenting on a government policy not under their jurisdiction, Chiu said relevant government agencies -- the Mainland Affairs Council, the Finance Ministry and the National Security Bureau -- should take charge of charting formal policy in this regard.

Echoing Chiu's view, PFP spokesman Liu Wen-hsiung said ranking government appointees should not comment on government policy beyond their administrative domains. He urged President Chen Shui-bian to correct Chung and Chen for their inappropriate words.

Arguing that the idea of levying a national security tax on mainland-based Taiwan investors will not be seen as a friendly move toward Beijing at a time when Taiwan is seeking to demonstrate its goodwill to mainland China, Liu claimed that such a chaotic approach by the new government will in turn negatively affect positive exchanges between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Security tax, proposed last month by new Central Bank of China Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng, is again under fire. The Executive Yuan clarifies that the security tax proposal had not been discussed by the Cebinet.
The China Times:
President Chen Shui-bian again confirms government policy of appointing local government officials rather than allowing the posts be elected.
The United Daily News:
Reviewing the "no haste, be patient" policy, the government now deregulates "restrictive" mainland-bound investment categories into categories "to be examined case by case"; Ceiling of such investment is also further raised to NT$80 million each project.
The Liberty Times:
The scale of putting government functionaries' personal wealth and assets under compulsory trust will be further expanded.
The China Post:
Tiananmen anniversary sparks appeals -- Mainland dissidents call for redress amid tightened security.
The Taiwan News:
Missile shield big odds; US defense option significant to Taiwan draws lots of doubts.
The Taipei Times:
Security tax idea again under fire; GIO head said Saturday that the government was taking seriously the idea of a special tax on cross-strait enterprises and trade. Nonsense, said almost everybody else.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 4, or the third day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1831: Prince Leopold, of the House of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, becomes the first king of Belgium, although King William II of the Netherlands refuses to acknowledge Belgian independence.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with US General Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1973: A Tupolev 144, the Russian supersonic airliner built on the lines of the Concorde, crashes at the Paris Air Show, killing six crew and 27 onlookers.
1982: US Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Cheyne J.Y. Chiu as the new ambassador to Swaziland.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes a revision of the Law of Negotiable Instruments. The revision is submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval.
1989: A massive gas explosion wrecks two crowded passenger trains about 1,190 km east of Moscow, killing over 460 people.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1991: The communist government in Albania under Fatos Nano resigns after a 20-day general strike.
1994: Five Iraqis and a Kuwaiti are sentenced to death in Kuwait for plotting to kill former US President George Bush with a car bomb while Bush was visiting Kuwait in April 1993.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST PRESIDENTIAL PRESS CONFERENCE SLATED FOR JUNE 20

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to meet with members of the domestic and foreign press on June 20, marking the president's first formal press conference since his May 20 inauguration, the Presidential Office reported on Sunday.

Delivering on a promise to the media, Chen will meet with reporters from home and abroad exactly one month after his inauguration to introduce his basic policies and ideals, Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said.

Issues to be discussed by Chen during the press conference will include cross-strait relations, the much-discussed "three direct links" with the mainland, national security, diplomacy, welfare policy and government financial resources, and policies on other domestic affairs, Chang added.

Chang said the president will answer all questions raised by members of the domestic and foreign press on June 20 -- an indirectly explanation of why Chen has recently declined to answer some questions of several foreign media organizations.

To prepare for the president's press conference, Chang added, he will meet with relevant officials from the Ministries of the Interior, National Defense, Economic Affairs, and Foreign Affairs, as well as the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Government Information Office, on Monday for the first meeting in advance of the important event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG TEMPLE TO INTITIATE 'DIRECT RELIGIOUS VOYAGE' ON JULY 16
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung County, central Taiwan, June 4 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chenlan Temple in Tahchia, Taichung County, announced on Sunday that it will lead a large pilgrimage to mainland China's Fujian province on July 16, initiating the first direct religious voyage across the Taiwan Strait in five decades.

Chenlan Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao said that he had performed a divination rite at the temple Sunday morning, in which Matsu, goddess of the sea, told him that the pilgrims should set sail on July 16.

He said that Matsu had informed him that the 7,000-member pilgrimage should leave Taichung Harbor on July 16, sailing aboard a fleet of fishing and tourism boats across the Taiwan Strait to Meizhou, an island which is part of Fujian province, after making a stopover on Kinmen, the ROC-controlled frontline island near mainland China.

Noting that making the pilgrimage to Meizhou to pay tribute to Matsu in person is a dream of millions of Taoist believers at Chenlan Temple, Yen said all the worshippers welcomed and appreciated Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's recent remarks that direct religious links with the mainland will be given top priority in the new government's mainland China policy.
Meizhou is located about 72 nautical miles across the Taiwan Strait from Taichung, and is Matsu's legendary birthplace.

Yen said he hopes the Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will approve the temple's application, filed on May 23, as soon as possible so that its planned direct voyage from Taichung to Meizhou can be made on schedule.

Yen assured the government that Chenlan Temple has ample experience in handling religious pilgrimages and gatherings of several hundreds of thousands of worshippers over the past nearly 100 years, and is confident in its ability to conduct the first-ever cross-strait religious voyage.
Yen also serves as speaker of Taichung County Council, and has campaigned for direct shipping links between Taichung and Fujian province for the past two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PRINTED CIRCUIT BOARD MANUFACTURERS TO ATTEND JAPAN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's printed circuit board manufacturers will attend an industry summit in Tokyo, Japan, on June 8 to discover new opportunities for cooperation in the future.

The Sino-Japanese summit is to be co-sponsored by Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taiwan Printed Circuit Board Association. Over 200 companies from both countries have registered to attend, including Taiwan's Compeq Manufacturing, Gold Circuit Electronics, and Chin Poon Industrial as well as Japan's Hitachi, Sharp, and CMK, among others.

According to CETRA, Japan's gradual outsourcing of printed circuit boards in recent years and mainland China's vast cellular phone market are both factors favorable for Taiwan manufacturers to seek out cooperative alliances with Japanese companies.

Taiwan is the world's third largest supplier of printed circuit boards, after the United States and Japan. Production value in Taiwan reached US$3.6 billion last year, or about 10 percent of the world's total supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STEP UP EFFORTS TO TAKE CARE OF VETERANS

TEXT.P: The government will step up its efforts to take care of retired servicemen, Yang Teh-chih, chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen, said over the weekend.

Yang said that taking care of veterans has been an important work of the commission, and it will step up its efforts in that regard, as the nation's veterans have contributed a great deal to the country.
Yang said that the average age of military veterans is 63.8 years old. There are a total of 364,688 vets who are over 65 years of age, accounting for 19.5 percent of the nation's elderly.

He also said the commission is now taking measures to grant veteran status to conscripts who took part in the "August 23 Battle," a major cross-strait battle during which mainland China fired hundreds of thousands shells on Kinmen in 1958. The commission also plans to grant the same status to members of Kinmen's self-defense force, local residents who fought in the same battle.
He said that the number of retired servicemen grows by about 6,000 every year, and the total number of 567,864 is not expected to vary greatly from one year to next.

Yang also said that there are currently 14 veterans' homes, accommodating 13,650 men. Though these facilities offer beautiful scenery, they are mostly dilapidated, he said, adding that the veterans are forced to live in cramped quarters, with each only enjoying 13.38 square meters of space, not up to the standards of homes for the elderly.
The commission is now trying to improve the facilities of the veterans' homes under a four-year plan, and give them more space to improve their living environment.

Looking ahead, he said that the commission will efficiently use its communications network to visit the veterans to learn about their living conditions. He added that it will prioritize the care of poor, sick, and disabled veterans, as well as those without families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN/MONGOLIAN AFFAIRS SUGGESTED AS BASIS FOR RESUMED DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the Cabinet-level Mongolian & Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) suggested on Sunday that negotiators from across the Taiwan Strait resume their long-stalled dialogue by first talking about Tibetan and Mongolian affairs.

MTAC Secretary-General Liu Hsueh-chao said that Tibetan and Mongolian affairs can be a good basis for reopening the cross-strait dialogue. Talks between the two sides have been suspended since June 1995 after Republic of China (ROC) President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States, which Beijing viewed as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, who is chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), met with his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, in Singapore in late April of 1993, a landmark meeting that broke the ice between top negotiators after an impasse of more than four decades.

The Koo-Wang meeting has since been considered the first official cross-strait dialogue in the history of the thorny relations between the two sides. The official dialogue, however, was unilaterally and indefinitely suspended by Beijing in 1995.

Although Koo visited Shanghai and Beijing in October 1998 and met with Wang during the trip, the rendezvous was informal and was not considered by either side as a second Koo-Wang meeting or a resumption of the official cross-strait dialogue.
Liu said officials from either side can meet to discuss issues concerning Mongolia, Inner Mongolia, Tibet and Xinjiang.
Taipei can also take the initiative of sponsoring cross-strait seminars on Mongolian, Tibetan and Xinjiang affairs so as to reach consensus between the two sides on certain issues.

Meanwhile, Liu said that the government should retain the organization and function of the MTAC so as to dispel Beijing's fear and suspicion that Taiwan is seeking independence, since according to the ROC Constitution, Mongolia and Tibet are ROC territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT PREACHES GOSPEL
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Northern Taiwan, June 4 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui preached the Gospel at a Presbyterian church in Tahsi Township, Taoyuan County, on Sunday.
He pointed out the need to discard one's ego so as to see facts clearly.
Lee said that people nowadays are like the blind who cannot see actual situations. In order to see all the questions clearly, he noted, there is a need to abandon ego and to open one's mind.
This was the second time for Lee to preach the Gospel since he left the Presidential Office on May 20.

Security was tight at the church, and church goers were barred from shaking hands with Lee. The unusual security measures were taken due to the retired military officer who recently threw red ink on Lee in a protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVILIAN ALLIANCE DRAFTS NATIONAL HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION LAW

TEXT.P: A civilian alliance to promote the establishment of a National Human Rights Commission unveiled on Sunday their draft version of the commission's organic law.

The National Human Rights Commission Promotion Alliance consists of 22 human rights, judicial reform, social movement, and attorneys' organizations that aim to help President Chen Shui-bian make good on his inauguration promise of establishing such a commission.
The alliance's draft law included 21 articles that describe the commission's place in the government, its responsibilities, powers, and membership.

The draft advocated a commission that answers directly to the presidential office, similar to Academia Sinica, the premier research institution in the country. The draft also stated that the commission should be supra-partisan with the authority to plan its own budget so as to guarantee its independence.

The commission's suggested responsibilities and powers include the investigation of major cases of human rights violations and systematic research aimed at coming up with proposals for amendments to the constitution and laws to bring the nation in line with international human rights standards.

Other suggested commission activities include the promotion of human rights education, regular compilation of national human rights reports, and the pursuit of cooperative exchanges with domestic and foreign organizations.
The draft proposed that the executive, judicial, and legislative branches all share the rights to select commission members, who should be experts and scholars from the public sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA APPROVES USE OF ANTI-BLINDNESS DRUG

TEXT.P: Canada has approved a new drug to treat an eye disease blamed for most blindness in people over age 50. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a common eye disease associated with aging. It gradually destroys sharp, central vision.
The medication, called Visudyne, was co-developed by CIBA Vision and Vancouver-based QLT Inc. Visudyne is injected into a patient's arm, then activated by shining a laser into the eye.
Researchers say it could be used by people suffering from AMD, including as many as 20,000 new cases of "wet AMD" -- the less-common form of the disease.
Patients with the disease lose their ability to read and recognize faces in as little as two months.

Approval of the drug comes after two studies on 609 patients in eight countries, including Canada. Researchers say 67 percent of AMD patients treated with Visudyne lost less than three lines of vision on a standard eye chart over two years, compared with 39 percent of the control group.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETURN OF TAIWAN STOCK INVESTMENT AVERAGES 5.81 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Returns on stock investment in Taiwan averaged 5.81 percent between the end of December 1999 and the end of May 2000, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

Sun Yad Plastic Fibers Corp. topped the list with a 192.8 percent rate of return. It was followed by Kye Systems Corp. with 164.98 percent, Chang Yih Co. with 154.55 percent, Elite Material Co., with 130.6 percent, and China Steel Chemical Corp. with 126.09 percent.

Everlight Co. was next with a rate of return of 123.27 percent. Next in line were Microelectronic Technology Corp. with 116.79 percent, Asia Chemical Co. with 116.57 percent, UB Office Systems with 111.89 percent, and Lite-On Technology Corp. with 111.31 percent.

Taiwan Development & Trust Corp. topped the downside list, with a return rate of negative 63.1 percent. It was followed by Yu Foung Textile with negative 38.29 percent, Chung Shing Bank with negative 36.89 percent, and Nan Yang Dyeing & Finishing Co. with negative 35.45 percent.

Far East Textile Corp. was also a loser with negative 33.33 percent. It was followed by Acer with negative 32.28 percent, Tatung Co. with negative 32.08 percent, Jui Li Enterprises with negative 30.83 percent, Lin San Hao International Development with negative 29.62 percent, and Lian Hwa Foods with negative 29.25 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARNIVAL FOR FOREIGN WORKERS HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first carnival for foreign workers was held in downtown Taipei on Sunday.
The festival, called "Hello Taipei! Taipei Residents & Migrant workers," was held on the plaza in front of Taipei Railway Station, one of the favorite hangouts of foreign laborers in Taipei.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou greeted the foreigners in English, Thai, and Indonesian under the scorching sun. He stressed that wherever they come from, they are most welcome to join the big family of Taipei.

Ma used the opportunity to promote the new waste bags that will be used exclusively for collecting garbage starting in July. He asked the foreign laborers three questions about the waste bags. A Filipino maid gave the right answers and won a TV.
Taipei City Government distributed a total of 40 prizes and distributed leaflets to promote the use of the garbage bags.

Singers and dancers from Taiwan and other countries gave performances to the great delight of the foreigners in attendance. Aboriginal singer Chi Hsiao-chun and the A-m band entertained the crowd with aboriginal songs. Ma's version of "Yellow Bird" was followed by enthusiastic applause.
Filipino workers were astonished to see popular Philippine band Asia at Pendong which performed their favorite song "Salt."

Thai performers gave a transvestite show, and Indonesian dancers performed a Balinese dance. Visitors also had the chance to see a Thai boxing match and sample exotic foods from Southeast Asia. Visitors said that it was a very gratifying Sunday afternoon.

The Bureau of Labor Affairs distributed condoms as part of its safe sex campaign. Religious groups as well as the three Taipei representative offices from the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand also set up pavilions to provide assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC APPROVED 932 FOREX BANKS AROUND TAIWAN AS OF THE END OF MAY

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) had approved the applications of 932 banks around Taiwan to operate foreign exchange businesses as of the end of May, the CBC said on Sunday.
864 of the approved banks are local institutions, and the remaining 68 are foreign banks.

In May, the CBC approved four banks to operate foreign exchange businesses. The successful institutions were the Chuke branch of the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan, the Sulin branch of Hua Nan Commercial Bank, and the Yenping and Taoyuan branches of Baodao Commerce Bank.
The CBC also approved 25 local banks to buy and sell foreign currency, without granting them the right to operate as foreign exchange banks.

The CBC also approved several appointed foreign exchange banks to expand their local business operations. Taipei Branch of Banque Nationale de Paris and Taishin International Bank were both granted permission to trade in New Taiwan dollar parity options.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOODWILL FLOTILLA REACHES MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy's goodwill flotilla has reached the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles, according to information released by the Defense Ministry on Sunday.
The flotilla consists of three frigates -- the French-built Lafayette-class Hsi-ning and Kang-ting frigates as well as the Chungho-class landing vessel.
This is the first time that the Lafayette-class missile frigates have joined the ROC goodwill flotilla.
The mission of the flotilla is to conduct training and promote goodwill with allied and friendly countries.
It left the naval port of Tsoying in southern Taiwan in the second half of May. After visiting the Marshall Islands, it will proceed to the Solomon Islands, Singapore and Bali.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT GIVES LECTURE IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 4 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh delivered a speech on "Science-Technology and Social Development" in Tokyo on Sunday, attracting over 800 local Chinese participants.
Lee arrived in Tokyo on Saturday for a weeklong visit at the invitation of a Japanese research institute.
The Japan Chapter of the Taipei-based Chinese Engineers Society and three other Chinese organizations in Japan took advantage of Lee's tour to arrange for the speech.
Lee told the participants that Taiwan has enjoyed a lead in the information-related industry, but it has to face the paradox between science-technology and social development.
He said that improving the country's competitiveness is important, but it is also important to learn how to cooperate with others.

The 1986 Nobel prize winner for chemistry pointed out that Taiwan must seriously consider how to develop a way for the island's everlasting development and to consider the relationship between humankind and nature.
Lee also touched on the issues of the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power generation unit, Taiwan's educational reform and the island's security problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' ARE PRIORITY OF CHEN ADMINISTRATION: MAC CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Matsu, Fujian Province, June 4 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said on Sunday that establishing the "mini three links" will be a priority of the new government under the leadership of President Chen Shui-bian.

The MAC chief made the remarks after arriving in Matsu on Sunday morning for a whirlwind visit in company of Lin Yi-fu, vice minister of economic affairs, Wu Jung-kwei, director of the Navigation and Aviation Department of the Ministry of Transport and Communications, and Liu Teh-hsuen, director of the political and legal department of the MAC.

Tsai and her entourage visited the Matsu Defense Command (MDC), where they were briefed by officials on the current status of Matsu's military defense. They later visited with officials of the government of Lienchiang County, who briefed them on port facilities in Matsu.

Tsai also met with local residents to hear their opinions on the proposed "mini three links" -- direct trade, transport and communications between Kinmen or Matsu and coastal cities of mainland China.

Liu of Lienchiang County recommended that the new government amend several inadequate regulations to enable the implementation of the "mini three links", which he said are sorely needed by residents of Kinmen and Matsu.

Liu said that the Lienchiang County government has already drawn up a temporary statute for commercial links between the Matsu area and mainland China. The legislation is subject to approval by the Central Government.

In return, Tsai said that she and President Chen Shui-bian have repeatedly expressed the government's position toward the three links issue. Prior to implementing the three links between Taiwan proper and mainland China, the government will allow the "mini three links" between the frontier islands and mainland China. However, she said that no timetable has been set for establishing them.
As the implementation of the initial links will be one of the new government's priorities, she said that she expects them to be in place by the end of this year.
She also promised to amend any inadequate laws or regulations so as to normalize commerce between Matsu and mainland China.
Tsai and her entourage also visited the airports on Nankan and Peikan Islands to get an idea of the facilities' capacity for handling passengers. The airport expansion project was underway.
Tsai returned to Taiwan on Sunday afternoon after attending a symposium with local residents.

Tsai had previously visited Kinmen accompanied by Gen. Teng Tzu-lin, director general of the Political Welfare Department of the Ministry of National Defense, as well as officials from ministries of Economic Affairs and Transport and Communications. They also toured defensive fortifications there, and observed Kinmen's port facilities prior to the opening of the "mini three links."

Tsai had kept a low profile on her Kinmen trip due to the sensitive nature of cross-strait relations. Tsai and her entourage flew into Kinmen on a military airplane, which stopped at a military apron to avoid publicity.
Lt. Gen. Chu Kai-sheng, the commander of Kinmen's defense forces, was only informed about Tsai's confidential trip on the previous day.

After being briefed on the military situation on Kinmen by Kinmen Defense Command officials, Tsai visited the ports at Shuitou and Liaolowan to inspect the facilities and assess their passenger-handling capacities.
Tsai reiterated the government determination to implement the "mini three links" prior to implementing the direct three links between the mainland and Taiwan proper.
Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tzai suggested that a cross-strait consultation center be established in Kinmen and military observers be stationed on both sides so as to establish mutual trust.

Chen also said that Kinmen can serve as a hub for mainland Chinese people traveling to and from the ROC. He further suggested that Kinmen be partially opened for mainland Chinese visitors, and that a special economic zone be established in Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL CRITICIZES PM'S FAILURE TO EMBRACE UNIFICATION GUIDELINES

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei's failure to embrace the National Unification Guidelines in his first administrative report will not help enhance national security, an official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said on Sunday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Department of Mainland Affairs Research, said that although President Chen Shui-bian had said in his inaugural speech that the National Unification Council and National Unification Guidelines will not be scrapped, whether or not he will actually follow them has come into question.

Chang noted that Tang had not followed the lead of past KMT premiers by reaffirming that he would stick to the National Unification Guidelines. He said that this shows that with the change of political power, the guidelines which have pointed the way for the nation's mainland policy over the years will be put aside.

Chang noted that Chen has not strongly rejected the National Unification Council and National Unification Guidelines, out of consideration of national security and stable cross-strait relations. The KMT official added that Chen's attitude has become remarkably passive in comparison to the past, when he was the standard bearer of the opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.

Chang urged Tang to insist on his ideals when he agreed to work under Chen as premier, adding that Tang had said at the time that he was accepting the offer to serve the country amid "tense and stark" cross-strait relations.
Chang said that Tang should have his own ideas about improving cross-strait ties, and not to be confined by Chen's attitude toward cross-strait relations.

He also said that the democratic development in Taiwan has reached a level where every step of the development of cross-strait relations will have to be agreed by the public, and he urged Premier Tang to stick to his ideas in improving cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 22.57 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its upward streak on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 22.57 points to close at 8,958.21.
Market turnover amounted to NT$88.86 billion (US$2.89 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES AUSTRALIA TO BID FOR LNG CONTRACT
DOC.DATELINE: Darwin, Australia, June 4 (CNA) (By Chin-ling Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Australia is welcome to compete in Taiwan's open bid for supplies of liquefied natural gas (LNG), Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said here on Sunday.

During a meeting with Australian Trade Minister Mark Vaile ahead of a key meeting of trade ministers from the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Lin told his Australian counterpart that Australian companies are welcome to compete in open bidding to sell LNG to Taiwan, which will consider product quality and price, freight costs, and the quality of after-sale service when granting the contract.

Australian LNG (ALNG), an alliance of six major Australian LNG companies, is poised to bid for a NT$400 billion (US$13 billion) 25-year contract to be offered by Taiwan Power Company (Taipower). The LNG will be supplied for use in thermo-power generation at Taipower's new Tahtan Power Plant, which is expected to have an installation capacity of 4 megawatts when fully operational. The plant will need about NT$18 billion (US$0.58 billion) worth of LNG fuel per year.

Meanwhile, Lin also exchanged views with Vaile on the fifth vice economic and trade ministers meeting between Taiwan and Australia, which is scheduled to be held July 27-28 in Taipei, and on E-IAP (electronic individual action plan) talks under the APEC framework.

Vaile, who will chair the APEC trade ministers' meeting on efforts to build momentum to relaunch a new round of World Trade Organization (WTO) talks, said Australia fully supports Taiwan's early accession to the WTO.
In return, Lin suggested that both sides develop a ministerial-level communication channel for useful dialogue to further bolster bilateral business and trade exchanges.

Lin also urged that Australia increase its purchases from Taiwan as Australia has long enjoyed a surplus in two-way trade between the two countries. In 1999, Taiwan exported US$1.92 billion worth of products to Australia while it imported US$2.68 billion worth of commodities from Australia, suffering a deficit of US$760 million.

APEC is composed of Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam. The APEC economies account for more than 80 percent of the world's total gross domestic product and 45 percent of total global trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 22.57 points to close at 8,958.21.
The bourse opened at 8,961.36 and fluctuated between 8,975.99 and 8,894.82 during trading.

A total of 1.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.86 billion (US$2.89 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.98 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$115.24 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 280 to 228, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.

Five of the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.5 percent, textile issues and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 0.4 percent, and cement shares at 0.3 percent
All the other major categories posted gains, with construction shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD EXPRESSES OPPOSITION TO SECURITY TAX

TEXT.P: The government is not planning to impose a security tax on cross-strait business and trade and on individuals dealing in this sector, Taiwan's top economic planner said on Monday.

Chen Po-chih, the newly-installed chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said he personally opposes the idea of a security tax and will oppose any government move to support the initiative.
Chen made the remarks in response to legislators questions at the Legislative Yuan.
Meanwhile, Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong, also at the Legislative Yuan, said the imposition of a security tax was only an opinion expressed by an academic and was far from being a government policy.

Shea said that Chen Shih-meng, who is presently a professor in National Taiwan University's Department of Economics, first made the security tax proposal while talking about cross-strait business and trade last month.
Shea added that the proposal was simply an idea put forth by a scholar and has nothing to do with the Ministry of Finance or the government's overall policy.
Chen has been appointed as deputy governor of the Central Bank of China, but will not take office until Aug. 1, Cabinet sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Monday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved up 8 points to close at 9,041, with 2,513 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July increased 14 points to finish at 9,050, with 74 contract transactions, while September futures lost 40 points to close at 9,160, with 12 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December and next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 9,033 for June; 9,036 for July; 9,200 for September; 9,403 for December; and 9,263 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported mixed results.
June TE futures moved up 2.5 points to close at 495.5, with 763 contract transactions, while July TE futures increased 3.4 points to finish at 496.5, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

June TF futures decreased 3 points to finish at 942, with 318 contract transactions, while July TF futures moved down 1.4 points to close at 946.6, with 22 contract transactions, and September TF futures edged down 0.8 points to finish at 948, with 15 contract transactions.
December TF futures remained unchanged at 959, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM TANG EXPECTED TO REGAIN 90 PERCENT OF HEALTH BY NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: Newly-installed Premier Tang Fei, who is still recovering from surgery carried out on April 16 to remove a chest tumor, is expected to regain 90 percent of his health by July if he is allowed sufficient rest, doctors said on Monday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Veterans General Hospital President Chang Mao-sung said Tang, whose chest wound has almost healed as of Friday following excellent after-surgery rehabilitation, will be physically capable of standing for legislative interpellation sessions by next month, as long as they do not exceed six hours.

He said that, as of Friday, the 68-year-old premier's health had recovered by 70 percent. If he receives sufficient rest and proper rehabilitation, Tang's health is expected to return to 100 percent in the months ahead, Chang noted.
Meanwhile, Veterans Hospital officials said that, based on his present condition, the premier is allowed to spend four half days working at his office this week.

Tang, the defense minister in the previous Kuomintang-led government, delivered his first administrative report to the legislature in his capacity as premier last Friday under close monitoring by doctors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HAS NO INTENTION OF RUNNING FOR KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said on Monday that he will not seek to serve concurrently as the party chairman of the Kuomintang because he believes the post is a full-time job that requires one hundred percent devotion.

Ma made the remarks during an interview with a local radio station in the wake of Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh's registration as the sole candidate for the party chairmanship of the Democratic Progressive Party last Friday, prompting speculation that Ma might be considering a similar move.

Ma categorically said he will not seek the position of KMT chairman, adding that he supports the acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who maintains a "moderate" stance, as the candidate for party chairman and in his efforts to push for party reform.

Ma said the KMT's situation is different from that of the DPP, saying that the KMT has a lot of reform work to do and the future KMT chairman will have to be able to devote his full energies to the post.
The popular Taipei mayor has been viewed as a possible candidate who might be able to revitalize the KMT after its humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election.

But Ma, who has never taken the initiative in seeking support for his job as a KMT Central Committee member or as a Central Standing Committee member over the years, said that this time he will actively solicit support in his KMT Central Standing Committee member election bid in order to promote his reform ideals.

Ma said that the most important task for the KMT at the provisional meeting of the party's congress later this month is reform of the party charter so as to pave way for the selection of party chairman through direct election, as well as a nationwide registration of its members.
Ma said that he was "cautiously optimistic" about the prospects for real reform within the KMT.

Ma said that reform of the party only began after the election defeat, and completion of the task will require time, adding that as long as the party revises its charter to allow for the direct election of its party chairman to reflect the true voice of its members, the party will gradually come out of the shadow of its humiliating loss.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TRYING TO CURB ONLINE DISSENT

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Ministry for Public Security has drawn up a black list of websites in an attempt to curb online political dissent, reported the Australian Financial Review on Monday.

Internet service providers in China have been warned that they risk losing their licenses if they do not block access to the blacklisted sites. The internet cafes now found in almost every city and town in China have also been warned by the ministry that they will be closed if their customers are found to be reading the reactionary material.
The daily reported Beijing's move against such online dissent is in response to the increasing use of the internet by groups expressing anti-government messages.

Meanwhile, Chinese authorities over recent weeks have used more traditional measures to ensure that the 11th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre passed as quietly as possible, the daily reported.

The daily quoted a Beijing newspaper as saying that more than 1300 people have been detained in the capital over the past few weeks for not carrying official identity papers. Amnesty International also reported last week that 213 people remain in prison or on medical parole in connection with the 1989 massacre.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 5, or the fourth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1783: A hot-air balloon, made by the brothers Joseph-Michel and Jacques-Etienne Montgolfier, slowly rises 6,000 ft. (2,000 m) into the air in Annonay, France.
1806: Louis Bonaparte, Napoleon's brother who fought with Napoleon in Italy (1796-1797) and Egypt (1798-1899), is declared king of the Netherlands.
1819: John Couch Adams, British mathematician and astronomer, is born. In 1845, he predicted to within 2 degrees the position of the planet Neptune, which was certified in 1846.
1883: John Maynard Keynes, British economist, is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1916: Horatio Herbert Kitchener, British soldier and war leader, drowns off the Orkneys Islands, northeast of the Scottish mainland, when the SS Hampshire, carrying him on a mission to Russia, hits a German mine and sinks. Earlier in his life, he brought the Boer War to a conclusion and served as secretary for war during World War I.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces.
1940: German forces begin their attack on France. They occupied Paris on June 14.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective control.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignias, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: US Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1955: The Taiwan Provincial Teachers College is reorganized into National Taiwan Normal University.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1963: British Secretary of State for War John Profumo resigns from his parliamentary seat and from his Cabinet position after admitting that he lied to the House of Commons about his association with the model Christine Keeler.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1973: Kaohsiung City becomes a sister city of Barranquilla in northern Colombia.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends his five-day visit.
1976: Federico Fortin Aguilar, president of the Honduras Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a nine-day visit.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1980: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui, Tainan Mayor Su Nan-cheng, and Keelung Mayor Chen Cheng-hsiung leave on a goodwill tour to the United States.
1988: A train packed with explosives blows up as it enters the station at Arzamas, an industrial city east of Moscow, killing more than 50 people and injuring several hundred others.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: US President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL CONTINUE PURSUIT OF UN REPRESENTATION: FM

TEXT.P: The new Republic of China government will continue pursuing representation in the United Nations, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Monday.
Tien made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee.
Tien said the ROC's UN bid is critical to the country's status, rights and interests in the international community.

"Although our UN bid has failed to make the agenda of the annual UN General Assembly plenary session over the past six years because of mainland China's opposition, we will not be daunted by the setback," Tien said, adding that the ROC's goal of seeking UN representation remains unchanged.

From 1994, the ROC's diplomatic allies presented a proposal to the UN Secretariat annually asking the UN General Assembly to form a special task force to study the issue related to Taiwan's UN representation. The proposal, however, was consistently killed at the Steering Committee discussion and failed to make the General Assembly agenda due to mainland China's boycott.

Tien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has begun planning for this year's UN bid. "The ministry is also scheduled to call a meeting between late June and early July to discuss in which way or form the ROC will re-join the United Nations," Tien said, adding that scholars, experts and legislators will be invited to explained their opinions at the planned meeting.
The ROC, a UN founding member, was forced out of the United Nations in 1971 when the UN General Assembly adopted Resolution No. 2758 which gave the China seat to Beijing at the expense of Taipei.

Tien said the MOFA will continue seeking a way for the 23 million ROC nationals' voices being heard in the United Nations. "We will also actively explore feasible measures for the ROC to take part in activities of various UN affiliates," he added.
The scholar-turned-minister further said the new ROC government will use new thinking to promote "comprehensive pragmatic diplomacy" based on the existing foundations.

Tien said since the ROC upholds democracy and freedom, it must promote "human rights diplomacy" and "democracy diplomacy" through actively helping other members of the international community improve their human rights conditions and creating a climate conducive for peace and democratic development around the world.

Noting that the ROC's private sector has rich manpower and material resources, Tien said the MOFA will strengthen cooperate with civilian organizations in expanding the country's diplomatic frontiers and cementing cooperation with as many other countries as possible.
"To reach this goal, the MOFA will assist private groups in joining non-governmental international organizations and developing 'Track' II unofficial dialogue and exchanges mechanism," Tien said.

In formulating the country's diplomatic policy and action plans, Tien said the MOFA will encourage private think tanks, social groups or individual members of the public to offer advice as reference. "The MOFA also plans to conduct opinion surveys to solicit and integrate public opinions on major diplomatic topics as reference for future foreign policy adjustments."
