Tien went on to say that he will endeavor to be a "hard-working, pragmatic and forward-looking" foreign minister and that youthfulness and professionalism will be guiding principles in rejuvenating the country's diplomatic work force.

Asked about the possibilities of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu visiting other countries or attending international meetings, Tien said the MOFA will do its utmost to help the country's top leaders realize their overseas travel plans so long as it receives an order.

Because of Beijing's consistent attempts to isolate the ROC in the international community, it has been difficult for senior ROC leaders to visit countries with which the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties.

As for the feasibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait stopping "zero-sum" diplomatic competition for winning diplomatic allies, Tien said a cross-strait "diplomatic truce" is unlikely until after the current cross-strait logjam sees a breakthrough and bilateral relations make progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO CONTINUE PRESSURING TAIWAN BUSSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Beijing will continue putting pressure on Taiwan businessmen to renounce any Taiwan independence sentiment because it thinks the same tactic of "mixing politics with business" worked with regard to former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten, the South China Morning Post reported today.

The report quoted a mainland source as saying that the Beijing leadership was convinced the "mischief" perpetrated by Patten - a reference to his efforts to promote democracy in Hong Kong - was contained because Beijing was able to oblige most Hong Kong businessmen to at least dissociate themselves with the last governor.

The source revealed that forcing Taiwan businessmen to declare support for the "one China" policy would remain a major policy on reunification ahead of the annual series of informal leadership meetings in the seaside resort of Beidaihe, scheduled to begin in early to mid-August.

"Politburo members, regional leaders and other senior cadres attending the Beidaihe meetings will make a new assessment on (Republic of China President) Chen Shui-bian," the source was quoted as saying.
"They will decide whether tougher measures, including quasi-military means such as missile tests close to Taiwan, are called for."
According to the report, President Jiang and his advisers are satisfied with the intimidation tactics applied to Taiwan businessmen.

"Through intermediaries, including influential SAR tycoons, the heads of most of the big Taiwan companies investing on the mainland have told Beijing they will not support pro-independence policies," the report pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE NOT ALLOWED TO ATTEND OBUCHI FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao confirmed media reports on Monday that Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chung-hsiung will not be able to attend the funeral of late Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, due to the wishes of the Japanese government.

Tien said that his ministry will officially relay the Republic of China government's regrets to the Japanese government and that President Chen will announce a replacement to attend the funeral later the same day.
Tien made the remarks while answering questions at a interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.
Chung Ming-yao, former ROC representative to Japan and current National Security Council secretary-general, has been rumored to be a possible replacement for Chang in attending Obuchi's funeral.
At the same time, Chang said that President Chen also had expressed regrets about the Japanese government's decision.

Chang said that such a highly politically-motivated move is not conducive to positive exchanges between Taiwan and Japan, and added that it is probably not something that the Japanese public supports. He also said that the Japanese government was too "sensitive" about an internal affair like this.

According to foreign wire services, the Japanese government is slated to hold a public funeral on June 8 for Obuchi, who died last month due to heart problems. Major world politicians, including US President Bill Clinton, will attend the services.

President Chen had originally appointed Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-ping, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Chang to represent him at the services. But Chang's presence has not been welcomed by the Japanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO DEAL WITH FUTURE 'ONE CHINA' ON EXISTING FOUNDATIONS: CHEN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is willing to deal with the question of a future "one China" based on all existing foundations, President Chen Shui-bian said on Monday.
Chen also pointed out that the existing foundations refer to all agreements, consensus or conclusions reached through dialogue and contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the past.

Noting that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are obliged to jointly face the question of a future "one China," Chen said the ROC is hopeful that the two sides can forge a consensus based on these existing foundations.
The ROC's first opposition leader-turned-president made the statements while meeting with a delegation from the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington-based think tank.

The delegation, headed by new CSIS President John J. Hamre, arrived in Taipei on Sunday to attend a roundtable meeting on the new challenges of the new millennium, to be sponsored by Taipei's Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC).

President Chen said it is of great significance that the roundtable meeting will open on Wednesday now that the ROC has completed its first democratic peaceful transfer of power between different political parties and that cross-strait relations are at a critical juncture.

Chen stressed that the greatest difference between the two sides of the strait lies in the ROC's upholding of such universal values as democracy and human rights, adding that the ROC will play a more active role in safeguarding and promoting human rights in the new century.
Noting that improvement of cross-strait ties are conducive to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Chen said goodwill and sincerity are needed to improve cross-strait relations.

He further said his May 20 inaugural speech highlighted three basic principles -- national dignity, democracy and goodwill. In his widely watched inaugural address, Chen also made the assurances that so long as mainland China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, his administration will uphold a "four noes" policy and will also not abolish the ROC's existing National Unification Guidelines and National Unification Council.

The "four noes" policy refers to no declaration of Taiwan independence, no changes to the ROC's national title, no inclusion of the controversial "special state-to-state relationship" concept into the ROC's constitution and no plebiscite on the "independence/unification" issue.

"My assurances signify my administration's unbiased openness toward the direction of future cross-strait relations. We have no bias and are willing to deal with the question of a future 'one China' on the current foundations," President Chen said.

He went on to say that US President Bill Clinton's recent emphasis on a fourth principle for resolving cross-strait issues -- any solution must have the consent of the people of Taiwan -- is very important.

"Since the ROC has become a full-fledged democracy, it must respect the free will and choice of its people. Taiwan people have legitimate rights to choose and decide on Taiwan's future," the president emphasized.

He reaffirmed the ROC's determination to resolve cross-strait disputes by peaceful means. "The most urgent task for the moment is resumption of cross-strait dialogue. We are ready to resume talks and negotiations with mainland china. Now, the ball is in Beijing's court. We hope Beijing can make a positive response to our goodwill."

Chen also said he hopes private US think tanks, like the CSIS, can help forge "Track II" or "Track III" unofficial contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and between Taipei and Washington to make for the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA GOV'T URGED TO KEEP REALISTIC TIES WITH US ON TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: Former Australian Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fisher on Monday urged the Australian government to maintain purposeful and realistic relations with the United States, particularly on the Taiwan issue.
In an article on The Australian on Monday, Fisher said the ugly side of ties between Canberra and Washington can be seen in US demands that Australia make a commitment on the Taiwan issue.
"Defense adviser in Washington Dick Armitage said in September last year that the US would expect Australia to help out with the dirty work in conflict with China over Taiwan," Fisher said.

"It would be far better for more energy to be put into developing confidence building measures across the Taiwan Straits and also urge restraint, as (Prime Minister) John Howard has done recently," he said.
"Might I point out that since the Union Jack came down on Hong Kong, there have been direct flights between China and Chinese Taipei, and they sky has not fallen in?" he said.

"Clearly Australia should maintain a purposeful relationship with the US, and with China and all of the members of APEC," he said, adding "We will best do this with a clear-sighted and realistic approach that examines every aspect of the Australia-US relationship, including the good, the bad and the ugly."

He said that the good side of relations between the US and Australia was manifested by the "breakthrough when the US House of Representatives abolished the annual renewal of China's most-favoured nation status."

The US move will prove to be good for Australia, Fisher said. "When permanent normal trade relations are confirmed by the US Senate, it will not only be a win-win situation for the US and China, but also indirectly for Australia as it moves China's application forward to become a member of the World Trade Organization," Fisher said.

Another sore point between the two nations is the new US$15 billion farms subsidy package being handed out by the US government to bolster American farm exports, he said, adding that the subsidies will put Australia in a bad position to compete in the global market.
"The US has set a bad example and will prompt other countries to think hard about how long they can maintain a non-direct subsidy approach," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DRASTIC CHANGE ON 'GO SLOW' POLICY: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will shortly host a meeting of local petrochemical and wafer manufacturers to discuss easing current restrictions on investment in the mainland, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Monday.

The MOEA had originally planned a meeting on Monday to discuss revising the principles governing Taiwan firms investing or engaging cooperative technology development in the mainland. Many had viewed the meeting as the forerunner of a drastic adjustment of the nation's "go slow, be patient" policy toward the mainland.

But the MOEA announced on Monday that the meeting had been canceled because of insufficient preparations. Instead, the ministry will invite related manufacturers for a discussion within the next two weeks.

Former President Lee Teng-hui imposed the "go slow, be patient" policy toward the mainland in 1996, banning local manufacturers from investing in infrastructure construction in mainland China, and subjecting all investments to a cap of US$50 million for each investment project.

Lin said that whether to allow petrochemical and wafer manufacturers to invest in the mainland has yet to be decided, and whether to raise the ceiling on each investment project to more than US$50 million is also still up in the air. He added that the minister will now invite related manufacturers to jointly map out an overall strategy.
The new government had said earlier that it would ease the restrictions as a goodwill gesture toward the mainland.

Lin said that the loosening of current restrictions on investment in the mainland should be done gradually. He noted that the possibility of drastic change in the policy is not high at present, since moving too quickly would use up Taiwan's leverage on the issue too soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD HOPES 'MINI THREE LINKS' IN PLACE BY YEAR END

TEXT.P: The country's top economic planning chief voiced the hope on Monday that the "mini three links" between Taiwan-controlled outlying islands and mainland China would be in place by this year, while making it clear that he is opposed to a "national security tax" plan.

Answering questions from the Legislative Yuan's Economic Affairs and Energy committee, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Pao-chih said he hopes that direct trade, transport and postal links between offshore islands and mainland China could be set up by the end of this year, as relevant government agencies have been actively working on the issue.
"As not too many laws and regulations are involved in legalizing the issue, the 'mini three links' are expected to be established by the end of the year," Chen noted.

According to the CEPD chief, the "mini three links" should focus on helping the outlying islands -- Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu -- develop their economies, while preventing a detrimental impact on Taiwan's overall economy.

Chen admitted that clandestine trade has long existed between remote islands and the mainland, and expressed his hope that regulating such practices would help develop the local economies on the outlying islands.

However, he elaborated that under the "mini three links" framework, mainland-made products will be only allowed to enter the outlying islands, while they cannot be transported from those islands to Taiwan proper.

"Otherwise, it would make those offshore islands a distribution center of mainland Chinese goods for Taiwan proper, a situation which is tantamount to an opening of the 'three direct links' between Taiwan and the mainland," he pointed out.

In addition, Chen said he is in favor of the allowing a "direct religious voyage" between Taiwan and mainland China, while voicing his disagreement to a proposed "national security tax" on Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.011 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$30.792.
The local currency opened at NT$30.791 and was traded between NT$30.783 and NT$30.811.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$391 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWAN TOURISTS TRAVELING ON SUMATRA

TEXT.P: No tourists from Taiwan are known to be traveling on the Indonesian island of Sumatra after a strong earthquake hit the region on late Sunday, the Taipei Association of Travel Agents (TATA) said on Monday.

The TATA said that it has looked into the matter following the earthquake, which measured 7.9 on the Richter scale. Officials said that they found that no Taiwan tour groups are currently traveling in that part of the southeast Asian country.

Since the outbreak of social unrest in Indonesia two years ago, only Bali remains as a popular destination within that country for Taiwan tourists, a TATA official said. Jakarta, Surabaya, and Medan only rarely see Taiwan tourists, he added.
According to wire services reports, at least 51 people were killed by the catastrophe in Sumatra.
At the same time, no Taiwan tourists currently visiting the Sabah and Surawak regions in neighboring Malaysia have been affected by the incident, the TATA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO LIFT BAN ON EXCHANGES OF HIGH-LEVEL VISITS WITH ROC

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu said on Monday that the Republic of China looks forward to seeing the United States lift its ban on the exchanges of high-level visits between the two countries.
Lu, the ROC's first female vice president, made the call during a meeting with a delegation from the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington-based think tank.
Lu said the ROC neither opposes Washington-Beijing engagement nor objects to US granting of permanent normal trade relations to mainland China.

Nevertheless, Lu said, the ROC earnestly hopes that the United States can adopt "five measures" to further strengthen bilateral ties and help improve relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"First of all, we hope that the US government will allow its senior officials to visit Taiwan and also opens its door to top ROC leaders," said the political dissident-turned-politician.

Lu went on to suggest that the United States rearrange the order of priority of the three pillars of its so-called "one China" policy by emphasizing "peaceful solution" to cross-strait disputes as the most important principle. At present, the US government places the "one China" concept at the first place.
Third, Lu said she is hopeful that US President Bill Clinton can issue a statement before the end of his presidential term reaffirming the US stance on peaceful solution to cross-strait issues.
In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, Lu said the United States should continue selling defensive weapons to Taiwan.
Fifth, Lu said she hopes the United Sates can play a more active role in cross-strait relations.
Touching on cross-strait ties, Lu said Taiwan and mainland China share very special relations because they are both "remote relatives and close neighbors."

In addition to geographic proximity, Lu said, the people on both sides of the strait share common ancestral and cultural links as many Taiwan people hailed from the mainland. Against this backdrop, Lu said the people on both sides should be friendly toward each other.

"However, in the political arena, the two sides have great differences and mainland Chinese authorities have never expressed goodwill toward the people of Taiwan and have not tried to understand their thinking and opinions," Lu noted.

The outspoken vice president further said the transition of the reins of power from the Kuomintang, Taiwan ruling party for the past 55 years, to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should mark an end to previous cross-strait tension and animosity.
"The DPP administration does not want to confront with mainland China but instead wants peace and friendship ," Lu said, adding that the people of Taiwan love peace and democracy.
Lu, a DPP stalwart, also said Taiwan can serve as a beacon to guide mainland China's future development.

For his part, CSIS President John Hamre said he also hopes that cross-strait issues can be resolved through peaceful dialogue, adding he believes that the next two years are crucial to the development of future cross-strait ties.

Hamre and two CSIS project directors -- Richard Fairbanks and Gerrit Gong -- arrived in Taipei on Sunday to attend a roundtable meeting on the new challenges for the new millennium, scheduled to open on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT POSSIBLE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 5 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said on Monday that a summit between the leaders of Taiwan and mainland China is possible within the coming four years, and that he would be very willing to help forge such a meeting.

Japan's Sankei Shimbun reported Lee as saying he would be willing to help bring about such a meeting, and that he would also be prepared to play the role of mediator with Beijing when necessary, which the daily newspaper said indicated his wish to serve as an envoy for the Republic of China government.

In the face of the current suspension of regular talks between Taiwan and mainland China, Lee said that a cross-strait task force should be set up to work out common ground between the two sides, the newspaper reported.
Addressing the issue of social development, Lee said national interests should take precedence over any political party's interests, especially when touching on matters of national concern.

According to Lee, Taiwan must stamp out its "black gold" politics if it is to pursue continued progress, while the well-being of the people, as well as the safety of their lives and property, are the most important issues facing the government.
Lee is currently visiting Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT SAILING FOR PILGRIMS: MAC

TEXT.P: The cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday that no timetable for opening direct sailing across the Taiwan Strait for religious pilgrimage is available at the moment.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, was responding to a press report that the council will unveil a solution to the "direct cross-strait sailing for pilgrims" issue within one month.

"The report is not correct," the MAC said in a three-point press release. For one thing, the MAC said the feasibility of the proposal is still under initial evaluation and that no timetable has been set for unveiling a conclusion of the study.
Second, the MAC said the evaluation is not for any specific religious organization.
Third, the MAC urged local people not to start preparations for direct cross-strait pilgrimage sailing before the government finalizes its evaluation and comes to a decision.
The Taoist Chenlan Temple in Tachia, Taichung County in central Taiwan filed an application with the MAC last month for permission to direct cross-strait sailing for religious pilgrimage.

The Chenlan Temple is dedicated to the Chinese Goddess of Sea, commonly known as Matsu in Chinese society. Many local Matsu followers like to make a pilgrimage to a Matsu temple in Meizhou, a small islet off the coast of southeastern mainland province of Fujian. As Taiwan bans direct cross-strait shipping services, local pilgrims usually have to waste much money and time for traveling to Meizhou via Hong Kong or Macau.

The Chenlan Temple plans to lease a Singaporean passenger ship to directly transport pilgrims to Meizhou from Taichung Harbor by making a stopover either at Taiwan-controlled frontline island of Kinmen or the offshore county of Penghu.
Chenlan Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao announced on Sunday that the temple has tentatively decided to start the pilgrimage on July 16.
However, Fu Tung-cheng, director of the MAC's economic affairs division, stressed that the MAC is studying the issue not because of the Chenlan Temple's application.
"We are making an overall evaluation of all similar cross-strait pilgrimage sailing," Fu said, adding that the MAC has not set any timetable for finalizing the evaluation.
If the feasibility study gets a positive conclusion, Fu said, the MAC will then begin to mull concrete measures for opening direct cross-strait sailing for religious purposes.

"We hope private religious groups will not hold unrealistic or too optimistic expectations of the study result," Fu said, adding that for the sake of ensuring national security, the MAC hopes local religious groups will cooperate with the government.
Meanwhile, Chenlan Temple Chairman Yen, also Taichung County speaker, said on Monday that without the MAC's approval, his temple will not make direct cross-strait pilgrimage sailing to Meizhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLDEN `TZUNGTZU' UNVEILED IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: With the approach of the Dragon Boat Festival, one of the most important holidays in the lunar calendar, various traditional and innovative glutinous rice dumplings, or Tzungtzu, have hit the market.

The United Evening News reported that one gold shop in Lukang, Changhua County, has even used five taels of gold to produce bamboo leaves made of gold which are used to wrap the traditional tzungtzu ingredients -- glutinous rice, meat, and dried mushrooms.

According to the goldsmith, if you do not mind missing the unique flavor of bamboo leaves, they are actually more suitable for the dish, "because they transmit heat quickly and do not get cold so quickly" as normal, albeit cheaper versions.
The golden tzungtzu sells for NT$50,000 (US$1,620) each, which the shop owner claimed is "not too expensive if you consider that gold tzungtzu leaves can be re-used every year."
The owner added that he has actually sold some golden tzungtzu. Dragon Boat festival falls on Tuesday this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR CONTINUED SEARCH FOR A MISSING SHIP

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker on Monday urged the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to form a special task force to assist in search for a gravel ship which has lost contact for more than three months.

Legislator Lee Ching-an of the newly formed opposition People First Party said the Hualien No. 1 gravel ship left the Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan at 5 p.m. on Feb. 28, with 21 crew members and 5,380 tons of gravel on board.

The freighter, owned by Taiwan's Eastern Shipping Co., was originally scheduled to arrive at the northern Taiwan port of Tamshui at 7 a.m. Feb. 29, but it failed to arrive on time. The ship owner tried to contact its crew, but to no avail. The military has assisted in search and rescue operations, but no trace or clue has so far been discovered.
Lee said a lack of vertical contacts among relevant government agencies has made "search and rescue work" even more difficult.

Lee said many questions surrounding the incident. "I couldn't understand why its crew members had not sent out distress calls if the ship developed mechanical failures or encountered any other troubles," she said. The freighter was equipped with four different distress call devices.
"And if the ship was abducted, why no relevant information or news reports have been released from mainland China, Japan or other neighboring countries?" Lee asked.

She said the MOTC should immediately form a special panel to help clarify these dubious points. Relevant government agencies should also not adopt a hands-off policy and should instead take necessary measures to help families of all crew members handle the aftermath.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO SET UP TRADE OFFICE IN KOREA

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is planning to help boost trade relations between and South Korea by setting up a trade office in Seoul, a senior CETRA official said on Monday.

CETRA and the Association for Trade Agents of Korea (AFTAK) inked a cooperation agreement for the office on Monday. CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo and AFTAK Chairman Li Son hi signed the agreement on behalf of their respective parties.

AFTAK is South Korea's biggest importers' organization. Li, who was in Taipei with a 16-member delegation to attend Computex Taipei which opened that day, called on CETRA with the aim of strengthening bilateral economic relations.

CETRA said that South Korea is the 13th-largest trading nation in the world and Taiwan's fourth-largest trade partner. Two-way trade in 1999 totaled US$9.79 billion, or an increase of 37 percent over the year-earlier level.
During the same period, Taiwan suffered a US$4.58 billion trade deficit with South Korea, the island's highest behind its deficit with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY LEADERS VISIT WITH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A leader of Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry on Monday said that he envisions Taiwan becoming a model digital economy for the world.

Stan Shih, chairman of Acer Group, made the remarks when he and other representatives of Taiwan's computer industry called on President Chen Shui-bian to offer their suggestions on the development of Taiwan's IT industry.

Shih said that in order to maintain Taiwan's IT edge in the digital era, the industry's strategy has to be changed. He explained that the traditional strategy of focusing on hardware manufacturing should be shifted toward a combination of hardware and software development.

Looking ahead, Shih said Taiwan will have to become a leading innovator in the IT industry. He envisioned that in five years, Taiwan will be a leading supplier of information appliances, and a center for providing digital services throughout the Asia-Pacific region. He further said that in 10 years, Taiwan will be a model digital economy for the world.

Shih noted that in 1993, when he was serving as the chairman of the Taipei Computer Association, he convened a meeting on IT strategies. The participants at the time had envisioned Taiwan as a recognized world center of the IT industry.

Shih recalled that the officials at the meeting had set goals for Taiwan to develop at least five mainstream products, to have more than 5 million personal computers, to produce more than US$40 billion worth of hardware products per year, and to produce an annual US$12 billion in software products.
The Taipei Computer Association recently reviewed the performance of the IT industry and found that the goals have all been met, with the exception of the software industry.
Shih said that the software industry failed to meet the goal set in 1993 because the scale of domestic demand is too small.

Shih was accompanied by Raff Liu, chairman of the Taipei Computer Association, Miao Fung-chiang, chairman of Mitac Group, and Huang Pin-jung, chairman of the Eten Information Systems, to meet with the President.
They suggested to Chen that he work to boost domestic demand, upgrade Taiwan's brand names in the world, use mainland resources, redistribute government resources, and develop the IT industry.

As the new government has planned to adjust the present "go slow, be patient" policy, which bans investment in mainland infrastructure construction and subjects each mainland investment project to a cap of US$50 million, the suggestion to use mainland resources has aroused attention.

President Chen was positive about the outstanding performance of Taiwan's IT industry, saying that the goal of turning Taiwan into a "green silicon valley" hinges on the renovation and ceaseless efforts of Taiwan's leading high-tech firms.
Chen vowed to provide an open and pluralistic environment, step up education efforts, and reduce hurdles to development.

Chen also instructed Eugene Chien, vice secretary-general to the president, to coordinate related government agencies and present substantial views and approaches so that the government and private sector can work together toward transforming Taiwan into a "green silicon valley."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES REPRIEVE FOR OLD TREES IN HOMETOWN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday urged the township government of his hometown in the southern county of Tainan not to fell hundreds of old trees lining a country road to his parent's home.

Chen, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician, comes from a poor family in Kuantien, Tainan County, and since his victory in the March 18 presidential election, a large number of A-bian (Chen's nickname) fans have swarmed to his hometown to catch a glimpse of the house where he spent his childhood and formative years.

This sudden influx of huge numbers of tourists from all over the island has caused serious traffic problems in Kuantien village and the surrounding region. The Kuantien township government has already felled scores of trees in the neighborhood of Chen's home to make way for a parking lot to accommodate the tour buses which transport curious passengers to the region every day.

Not content with this desecration, however, the township government also plans to widen a major road leading to Chen's home in order to relieve traffic jams in the area. A further 600 old trees lining the road will have to be felled simply to accommodate the project.
Many local environmental groups have asked Chen to stop the Kuantien township government from carrying out its expansion project.

In response to the environmental groups' call to save the old trees, Chen said the road to his home is known as a "green tunnel" because of the beautiful mango trees that line its verges. "The old trees are a valuable asset. If they are felled, it will be a great loss to all Kuantien residents," he said.
Chen said he has ordered Chen Tze-nan, a deputy secretary-general to the president, to contact the Kuantien township government and urge them to protect the old trees.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-USA BUSINESS COUNCIL TO HOLD ANNUAL MEETING IN TAIPEI ON JUNE 14

TEXT.P: The 24th Joint Conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils will be held at the Taipei Grand Hotel on June 14 for three days, the Taipei-based ROC-USA Business Council said in a news release on Monday.

The conference has traditionally been held in November or December, the council said. It added that due to the recent induction of a new ROC government and the fact that some major events such as the Taipei Computer Show and the 2000 Information Technology Conference will be held in June, the conference has been moved forward.

The council expressed its hope that the conference will provide local enterprises with good opportunities for increasing their business as well as recruiting skilled employees, since many outstanding foreigners in related fields will be present.

Wang Chung-yu, board chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council, said that a US Cabinet member will attend the Taipei conference and added that any attendee to this year's conference will be eligible to attend seminars that previously had not been open to ROC nationals.

These new seminars include the "Defense and Aerospace Program" and a breakfast briefing by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei. Additional events include seminars on information technology, banking and finance, biotechnology, and three-way relations among the US, China, and Taiwan. There will also be workshops on power and energy, as well as transportation.
A day-long investor forum will be conducted on June 15 for attendees seeking foreign partnerships, Wang said.

Wang trumpeted the importance of this year's conference, as the meeting will be held at a time when three-way ties between Taipei, Washington and Beijing are at a critical point, and cross-strait relations are especially sensitive.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND AND TAIWAN SHOPPERS ACCOUNT FOR 47% OF FOREIGN SHOPPING IN HK
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 5 (CNA) (By Su Chen-hui & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and mainland Chinese tourists accounted for 47 percent of total retail purchases made by foreigners in Hong Kong last year, according to statistics released by Hong Kong Tourism Association on Monday.

The same statistics show that foreign tourists bought goods worth a total of 25.8 billion Hong Kong dollars last year. Mainland China tourists accounted for 26 percent of the total, while Taiwan tourists bought 21 percent.

Retail shopping accounted for 50 percent of the total consumption of tourists in Hong Kong last year. Clothing was the hottest seller, with a total turnover of 8.5 billion Hong Kong dollars, 33 percent of all shopping by foreigners.

Jewelry was next, with 5.6 billion Hong Kong dollars in total sales, and 22 percent of total retail consumption by foreigners. Retailers also sold 3 billion Hong Kong dollars' worth of leather items to tourists.

A spokesman for the association said that the consumption of jewelry decreased by 10 percent in 1999 as compared with the previous year. He attributed the decrease to the economic slowdown in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES TOLD TO DRESS DOWN IN BID TO SAVE ENERGY

TEXT.P: Sparsely clad workers might no longer raise eyebrows in government offices this summer, as the administration has found a good way to save energy.
The Executive Yuan has circulated a note recently among workers in various government departments urging them to wear less clothing, with the goal of saving energy during Taiwan's sweltering summer.

As part of the government's effort to ease the need for the construction of a controversial nuclear plant, the memo advised employees to dress casually, and to switch on office air conditioners only intermittently.
Coats and ties for men should be reserved for receiving or meeting with outside guests, said the notes.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK TRANSACTION TAX REVENUES IN MAY PLUNGE TO FIVE-MONTH-LOW

TEXT.P: Due to the recent sharp drop in stock trading volume, stock transaction tax collections in May plunged to a five-month-low of NT$8.6 billion (US$286.6 million), according to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Monday.

Dragged down by a plunge in stocks on the NASDAQ, uneasiness over Taiwan's relations with mainland China, and Beijing's war games since May 25, equity prices on the Taipei Security Exchange (TSE) plummeted during May, causing most investors to flee to the sidelines.

The TSE's weighted price index dropped to 8,281 points on May 11, near the last year's average level, with daily volumes evaporating to as low as NT$80 billion (US$2.66 billion) for four consecutive business days.
As a result, the stock transaction tax, set at 0.3 percent of every transaction, declined to NT$8.6 billion (US$286.6 million), against NT$15.3 billion (US$510 million) during the previo7us month.

Including the May figure, accumulated revenues from the stock transaction tax in 2000 have reached NT$116 billion (US$3.86 billion), just NT$6 billion (US$200 million) shy of the NT$122 billion (US$4.06 billion) annual target, due to a booming stock market earlier this year.
The year's target is expected to be met by the end of June, said MOF officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI KICKS OFF, DOUBLE-DIGIT INDUSTRY GROWTH PREDICTED

TEXT.P: Asia's largest computer show kicked off on Monday in Taipei, with over 1,000 domestic and foreign information technology (IT) companies vying for the attention of an estimated 20,000 international buyers.

The 20th annual Taipei International Computer Show (Computex Taipei), organized jointly by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), is one of the three largest IT shows in the world. The five-day exhibition is being held at the Taipei World Trade Center and the Taipei International Convention Center.

CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-Kuo said at the show's opening ceremony that Computex Taipei is a good indicator of Taiwan's IT industrial growth for the year. He added that the show, the largest to date, will draw an estimated crowd of over 20,000 foreign buyers who will bring in sizable orders for local companies.

TCA Chairman Raff Liu pointed out that Taiwan's IT industry achieved an 18.4 percent annual growth rate last year, despite the impact caused by the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, and he estimated that the industry will enjoy a sustained growth rate of over 10 percent over the next few years.

Liu also noted that many domestic companies are moving into the World Wide Web and communications products such as videophones, television set-top boxes, and other information appliances. This, he said, shows the international competitiveness of local companies.

Information Industry Institute (III) adviser Sun Chen-ju said that following Taiwan's success in the information hardware industry, the domestic software and service industry has the potential to reach an estimated market of NT$200 billion (US$6.5 billion) by 2002.

Computex Taipei features 2,151 booths divided into ten areas: communications products; display equipment; components and accessories; peripherals; software applications; computer systems and board-level products; new companies; foreign companies; combined products; and media.
Acer, Asustek, Mitac, Quanta, Intel, and National Semiconductor are among the 1,030 companies represented at the show. Foreign products from 102 companies account for 281 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS POSTPONE TRIP TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A group of Kuomintang lawmakers who planned to visit mainland China early this month announced on Monday a cancellation of the trip owing to an absence of an invitation, according to sources from the Legislative Yuan.

In a written statement, members of the "E-Generation Alliance," a sub-group of Kuomintang lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, said the trip, scheduled for June 7-10, had to be postponed because, as of Monday, they had not received a formal invitation from mainland Chinese authorities.

According to "E-Generation" lawmakers, they were supposed to make the four-day visit, sponsored by Kuomintang Legislator Chen Keng-teh, at the invitation of Beijing's quasi-official intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
They said they have no idea why the ARATS invitation had not reached Taipei by Monday.

In preparation for the trip, which they said they attached great importance to, the lawmakers had visited Taiwan's "King of Business" -- founder of Formosa Plastics Group, Wang Yung-ching -- to exchange views. Wang has made a significant amount of investment in mainland China and was opposed the previous government's "no haste, be patient" policy to curb expanded Taiwanese investment on the Chinese mainland.

They had also met with Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to exchange views on relevant issues. Tsai was quoted as having told them that she hopes the lawmakers will stand firm on Taiwan's stance regarding the "one China" issue while visiting the mainland.

Tsai also said that she will make efforts to push for "direct religious voyages" across the Taiwan Strait to facilitate the annual religious journey by Taiwanese worshippers to Meizhou in mainland China's Fujian province.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING TO JOIN WTO 'ESSENTIALLY SIMULTANEOUS'
DOC.DATELINE: Darwin, Australia, June 4 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said here on Sunday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to join the World Trade Organization before the end of this year.
Lin made the remarks after a closed-door meeting with WTO Director-General Mike Moore.
Lin said the Republic of China and mainland China are expected to be admitted to the WTO on the same day. "The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will join the WTO 'essentially simultaneous,'" he added.
Asked whether mainland China may join the WTO ahead of Taiwan and then boycott Taiwan's entry, Lin said Taiwan cannot control all "variables."
Nevertheless, Lin said Taiwan has been prepared for the worst. "We have prepared measures to cope with any unexpected contingencies," he added.
Lin said he hopes the Legislature Yuan, Taiwan's parliament, can pass three to four WTO-related bills as soon as possible in preparation for Taiwan's WTO accession by year's end.
Lin headed a delegation of ROC officials to attend a trade ministers meeting of the 21-member Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to open on Monday.

Following his meeting with Moore, Lin also held separate bilateral meetings with Australian Trade Minister Mark Vaile and US Deputy Trade Representative Richard Fisher to exchange views on matters of mutual concern. During their talks. both Vaile and Fisher reaffirmed their countries' support for the ROC's WTO bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AGAINST CONFLICT IN TAIWAN STRAIT: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The US government will not encourage any conflict in the Taiwan Strait and should continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan, according to former US Deputy Defense Secretary John J. Hamre in Taipei on Monday.
Hamre arrived in Taipei on Sunday to attend the Seventh Taipei Roundtable, a meeting on the new challenges for the millennium that is scheduled to open on Wednesday.

Hamre, who is president and CEO of the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington-based think tank, arrived with CSIS Asia Program Director Gerrit W. Gong and CSIS counselor Richard Fairbanks.
He said that the United States has always urged the governments on either side of the strait to resolve their political differences through peaceful means.

Hamre added that he knows from his experience in the US Department of Defense that the US government carefully considers the issue of continued military sales to Taiwan every year. With both primary candidates for the next US presidency openly proclaiming the importance of Taiwan's security, the United States should continue its policy of selling defensive weapons to Taiwan, he went on.

As to whether Taipei and Beijing should return to the 1992 agreement of "one China, with separate interpretations as to the meaning of the term" as a basis for negotiations, Gong said that returning to "one China" would be beneficial for both governments.

Fairbanks for his part said that the United States will continue to abide by its own "one China" policy and its principle of maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait. He also said he hoped that Taiwan's new government will negotiate patiently with mainland China.

The Seventh Taipei Roundtable is organized by Chinatrust Commercial Bank and will be attended by experts and scholars in international strategies and economics. President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to give the opening address.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER REJECTS JOB AS PRESIDENTIAL SENIOR ADVISER

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Monday turned down an offer of a job as a senior adviser from President Chen Shui-bian.

Siew told reporters after a meeting with Chen that he appreciated Chen's "kind" job offer but that he would rather serve as a civilian volunteer for anything in the interests of the nation and people.
Siew was the vice presidential running mate of Chen's Kuomintang rival Lien Chan in the March 18 presidential race.
Chen offered the largely ceremonial job to Siew in May when the former premier was in Japan on a private visit.
Since being sworn in as president on May 20, Chen has offered many political appointments to his former rivals as a gesture of reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CHANGES ENVOY FOR JAPANESE PM'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Monday appointed Presidential Senior Adviser Peng Ming-min to replace Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung as his representative at the funeral of late Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.

The change was made because the Japanese government refused to allow Chang to attend the June 8 funeral service as Chen's representative. Many important world figures, including US President Bill Clinton, are expected to attend the service.
Chang expressed regret at the Japanese government's decision, and told local reporters that his visit was to have been "a courtesy call."
Later in the day, one of Peng's aides confirmed that Chen had appointed him as a replacement envoy.

The ROC government was originally to have sent a three-member delegation comprising Chang, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu to attend the funeral on behalf of the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPRISONMENT FAILS TO MUZZLE TWO CHINESE DISSIDENTS

TEXT.P: Five years of imprisonment has failed to prevent two mainland Chinese dissidents from calling for an early vindication of the 1989 student-led demonstrations at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, according to a report released here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said in the report that the dissidents, Lu Yongxiang and Huang Yanming of Guiyang city in southwestern Guizhou province, were each sentenced to five years in prison after they distributed printed materials at Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1995, calling for an early vindication of the pro-democracy movement.
The movement was labeled by the government as a counter-revolutionary rebellion, and was bloodily suppressed by army troops on June 4, 1989.
After serving their full prison terms, the two dissidents were released Monday morning.

Immediately after their release from prison, they signed and issued an open letter Monday with 12 other dissidents, urging the government to reappraise the Tiananmen incident and release all political prisoners, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan calls for cross-strait talks on the establishment of a 'Kinmen-Matsu peace zone.'
The China Times:
President Chen says the 'confederation' concept reflects new thinking and can be used to forge consensus on the future of cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
The United Daily News:
'Wealthy' elderly citizens will be denied access to the proposed NT$3,000 monthly subsidy for the elderly.
The Liberty Times:
Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan complains that senior Investigation Bureau officials are biased in selecting cases for in-depth investigations.
The China Post:
1.18 million elderly may not get pension.
The Taiwan News:
Consensus, if any, should be basis for cross-strait talks, says President Chen.
The Taipei Times:
US must prioritize peace: Veep Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 6, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1660: The Peace of Copenhagen is signed, ending a generation of war between Denmark and Sweden. The treaty delineates their borders, with Denmark regaining Fyn and Bornholm from Sweden.
1683: The Ashmolean, the first public museum, is opened in Oxford, England.
1801: The Treaty of Badajoz is signed, ending the War of the Oranges between Spain and Portugal.
1884: The Vietnamese emperor recognizes the French protectorate under the Treaty of Hue.
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58 and the republic form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1933: The first drive-in movie opens in Camden, New Jersey.
1934: The US Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of US Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1961: Carl Gustav Jung, Swiss psychiatrist and founder of analytical psychology, dies in Switzerland at the age of 85. His works include "The Psychology of the Unconscious."
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1972: An underground coal mine explosion at the Wankie colliery in Rhodesia kills 422 miners.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States, and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the world's biggest bubble blower. He blows a bubble measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit of a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in 23 years after the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The UNSC votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed on Tuesday that Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao has a plan to visit the Balkan state of Macedonia late this month.
The ministry was responding to a newspaper report that Tien is scheduled to arrive in Macedonia on June 20 for his first overseas trip since assuming his current post.

However, the ministry said Tien's travel plan, including the departure date and itinerary, has yet to be finalized. "When all relevant details are set, we will make a formal announcement," said a MOFA spokesman.

Diplomatic sources said Macedonian Parliamentary Speaker Savo Klimovski invited President Chen Shui-bian and Foreign Minister Tien to visit his country when he last visited Taipei in May to attend Chen's inauguration.

According to the sources, ROC Minister to Macedonia Peter Cheng can be promoted to the status of ambassador in the near future. If all goes well, the sources said Tien's Macedonia trip may take place either in late June or early July.
A report carried in Tuesday's United Daily News (UDN) quoted Macedonian sources as saying that Tien will start an official visit to Macedonia on June 20.

The report said Tien may take advantage of his visit to help pave the way for President Chen to visit Macedonia later this year. Macedonia forged formal diplomatic ties with the Republic of China in January 1999, making it the ROC's second diplomatic ally in Europe.

The UDN report said Tien is likely to visit the ROC's another European ally -- the Vatican City -- following his Macedonia trip. According to the report, Tien, a political scientist-turned-minister, has extensive connections in eastern Europe. He reportedly helped arrange for former ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu to deliver a speech in Poland two years ago.
Meanwhile, MOFA officials said Tien's planned visit to Macedonia is mainly aimed at cementing the ROC's relations with the southeastern Balkan state.

Because of Macedonia's domestic political factors, ROC Minister Peter Cheng has been unable to present his credentials to the Macedonian president. As a result, he has also not yet been formally recognized as an ambassador. The ROC government is hopeful that the "credentials" issue can be resolved as soon as possible.
The ROC has signed a cooperative agreement with Macedonia on the construction of an export processing zone (EPZ) near the Macedonian capital of Skopje to help attract Taiwan investors.
As the EPZ project has not yet received warm response from Taiwan investors, Tien is expected to tour the zone during his upcoming Macedonia visit to get first-hand information about the project.

Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew headed a delegation of senior government officials and business executives to visit Macedonia last August. During his visit, Siew held talks with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georievski and signed many bilateral cooperative accords. In addition, Siew announced 10 aid programs for helping Macedonia improve its transportation, water supply, education and social welfare services.
Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui reportedly also expressed his intention to visit Macedonia when he met Macedonian Parliamentary Speaker Klimovski in Taipei last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MOBILE PHONE COMPANY DEALT SEVERE BLOW IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Less than two weeks after the US House of Representatives voted in favor of granting permanent normal trade relations status to mainland China, a major US mobile phone carrier's grand vision of breaking into the Chinese market has been dealt a severe blow.

San Diego-based Qualcomm's grand ambition of selling its Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) technology to China's second largest mobile phone carrier was shattered when China Unicom abandoned its plans to use the US technology and decided to stick to its own third-generation standard, the Australian Financial Review reported Tuesday.
Beijing, however, had used its huge mobile phone market as a bargaining chip in its efforts to win the PNTR vote in the US House of Representatives recently.
Qualcomm's plans to sell as many as 10 million mobile phones through its CDMA technology by the end of this year has now fallen apart, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN FIRM STRIKES OIL IN GULF OF MEXICO

TEXT.P: A Canadian oil company announced Monday that it has struck oil at its deep-water Gunnison prospect in the Gulf of Mexico.
Canadian Occidental Petroleum said the 5,180-meter well on Garden Banks, located in waters 960 meters deep, encountered oil in three main zones.

The Calgary-based company's partners include Kerr-McGee Oil and Gas Corp., which is also the operator with a 50 percent interest in the project, and Cal Dive International Inc., which has a 20 percent interest.

CanadianOxy chief executive Vic Zaleschuk said that "the sands have excellent permeability and porosity, and this discovery has the potential to significantly increase our overall reserves and production from the Gulf of Mexico."

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIO AUSTRALIA EXPECTED TO CUT BROADCAST TO S.E. ASIA

TEXT.P: Radio Australia is facing the possibility of losing all of its shortwave radio coverage over most of Southeast Asia as its temporary lease of a Taiwan transmitter is set to expire in August, reported the Australian on Tuesday.

Radio Australia, an affiliate of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, closed its powerful transmitter facility in Darwin in 1997 when the Howard government reduced its annual budget, cutting its coverage from several languages, including Mandarin, to only English after the closure.
Since then, Radio Australia has had to rely on the temporarily leased Taiwan transmitter, now being operated by Merlin International, a former division of the BBC, for its short-wave broadcasts.
But the lease will expire this August and Radio Australia has been unable to find the funds to renew it, according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA NEGOTIATING WORKING HOLIDAY ARRANGEMENTS

TEXT.P: The Australian government is presently negotiating reciprocal working holiday arrangements with 16 countries, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs said.

The countries that presently have reciprocal working holiday arrangements with Australia are Canada, Ireland, Japan, Malta, the Netherlands, South Korea and the United Kingdom, with Germany to be added to the list as of the first of July.
Citizens aged between 18 and 30 of countries that have such arrangements with Australia are permitted to acquire working holiday visas that are eligible for up to twelve months.

Changes in the overall scheme by the Australian government include only allowing citizens of countries with which Australia has reciprocal arrangements to apply for working holiday visas. Previously, people from non-agreement countries could also apply.

The statement faxed to CNA said the Australian government is now committed to establishing working holiday arrangements with a range of countries and is currently in discussions with Taiwan, Italy, Spain, France, Greece, Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Israel, Cyprus, Australia, Switzerland, Finland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and the United States.
The purpose of working holiday arrangements is to help boost the number of young foreign tourists to Australia, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS TO ORGANIZE GROUP TO VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: The New Party's (NP's) Legislative Yuan caucus will organize a delegation to visit mainland China in mid-June, the pro-unification opposition party announced on Tuesday.

Feng Hu-hsiang, the NP's parliamentary whip, said the party's move was prompted by rising public concern here about whether the government should open direct "three links" and pilgrimage sailing across the Taiwan Strait.

Feng said the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) has formally invited the New Party, which controls less than 10 seats in the legislature, to send a delegation to visit the mainland.
"The NP's legislative caucus has approved the proposal," Feng said, adding this will be the first time that the New Party has organized a mainland visit in the name of its parliamentary caucus.
Feng said the delegation, to be composed of five to six NP legislators, is scheduled to leave for the mainland in mid-June for a weeklong visit.
According to Feng, the group will first visit Shanghai to meet with ARATS President Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

The NP delegation will then travel to Beijing where the group will meet with senior mainland leaders. "We are hopeful that the upcoming visit can help break the current cross-strait logjam and boost mutual reconciliation," Feng said.

He pointed out that topics to be discussed with senior mainland leaders will focus on issues related to the proposed opening of direct cross-strait "three links" -- trade, postal and transportation services, direct "mini three links" between Taiwan's frontline islands and mainland China's southeastern coastal cities, and direct sailing from Taiwan ports to Meizhou Island off mainland China's Fujian province for religious pilgrimage.

Prior to its departure for the mainland, Feng said, the NP delegation will pay visits to Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Wang's Taiwan counterpart, and Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials to gain a better understanding of the Republic of China government's stances on all those issues.

Both SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. SEF is under the supervision of the Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

Noting that many current cross-strait issues are deadlocked over the so-called "one China" principle, Feng said he hopes the NP's upcoming mainland trip can help score a breakthrough in cross-strait ties.

Feng said cross-strait relations remain at a low ebb after the inauguration of the new ROC government. "The New Party wants to conduct dialogue with Beijing authorities to help minimize cross-strait misunderstanding," he said, adding that since resumption of cross-strait dialogue is a national consensus here, the NP delegation will convey it to top mainland leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHALE-WATCHING BECOMES MORE POPULAR IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Whale-watching in waters off Taiwan coasts has become a popular leisure activity, with the number of whale watchers forecast to reach 150,000 this year, up from last year's total of 60,000, a government official said on Sunday.

The official with the Fisheries Department under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture noted that some measures have been enforced to protect the whales' environment and to ensure the safety of the tourists.

Whale watching vessels are required to keep their speed below eight knots when they approach and depart target areas, and must further reduce their speed when the whales are within 100 meters of the ships.
Only two vessels are allowed within 50-100 meters from the whales at one time, and the watchers are required to refrain from making noise.
The whale watching season in Taiwan is from April to October. About 30 vessels are operating whale-watching cruises from several eastern ports in Taipei, Ilan, Hualien and Taitung Counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY 23% SAY TAIPEI MAYOR CAN WIN PRESIDENTIAL RACE: POLL

TEXT.P: If incumbent Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou challenges President Chen Shui-bian in the next presidential election, only 23 percent of the public believe the popular mayor would win, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

Focus Survey Research Corp. was commissioned by Taipei City Councilman Ke Ching-sheng and four of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) colleagues to conduct the June 1-2 survey, which has a margin of error of 3.1 percent. The research firm called 1,000 people, all of whom are over 20 years of age.

Ke noted that although Ma has stressed that he intends to run for reelection in the mayoral race, he has recently said that he will actively solicit support for himself to serve as a Kuomintang (KMT) Central Standing Committee member.

In view of the KMT's humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election, which left the long-ruling party in disarray, and the large defection of KMT party members to form the People First Party (PFP) led by former KMT heavyweight James Soong, Ma is very likely to represent the KMT as its candidate in the next presidential election, Ke said.

The survey showed that more women than men believe that Ma can win the next presidential election, while voters older than 60 and people who have received only elementary educations have less confidence in Ma.

Meanwhile, the survey also found that around 60 percent of Taipei residents are satisfied with the performance of Taipei City Government. The approval rating for the mayor is even higher, at 72 percent.
But only 44 percent of the residents believe that Ma will be reelected as mayor, showing that there is huge gap between his approval rating and those whose who deem he will be reelected.

The survey found that residents' satisfaction over traffic, social order, and efficiency and service were 59.9 percent, 60 percent, 60.4 percent, respectively, while disapproval ratings were 25.9 percent, 30 percent and 22.1 percent, respectively.
An analysis of similar surveys over the past 18 months shows that Ma's approval rating has climbed steadily higher, while dissatisfaction with the mayor is at its lowest point.
The survey showed that residents' satisfaction with the Taipei City Government team as a whole is less than that of the mayor. However, a well-run city cannot depend on Ma alone, Councilman Ke said.

Ke said that the approval rating for Ma has to do with his personal charisma and his clean image. However, Ma's road to reelection will he bumpy, as the political scene has changed since the March presidential election, which saw the KMT lose its five-decade grip on power to the DPP, he said. Other complications include Ma's dwindling support from the KMT, and the the formation of a powerful PFP, Ke said.

Ke concluded that if all four parties field candidates for Taipei's mayoral election, and the DPP can successfully field a capable person, the DPP will capitalize on the support given to former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the DPP, and retake the mayoral post from the KMT in next mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ASKED TO DECIDE ON DIRECT RELIGIOUS TRIP IN ONE WEEK

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) lawmakers on Tuesday criticized the government's reserved attitude toward allowing a direct religious voyage across the Taiwan Strait, asking relevant authorities to respect public opinion and make a final decision on the issue within a week.

Speaking at a public news conference, PFP legislative leader Chiu Chuang-liang said former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan and all PFP lawmakers would consider traveling on board the same ship with followers of Matsu to worship the sea goddess in her birthplace of Meizhou, in mainland China's Fujian province, if the government does not change its stance toward the issue.

Yen Ching-piao, chairman of Chenglan Temple in central Taiwan's Taichung county, has decided to embark on July 16 on a pilgrimage to Meizhou, an islet of Fujian province, which lies directly opposite Taiwan. Thousands of local Matsu followers are expected to take part in the annual event.

PFP Lawmaker Shen Chih-hui called on President Chen Shui-bian not to break his campaign promise of permitting the "three direct links" between Taiwan and mainland China, and further urged Chen to "never break his promises to Matsu."

Stressing that both the motive and purpose behind the religious trip are simple, Shen said the government should allow such a positive cross-strait cultural exchange amid strained relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP legislative spokesman, also blasted the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the highest government agency in charge of drawing up Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, for its reservation on the issue.
He said the MAC has only found fault with some small issues, and voiced his suspicion that MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is seeking to pass the buck to Chen.

Liu said the government's insistence on first opening the "mini three links," before allowing the full "direct three links" and than direct religious links does not help resolve practical problems arising from current bilateral exchanges.
Although the public has long demanded that the government permit direct cross-strait religious voyages, Liu said the government has failed to convene a task force meeting to discuss the issue.
As the July 16 scheduled embarkation by Chenglan Temple worshipers is approaching quickly, Lin urged the government to give the pilgrims a clear answer as soon as possible.
Meanwhile, Yen said religious faith has nothing to do with politics, and called on the government to allow them to conduct a direct religious voyage to Meizhou.

But if the government refuses to do so, Yen said he and Chenglan Temple followers will have to carry out the trip via a third country. "Chenglan Temple will not lead the pilgrims to embark on the trip in violation of government laws," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC CATTLE TEST NEGATIVE ON MAD COW DISEASE

TEXT.P: Forty-two domestic cows turned up negative on tests conducted by the Council of Agriculture (COA) this year to detect the mad cow disease, a brain-wasting cattle disease that has swept through Europe in recent years.

A COA official said that domestic cows can be infected through imported bonemeal or feed additives that they consume. To prevent bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, from contaminating the domestic beef supply, the COA will continue to conduct spot checks using the latest techniques, he added.

BSE has been reported in Britain, Ireland, France, Switzerland, Portugal, Holland, Belgium, Luxemberg, and Lichtenstein over the past few years. Another case surfaced in Denmark in February. Experts believe that its human form, a variant of Creutzefeldt-Jakob disease, can be contracted by eating contaminated beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DENIES REPORTS ON TSAI'S US VISIT

TEXT.P: An aide of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on Tuesday categorically denied news reports that Tsai will visit the United States on June 13.
The MAC officials said that the reports were completely without grounds.

Local mass media reported recently that the MAC chairwoman, accompanied by officials from the MAC and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), would visit the United States in mid-June to call on Richard Bush, board chairman of the American Institute of Taiwan (AIT), as well as think tanks and scholars, to brief them on the new government's cross-strait policy.
The reports also said that the group had not ruled out a coincidental meeting of U.S. officials in Washington D.C.
In responding to a CNA inquiry, the aide stressed that Tsai has no plan to visit the United States in June.

The MAC chief is said to be busy preparing her reports on the "mini three links" issue between the offshore islands Kinmen and Matzu and coastal cities of mainland China, which she will present to the Legislative Yuan for interpellation.
Tsai is also expected to make an important announcement on the "mini three links" issue at the Legislative Yuan, as she had previously visited Kinmen and Matzu.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE HITS NORTHEASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.8 on the Richter Scale hit northeastern Taiwan's Ilan county on Tuesday. No casualties or property damages were reported, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
The CWB said that the quake was centered 33.6 kms south of Ilan City, and occurred at 9:49 a.m. on Tuesday.

The quake shook the nearby town of Nanao with a Richter scale force of 4. Residents of Ilan City, as well as Sankuang township in Taoyuan county, also felt the quake, which shook those areas with a force of 2 on the Richter scale. The quake was also felt in Taipei, as well as Hualien on Taiwan's east coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI 3 LINKS' SHOULD SERVE POLITICAL PURPOSE: ACTING KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Acting Chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Lien Chan said that the "mini three links" between Taiwan-controlled outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.

Lien said the links should not be a unilateral goodwill gesture of the new government, but should serve the political purpose of establishing peace zones in Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu Islands, and Fujian province in the mainland.
Lien made the remarks when he met with nine KMT legislators to exchange views on cross-strait relations and party affairs on Monday.

Lien said that the opening of the "mini three links" could not consider only economic factors, or only be a mechanism to bring the current clandestine trade between Taiwan's outlying islands and Fujian province into the open.

He said that through the process of negotiation, peace zones could be established in Kinmen, Matsu and Fujian province, adding that he first broached the idea when he spoke on cross-strait policy during the presidential campaign.

He reiterated that the KMT's policy toward three links -- direct trade, postal and transport links -- is clear, saying that a good chance to establish the links will emerge after both sides join the World Trade Organization.

Asked if he is willing to visit mainland China in his capacity as KMT party chairman, Lien said that his answer would depend on the development of cross-strait relations. He said that if his visit to the mainland would contribute to the welfare of the 23 million people in Taiwan, he is willing to consider going; but he is not considering it now.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD DATA TECHNOLOGY CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The World Conference on Data Science and Technology will be held in Taipei from June 11 to 14, with more than 1,000 participants coming from 46 countries.
An organizer said on Sunday that the conference is scheduled to coincide with the 2000 Taipei International Computer Exhibition.
Among the world data industry leaders invited to the event are Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates and Cisco President John Chambers.

Both Gates and Chambers will speak before the conference on June 13 and attend press conference respectively. They will also meet with leaders from the government and the local information technology industry during their short stay.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will throw a welcoming party for conference participants on the evening of June 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPUTEX ATTRACTS SOME 10,OOO BUYERS ON OPENING DAY

TEXT.P: Almost 10,000 buyers poured into the Taipei International Computer Show, also known as Computex Taipei, which opened at the Taipei World Trade Center on Monday, creating a record for the first day attendance at the exposition, an official of China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said on Tuesday.
Foreign buyers accounted for 7,000 of the total, an indication that Computex Taipei has caught the eyes of information technology (IT) industry leaders around the world, the CETRA official said.
He said that a total of 9,801 buyers, including 7,011 foreign buyers, visited the exhibition ground on Monday, the first day of opening.
Foreign buyers came chiefly from the United States, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Singapore.
More than 1,000 computer manufacturers and traders are taking part in the exhibition, which marks the 20th anniversary of the exhibition.

Due to the rapid development in Taiwan's IT industry, more and more IT makers join the exhibition every year, making the Computex Taipei one of the three most important IT shows in the world, after exhibitions in Hannover, Germany and Las Vegas, USA.
Foreign buyers attending the show's opening day this year increased by 72 percent over last year's show, which attracted only 4,077 foreign buyers, the official said.
He said that the June 5 to 9 show is expected to attract more than 20,000 buyers from abroad and at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELIGIOUS GROUPS SHOULD NOT PUSH FOR DIRECT SAILING IN NAME OF GOD
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, June 6 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said on Tuesday that local religious groups should not pressure the government to open direct sailing across the Taiwan Strait for pilgrims in the name of any deity at the moment.

Lu was commenting on a central Taiwan Taoist temple's plan to lease a ship to transport pilgrims directly from Taiwan to a mainland China-controlled islet to pay tribute to Matsu, the Chinese Goddess of Sea, in July.

Lu said after attending the opening ceremony for a Dragon Boat race in Tayuan in the northern Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, that improving relations with mainland China is the new ROC government's established policy and goal.

Nevertheless, Lu said, as Beijing remains hostile toward Taiwan and has not made any goodwill response to President Chen Shui-bian's olive branch, local religious groups should not pressure the government to lift its ban on direct cross-strait shipping services in the name of the wish of the goddess right now.

Lu, who quit the post of Taoyuan County magistrate just before assuming the vice presidency on May 20, further said national security should always be the top concern in mulling issues related to cross-strait engagement.
Lu also said she thinks the time is still not ripe to consider direct shipping link issues in view of Beijing's continued saber-rattling against Taiwan.

There have been calls in local society for opening direct "three links" -- trade, mail and transportation -- with the mainland. The Legislative Yuan even passed a bill on opening direct "mini three links" between several of Taiwan's outlying islands, such as offshore Penghu County and frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China's southeastern coastal cities.
