In anticipation of the government's approval of the opening of direct "mini three links" in the near future, the Chenlan Temple in the central county of Taichung announced a plan on Sunday to lease a foreign vessel to transport local Matsu followers directly from Taichung Harbor to Meizhou, a small islet off mainland China's southeastern province of Fujian, on July 16.

Commenting on the debate about whether the government should open direct cross-strait pilgrimage sailing, direct "mini three links" or overall direct "three links" in the near future, Lu said as national security and interests are at stake in opening such links, the government should make a comprehensive evaluation and careful planning before making a final decision.

Moreover, Lu said, negotiations with the mainland are needed to resolve some technical issues. As Beijing remains reluctant to resume cross-strait dialogue, Lu said she does not think that a breakthrough to the direct shipping link issue can be achieved any time soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER ASKS INVESTIGATION BUREAU TO PLAY ITS ROLE

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Tuesday said that he has a simple request for the Investigation Bureau -- that the bureau play its "judicial police" role and follow the directions of public prosecutors when handling cases.

Chen expressed on Monday that he felt "powerless" when dealing with the bureau, which is a part of his ministry. He also criticized the bureau for its lack of impartiality in choosing which cases to follow up on.
Chen added on Tuesday that he was not trying to adversely affect the investigators' morale, but merely hoped to improve the situation by bringing the problems out into the open.

Chen said that he was reflecting the concerns of some prosecutors and investigators, who told him that sometimes prosecutors have trouble directing investigators, and investigators have trouble getting responses from their superiors on certain cases.

Investigation Bureau rules require that cases be submitted and approved before moving ahead with the investigations, a system that bureau officials said was designed to protect human rights by first determining the strength of evidence and whether the cases fell under the bureau's jurisdiction.

However, Chen said that many cases ended up at a dead-end because of the system. In fact, no one in the bureau has the legal authority to decide what can or cannot be investigated as long as they have a lead on any possible criminal activities, he said. He added that only prosecutors have the authority to determine whether to follow up on cases after preliminary investigations have been conducted.

Chen said that his ministry and the Investigation Bureau should start by coming up with a common ground to prepare for future cooperative efforts against corruption and "black gold" politics. He added that it is not yet time to name a new bureau director, and that he will continue to observe the situation for a period of time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSES NO INTELLIGENCE THREAT TO US: ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C., June 6 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China Representative in the United States Stephen Chen on Tuesday categorically denied a May 24 Washington Post report that Taiwan poses an intelligence threat to the United States.

In an open letter published in the newspaper, Chen said that he was dismayed to learn that the US Department of Justice has included Taiwan on a list of "countries that pose a threat" to US national security.

"As my country's principal representative in the United States, I would like to make it perfectly clear that no personnel or offices stationed by my government in this country have ever engaged in any intelligence activities that were illegal or posed a threat to the United States," Chen said.

"We would never knowingly jeopardize our close and friendly relationship with the United States. Two-way trade between both countries totaled US$50.6 billion last year, and there are significant exchanges between the two countries in the fields of culture, science, education and tourism," Chen said.
"As a full-fledged democracy, we share with the United States a common commitment to preserving peace and stability in Asia," he pointed out.

He further said that the ill-advised decision to include Taiwan on the list is most regrettable. "Ta-wei Lee, my country's vice minister of foreign affairs, has expressed our serious concern to Raymond Burghart, the director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT)'s Taipei Office, and we have asked for an explanation from the relevant US authorities," Chen noted.

"In the meantime, however, I would like to assure all of our many friends and supporters in the United States that the 23 million people of the Republic of China on Taiwan cherish the traditional ties of friendship between our two peoples, and we are eager to continue working with the United States to usher in a new era of peace and prosperity in the coming century," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US THINK TANK HOLDS CONFERENCE ON TAIWAN'S PROSPECTS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 5 (CNA) (By Shu Lu-sheng & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The RAND Center for Asia-Pacific Policy on Monday sponsored a conference titled "Taiwan Enters a New Era: Prospects and Implications" in Santa Monica, California.

Taiwan's Government Information Office Deputy Director-General Frederic Chang delivered a speech at the event in which he said that new Taiwan administration inaugurated on May 20 is heading into the new century with confidence.

He described the recent democratic and peaceful transfer of power to the administration led by Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party as one of the most significant political developments in Asia.
Chang noted that the election was an expression of confidence that the Taiwanese can find ways to resolve the long-standing impediments to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

The GIO official said that the new government hopes to see an early resumption of cross-strait dialogue between mainland China and Taiwan, and added that the new government's domestic priority is to crack down on "black gold" and corruption in politics.

The main topics of the conference were interpreting the electoral outcome in Taiwan, the future of Taiwan's political and economic structure, cross-strait relations, and US-mainland China relations: Congress and Taiwan.

Former US Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for East Asia Kurt Campbell told the conference that it remains possible for mainland China to invade Taiwan by force, although most people consider the possibility as remote.
Campbell said that the Taiwan Strait is still filled with crisis, and added that its development is not so optimistic as many people have thought.
He said that cases of miscalculation between Beijing and Taipei are likely to grow as the two authorities do not understand each other well, leading to an unstable cross-strait situation.
Campbell suggested that the United States intervene positively in Asia-Pacific affairs so as to create a more stable environment for a resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
Meanwhile, RAND Corporation senior advisor Jonathan Pollack described Taiwan as a unique political laboratory.
He pointed out that the largest challenge to Taiwan's new president is how he will deal with the pressure against Taiwan from the Beijing government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR TEAM SPIRIT TO BOOST NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, June 6 (CNA) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday called on all people around Taiwan, regardless of their party affiliations and ethnic origins, to stand united to work for national development and progress.
Chen made the appeal while attending the opening ceremony of a Dragon Boat race in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan in celebration of the Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on Tuesday this year.
Chen, the Republic of China's first opposition leader-turned-president, said operating a Dragon Boat needs coordination and cooperation of all team members.

"Carrying out national development projects is like operating a Dragon Boat and cannot rely on individual efforts," Chen noted, adding that he hopes local people can draw inspirations from Dragon Boat races and work hand-in-hand to upgrade national competitiveness.

"So long as we all stand up, Taiwan will stand up. Let us work together and make concerted efforts to create a bright future for our country," Chen told a huge crowd of local residents who turned out to greet the president and watched the annual Dragon Boat race.

Similar Dragon Boat races were held in many other cities and counties around the island as a major activity celebrating the Dragon Boat Festival, one of the three most important festivals in Chinese society.

The festival, which falls on the fifth day of the fifth moon on the lunar calendar, commemorates Chu Yuan (343-290 B.C.), a patriot poet who drowned himself in a river in an attempt to inspire the government at that time to launch reforms. Eating Tzungtzu, or rice dumplings, is another popular custom in celebration of the festival. (By Sofia Wu) ENDIEM ZCZC CEP023 06-06-00 NATIONAL SECURITY TAX PLAN NOT WORTH TRYING: KMT AIDE

Taipei, June 6 (CNA) Amid hot debate over whether the government should levy a "national security tax" on mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen, a raking Kuomintang official said on Tuesday that the proposed measure is neither praiseworthy nor workable.

Hailing the country's top economic planner for his outright opposition to the proposal, Chang Jung-kong, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, stressed that the measure is not worth trying and represents a form of political discrimination against Taiwan businessmen with operations in the mainland.

He said that the KMT will continue to remain highly concerned over the issue as part of its efforts to help protect the interests of Taiwan investors, and because the disputed plan goes against a promise made by the present Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led administration that it will ease restrictions on mainland-bound investment by Taiwan companies.

Pointing out that the "national security tax" plan is not the correct and feasible way to regulate investment by Taiwan firms in mainland China, the China expert stressed that it will only create a heavier legal burden on Taiwan businesspeople in the mainland while encouraging local investors to use illegal means to conduct investment on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.
What is worse, Chang claimed, is that the motive behind the plan is to create political discrimination against Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland, which he said is not laudable at all.

Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih made clear on Monday at the Legislative Yuan that he is opposed to the "national security tax" plan proposed recently by S.M. Chen, vice governor-designate of the Central Bank of China.

Meanwhile, caucus members of the opposition People First Party (PFP) at the legislature strongly criticized the DPP administration's inconsistent stance on the issue, saying that rash comments by "irrelevant" Cabinet members will only mislead the public.
Lawmaker Chou Hsi-wei said skeptically that Chen raised the proposal rashly at this moment to underscore "a certain political significance."

But he added that he suspected that such an approach would only reduce the revenues for the national coffers, fuel clandestine trade and hurt Taiwan industries, an indication that the DPP has yet to adjust its mindset from that of an opposition party to a ruling party.

Chou said Taiwan businessmen in the mainland are being squeezed by the governments on both sides of the strait, as the mainland authorities have increased pressure on pro-Taiwan independence firms while Taiwan authorities are also seeking a way to tackle those firms' mainland investments.
He described local firms with mainland investments as "turning from bamboo shoots to dried bamboo."

PFP legislative speaker Liu Wen-hsiung also voiced his disagreement with the tax proposal, claiming that it will force local mainland-bound investors to invest through a third country, leading to an outflow of Taiwan capital.
He also blasted the DPP-led government for allowing any and all Cabinet members to comment on the issue as they saw fit, satirically calling it a "ringer vehicle."

DOC.HEADLINE: BASEBALL COACH STRUCK BY LIGHTNING

TEXT.P: The chief coach of the Taiwan Professional Baseball League, Chao Hsi-chiang, was struck by lightning on Tuesday, but was declared out of danger after being rushed to hospital for treatment.

Chao was struck as he walked along a covered passageway of the Hsinchuang baseball stadium in suburban Taipei, where a game between Taipei and Taichung teams had been temporarily stopped because of heavy rain.

He was able to return to the stadium after receiving treatment for burns to his left hand, but the doctor who treated Chao said he had damaged a nerve in his middle finger and would need six months to recover fully.

Market turnover amounted to NT$148.05 billion (US$4.82 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 7, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1329: Robert I, king of Scotland known as "Robert the Bruce," dies at the age of 55. He defeated Edward I of England, crowned himself king and went on to win Scottish independence from England in the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314.
1712: Philadelphia bans the import of slaves.
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1916: Li Yuan-hung becomes president of the Peking (Beijing) government, after Yuan Shih-kai's death due to illness the previous day.
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1937: Hollywood star Jean Harlow, the original platinum blonde, dies of cerebral edema at the age of 26.
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into the US to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1973: General John D. Ruan, chief of staff of the US Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: The first Sino-Korean Cement Manufacturers Amity Conference is opened in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two US combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1977: Street parties are held all over Britain to celebrate Queen Elizabeth's silver jubilee.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law in its third reading, putting the manufacture, possession, or use of firearms and other weapons under tighter control. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1988: Bangladesh makes Islam its state religion.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: More than 96 percent of Indonesians voters turn out to vote in democratic elections for the first time since 1955.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON TO SEND CABINET OFFICIAL TO TAIPEI FOR CONFAB
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton will dispatch a Cabinet official to Taipei to attend the upcoming joint meeting of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and the ROC-US Business Council, sources at the White House said on Tuesday.

P.J. Crowley, spokesman for the White House National Security Council, in response to a question from the CNA, said the Clinton administration will make a final decision on the Cabinet official within days and will probably announce the name of the official on Friday.

Crowley also said that sending a Cabinet member to Taiwan will not be affected by the Senate vote on granting permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status to China. "No, it will not be affected," he replied when he was asked by the CNA about the impact of the upcoming PNTR vote in the Senate.

Meanwhile, Rupert J. Hammond-Chambers, acting president of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, said that "we expect the US delegation to be led by a Cabinet member as has been the case in the past."
"We believe a strong US delegation will send a strong message concerning how the US views its business relations with Taiwan, particularly after a new government was inaugurated there," Rupert added.

In addition to the Cabinet member, other members of the US delegation to the joint meeting scheduled for June 14-15 in Taipei will include Phil Agrass, a deputy assistant secretary of the US Department of Commerce, customs officials from the Department of the Treasury, and other officials from the Department of State, said White House sources.

Raymond Burghardt, director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office and the de facto US ambassador to Taipei, will also attend the annual meeting as head of the US delegation, which will be comprised of several hundred other delegates from the private industrial and business sectors.

Newly-installed Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a speech to open the meeting, whose theme this year will be Taiwan's high-technology development and related business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 157.26 points to close at 9,115.47.
Encouraged by a big hike in electronics share prices, the bourse opened at 8,943.63 and fluctuated between 9,116.24 and 8,943.63 during trading.

A total of 2.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$148.05 billion (US$4.82 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.61 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$88.86 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 273 to 256, with 71 stocks remaining unchanged.

Six of the eight major categories lost ground, with construction stocks and textile issues moving down the most, both at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3.2 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index Futures for July increased 161 points to finish at 9,211, with 139 contract transactions, while September futures moved up 140 points to close at 9,300, with nine contract transactions.
December futures gained 137 points to close at 9,311, with five contract transactions, while next March futures surged 249 points to finish at 9,520, with one contract transaction.

Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO BE A `RESPONSIBLE GREAT NATION'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Wednesday that Taiwan and the United States must cooperate to assist mainland China in becoming a "great nation" that is not only willing, but also capable of fulfilling its responsibilities.

Addressing the opening of the Seventh Taipei Roundtable, Chen said that "great power" status is not illustrated by the active expansion of a country's military capabilities or by its military threats against smaller nations.

As a great nation, Chen noted, mainland China should understand its responsibilities as a leader in the Asia Pacific region, rather than attempting to achieve "great nation diplomacy" by suppressing Taiwan in the international arena and creating tension in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen said that it is worth questioning whether or not mainland China understands the international, political, military and economic responsibilities a great nation must shoulder, as the nations of the world attach great expectations to the status of mainland China as a great nation.
Even if mainland China understands the responsibilities of a great nation, does it have the capabilities to shoulder such responsibilities? Chen asked.

The Seventh Taipei Roundtable, co-sponsored by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington-based think tank, and Chinatrust Commercial Bank, kicked off on Wednesday. The theme of the roundtable this time is the challenges of the new millennium.

In his speech, Chen said that while the international community expresses a common concern for "collective security," Taiwan still faces the threat of potential regional conflicts initiated by individual rogue states.

Stressing that Taiwan's role in the new century cannot be ignored, Chen said the new ROC government is willing and capable of preserving peace in the region, and the new government has the sincerity and goodwill to initiate the comprehensive normalization of relations with mainland China.

Chen said Taiwan's political democracy is conducive to helping mainland China learn to shoulder its responsibilities as a great nation. Positive cross-strait economic interaction has constructive effects for the globalization and liberalization of mainland China's economy and for the healthy development of a global trade system, he added.
"The avoidance of conflict and the maintenance of peace in the Taiwan Strait form the cornerstone to realizing stability and prosperity in the Asia Pacific region in the 21st century," he continued.

Chen reiterated that the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait must respect the free choice of the people. In other words, he said, the people of Taiwan have the ultimate right to determine their future. Even US President Bill Clinton supports the notion that the resolution of cross-strait issues must "have the consent of the people of Taiwan." President Clinton's words are a demonstration of a great nation's stature, he added.

Meanwhile, he noted that the long-term friendship between Taiwan and the United States is based on the two countries' common interests of democracy, security, and trade. In the process of American engagement with China, the US has an obligation to enable mainland China to understand the responsibilities of a great nation, he added.

Taiwan and the US must cooperate to assist mainland China in becoming a great nation that is not only willing, but also capable of fulfilling its responsibilities, he reiterated, adding that only then will the Taiwan-US relationship be solidified and uninhibited by the potentially destabilizing "China factor."

Finally, Chen noted that a new government took power in Taiwan on May 20, adding that the US and China will also have new leadership within two years. These changes will generate great challenges, he said.

"I personally believe that only with greater wisdom, creativity, and patience, with full appreciation of the meaning of `rights' and `responsibilities,' can we overcome the serious challenges of the new century," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHTY PERCENT OF AMERICANS SEE TAIWAN AS AN ALLY: POLL

TEXT.P: Eighty percent of Americans consider Taiwan to be an ally or a friendly country, while 51 percent say that Communist China is a friend or ally of the United States, according to the latest Gallup poll results released Tuesday.

The poll, conducted May 12-21 based on telephone interviews with a random national sample of 1,011 American adults, shows that only 9 percent of the American public considers Taiwan as unfriendly, and 1 percent say Taiwan is an enemy of the United States.
But 30 percent of Americans surveyed say mainland China is unfriendly, while 13 percent consider it to be an enemy of the United States.

In a similar Gallup poll conducted in March 1996, during the missile crisis across the Taiwan Straits, 59 percent of Americans had a very or mostly favorable opinion of Taiwan, while 37 said their overall opinion of Taiwan was mostly or very unfavorable.
The same poll showed that 39 percent of Americans had a very or mostly favorable opinion of mainland China, while 51 said their overall opinion of China was mostly or very unfavorable.

A September 1979 Gallup poll found that 63 percent of Americans had a very or mostly favorably opinion of Taiwan, with only 20 percent having a mostly or very unfavorable opinion of Taiwan. Sixty-four percent of Americans at that time said that they had a very or mostly favorable opinion of China, while 25 percent had a mostly or very unfavorable opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA, ARGENTINA SEEN LESS AFFECTED BY KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: Taiwan, mainland China, and Argentina will be less affected by the Kyoto Protocol because of their diverse trade and production structure, but most developing countries will be much more affected by the emission standards, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resources Economics (ABARE).

In a statement faxed to the CNA on Thursday, ABARE Executive Director Brian Fisher said that "implementing the Kyoto Protocol would have significant but varied economic impacts on developing countries, even though they have no emissions targets under the protocol."

"The impacts occur through trade and investment linkages with developed countries, and the net economic impact on any one developing country would depend on its particular production and trade structure," he said.

"Developing countries that rely on exports of fossil fuels , such as the Middle East, Venezuela and Indonesia, face reduced export earnings and income. This is because developed countries will reduce fossil fuel consumption to meet their emission targets," Fisher continued.

"But countries that rely on exports of emission intensive goods, such as Brazil, India and South Korea, tend to benefit from improved competitiveness as a result of penalties placed on emission intensive production in developed countries," he said.
Economies with a more diverse trade and production structure, such as Argentina, Taiwan, and mainland China are projected to be relatively less affected, he pointed out.
Fisher said developing countries face up to US$7.1 billion over the next 10 years in improving their emission standards to meet the requirements of the Kyoto Protocol.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTREAL PLANNING TECHNODOME TO ATTRACT VISITORS

TEXT.P: The city of Montreal, whose Biodome has become a popular tourist attraction, is planning to build a Technodome in order to attract a wide variety of visitors.

Promoters on Tuesday said that some 6.7 million visitors would likely visit the proposed giant amusement park each year, an estimate that echoes earlier market surveys done for Heathmount Arts and Entertainment Corp. and Quebec's Societe Generale de Financement (SGF), a provincial funding agency.
Heathmount and the SGF are presently locked in a public struggle with the Port of Montreal over land for the site.
Abraham Reichmann, chief executive of Heathmount A.E., along with SGF officials, used the results of the new survey to make a pitch to local business leaders.
The backers revealed the names of 40 prominent Quebecers who have thrown their support behind the C$1.04-billion project.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC ORGANIZERS FACING FINANCIAL SHORTFALL, UNSOLD TICKETS

TEXT.P: The final countdown is only 100 days away, but Australian organizers of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games are facing a financial shortfall of US$100 million as about 2.5 million tickets remain unsold.

Organizers told reporters that they still need about US$100 million to meet their budget and have found it difficult to sell the remaining 2.5 million tickets, most of which are to less popular events.
David Richmond, the director-general of the Olympic Coordination Authority, said the organizers face a huge challenge in selling the large number of remaining tickets.

Even with some further overseas sales, organizers will still face a serious revenue shortfall unless they can move large numbers of tickets for less attractive sports when they begin live telephone sales on Sunday, said Richmond.
He blamed part of the difficulty in selling the tickets to the relatively small population of Australia and the relatively small number of people living close enough to Sydney to attend many events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA URGED TO MOVE TOWARD COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China should stop their competition on the diplomatic front and adopt new thinking to bolster bilateral cooperation, Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Wednesday.

Fielding questions during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan on a proposal he made for a diplomatic truce between Taiwan and mainland China, Tien expressed the hope that the current situation across the Taiwan Strait will stabilize soon and enter a new era of dialogue and peace. He noted that this is also the desire of the people of Taiwan.

While calling for a truce in the diplomatic war between the two sides of the strait, Tien claimed his ministry will do its best to consolidate ties with ROC diplomatic allies and boost substantive links with other friendly countries in order to protect national dignity within the international community.

The foreign minister also confirmed reports that he is planning a trip to Macedonia and pointed out that the major purpose of his visit to the Balkan state is aimed at strengthening diplomatic relations between the two countries.

Tien's remarks came on the heels of a statement made by mainland China's Foreign Ministry on Tuesday that "there is no such problem as a `diplomatic truce' between Taiwan and mainland China under the `one China' principle."

Meanwhile, National Security Council (NSC) Vice Secretary-General Chiu I-jen told local media that the issue of a "cross-strait diplomatic truce" has been repeatedly put forward by the political and academic sectors. However, he went on, the fact remains that the matter cannot be unilaterally decided by Taiwan and will require a friendly response from mainland China. This, he said, is impossible.
Chiu made the remarks to reporters after attending a roundtable meeting in Taipei of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a US-based think tank.

Commenting on the hotly debated issue about the opening of "direct cross-strait religious links," Chiu said that it is not necessary for the NSC to coordinate the matter, as the Mainland Affairs Council, the government agency in charge of the issue, has so far handled the case quite properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESCUE TEAMS LEAVE TO AID INDONESIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan rescue team departed Taipei on Wednesday for the Indonesian island of Sumatra to help with emergency aid and search work in the wake of a devastating earthquake which struck on Sunday, according to sources from Taipei County Government.

The team, comprising five emergency aid specialists from the Taipei County Government Fire Department and one medical doctor, is the first emergency aid mission from Taiwan to conduct rescue and search work overseas.
The team took with it 640 kg of rescue and search gear, including sonar detectors, image probes, electricity generators, digging tools and satellite telephones.
In order for the team to respond as rapidly as possible, it left for Indonesia without waiting for another team from the southern county of Pingtung.
The Pingtung team, also comprising six men -- five specialists from the Pingtung Fire Department and one architect -- was scheduled to take a later flight to the stricken area.
Going with the Pingtung team will be life detectors, fiber-optic detectors and other advanced search and rescue gear.

Both the Taipei County and Pingtung emergency aid teams were established late last year after Taiwan was battered by a catastrophic 7.3-magnitude earthquake on Sept. 21, in which nearly 2,400 people were killed, some 8,400 were injured and 100,000 others were left homeless.
The teams received four weeks of intensive training in Singapore earlier this year.
Interior Minister Chang Po-ya met the team members before their departure and presented them with the national flag to signal the honor and pride of the Republic of China.
Chang said it is time for Taiwan to reciprocate for the incalculable help and assistance it received from the rest of the world after the September quake.
It is estimated that the Sumatra earthquake, measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale, has so far killed at least 117 people and injured nearly 700 others.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARIBBEAN NATIONS WORRIED ABOUT FREE TRADE EXPANSION

TEXT.P: Many of the smaller member countries of the Organization of American States (OAS) expressed their concerns Tuesday about the expansion of free trade in the region during a conference in Canada.
When Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien opened the OAS conference, he said Canada would push for a free trade deal for the Americas because it will benefit everyone in both hemispheres.

But about 10 foreign ministers from small islands in the Caribbean expressed their skepticism. Billie Miller, from Barbados, said the developing countries cannot abandon subsidies to make the transition to free trade without a great deal of pain.
"Globalization can have an early, negative impact that may well outweigh any eventual, positive outcome," he said Tuesday.
Sam Condor of St. Kitts and Nevis said that if there is going to be a free trade agreement, Caribbean countries are going to want certain exemptions to buy themselves some time.
"All we are asking is for the international community to understand that we are at a tremendous disadvantage, and we will need some concessions," said Condor.
The most dramatic attack on the pro-free trade stance of Canada and the United States came from the tiny country of Saint Lucia, which has a population of just 150,000.
Saint Lucia's Foreign Minister George Odlum said "there must be an acceptance of the principle of the redistribution of resources."
In a speech at the conference, Odlum said that in Saint Lucia, farmers are feeling more and more insecure as the United States touts the merits of globalization and free trade."
Odlum noted that both Canada and the US have reduced their foreign aid to the region while telling the poorer countries to put their faith in free trade.
He told his colleagues there should be more room, not less, for government assistance in the Americas.
The foreign ministers of several Caribbean countries said the forces of globalization don't give them many choices and they are afraid and unsure of where their nations are headed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA WAR GAMES THREATEN TAIWAN: MND

TEXT.P: The recent spate of drills and war games conducted by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is part of Beijing's scheme to intensify its military threat to Taiwan, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said on Wednesday.

Wu said that although the ROC Ministry of National Defense (MND) had not yet released any news about an imminent PLA test-firing of long-range Dongfeng-31 ballistic missiles in mainland China, he believed that the test-firing, the fifth of its kind, is designed as political posturing directed toward Taiwan.
By stepping up its military threats against Taiwan, Beijing is also attempting to persuade Taiwan into recognizing its political overtures, Wu added.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Wu admitted that the ROC Armed Forces are at present incapable of defending the island against Dongfeng-31 missiles, the most lethal nuclear-capable missiles in the mainland's arsenal and capable of reaching as far as the western United States.
The flight path of the imminent Dongfeng-31 test is reportedly to be from northern Shanxi region toward mainland China's northwestern Xinjiang region.
However, Wu said, the ROC military is now has "limited" capability of defending PLA's M-series missiles launched from the mainland.

Meanwhile, Wu, who took office on May 20 succeeding Tang Fei, who became premier, said a comprehensive reform of the national defense system is scheduled to be completed by early 2003 which will see the ROC military transformed into a leaner yet more invincible force.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT PILGRIMAGE: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of the nation's policy toward mainland China reaffirmed on Wednesday that there is no timetable for direct pilgrimages to the mainland.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that the matter is still being assessed, but she added that the MAC is willing to mull the plan in a positive manner.

Tsai made the remarks during a seminar when she met with Taiwan business leaders investing in the mainland and noted that a number of temples, including Chenlan Temple in Tachia, Taichung County, have filed applications with the MAC for direct sailings across the Taiwan Strait to allow devotees of the goddess Matsu to make pilgrimages to her traditional home in Meizhou, Fujian Province.
At present, such pilgrimages must take a route through a third country or area, as direct cross-strait travel is prohibited.
Tsai said that the MAC must make an overall assessment to gauge the effect of granting the request on the country's mainland policy as a whole, especially with regard to national security.

The Chenlan temple plans to lease a Singaporean passenger ship to directly transport pilgrims to Meizhou from Taichung Harbor, making a stopover either at the Taiwan-controlled frontline island of Kinmen or the offshore county of Penghu.
Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao announced on Sunday that the temple has tentatively decided to start the pilgrimage on July 16.

However, Tsai urged patience, and stressed that the government has employed "rational thinking" in weighing the policy. She added that the overall security of the nation must take priority over religious voyages.

Chenlan temple is organizing 6,000 pilgrims to make the voyage, but there are worries that mainland Chinese would be able to infiltrate the group on its return to Taiwan after the pilgrimage and enter the country illegally.

Tsai said that she was happy with Yen's assurance that he will respect ROC law, adding that as he is concurrently Taichung County speaker, he should know that he has influence over local followers and the political environment, and that he should serve as a law-abiding role model. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP018 06-07-00 NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET
Taipei, June 7 (CNA) The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.001 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$30.791.
The local currency opened at NT$30.767 and was traded between NT$30.757 and NT$30.830.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$553 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WOULD SHOW CONCERN OVER MAINLAND MILITARY ACTION AGAINST ROC

TEXT.P: If mainland China were to decide to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait problems by military action, the United States would show its grave concern, as it did in 1996, a US military expert said here on Wednesday.

John, J. Hamre, president of the US-based think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), stressed that the United States will never accept a unilateral decision by the Chinese communists to use military force against Taiwan, as US public opinion always supports a peaceful resolution of the dispute between Taiwan and mainland China.

Hamre made the remarks in a speech delivered at the seventh roundtable meeting jointly sponsored by CSIS and Chinatrust Commercial Bank in Taipei. President Chen Shui-bian and Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao also addressed the gathering.

Since the United States has always urged Taiwan and mainland China to resolve their problems peacefully, it is also very aware that so long as either side harbors hostility toward the other, the two sides will not be able to sit down and talk through their disputes, Hamre said.

As to the question of whether "US concern" means that Washington may play the role of mediator in cross-strait negotiations, Hamre, who once served as US vice secretary of defense, said that he knows Taiwan has high expectations of such a possibility, but added that he was not sure whether it would be appropriate or workable.
"After all, Taiwan and mainland China should try to resolve their problems on their own," he emphasized.

Describing President Chen as very cautious in choosing his words when addressing cross-strait affairs, Hamre gave high praise to Taiwan's new president for his rational attitude toward the mainland -- that Taiwan will not intentionally provoke mainland China, while the mainland should also adopt peaceful means to mend bilateral differences.

Hamre further pointed out that Washington would be glad to see Taipei and Beijing set up active dialogue channels as long as Taiwan does not provoke the mainland, a point which he said the Taiwan people must understand.

In response to a question raised by a participant at the meeting on what the United States would do if Taiwan decided to change the status-quo regarding the unification-independence issue, Hamre said only that the United States should gain a deeper understanding of Taiwan than it has in the past. He noted that democracy has come of age in Taiwan, as it has in the United States, and described this as an encouraging phenomenon.

As to a question from ROC National Security Council Vice Secretary-General Chiu I-jen about the significance of the establishment of a strategic partnership between the United States and mainland China, Hamre called the name of the relationship a "label," and claimed that such ties do not reflect substantive relations between the two sides.
Judging from past US experience, he contended that the United States is not expected to build a warm relationship with the mainland solely on the basis of such a concept.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY EYEING TAIWAN BEEF MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, June 7 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Paraguayan company is considering shipping "three to four cartons" of frozen beef to Taiwan by air in an attempt to crack the island's growing red meat market, business sources in the Paraguayan capital said on Wednesday.

Arsenio Vasconsellos, a manager of a Paraguayan refrigeration company, said that the first batch of three to four cartons of frozen beef would go on trial sale to sound out how Taiwan consumers like the beef from far-away Paraguay.
If the Taiwan market is cracked, Vasconsellos said, future deliveries will be shipped by sea, a journey of about two months.

Last year, the ROC government granted Paraguay the right to export 222 metric tons of frozen beef to Taiwan as part of the island's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO). Until recently, however, no local importers have shown much interest in Paraguayan beef.

Meanwhile, the government turned down an appeal by Paraguay's agriculture and meat exporters to lift import tariffs on Paraguayan beef, saying that a tariff exemption for Paraguay would run counter to the WTO spirit of free and equal trade opportunities for all countries.
Taiwan imports about 50,000 metric tons of beef annually, about the amount of Paraguay's total annual beef exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE RAPE VICTIMS IN INDONESIA STILL TRAUMATIZED

TEXT.P: Many ethnic Chinese women who were abused and raped during the Indonesian riots of 1998 still have not recovered from their traumatic experiences, several local private groups said on Wednesday.

The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, The Garden of Hope, End Child Prostitution and the Chinese Association for Human Rights said that some victims have isolated themselves from the outside world and have refused psychological counseling.

As the groups jointly donated NT$260,000 collected over two years to World Vision to finance the next two years of the rehabilitation project, they said they hope that they can help the women come out of the shadow of their nightmarish experience.

Fu Shu-chi, vice executive director of World Vision of Taiwan, said that of the 168 known cases, only around 70 have solicited treatment. Many of the women, confined by their traditional concept of chastity, have refused contact and isolated themselves, he said, adding that it is this self-imposed isolation which most worries social workers.

According to the World Vision of Indonesia, the age of the victims ranges from months-old babies to people over the age of 90, some of the victims have tried to commit suicide, while others have been unable to overcome the fear of being alone and lead a normal life.

Fu said that most of those now receiving treatment are middle-aged women, and that most of them solicited psychological therapy after encouragement from their families, showing the attitude of the family is crucial.

Lawyer Wang Ching-feng, who organized group visits to Indonesia to lend support to abused ethnic Chinese in the wake of the May 1998 riots which saw the ouster of Indonesian President Suharto, urged Indonesia not to try to cover up the victims. He added that the situation which led to ethnic Chinese being used as scapegoats must change, and said that "ethnic integration and harmony" would be the best way to solve the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC MEETING SUPPORTS WTO ENTRY FOR TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Darwin, Australia, June 7 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Trade Ministers' Meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on Wednesday called for the early entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

A meeting of senior APEC officials that was held on Tuesday worked out a report to call on WTO members to support the early WTO admission for Taiwan and mainland China, and the report was submitted to the APEC Trade Minister Meeting for approval.

It was agreed at the meeting that a new round of talks will require a balanced agenda that is sufficiently broad-based to respond to the interests of all WTO members. Particular attention should be given to the needs of developing and the least-developed economies.
It was also agreed at the meeting that successful talks will require political will and flexibility from all participants, together with adequate preparatory work.
Concerning Taiwan's WTO entry, the meeting reached a consensus that the participants "support the rapid accession to the WTO for Chinese Taipei."
E-commerce and biochemical technology issues were also discussed at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION ARRIVES IN TOKYO FOR LATE JAPANESE PM'S FUNERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 7 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A three-member Republic of China mission arrived in Tokyo on Wednesday to attend the funeral service for late Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi scheduled to be held on Thursday.
The ROC mission comprised Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and presidential senior advisers Koo Chen-fu and Peng Ming-min.

On hand at the airport to greet them were Lo Fu-chen, ROC representative in Japan, and Toshio Goto, board chairman of the Interchange Association, a semi-official organization set up to take care of the interests of Japanese people in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between Taipei and Tokyo.
During their stay in Tokyo, the delegates will also call on Sadanori Yamanaka, board chairman of the Japan-ROC Dietmens Council, and other Japanese civic leaders.
Delegations from more than 100 countries and regions around the world will attend the funeral service to bid farewell to Obuchi, who died on May 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY SEEN AS BRIDGE FOR CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: US THINK TANK
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, June 6 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Democratic development in Taiwan was the focus of a seminar sponsored on Tuesday by the Los Angeles-based think tank the Claremont Institute.

Scholars from Taiwan and the United States held extensive discussions on how to establish a "channel of peace" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait at the seminar titled "Democracy: the Bridge between Mainland China and Taiwan."
Institute Director Thomas Silver said that the seminar aimed to spread the democratic system practiced in the United States and Taiwan to mainland China, and to influence the people of the mainland.
Richard Baum of the University of California at Los Angeles said that helping the democratization of the mainland will be crucial to easing the tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Baum also said that Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization will help it integrate with world trends and will contribute to the establishment of a "bridge of cross-strait peace."

Bruce Herchenshoh, a distinguished fellow of the institute, said that he cannot agree with mainland China's "one China" policy, and that he is strongly opposed to Taiwan being a part of China unless Beijing starts practicing democratic politics.

He added that he is also strongly opposed to the "one China" policy espoused by the United States, saying that Washington focuses too much on prying open the mainland China market, and forsakes its requests for democratic development in the mainland. He added that this is an "unwise" approach.
He also predicted that after US presidential election in November, there will not be many changes to Washington's current "one China" policy.

The scholars from Taiwan, including He Szu-yin, director of the Institute for International Relations at National Chengchi University, Chao Chien-ming, director of the Sun Yat-sen Graduate Institute of Social Science and Humanities at the same university expressed "cautious" views about the progress of democratization in the mainland and elaborated on the stages and achievement of Taiwan's democratic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FIFTH-BEST PLACE IN WORLD FOR INVESTMENT: SWISS FIRM

TEXT.P: Taiwan was ranked as the fifth-best place for investment among fifty countries surveyed by a Swiss consultancy firm, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) disclosed on Wednesday.

Quoting the results of a survey conducted by the Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI), MOEA said Taiwan scored 72 points, tied for fifth place with the United States behind Switzerland, Singapore, the Netherlands and Japan.
The Business Risk Service issued by BERI for June gives Taiwan "1B," or "good" status in terms of its profit-making chances for investors.

Taiwan also ranked the second-best country in Asia, next only to Singapore, but far ahead of Japan which landed in 14th place. Mainland China and South Korea were tied in 26th position, and Thailand ranked 28th.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves ranked second among the fifty countries surveyed and its ability to pay with foreign exchange listed third. However, its political risk was relatively higher, ranking 16th, mainly because of its volatile ties with Beijing, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK URGES TAIWAN POLITICAL PARTIES TO FORGE CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: A China expert and member of a Washington think tank on Wednesday urged Taiwan's political parties to begin forging consensus or risk allowing divisiveness to undermine cross-strait relations.

"It is time to cheer for the home team together," said Gerrit W. Gong, Asia program director and Freeman Chair in China studies for the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), at a symposium in Taipei.

Sponsored by Chinatrust Commercial Bank and the CSIS, the CSIS Taipei Roundtable 2000 titled "The Challenges in the New Millenium" is the seventh of such meetings of US and local experts held in Taipei. The scholars and policy-makers met to exchange their views on a broad range of political and economic issues.
Gong, a Rhodes Scholar and third-generation Chinese American, noted that Beijing encourages political infighting in Taipei, but that Washington hopes to see consensus.

Gong suggested that Taipei send delegations to Washington over the next several months, not only to achieve some consensus among US and ROC lawmakers, but also to work out agreements among the various political parties in Taiwan.

Lo Chih-cheng, a domestic political science scholar and director of programs at the Institute for National Policy Research (INPR), a local think tank, also expressed concern that there's a lack of domestic consensus, as well as too many "misperceptions" and a lot of "misinformation" in Beijing.

Lo said that the "best strategy" for the government is to steer clear of trouble in the Taiwan Strait. Lo suggested that Chen should first focus on domestic issues to build up national consensus, which has been lacking -- particularly in mainland Chinese affairs.

This divisiveness is only aggravated by the fact that Chen lacks a strong public mandate, he said. Chen garnered only 39 percent of the popular vote in the March 18 election that propelled him and his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) into power.

However, Lo said that the new government now appears to feel more confident, and perhaps is secure enough to come to the negotiating table. Whereas previously the DPP's only proposed solution to cross-strait issues was independence, it has no such predisposition now that it holds power, and has embraced a willingness to discuss "three links" and a possible "future one China," he said.
Lo urged the United States to "encourage" mainland China to come to the table as well, adding that more dialogues without preconditions will add to the chance for peace and stability.
Commenting on Chen's stance on mainland Chinese issues, Gong said that it will be "interesting" to watch Chen's attempts to avoid provocation and yet not to appear weak.

Gong also claimed that the greatest challenge to the island may be cyber-security, adding that Taiwan has to defend against possible invisible attacks from parties who try to sniff out weaknesses in Taiwan's governmental and civil computer systems.
Gong said that the concern is not so much that mainland China will use such tactics, but rather that disaffected groups may be "volatile" and aim to do harm.
"Peace is necessary for prosperity. Prosperity facilitates peace," Gong concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S US$ 113.1 B. IN FOREX RESERVES REMAINS WORLD'S NO. 3

TEXT.P: Taiwan held a total of US$113.12 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of the end of May, a figure that allows the island to maintain its position as the world's third largest holder of foreign exchange behind Japan and mainland China, despite a decrease of US$541 million from the previous month, the Central Bank of China(CBC) reported on Wednesday.
Despite the one-month drop, reserves increased by US$17.41 billion compared with May 1999. The CBC official attributed the increase to the huge influx of foreign capital during the past months.
Taiwan foreign exchange reserves broke the US$100 billion mark in August 1999 and jumped to US$110.05 billion at the end of January 2000.

Foreign reserves then declined to US$113 billion at the end of March, due to the government's efforts to maintain stability in the financial markets during the presidential election. However, reserves bounced back quickly to reach US$113.66 billion at the end of April.

CBC officials attributed the decrease of foreign exchange reserves in May to the huge outflow of foreign capital during the month as well as CBC interference in the foreign exchange market to bolster the New Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS OPTIMISTIC ON TAIWAN'S SUCCESS IN NEW ECONOMY

TEXT.P: A financial executive and economics expert said on Wednesday that Taiwan is well prepared to face the "technological shift" of the "new economy."

Kenneth Courtis, managing director and vice chairman of Goldman Sachs Asia, said that the world economy is now engaged in a period of change of the same scope and dimension as the 19th century Industrial Revolution. The changes are shifting the balance of global economic and political power, he added.

Courtis made his comments at the Taipei Roundtable 2000, the seventh of such meetings held in Taipei for US and local experts to exchange their views on a broad range of political and economic issues. The seminar is jointly organized by Chinatrust Commercial Bank and the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a Washington think tank.

Courtis said that he is very optimistic about Taiwan's future, citing Taiwan's eager embrace of digital technology and the new economy as a recipe for certain success. He added that those who can ride the wave across the digital divide will become important political leaders in the region.

Courtis noted that in the distant past, American companies were differentiated between "electrical" and "non-electrical" firms, but it is now impossible to imagine how a "non-electrical" company could survive. Similarly, he added that there may be differences between new economy and old economy companies now, but in the future, there will only be successful companies and dead companies that are "dinosaurs in the economic Jurassic Park."

Yang Shih-chien, former ROC minister without portfolio, noted that a digital economy is indeed emerging in Taiwan along with its industrial reform. He predicted increased economic competitiveness from Taiwan within the next two or three years due to its entry into the information age, which he said will force mainland China to carry out its own reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON D.C. CITY COUNCIL HAILS ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C. June 6 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The City Council of Washington, District of Columbia passed a resolution on Tuesday to name the same day as "Stephen Chen Day" in recognition of Chen's contributions to the promotion of friendships between the United States and Taiwan.
Chen, is the Republic of China representative to the United States. He will be replaced by former ROC Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen.

The resolution resulted from a motion proposed by Council Chairwoman Linda Cropp. Cropp noted that Stephen Chen, an ROC career diplomat, is proficient in many foreign languages, and has served as a bridge between the people of the ROC and countries in which he has been stationed, thus strengthening peace and understanding throughout the world.
Chen responded by saying that the honor was very significant for him, as he enters into the 48th year of his diplomatic service.
Additionally, leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives are scheduled to honor Chen at a farewell reception on Thursday.
Chen is expected to return to Taiwan at the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE PERCENT PAY RAISE FOR PUBLIC FUNCTIONARIES NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Military personnel, public functionaries and teachers will get a pay raise of no less than three percent next year, the Central Personnel Administration (CPA) said on Wednesday.
CPA Director-General Chu Wu-hsien said that due to budgetary difficulties, military personnel, public functionaries and teachers will not be given salary increases in the second half of this year.

But following the social welfare policy of President Chen Shui-bian, a pay raise is scheduled for January 1, 2001, he said, adding that whether the ratio will be three percent or higher will depend tax revenues and related budgets in the second half of the year.
Chu said that Premier Tang Fei has instructed that the pay raise for military personnel, public functionaries and teachers should be "at least more than three percent."

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL REPORTS FIRST TAIWAN CASE OF COSTELLO SYNDROME

TEXT.P: A Taiwan hospital has reported the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
Doctor Ho Chia-wei of Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital said that his patient, a two-year-old baby girl, was born with the debilitating condition.

Ho said that for two years, her mother had to endure the stares of others because of her baby's dark skin, flat nose, curly hairs and wrinkles on her head, face and palms -- a two year old girl with an old woman's appearance.
Ho said that the rare case could not be found in domestic medical literature, and he is planning to report the case in an international medical journal.
Ho said that the girl was first brought for treatment when she was 18 months old, because of poor digestion and a weak immune system.

The little girl's mother said that during her pregnancy, she had hyperamniosis, an abnormally large quantity of the fluid in which a fetus is suspended in its mother's womb. The mother's uterus had 1.5 times the volume of amniotic fluid as that of the average pregnant woman.
Ho said the girl also suffers from a hereditary heart ailment, and she has already undergone one heart operation.

The doctor said that this is the first such case in Taiwan, and only the 37th in the world. His initial hypothesis is that the girl's genetic mutation may have been caused by some sort of insulin metabolism dysfunction.
Ho said that as the fat and protein level of the patient is different from normal children, she has grown to only a little more than seven kilograms.
Ho noted that the oldest such patient has reached 38 years of age, and is still alive and well. He added that his patient has a good chance to grow to adulthood if she is given the proper care.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US OFFICIALS TO STREAM INTO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Former United States officials will be streaming into Taipei this year as they attempt to help break through the impasse between Taiwan and mainland China.

Gearing up for the new cross-strait dynamic that is still unfolding after President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration, former US Defense Secretary William Perry is expected to arrive in Taiwan at the head of a US delegation to pitch for a second communication mechanism between Taipei and Beijing.

Perry, who initiated the idea of "track II" contacts in 1998 as a supplement to the semi-official channel between Taipei and Beijing, has regularly shuttled across the strait ever since, relaying the opinions of leaders in Taiwan and mainland China to each other.
He last visited Taipei between March 7-8, 1999, immediately following a trip to Beijing. He met with then-President Lee Teng-hui, and officials at the National Defense Ministry and Foreign Ministry.
Perry will visit Beijing after Taipei this year, a Foreign Ministry official familiar with Perry's schedule said on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, Kurt Campbell, former US deputy assistant secretary of defense for East Asia affairs, will visit Taiwan next week.

Campbell's Taiwan visit comes after he made headlines in Taipei on Wednesday by issuing a warning in Los Angeles that there is a real possibility that Beijing might decide to attack Taiwan at great risk to itself, despite the wide belief to the contrary.
Another annual gathering between business leaders of Taiwan and the US will be staged in Taipei next week.

Members of both the US and Taiwan delegations to the annual joint conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and the ROC-USA Business Council will be simultaneously announced on Friday in Taipei and Washington.

Fearing opposition from Beijing, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has declined to reveal the list of US delegation members, but high-ranking US trade officials are expected to attend the event, following the precedent established in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFICIAL'S WARNING STIRS UP PUBLIC OUTCRY IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) (By Belle Chou & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong-based Beijing official's warning to Hong Kong business executives to shun alliances with Taiwan firms that Beijing deems pro-Taiwan independence has caused an outcry in the special administration region, according to a opinion poll on Wednesday.

The poll, conducted by the Democratic Party, found 62 percent of the respondents considered the warning a violation of the "one country, two systems" principle laid out by Beijing as the basis for taking over the former British colony in 1997.
Fifty-six percent of the 727 people interviewed in the survey said the warning jeopardizes economic development in both Hong Kong and mainland China, according to the poll's results.

The poll also showed about two thirds of the respondents believed the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region should ask Beijing to ensure that such interference will never happen again.

The Democratic Party officials urged Beijing to require its representatives stationed in Hong Kong to refrain from any remarks that undermine the "one country, two systems" principle and sap foreign investor's confidence in Hong Kong's capitalism.

Although Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa has conveyed to mainland Chinese officials based in Hong Kong the public's concerns about their interference in Hong Kong affairs, the Democratic Party said it is not enough.

The party called Tung to seek clarification from leaders in Beijing so as to quell overseas investors' suspicions about mainland China's 1997 commitment to keep Hong Kong's free-wheeling capitalism intact for 50 years.

The poll, carried out between June 2-5, was aimed at gauging the public's response to a Beijing official's warning that Hong Kong businessmen should stay clear of business figures who favor Taiwan independence when choosing Taiwan-based partners.
