DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 47.59 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 47.59 points to close at 9,067.88.
Market turnover amounted to NT$155.64 billion (US$5.07 billion)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 47.59 points to close at 9,067.88.
Due to heavy profit-taking after an upward streak, the bourse opened at 9,151.31 and fluctuated between 9,209.48 and 9,055.72 during trading.

A total of 2.4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$155.64 billion (US$5.07 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.2 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$148.05 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers 262 to 229, with 119 stocks remaining unchanged.
Three of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.3 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.2 percent, and construction stocks at 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Thursday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved down 61 points to close at 9,114, with 2,896 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 63 points to finish at 9,148, with 142 contract transactions, while September futures lost 40 points to close at 9,260, with six contract transactions, and next March futures plunged 139 points to finish at 9,381, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 9,175 for June; 9,211 for July; 9,300 for September; 9,425 for December; and 9,520 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported negative results.
June TE futures moved down 5.3 points to close at 503.1, with 1,345 contract transactions; while July TE futures decreased 8.3 points to close at 501.2, with 27 transactions.
September TE futures lost 14 points to finish at 505, with three contract transactions, and next March futures moved down 2.25 points to close at 535, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were reported for December TE futures.
June TF futures decreased 2.8 points to close at 938, with 370 contract transactions, while July TF futures remained unchanged at 948, with 30 contract transactions.
However, September TF futures moved up 1 points to finish at 947, with 10 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 8, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
632: Mohammed, Arab prophet and founder of Islam, dies in Mecca at the age of 62. At the age of 40, he began to preach as God's prophet of Islam as the true religion. Mohammed established a theocratic state at Medina after 622 and began to convert Arabia to Islam.
1809: British-born American writer and Revolutionary leader Thomas Paine dies in New York at the age of 72. He wrote the pamphlet "Common Sense" in 1776 arguing for American independence from Britain. In England, he published "The Rights of Man" (1791-1792), a defense of the French Revolution.
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1921: Suharto, former president of Indonesia, is born.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army as his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1942: Japanese submarines and aircraft attack Australia, striking at Sydney and Newcastle.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: US President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 US troops from Vietnam.
1973: The Federation of Asian Women's Associations opens its 6th general meeting in Taipei.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the US National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The Republic of China-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1981: A 23-member delegation of the Japanese National Defense Association headed by Zenshiro Shiina arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first ethnic Chinese American astronaut.
1986: Kurt Waldheim becomes president of Austria despite growing evidence that he collaborated with the Nazis during World War II.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Communist China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR US OFFICIAL SUPPORTS CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior US Department of State official has voiced support for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to follow the example of Seoul and Pyongyang in holding a summit meeting to help forge a consensus on major issues of mutual concern.
Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary for East Asia and Pacific affairs, made the statement in an American Embassy Television Network program, titled "Dialogue," on Monday.

Shirk said since both ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, hope to see progress in cross-strait relations, a meeting between them after a new round of "Koo-Wang" talks will be a dramatic and appropriate development.

The Koo-Wang talks refer to meetings between Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Beijing's Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) President Wang Daohan.

The first Koo-Wang meeting was held in Singapore in 1993 to lay a framework for regular cross-strait dialogue and exchanges in the absence of official ties. Koo and Wang met again in Shanghai in October 1998 after a five-year hiatus in high-level cross-strait contact. Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mentor to mainland Chinese President Jiang, originally promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan last year, but Beijing postponed Wang's Taiwan visit indefinitely after former ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview last July. There are signs recently that a new round of Koo-Wang meeting is likely to take place this autumn.
In her response to an inquiry from mainland Chinese reporters, Shirk said the United States has a legal obligation to help Taiwan defend itself.

"We are very careful in our arms sales to Taiwan. They are always purely defensive," Shirk said, adding that cross-strait problem is really a difficult one that is going to take effort by the two sides to build a more positive basis for the relationship across the Taiwan Strait -- through their economic exchanges and political dialogue.

In addition, Shirk said, the United States would like to see "military confidence-building measures" across the Taiwan Strait, and eventually a reduction of arms on both sides of the strait. "So that is something that would be highly desirable from the standpoint of everyone."

The US State Department published the full text of Shirk's speech in the "Dialogue" program on its Internet website. In the program, Shirk held talks with reporters in major mainland Chinese cities, including Beijing, Shenyang, Shanghai and Guangzhou, through satellite links. Nearly half of the 20-plus questions posed by mainland journalists were related to Taiwan.

Asked whether the US public understand that the United States is likely to get involved once a cross-strait military conflict breaks out, Shirk said the US public are fully aware of this and that it is one of the major reasons that the United States hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can hold dialogue to defuse tension.

Shirk further said how the United States will cope with a cross-strait conflict will depend on the actual situation, but she added that a general understanding is that the United States will respond if any side uses force in the Taiwan Strait.

Touched on the possibility of a cross-strait summit meeting, Shirk said some mainland people are worried about new Republic of China President Chen's party affiliation. Nevertheless, Shirk said, the US government is impressed by Chen's goodwill message toward Beijing.
Chen is a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan's main opposition party until Chen took the reins of power from Lee Teng-hui of the Kuomintang on May 20.

Shirk said Chen has laid out the "infrastructure" for cross-strait relations under his presidency, including the ROC's constitution, no abolishment of the existing National Unification Guidelines, and a "four noes" policy, which refers to no declaration of Taiwan independence, no changes to the ROC's national title, no referendum on Taiwan's future and no inclusion of the "state-to-state" theory in the constitution.

Shirk said the Clinton administration sees some positive signs in the cross-strait relationship. "We see that both sides of the strait, Beijing and Taipei, are proceeding in a very pragmatic and moderate manner, and in fact seem to be inching their way toward the resumption of dialogue...And this is an effort that is strongly encouraged on both sides by the United States."

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN FOR INITIAL DIRECT LINKS TO BE COMPLETED IN 6 MONTHS: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen said on Thursday that the plan for small-scale direct links between Taiwan-controlled outlying islands and mainland China will be completed in six months.

But the government will not fix the timetable for implementation of the plan as it involves the development of political interaction across the Taiwan Strait, she told a committee of the Legislative Yuan.

The MAC chief told the lawmakers that the government is positive in promoting the small-scale direct trade, postal, and transportation links between Kinmen, Matsu, and Penghu and mainland China, but priority consideration must be given to national security.
She noted that the Cabinet-level MAC will complete its evaluating and planning operations on the issue in six months, with the hope of promoting favorable cross-strait interactions.
But Tsai also stressed the need for considering related issues, such as the nation's security, economic and social development, laws, the government's overall mainland policy, and Beijing's response.

On the demand by a local religious group to be allowed to make a direct religious pilgrimage between Taiwan and Fujian on July 16, Tsai said that such a direct voyage will only be allowed when the government completes its plan for small-scale direct links.
However, she pointed out that it will not be a problem if the religious group sails for mainland China via Japan's Ishigaki Island, as it did last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IT INDUSTRY TAKES AIM AT HOUSEHOLD IT APPLIANCE MARKET

TEXT.P: The trend of decreasing personal computer (PC) prices in the world market has affected the profit margin of Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry, and computer manufacturers are seeking to shift their production lines to household IT appliances.

In 1999, Taiwan-made IT product output totaled US$46,989 million, making Taiwan the third largest supplier of IT products in the world. Taiwan grabbed the biggest share of the global market for laptops, monitors, main boards, change mode power supplies, computer cases, scanners, keyboards, mouses, and CD-R drives.

Hardware makes up a fairly high proportion of Taiwan's IT industry, and orders from leading international brands account for a lion's share of Taiwan's hardware output. As the profit margins of Other Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) products are declining, the manufacturers need to develop products of higher value.

Laptops have been most influenced by the trend of decreasing prices. In the first quarter of this year, Taiwan's laptop output totaled 6,468,000 units with the value amounting to US$1,794 million, indicating a 58 percent growth in quantity, but only a 12.3 percent growth in value as compared with the same period last year.

At the 2000 Computex Taipei being held at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall from June 5-9, at least 200 manufacturers are introducing their latest household IT appliance designs to the market.

Many international computer manufacturers interested in the household IT appliances market are seeking alliances with Taiwan's computer and peripherals manufacturers to take advantage of Taiwan's solid hardware manufacturing background.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICPS AND PORTAL SITES CHALLENGE PRINT MEDIA

TEXT.P: The print media is facing competition from web sites as more and more portal sites are seeking alliances with ICPs (Internet Content Providers) to issue electronic newsletters.

To win the loyalty of page viewers, many web sites, particularly portal sites, are offering their members real time news services by issuing electronic newsletters and sending the newsletters via e-mail.

Though portal sites have the advantages of internet technologies and band width for transmission, they may not be specialized in creating content. Some print media, aware of the challenge posed by the internet era, are cooperating with web sites to offer on-line news services, a mutually beneficial solution for newspapers and web sites.

A successful model is Seednet's e-newsletter alliance which offers 64 kinds of e-newsletters of different categories, ranging from politics and social events, business and finance, science and technology, fashion, entertainment, and arts and literature. Since its establishment in September 1999, Seednet's e-newsletters have attracted 830,000 subscribers.

Most of the Seednet e-newsletter subscribers are aged between 20 and 35, and the subjects they are most interested in are personal health, business and finance, self-training, and entertainment, according to Seednet's surveys.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DOING ITS BEST TO SEAL MOSEL VITELIC DEAL
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, June 7 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Canadian federal government is doing everything it can to try to seal a deal with Taiwan's Mosel Vitelic to relocate the company's microchip processing operations to Quebec, said Canada's Industry Minister John Manley on Wednesday.

Manley, who is playing a large role in the push for the investment project, said the federal government will do everything possible to help the provincial government of Quebec strike the Mosel Vitelic deal.

Manley even visited Taiwan in person in September 1998 to meet executives of Mosel Vitelic to convince the Taiwanese company to relocate its microchip processing operations to Canada -- which would represent a C$3 billion investment in the country and 1,500 new jobs for Canadians at the high-technology plant, while indirectly creating some 6,500 other job opportunities.

He added that although there has been no major silicon wafer manufacturer located in Canada to date, making the country relatively more backward in this field of high-tech production, seeking the Mosel Vitelic deal is not simply aimed at redressing this unfavorable situation.
"The company is keenly welcome to come to Canada because the investment will create a great number of job opportunities," Manley said.

Meanwhile, Bernard Landry, deputy premier and minister of finance in Quebec, said the province is "almost certain" that Mosel Vitelic will formally announce in July that it will set up a silicon wafer plant near Montreal.

Landry said it is hoped that the federal government will provide some C$200 million as an incentive subsidy for the Taiwanese project, coupled with a 10-year tax holiday to be offered by the Quebec government.

According to reports from Taiwan, Mosel Vitelic's spokesman said recently that the company has ruled out all other countries and areas overseas for the giant investment and that only Canada and Germany remain as possible locations.

Spokesman Chang Dong-lung said that unless Canada comes up with useful incentive programs, which require legislative approval, in the near future, the company does not exclude the possibility of choosing Germany as the location for its new 12-inch wafer plant, according to the reports.

An official from the Canadian Ministry of Industry said the ministry has several investment incentive programs which can be applied to induce Mosel Vitelic to locate in the country. The most feasible one is the Scientific Research and Experimental Development Program, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE CABINET OFFICIALS GIVE UP DUAL NATIONALITY

TEXT.P: Five Cabinet members of the newly-installed government have given up their dual nationalities so as to allow them to work legally in the Executive Yuan, sources from the Examination Yuan said on Thursday.

The five Cabinet offficials who have signed formal written papers giving up their foreign nationalities are Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, Education Minister Ovid J.L. Tzeng, Research, Development and Evaluation Commission Vice Chairman Chi Kuo-chung, National Science Council Vice Chairman Hsieh Ching-chih and Taipei Representative in Japan Lo Fu-chen, said officials from the Ministry of Personnel under the Examination Yuan.
According to laws governing public functionaries and their employment, individuals who possess dual nationalities are not qualified to be employed in Cabinet-level government posts. By Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: US ANNOUNCES PROPOSED ARMS SALE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United States announced on Wednesday the proposed US$356 million sale of two electronic systems for use on Taiwan's US-made F-16 jet fighters.

Pending the expected approval by Congress, Washington will transfer 48 AN/ALQ-184 electronic countermeasures pods, worth $122 million, and 39 sets of Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods, with an estimated value of $234 million. The sale will include related spare parts, support equipment, personnel training, and related items.
The prime contractors will be Raytheon Company's Electronic Systems Division of Goleta, California, and Lockheed-Martin Corp. of Orlando, Florida, respectively.

A Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pod is the export derivative of a system known as LANTIRN (Low-altitude Navigation and Target Infra-Red for Night). This system increases the F-16's capability of flying and targeting at low altitudes and in poor visibility.
The United States announced the sale of 28 Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods to Taiwan in 1998.
AN/ALQ-184 electronic countermeasures pods are used to jam enemy radars and to help the F-16 evade incoming missiles.
Today's announcement marks the first proposed arms transfer to Taiwan after the island's voters chose a new government on March 18.
On March 7, the United States announced the sale of Hawk air defense missiles and upgrades for one of Taiwan's aging air defense radars. The estimated cost was $206 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND CHINA DIVIDED BY A YAWNING GAP

TEXT.P: The fact that Communist China and Taiwan are "divided by a yawning gap created by history, culture, society, the economy, and basic values," is an enormous impediment to better relations between the two, reported The Washington Post on Wednesday.

John Pomfret, correspondent of the influential American newspaper, reported from Taipei that the gap is evident in the architecture of their cities, the content of their cultures, the buzz of their businesses, and the fundamentally distinct feel of both places.

"It explains why China's appeals for reunification with Taiwan based on race, history and national identity, which have some resonance among overseas Chinese communities, fall largely on deaf ears on this island of 23 million people. It illustrates why Taiwan's claim to a separate identity, put forth by Chen in his inaugural speech, garners no understanding in China," he pointed out.

Pomfret said recognition of this widening gap has convinced some Communist Chinese officials, particularly in the military, that "it will take a war for Beijing to gain control of Taiwan. This faction remains a vocal lobby for action."

However, he said, Communist China's civilian officials hold sway in the government for the time being and argue that negotiations could do more to solve the issue. So far, however, no talks are in sight.

"The fundamental issue is that China wants to unite with Taiwan, while the island and its government are moving in the other direction. China feels it has all the power of history and race on its side. Its aging president, Jiang Zemin, is concerned with his legacy and wants at the very least to avoid being blamed by history for losing Taiwan," Pomfret said.

In Taiwan, however, 45 percent of respondents in the most recent government opinion poll identified themselves as Taiwanese, while only 14 percent considered themselves Chinese -- a huge change from the 1980s when almost everyone considered themselves Chinese, he said. The remainder of the respondents said they feel they have "dual identities."

"China says we have got to accept the `one China' principle before we go into talks. Well, the basic problem is most of us don't want that. And we are a democracy now," a senior official in Chen's government was quoted as saying.

Pomfret added that with government monopolies in numerous industries being eliminated by democratization, Taiwan's economy is now one of the most competitive and free-wheeling in the world. The average per capita income is around US$13,000, more than 10 times that of mainland China.

Optimists argue that over time, as the economic gap between the two sides narrows, relations will improve. But almost everyone in Taiwan also stresses that unless China begins to embrace political reform, Taiwan will continue moving further and further away, said Pomfret.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAILS US ARMS SALES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 8 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Thursday it welcomes any US arms sales that can help upgrade the Republic of China's defense capabilities and safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait.

The ministry was responding to reports that the US Pentagon has announced sales to Taiwan of two weaponry systems designed to upgrade the defensive and navigation capabilities of its F-16 jet fighters.

According to the reports, the Clinton administration will transfer to Taiwan 48 AN/ALQ-184 electronic countermeasures pods, worth US$122 million, and 39 sets of Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods, with an estimated value of US$234 million. The sale will include related spare parts, support equipment, personnel training and related items.

The proposed deal, worth a total of US$356 million, is pending an expected approval by Congress. It also marks the first proposed arms transfer to Taiwan after the island's voters chose a new government on March 18.
The MND would not confirm the deal, saying it is the ministry's established policy not to make any comment on US weaponry sales to Taiwan.

According to the Pentagon announcement, the prime contractors of the proposed arms sales will be Raytheon Company's Electronic Systems Division of Goleta, California, and Lockheed-Martin Corp. of Orlando, Florida, respectively.
The Pentagon also said the sales of electronic countermeasures pods and Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods "will not affect the basic military balance" in the Taiwan Strait region.

Military sources said Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods are the export derivative of a system known as LANTIRN (Low-altitude Navigation and Target Infra-Red for Night). This system increases the F-16's capability of flying and targeting at low altitudes and in poor visibility.
The United States announced the sale of 28 Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods to Taiwan in 1998.
Meanwhile, AN/ALQ-184 electronic countermeasures pods are used to jam enemy radars and to help the F-16 evade incoming missiles.
On March 7 this year, the United States announced the sale of Hawk air defense missiles and upgrades for one of Taiwan's aging air defense radars for an estimated cost of US$206 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE REGISTERED DOUBLE-DIGIT INCREASE IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports registered a double-digit increase in May, according to customs-clearance statistics released by the Finance Ministry on Thursday.
Exports were listed at US$13.15 billion, up 23.8 percent over the same month last year, while imports rose 44.1 percent to US$12.71 billion.
The island enjoyed a trade surplus of US$440 million, down US$1.37 billion from May of last year.

Continued economic growth in North American and European countries as well as stronger-than-expected economic recovery in Asian countries were factors in the substantial increase in Taiwan's exports and imports in May.
This was the eighth consecutive month that Taiwan's foreign trade registered a double-digit increase.

Exports in the data and communications industries and of electronics, steel, machinery, and optical products all increased substantially, while exports of heavy chemical products grew 29.6 percent to US$2.05 billion.
Imports of capital equipment, and agricultural and industrial materials also posted large increases.
In the first five months of this year, Taiwan's exports totaled US$58.28 billion, up 22.6 percent over the same period last year, with imports growing 33.9 percent to US$56.42 billion.
Taiwan's trade surplus in the first five months of this year reached US$1.86 billion, down US$3.55 billion over the corresponding period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG EMERGENCY RESCUE TEAM LEAVES TO AID INDONESIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Following in the steps of the first Taiwan rescue team, which was from Taipei county, a team from the southern county of Pingtung departed Thursday for Indonesia to help with emergency aid and search work in the wake of a devastating earthquake which struck the island of Sumatra on Sunday.

The Pingtung team, comprising five emergency aid specialists from the city's Fire Department and one architect, boarded a China Airlines direct flight to Jakarta where they will transfer to a flight to Sumatra, where the earthquake killed at least 117 people and injured nearly 700 others. The temblor measured 7.9 on the Richter scale.

According to the team leader, the Pingtung rescuers did not bring the tools used to search through destroyed buildings in Taiwan after the island was battered by a catastrophic 7.3-magnitude earthquake on Sept. 21 last year. He explained that Indonesian buildings are structurally different from buildings in Taiwan, so the tools would not be useful there.
Instead, the team took life detectors, fiber-optic detectors and other advanced search and rescue gear, he noted.
Also departing for Sumatra on Thursday was a medical team comprised of 12 doctors and nurses who volunteered their services to aid the Indonesian quake victims.

The Taipei County team, comprising five emergency aid specialists and one doctor, took with it 640 kg of rescue and search gear, including sonar detectors, image probes, electricity generators, digging tools and satellite telephones, when it left for Indonesia on Wednesday.

Both the Taipei County and Pingtung emergency aid teams were established late last year after Taiwan was jolted by the killer earthquake -- the deadliest Taiwan quake of the 20th century -- which claimed the lives of nearly 2,400 people, injured some 8,400 and left 100,000 others homeless.
The teams had received four weeks of intensive training in Singapore earlier this year.
The disaster in Sumatra marks the first time that emergency aid missions from Taiwan have conducted search and rescue work overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR UNIONS HOPE SENATE PROCEDURES DELAY PNTR PASSAGE

TEXT.P: Despite their disappointing defeat in the US House of Representatives last month, labor unions are counting on the Senate's unique procedures to give them a chance to delay passage of the legislation that would grant Communist China permanent normal trade relations status.
These labor unions are hoping that the debate in the Senate will be framed on Beijing's horrible human rights record.

However, 10 Democratic senators sent a joint letter on Wednesday to Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.) and Minority Leader Thomas Daschle (D-SD), urging them to bring the PNTR legislation to the floor at the earliest possible date before the Senate recess, which begins on July 4.

While labor lobbyists admit they have little chance of stopping the passage of the bill, they hope to slow it down enough to push a vote closer to the election in November, or perhaps into the next Congress.
"If there is any way to stop it, it's going to be a procedural issue," said Mike Mathis, government affairs director for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
If the Senate passes a bill different from the House version, a conference committee could send it back to the House, leading to another controversial vote there, noted labor groups.

Several senators, including Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms, a Republican from North Carolina, and Paul Wellstone, a Democrat from Minnesota who are on the committee's panel on East Asian affairs, have raised serious concerns about Beijing's human rights record and prison labor practices, among other issues.
Sen. Helms has also promised a "robust debate" on whether to grant Communist China PNTR status, which would include a discussion on Communist Chinese threats against Taiwan.

However, Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla.; Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn.; and several others told a Capitol Hill press conference that a letter signed by 10 members of the Senate New Democratic Coalition will be sent to Senate leaders Lott and Daschle Wednesday to express their desire for an early vote on PNTR.

"There will be efforts from opponents to offer amendments that they will seek to win support for. This bill, in our opinion, is so important that we are offering our support to defeat all such amendments, knowing that many of those amendments may well be amendments of merit that under other circumstances we would support," the Democrats said.
They also called on their colleagues in the Senate to join them in achieving the objective of early final passage of the PNTR bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC CULTURAL SUMMIT OPENS FRIDAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit is scheduled to kick off Friday in Taipei with the participation of mayors, officials and delegates from 26 cities from around the region as well as Taiwan.

The 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit, the first of its kind in the Asia and Pacific Rim region, is also the first large-scale international gala activity that the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs has sponsored since the bureau's inception more than two years ago.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will deliver a keynote speech entitled "The Dilemma of Asian Values" during the opening session of the summit, scheduled to run from June 9 to June 11 at the Grand Hotel.

Officials from the Cultural Affairs Bureau said that during the summit, delegates from the cities will take part in discussion panels on "the differences of Asian cultures, the challenges of modernization, and the feasibility of establishing a long-standing mechanism of electing Asian cultural cities" -- models of cultural development and protection.
The 26 delegations will also be required to each take seven minutes during the opening session to introduce their respective cities, cultures and peoples.

At a pre-summit press conference, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou noted that Europe initiated the election of cultural cities and related gala activities on that continent 15 years ago. Asia, with its diverse and equally-important cultures, should emulate Europe and engage in similar activities to help energize Asian cultures as well as bolstering friendship among the cities in the region.

Lung Ying-tai, director of the Taipei Bureau of Cultural Affairs, said the summit is a golden opportunity for people in the region to conduct talks on a city-to-city basis. To show that high-technology is also part of the culture, the entire process of the summit and related activities will be broadcast online, allowing people from around the world to witness the activities as they happen, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST 2000 WORLD CONGRESS ON INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Executives of leading international information technology firms will meet in Taipei at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology from June 12-14 to discuss the development and applications of the IT industry.

The star-studded occasion, with speakers including Hewlet-Packard President Carly Fiorina, Bill Gates of Microsoft, John Chambers of Cisco Systems, and Robert Young of Red Hat, is being sponsored by the Information Service Industry Association of China, Taipei (CISA), a member of the World Information Technology and Services Alliance (WITSA).

In the past 22 years, WITSA members had sponsored 11 world congresses for the IT industry around the world. The 1,500 attendants to the 12th world congress in Taipei will focus discussions on the impact of information technology on world economics, emerging IT strategies, business models and applications, and the industry's prospects.

Among the 25 speakers at the three-day conference are 1999 Nobel Laureate in Economics Prof. Robert A. Mundell, Patricia Hewitt, the United Kingdom's minister for small business and e-commerce, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, and the CEOs of several multinational corporations.

The Computex Taipei, being held June 5-9, and the World Congress on Information Technology, being held June 12-14, have focused international attention on developments in Taiwan's IT industry. From a heavy reliance on OEM (Other Equipment Manufacturer) and ODM (Other Design Manufacturer) orders, to the establishment of Taiwan brand names, Taiwan's IT industry is gradually maturing and winning international recognition.

Though hardware remains the largest foreign exchange earner of Taiwan's IT industry, an increasing number of manufacturers are putting their efforts into software, the internet, as well as communications products and services.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD NOT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CHEN'S HANDLING OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said on Thursday that he is not optimistic about the way that President Chen Shui-bian's new government is handling the souring relations between Taiwan and mainland China.
Lien, who lost his presidential bid to Chen in last March 18's election, made the remarks while meeting with John Chipman, director of the London-based International Strategy Research Institute.

The former vice president said that Beijing does not trust Chen, even if Chen has borrowed the KMT's mainland policy and used the KMT's language. He added that he is therefore not optimistic about the new administration's policy.
Lien admitted that Chen's May 20 inaugural speech was moderate and pragmatic, and was praised by foreign countries, including the United States and Japan.
But he said that although Chen has taken a flexible posture toward the current situation, the pro-independence nature of Chen's Democratic Progressive Party remains unchanged.
When questioned on the best way for the DPP government to handle cross-strait relations, Lien replied: "To follow in the KMT's footsteps."
Lien said that the KMT's past policy toward mainland China was the result of repeated discussions by related government agencies and the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT INTERACTION NOT EQUAL TO DIPLOMATIC TRUCE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said on Thursday that diplomatic interaction between Taiwan and mainland China cannot be considered to be the same as a truce in the diplomatic war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Tsai said Taiwan has no intention of engaging in any vicious competition with mainland China in the international community, but added that it is undeniable that Beijing is the biggest challenge facing Taiwan in its efforts to explore Taipei's presence in international organizations.
"A greater international role is a must for a nation's continued development," the MAC chief noted.
The MAC head made the remarks at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

As long as mainland China responds with good will to Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao's recent proposal for a truce in the cross-strait diplomatic wrangle, Tsai said the MAC, in conjunction with the Foreign Affairs Ministry, would like to study the feasibility of transforming bilateral competition in international circles to peaceful co-existence.
"That would also boost the overall interests of the international community and help improve our bilateral relations," she said.

However, judging from the "double handling" approach adopted by mainland Chinese authorities and their mindset in dealing with Taiwan affairs, Tsai claimed that it would be very hard for both sides to achieve the "win-win" situation in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR DOWN 0.5 CENTS ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar depreciated NT$0.5 cents against the greenback on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Market to close at NT$30.796 on Thursday.
The NT dollar opened at 30.787 against the U.S. dollar, and was traded between 30.786 and 30.820.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading shrank to US$371.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOOS AD EXECS TO 2001 ASIAN ADVERTISING MEETING IN TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 7 (CNA) (By Mark Ou & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: An advertising industry delegation from Taiwan urged members of the International Advertising Association (IAA) to attend the Asian Advertising Meeting scheduled to be held in Taipei next year.
The Taipei delegation, comprised of 28 advertisers and representatives of the mass media, arrived in London to attend the IAA's annual convention.
In addition to attending IAA panel discussions and seminars, the Taipei delegation took the opportunity to distribute tourism-related literature to participants at the IAA convention.

Lai Tung-ming, honorary team leader of the delegation, noted that Taipei will host the biannual Asian Advertising Meeting in November 2001. Lai took the opportunity to lure foreign advertising executives to attend the Taipei event.
Lai said that he has met with many attendees, all of whom said that they were deeply moved by the peaceful transition of power in the Republic of China, Lai said.

They were also impressed with the ongoing reconstruction work in the areas damaged by last year's earthquake, which jolted central Taiwan on Sept. 21, Lai said. He added that the foreign executives with whom he has met have all showed keen interest in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MEDICAL TEAM LEAVES FOR SUMATRA TO HELP QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A 10-member Republic of China medical team left for Sumatra on Thursday to offer humanitarian medical services to people injured in a killer earthquake that rattled the Indonesian island on Sunday.

The team, composed of 10 surgeons, dentists, nurses and volunteers, was organized by the Luchu Club, a private association of medical professionals in Taiwan. The association has long offered free medical services to aborigines around the island and refugees in war-torn countries around the world.
Liu Chi-chun, head of the team, said the group will mainly offer auxiliary medical services to Indonesian quake victims because it only took simple medical facilities and pharmaceuticals.

Most of the mission members are no stranger to offering medical services in disaster zones as they had joined relief work in Macedonia, Liberia and Dharamsala (the seat of the exiled Tibetan government in India) in the past few years, Liu said.
The group is scheduled to return on June 14, Liu said, adding that if necessary, the team will extend its stay in the Sumatra quake-stricken areas.

The Luchu team was the third Taiwan voluntary group to leave for Sumatra since the Indonesian island was hit by a 7.9-magnitude earthquake that killed at least 117 people and injured nearly 700 others.

An elite rescue team organizd by the Taipei County Government's fire department left for Sumatra on Wednesday and another specialist team from the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung traveled to the Indonesian island on Thursday morning.

The Taipei and Pingtung county governments organized elite rescue and relief teams after a devastating 7.3-magnitude earthquake ripped through the mountain region of central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 and resulted in the death of more than 2,300 people, injury of some 8,400 others and collapse of tens of thousands of schools and private homes.
The Sumatra mission marks the first time that trained ROC rescue personnel have joined disaster relief operations abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: PNTR PASSAGE WOULD INHIBIT US ABILITY TO BLOCK TECHNOLOGY TRANSFERS

TEXT.P: Once the United States completes legislation to grant permanent normal trading relations to Communist China, no US administration will be able to block transfers of vital technology to that country "without risking an international trade war and sanctions against the US economy from the World Trade Organization," an analyst has warned.

Kenneth Timmerman, a writer who has investigated sales of US high technology to China for six years, wrote in the current issue of The Washington Times' weekly magazine that the Dongfeng-31 long-range missile, to be test-fired by the Communist Chinese military, is a product of the Clinton administration's policy of allowing US companies to ship vital technology and equipment to mainland China.

Timmerman said a Communist Chinese scientist who defected had told him that Beijing "acquired most of the specialized military equipment and technology they needed for the DF-31 in the United States with the help and approval of the Clinton administration."

The scientist described in great detail how technology and cash from Lockheed, Martin Marietta, and Motorola enabled his superiors at China's Hexi Machinery and Chemical Company to develop a new generation of solid fuel strategic missiles that eventually resulted in the development of the DF-31, wrote Timmerman.

The State Department bolstered the defector's account in April by accusing Lockheed of 30 violations of the Arms Control Act and International Traffic in Arms Regulations in their peddling of rocket technology to Communist China.

The defector told Timmerman that the deal with US defense contractors came at just the right time. "Our factory was in trouble before I started working there. Then we got a major contract from the US and things took off." Motorola's contribution to Beijing's missile program was a result of its deal with Great Wall Industries Corp. to launch 12 of its Iridium global satellites.

"As part of the contract, the Chinese agreed to develop a `smart dispenser,' allowing them to launch several satellites from a single rocket," Timmerman wrote, adding that this was a feat which up until then Communist China could not perform.
"Our US partners gave us the specifications and technical assistance to produce the dispenser," the defector was quoted as saying.

The help China got from Motorola gave them the ability to build multiple warhead missiles. For the Communist Chinese, the deal was a success, but for Motorola, it ended in disaster. The Iridium project went belly up and they had to destroy the 12 satellites the Chinese launched for them, noted Timmerman.

Meanwhile, Martin Marietta, since merged with Lockheed, helped Hexi develop a so-called solid fuel "kick motor," which is used to push satellites into earth orbit. "Before we received this help from the United States, China had never succeeded in developing propellants powerful enough to be used for strategic-range solid fuel rockets," the defector said.

With the DF-31 up and running, Timmerman said, China is now working on a new ICBM, the DF-41, which will have a range of some 7,500 miles. Intelligence sources say the new missile is expected to carry multiple nuclear warheads, according to the Cox Committee report on Communist China's theft of US nuclear secrets released last May.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S DEPUTY PM SAYS TAIWAN-M'LAND REUNIFICATION 'INEVITABLE'

TEXT.P: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Long said he believes that reunification between mainland China and Taiwan is only a matter of time.

In a speech at the National Press Club in Canberra on Wednesday, Lee said Beijing no longer believes that the Taiwan issue can be deferred indefinitely, but it has not yet worked out when or how to act on Taiwan.
Brigadier Lee, son of Singapore's elder statesman Lee Kuan Yew, is visiting Australia as a guest of the Commonwealth government, which regards him as a future leader in his country.
Lee said it is quite clear that Beijing would likely take the "fateful steps" if Taiwan moved to break away from the mainland.

He said President Lee Teng-hui's declaration of a "special state-to-state" relationship between mainland China and Taiwan last July transformed Taiwan into "the single most urgent item on China's agenda."
No leader in Beijing can afford to be blamed for losing Taiwan. They will discuss and assess it carefully among themselves before reaching a collective view, probably later this year, he said.
Lee, however, acknowledged that he does not know whether China's "one country, two systems" formula can provide a basis for reunification.
"Taiwan has said the formula is not a solution, but that does not mean `one China' will not one day come to pass because the mainland is quite determined," he said.

Lee noted that the only player that has the ability to stop a Communist Chinese takeover of Taiwan is the United States. But he doubted whether the United States is as prepared to fight as the Communist Chinese are.
In his view, reunification eventually will happen, but he cannot be sure about when or how it will happen.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE JOURNALIST RECOUNTS HER HORRIFYING TAXI RIDES IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A veteran Australian journalist stationed in mainland China recounted her horrifying experience from taking taxis in Beijing, the capital of the world's most populous country.

Lynne O'Donnell, correspondent of the mass-circulation newspaper The Australian, recounted her horrifying experience when she recently took a taxi from the Beijing Airport to her office in the center of the city.

She recounted that when the taxi left the airport freeway, a van swung dangerously into the taxi's path. "The van overtook us and half a dozen thugs hung out of the window, spitting and swearing in our direction," she wrote.
"When we stopped behind the van at the next set of lights, the thugs climbed out and walked towards us. To my horror, and despite my shrill protestations, the taxi driver also got out," she said.
The lights changed and the van drove off, she said.
"My luggage and I were stranded in the middle of a busy highway as the driver and the louts bumped chests on the verge," she said.
The taxi driver only said that the thugs had been rude to him. "What could I do?," he asked.

Several days later, O'Donnell said she had the misfortune of finding herself in the care of another taxi driver who happened to have a flat tire on her way to an appointment. The driver grabbed her and demanded the full fare for an incomplete journey, O'Donnell recounted.
"My attempts to take advantage of a much-ballyhooed taxi complaints hotline came to naught. For a week, no one answered the phone, and when they did they wanted details in writing," she said.
"The customer is king in Communist China? Not in my lifetime," she concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINAL LEG OF OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY STARTS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Olympic torch on Thursday began its 100-day journey from Uluru in Australia's Northern Territory to Sydney, the venue of the 2000 Olympic Games, as the country at the same time started producing 3,100 gold, silver and bronze medals for the September competition.

The torch arrived at Uluru National Park from New Zealand on Thursday, and the honor of being the first Olympic torch relay runner on Australian soil went to Nova Peris-Kneebone, who won a gold medal in field hockey at the Atlanta Olympic Games in 1996.
Altogether, about 11,000 Australians from all walks of life will carry the torch during its 100-day journey, including former medalists from various sports, celebrities, and ordinary people.

In the meantime, the Perth Mint will produce 1,000 gold medals for the victors of the various Olympic contests. The Royal Australia Mint in Canberra will produce about 1,000 silver medals and another 1,100 bronze medals for second and third place finishers.
Altogether more than 10,000 athletes from more than 100 countries are expected to compete in the Olympic Games, organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF 2ND CKS TERMINAL POSTPONED TO LATE JULY

TEXT.P: After months of delay, the second terminal of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport is expected to be opened in mid-July, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Y. H. Chang said on Thursday.

Chang made the remarks for Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan in response to questioning from Kuomintang (KMT) Lawmaker Chen Ming-wen, who expressed his dissatisfaction with the ongoing delays and demanded Yeh set a clear timetable for the opening of the complex.

Stressing that she wants the complex to be opened for public services under the best and safest of conditions, Yeh said she cannot put forward a clear timetable at present, because part of the air traffic control system is still being tested.

The opening of the second CKS terminal had been originally scheduled for February this year, but it was postponed because of the presidential election in March, which saw Taiwan's first transition of central government power, from the KMT to the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATIVE HEAD MEETS JAPAN-ROC PARLIAMENTARY COUNCIL CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Republic of China (ROC) Legislative Yuan, called on Sadanori Yamanaka, board chairman of the Japan-ROC Parliamentary Council on Thursday.

During the meeting, Yamanaka expressed his concern over future political developments in Taiwan after President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration, as well as relations among the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Kuomintang and the newly-established People First Party.
Yamanaka also suggested that President Chen Shui-bian listen to the opinions of senior politicians of the ruling party as well as opposition leaders.

According a Legislative Yuan news release, Yamanaka told his ROC visitors that he will continue to lead the pro-Taipei parliamentary group so as to unify all Japanese political forces that support Taiwan.
Wang is currently in Tokyo with Presidential Senior Advisers Koo Chen-fu and Peng Ming-min. The officials are to attend Thursday's funeral services for the late Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.

Yamanaka said that he expects that the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will win more than 50 percent of legislative seats in the election on June 25. He expressed his hope that he can call on Wang in Taipei after the Lower House election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN MUSICIAN AMONG THE SOLOISTS AT CONCERT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-born musician will perform on Thursday night as a soloist at a concert entitled "A Night of Asian Music and Dance," which is being sponsored by the Australian National University in Canberra.
Betty Chen, 50, will perform four compositions, two of which were composed by her teacher, Professor Liang Tsai-ping. Chen is a virtuoso player of the kucheng, a traditional stringed Chinese zither.
Chen began studying the kucheng 22 years ago in Taiwan, and continued to play the instrument after she emigrated to Australia. She first settled in Brisbane, and later moved to Canberra.
In addition to performing, she currently teaches about 10 students, including one who is studying at the Canberra School of Music.
"I am glad to have the chance to promote our Chinese culture in Australia, and the kucheng is a beautiful classic Chinese instrument that is worthy of introduction to Australia's people," she said.
Dr. Liu Po-lun, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra, is among the hundreds of guests expected to attend the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY PROMOTES WELFARE SERVICES FOR SPINAL CORD PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China First Lady Wu Shu-chen on Thursday attended the opening ceremony for a new activity center in Taipei for people who have suffered spinal cord injuries or problems.

According to Wu, who has been confined to a wheelchair since suffering a serious spinal cord injury in an alleged politically motivated traffic accident in 1985, Taiwan currently has about 30,000 spinal cord patients.

"More worrisome is that the number of spinal cord patients has been increasing at a speed of 1,200 people annually," Wu said, adding that many spinal cord patients are young or middle-aged men, with an average age of 28.

Noting that almost all spinal cord injuries are caused by traffic, workplace and sports accidents, Wu said spinal cord patients must endure physical inconveniences and psychological trauma, as well as becoming a burden to family and society.
"Against this backdrop, we should pay more attention to spinal cord issues and to the plight of sufferers," Wu said.
The first lady went on to say that she is pleased to see the opening of the new activity center operated by the Lin Yu-chi Memorial Foundation to promote welfare services for spinal cord patients.

Also present at the ceremony was Cheng Hung-chih, a neurosurgeon at the Taipei Veterans General Hospital (VGH) who specializes in the study of "central nerve injury repair strategies" with the aim of helping spinal cord patients.

Cheng said at the ceremony that the VGH opened a neural regeneration laboratory in May 1996 which was authorized by the Department of Health in July 1998 to begin clinical experiments on spinal cord repair. "So far, we have performed microsurgery and used `growth factors' to treat five spinal cord patients whose conditions have improved significantly with the treatment," he explained.

Cheng said his research team has performed numerous experiments on animals and has found that injured central nervous systems can be regenerated through special treatment using microsurgery and growth factors.
Cheng, who is also chief doctor for First Lady Wu, said the team's research results will be published in an authoritative international magazine later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT INSPECTS MINISTRY OF NATIONAL DEFENSE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday inspected the Ministry of National Defense (MND), where he listened to defense affairs briefings in his capacity as the nation's commander-in-chief.

Chen's first inspection visit to the ministry since taking office came a day after defense minister Wu Shih-wen confirmed that mainland China was showing signs of preparing to test fire its Dongfeng-31 ballistic missile.
Reports have said that mainland China has recently deployed combat troops and advanced weapons in the Nanjing Military Region.

Mainland China is widely expected to continue its military posturing in an effort to intimidate Taiwan's public, but Beijing's fundamental stance toward Taiwan will not begin to become apparent until after the August Bedaihe meeting of senior Beijing officials.

Top military officials, including Wu, Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming, and Director of the General Political Warfare Department Gen. Teng Tzu-lin, lined up to greet Chen according to formal military protocol, an indication of the significance of the event.
The army, navy, and air force commanders-in-chief were also on hand to present their reports.
Chen had previously visited the ministry as the nation's president-elect after his victory in the March 18 election. He was inaugurated on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NATIONAL SECURITY TAX' UNFAIR TO LOCAL FIRMS: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: A proposed "national security tax" on mainland China-based Taiwan firms would be unfair to those companies if the measure were to be put into practice at present, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said on Thursday.

Tsai said the proposed plan would increase the tax burden and operating difficulties for Taiwan businesses with operations in the mainland, who are already heavily restricted by the mainland Chinese authorities.

As the proposal does not form a part of current or future government policies, the MAC head said she has not even assessed the feasibility of the much-debated plan, which was raised recently by S.M. Chen, vice governor-designate of the Central Bank of China.
Tsai, the top government official in charge of charting Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, made the remarks at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, with regard to the long-awaited direct "mini three links" -- trade, transport and postal -- between the Taiwan-controlled Kinmen and Matsu islands and offshore islets of mainland China, Tsai categorically promised to carry out the plan in the near future.

Tsai claimed that she will work out a concrete package to implement the plan within six months, but added that there will not be a specific timetable, because the establishment of such a linkage also depends on the attitude of the other side of the Taiwan Strait.
However, she pointed out that she will first seek to legalize the existing clandestine direct trade between the two sides in an effort to reduce smuggling before imposing the new measures.
If mainland China responds with goodwill to those measures, Tsai said the government will then consider also opening Penghu Island to direct trade, transport and postal links with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTHER RECEIVES LIVE LIVER TRANSPLANT FROM SON

TEXT.P: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung carried out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation on Wednesday, giving a woman a section of liver donated by her son.

Both Lin Yun-ju, 24 and his mother Wu Feng-ying, 50, recovered well from the surgery, and by Thursday morning, Wu's new liver was beginning to secrete badly needed bile, said Dr. Chen Chao-lung head of a team of 10 surgeons who carried out the surgery.
The 12-hour procedure involved two separate operations, one to remove 750 grams, or 56 percent, of Lin's healthy liver and the other to transplant it into Wu, who suffered from biliary cirrohsis.

Chen estimated that Lin will be released from the hospital in a couple of days while Wu will remain in intense care for two weeks to undergo anti-rejection treatment, as is usual for liver graft patients.
It was the hospital's 43rd liver graft operation with liver tissue from a live donor, and the first case where a son donated part of his liver to his mother, said Chen.

He added that people can survive with only 20 percent of their liver, but noted that most liver diseases are not diagnosed until more than 80 percent of the liver is damaged and the patient is already terminally ill.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS VETERAN FOR CREATING SCULPTURE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received a special gift at the Presidential Office on Thursday -- a bronze bust of himself crafted by a retired military serviceman.
Chen told the maker of the bust, Sun Tien-heng, that he deeply appreciates the gift.
"Today is my happiest day since my inauguration simply because of your invaluable present," an emotional Chen told Sun, who is in his late 70s.
Chen, a native Taiwanese who at 49 is the ROC's youngest president, said he was moved by Sun's sincerity and love of Taiwan.

Sun, a veteran who moved to Taiwan in 1949 when the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, has created many bronze sculptures featuring ROC national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the late President Chiang Kai-shek.

After Chen won the March 18 presidential election, Sun spent two months creating Chen's bust with the intention of presenting it to the new president as a gift. A local newspaper reported Sun's wish and Chen's aides helped arrange for Sun to present his creation to the president in person.
Sun said that although he and Chen come from different ethnic groups, he believes that Chen will work for Taiwan's well-being.

"I really admire your democratic thinking and generosity," Chen said in return, adding that Sun's remarks echo his own constant exhortation that the end of the election should mark the beginning of a "grand reconciliation" in local society and the rise of reason.

Chen said he did not think he deserved Sun's gift. "The people who really deserve praise and `enshrinement' are the 23 million residents of this island who have jointly created enviable economic and democratic achievements with limited resources over the past five decades."

The president further said he will treasure Sun's gift as an invaluable objet d'art and place it in his study. "The bust will remind me of Sun's generosity," Chen said, adding that he hopes that ethnic sentiment or rivalry will become things of the past and that people of different origins will work hand-in-hand to create an even brighter future for the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE FISHING BOAT CAUGHT FOR ILLEGAL TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: The Kinmen Coastal Patrol detained three mainland Chinese fishermen on Thursday for illegally peddling agricultural products in Taiwan waters.
The mainland Chinese sampan Tung Teng Yang was gathered with some 40 other fishing boats near the northern shore of Kinmen, when two patrol boats broke up the group and gave chase.

The patrol boats caught up with the Tung Teng Yang, and officers detained the three people on board for illegally trafficking farm goods in violation of a statute governing relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China.
The sampan carried what the coastal patrol said was a typical family-style smuggling group along with their wares, which included dates, seaweed, glutinous rice, tea, sesame oil and ginger.

According to Wu Hsin-bang, interim captain of the Kinmen Coastal Patrol, the northern shore of Kinmen has long been a blind spot in the patrol's anti-smuggling efforts because their large patrol boats have trouble entering the shallow waters in the area.
However, Wu said that the patrol has recently acquired inflatable boats and light patrol craft which have allowed increased access to all waters in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER REMAINS TOP KILLER

TEXT.P: Cancer remained the top killer of local people in 1999 and accidents became the No. 2 cause of death for the first time last year because of the devastating 921 earthquake, the Department of Health (DOH) reported on Thursday.
It was the 18th consecutive year that malignant cancer topped the list of 10 biggest causes of death among the people of Taiwan, the DOH said.
As the 921 earthquake alone claimed 2,437 lives, accidents emerged as the second largest cause of death in 1999, rising from the fourth place a year ago.
The eight other major killers were stroke, heart disease, diabetes, chronic liver disease and cirrhosis, pneumonia, kidney ailment, suicide, and hypertension, in descending order.

Another noteworthy trend was that the number of people who committed suicide has increased steadily in the recent years. In 1998, suicide made the top 10 killers list for the first time in 1998 and moved up one notch to ninth place last year.

According to DOH statistics, a total of 2,281 local people committed suicide in 1999, or an average of six people killed themselves each day. Meanwhile, the highest death rates of suicide were recorded in Taitung County, Nantou County, Keelung City, Yunlin County and Miaoli County.

Nantou, Yunlin and Miaoli ranked among the hardest earthquake-stricken areas. Nevertheless, DOH officials said it needs a long-term observation to determine the impact of the 921 earthquake on the suicide rate.
DOH officials said elderly people were the high-risk group for suicide, while people of 35-49 years old were the age group with the largest number of suicide deaths.

DOH data also show that the death rates of hypertension and pneumonia dropped significantly last year, while the death rate of diabetes rose substantially. "The causes for these changes require further studies," a DOH official said.

According to DOH tallies, the average life expectancy of local people reached 74.85 years in 1999, slightly higher than 1998's 74.83. The statistics also show that local women lived longer than their male counterparts. The average life expectancy of local women was 77.97 years in 1999, while that for their male counterparts was 72.28 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE PROPOSED FOR DISCUSSION AT G8 SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Security in the Taiwan Strait is of grave concern to the international community, and the upcoming G8 summit should put the issue on its agenda for discussion, a British military expert commented on Thursday.

If the G8 group agrees to discuss the issue, it will not only reflect European countries' high degree of concern over security in the strait, but will also help ease Washington's difficulties in "handling" cross-strait affairs, said John Chipman, director of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS).
He made the remarks to reporters following a meeting with Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao to exchange views on the international situation.

Although Chipman said he is willing to raise the proposal with the world's eight major industrial powers, he also admitted that it will be a serious challenge, because Japan may not be willing to discuss issues within its own region, while some European countries may expect the United States to take the initiative in making such a suggestion.

But he added that in any case, inviting G8 countries to discuss the issue of Taiwan Strait security and making a proposal to Taiwan and mainland China to resume their negotiations would be a "pioneering move."

However, Chipman said he will not suggest that the G8 group issue a detailed statement on the issue, elaborating that it would be better for the group to release a cautious declaration to stress the importance of the resumption of cross-strait talks, because cross-strait security is of great concern to both the Asia-Pacific region and the entire international community.

Turning to mainland China, the IISS head said that to his knowledge, the mainland is also willing to rekindle talks with Taiwan as soon as possible. He claimed that Beijing would be unlikely to overreact if the G8 group were to include the Taiwan security issue in its discussions.

The G8 countries -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United States and Russia -- are slated to hold a summit meeting in Okinawa in July to discuss issues related to globalization, currency policies and weapons proliferation.

Earlier the same day, Chipman also met Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung of the Democratic Progressive Party, which now is Taiwan's ruling party following the victory of its candidate Chen Shui-bian in the March 18 presidential race.

On the question of whether Taiwan and mainland China should return to the "one China, separate interpretations" framework supposedly agreed upon by both sides in 1992, Lin said that it is now meaningless to argue over whether the two sides effectively reached any consensus that year.
According to Lin, the most important task for Taiwan and mainland China at present is to reopen talks to forge a new agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIGHT FLARES UP WITHIN JUSTICE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan snubbed the head of the Investigation Bureau (IB) publicly on Thursday after an fight between them went public.

Chen refused to shake hands at the Legislative Yuan with Wang Kuang-yu, director of the IB, although Wang had already offered his hand out at the urging of legislators who tried to mediate between them.
The scene, captured by TV cameras and broadcast on evening TV news shows, was only the tip of the iceberg.
Chen, who has been in office for barely two weeks, was at odds with the IB even before he took office on May 20.

He has criticized the bureau's work and pledged to break the bureau into two or even three separate agencies after he received a brief from the agency before he assumed office, drawing public opposition from the IB.
He complained on Wednesday that he cannot control the bureau although he is technically the direct superior of the Justice Ministry's crime-investigating arm.
Chen accused the national crime-fighting arm of resisting his instructions and those of ordinary prosecutors, and of probing criminal cases selectively.

He claimed that the head of the IB has warned him through various lawmakers to stop "poking his nose into the business of the bureau" which considers itself more a private controlling tool of the country's leaders than a normal law-enforcing agency.

Although they touched a chord among the rank-and-file prosecutors, Chen's complaints did not win much sympathy from his Cabinet colleagues and superiors, with President Chen Shui-bian making it clear that he will not step into the dispute.
Calling it a matter for the Cabinet, the president said he believed Premier Tang Fei can handle the problem properly.

Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chang Chun-hsiung told the press on Thursday that it would be difficult to transform the IB, which is a major pillar of the country's security network, into a simple law-enforcement agency under the Ministry of Justice.
He also said he hoped Chen and Wang can pocket their pride and work together for the nation.
Meanwhile, National Security Bureau Director Ting Yu-chou, who is the country's supreme security official, praised Wang as a hard-working and law-abiding government official.

Ting said the IB plays a major role in national security and cannot be replaced immediately by any other agency. He added that he believed the dispute between Chen and Wang will be solved through time once they learn how to get along with each other.

Also that day, a group of prosecutors from the Chiayi District Prosecutors' Office wrote an open letter on Thursday backing Chen's power struggle with the IB in which they claimed that detectives from the bureau often ignore prosecutors' instructions when probing criminal cases.

Noting that many former justice ministers have been forced to step down after trying to rein in the "intractable" agency, the prosecutors said they would rally behind the minister's efforts to bring the IB under control.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL PLANE AT CENTER OF HK BOMB HOAX
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 8 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong police confirmed on Thursday that they received a phone call from an anonymous man on Thursday evening claiming that a bomb had been planted on an incoming plane.
The plane was allowed to land, whereupon a thorough search was carried out, but no bomb was found.
Although the police would not reveal the plane in question, it was rumored to be a China Airlines plane which arrived in Hong Kong from Bangkok at 7 p.m. and left for Taipei after being searched.
