DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 9, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
68: Nero, emperor of Rome, stabs himself in the throat with a dagger and dies at the age of 31. His early reign was dominated by his mother, Agrippina the Younger. He had his mother and wife murdered, and he may have set the Great Fire of Rome in 64. His cruelty and irresponsibility provoked widespread revolts which led to his suicide.
1672: Peter I, Russian emperor known as "Peter the Great," is born. He extended Russian territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores, reformed the administration of the state, and founded St. Petersburg as a new capital.
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," "Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1908: King Edward VII of England visits Tsar Nicholas II on board the royal yacht in the Baltic Sea, the first meeting between a British monarch and a Russian tsar.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1940: The king and prime minister of Norway order their troops to stop fighting at midnight, surrendering to the Nazis.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned by the Nuremberg tribunal to hang for "crimes against humanity." In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Richard M. Hoban, vice-commander of the US Air Force Logistics Command, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Barbados Deputy Prime Minister Cuthbert Edwy Talma arrives in Taipei accompanied by his wife for a six-day visit.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the mainland Chinese communist regime.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo changes four of eight ministers, three ministers of state and the secretary-general of the Executive Yuan. New ministers named are Walter Fei, finance; Lin Chin-sheng, communications; Wang Tao-yuan, justice; and Chang Feng-shu, interior.
1980: Foreign Minister Chu Fu-sung returns from a 20-day, 6-nation trip to Central America.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: The ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1995: The Parliament of Japan passes a controversial resolution designed to atone for the country's role in World War II.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Mainland China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew appoints Yang Chao-hsiang, former vice minister of education and current chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin Ching-chiang as education minister.
1999: Yugoslavia and NATO sign an agreement for the swift withdrawwal of Serbian forces from Kosovo, following lengthy talks in Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-TAIWAN DEFENSE, AEROSPACE SEMINAR TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A seminar on defense and aerospace cooperation between Taiwan and the United States is scheduled to be held in Taipei on June 16, sources from the USA-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council said on Thursday.
Kurt Campbell, former US deputy assistant secretary of defense, will deliver a keynote speech to the seminar on the prospects of defense relations between the United States and Taiwan.

David Laux, senior director for Asian affairs at the National Security Council during the Reagan administration and former president of the USA-ROC Business Council, will be part of the US delegation.

Other members of the US delegation will include executives from Lockheed Martin Corp., builder of the F-16 jetfighter, the backbone of Taiwan's air defense, and representatives from other US defense industry companies.
ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen has been invited to address the luncheon session, while Alan Hung, an admiral in the ROC Navy, will brief the seminar attendants on Taiwan's strategic situation.

Other members of the ROC side attending the seminar will include former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi, Hsiao Mei-chin, former international affairs director of the Democratic Progressive Party, and Paul Hsu, a senior partner of Lee and Li Attorneys-at-Law.

The defense seminar is part of the activities of the three-day 24th Annual Joint Conference of the USA-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and the ROC-USA Business Council scheduled to be held June 14-16 in Taipei.
US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater is scheduled to go to Taipei next week to make a keynote speech at the high-profile annual joint meeting, the sources said.
Slater will be the first US Cabinet member to visit Taiwan after the new president Chen Shui-bian's inauguration on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer moving down 31.22 points to close at 9,036.66.
Affected by the poor performance in the financial sector, the bourse opened at 9,113.07, and fluctuated between 9,136.75 and 9,011.2 during trading.

A total of 1.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$113.97 (US$3.71 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.4 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$155.64 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 403 to 128, with 75 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only electrical stocks gained ground, moving up by 0.3 percent.

The other categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares and textile issues, both at 1.7 percent, foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 1.2 percent, cement shares at 1.1 percent, and construction stocks at 0.4 percent.

TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 23 points to finish at 9,125, with 149 contract transactions; and September futures lost 29 points to close at 9,210, with 29 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading on Friday were: 9,114 for June; 9,148 for July; 9,239 for September; 9,364 for December; and 9,361 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

June TE futures edged up 0.4 points to close at 503.5, with 877 contract transactions; while July TE futures increased 2.3 points to finish at 503.5, with 46 contract transactions; and September TE futures moved up 6.5 points to finish at 511.5, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT, US CABINET MINISTER TO ATTEND JOINT CONFAB

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and several senior US officials will attend the 24th Annual Joint Business Conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils to be held in Taipei June 14-16, organizers said on Friday.
A spokesman for the Taipei-based ROC-USA Business Council said President Chen will deliver an address at the opening ceremony of the joint conference.
Meanwhile, reports from Washington, D.C. said US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater has also been invited to make a keynote speech at the opening session.

According to the reports, the two business councils and the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), a quasi-official organization authorized by the US government to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties, will formally announce Slater's Taipei visit on Saturday.
Slater will be the first US Cabinet minister to visit Taiwan after Chen was sworn in as the Republic of China's first opposition leader-turned-president on May 20.

Slater is an old friend of US President Bill Clinton. Both are from Arkansas, and Slater was Clinton's special assistant for community and minority affairs back in the late 1980s when Clinton was the governor of Arkansas.
Observers said Slater's presence at the upcoming conference signifies the importance the US government attaches to its business relations with Taiwan.

The theme of this year's conference will be "21st century business opportunities." Hundreds of senior industry and business executives from Taiwan and the United States will attend the three-day conference to discuss a broad range of issues related to information technology, finance and banking, biotechnology, power generation and energy resources, transportation services and many other relevant topics.

Organizers said all conference goers will also be allowed to attend a roundtable meeting on defense and aerospace industry development and a breakfast meeting to be sponsored by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei. This will be the first time that Taiwan participants to the annual joint conference are offered access to the two seminars. In the past, the two events were open only to American business executives.

Organizers further said the agenda of the transportation seminar will discuss the possible impact on harbor and shipping services of Taipei's and Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization later this year, and that the information technology session will focus discussion on the impact of broadband technology on Taiwan's and Asia's telecommunications industry.
In addition, a special seminar on the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular relations will also be held during the annual event.
Organizers will also sponsor a one-day investment seminar on June 15 for multinational business groups or financial institutions to seek suitable joint-venture partners and investment opportunities.

The joint conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils is the largest annual gathering of trade and finance officials and business leaders from the two countries to boost bilateral economic exchanges and cooperation. The event has been held in Taiwan and the United States alternately.
Raymond Burghardt, director of the AIT's Taipei Office and the de facto US ambassador to Taipei, will attend the annual meeting as head of the US delegation.

Other members of the US delegation will include Phil Agrass, a deputy assistant secretary of the US Department of Commerce, Senator John D. Rockefeller, Frank Carlucci, chairman of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, and David Laux, president of the US-Taiwan Business Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KEENLY EXPECTS RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: KOO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been keenly expecting the resumption of official cross-strait dialogue, which was suspended unilaterally by Beijing last year, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China reiterated on Friday.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the quasi-official intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said that sometime this October would be an ideal time for his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, to visit Taipei to reopen official cross-strait dialogue, according to a report in Yomiuri Shimbun on Friday.

In an interview with the Japanese daily, Koo, who is part of an official Taiwanese delegation in Tokyo to attend the funeral service for the late Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi scheduled for Thursday, said a visit by Wang to Taipei to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue is the common wish of most of the people in Taiwan.

Koo, who is also a senior advisor to the ROC president, last visited Shanghai and Beijing in late 1998. He said that if Wang finds it difficult to go to Taiwan, he would be willing to travel to the mainland to resume the talks, according to the paper.

Koo noted that as the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not reached a consensus on the "one China" issue, cross-strait dialogue is conducive to reaching an agreement on the issue. "Both sides can also talk about unification-related matters, as long as the dialogue is resumed," he said.

Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), was previously scheduled to visit Taipei last autumn for the second "Koo-Wang" meeting -- an event that was expected to resume the long-stalled official cross-strait dialogue, the Japanese daily reported.

The visit, however, was unilaterally suspended by Beijing last July after the ROC president at the time, Lee Teng-hui, spelled out a redefinition of the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state" relationship, which Beijing considered as another move by Lee promoting Taiwan independence, the report said.

Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in April 1993, marking a landmark ice-breaking meeting of officially-appointed negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China after more than four decades of no contact in the wake of the civil war in China which ended in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater is scheduled to visit Taiwan next week to make a keynote speech at the 24th Annual Joint Business Conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) & ROC-USA Business Councils, sources told CNA on Thursday.
The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and the two business councils are expected to make the official announcement on Saturday.
Slater will be the first US Cabinet member to visit Taiwan after the new president Chen Shui-bian's inauguration on May 20.

Rupert J. Hammond-Chambers, acting president of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, refused to confirm Slater's visit but stressed that "a strong US delegation will send a strong message concerning how the US views its business relations with Taiwan."

Slater is believed to be an old friend of President Bill Clinton. Both are from Arkansas, and Slater was Clinton's special assistant for community and minority affairs back in the late 1980s when Clinton was the governor of Arkansas.
This trip will represent the first visit to Taiwan by Slater, who became the secretary of transportation in February, 1997, sources said.

In addition to Slater, other members of the US delegation will include Phil Agrass, a deputy assistant secretary of the US Department of Commerce, Senator John D. Rockefeller, Frank Carlucci, chairman of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, and David Laux, president of the US-Taiwan Business Forum.

Raymond Burghardt, director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office and the de facto US ambassador to Taipei, will also attend the annual meeting as head of the US delegation, which will be comprised of several hundred other delegates from the private industrial and business sectors.
The 24th Annual Business Conference of the Councils will be held June 14-16 in Taipei. Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will make a speech at the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYSE INVITES NINE OTHER BOURSES TO FORM GLOBAL STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Stock exchanges in Hong Kong, Europe, Australia, Tokyo, Toronto, Mexico and Brazil are among the nine bourses that have been invited by the New York Stock Exchange to form a global stock market, the Australian Financial Review reported on Friday.
If it takes shape, the stock market would be biggest bourse in the world, worth US$20 trillion and representing about 60 percent of the world's shares, the daily reported.

Australian Stock Exchange managing director Richard Humphry on Thursday declined to comment on the status of the global venture, which would allow 24-hour, cross-border trading aimed at increasing the liquidity of participating stock exchanges and reducing costs.
Initially 1000 large stocks, including 250 in Asia, would be traded, the daily reported.
But response to the proposed venture has initially been lukewarm in Australia, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN TO EVACUATE ROC NATIONALS FROM SOLOMON ISLANDS PUT ON HOLD

TEXT.P: Contingency plans to evacuate Republic of China nationals from the Solomon Islands have been put on hold after fighting in the tiny Pacific island nation reportedly eased, a foreign affairs official said on Friday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Henry Chen said that the ROC embassy in the Solomon Islands reported that the rival parties have reached a two-week cease-fire agreement and that normal flights in and out of the country should resume shortly.

After fighting erupted in the Solomon Islands earlier in the week, the ministry on Thursday convened a task force of officials from various government agencies which decided that a goodwill naval flotilla visiting the area would stand by for an evacuation of ROC nationals until the situation in the country calmed down.
The Solomon Islands is one of 29 nations that has diplomatic ties with the ROC.

MOFA estimates that there are over 800 ethnic Chinese presently in the Solomon Islands, including 50 staff members of the ROC embassy and members of an agricultural mission, all of whom are safe, along with their dependents.
Chen said that the latest report from the ROC embassy said that nine ROC passport holders have boarded the naval ships and are preparing to return home.

Chen stressed that first priority will be given to ROC nationals and passport holders, but added that for humanitarian reasons, it will also do everything in its capacity to help other Chinese residents.

The Solomon Islands has been the scene of ethnic conflict for the past 18 months. The rebel Malaita Eagle Force, led by Honiara lawyer Andrew Nori, took Prime Minister Bartholomew Ulufa'alu hostage on Monday and seized key installations around the capital in an attempted coup.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL OPERATION BENEFITS PARKINSON'S PATIENTS FOR 5 YRS

TEXT.P: Canadian researchers have found that the benefits of an extraordinary operation to help people suffering from Parkinson's disease can last for more than five years.

In this week's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine, Toronto researchers reported that the benefits of having a pallidotomy are long-term. The operation relieves tremors of the hands and feet and allows people with Parkinson's disease to move at a more normal speed.

Pallidotomy involves inserting an electrode into the patient's brain. An electrical current is used to locate and destroy a pea-sized part of the brain that causes the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.
The patient remains awake during the operation in order to help guide the surgeon through the maze of brain cells.

Peter Kingston is one patients who has benefited from having a pallidotomy. He has suffered from Parkinson's for 30 years and could barely walk six years ago. The operation has given him back his mobility.

"The surgery has turned back the clock on their illness," said Dr. Andres Lozano, a pioneer in Parkinson's research and one of the study's authors. "They've reverted back to the stage they were in their illness five years before, where they were more independent."
The surgery isn't a cure. As the disease inevitably progresses, many people have to go back on medication. And the surgery has risks.

"There are some patients, fortunately not in our hands, but in others who have died from this surgical intervention. There are patients who have had strokes and hemorrhages in the brain as a complication of this procedure," said Dr. Anthony Lang, a Toronto neurologist.
Still, Kingston said the risks were worth it. Now he's back working at his regular job and enjoying walks he couldn't have managed before the operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SHOULD BE DENIED US STUDENT VISAS: FEDERATION

TEXT.P: The Federation for American Immigration Reforms has urged the US government to deny student visas to all future mainland Chinese applicants because its feels almost all of them will likely try to stay in the United States after graduating.

The anti-illegal immigrants group pointed out in its latest report that Communist China sends more students to the United States than any other country -- more than 50,000 last year. It added that, when applying for student visas, all of them promised to return home after they finished their education in the US, but almost all of them are expected to stay in the country instead.

Some mainland Chinese students manage to remain by taking hi-tech jobs at American firms, earning them admission as permanent employment-based immigrants. Others marry US citizens, making them eligible to live in America as immediate relatives. Many just "disappear" and remain in the country illegally, pointed out the federation.

A US immigration official in Beijing was quoted as saying that his experience was that 99 percent of mainland Chinese students remain in America after graduating. US counterintelligence officials say that some mainland Chinese students are spies, ordered to report what they learn about physics, computer science, and other high-tech disciplines to the Beijing regime, according to the federation's report.

This was also one of the conclusions arrived at last year by the House Cox Committee on Communist Chinese espionage, which noted in its investigation report that Chinese students have access to high-performance computers at national weapons laboratories, said the federation.

The laws guiding the issuance of visas state that non-immigrant visas should not be granted if the interviewing officer suspects that the applicant does not intend to return to his or her homeland. "Since almost no Chinese foreign students actually return, that should be reason enough to deny student visas to Chinese applicants," emphasized the group.
It cited a recent survey of students at mainland China's top five universities which found that 70 percent of them planned to study abroad, and most of them wanted to go to the United States.

There are 128 American colleges and universities that have at least 100 mainland Chinese students in attendance, with three quarters of all the students being graduate students, according to US statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA BEGINS EVACUATION OF EXPATS IN SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Australia has begun the evacuation of about 700 Australian expatriates and 600 foreign nationals from Honiara as rival militias in the Solomon Islands continue talks on resolving their differences.

Prime Minister John Howard, who is visiting Tokyo, on Thursday left open the possibility of Australian involvement in a peacekeeping force after the HMAS Tobruk landed in Honiara on Thursday night to begin the evacuation.

New Zealand is also sending a frigate to the Solomon Islands to evacuate New Zealand expatriates, and the ship is expected to reach Honiara on Saturday, according to the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday.

Australian Defence Minister John Moore on Thursday night confirmed that about 250 Australians had been taken aboard the Australian naval ship and more are expected to board the frigate, which is scheduled to leave Honiara on Friday morning.
Australia played a leading role in negotiations with the warring rival militias on Thursday concerning the evacuation of the expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS NABBED IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA)'s southern Taiwan operations nabbed two illegal mainland Chinese immigrants on Thursday and are continuing to track down their Taiwan connections, CGA authorities reported on Friday.

A mainland man identified as Lin Xinchuen, 23, from Fujian Province was arrested at the door of a convenience store in Hsinying City, Tainan County. He admitted that he sneaked into Taiwan recently and stayed at a place arranged by a Taiwanese man surnamed Lee.
The other illegal, a 50-year-old, identified as Guo Renzu, also from Fujian, was arrested in Dahshu Township, Kaohsiung County.
Information gathered by CGA officials shows that "snake heads" across the Taiwan Strait have been smuggling mainland people from the mainland to Taiwan at a cost of 21,000-38,000 renminbi per head.

The illegal immigrants, most of whom are from Fujian, are transported by mainland fishing boats to waters off the west coast of Taiwan or the Penghu islands in the Taiwan Strait, where they are picked up by local connections, the CGA officials said.
Meanwhile on Thursday, CGA investigators discovered an illegal oil reservoir in Taichung County, central Taiwan.
The investigators, acting in the company of Taichung police, found the 25,000-liter reservoir and arrested three men, including a driver and the oil's owner.
The police were investigating the source of the illegal diesel.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF MOSCOW-TAIPEI COORDINATION COMMISSION HONORED
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 9 (CNA) (By H.K. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung conferred a medal on Thursday upon Oleg Lobov, head of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, in recognition of his contributions to Taipei-Moscow relations.

Lobov expressed thanks for the medal, and pointed out a link between ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Russia. Chen visited Moscow in 1995, when he was mayor of Taipei, to receive an honorary Ph.D. from Plekhanov Russian Academy of Economics.
According to Lobov, the two countries will continue to develop a closer relationship because of this link.
Lobov has contributed a great deal to the establishment of representative offices in Russia and Taiwan, laying a solid basis for pragmatic diplomacy between the two nations.
Because of Lobov's efforts, a series of Russian cultural and artistic groups have visited Taiwan, while trade and economic relations between the two nations have also taken big strides.
But Lobov's influence dwindled during the latter half of Boris Yeltsin's rule, one example of which is the long stalled direct air links between Taipei and Moscow.
It is understood that State Duma Deputy Alexei Mitrofonov will also be honored by the ROC government with a diplomatic medal later.

DOC.HEADLINE: BCC OPENS KINMEN RELAY STATION TO SERVE BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) formally opened a relay station on the Republic of China-controlled frontline island of Kinmen on Friday to serve audiences on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

BCC, which is owned by the Kuomintang, Taiwan's ruling party until May 20, said the Kinmen relay station will offer round-the-clock broadcasting services for troops and civilians residing in Kinmen as well as for residents in coastal areas of mainland China's Fujian province, which lies opposite Taiwan.
BCC Chairman Chien Han-sheng went to Kinmen to preside over the inauguration of the relay station, which cost some NT$70 million (US$2.3 million).
Chien said the opening of the relay station marks an end to a decades-long monopoly of Kinmen airwaves by mainland China-based radio stations.

According to Chien, since the relay station began broadcasting programs on an experimental basis on April 13, FM 96.3 has become one of the most popular radio channels among military servicemen and civilian residents on Kinmen.
The relay station, located on Mount Tawu, the highest peak in Kinmen, will provide the most popular news, music, fashion and cultural programs broadcast on BCC's various networks, Chien said.

"People residing throughout Kinmen can from now on receive BCC programs all day long," Chien went on, adding: "The approximately 6 million residents of Fujian's Xiamen, Zhangzhou and Chuanzhou areas can also receive our programs clearly."
Chien said he believes that the BCC relay station on Kinmen will soon become the fastest channel for Taiwan investors in the Fujian area wishing to hear information about Taiwan.

"Allowing Taiwan businesspeople in the coastal Fujian area to hear voices from their homeland will mark yet another breakthrough in exchanges across the Taiwan Strait," Chien said, adding that BCC is hopeful that the new relay station will help boost cross-strait cultural and information interchanges.

Chien further said BCC is scheduled next year to open a similar relay station on Matsu, another ROC frontline island off the southeastern mainland coast, to serve garrison troops and civilian residents there. Matsu is only a few kilometers away from the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT ON `PRIVATE VISIT' TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A visit to mainland China by former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan is a "purely personal trip," an official of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said on Friday.

Chiu Chuang-liang, PFP legislative whip, confirmed that Liu took a leave of five days from the PFP caucus to visit a Taiwan businessman friend in the mainland, and added that he is scheduled to return on Sunday.

Legislator Chen Chao-jung, who is close to Liu, said the friend, who has good relations with high-level mainland officials, including President Jiang Zemin, has repeatedly invited Liu to visit, and has tried to arrange for him to meet with Jiang, although Chen said the meeting might not take place given the current cross-strait tension.

Chen said that it is difficult to communicate with the mainland at present, and added that the government should encourage the private sector to set up dialogue channels to convey the mainstream views of the Taiwan people.
He dismissed allegations that Liu has himself solicited meetings with mainland leaders as "absolutely untrue."

Chiu also said that Liu received an invitation from his friend several months ago, and "it is natural" for him to go now. He will apparently also try to learn first-hand about the situation of Taiwan businessmen there during the visit, his first to the mainland.

Chiu noted that a PFP-organized group providing services to Taiwan businessmen in the mainland is expected to go there in July, and said that a series of public hearings will be held in late June to discuss the government's mainland policy and its direction. He pointed out that Liu's visit will give him a better understanding of the situation in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMEN HOST OUTGOING ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 40 congressmen hosted a lunch party at the Capitol on Thursday to bid farewell to outgoing ROC Representative Stephen Chen.

Around 19 senators and 21 representatives, including Trent Lott (R-MS) and Thomas Daschle (D-SD), Republican and Democratic leaders at the Senate, respectively, attended the lunch along with more than 200 dignitaries.

A day earlier at the House of Representatives, William Lipinski (D-IL) also hailed Chen's outstanding professional spirit and diplomatic skills and thanked him for his contribution to the promotion of close and friendly ties between the two countries.
Former Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen is scheduled to take over Chen's post as the Republic of China's de-facto ambassador to the United States at the end of this month.

Lipinski also paid his respects to the 23 million people living in a democratic and prosperous Taiwan. The island's second democratic presidential election on March 18 and its first peaceful transition of central government power on May 20 should be a good model for mainland China, he added.
Lipinski voiced his hope that with the increasing influence of Taiwan's democratization, cross-Taiwan Strait problems can be settled peacefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOOR TO OPEN WIDER FOR MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is to open its doors wider to mainland Chinese people who have married ROC nationals, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday.
The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said it has drafted a bill amending current regulations governing visits to Taiwan by mainland Chinese spouses.

Liu Teh-hsun, director of the MAC's Legal Affairs Department, said at a public hearing sponsored by the opposition People First Party's (PFP's) Legislative Yuan caucus that pending approval by the legislature, the amendment bill will allow mainland spouses to stay in Taiwan for up to one year per visit until such time as they are granted residence status.
At present, mainland spouses can stay for a maximum of six months on each visit.

Under the revised law, Liu said, mainland spouses will also be able to apply to revisit Taiwan for "family reunions" after they leave Taiwan. "And their applications will not be subject to restrictions imposed by the current annual permanent residence quota for mainland spouses," he added.
The new bill will also allow those mainland spouses who have children with legal household registration in Taiwan to extend their duration of stay to three years, Liu said.
Under the new bill, Liu said, each mainland spouse will also be given a health insurance number, so that he or she will be able to join the ROC's National Health Insurance program.
If all goes well, Liu said, the new measures can be implemented from July 1 at the earliest.

At present, the ROC offers an annual quota of 3,600 for mainland spouses applying for permanent residency in Taiwan. PFP legislators present at the hearing urged the government to further increase the quota in order to meet the rising demand.

In response, Liu said the quota is set in-line with the government's population policy. "According to the current rules, it takes only about four years for prospective mainland spouses to obtain permanent residency here," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR APPRECIATES NT$0.01 ON TAIPEI FOREX MART

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated by NT$0.01 against the greenback on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Market on Thursday, closing at NT$30.786.
The local currency opened at NT$30.808 against the US dollar and was traded between NT$30.750 and NT$30.820.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$473 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER ENCOURAGED BY SUPPORT FOR WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-hsin said on Friday that he was encouraged during a regional trade meeting in Australia by the support for simultaneous entry of both sides of the Taiwan Strait into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Lin, who had just returned from Darwin where he attended a trade ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on June 6-7, said that he met with WTO Director-General Mike Moore and US Deputy Trade Representative Richard Fisher during the meeting.

He also held bilateral talks with trade ministers from Japan, Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and Brunei to solicit their support for the Republic of China's entry into the world trade regulatory body.

Lin said that the APEC members gave positive responses to the ROC's WTO bid, with Moore expressing confidence about Taipei's entry, and Fisher saying that he supported Taipei's simultaneous entry with Beijing.

Lin, who also met privately with officials from mainland China, Hong Kong and Singapore during the meeting, added that the mainland has almost completed bilateral entry consultations with WTO members.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADBAND INTERNET CENTURY EDUCATIONAL SUMMIT TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Education and Academia Sinica are to jointly sponsor a "Broadband Internet Century Educational Summit," to be held in Taipei next Tuesday.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, Education Minister Tseng Chih-lan and Cisco Systems President John Chambers will conduct a dialogue on the future development of broadband networking systems and educational networking systems.
A number of scholars, experts, industrialists and researchers will also be invited to attend the summit.

A spokesman for Cisco Systems (Taiwan) Co. said that his company has for several years been making efforts to cultivate Internet professionals in Taiwan. The Cisco Systems Networking Academy was established in Taiwan in September 1998 and presently boasts 33 regional or local schools.
He also noted that Cisco Systems has established 2,615 academies in 61 countries around the world.

The main purpose of establishing these schools, he said, is to help non-profit educational institutes to cultivate more networking talent and break the barrier of educational restrictions around the world.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
