DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 10, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1190: Frederick I, known as "Frederick Barbarossa," Holy Roman emperor and king of Germany and Italy who spearheaded the Third Crusade, is drowned in the Saleph River in Cilicia (now in Turkey) on his way to the Holy Land.
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy, and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1905: China's Ching court starts minting silver coins prior to adopting a silver dollar system.
1922: American singer and actress Judy Garland is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," and "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1926: Korean communists agitate people in Seoul to hold anti-Japanese demonstrations.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: US marines invade the Japanese Ryukyu islands, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors, and makes a 200-percent expansion of its territory.
1970: The ROC and the Republic of the Philippines sign a cultural agreement in Manila.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1972: Chang Feng-hsu assumes office as the new mayor of Taipei, succeeding Henry Kao.
1975: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, addressing the Kuomintang, pledges to carry out Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the late President Chiang Kai-shek's anti-communist policy.
1976: Lin Yang-kang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Reconstruction Department, is appointed mayor of Taipei City by the Executive Yuan.
1980: The Ninth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens at the International Hall of the Civic Aeronautic Administration in Taipei with 109 Chinese and American scholars and experts participating.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern mainland China, defects at the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1990: Alberto Fujimori, of Japanese ancestry, beats Mario Vargas Llosa to win Peru's presidential election.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for infringement of copyright.
1993: The United States announces it will send 300 troops to Macedonia to help the 700 Scandinavian UN troops already there to stabilize the region.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and reaffirms the ROC's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperation programs with Macedonia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: US Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater will travel to Taiwan to attend the annual joint conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) and the ROC-US Business Councils on June 14 and 15 in Taipei, Taiwan, said his office on Friday.

Slater will address the opening session and discuss economic and commercial issues of mutual interest to the United States and Taiwan as well as issues in the transportation sector, according to a press release issued by the Department of Transportation in Washington on Friday.

Slater's visit continues an eight-year tradition in which a US Cabinet-level official has participated in the conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, which is a private, non-profit organization of American and Taiwan business representatives and gathers alternatively in Washington and Taipei.

The US was Taiwan's largest trading partner, absorbing 25.4 percent of Taiwan's exports and supplying 18 percent of its imports in 1999. Taiwan was the seventh-largest trading partner and the eighth-largest export market of the United States last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FOREIGN MINISTER TO FLY TO SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer is scheduled to fly into Honiara on Saturday in an attempt to help end the dispute between two rival militias in the Solomon Islands.
Downer will be joined by the foreign ministers of New Zealand and Botswana and a senior official from Malaysia in efforts to seek a settlement to the current conflict.
Downer on Friday night told reporters that the Commonwealth ministers would seek to get the peace process in the Solomon Islands "back on track."
Meanwhile, the Australian Navy's HMAS Tobruk was scheduled to leave the Solomon Islands on Friday night carrying more than 400 Australian civilians and other foreign citizens out of the country.

A second naval ship, the HMAS Manoora, is due to arrive in the Solomon Islands this weekend. The ship has the capacity to evacuate more than 300 Australians and 300 foreign nationals still in the troubled islands, reported the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOAT PEOPLE GIVING A HEADACHE TO AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Australian government is under pressure after hundreds of boat people escaped from detention camps in Port Hedland and Curtin in Western Australia, following an earlier escape by refugees from a detention center in Woomera in Southern Australia.
About 250 refugees escaped from the Port Hedland and Curtin detention centers following reports of a breakout at Woomera where about 500 boat people escaped on Thursday night.

Many of them have since returned to the centers, but about 250 remain on the loose in the three places as of Saturday. Police and immigration officials have been sent to negotiate their return to the camps.
The Australian government is under pressure to quickly resolve the illegal migrant problem, immigration experts said.

Australia is also facing increased costs for the deportation of refugees, with the budget nearly doubling to A$200 (US$130) million in fiscal 2000-01 from that of the current year, which ends on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TAIWAN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FIRMS LISTED IN TOP 100 WORLDWIDE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 9 (CNA) (By J. J. Hwang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan computer-related firms were listed among the 100 best performing information technology (IT) firms in the world by the US-based Business Week magazine.
The list was compiled by the magazine according to the IT firms' profits.

The wafer foundry Taiwan Semiconductor Corp. ranked fifth on the list, with a profit of US$963 million and US$2.8 billion in total revenues in 1999. The company's revenue increased 98.6 percent over last year's total, while the profit level drove the company's stock price up 147.1 percent.

Another Taiwan-based computer manufacturer, Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Ltd., ranked 27th on the list. It achieved US$242 million in profits and US$1.89 in total revenues for a 45.6 percent increase over last year's revenues. The value of the company's stock also increased from last year, rising 102 percent.

Asustek Computer Inc., whose profits were dented because it used Intel's defective chip in its motherboard, ranked 59th on the list, with earnings of US$466 million and total revenues of US$1.6 billion last year for an annual revenue growth rate of 39 percent and a 11.4 percent increase in the value of the company's stock price, said Business Week.
Finnish telecommunication giant Nokia topped the list, followed by software manufacturers Siebel Systems, Oracle, and Nvidia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUN YUN-SUAN SAID TO RETURN TO TAIWAN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Senior presidential advisor and honorary chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation Sun Yun-suan is slated to return to Taiwan from mainland China on June 17, according to a Taiwan businessman based in the northern mainland province of Shandong.

The Taiwan businessman, surnamed Deng, who maintains close business relations with Sun's nephew, also brushed aside rumors that Sun's health is seriously ailing, saying he has not heard anything about it.

According to Deng, Sun, accompanied by his sister, is currently visiting Qingdao, Shandong province. Deng said Sun will proceed to Yantai on Tuesday to meet with Taiwan businessmen based in that city. He will then pay a visit to Penglai, the town where he was born, before flying back to Taiwan next Saturday.
Sun, a widely respected political figure in Taiwan, served as premier from 1978 to 1984. He was born in Shandong province in 1913.

DOC.HEADLINE: STAFF TRIES TO DISPEL MISGIVINGS ABOUT LU'S `BAD GUY' REMARKS (I)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu's staff said on Saturday that she never said anything to the effect that President Chen Shui-bian will play the role of the "good guy" while she plays the role of the "bad guy" in the new government.

The staff was trying to counter the flap caused by Lu's remarks while addressing the National Forum on Women's Affairs. Lu avoided the media on Saturday morning, only passing a message through her security guards that she "would not accept interviews."

Lu said during her address on Friday that men have been responsible in the past for causing the tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and that Beijing has vented its anger on two Taiwanese women -- herself and A-mei, the pop diva who sang the ROC national anthem at President Chen's inaugural ceremony.
Lu praised President Chen Shui-bian's "high intelligence" for picking her as vice-president and to play the role of "bad guy."

She also pointed out that Chen also asked Tsai Ing-wen to serve as the top policy-maker concerning the ROC's mainland policy and Chung Chin to be the government's spokesman, allowing the "beautiful voice of Taiwanese women to emanate from the political stage."

The Presidential Office later on Friday issued a statement saying that the nation's constitution provides for the president to be responsible for military affairs, foreign relations, cross-strait affairs, and major policy decisions.

The statement said that some people may believe that related policies or comments related to the above mentioned areas of responsibility carry a "bad guy and good guy" design, or that such a design has been used with the purpose of confusing the actual meaning of the government's policies, but this is "untrue."
Members of Lu's staff said she "absolutely" did not say that "President Chen plays the role of the good guy, and she plays the role of bad guy."

According to her staff, Lu actually meant that Chen was wise in choosing a woman deputy, and that mainland China, from President Jiang Zemin to various news media, which have called her a "traitor" and "scum of the Chinese nation," have relentlessly launched a smear campaign against her and have turned her into the "bad guy."

The staff said that the Vice President does not think the statement issued by the Presidential Office was aimed at her and stressed that there is good coordination between the president and vice president, adding that the vice president will respect the nation's constitution.

They said that the timing of the Presidential Office's statement creates the false impression of a connection to her statements, adding that the public need not worry about there being poor communication within the Presidential Office.

Sources at the Presidential Office said privately on Saturday that Lu needs to be careful in her articulation because of her high-profile position and that her words could trigger different responses if they are over interpreted.

The opposition People First Party urged that the vice president exercise self restraint and that the Presidential Office explain clearly the vice presidential powers in order to stave off similar controversies in the future.
Chiu Chuang-liang, the PFP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that Lu should restrain herself and should not randomly speak on behalf of the Presidential Office. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: STAFF TRIES TO DISPEL MISGIVINGS ABOUT LU'S `BAD GUY' REMARKS (II)

TEXT.P: Vice Professor Kuo Cheng-liang of Soochow University even suggested reforming the constitution to give the president the power to replace the vice president if Lu continues unchecked.

Kuo said that Lu's remarks on Friday are tantamount to a confirmation that Taiwan is using a "double-handed" strategy in the handling of cross-strait relations, which he said endangers national security.

Kuo noted that Chen of the pro-independence DPP party has continued to send out conciliatory messages to the other side of the Taiwan Strait since his election on March 18, but the United States and mainland China might question Chen's goodwill and sincerity because of Lu's comments.

Lu, a stalwart of the DPP, triggered a strong response from Beijing after commenting in an interview following the Mar. 18 election victory that Taiwan should be considered a "remote relative and close neighbor" of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA MUST WALK ITS OWN PATH SAYS ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said on Saturday that Asia must walk its own path, rather than blindly pursue western values.

While hailing such western values as liberty and equality, Lee said that Asia cannot just follow the road of western countries. "We must walk our own path so as to be able to create a new era for Taiwan in the coming new millennium, because our environments have become too deplorable," he stressed.

He said that if mainland China's level of petroleum consumption reached Taiwan's present level, the entire global supply, at present production levels, would not be enough to meet the mainland demand, pointing out that this indicates that Taiwan has gone too far in terms of the amount it consumes.
"If this situation continues, we will not be able to secure sustained development, and this will affect our younger generations," he noted.

Judging from history, Lee said Asia has a rich legacy of contributions to the entire world and claimed that the continent can make even greater contributions to mankind if it knows which direction to move in.
Lee made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit, whose focus this year was on the "Dilemma of Asian Values."
Scores of representatives from 26 Asian cities took part in the two-day event sponsored by the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs at the Grand Hotel.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou also gave a speech at the gathering, welcoming the foreign dignitaries with a quote from Confucius -- "it is a great pleasure to meet friends from far away."
Ma said this event provides a good opportunity for cultural exchanges among Asian countries, and he expressed the hope that the summit could be further bolstered in the future.

He said the Taiwan City Government attaches a great deal of importance to cultural activities as part of its efforts to build Taiwan's largest city into a world-class capital by giving its citizens the chance to fully participate in all these activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EVIDENCE OF KICKBACKS FOR FRIGATES PURCHASE: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: There has been no evidence that any one in Taiwan received a commission from the purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates in 1991, said the Ministry of National Defense (MOND) on Saturday.

In a response to reports in the Paris-daily Le Figaro on Friday, the ministry pointed out that a special committee consisting of military prosecutors and ombudsmen at the Military Justice Bureau had been formed last year to look into allegations that kickbacks were involved in the US$2.8 billion deal.

Both Chief of the General Staff Tang Yiau-min and the defense minister at the time, Tang Fei, who is now the premier, have vowed to get to the bottom of the case, but the military investigators have thus far turned up no evidence supporting Le Figaro's claims that military leaders and former ruling party Kuomintang's leaders benefited from the deal.

The MOND said its investigators have asked French authorities on six different occasions for more information into the alleged scandal, and the French side's reply each time has not implicated anyone in Taiwan.

The MOND added that, according to the terms of the contract, it is entitled to claim damages from the frigates' French builder if it is discovered that any kickbacks were factored into the price tag of the warships.

Le Figaro quoted anonymous sources as saying that Thomson-CSF, the French builder of the six frigates, paid a total of 2.5 billion francs in commission to Taiwan's Kuomintang officials, senior military officers, and even Beijing officials to preempt their opposition.

The paper said the kickbacks were paid with the French government's connivance, adding that ROC Navy officer Kuo Li-heng was imprisoned for receiving a payment of 1.5 million francs from Thomson-CSF brokers.
Former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas has come under investigation for allegedly accepting bribes for the approval of the sale of the warships to Taiwan in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL DRAGON BOAT RACE OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2000 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race officially kicked off on Saturday at Tachia Park, located alongside the Keelung River, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening ceremony.

Addressing the opening of the traditional event in commemoration of the patriotic poet Chu Yuan, Ma called on the public to cultivate their sense of team spirit and increase their health by participating in the annual activity.

Foreign dignitaries, including ambassadors from Malawi and Panama, as well as trade representatives from Holland and Bolivia, along with ROC central government and municipal officials in charge of sports affairs, also took part in the event.
A total of 71 teams from both Taiwan and abroad are competing for group trophies in the two-day race.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU PILGRIMS WILL TAKE LEGAL ROUTE TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese followers of Matsu, the goddess of the sea, will begin their annual pilgrimage to mainland China as scheduled on July 16 by taking a lawful route through a third country or area, said the chairman of Chenlan Temple on Saturday.

Yen Ching-piao made the announcement after days of heated debate on the issue of direct pilgrimages from Taiwan to mainland China. He said that even if the government cannot complete the measures related to direct cross-strait pilgrimage sailing before July 16, the followers of Matsu, who worship at Chenlan Temple in Tachia, Taichung, will depart on that date as was earlier decided upon during a solemn ceremony.
Yen said the pilgrims will take a legal route through a third country or area, instead of going directly to mainland China, to the goddess' traditional home in Meizhou, Fujian province.
Yen said he had pushed for direct cross-strait sailing because he wanted to spare the elderly followers from the burden of a long and laborious trip.

He pointed out that the followers appreciate the new government's goodwill, noting that the Mainland Affairs Council had said earlier this month that it would present a proposal within a month on opening the Taichung-Meizhou route on a "trial basis."

But Yen said that after asking Matsu and deciding on the date of departure, the MAC backed down from its promise, saying the matter involved national security as well as quarantine problems and the issue of which flag to fly on the vessel and would not be resolved in time.

Chenlan Temple had planned to lease a Singaporean passenger ship to directly transport pilgrims to Meizhou from Taichung Harbor, making a stopover either at the Taiwan-controlled frontline island of Kinmen or the offshore county of Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFI DELEGATION TO VISIT MAINLAND IN LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: A trade promotion delegation of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) will visit mainland China from June 25 to July 2.

CNFI Chairman K. C. Lin will travel at the head of the delegation, which will visit Beijing, Shanghai and Wuxi, at a time when signs of reduced tensions have appeared in relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait following the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian on May 20.
It will be the second CNFI trade promotion mission to visit mainland China since 1996, when the first CNFI delegation, led by former chairman Kao Chin-yen, headed to the mainland.

Bilateral Taiwan-mainland China relations began to sour in 1996 after mainland China test-fired missiles in the Taiwan Strait ahead of the island's presidential elections and after an unofficial visit by former President Lee Teng-hui to the United States in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ATTENDS COMMENCEMENT OF CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday attended the commencement of National Cheng Kung University in southern Taiwan and urged the graduates to become successful trouble-shooters.

He said that he came to the commencement to share the joy of the graduates and to extend his appreciation to the university for the acception of the university's president, Weng Cheng-yi, to serve as National Science Council chairman in the new ROC government.
Chen quoted a recent "Commonwealth" magazine survey of 100 major local enterprises that found that Cheng Kung University graduates were the most sought after graduates by the enterprises.
He thus praised the university's achievements and urged the graduates to pursue further success based on the already-established reputation.

Chen said that success does not mean defeating others, but surpassing oneself, and added that all people must be well prepared for the 21st century so as to win a seat for Taiwan in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SHIP GATHERS INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION NEAR TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 10 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force confirmed on Friday that a mainland Chinese intelligence-gathering ship recently sailed through waters off the Boso Peninsula near Tokyo.
The Sankei Shimbun daily reported that this was the first time that a mainland Chinese intelligence-gathering vessel had been spotted operating in that area.

According to the report, the vessel passed through the Tsushima Strait between May 14-20 and proceeded in a northward direction, sailing through the Tsugaru Strait between May 23-26. It then headed south to the Boso Peninsula area around May 30.
Later, the ship sailed through waters off southern Shikoku and returned to mainland Chinese waters on June 9 after staying in waters 300 kilometers west-northwest of the Amami Big Island on June 5.
The Japanese government expressed its displeasure over the intelligence-gathering activities of the mainland Chinese vessel.

Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Komu Nonaka took up the issue when he met with a visiting Beijing official in Tokyo on Friday, saying that such activities were not conducive to the development of bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE-DAY ARTILLERY DRILLS BEGIN ON MONDAY

TEXT.P: The ROC military is slated to conduct three days of artillery firing drills in the waters off the coast of the frontline Little Kinmen Island beginning on Monday, the Kinmen Defense Command announced on Saturday.
Military sources stressed that this is only a routine training exercise and called on the public not to speculate over the issue and to stay calm during the three-day period.

According to the sources, the drills will take place as originally scheduled and have nothing to do with the recent spate of military exercises by mainland Chinese troops in the coastal region opposite Taiwan or with the heated debate concerning direct religious voyages by Taiwan pilgrims to mainland China's Fujian province.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 11, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1488: James III of Scotland is murdered after his defeat at the Battle of Sauchieburn, Stirling. He is succeeded by his son, James IV.
1727: George II of England accedes to the throne following the death of his father, George I, the first Hanoverian king of England.
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a US representative and was the only legislator to oppose US involvement in both World Wars.
1898: A reform movement, initiated by Kang Yu-wei and Liang Chi-chao, gains the sympathy of Emperor Kuang Hsu but meets with strong opposition from the Empress Dowager Tzu Hsi. The movement came to an inglorious end in only 100 days.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1947: China protests to the Soviet Union against its invasion of Sinkiang.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker's.
1955: Horrified spectators witness the Le Mans racetrack in France becoming a scene of carnage when one of the cars competing in the 24-hour Grand Prix loses control and plunges into the grandstand, killing 85 people and injuring 200 others.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1970: Aleksandr Feodorovich Kerenski, the prime minister of Russia in 1917 before the Bolshevik Revolution, dies in exile in New York.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director -general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River," and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden, and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada, bearing two gold and four bronze medals.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG QUAKE HITS CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale again hit the central Taiwan county of Nantou early Sunday morning, injuring 16 people, police said.
The quake took place at 2.23 a.m., with its epicenter at 47.4 kilometers north of the Jade Mountain. Five aftershocks with magnitudes ranging from 4.3 to 5.1 were recorded.

This was the second time in less than nine months that the mountainous Nantou County was stricken by strong quakes. The landlocked country was still recovering from the killing quake which hit Sept. 21 last year, killing more than 2,400 people islandwide.
The quake was felt on the other parts of the island, including Yunlin, Tainan, Taitung, Hualien and Taipei.

Seismologist with the Central Weather Bureau said that the early morning quakes were the aftershocks of the Sept. 21 quake, and had nothing to do with the quakes which hit Indonesia and Japan last week.
More than 12,000 aftershocks of the Sept. 21 quake have been recorded so far.
Meanwhile President Chen Shui-bian asked the government agencies to be on the alert against the quakes so as to minimize the possible causalities.
Premier Tang Fei, who is still hospitalized at the Veterans General Hospital, instructed the troops stationed in Central Taiwan to be well prepared against the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Presidential Office, National Security Council and Mainland Affairs Council will be jointly in charge of the policymaking on cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.
The China Times:
Strong earthquake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale hit Taiwan.
The United Daily News:
Premier Tang Fei will meet with related government officials over direct cross-strait pilgrimage sailing on Monday.
The Liberty Times:
Strong quake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale shakes Taiwan early Sunday.
The China Post:
Syria President Assad dies at 69.
The Taiwan News:
Role-playing by vice president denied.
The Taipei Times:
Chen 'dissatisfied' with Lu's remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AFTERSHOCKS EXPECTED: SEISMOLOGIST

TEXT.P: More aftershocks with magnitude of up to five on the open-ended Richter scale are likely to jolt Taiwan in the next two weeks, a seismologist warned on Sunday.
Hsin Tsai-chin, deputy director of the Central Weather Bureau, made the remarks while briefing Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun on the latest earthquake which hit Taiwan early Sunday morning.
The quake, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale, jolted the mountainious Nantou county in central Taiwan at 2: 37 a.m., leaving two dead and 35 injured.
Hsin said that more than 100 aftershocks, eight of them with magnitude of four, have been recorded by 10 a.m.

He said that most of the quakes repeatedly jolted the mountainous areas stricken by the 7.3-scale Chichi quake, which had left over 2,400 people dead, 11,000 injured and 100,000 homeless, on Sept. 21 last year.
Although those quakes had only limited impact on the densely populated city areas, but they may add to the fragility of the earth surface of the areas, and thus causing frequent landslides.
Saying that more aftershocks will come in the next one to two weeks, Hsin however ruled out the possibility of new quakes that will be stronger than the Chichi quake. (Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S INAUGURATON MARKS CULMINATION OF TAIWAN'S REFORMS

TEXT.P: US Representative Tom Lantos (D-Cal.) said on Friday that the May 20 presidential inauguration of Democratic Progressive Party leader Chen Shui-bian "marked the culmination of decades of political, social and economic reform" of the Republic of China.

Lantos told the House floor that "Chen's ascent to power -- the first President not a member of the long-dominant Kuomintang (KMT) party -- is only the latest illustration of the democratic culture that characterizes Taiwan in the 21st century."

Taiwan reflects the principles envisioned by Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founding father of the Republic of China, when he led the successful movement to overthrow the Chinese emperor and the imperial system nearly 90 years ago, he said.

While events following Dr. Sun's victory have been tumultuous -- civil wars, World War II, the establishment of the People's Republic of China, and the transfer of the Republic of China to Taiwan, this history has "strengthened the Taiwanese people and forced them to overcome obstacles in the way of their freedom and prosperity," emphasized the California Democrat.
Lantos said he is confident that Taiwan under the leadership of President Chen Shui-bian will continue to work for peace with mainland China in the years to come.

He urged members of the US Congress to join him in offering wholehearted congratulations to President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu on their inaugurations, and in commending the people of Taiwan for their commitment to peace, democracy and human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP DELEGATION WILL VISIT MAINLAND CHINA TO PROMOTE RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party (NP) will organize a delegation to visit the mainland to promote reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Elmer Feng, NP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said on Sunday.
Feng said that the delegation, at the invitation of Beijing's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will depart for the mainland next Sunday for a weeklong visit.

Before the departure, Feng said the delegation will confer with Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, and officials of the Straits Exchange Foundation, ARATS' Taiwan counterpart, to garner their opinions in order to convey a more accurate voice of Taiwan's government to Beijing leaders.

Feng said that the delegation members will first stop in Shanghai where they will call on Wang Daohan, ARATS chairman and mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan. He added that they will then travel to Beijing to meet with leaders there.

Feng said that the delegation will not rule out the possibility of exchanging views with Beijing leaders on direct cross-strait links, the "mini" cross-strait links, and direct cross-strait religious pilgrimages -- all issues that are being hotly debated in Taiwan.
He noted that the development of cross-strait ties is now stalled over the "one China" row, and he expressed his hope that the visit will help secure a breakthrough.

Beijing has insisted that Taipei embraces the "one China" principle before the two sides can resume stalled talks, while Taipei has maintained that "one China" can be an issue -- but not a precondition -- for talks.

Feng said that the two sides need a dialogue, as cross-strait tensions continue to simmer in the wake of the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian on May 20, despite his series of conciliatory notes. The NP official said that his party, which has long supported unification, is in a good position to help both sides resume dialogue as well as reduce misunderstanding between them.
Feng said that six NP legislators have confirmed that they will take part in the delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER TAKES COMMANDING OF 6/11 QUAKE STRICKEN AREA RESCUE WORK

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun took command on Sunday of government rescue work in the area stricken by the same day's earthquake.
On behalf of Premier Tang Fei, who is recovering from a surgery at General Veteran's Hospital in Taipei, Yu will supervise related government agencies in implementing the quake rescue work.

Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsian and Chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan Chen Hsi-huan briefed the vice premier on quake-related damage in Nantou County as well as the COA's preliminary rescue efforts.

Yu also visited the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transport and Communications and the Central Anti-Disaster Center of the Ministry of Interior on Sunday morning to get first hand information on the earthquake, which jolted the central Taiwan at 2:23 a.m. on Sunday.
Premier Tang Fei ordered related government agencies to take inmediate action to deal with the damages and casualties caused by the earthquake.
The Central Taiwan Reconstruction Committee, led by State Minister Huang Jung-tsun, resumed its duties on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE MEASURING 4.7 HITS TAICHUNG ON SUNDAY AFTERNOON

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale hit the central Taiwan of Taichung early afternoon on Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced, adding that no casualties or property damage were inmediately reported.
The CWB said that the epicenter was located 47.1 kilometers southeast of Taichung and the quake occurred at 12:47 p.m. on Sunday.

The earthquake shook the Tehchi area of Taichung County, Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, Kuken in Yunlin County, Taichung, and Changhua with a Richter scale force of 2. The temblor was also felt in Miaoli, Chiayi, Toulio and Hualien, where it hit with an intensity of 1 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING EXPRESSES CONCERNS OVER STRONG EARTHQUAKE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) sent a message expressing its concern for victims of the strong earthquake which jolted Taiwan early Sunday morning.

The temblor, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale, hit central Taiwan, causing great consternation among local people, especially in Nantou County, which had borne the brunt of the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999 and left more than 2,300 death around the island.

ARATS said that it learned about Sunday's quake from Taiwan media reports that the quake had left at least two dead and more than 30 injured. The organization said that it wished to extend its sympathy and condolences to the quake victims.
ARATS is a semi-official body set up by mainland China to communicate with Taiwan in the absence of official ties. Its Taiwan counterpart is the Straits Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO GOVERNOR ISHIHARA SPEAKS HIGHLY OF ROC LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Outspoken Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara spoke highly of the Republic of China's former President Lee Teng-hui, President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on Sunday.
In a front page Sankei Shimbun article, Ishihara said that he was deeply impressed by the Republic of China's first peaceful transition of power on May 20, which the Tokyo mayor had attended.

Ishihara said that he would never forget the kindness and respect shown by the newly-inaugurated Chen when he escorted former President Lee away from the inaugural site immediately after the transfer of power.

He compared Lee's facial expression at the time to that of a Japanese Samurai warrior -- satisfied that he had fought the good fight. Ishihara added that although Lee's expression may have caused speculation about his role in the defeat of the ruling Kuomintang, there is no doubt that Lee is a patriot. He said that Japan's political scene has lacked such a ruler since the end of World War II.

Ishihara also gave praise to President Chen for his determination and dedication in supporting the welfare and interests of the people of Taiwan, in spite of assuming power at the relatively young age of 49.
Ishihara said that he was also deeply impressed by the gentle yet determined look in the eyes of Vice President Annette Lu.

The controversial mayor noted that President Chen and his Vice President Annette Lu had been imprisoned for their political beliefs and have paid highly for their successful pursuit of democracy and freedom. The sharp expressions in their eyes stem from their devotion to their beliefs and willingness to sacrifice, qualities that cannot be found in Japanese politicians today, Ishihara said.

Ishihara called on all Japanese politicians to emulate Lee, Chen and Lu. He stated that Japanese politicians should fight for the interests of the people and the nation, instead of engaging in factional party politics and infighting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUDSLIDE ISSUE TAKES CENTER STAGE AFTER EARTHQUAKE

TEXT.P: The government is rushing to prepare against possible mudslides after an earthquake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale hit central Taiwan early Sunday, with thunderstorms forecast for the next several days.
Premier Tang Fei on Sunday said the government will allocate NT$200 million (US$6.5 million) to a mudslide prevention and control fund.

Tang, who is still recovering from surgery at Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, said that the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the Council of Agriculture (COA), and other government agencies have all thrown in their efforts in response to the Sunday quake.

According to government spokesman Chung Chin, Tang telephoned Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen immediately after the quake and instructed Wu to order troops in central Taiwan to coordinate with local government officials in disaster response efforts.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) recently completed a draft proposal to mark off mudslide-prone zones and limit large-scale development in those areas. Nearly 300,000 hectares will be protected from development under the proposed plan.

Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pei-hsian on Sunday urged the central government to set up a mudslide preparation fund ranging from NT$500 million (US$16 million) to NT$1 billion (US$32 million) to provide for immediate, effective help to the government-designated disaster area. Nantou County was the epicenter of both Sunday's temblor and last September's devastating quake, which measured 7.3 on the Richter scale.

Peng also noted that his proposal for the military to adopt mudslide-prone zones has been accepted by Tang. Peng said that placing responsibility for these zones on the armed forces will be beneficial to mudslide prevention efforts as a whole.
Tang was defense minister at the time of last year's Sept. 21 earthquake, which killed 2,400 people. Land-locked Nantou County is still recovering from the killer quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 ACTIVISTS TO UNVEIL ALTERNATIVE OPTIONS TO 4TH NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: Six activists opposed to the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear plant are to unveil alternative options to the controversial project on Monday.

The six, including Lai Ching-lin, ruling Democratic Progressive Party whip in the Legislative Yuan, as well as five college professors, have been confirmed as members of the roughly 20-member reassessment committee. They are expected to contend with five scholars in the committee who are in favor of continuing the construction.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs set up the committee to reassess the project. The committee is expected to deliver its report within six months.
Lai and the scholars are expected to unveil six alternative options to the proposed nuclear plant in Kungliao, Taipei County, in northern Taiwan.
The options reportedly include the use of alternative energy sources, including wind-generated electricity, geothermal power, and solar energy, all of which are better for the environment.

Other options include liberalizing the power industry by allowing the private sector to compete in the power-generation industry and thereby cut costs. The government has already pumped NT$40 billion into the construction of the 4th nuclear plant, a figure that could expand by another NT$40 billion if those contracted work on the plant is stopped.
However, continuing the construction could be even more costly, as the total cost of the nuclear facility reportedly could accumulate to NT$400 billion.

Other options to be presented include increasing the efficiencies of the island's other three nuclear power plants, power co-generation, and measures to conserve energy. Finally, to avoid scrapping the new plant altogether, they will advise turning it into a natural gas power generator, which would require building a natural gas pipeline from Yungan in Taoyuan County to Aoti in Taipei county.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFORMING TAIWAN INTO 'GREEN SILICON ISLAND' TOP PRIORITY: CEPD

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic policy planner has said that Taiwan will be transformed into a "green silicon island" by pooling the strengths of the government and private sector.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the idea was broached by President Chen Shui-bian during the presidential campaign, and that the first priority of a national four-year plan will be to transform the Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

Chen said that to realize the goal, the CEPD has to cease its outdated thinking, which puts too much emphasis on production, and find a way to make economic development compatible with environmental protection.
Chen said that he is hoping that science-based industrial parks, which have successfully blended economic development and environmental protection, can be expanded to the whole island.
The CEPD will also combine the proposed national pension and subsidy for the elders so as to efficiently use social welfare resources, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR MANUFACTURING COMPANY UNAFFECTED BY EARTHQUAKE
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, Northern Taiwan, June 11 (CNA) (By Wen-Hung Fang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip foundry, was unaffected by the major earthquake that hit central Taiwan on Sunday, the firm has announced.

TSMC Vice President K.C. Chen said that there was no power outage in the company's fabrication plants after the earthquake struck. She said that TSMC's buildings, water distribution, and power distribution systems were unaffected as well.
According to Chen, initial estimates indicate that less than half a day's wafer moves was lost. Normal manufacturing resumed after equipment inspections, she added.

Sunday's temblor measured 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale and hit central Taiwan's Nantou County. The land-locked county was still recovering from last year's Sept. 21 earthquake, which killed more than 2,400 people islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD IT HEAVYWEIGHTS GATHER IN TAIPEI TO KICK OFF YEAR 2000 WCIT

TEXT.P: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology WCIT), the first such event ever held in Taiwan, will formally kick off its three-day session on Monday, June 12, with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.

Many of the world's IT leaders will attend the session, including Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, Cisco Systems President and CEO John Chambers, Hewlett-Packard President and CEO Carly Fiorina, and many others.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will host a reception on Sunday night to welcome the participants in the meeting.

Other important IT leaders like Acer Group Chairman and CEO Stan Shih, Prof. Lester C. Thurow of MIT, 1999 Nobel Laureate in Economics Prof. Robert A. Mundell, US Senator John D. Rockefeller, Ericsson President Kurt Hellstrom, and Patricia Hewitt, UK minister for Small Business and e-Commerce, will also serve as speakers at the panel discussion.

Fiorina will also attend a summit meeting with local IT leaders on June 13 at the invitation of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), Kao I-hsin, secretary general of CETRA said on Sunday.

Gates, Chambers, and Fiorina will meet with Lee Yuan-tseh, President of Academia Sinica, and Minister of Education Tseng Chih-lang on educational networking systems development at a separate meeting to be sponsored jointly by Academia Sinica and the ROC Ministry of Education.
The WCIT will close on June 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN PACIFIC CITIES TO PROMOTE CULTURAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Officials from 30 Asian Pacific cities reached an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" Sunday in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.

They signed a draft proclamation Sunday afternoon on their plan to establish the mechanism, called "the Asian Pacific Capital of Culture", at the conclusion of the two-day summit sponsored by the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of the Taipei city government.
Under the plan, these cities will sponsor various activities in turn to promote cultural exchanges among them. They include Anchorage, Los Angeles, Perth, Seoul, Jakarta, Bangkok, and Taipei.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the bureau of cultural affairs of his city government will soon establish a website to help promote the activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 12, or the 11th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1667: Jean-Baptiste Denys, personal physician to King Louis XIV of France, successfully transfuses the blood of a sheep into a 15-year-old boy.
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1917: King Constantine of Greece abdicates in favor of his son, Prince Alexander.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as US ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before going to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1931: As part of their crackdown on bootleggers, Chicago police arrest Al "Scarface" Capone, the Italian-born American gangster who ruled the Chicago underworld with an iron fist, charging him with 5,000 offenses under America's Prohibition laws.
1938 China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1975: A judge rules that Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's landslide victory in 1971 was invalid becuase civil servants illegally aided her campaign.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: Strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human-powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohamed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabian.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served as prime minister for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other person in the 20th Century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti-communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members of both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 81.22 points to close at 8,955.44.
Affected by Sunday's earthquake, the bourse opened at 9,065.22 and fluctuated between 9,083.85 and 8,935.47 during trading.

Losers outnumber gainers 416 to 115, with 65 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by cement stocks and construction shares, both at 2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.4 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1 percent, and electrical shares at 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CASE OF JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS THIS YEAR IN TAIWAN REPORTED

TEXT.P: The first case of Japanese encephalitis this year in Taiwan was reported in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, doctors said on Monday.

The patient, a 56-year-old cleaner who lives in Pingtung county, was sent to hospital on June 3 after he developed persistent symptoms of high fever, headache, and drowsiness. His family originally suspected that he had got a cold.
Doctors diagnosed him as suffering from a central nervous system disorder, and samples sent to the Department of Health confirmed that he had Japanese encephalitis.
The patient is now being transferred to the Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital for treatment.

Doctor Yang Bing-chang of Paochien Hospital in Pingtung said that although Japanese encephalitis has mostly struck young children, adults can also be affected, adding that one's living environment is the largest factor in acquiring the disease.

Yang said that people who live near paddy fields or hog farms are more vulnerable. The patient's occupation may also have played a role. As a cleaner, he may have contracted the disease from a mosquito bite.
The Bureau of Health in Pingtung County has urged the public to maintain a clean living environment and has stepped up efforts to exterminate mosquitoes in order to cut the risk of contraction.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FOREIGN MINISTER WARNS OF VOLATILE SECURITY SITUATION

TEXT.P: Australia's defense secretary has warned that the country is facing a volatile security situation in the region due to tensions across the Taiwan Straits, the nuclear rivalry in South Asia, and the powder keg on the Korean peninsula.
The Sydney Morning Herald on Monday quoted Allan Hawke as saying that "Australia is geographically positioned within a region of rapidly changing economic, political, and social circumstances."

In a speech to an ex-services group in Melbourne recently, Hawke also warned of the continuing crisis in Indonesia, which is facing separatist movements in Aceh and West Papua, and the instability in Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific countries, including Fiji and the Solomon Islands.

Even more dangerous, he said, are the band of potential big-power confrontations that involve some of Australia's major trading partners, the security of the shipping lanes crucial to regional economic growth, and the strategic interests shared by Australia and its traditional ally -- the United States, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ASKED TO HELP END CRISIS IN SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Solomon Islands police chief has made an urgent request to Australia to help end the crisis as the South Pacific country moves toward a possible civil war after a raiding party from Papua New Guinea seized control of one the nation's islands.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Saturday went to Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, with his counterparts from New Zealand and Botswana and a senior Malaysian official in an attempt to help resolve the dispute between rivalry militias following a coup on Monday by the Malaitan Eagle Force militia, which is holding the country's prime minister in prison.

Downer said Australia will not send any troops to restore order and would only send troops into Honiara to help with any further evacuation of Australians and other foreigners if the security climate deteriorated, adding that Australian troops would serve as peace keepers if they were sent.
His comments came in response to comments by John Homelo, acting police chief of the Solomon Islands, who told reporters that "what I'm looking for is assistance from Australia -- we need some help."
So far, Australian and New Zealand naval ships have evacuated more than 600 Australians, New Zealanders, and other foreigners, including American, Canadian, and British citizens.

There are now about 200 Australians who still remain in the Solomon Islands waiting to be evacuated. Australia's second naval ship is due to arrive in the Solomon Islands on Monday to make further evacuations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS DPP WINS INCREASED RECOGNITION, SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan people's attitude toward major domestic political parties has changed significantly following the island's first democratic transition of power, according to the results of an opinion survey released on Monday.

The telephone poll of 1,011 adult residents, conducted by the mass-circulation United Daily News (UDN) from June 9-10, found that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has won the recognition of more than half of those interviewed for its performance since taking the reins of power from the Kuomintang for the first time on May 20.
Survey results show that the DPP also took leads in terms of popularity and social image.

According to the poll, 51 percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with the DPP's performance as a ruling party, while 21 percent gave a thumbs-down to the 13-year-old party's performance over the past three weeks.
Meanwhile, 42 percent said they were dissatisfied with the KMT's performance as an opposition party, and 29 percent gave a thumbs-up to the party's performance.

The poll also found that the respondents were divided over the newly formed opposition People First Party's (PFP's) performance, with 32 percent giving a positive evaluation and 31 percent giving a thumbs-down.

Asked whether they like the DPP, 53 percent said "yes" while 29 percent said "no." In contrast, 41 percent said they like the KMT, compared to 40 percent who said they dislike the party, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20.

While 36 percent of those interviewed said they like the PFP, a roughly equal 31 percent said they don't like the party, headed by charismatic former Taiwan Governor James Soong, who lost to DPP's Chen Shui-bian with a narrow margin in the March 18 presidential election.

Poll results further found that the DPP (48 percent) was thought to be the most dynamic and vibrant among major local political parties, followed by the PFP (16 percent), the KMT (5 percent) and the New Party (1 percent).
Forty percent of those interviewed also said they thought that the DPP most cares about public opinion; 19 percent chose the PFP; 5 percent cited the KMT; and 2 percent opted for the New Party.
Asked which party attaches greatest importance to social justice, 35 percent cited the DPP, compared to the PFP's 17 percent, the KMT's 6 percent and the New Party's 5 percent.
The DPP was also perceived to be the most active in promoting political and social reforms, 46 percent; followed by the PFP, 12 percent; the KMT, 7 percent; and the New Party, 2 percent.
Meanwhile, 47 percent said they think that the KMT was the most conservative; followed by the New Party (11 percent); the PFP (7 percent) and the DPP (3 percent.)

According to the poll, 31 percent said they found that the DPP's platform, policy or stance are closest to their views; 23 percent chose the PFP's; and 13 percent said they thought that the KMT can best reflect their opinions.

Only 9 percent said they feel that legislators had focused on policy issues in their questioning of Cabinet members of the new government, while 57 percent said they thought that the lawmakers just intended to attract media attention.
The survey also found that 41 percent of the respondents were dissatisfied with KMT lawmakers' performances, compared to 35 percent who gave a positive evaluation.

As for the PFP lawmakers' performances, 37 percent gave a thumbs-up, while 27 percent gave a thumbs-down. In contrast, 44 percent said they are satisfied with the DPP legislators' performances in the legislature and 28 percent gave a negative answer.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE'S VISIT TO JAPAN NOT VERY POSSIBLE IN A YEAR: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan said on Monday that one of his most important missions is to push for the Japanese government to allow a visit by former President Lee Teng-hui in six months to a year, but that he doubts that it will be possible.

Fielding questions in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Lo admitted that chances are slim for the arrangement of such a Lee visit to Japan within a year, especially considering the many exchanges of ranking mainland Chinese and Japanese officials that are scheduled for September and October.
But Lo made it clear that he will do his best to help arrange a visit by Lee to Japan as soon as possible. The former Republic of China president enjoys wide admiration in Japan.

The new ROC representative to Japan went on to say that he has met several Japanese political heavyweights, including former Premier Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, as well as more than 200 Japanese Parliamentarians to exchange opinions on bilateral relations between the two countries since assuming the post over two weeks ago.

In an effort to prevent an impasse in two-way communications with Japan's younger political leaders and to respond to the Japanese government's concerns about the new administration of President Chen Shui-bian, Lo also vowed to further strengthen contacts between Taiwan and all Japanese circles.

Replying to lawmakers' question of why bilateral Taiwan-Japan ties have remained at a low ebb in recent years, Lo attributed the situation to Japan's serious fear of mainland China and to its long-standing conservative tradition.

Lo, however, pointed out that Japan's political sector has markedly changed its attitude toward mainland China. Furthermore, the Japanese academic spectrum has also in recent years gained a deeper understanding of the importance of the issue of security across the Taiwan Strait, he added.

He contended that Taiwan in the future should gauge its relations with Japan based upon a larger framework under which Japan should understand that Taiwan's multilateral ties with the United States and Southeast Asian countries are of great importance to security in the Taiwan Strait.

Turning to the question of a proposal by John Chipman, director of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, that the Group of Eight (G8) powerful nations include the cross-strait security issue in its upcoming summit meeting in Okinawa, Lo told legislators that relevant ROC authorities have been working on coming up with a policy on the issue.
However, he noted that further discussion would be required before a decision is made on whether the highlighted issue should be Taiwan Strait security or Asia-Pacific security.

Kuomintang lawmaker Chen Shei-saint expressed his suspicion that the proposal is an attempt to make the Taiwan Strait issue an international matter, a move which he claimed will undoubtedly provoke strong protest from Beijing, since it considers the issue to be internal.
According to Lo, the Taiwan Strait issue is not a simple question, and the G8's decision on whether to include it should be respected.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.014 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$30.8.
The local currency opened at NT$30.784 against the US dollar and was traded between NT$30.784 and NT$30.810.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$258.5 million. (By Elisa Kao) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP013 06-12-00 MIT PROFESSOR EMPHASIZES CREATIVITY IN INTERNET ERA

Taipei, June 12 (CNA) A Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) professor said on Monday that educational systems in East Asia put too much emphasis on memorization, thereby hurting students' creativity.

Dr. Lester C. Thurow, Lemelson Professor of Management and economics at MIT's Sloan School of Management, made the comments while delivering an address at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT) being held in Taipei June from 12-14.

Thurow also suggested that Taiwan work to emulate successful high-technology development in Finland, where concentrated efforts in telecommunications technology have made the Finnish firm Nokia a world leader in mobile telephony.

Thurow noted that Finland is a small country with limited resources, but has nevertheless succeeded by concentrating on one specific field in hi-tech development, a model that other small countries should use as an example.

The professor of management and economics said that an enterprising society should encourage creativity and tolerate failure. A US survey shows that most newly-established firms there experience at least two bitter failures.

As the world's third largest supplier of information technology (IT) products, Taiwan is seeking to secure an important role in the IT era. Thurow said that creative and experienced hi-tech personnel, good infrastructure and large investments in research and development are required to make Taiwan a leader in this field.

Countries like the United States can afford tremendous R&D investments, he said, adding that the US$300 billion investments in IT R&D projects in the US represents only 3 percent of the nation's gross national product (GNP). Small countries will find it difficult to catch up with leading industrial countries in terms of R&D investments, said the professor.

Thurow also pointed out that retail stores have not undergone many changes in the past 500 years, but traditional retail formats will be challenged over the next 10 years. With Internet shopping gaining in popularity, he predicts that by the year 2010, half of all retail businesses will be forced out of the market.

In addition to the IT industry, the professor said that biochemistry and microcomputer technology will play key roles during the next 50 years. He said that the new definition of "superpower" is a country that has the ability to dominate the world with supreme technologies.
Thurow is recognized as one of the most influential economists of the late 20th century.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP CEO SPEAKS ON HUMAN FACTOR IN IT DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Information technology is affecting the distribution of wealth and influencing human lives in a positive way, the head of a US-based computer company said on Monday at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT), currently being held in Taipei.

Carly S. Fiorina, president and CEO of Hewlett-Packard, stressed the human factor in technological development and applications. In her speech "Invent/Reinvent: Strategic Imperatives for the Internet Era," she specified how the Internet can offer solutions to existing problems.
The HP CEO said that her firm has applied Internet technologies to solving food distribution problems in the United States. She also stressed that the Internet has expanded educational horizons.

The IT leader said that a good format for success in the Internet era can be learned from the Darwinist concept of survival of the fittest. In the new era, only firms that are able to adapt to the new challenges of the IT era can survive.
Emphasizing the importance of the human factor in applying technology, Fiorina said that information technology is meaningful only when it can serve the welfare of mankind.

Noting the HP has been in Taiwan for 30 years, Fiorina praised the nation's ability to continuously innovate. Taiwan remains an important source of computer and part supplies to the multinational corporation, and HP will purchase NT$4.5 billion worth of IT products from Taiwan this year, the HP president disclosed.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES KEEN ON 'MINI THREE LINKS' BY YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: Following the government's announcement of a plan to work out concrete measures to set up the "mini three links" in six months, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said on Monday that in principle, it respects Premier Tang-fei's decision on the matter.

However, KMT spokesman Jason Hu said that his party will ask the government to put forward within a month an assessment on the impact of a direct religious voyage across the Taiwan Strait, now that relevant authorities have repeatedly said that such a cruise would affect national security.

Hu stressed that the KMT's stance is that the government should take into account the "overall" public interests when outlining measures to allow direct religious trips across the Taiwan Strait as well as the so-called "mini three links" -- direct trade, transport, and postal links between Taiwan-controlled frontline islands and offshore islets of mainland China's Fujian province.

If a direct religious voyage by Taiwan pilgrims to the mainland is found to pose no threat to national security, the KMT will actively push for the legislature to allow such trips based on the existing legal framework and public support.

He stressed that the KMT's policy toward the direct religious voyage is based on its concern for the needs of the people, an attitude which he said has nothing to do with any "certain temple." The religious voyage to the mainland has been promoted by Taichung County's influential Chanlan Temple.

Hu made the remarks after he and other opposition lawmakers visited Tang to gain an understanding about the government's attitude toward the issues regarding direct religious voyages and the "mini three links."

Following the meeting with opposition lawmakers, Fang promised to work out an evaluation on the "mini three links" within three months, and to follow up with detailed measures in six months. Any direct cross-strait religious trips will be first put into practice under this framework.

Meanwhile, People First Party legislative spokesman Liu Wen-hsiung said they are happy about Tang's promise. He also urged the premier to fulfill his pledge that he will push for the resumption of a cross-strait dialogue as soon as possible.

If the government takes the initiative to talk with the mainland on setting up the "mini three links," it will help the international community gain a better understanding of Taiwan's sincerity in promoting cross-strait ties, Liu claimed.
