DOC.HEADLINE: HEWLETT-PACKARD CEO PRAISES TAIWAN'S IT DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Hewlett-Packard (HP) Chief Executive Officer Carly Fiorina on Monday praised Taiwan for setting an example of "invention and reinvention" in its development of information technology (IT).
Speaking on the opening day of the 12th World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT), Fiorina said that IT affects the distribution of wealth and has a positive influence on human life.

Fiorina said at the biennial conference that an important principle of IT is "invention and reinvention." She added that Taiwan is a "perfect example" of this growth cycle, and echoed President Chen Shui-bian's earlier call to make Taiwan into a "green silicon island."
Fiorina pointed out that HP has been in the Taiwan market for 30 years, and that it plans to continue to purchase IT products worth a total of US$4.5 billion from Taiwan this year.
According to Fiorina, IT can help instill personalized service into any process and application. These services will help people resolve their problems with more convenience, she added.

In the future, only those who can adjust to the emerging IT era will have the competitiveness to survive, Fiorina said. However, she went on that human welfare should be the fundamental consideration of any IT innovation, because "in the end, it's all about people."

Some 1,500 executives from 82 countries are in Taiwan to attend the three-day congress titled "IT for a Better World -- A New Millennium." This is the first time that the congress has been held in Taiwan. WCIT 2002 will be held in Australia.
Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates and Cisco Systems CEO John Chambers are scheduled to speak on the second day of the congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN US TO LOBBY FOR VISIT BY FORMER PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By Jane Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen based in North America are planning to invite former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to visit the United States this year as part of their efforts to counter Beijing's opposition to Lee's trips abroad.

C.H. Chuang, vice chairman of the North American Federation of Taiwan Businessmen Associations (NAFTBA), told CNA on Sunday that NAFTBA members will officially raise the proposal in their annual meeting slated for June 24 in San Francisco.
Once the proposal is approved, more than 10,000 NAFTBA members will start to lobby for Lee to be allowed to make a second trip to the United States in September or October, he noted.

The former president last visited the United States in 1995, when he made a trip to his alma mater, Cornell University. The visit sparked fury among the Beijing leaders, who saw it as a move to advocate Taiwan independence.

According to Chuang, Taiwan businessmen with operations here are very angry with Beijing's attempts to block Lee's visits to foreign countries, and wish to use this opportunity to allow the United States to act as a free and democratic nation which does not give way to pressure from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR UNVEILS ALTERNATIVES TO 4TH NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Monday unveiled alternatives to the construction of Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant.

Lai Ching-lin, convenor of an environmental policy panel under the DPP legislative caucus, together with a number of scholars from an anti-fourth nuclear plant group, presented the options at a press conference.

Lai described six options to replace the nuclear plant as: power co-generation; upgrading of energy efficiency; improvement of industrial infrastructure; expansion of natural gas production; promotion of recycling energy sources; and liberalization of the power industry.

Lai and several of the group members are also members of a reassessment committee set up by the Ministry of Economic Affairs that will present a report within six months on whether to continue with construction of the fourth nuclear plant.
Lai stressed that there are supporters within the state-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) for the building of a natural gas plant to replace nuclear power generation.

Taipower was given a green light to build the fourth nuclear plant in Kungliao, Taipei County, in March 1999. Although it first broached the idea in 1980, detailed plans to build the first two generators were only sent to the Atomic Energy Council for review in Oct. 1997, due to the strong opposition to nuclear power.

Lai said that Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has estimated that it can build a natural gas pipe that would connect natural gas collecting stations in Yungan, Taoyuan County, and Shenao, Ilan County, and then transport gas to the site of the fourth nuclear power plant, which could instead become the site of a natural gas power plant.

Lai said that while it is estimated that the first generator of the natural gas plant could be completed in five years at a cost of NT$10.7 billion (US$326.21 million), the construction of the fourth nuclear plant is expected to cost NT$900 billion. (US$29,22 bullion).

Lai noted that electricity consumption by the island's industrial sector now accounts for 60 percent of the total consumption, compared with about 50 percent in Europe and United States, and around 40 percent in Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE SAY 'NO' TO RELIGIOUS LINKS IF SECURITY IS AT STAKE

TEXT.P: The majority of local people will oppose the opening of direct sailing across the Taiwan Strait for pilgrimage if the Republic of China's national security is at stake, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Monday.

The telephone poll of 1,098 adult residents, conducted by the Taiwan Area Public Administration Society over the weekend, found that 87.5 percent of those interviewed said they would oppose the Chenlan Temple's plan to transport pilgrims directly from Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan to mainland China's Meizhou islet off Fujian province if the plan would affect national security.

Nevertheless, if the direct pilgrimage plan poses no threat to national security, 60 percent of the respondents said they would throw support behind the plan, but 34.3 percent said they still could not agree to the proposal.

Poll results show that 52.9 percent of those interviewed said they feel Chenlan Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao has been pressuring the government to open direct cross-strait pilgrimage voyage in the name of Matsu, or the Chinese Goddess of Sea.
Meanwhile, 68.2 percent said they think it is inappropriate for legislators to demand the government allow Chenlan Temple followers to embark on a direct pilgrimage to Matsu's birthplace in Meizhou.
About 75 percent said they think the government should conduct a comprehensive feasibility and impact study before opening direct religious links with the mainland.

Forty-two percent of those interviewed also said they support the Cabinet's plan to complete the direct "three links" feasibility study within six months, and 64.3 percent said they believe that the government has the sincerity to deal with the "three links" issues.

Asked whether they would worry about national security if the government open direct trade, transportation and mail links with the mainland right now, 60 percent said "yes" while 35.4 percent said "no."

The survey also found that 64.1 percent of the respondents said they feel that mainland China has become more hostile toward Taiwan after Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party won the March 18 presidential election, but 22.2 percent said they think otherwise.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES REACH CONSENSUS ON `MINI THREE LINKS' TIMETABLE

TEXT.P: Taiwan legislators reached a consensus on Monday for a timetable on the "mini three links" issue, which has been a source of debate and controversy since the new administration took power on May 20.

According to the Government Information Office (GIO), lawmakers across the political spectrum reached a fundamental consensus on the "mini three links" timetable after discussions with Premier Tang Fei in which he promised to come up with an assessment in three months, followed up by detailed measures in another three months.

The lawmakers agreed that there would be no debate on the issue in the Legislative Yuan the following day. Instead, it was decided that representatives from each party would speak on the topic, whereupon three resolutions would be passed without a vote, temporarily putting an end to the stalemate on the issue.

The resolutions are expected to include a six-month timetable, a demand for the government to give priority to establishing experimental direct links for religious purposes under the framework, and a call for the government to continue its efforts to resume cross-strait talks.
The so-called "mini three links" refer to direct trade, transport, and postal links between Taiwan-controlled frontline islands and offshore islets of mainland China's Fujian province.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX EXPECTED TO SIGN ACCORD WITH TOKYO STOCK EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) officials are expected to sign a cooperation agreement with their Tokyo Stock Exchange counterparts in the near future, TAIEX sources said on Monday.
A joint meeting of the TAIEX board of directors was scheduled to be convened on Tuesday, which the sources said was expected to approve various cooperation projects with foreign counterparts.

In addition to establishing cooperation links with the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the TAIEX officials will also sign a memorandum with Thailand Stock Exchange officials and terminate a memorandum with their counterparts in the Toronto Futures Exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: CISCO PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: John Chambers, president of Cisco Systems and the world's richest man in the high-technology field, arrived in Taipei on Monday to attend the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology from June 12-14.

Chambers is scheduled to speak on the second day of the congress, which is sponsored by the Information Service Industry Association of China, Taipei, a member of the World Information Technology and Services Alliance.
Chambers, who has visited Taiwan 17 times, pointed out upon arrival that he visits the island frequently because his company has a branch office here.
This high-tech tycoon said that with the world entering the Internet era, the new generation must have "the notion of life-time learning" in order to catch up with world trends.

The congress brings together some 1,500 executives from leading international information technology firms to discuss the impact of information technology (IT) on world economics, emerging IT strategies, business models and applications, and the industry's prospects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR INFO TECH AS CROSS-STRAIT PEACE ENVOY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Monday that information technology can serve as a "peace envoy" for improving relations across the Taiwan Strait and maintaining stability in the region.

Chen made the statement while meeting with three keynote speakers at the opening session of the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT2000) -- Carly Fiorina, president and chief executive officer (CEO) of Hewlett-Packard Co.; Lester C. Thurow, a management and economics professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology; and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih.
Chen said he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can cooperate and exchange expertise in information technology (IT) for mutual benefits.

"I'm convinced that cross-strait cooperation in the IT fields can help forge new opportunities for lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait," Chen said, adding that as the top leader of the Republic of China, he is obliged to improve cross-strait relations and maintain peace and stability in the region.
Earlier in the day, Chen also delivered a speech at the WCIT2000 opening ceremony. In his speech, Chen detailed his hope to make Taiwan a "Green Silicon Island" in 10 years.
"We hope that our future generations will enjoy not only highly developed technology but also a clean healthy environment," Chen said.
Moreover, Chen said, the ROC government plans to initiate a "Humanity Technology Island" to promote a balanced development of both culture and technology.
"Hopefully, the spirit of 'respect for nature, concern for people' will gradually be fostered, so that technology will not overburden nature during this time of vast development," Chen said.

Noting that the ROC will promote the parallel development of technology integration and humanity technology, Chen said it is expected to integrate theoretical research, applied and industrial technology into the spirit of humanity and environmental friendliness.

"With the technology and product trade to other parts of the world, I believe positive interaction between Taiwan and our friends will be promoted, that we will all work together to realize a 'Green Global Village,'" the president added.

WCIT2000 is the first global IT event to be held in Taiwan. The three-day extravaganza brings together more than 1,500 IT experts, scholars, administrators and business executives from 85 countries around the world.

A total of 30 IT heavyweights, including Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates and John Chambers, president and CEO of Cisco Systems Inc., will deliver speeches on various IT-related topics during the three-day meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST SAYS `ASIAN CURRENCY' MAY SOLVE CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE

TEXT.P: An economics expert said on Monday that a unified currency for Asia might serve as an economic catalyst to help solve the cross-Taiwan Strait problems.

Speaking on "optimal currency areas and capital markets for the new economy" at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology, Robert Mundell, professor of economics at Columbia University and winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize for Economic Science, said Taiwan should not consider cross-strait investment interaction a threat.
He suggested the formation of a unified Asian currency region, with the greater China region -- mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan -- as a sub-region.

Mundell said Taiwan should not step aside from the mainland Chinese market, and added that the mainland is expected to join the World Trade Organization and that its marketplace is gradually opening to the world.
Praising Taiwan's success in advancing its information industry, Mundell said that as the third-largest hardware supplier in the world, the island should reinforce its advantages in this field.
Optimistic about the future of Internet-inspired economies, Mundell said that information technology can help lower the costs of conventional economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS FIVE MILLION INTERNET SURFERS

TEXT.P: At least 5 million people in Taiwan use the Internet and with the introduction of the broad-band environment, surfers can enjoy high-quality low-cost services, according to a government official on industrial development.

Dr. Shih-chien Yang, convener of the National Information Infrastructure (NII) Committee, said at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology in Taipei that all primary schools in Taiwan now have computer centers, and that while it has encouraged the development of the information technology (IT) industry, the government has made equal efforts to promote information education.

Yang added that Taiwan has attained high development in semi-conductor manufacturing and other IT sectors, and said that more emphasis will be put on the advancement of Internet and related technologies in the next two to three years.

Stan Shih, chairman and CEO of the Acer Group, spoke on the same occasion about effective resource management for Internet economics. Suggesting the establishment of an Internet organization among the numerous small- and medium-sized enterprises in Taiwan, Shih said that these businesses should unite themselves via the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES SHOULD BE SAVED: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Monday that some traditional industries should be helped toward "a rebirth."
Lin made the remarks as he reported to a Legislative Yuan committee on a package to revitalize traditional industries.

The legislators also asked him about a statement Sunday by economist Lester C. Thurow that traditional industries which are not viable should be allowed to fail. Thurow was speaking at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology which opened in Taipei on Monday.

Thurow said that while some traditional industries could use new technology to maintain their competitive edge, many others should be phased out. He added that as long as Taiwan produces more new and high value-added products, then it is not a bad thing for traditional industries to move overseas.
Lin said Thurow's words may not necessarily fit Taiwan's situation, and added that some of the island's traditional industries that have good fundamentals will be helped.

He also said, however, that the government has only limited resources, and that some traditional industries that have lost competitiveness will be unable to continue even if tax incentives are offered.

He noted that although bicycle manufacture is deemed a traditional industry, some manufacturers have dedicated themselves to the development of new and high value-added products, and pointed out that their products remain highly competitive.

To help traditional industries to obtain land for plant construction, Lin said the government will coordinate a development fund under the Executive Yuan to provide NT$10 billion (US$324.67 million) to purchase land which can then be rented to small- and medium-sized industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN-ROC DIETMEN COUNCIL DELEGATION LIKELY TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: A Japan-ROC Dietmen Council delegation led by Chairman Sadanori Yamanaka will visit Taipei in July, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said on Monday.
Wang met with Yamanaka last week while attending the Japanese government and ruling Liberal Democratic Party-sponsored funeral service for late Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi on June 8.
He said Yamanaka had changed his mind about resigning and hoped to lead a delegation to visit the Republic of China in July after the election of Lower House slated for June 24.

Wang described Yamanaka as a heavyweight Japanese politician who has always been concerned about the security of Taiwan and events related to Taiwan. Wang added that Yamanaka has a deep passion for Taiwan because he is a graduate of Taipei Normal School and used to teach at Likan Primary School in Pingtung County.

Yamanaka helped to obtain pensions for Taiwanese who served in the Japanese Imperial army and helped to win compensation for local people who had postal deposit savings when Taiwan was under Japanese rule.
The Legislative Yuan will extend a formal invitation to Yamanaka on June 26, Wang went on.
Wang said that the ROC-Japan Parliamentary Council, which was originally composed of KMT parliamentarians, will also be expanded to include parliamentarians of all parties.
Asked whether he promoted the idea of a visit to Japan by former President Lee Teng-hui, Wang said that as the issue is too sensitive at this time, he did not raise the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS' WAGES TO BE `MODIFIED': MOEA

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said on Monday that the government will try to "modify" foreign workers' wages so that employers will no longer have to pay them the basic minimum wage.

Speaking at a legislative interpellation session, Lin said that if the move is successful, foreign workers will not be paid on the same basis as the basic wage for local laborers, currently NT$15,800 per month.

Legislator Hsiao Chin-lan (KMT-Kaohsiung County) said that foreign workers in Taiwan enjoy a higher basic wage than they can obtain in their own countries, which she claimed increases local production costs.

Lin said that his ministry will hold talks with the Council of Labor Affair (CLA) on the issue. The CLA has recently proposed cutting working hours and cutting the number of foreign workers, as well as raising the basic wage for ROC nationals.
Hsiao pointed out that if the CLA proposals are implemented, it will deal a heavy blow to the islands manufacturers.

Lin also claimed that foreign workers actually earn more than the basic wage in Taiwan, and said he hoped that the situation for local employers will improve after foreign workers' wages are no longer bound to the basic wage.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIAL TO ATTEND TAIWAN-US, US-TAIWAN BUSINESS COUNCILS CONFAB

TEXT.P: US Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater will attend the annual joint conference of the Republic of China (Taiwan)-US and the US-ROC Business Councils scheduled to be held on June 14-16 in Taipei.

Wang Chung-yu, president of the Association for the Promotion of ROC-US Economic Cooperation, said at a press conference on Monday that Slater will read a message from US President Bill Clinton at the conference, which will be opened by ROC President Chen Shui-bian.

The main purpose of the joint conference is to promote the understanding by the US government of the new ROC government's policies, Wang said, adding that he hoped that trilateral ties among Washington, Beijing and Taipei will be further improved as a result of the conference.

US-ROC Business Council Chairman Frank Carlucci, the deputy head of the Center for Strategy and International Studies (CSIS), Kurt Campbell, and Senator John D. Rockefeller will also be present at the joint conference.

Meanwhile, Phil Agress, acting deputy secretary of the US Commerce Department (Asia-Pacific affairs), will also arrive in the ROC to attend a business executives' luncheon during the joint conference.
Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun will host a dinner on Wednesday night to entertain 200-plus US delegates and 300-plus ROC delegates to the joint conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR GROUP DEMANDS SAY AT INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY CONGRESS

TEXT.P: A group of media workers on Monday demanded a say in the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT2000) which opened in Taipei that day.

The National Federation of Mass Media Trade Unions said in an open letter that workers' views should be taken into account when the congress discusses on its third and last day on Wednesday how information technology (IT) may be applied to create better lives for human beings.

In what they called an effort to expose the seamy side of the much-touted "new economy" created by IT, the group claimed that the new economy developed at the cost of workers, many of whom have lost their jobs.
Unless social justice is fully respected, they said, the new economy will undo hard-earned achievements in job security since the industrial revolution, and will make workers' lives a misery again.

Expressing concern that the new economy will lead to a widening of the gap between rich and poor, the letter demanded that workers' rights be put on the agenda of the congress and that labor representatives be allowed to take part in the congress which has brought together about 1,500 leaders of the IT industry, government officials and academics from 80-plus countries.

Citing Taiwan as an example, they said the rush of local media to enter cyberspace and remain competitive has led to the cutting of many graphic media jobs and has forced many senior and less-educated workers to face the prospect of mass layoffs.

They called on the congress attendees to extend their support for their demands for Taiwan's labor laws to be changed so that employers would be forced to offer employees six months of training to prepare them for finding new jobs before any layoff.
They also asked for the implementation of a tax on e-commerce to finance a vocational training program for laid-off workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOSPITAL, FOUNDATION TO SET UP CRANIOFACIAL CENTERS ACROSS ASIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation and Chang Gung Memorial Hospital plan to establish craniofacial centers in Cambodia, Vietnam, the Philippines and mainland China to help children with cleft palates, a hospital official said on Monday.

According to Chang Gung Craniofacial Center primary physician Luo Lun-chou, the 20-year program seeks to establish one craniofacial center per 10 million people in these countries. Mainland China, for example, would need 60 centers, he said.

Luo said that three medical personnel from the Philippines are currently in Taiwan to learn craniofacial plastic surgery procedures and patient-care techniques, while Cambodia will send two medical professionals to Taiwan in July. These "seed training" initiatives are being sponsored by the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation.

According to the center, one in 500 newborns in Taiwan have cleft palates, but they receive good medical care. Luo and other Chang Gung medical experts recently returned from their third voluntary medical mission to Cambodia, where children do not have the same opportunities for good medical treatment.

Lou said that cleft palate patients tend to have trouble drinking and speaking, and some even remained that way until the age of 21, when the Chang Gung physicians performed plastic surgery on them during one of their missions.
Luo added that his center and the foundation will also extend their training sponsorship programs to other medical fields such as dentistry and language therapy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY PEAK IN OVERDUE LOANS BY STATE-RUN BANKS

TEXT.P: Overdue loans by Taiwan's seven state-run banks peaked in May to a record NT$333.5 billion (US$11.11 billion), the Ministry of Finance announced on Monday.
Defaulted loans accounted for more than 5 percent of total loans in all except one of the seven banks.
Chang Hua Commercial Bank topped the list with a total of NT$50.9 billion in unpaid loans, or 6.37 percent of the money it lent to borrowers.

It was followed closely by Hua Nan Commercial Bank, with 5.99 percent of its loans, or NT$46.1 billion, unpaid; Taiwan Cooperative Bank, at 5.79 percent, or NT$65 billion; First Commercial Bank, at 5.69 percent, or NT$47.7 billion, The Medium Business Bank of Taiwan, at 5.52 percent, or NT$36.7 billion; and the Land Bank of Taiwan, at 5.04 percent, or NT$55 billion.
Bank of Taiwan was the only state-run financial institution with an overdue loans rate of less than 5 percent, at 2.48 percent, or NT$32.7 billion.
Officials at the Ministry of Finance blamed the increasing amount of unpaid loans to the disastrous Sept. 21 earthquake which destroyed or damaged many buildings used as collateral for bank loans.

The officials explained that the more overdue loans a bank has, the weaker its health. They added that the MOF has cut the business tax on banks by half to help them write off the bad loans after the Sept. 21 earthquake, in the hope that the overall bad loan rate can be reduced to less than 2.5 percent in five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT POLL SHOWS PARTY RANKS THIRD IN APPROVAL RATING

TEXT.P: A poll commissioned by the Kuomintang shows that public approval of the KMT ranks third after the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the newly formed People First Party (PFP), KMT Spokesman Jason Hu said on Monday.

Hu said that the poll sends a warning signal to the KMT, and added that the party is planning to form a "rapid response" mechanism to try to narrow the gap between the party's own estimation of itself and what the public thinks of it.

Meanwhile, another poll, conducted by the United Daily News, shows that the DPP led in "satisfaction," "approval," and "social image," among all the parties, and that PFP also led the KMT in "political party image," and "identification," as well as "image."

The KMT began an excruciating period of soul-searching and vowed to make across-the-board reforms after its humiliating loss to the DPP in the March 18 presidential election that ended the party's five decades of rule in Taiwan. Independent presidential candidate James Soong, a former KMT stalwart, finished close behind the DPP's Chen Shui-bian and formed the PFP soon after the election. The KMT's Lien Chan finished a distant third.

Hu said the results of the KMT's own poll are similar to those of the local paper, adding that in terms of political party identification, the DPP was followed by the PFP, the KMT and the New Party. Hu would not disclose the exact figures of the approval ratings received by each party.

But sources said the poll shows that the approval rating for the DPP was 29 percent and the PFP obtained nearly 20 percent, while the KMT garnered only a little more than 10 percent. The sources said they were "mystified" by the results since the KMT had put so much effort into reform since its defeat.

In order to try to improve its poor image rating, Hu suggested that the KMT Central Policy Committee should conduct a poll on one or two major issues closely related to the public every week and then publish the results to use as reference in its monitoring of the DPP administration.

Wang Tan-ping, executive secretary of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said frankly that the reason the public has lost confidence in the party is because it has lied to the public, and has always had the habit of broadcasting good news but hiding the bad.
