DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 13, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
323 BC: Alexander the Great, king of Macedonia who came to the throne at the age of only 20 and conquered Persia, Egypt, Babylon, Central Asia and part of India, dies in Babylon at the age of 33 upon his return from India.
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1842: Queen Victoria becomes the first British monarch to travel by train when she takes a trip from Slough to Paddington.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1893: The first women's golf championship is held at Royal Lytham in Britain and is won by Lady Margaret Scott.
1900: A group of volunteer soldiers known as the Boxers go on the rampage through Beijing in protest against the "foreign devils" who have such a hold on their country. Popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by the unequal treaties combined to spark what becomes known as the Boxer Uprising.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the US Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the US Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1988: The Soviet Union holds its first beauty contest.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1990: East Germany begins the final demolition of the Berlin Wall, which was built in 1961.
1994: The foreign ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit UN nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 64.35 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 64.35 points to close at 8,891.09.
Market turnover amounted to NT$ 94.87 billion (US$3.09 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 64.35 points to close at 8,891.09.
Affected by a drop in the NASDAQ index in the United States, the bourse opened at 8,905.45 and fluctuated between 8,984.13 and 8,879.52 during trading.

A total of 1.49 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.87 billion (US$3.09 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 1.52 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$94.75 billion (US$3.09 billion).
Losers outnumbered gainers 395 to 120, with 83 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues and cement stocks, both at 1.5 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, electrical stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: GATES SPEAKS ON UPGRADING PC WITH INTERNET SOFTWARE

TEXT.P: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates said Tuesday in Taipei that personal computers are increasing in numbers but decreasing in functions, adding that with internet software, PC functions can be upgraded.
The chief software architect of Microsoft arrived in Taipei Monday night to attend the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology. He is one of the speakers at Tuesday's sessions.

Gates said that Microsoft is developing a new generation of windows service, stressing personalized products. The amount of investment in this new project is two to three times that of the moon-landing project, he disclosed.
Gates gave a lecture on the topic of the internet at National Taiwan University in Taipei on Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Tuesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved down 119 points to close at 8,889, with 3,019 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 93 points to finish at 8,945 with 242 contract transactions, while September futures lost 85 points to close at 9,020, with seven contract transactions, and December futures plunged 170 points to finish at 9,088, with seven contract transactions.
Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were: 8,955 for June; 8,994 for July; 9,020 for September; and 9,050 for December.
Electronic (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported negative results.
June TE futures moved down 6.35 points to close at 497.5, with 957 contract transactions, while July TE futures lost 7.1 points to finish at 497.7, with 78 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
June TF futures edged down 0.2 points to close at 882, with 264 contract transactions, while July TF futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 892, with 41 contract transactions.
September TF futures lost 0.2 points to close at 898, with three contract transactions, while December TF futures moved up 1.8 points to finish at 904, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT PROPOSES PRINCIPLES FOR INTERNET POLICY MAKING

TEXT.P: An American expert in electronic commerce proposed at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology that certain principles for internet policy making should be defined as the internet has changed everything including government.

James Gilmore, governor of Virginia and chairman of the US Advisory Committee on Electronic Commerce, said Tuesday that the internet has led to transformations in commerce as well as in society, adding that the internet does not fit into the existing global structure, which is divided by national boundaries.
Since the old rules of governing may not work well in the emerging internet age, Gilmore said that certain principles for internet policy making should be defined.
The five principles named by Gilmore mostly refer to ethics. Gilmore pointed out that, first of all, "the internet cannot be a medium only for the privileged."
The second principle suggests that "government must marshal the internet to become more efficient and productive in the delivery of its services, just as the private sector does."
Thirdly, Gilmore urged the establishment of an international order that frees individuals from unnecessary taxes and tariffs that detract from the quality of life of the people of the world.
While cyber-terrorism is a potential threat, Gilmore said internet safety should be an important principle.
All in all, Gilmore said that a standard as borderless and universal as the internet needs to be set for efficient governing in the internet age.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING NEED NEW FRAMEWORK FOR RELATIONS: MAC CHIEF (I)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should craft a new framework for bilateral relations, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said in a recent interview with CNA.
"We hope to negotiate a brave new framework for engagement with mainland China," the Republic of China's new top mainland policy planner expounded.

In her view, Tsai said, President Chen Shui-bian's call in his widely watched May 20 inaugural speech that the two sides of the strait jointly deal with the question of a future "one China" means that Taiwan and mainland China should pool their wisdom to work out a new structure for constructive interaction.

The sophisticated but self-effacing legal expert further said she does not think that the future of cross-strait relations should still be restricted to just three options -- unification, independence or the status quo.

In the face of the changing world situation and the arrival of the new millennium, Tsai said the two sides of the strait need to use new thinking to sketch out a new framework for sustainable peaceful engagement. And the new framework must allow either side to decide its own affairs, she added.

Noting that "unification" and "independence" are not necessarily completely incompatible in defining cross-strait relations, Tsai said the anticipated co-existence framework should be flexible enough to accommodate the demands of both pro-unification and pro-independence members of the general public.

According to Tsai, precisely defining unification and independence is no easy task. "There is only a razor-thin line between them," she explained, adding that if either side of the Taiwan Strait insists on a rigid, clear-cut definition of their relationship, there will be no room left for flexibility or "breathing space."

Tsai said that since Taiwan and mainland China have been separated for more than five decades, they need room, flexibility, tolerance and patience to forge goodwill and consensus for resolving thorny bilateral disputes.

"I'm hopeful that our two sides can forsake old-fashioned logic and use novel thinking to formulate a new framework or formula for peaceful co-existence and co-prosperity," said the soft-spoken policy planner.

Tsai came into the public limelight only after she assumed the top MAC post under Chen's administration. But in fact, the former international trade law professor at National Chengchi University is no stranger to cross-strait affairs.
She was a commissioner of the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission and an adviser to the National Security Council during the Kuomintang government era.

In the past, she often represented Taiwan at meetings of major international trade bodies, such as the World Trade Organization (WTO) and its precursor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), as well as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Tsai was noted for her sharp mind, delicate sensibility, eloquence and composed manner in negotiations for Taiwan's membership or interests in those multilateral trade organizations.

With her rich experience in international negotiation and debate, Tsai was selected as a member of a delegation headed by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, which embarked on an ice-breaking visit to mainland China in October 1998.

Tsai took part in Koo's two rounds of meetings in Shanghai with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). She was also present at Koo's meetings in Beijing with mainland China's leading officials in charge of Taiwan-related affairs, including President Jiang Zemin, Vice Premier Qian Qichen and ARATS Vice President Tang Shubei. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FRAMEWORK FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS (II)

TEXT.P: Moreover, Tsai is believed to be the chief architect of the controversial "two states" or "special state-to-state relationship" theory unveiled by former ROC President Lee Teng-hui last July.

Beijing accused Lee of promoting Taiwan independence by defining cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" and angrily announced an indefinite postponement of a planned reciprocal visit to Taiwan by Wang, which was originally scheduled for the autumn of 1999.
Tsai said in the CNA interview that the "special state-to-state" definition faithfully depicts an existing political reality and should not be interpreted as a move to promote Taiwan independence.
"What I want to stress is that the `special state-to-state' relationship' theory is largely compatible with Beijing's cherished `one China' principle," Tsai said.
Nevertheless, she said that as the theory has been "seriously misunderstood," the new ROC government has decided not to mention it again.
"The decision is a goodwill gesture toward Beijing," Tsai said, adding that the MAC is willing to take any measures conducive to confidence-building between the two sides.

Asked about the dispute over Beijing's so-called "1992 consensus on the `one China' principle," Tsai said the SEF and ARATS indeed discussed the issue in 1992, but failed to reach a consensus on the definition of "one China."

"As a result, the discussion ended in disarray, with each side insisting on its own interpretation of `one China,'" Tsai emphasized, adding that the ROC cannot accept Beijing's latest explanation of the so-called 1992 consensus on the "one China" principle.
Beijing said in a 2,000-word comment on Chen's inaugural speech that it would be willing to resume cross-strait dialogue if Taipei were to abide by the "1992 consensus."
According to Beijing, the "1992 consensus" means that both sides insist on the "one China" principle -- there is only one China of which Taiwan is an inalienable part.
"As Beijing has consistently claimed that `one China' refers to the People's Republic of China, we were unlikely to have agreed to this principle," Tsai stressed.
In fact, Tsai said Beijing itself has many times changed its stance on whether the two sides reached a consensus in their 1992 discussion.

"Beijing denied in 1996 and 1998 the existence of the so-called 1992 consensus, but now it insists that there is what it calls `consensus,'" Tsai said, adding that if Beijing's latest claim were correct, it would not have bothered to deny the consensus' existence in 1996 and 1998.

Asked how the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can break their current logjam, Tsai said the ball is now in Beijing's court, as Chen already did his utmost to show goodwill and sincerity toward mainland China in his inaugural address.
Tsai further said the new ROC government attaches great importance to the interaction and long-term relationship between SEF Chairman Koo and ARATS President Wang.

"I believe that the two elder statesmen are the persons most likely to develop the good chemistry needed to reach a consensus on sensitive cross-strait issues," Tsai said, adding that cross-strait relations still must rely on the efforts of the two men, at least for the foreseeable future.
Tsai said she believes both Koo and Wang hope to meet again to complete their historic mission of helping achieve a breakthrough in deadlocked cross-strait relations.

Against this backdrop, Tsai said the two sides should make concerted efforts to pave the way for a new round of Koo-Wang talks to rejuvenate the cross-strait dialogue channel for sustainable constructive interaction.
"We have never stopped preparations for Wang's visit, and Koo has also expressed his willingness to travel to the mainland again to meet with Wang if necessary," Tsai said.
Touching on the WTO issue, she noted that both Taipei and Beijing are expected to join the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body in the fourth quarter of this year.

Tsai said she does not think Beijing will boycott Taiwan's WTO accession because "essentially simultaneous entry" by both sides of the Taiwan Strait is an international consensus and a condition for the United States to grant permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) to mainland China. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FRAMEWORK FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS (III)

TEXT.P: "Moreover, a boycott by mainland China would certainly cause a regression in cross-strait relations, a development that the Beijing leaders would not like to see," Tsai said.
As for the opening of direct "three links" with the mainland, she said the MAC is studying the feasibility and possible impact of opening direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links.
Tsai said the MAC will give priority to considering the opening of direct cross-strait pilgrimages to meet the demand of local followers of Matsu, the Chinese Goddess of the Sea.

Meanwhile, she said, the MAC is scheduled to complete a comprehensive evaluation of the feasibility and possible impact on Taiwan's national security of the proposed opening of direct trade, mail and transportation links between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China's coastal cities, commonly known as direct "mini three links," within six months.

According to a bill passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the government can legalize direct "mini three links" before the opening of overall direct cross-strait three links to help boost the economic development of such outlying islands as Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

Tsai said national security is the top concern in preparing for opening either direct pilgrimages or "mini three links." Moreover, she added, resumption of cross-strait dialogue is needed because Taiwan can unilaterally open neither direct "mini three links" nor direct religious voyages.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIRGINIA GOVERNOR URGES GOVERNMENT LEADERS TO EMBRACE THE INTERNET

TEXT.P: Virginia Governor James S. Gilmore III on Tuesday urged government policy leaders from around the world to embrace the Internet as an opportunity to usher in "an era of the individual" instead of seeing it as a digital divide.

Speaking at the 12th World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT) on the topic of "Governing in the Internet Age," Gilmore, who also chairs the US Advisory Committee on Electronic Commerce, said that governments need to adopt a new, different view of the Internet.

Gilmore urged the world's governments to embrace the principle of universal empowerment by working toward making the Internet as available to everyone as the telephone is today. He added that governments should marshal the Internet to become more efficient and productive in the delivery of its services in the same way the private sector does, and pass on the resulting savings to the people.

Gilmore also advocated an Internet that is free from unnecessary taxes and tariffs on e-commerce. He criticized the European Union's recent decision to collect the EU's Value Added Tax from Internet sellers, saying that some of the sellers may not even be connected with the EU. Gilmore also criticized the EU's recent discussions concerning implementing rules that would require EU citizens to turn over their passwords.

Gilmore said that the Internet is reshaping the business world by making commerce more available to small businesses and individuals that were once limited by physical space. He said that all these businesses can now market worldwide because everyone is "next-door" on the Internet.

Other speakers in Tuesday's high-powered lineup included Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, who said that the ongoing industry transitions will depend on further technological breakthroughs from Microsoft's partners in Taiwan.

This year marks the first time that the WCIT, a biennial event, is being held in an Asian country other than Japan. The theme of WCIT 2000, an industry event spanning three days, is "IT for a Better World: A New Millennium."

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL GATES PRAISES TAIWAN COMPANIES AT WORLD CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates on Tuesday praised Taiwan companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.

Speaking to industry and government leaders on the second day of the 12th World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT), Gates said that the ongoing industry transitions will depend on even more technological breakthroughs from Microsoft's partners in Taiwan.

Gates predicted that teleconferencing, wireless, and voice recognition technologies will play "a very critical role" in the home and in the business environment of the future. Real time collaboration will make businesses more efficient, he added.

Gates said that a possible transition to a speech interface for the personal computer of the future is comparable to the shift from text-based DOS to Microsoft's Windows graphical user environment, particularly in terms of the controversy and skepticism generated among industry experts and consumers during the transition. However, he predicted that speech recognition will become a commonplace technology in the future.

Gates described the current phase of the Internet revolution as one that is about driving profitability and making existing businesses more efficient. He said that the trend is moving away from a "presentation network" to a more personalized system that puts the user in control. Better security and higher standards for software and hardware products will be a hallmark of the future Internet environment, he added.
Gates also predicted that set-top boxes, mobile videophones, and other market-focused information technology products will make a splash in the future.

WCIT 2000 marks the first time that the conference is held in Asia outside of Japan. Some 1,500 industry leaders from more than 80 countries around the world are attending the three-day event, which opened on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOTT SAYS HE WON'T RUSH SENATE VOTE ON PNTR FOR CHINA

TEXT.P: Although the White House, the American business community, and some Democratic senators have all called for the swift passage of the bill granting Communist China permanent normal trade relations status, US Senate Republican leader Trent Lott said Monday that he would not rush to schedule a vote on the important bill.

Sen. Lott (R-Miss) told a press conference that he knows there is broad support for the PNTR legislation in the Senate and he has always indicated his support for it. But he pointed out that if the Senate rushed through trade bills each time they had strong feelings on certain legislation, they would have gotten into all kinds of trouble by now.

He is going to meet with all sides in the next two weeks to hear the thoughts of people from the manufacturing, agricultural, and labor sectors and to make sure that the senators will have a chance to have their say and offer amendments, said Lott.

Even though a large number of senators would prefer not to change the PNTR bill, Lott noted that several senators who support the bill would not want to vote against the amendment proposed by Sen. Fred Thompson (R-Tenn.) to ban China from further proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. So he needs time to work out an arrangement for the Thompson non-proliferation amendment and the PNTR bill to be dealt with as separate legislation.
Besides, the Senate majority leader said, he has got to continue to look for ways for the Senate to move several appropriations bills in the next two weeks.
Sixty-three members in the 100-member US Senate said they would vote in favor of granting China PNTR status, according to a recent Reuters poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALTERNATIVE TO TMD SYSTEM EXISTS FOR TAIWAN: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Rather than include Taiwan in a region-wide Theater Missile Defense system, the United States could continue to provide the island with "low-tier" missile defense technology, including upgraded Patriot missiles and early warning radar, while giving it additional protection via sea-based TMD on American warships, according to an American Asia expert.

Greg May, assistant director of the Washington-based Nixon Center, wrote in a recent analysis that Beijing's opposition to missile defense must be studied in the context of China's glaring vulnerability. Unlike Russia, which has more than enough missiles to overwhelm a limited American national missile defense system, China only has around 20 ICBMs, all are DF-5s capable of hitting North America but take several hours to prepare for flight.

In the event of a preemptive nuclear strike, "China would be lucky to get any of its DF-5s in the air. When an NMD system is added to the mix, China worries that even its minimal deterrent capability will be rendered invalid," noted May.

In addition, he said, "China believes American missile defense programs will harm its regional interests. Beijing worries that a US-led TMD effort will expand America's influence in East Asia and blunt China's short- and intermediate- range ballistic missiles, which China uses to compensate for its poor navy and air force," he said.
"Most importantly, Beijing fears TMD extension to Taiwan would create a de facto alliance between Taipei, Washington and Tokyo that would destroy any chance of China-Taiwan reunification," he noted.

None of this is to say that missile defense is a bad idea simply because China dislikes it. "China cannot dictate US decisions and it is ridiculous to suggest, as Beijing often does, that America has an obligation to leave itself and its allies completely vulnerable to missile strikes. However, the US would be foolish to totally ignore China's concerns, thus insuring maximum damage to US-China relations," added May.
One of the key factors that will determine whether the US can pursue missile defense while avoiding a new Cold War with China will be whether the US extends TMD to Taiwan, he wrote.

Taiwan wants to join a TMD system as a way of boosting its security ties with the United States and Japan. "But given Taiwan's proximity to China, a costly TMD system capable of intercepting missiles at very high altitudes does not necessarily make military sense," he pointed out.

"South Korea has opted out of TMD due to similar cost-benefit concerns. Rather than officially include Taiwan in a region-wide TMD effort, the US could continue to provide Taiwan with `low-tier' missile defense technology.....while giving it additional cover via sea-based TMD on American warships," emphasized May.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING BETWEEN TWO KIMS SEEN RAISING HOPES AND FEARS

TEXT.P: Tuesday's meeting between President Kim Dae-Jung of South Korea and North Korean dictator Kim Jong-Il is being forced to carry an "enormous freight of expectations," according to a veteran columnist in Australia.

In a commentary in The Australian, the daily's foreign editor Greg Sheridan said Kim Jong-Il's recent visit to mainland China before Tuesday's summit indicates that the dictator could be willing to implement some economic reforms in North Korea.

"But if the North were to embrace even the most modest of economic reforms, and make even the smallest symbolic gesture of goodwill to South Korea, it could expect substantial aid and rapid economic benefits," he commented.
"Of course, there are countless ways in which the summit could still go totally wrong," he noted.

"The US is keen for Kim Dae-Jung to press his counterpart on nuclear and missile issues, especially as suspicion is growing that the North is reneging on its 1994 deal to abandon its nuclear weapons program. There is particular suspicion that the North has constructed a new and secret nuclear weapons laboratory at Kumchangri, in the country's remote northwest," he said.
"Be that as it may, if the summit is any kind of success, it will be the most hopeful development in Korean security for a very long time," he pointed out.
But Sheridan also noted that predicting the behavior of Pyongyang's erratic leadership "is always difficult," citing the one-day postponement of the summit between the two Kims as an example.

DOC.HEADLINE: CISCO CEO CHAMBERS COMMENTS ON TAIWAN'S IT INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: John Chambers, CEO of Cisco Systems,spoke highly about Taiwan's investment environment, disclosing that Cisco will have a US$6 million cooperation project with Taiwan's information industry next year.

Chambers was invited to speak at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology being held in Taipei from June 12-14. In his speech on "The Network Effect - Productivity in the New Economy," Chambers predicted that network-effected electronic commerce will total US$524 billion in five years.
Chambers pointed out that Internet businesses will continue to grow through mergers and alliances over the next ten years. He said he foresees tremendous growth opportunities for e-commerce in Asia.

Together with Education Minister Ovid Tzeng and Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-Tseh, Chambers attended a roundtable discussion in the afternoon on the development trends in broadband networks. The three unveiled the creation of Taiwan's first optical fiber community area network, Taipei GigaPop (TPGP).

Cisco is responsible for the overall network design of the Taipei GigaPop plan, a broadband fiber-optic network infrastructure that will provide a high-speed information network backbone for educational research in the Taipei metropolitan area.

Chambers said that Cisco's cooperation project with Taiwan's IT industry will amount to US$500 million in five years. Commenting on Taiwan's Internet industry, Chambers said that Taiwan should learn from the Silicon Valley in transforming its IT industry from semi-conductor manufacturing to software development.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATE PAYS TRIBUTE TO ROC REPRESENTATIVE IN RESOLUTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States Senate has passed a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the US, for his distinguished service.
The US Senate unanimously passed the resolution proposed by Larry Craig (R-Idaho), John Rockefeller (D-W.Va.), and Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) in a floor meeting on June 9.
Congress congratulated Chen on his many years of distinguished service to Taiwan and his friendship to the United States and offered best wishes to Chen on the occasion of his retirement.
The resolution noted that Chen, during his 47-year diplomatic career, served in the Philippines, Brazil, Argentina, Bolivia, and the United States.
Chen also served in a number of important posts in his government at home, including the post of vice foreign minister and deputy secretary general to the president, it added.
Chen has been a friend of the United States and has earned the respect and genuine affection of many members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, the resolution said.
Chen is scheduled to return to Taiwan in mid-June and his successor Chen Chien-jen is expected to assume his post later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CISCO TO INVEST 500 MILLION US DOLLARS IN TAIWAN IT COMPANIES

TEXT.P: John Chambers, the chief executive officer of computer industry giant Cisco Systems, said on Tuesday that his company will invest US$6 million in Taiwan next year, leading to a total investment of US$500 million by 2003.

Speaking at a press conference at the World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT), Chambers praised Taiwan's government and educational institutions for supporting the local technology environment. However, he urged Taiwan companies to continue to innovate, bolster their research and development efforts, and open up new markets.

Chambers said that Taiwan's infrastructure developed at a rapid pace over the past two years, with an expanding wireless communications market, ever lowering telecommunications fees, and an increasing number of Internet users. He added that he foresees tremendous growth opportunities in Taiwan.

In his speech to some 1,500 industry leaders at the same occasion, Chambers noted that every company is in transition because of the ongoing information revolution. Countries that were unable to catch the first wave of the industrial revolution now have the opportunity to surpass even Europe and the United States during the second revolution brought about by the Internet, he said.

Chambers added that the ability to "keep a finger on the pulse of the customer" can enable a company to do well in the fast-paced information society. He said by way of example that Cisco changed its market approach seven times in a single decade. Cisco now ranks first in corporate market value in the United States.

WCIT 2000 marks the first time that the conference is held in Asia outside of Japan. Industry experts from more than 80 countries around the world are attending the three-day event, which opened on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING URGED TO LEARN FROM 2 KOREAS FOR RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: ROC lawmakers across the political spectrum on Tuesday urged top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to learn from two Koreas to seek reconciliation and a breakthrough to their current deadlock.
The legislators made their appeal at a Legislative Yuan plenary meeting as North Korean leader Kim Jong-il and South Korean President Kim Dae-jung opened a historic summit in Pyongyang on Tuesday.
New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao said the two Koreas used to be bitter rivals, but now they are holding their first summit meeting in 55 years.
"Seeing the two previously feuding Koreas get down to talks, I feel sad that relations across the Taiwan Strait are still mired in a logjam," said Lai.

The lawmaker from the small pro-unification opposition party urged mainland China to show goodwill by suspending Taiwan-targeting military exercises for one year or at least allowing Wang Daohan, Beijing's top negotiator with Taipei, to visit Taiwan this autumn.

Meanwhile, Lai advised ROC Vice President Annette Lu to stop provocative rhetoric against Beijing. He also pushed President Chen Shui-bian to take concrete steps to signify his sincerity to improve cross-strait relations.

Lai suggested that Chen's administration set a timetable for opening direct trade, postal and transport links with the mainland in preparation for two sides' accession to the World Trade Organization in the fourth quarter of the Taiwan Strait.
"The move can also signify our goodwill toward Beijing to help foster a friendly atmosphere for resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue," he noted.

Wang Tien-ching, a lawmaker from the newly formed opposition People First Party (PFP), said he hopes the ongoing North-South Korean summit could inspire Taiwan and mainland Chinese leaders to seek feasible ways to break their current impasse.

Legislator Lin Cheng-tse of the Kuomintang, the Republic of China's ruling party until May 20, said if the top leaders of the two Koreas, which had fought bitterly in the past, can sit down to talks, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have no excuse to continue resisting "detente."

Hopefully, Lin said, the thousands of detained illegal mainland Chinese immigrants can be sent back to their homeland as early as possible and mainland spouses of Taiwan people can receive better care here.

"We also hope mainland leaders can forsake attempts to use force against Taiwan and that the long-stalled Koo-Wang talks can resume soon to pave the way for a cross-strait summit to craft a new framework for peaceful engagement and constructive interaction," Lin urged.

The Koo-Wang talks refer to meetings between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Koo and Wang held a historic meeting in Singapore in 1993 to lay a framework for SEF-ARATS exchanges, and they met again in Shanghai in October 1998 when Koo made an ice-breaking visit to the mainland. Wang originally planned to made a reciprocal visit to Taiwan last autumn, but Beijing announced an indefinite postponement of Wang's travel plan after former ROC President defined cross-strait relations as a special state-to-state relationship in July 1999. Beijing regarded Lee's definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS CHAMBERS, GATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday received Cisco Systems President and CEO John Chambers and Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, respectively, at the Presidential Office.

Chen, who first met with Chambers, said he was very happy to receive the leader in Internet infrastructure development, who was recently named one of the world's most prominent CEOs by Fortune magazine. Under Chambers' leadership, Cisco Systems has been the fastest-growing company in the world, and Chambers fully deserves the title of "digital world leader," Chen noted.

Chen said that Chambers' success has a lot in common with his own administrative philosophy. He invited Chambers to be his personal technology adviser, which he said would allow him to learn from the executive's success and introduce a more entrepreneurial administrative culture to government agencies, sharpening their competitive edge.
Chen said while meeting with Chambers that his major philosophy in regards to running the country is as follows:
-- He tries to listen to the different voices of the people.
-- He is in favor of a government of all the people, because the success of a country lies in working together rather than in just one individual's efforts.
-- His goal is to transform Taiwan into a "green silicon island" by 2010 so that the island can be a pioneer of the world digital economy in the 21st century.
-- He will try to develop a spirit of partnership between the central and local governments, as well as between the government and the private sector.

Chambers also summed up his strategy for success. He told Chen that running Cisco has taught him that the customer should always come first, and that a firm should maintain a high level of quality as well as a loyal team. He added that his company constantly seeks to use new technologies to upgrade its competitiveness, and always has an eye on its strategy.

The Cisco Systems chief said he is very impressed by Taiwan's technological development, and voiced his willingness to set up a lifelong enterprise-government partnership with the ROC government to help Taiwan further develop its technology education.
Chambers presented a ceramic painting to Chen, and wished good health and prosperity to the Republic of China's new head of state and its people.
Chen described his meeting with Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates as a kind of summit, noting a slogan of his presidential campaign -- "young leaders, world trend."

Chen said he had been criticized by his rivals for being too young to vie for the presidential post. Chen again dismissed such criticism, pointing out that Gates had established Microsoft at the tender age of 19.

Chen said in the meeting with Gates that any entity that wants to keep a competitive edge -- whether a government, an enterprise, or an individual -- must follow two principles: it must maintain a high degree of creativity and invention, and have the courage to face failure so as to quickly get rid of old burdens and move toward broader new horizons.
Thanking Chen for his time, Gates said Taiwan's choice of Chen as the nation's new leader is a very important development which carries a special significance.

Gates hailed the efforts made by ROC authorities to sponsor the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology currently being held in Taipei, and said the event provides a good opportunity for all information technology figures to exchange their opinions and seek out new partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S YOUNGEST HEART TRANSPLANT PATIENT CHECKS OUT

TEXT.P: Asia's youngest heart transplant patient checked out of National Taiwan University Hospital on Tuesday.

Chang Chi-kai underwent the heart transplant operation at the same hospital in March, when he was only five months old. He weighed just four kilograms at the time, but has grown to 5.1 kilograms since the surgery.

Chang was diagnosed as suffering from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a disorder of the heart muscle, right after his birth in late September. He soon developed the symptoms of restlessness, cold sweats, and dyspnea, or difficulty in breathing.
Chang also showed no appetite, and was growing more slowly than normal. Doctors told his family that the only way to save him would be to undergo the heart transplant operation.
After five months of waiting, Chang received a replacement heart from a one-year-old baby who had died of a brain tumor.
After the surgery, Chang's system has shown only very mild signs of rejecting his new heart. Under the hospital's excellent care, he has become more lively than ever before.
Although he currently consumes half of his baby formula through a tube feed, it is better than before when he could not even have baby formula, said his grandmother.
Dr. Wang Shui-shen, a surgeon at the university hospital, said that the new heart has, by itself, shrunk to fit inside Chang's chest cavity, and that it will grow with Chang in the future.

Wang said that performing a heart transplant operation is safer in patients who have reached 10 years of age, since the risk for patients under 10 is five to six times greater than that of adults. He added that Chang is the youngest person in Asia to have received a heart transplant operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.001 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$30.801.
The NT dollar opened at NT$30.794 against the US dollar, and was traded between NT$30.794 and NT$30.808.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$287.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR GREATER COMMUNICATION ACROSS STRAIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said on Tuesday that Taiwan and mainland China should work to boost mutual understanding and bilateral exchanges after a separation of more than 50 years.

Lu made the remarks when meeting with US Senator John Rockefeller (D-W.V.), who is currently visiting Taipei to attend the 12th World Congress on Information Technology and the 24th annual joint Business Conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and the ROC-USA Business Council.
Lu thanked Rockefeller for his long-standing support of the Republic of China, and expressed the hope that the senator will continue to back Taiwan in the US Congress.

The vice president also asked about the current status of entrepreneurial cooperation between Taiwan and West Virginia, saying that she would be very happy to see even greater fruit from two-way cooperative ventures.

Rockefeller, who has long maintained very close relations with Taiwan, said he is also very concerned about the development of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and underscored the importance of maintaining security in the strait.
As a good friend of the ROC, Rockefeller promised to continue supporting Taiwan and providing advice to the ROC government.
Rockefeller also paid a visit to Premier Tang-fei later the same day. He took the opportunity to hail Chen's recent efforts to reduce cross-strait tensions.

According to the US senator, Chen's remarks on cross-strait relations have been quite appropriate, and the US side feels that his words have to some extent helped dissolve bilateral tensions between Taiwan and mainland China.
Teng praised Rockefeller as a genuine friend, and urged the US senator to continue backing the ROC in the US Congress. He also thanked him for his praise, on behalf of Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS SINCERITY TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed on Tuesday that the Republic of China is willing to open dialogue and negotiations with mainland China on the principles of parity, democracy and goodwill.
Chen made the vow during a tea party held at the Presidential Office in honor of resident representatives of countries with which the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties.
The president said he is hopeful that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume dialogue and work hand-in-hand to ensure peace and stability in the region.

Meanwhile, Chen said the ROC government will pool wisdom and resources with private groups to promote "total diplomacy" with a view to strengthening exchanges and cooperation with countries around the world and to participating in as many international organizations and activities as possible.

Chen and Vice President Annette Lu jointly hosted the tea party to express their gratitude for the attendance of foreign envoys at their May 20 inauguration, which also marked the ROC's first democratic transition of power from the long-ruling Kuomintang to the Democratic Progressive Party.

Chen, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician, also expressed thanks to all the foreign resident representatives for their contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and their home countries.
As an economically free and prosperous democracy, Chen said, the ROC is more than willing and can afford to take part in international humanitarian aid or relief projects.

However, Chen said because of Beijing's constant boycott, the ROC has been shut out of many international organizations and unable to forge normal diplomatic relations with major countries around the world.

"We appreciate all the support your countries have given to us for our bid to join major international organizations and activities in past years. And we hope your countries can offer us even more recognition and support for our national cause in the future so that we can join forces with the international community to create a new century of peace and prosperity," the president urged.

More than 60 resident foreign representatives and their spouses attended the tea party. Among the participants was Raymond Burghardt, head of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 'GLASS BABIES' TRAVEL TO VISIT TOKYO'S DISNEYLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, June 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) patients, more commonly known as the "glass babies," left for Tokyo Tuesday to embark on the first ever overseas trip of their lives.

Thirteen OI patients, whose ages range from 5 to 35, will be accompanied by 32 volunteer social workers, family members and medical personnel during their four-day tour of Japan, which will include a day at Tokyo's Disneyland -- a mecca for most children in Asia.

Cathay Pacific donated the air tickets and accommodation in Japan for the 13 OI patients, who suffer a hereditary disease characterized by abnormally brittle, easily fractured bones. The remaining 32 visitors paid their own fees, according to the Taipei-based Chinese OI Patients Association.

The patients suffer from a deficiency of typelprocollogen, a fibrous protein constituent of bones and cartilage, tendons, and other connective tissues. Their physical problems involve abnormally developed teeth and bones, as well as eyesight and hearing problems.

The patients don't grow normally, and are usually baby-sized even when they reach the age of adulthood. They also have weak hearing and grayish-blue sclera, the normally white fibrous tissue that covers all of the eyeball except the cornea.

Lin Li-chih, founder of the Chinese OI Patients Association and a "glass baby" himself, said at the age of 29, he has the same mind and intelligence of a normal grown man, but with a body of a three-year-old child -- coupled with brittle, easily fractured bones. He added that he will need to be taken care of all his life, and cannot move around without a wheelchair.

An 11-year-old female OI sufferer surnamed Lin, who is among the tour group, lay in a wheelchair looking like a one-year-old baby. She said that she is thrilled to be able to board an airplane to fly overseas, and added that visiting Disneyland would be a dream come true for her.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED HAT CHAIRMAN SPEAKS ON `TRANSPARENT TECHNOLOGIES'

TEXT.P: Bob Young, chairman and co-founder of Red Hat, Inc., spoke on Tuesday at the 2000 World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT) in Taipei about how open software sources have changed and benefited the computing industry.

The leader in open source Internet infrastructure solutions spoke immediately after Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, and while promoting the open source Linux software, mockingly referred to Microsoft as "viciously successful."

Young said Red Hat's idea of making software sources "transparent technologies" is based on treating customers as partners and pointed out that Red Hat earns its profits from maintenance and services rather than from royalties.

Expressing confidence in Red Hat's business model, Young said that the 6 billion people around the world provide tremendous business opportunities. As people rely more and more on technology, they should be allowed to use software freely, he went on.

Referring to competition between Red Hat and Microsoft, Young said that Red Hat operates differently from the proprietary Microsoft operating system and added that it is unlikely that Microsoft will change its system.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT SAYS HE `HEEDED VOICE OF PEOPLE'

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that he listened carefully to the "voice of the people" during his 12 years as Taiwan's head of state.
Lee made the remarks when he received around 40 representatives of Taiwan businessmen from the world who had come to pay tribute to the former president.
In a 30-minute address, Lee also said that he was receiving the representatives as "old friends."

He noted the three features of Taiwan's business councils, saying that they have pooled the strength of Taiwan businessmen around the world, that they have prepared Taiwan for the introduction of high technology to upgrade the development of local technology, and that they have played a role in establishing close relations with neighboring countries.

Lee said that with Taiwan business investment around the world totaling US$150 billion and with its foreign exchange reserves of US$120 billion, the two figures combined makes its economic might "even stronger than Japan's."
He also said that he has been writing since his retirement, noting that he has been working on two articles related to Taiwan's economy that will be published in mid-July.
He stressed that in the future, information will play a crucial role and urged his guests to bring information from around the world to Taiwan.

He expressed the hopes that Central Bank of China will help Taiwan businessmen solve their financing problems, that the Ministry of Education will help with the education of the children of Taiwan businessmen, and that Taiwan businessmen will cooperate with each in the field of information exchange.

Lee also said that he was happy to see the peaceful transfer of political power. But he did not respond to calls from his visitors that he continue to lead the Kuomintang, which has been in disarray since its humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election. Lee stepped down as party chairman to take responsibility for the election defeat.

During the meeting, Wang Kuei-jung, first president of the Taiwan Businessmen's Council in North America, suddenly knelt down before Lee to express his deepest respect for Lee's contribution to Taiwan's democratic and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S MILITARY CONDUCTS ROUTINE TRAINING EXERCISES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday that annual live-fire exercises which ended on June 4 in mainland China's coastal Fujian Province were routine.
MND Spokesman Kung Fan-ting said the exercises at Quanzhou Bay, Fujian Province, were annual sea exercises and included the firing of 152-millimeter shells.
He added that the MND is keeping tabs on whether similar activities are scheduled to take place.

Kung stressed that the MND closely monitors mainland military movements and its development of weapons systems, and that it will keep Taiwan's public informed about them as long as national security is not compromised.
Meanwhile, the MND announced that it will present more information in its website (www.mnd.gov.tw) starting from Wednesday.

The MND said that the new version of its website will include 16 categories, including the nation's military purchases, national defense reports, and guidelines for those preparing to enter military service.
Since the MND first established a website in February 1996, it has registered more than 965,000 "hits," and currently offers more than 8,000 pages.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS HAVE NOT DUMPED SRAM IN US: ITC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The US International Trade Commission (ITC) on Monday ruled in favor of Taiwan at the second remand of a final antidumping investigation on imports of static random access memory (SRAM) semiconductors from Taiwan.

The ITC found that the SRAM industry in the United States is not materially injured or threatened with material injury by imports of SRAM semiconductors from Taiwan that the US Department of Commerce had determined were sold in the United States at less than fair value.

The case was remanded to the ITC by the US Court of International Trade (CIT) on June 30, 1999, and again on April 11, 2000, despite the fact that the ITC had previously made a decision in Taiwan's favor in April 1998.
The ITC's remand determination will be delivered to the CIT by June 26, 2000.
The SRAM-dumping lawsuit was filed by US-based Micron Technology Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCK LANDING SHIP "HSUHAI" TO BE COMMISSIONED SOON

TEXT.P: The Anchorage-class dock landing ship leased by the Republic of China Navy from the United States will be commissioned in early July, a navy officer said Tuesday.
He said the combat readiness program for the amphibious vehicle will be completed soon.

The ship, which was first commissioned by the US Navy in 1971, arrived in a navy base in southern Taiwan in early June. It is 171 meters long and 25 meters wide with a displacement tonnage of 8,600-13,700 tons. It has a maximum speed of 22 knots and is able to sail 14,800 nautical miles before refueling.
To be renamed "Hsuhai," the ship will replace the old landing ship "Chung Cheng," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO GRASP IDEA OF RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged Beijing on Tuesday to resume cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue as soon as possible in line with the world trend of reconciliation and peace.

MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin noted that the leaders of South and North Korea started a historic summit in Pyongyang on Tuesday, which is expected to produce positive effects on peace on the Korean peninsula and on the security and stability of the East Asia region.

Lin said the Korean summit is a significant event that proves that two sides with differing political stances and systems can establish dialogue and communication channels as long as they try to eliminate the differences in their political stances in order to pursue reconciliation and cooperation.

Echoing ROC President Chen Shui-bian's words in his inaugural speech on May 20 that "now is a new opportunity for the two sides (of the Taiwan Strait) to create an era of reconciliation together," the MAC official urged the mainland Chinese authorities to work with the ROC to normalize cross-strait relations and resume as soon as possible bilateral dialogue and negotiations based on the existing foundation.
If the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can move in the same direction, a summit between the leaders of the two sides is foreseeable, Lin claimed.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said the Korean summit will not only help promote the security of Northeast Asia, but will also bring detente to the tense cross-strait situation.
MOFA spokesman Henry Chen added that officials of the ROC's representative office in South Korea will closely observe the developments following the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MICROSOFT TO SET UP WINDOWS HARDWARE QUALITY LAB IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Microsoft Corp. will establish a Windows hardware quality lab (WHQL) in Taipei to allow more Taiwan makers of computer hardware to acquire "Windows certificates," Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates said in Taipei on Tuesday.

At a press conference on the second day of the biennial 2000 World Congress on Information Technology, Gates said the Microsoft WHQL will help accelerate marketing in world markets of hardware and related products produced by local manufacturers.
Gates also said software remains the key to global business in the future at a time when many enterprises are seeking new possibilities to further expand their businesses in the Internet arena.

Gates said Microsoft will continue to reinforce creativity in more complex broadband technology, guaranteed-secure Internet transactions, personal computers fitted with microphones, and wireless telephones with computer screens.
He stressed that Microsoft's ideal is to create a new service platform to bring about numerous business opportunities for thousands of companies and clients that cooperate with Microsoft.

Gates said that Internet business is now swiftly entering its third stage -- an Internet service that is very personalized that will allow enterprises, consumers and program developers to obtain tailor-made services at any time, anywhere, using any Internet-compatible equipment.
Answering questions about a court-ordered breakup of Microsoft, Gates described the federal ruling as an "unfortunate distraction" that he believed will eventually be resolved in Microsoft's favor.

He claimed last week's ruling, which imposed restrictions on Microsoft's business conduct, "did not reflect reality" and was a "rewriting of the rules" in terms of giving consumers a choice of products.
"We all know this is a fast-paced competitive business. We thrive on competition. If anything, the most this kind of misguided lawsuit can do is to draw our team together," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PYONGYANG SUMMIT INSPIRATIONAL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: LIEN

TEXT.P: Former ROC Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that the ongoing summit between South Korea and its reclusive northern neighbor is inspirational to relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Lien, now the acting chairman of the Kuomintang, Taiwan's ruling party until May 20, further said whether the historic meeting in Pyongyang between South Korean President Kim Dae-jung and his North Korean counterpart Kim Jong-il can succeed depends on the previous preparatory works and the current general environment.
As for the possible impact on cross-Taiwan Strait relations of the "two Kims" summit, Lien said it needs further observation and study.

Meanwhile, Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, said he sees little possibility for the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet in the foreseeable future.
Chang said although there is no immediate crisis of the eruption of a military conflict between the two sides, their relations remain deadlocked.

Chang pointed out that the two Koreas basically enjoy an equal status and that neither of them forsakes the goal of eventual unification. "The relations between them can be defined as a special state-to-state relationship," he added.
Turning to cross-strait relations, Chang said when the KMT was in power, it repeatedly urged the mainland Chinese government to accept the concept -- "China is a divided country."
"However, Beijing consistently rejected the KMT's call, insisting that Beijing itself, not Taiwan, has inherited China's sovereignty," Chang said.
In addition, Chang said, mainland China has traditionally harbored a "bullying mentality" toward Taiwan due to their huge gap in size and population.

"Mainland leaders have been unwilling to face up to the cold reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been separately ruled and do not subject themselves to each other's jurisdiction," Chang noted.

He recalled that Taiwan has long welcomed top mainland leaders to visit the island. "In 1995, then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui suggested that he and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, met in an international setting. However, Jiang bluntly snubbed the proposal."
Against this background, Chang said he thinks that chances for a cross-strait summit in the foreseeable future are slim.

Commenting on the current "two Kims" summit, Chang Wu-yueh, head of the Tamkang University's Mainland Affairs Research Institute, said mainland China should draw inspiration from the development of Seoul-Pyongyang relations.

Noting that the two Koreas have conducted official contacts since 1972 and have consistently treated each other on an equal footing in the international community. "Neither of them worries that their engagement on an equal footing would result in permanent division," Chang said.

He further said as mainland China's land area is 270 times that of Taiwan and its population 60 times Taiwan's, Beijing leaders need not worry that treating Taiwan as an equal would drive Taiwan farther away or hinder eventual unification of the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC ESTIMATES ROC ECONOMY WILL GROW 6.3% THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, May 13 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Shammy Chao)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's economic growth rate for 2000 and 2001 is expected to reach 6.3 and 6.8 percent, respectively, up from last year's 5.7 percent, according to the economic outlook report for the Asia Pacific region released by the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on Tuesday.

The same report showed that Japan's economy grew by 0.3 percent in 1999, a figure that is expected to reach 1.2 percent in 2000 and 2.1 percent in 2001. Japan's growth remains the lowest among all the East Asian countries.

The same APEC report also forecasted the economic growth rates of other major Asian economies for this year and the following year. Mainland China is expected to achieve economic growth of 7.3 and 7.6 percent in the next two years; South Korea, 8.5 and 5.9 percent; Hong Kong, 6.8 and 4.7 percent; and Singapore, 6.5 and 5.5 percent.

Meanwhile, the report's forecasted economic growth for the U.S. in 2000 and 2001 was 4.1 and 2.7 percent, respectively; for Canada, 4.4 and 3.7 percent; for Australia, 3.4 and 3.2 percent; and for New Zealand, 3.9 and 4.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEWLETT-PACKARD CEO PROMOTES PRODUCTS MADE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Hewlett-Packard (HP) CEO Carly Fiorina on Tuesday lauded the entrepreneurial spirit of Taiwan manufacturers and the resolute policy of the government, factors which she said are bound to turn Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

At the invitation of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council, Fiorina squeezed some time out of her tight schedule to feature in an ad in which she echoed her words on the opening day of the World Congress 2000 on Information Technology (WCIT) to promote the excellence of made-in-Taiwan (MIT) products.

Fiorina said the entrepreneurial spirit of Taiwan manufacturers and their high competitiveness are the biggest advantages that are moving Taiwan forward, and added that Taiwan enterprises have performed brilliantly in invention and reinvention.

A comparison of the perception of the words "made-in-Taiwan" 30 years ago and now will show that MIT now stands for a world-class quality, and that MIT products are outstanding both in inventive R&D and design.
Bill Gates, chairman of computer giant Microsoft and Andrew Grove, chairman of Intel, have featured in similar ads produced by CETRA in the past.

Fiorina attended a discussion panel earlier in the day with local business leaders Miao Feng-ching of Mitac and Douglas Hsu of Far East Group, to exchange views on finding a pioneering spirit and on the courage and challenges of leaders.
She said that Taiwan enterprises maintain a full competitive edge by offering high value-added products through its consistent inventiveness, adding that MIT products are now world-class.
But at the same time, Taiwan and other Asian business leaders display relative modesty, which she said aims to cover their competitiveness, a point that US enterprises need to learn.

Fiorina, who has been rated by the Fortune magazine as the most valuable business anger in the US for two consecutive years, also spoke of the key to HP's success, which she attributed to correct decision-making and giving her staff a free environment to pursue their innovations.
She also cited the Chinese wisdom of the "middle way" as a guideline for management and leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S FUTURE LIES IN ENTIRE CHINA: MAINLAND SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 12 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Thirty US-based mainland Chinese scholars and students issued a joint open letter to the Kuomintang on Monday, reminding the Republic of China's ruling party until May 20 that its future lies in entire China.

The group of mainland scholars and students, led by Xin Haonien, a visiting professor at Columbia University, issued the open letter a week before the KMT holds an extraordinary national congress to discuss party rejuvenation after its embarrassing defeat in Taiwan's March 18 presidential election.

The mainland scholars and students said in the letter that although some people rule out the KMT's possibility of regaining power in Taiwan, they believe that the party still have a bright future in entire China.
The letter said as the KMT has never ceased pursuit of progress throughout its 100-plus years of history, it is unlikely to fall apart nor to be defeated.
While KMT members feel frustrated by the election defeat, the letter said, they should find comfort in the realization of democracy in Taiwan.

Noting that the KMT defeat proved the fairness and openness of the March 18 vote, the letter pointed out that the KMT, unlike mainland China's Chinese Communist Party, does not face any threat to fall apart. Moreover, it said, the party does not lose the freedom or chances to take part in future elections in Taiwan or even in mainland China some day.

The letter reminded its members that the party has a glory history, completing six great missions in the past century -- overthrowing the corrupt Ching dynasty and establishing the Republic of China; defeating war lords and unifying the whole China; resisting Japanese aggression; enacting the democratic "ROC Constitution"; insisting on its anti-communist policy; and building Taiwan into a prosperous democracy.

The letter said so long as the KMT can keep in line with Taiwan's and even entire China's public opinions, work firmly to defend Taiwan's democratic system, and strive for China's unification under freedom and democracy, the party will certainly have a bright future in Taiwan and entire China.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMC PRESIDENT STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF DATA STORAGE

TEXT.P: Any company which is capable of transforming astronomical and fast-growing data into useful information is entitled to enjoy the best competitiveness, EMC President and COO Joseph Tucci said in Taipei on Tuesday.

At a speech on the second day of the World Congress 2000 on Information Technology (WCIT), Tucci said that at a time when Internet development is entering the "fourth stage," the volume of online data is increasing four-fold annually rather than the one-fold annual growth of previous years, a fact which indicates the importance of data storage.

In a speech titled "Where the World's Information Lives," Tucci estimated that the global data storage market will reach US$44 billion this year, based on the fact that most of EMC's clients spent half of their information-related operational costs on data storage.

Quoting David Moschella from his book "Waves of Power," Tucci said there are four stages in the development of computer science and application. In the first stage -- the system-centric era -- computer users had a population of 10 million worldwide.
In the second stage -- the PC-centric era -- some 100 million people used computers and related systems, Tucci said.
In the third stage -- the Internet-centric era -- about 300 million regularly surfed online.
In the fourth stage -- the content-centric era -- which has recently kicked off, the Internet population worldwide is expected to reach 1 billion in five years, Tucci went on.

He said that by 2005, all data will be stored in digital form and the world will be facing the greatest-ever "information wave." He added that information itself will become increasingly invaluable with the growth in the number of users.
EMC is a world leader in intelligent storage systems, software and Internet-system manufacturing and related services.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD INDUSTRY SHOW TO KICK OFF ON JUNE 15

TEXT.P: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Industry Show is scheduled to open on June 15 at the Taipei World Trade Center, with a total of 560 firms from more than 10 countries occupying 1,100 booths.
Countries such as Canada, France, Australia and Austria will have their own pavilions at the event in order to showcase their distinctive local foodstuffs.

For Taiwan's part, the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan and several local agricultural associations will be responsible for the display of Taiwanese foods at the annual event. The local displays will feature mainly CAS-certified food, seafood, and livestock products, with the aim of reinforcing the image of local agricultural products.

In conjunction with the show, the organizer -- the semi-official China External Trade Development Council -- will also hold more than 10 seminars to discuss issues such as the opening up of the foodstuff market subsequent to Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization, the effectiveness of Chinese herbal medicine in treating cancer, and the market for American organic food.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER: NUCLEAR WASTE DISPOSAL PACT WITH PYONGYANG STILL VALID

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) on Tuesday denied news reports that it is seeking to extend a contract that it signed with North Korea on the disposal of nuclear waste.

The state-run firm signed a contract with Pyongyang in January 1997 under the terms of which the North Koreans agreed to dispose of 60,000 barrels of low-grade radioactive nuclear waste produced by Taipower's nuclear power plants.
However, pressure from mainland China and South Korea means that the terms of the contract have never been realized.

Local media reported recently that as the 1997 contract is due to expire this year, Taipower and North Korea have agreed to an extension of the pact for five years, with Taiwan paying Pyongyang US$3 million in storage site construction costs, in addition to an additional US$1 million per year for the management of the site.

"The existing contract is still valid and will be realized as soon as the Atomic Council under the Executive Yuan gives a green light to the export of our nuclear waste," Taipower said in a press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: INAUGURAL INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY AWARDS BESTOWED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Some 10 groups and institutions from around the world were honored on Tuesday with information technology awards at the World Congress 2000 on Information Technology (WCIT) now under way in Taipei.

The inaugural Global IT Excellence Awards were given to people influential to the promotion and application of IT, according to the World Information Technology and Service Alliance (WITSA), a body supervising the WCIT.

The National Information Infrastructure (NII), a Taiwan planning agency, received the Digital Opportunity Award, which is given to those who have simplified IT so that the public can enjoy the benefits it brings.

The awards are divided into three categories: the Public Sector IT Excellence Award and the Private Sector IT Excellence Award, which aim to encourage the application of IT and the progress of related industries; and the Digital Opportunity Award.

The winners of the Public Sector IT Excellence Awards were: the State Tax Administration Agency of the Spanish Ministry of Finance; the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore; and Foster Parents Plan, a member of PLAN International of Canada.

The winners of the Private Sector IT Excellence Awards were: Leonia WAP Bank of Finland; Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd.; Fifth-Generation Total Information System; and Banco Rio de la Plata S.A. of South America.
The winner of the Chairman's Award was P&G 2000 of Romania.
The award ceremony, held at National Theater, was interspersed with performances, and the guests were thrilled to see a new dance routine by the Cloud Gate Dance Ensemble.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REPEATS CALL FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday said that his administration is willing to engage in dialogue with mainland China on the basis of equality, democracy and goodwill.
Chen made the remarks at a tea party he hosted jointly with Vice President Annette Lu in honor of the envoys of countries that have no diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Chen said that his administration will pool the strengths of the public and private sectors to launch "all dimensions" diplomacy to enhance exchanges and cooperation with countries around the world and to take part in international organizations and activities.
He thanked the envoys for their contributions to promoting friendly ties between their home countries and Taiwan.

He also expressed regret that the ROC, despite being a democratic country and a free economy, has not been allowed to give its full feedback to the international community due to the continual blockade of the country by mainland China, and he called for more international support for Taiwan.
Around 60 foreign representatives, including Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), attended the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAIL CORP. SIGNS DEAL WITH JAPANESE FIRM

TEXT.P: Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) signed a preliminary agreement with Japan's Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) on Tuesday for purchasing core system and equipment for the island's first high-speed railway.
The memorandum of understanding (MOU) on the NT$95 billion (US$3.1 billion) deal was sealed by THSRC President Lee Kuo-hsiung and TSC representative Yoshiyuki Yokota in Taipei.
It was the largest single procurement contract ever struck between Taiwan and Japan. The deal also marked a major step forward in the island's ambitious high-speed railway project.
THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing said by signing the MOU, TSC has become the the THSRC's sole supplier of core equipment and power system for the island's high-speed rail system.
Describing the MOU as "one of the most important milestones" for the project, Ing said a formal contract is expected to be signed in four to six weeks.

According to the MOU, TSC, led by Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, will supply "bullet" train carriages and locomotives, as well as signaling, communication and electrification systems for Taiwan's high-speed rail line.
To hedge against risks of exchange rate fluctuations, THSRC will pay for TSC products in three currencies, the New Taiwan dollar, the Japanese yen and the US greenback.

The electrification system to be used by THSRC will be an upgraded and modified version of 700E being used in Japan's Shinkanen systems, Ing said, adding that the Shinkansen's good security records and its electrification system's environmental friendliness are major factors that THSRC decided to pick TSC as its supplier and partner. TSC has promised to offer five-year maintenance services and to help train relevant personnel.
THSRC, a business and industry consortium, won the NT$440 billion contract in July 1998 to build the 340 kilometer-railway under a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula.

Ing said TSC will obtain a 10 percent stake in THSRC by contributing about NT$13.5 billion in cash. "The first installment of capital from TSC, about NT$2.4 billion, is expected to come in late this year," she said, adding that THSRC's capitalisation is scheduled to increase to NT$132.1 billion in five years.
Except for Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, TSC partners also include Marubeni Corp., Mitsui Corp.' Sumitomo Corp., Kawasaki Heavy Industries, and Toshiba Electric.
TSC unexpectedly defeated the Alstom-Siemens Eurotrain consortium last December to win exclusive negotiating rights for the THSRC's core system and equipment contract.

Eurotrain consortium, which was named THSRC's "preferred bidder" on a preliminary 1997 deal for the supply of the equipment and systems, in January filed an injunction with the Taipei district court to bar THSRC from signing the contract with the Japanese consortium.
The legal action was dropped after the judge said Eurotrain failed to provide sufficient evidence for an injunction against THSRC.
Construction on the high-speed railway, linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south, started last year and the rail system is expected to become operational in 2005.
