DOC.HEADLINE: US TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR CONFAB

TEXT.P: US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater arrived in Taipei Wednesday morning to attend meetings to discuss how the United States and Taiwan can expand transportation and trade ties with each other and with the rest of the world.

In a formal statement upon his arrival, Slater said he was pleased to have the opportunity to visit Taiwan to reaffirm and strengthen the long standing friendship between the American people and the people of Taiwan.

At the invitation of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and its Taiwan counterpart -- the ROC-US Business Council, Slater is the third consecutive US secretary of transportation to participate in the annual meeting, slated for Wednesday and Thursday.

Slater said President Clinton and Vice President Gore are grateful for the work of the two councils and applaud their efforts to promote broader and closer economic and trade relations between the two peoples.

"Both the president and vice president firmly believe that transportation is the crucial link in enabling free trade to contribute to prosperity throughout the world in this new century and new millennium," Slater said.

He added that the theme of this year's conference: "Taiwan's New Landscape: Business Opportunities in the 21st Century," underscores the future economic and commercial relations between the US and Taiwan.
"I look forward to hearing the perspectives of American and Taiwan businessmen and women, who are the foundation of our vibrant economic relationship," he said.

"I am also here to explore how the business community and transportation leaders can work together to encourage global economic development by improving the quality of the transportation choices and decisions we make - particularly over the next 25 years," he continued.

Slater also noted that Taiwan continues to maintain its impressive economic growth, which is a reflection of the success of Taiwan's economic and political systems. "The people of Taiwan are the key reason for this success story," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 14, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1645: Parliamentary troops under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell inflict a heavy defeat on Prince Rupert's Royalist forces at Nasby in the English Midlands, scoring a decisive Parliamentary victory in the Civil War.
1777: The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1789: After drifting an incredible 3,500 miles in an open boat, English Admiral Captain Bligh and 18 royal crew members, cast adrift from the HMS Bounty, eventually reach the island of Timor in the East Indies.
1838: Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894: After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Columbian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900: The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920: In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936: Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940: German troops march into Paris, and the flag of Nazi Germany, bearing the swastika, is hoisted up the Eiffel Tower.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943: The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949: Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952: The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is put on public display in the United States.
1955: The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964: In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: A Japan Airlines DC-8 crashes at Delhi airport, killing 87 people.
1973: a 10-member Chinese national judo team headed by Mao Ming-chu leaves for Lausanne to take part in the 8th world championships.
1974: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung and Deputy Premier Cuthbert Edwy Talma of the Barbados sign a joint communique in Taipei announcing the extension of the Sino-Barbados agricultural technical cooperation agreement.
1975: More than 500 Chinese poets and Dr. Jeno Platthy, chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Third World Congress of Poets, gathered in Taipei to celebrate Chinese Poets Day and pay homage to poet Chu Yuan of the period of Spring and Autumn Annals.
1978: A technical cooperation agreement between Saudi Arabia and the Republic of China is signed.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Huang Shao-ku and Hung Shou-nan as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, respectively, following unanimous approval by the Control Yuan.
1982: Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo visits the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Taipei to extend his condolences over the passing of King Khalid ibn abdul Aziz.
1989: Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth.
1992: Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
1997: Vice President and Premier Lien Chan announces that the government will establish a Ministry of Culture.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 44.14 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 44.14 points to close at 8,935.23.
Market turnover amounted to NT$ 117.79 billion (US$3.84 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE INDUSTRIES TO BE ALLOWED TO INVEST ON MAINLAND: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said on Wednesday that about 94 percent of industries will be allowed to invest in mainland China in the future.
Lin made the remarks in a report on investment activities across the Taiwan Strait at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economic Affairs and Energy Committee.

The business executive-turned-minister told lawmakers that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is reviewing the previous Kuomintang government's "go slow" policy on mainland China-bound investment.
"We are considering whether we should further ease restrictions on investment in mainland China," said Lin, a former vice chairman of China Motor Corp., an affiliate of Yulon Motor Group.

Under current regulations, about 72 percent of industries are allowed to invest in mainland China and only 4 percent are on an off-limits list. The remaining industries are subject to government screening and approval on a case-by-case basis.
Lin said the MOEA is mulling whether to liberalize investment in mainland China's upperstream petrochemical industry and semiconductor industry, both of which are now on the "off-limits" list.

In the near future, Lin said, some industries on the "off-limits" list will be moved to the list of "screening and approval on a case-by-case basis," and about 24 percent of those on the "screening" list will be included into the "free investment" list.

According to Lin, mainland China was very eager to attract Taiwan investment eight to nine years ago. "But it has now become more selective and reserved to the fields to be open to Taiwan investors," he noted.

Moreover, Lin said, as most of Taiwan-owned companies on the mainland are export-oriented, they are keener than their mainland counterparts to see opening of direct cross-strait trade, postal and transport links.

Against this backdrop, Lin said the MOEA will also review the current ban on the direct cross-strait "three links." If national security can be ensured and cross-strait dialogue can resume, he said, the government does not rule out the possibility of taking bold steps to ease the "three links" ban.
Lin further said mainland China now badly welcomes Taiwan investment in upperstream petrochemical, wafer and telecommunications industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO TURN ROC CAPITAL INTO A CYBERCITY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday said that the capital city must forge itself into a "cyber city" in order to become a competitive international metropolis as well as a regional center in the information revolution.

Speaking to industry and government leaders from over 80 countries on the final day of the biennial World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT), Ma said that Taipei must break away from the traditional mindset of building the city on its limited physical space. Instead, he added, Taipei is embracing information technology to make municipal information and services widely available to the public through the Internet.

Ma said that the establishment of an expansive public information network will allow the citizens of Taipei to spend less time on traffic-prone streets running errands or even commuting to work. According to Ma, the number of vehicles per kilometer of Taipei city road is 1,058, compared to 141 in Tokyo, 173 in Singapore, and 267 in Hong Kong.

Ma, who was elected to office in December 1998, said that by the end of his term in 2002, all of the city government's 57 "level one" agencies and their direct subordinate agencies will have attained a ratio of one computer per employee. Also by 2002, he said that the city will have installed 800 public information kiosks, with an initial 200 kiosks in place by the end of 2000.

Stressing the importance of universal access to the Internet, which he called "the most influential tool of the 21st century," Ma said that Taipei plans to provide network services on the same commodity principles of existing public utilities: affordability and convenient accessibility. Beginning this year, Taipei is offering every one of its citizens a free, life-long email address, added Ma.

WCIT 2000 marks the first time that the conference is being held in Asia outside of Japan. The theme of WCIT 2000, an industry event spanning three days, is "IT for a Better World: A New Millennium." WCIT 2002 will be held in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 44.14 points to close at 8,935.23.
Encouraged by a rebound in stock prices in the United States, the bourse opened at 8,978.45 and fluctuated between 9,014.27 and 8,911.38 during trading.

A total of 1.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$117.79 billion (US$3.84 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.49 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$94.87 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers 271 to 227, with 109 stocks remaining unchanged.

Half of the eight major categories lost ground, with both foodstuff shares and construction stocks moving down the most a 0.5 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.8 percent, and electrical shares at 0.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Wednesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved up 76 points to close at 8,965, with 2,335 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July increased 47 points to finish at 8,992, with 365 contract transactions, while September futures gained 46 points to close at 9,066, with 28 contract transactions.
Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 8,949 for June; 9,010 for July; and 9,020 for September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported positive results.

June TE futures moved up 5.5 points to close at 503, with 939 contract transactions, while July TE futures increased 6 points to finish at 503.7, with 177 contract transactions, and September TE futures gained 4 points to close at 509.5.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures gained 11 points to close at 893, with 228 contract transactions, while July TF futures increased 10 points to finish at 902, with 28 contract transactions.
September TF futures moved up 6.2 points to finish at 901, with 15 contract transactions, while December TF futures gained 4 points to close at 908, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WILL NOT MEDDLE IN TSEA LEGISLATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The new government of the Republic of China will stand firm on its policy of not meddling in the "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act" (TSEA) legislative process in the US Congress, the ROC representative office here said on Tuesday.

According to the office, Taipei would be glad to see the US Congress pass the bill, but it will not try to interfere. The ROC's position on this matter has not changed with the recent inauguration of Presdient Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the office noted.
The ROC representative office added that the Foreign Affairs Ministry in Taipei has also instructed it to underscore the ROC's unchanged stance toward the issue.
Outgoing ROC Representative Stephen Chen was strongly criticized by the then opposition DPP lawmakers for failing to lobby US congressmen for approval of the bill.

The TSEA, initiated by pro-ROC senators and House representatives, was worked out with the aim of further boosting two-way military exchanges between Taiwan and the United States. The TSEA passed the House of Representatives last October, but failed to gain enough support later in the Senate.
The US administration has repeatedly said that it will not support the TSEA legislation under the pretext that Taiwan's security has been well served by the existing Taiwan Relations Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: 44-HOUR WORKWEEK A `WIN-WIN' POLICY, SAYS ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi on Wednesday described the Cabinet-version of shortening the workweek from 48 hours to 44 hours as a "win-win" policy beneficial to both capital and labor.

Lin said the proposed shortened workweek legislation, pending approval by the Legislature on Friday, should not adversely affect Taiwan's overall competitiveness as the industrial and business sectors will be allowed six months to adjust before the program formally takes effect on Jan. 1, 2001.
The industrial sector can accelerate automation and improve the production process in order to reduce the impact of the shorter workweek, Lin added.
The Executive Yuan passed an amendment on Wednesday cutting the maximum number of work hours per week without any preconditions from 48 to 44, starting Jan. 1, 2001.
The amendment allows workers to either have one-and-a-half days off each week, two days off every other week twice each month, or three days off at one time each month.
President Chen Shui-bian was pleased to hear about the passage of the 44-hour workweek proposal, which was one of his election promises, said Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung.
Chang said the president expressed the wish that the proposal will be passed smoothly by the Legislative Yuan on Friday.

Meanwhile, the government spokeswoman, Chung Chin, told reporters at a press conference in the wake of the amendment's passage that Premier Tang Fei described the amendment as a commendable agreement reached by the government, employers, and workers.
The 44-hour workweek program is one of the Cabinet's major administrative guidelines for 2001 passed by the Executive Yuan on Wednesday.
The Chinese Federation of Labor, the top labor group in Taiwan, welcomed the amendment, calling it a new example of conciliation between capital and labor.
Five other major labor groups, including the Federation of Industrial Labor Unions in Taiwan, all expressed their satisfaction with the proposal.

Business, however, seemed less than pleased with the development, as the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), the largest group of industrial entrepreneurs in Taiwan, said it accepted the amendment with a feeling of disappointment.

CNFI Deputy Secretary-General Kuo Yung-hsiung said the government should let employers and employees resolve the matter in a way that is acceptable for both sides. He said the government should not step in and make decisions for the two sides unless negotiations break down.
The shorter workweek is expected to have a direct impact on about half of all the manufacturing industries islandwide, Kuo noted.

Commenting on the Cabinet's passage of the 44-hour workweek, Far Eastern Textile Vice President Wang Hsiao-yi said the shortened workweek threatens to cost manufacturers a 10 percent increase in personnel costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE TO BE PRIORITY TASK

TEXT.P: Promoting dialogue across the Taiwan Strait will be a priority task for the Cabinet over the next year, according to a government work plan for 2001 unveiled on Wednesday.
The Cabinet approved its six-point 2001 work plan at its weekly meeting presided over by Premier Tang Fei.
The package outlined six major policy goals for the coming year:
-- Establishing clean politics and improving public order to upgrade the quality of life;
-- Creating a better economic climate to maintain Taiwan's market niches;
-- Speeding up government restructuring to forge a new partnership between the government and the general public;
-- Accelerating reconstruction in the "921" earthquake-stricken areas and helping victims rebuild their homes and lives.
The package also included concrete measures to be taken by the Cabinet to realize its major policy goals as follows:
-- crackdown on organized crime and official corruption;
-- evaluating the feasibility of opening direct trade, postal and transport links with mainland China;
-- gradually cutting the import quota for foreign workers;
-- implementing the "3-3-3" welfare services step-by-step;
-- shortening work week; building Taiwan into a green silicon island;
-- consolidating the inspection system for banking and financial institutions;
-- improving financial relations between central and local governments;
-- and reviewing domestic regional development plans to ensure balanced urban and rural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.014 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$30.815.
The local currency opened at NT$30.802 and was traded between NT$30.795 and NT$30.820.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$243.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KIMS' SUMMIT SEEN HAVING POSITIVE IMPACT ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: The historic summit between North and South Korean leaders will have a positive impact on the possible meeting between Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and People's Republic of China President Jiang Zemin in the foreseeable future to sort out cross-strait differences, political experts said.

In an interview with the CNA on Wednesday, Gary Klintworth, a veteran China-Taiwan expert, said that "if an isolationist and hostile Kim Jong-Il can put up such an amicable smile to greet his South Korean counterpart Kim Dae-Jung, there is no reason why the Chinese leader could not do that."

"The extraordinary pictures of the North Korean dictator Kim Jong-Il greeting South Korea's democratically elected President Kim Dae-Jung at Pyongyang airport offer the best hope we have had in decades that substantial change may be about to occur in the world's looniest Stalinist redoubt, North Korea," said Greg Sheridan, foreign editor of The Australian.

Other experts said that the amicable meeting between the two Kims has captured the imagination of rival leaders or countries and could help ease tensions in the Korean Peninsula while offering hope for reconciliation after 50 years of hostility between the two rival Koreas.

"It will be easier for China's Jiang Zemin and other leaders to shake hands with their Taiwanese counterparts. If the North Korean leader can do it, why can't the Chinese leader do the same," Klintworth said.

He pointed that it's easier for mainland China to hold talks with Taiwan because both Taipei and Beijing have been in contact since Taiwan in 1987 lifted a ban on its citizens visiting relatives on the mainland.

Returning to Canberra a few days ago from recent trips to both Taiwan and China, Klintworth said he had the impression that moderates in mainland China were gaining the upper hand in forming policy, particularly regarding matters on the reunification with Taiwan.

In an article published in The Australian on Wednesday, Kevin Rudd, a former Australian diplomat and now a federal Labor Party member of Parliament, said that history possibly repeats itself in international politics.

"Sometimes, just sometimes, in the otherwise tawdry world of international politics, you have the sense that you just might be seeing history in the making, such as Richard Nixon's meeting with Mao Zedong, Boris Yeltsin standing on the tank in front of the Russian Duma, and the resignation of President Soeharto," he noted.

He said the "sunshine policy" of rapprochement and engagement with North Korea championed by South Korea's President Kim Dae-Jung is working and he believes "the first, perhaps faltering step has been taken."
"Let's hope Beijing and Taipei are watching," he added.
Experts said reconciliation between North and South Korea would not only ease tensions in the Korean Peninsula, but would also reduce fears of North Korea's nuclear threat.

The United States will be one of the Western powers hoping to see that reconciliation happens between the two Koreas as this would pave the way for possible reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits, experts said.

But they also acknowledged that it will be quite a long time before reunification occurs on the Korean peninsula and that leaders of the two countries need lots of patience and wisdom to overcome the obstacles on the way to their eventual target.
They believe the Korean case could be applied to Taiwan and mainland China in their search for reconciliation.
"The first summit of the two Kims has set a good example for both Chinese and Taiwanese leaders and it could give inspiration to both Jiang Zemin and Chen Shui-bian," Klintworth said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT SHOULD BE USED MORE IN MEDICAL FIELD: MEDICAL EXPERT

TEXT.P: The application of information technology (IT) should not be confined only to business but should also be used in the medical field to allow more people to lead better lives, Operation Smile Founder William Magee said on Wednesday.

In a speech on the third day of the World Congress 2000 on Information Technology (WCIT), Magee, founder of Operation Smile, Inc., said that his organization has already conducted "long-distance, cross-continent" craniofacial surgical procedures through the medium of television conferencing and the Internet.
The operations help change the lives of many people and make the world more beautiful, Magee said in his speech titled "Information Technology Changing the Face of the World."
Although Magee's speech was not directly related to the development of the IT industry and business, he was so eloquent and touching that he received a standing ovation from the conference attendees.

Magee, whose Operation Smile has conducted plastic surgery on children all over the world, including Vietnam, Myanmar, Nicaragua and Columbia, said children who suffer facial defects usually suffer from very low self-esteem all their lives, but added that this can be changed with just a four- or five-minute operation.
However, he went on, children from poor, remote, and backward areas are unlikely to ever get the opportunity to benefit from even such a simple, fast procedure.

He noted that last year, under the sponsorship of Operation Smile, local surgeons in Colombia conducted several craniofacial surgical procedures on children, with help provided by plastic surgeons in the United States communicating via a broadband Internet system.

Magee added that he is now planning an online college in the hope that through Internet teaching, medical personnel in backward areas can learn more advanced technologies and medical knowledge so as to help them upgrade their practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT ASIAN COUNTRIES TO INITIATE ASIAN INTERNET NETWORK THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and seven other Asian countries will inaugurate the Asian Internet Network on Thursday with the aim of gradually reducing regional fees, officials at the Communications Authority of Thailand (CAT) said.

The co-founders of the project are Thailand's CAT, Chunghwa Telecom of Taiwan, Indonesia Satellite Corp., Japan's KDD, Long Distance Telephone of the Philippines, Korea Telecom, Singapore Telecom, and Telekom Malaysia, said the officials.

The collaboration was initiated two years ago in a bid to reduce the net traffic routes to the United States and bring cheaper charges to users. Furthermore, the initiative will enhance the speed capacity of traffic among the eight countries.

The Asian Internet Network is connected with the Internet gateway in each of the eight countries with an initial bandwidth capacity of 512 kilobites per second.The bandwidth volume can be increased by 70 percent if demand grows.
This fee structure was the most hotly debated topic at an IT ministerial meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) held last month in Mexico.
According to a report by Singapore's IT Ministry during the meeting, Asian ISPs pay an annual US$5 billion to US-based ISPs, but no money has come the other way.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON WISHES SUCCESS TO ROC-USA, USA-ROC JOINT BUSINESS CONFAB

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton sent his greetings to the participants in the 24th annual Joint Business Conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-USA Business Councils, which kicked off on Wednesday in Taipei.

Clinton said he appreciates the work of the two councils in promoting broader and closer economic and trade relations between the American people and the people of Taiwan, and extended his best wishes for a successful and productive conference.

In his message, Clinton said both the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and the ROC-USA Business Council have made important contributions to the development of strong economic relations between the United States and Taiwan, and he is confident that this year's meeting will further advance those ties.

He said the theme of the conference -- "Taiwan's New Landscape: Business Opportunities in the 21st Century" -- is especially appropriate this year, as Taiwan coped exceptionally well with the Asian financial crisis, demonstrated remarkable resilience in its quick recovery from last September's devastating earthquake, and recently completed the peaceful transition of power from one political party to another.

"We hope this year brings a historic development that will influence the activities of both of your councils -- the entry of both Taiwan and the People's Republic of China into the World Trade Organization," he added.

"Taiwan's and the PRC's accessions will benefit the two economies, increase cross-strait stability, and help to strengthen the world trade system. We hope that American companies will make their own contributions to this process," he continued.

Clinton said that over the past five decades, through hard work and good management, Taiwan has become the world's 17th-largest economy and the United States' seventh-largest trading partner. "These are impressive accomplishments upon which Taiwan continues to build," he went on.
"We note and applaud the new leadership's desire to further open Taiwan's economy by promoting greater transparency and international competitiveness," he said.

"We will be watching closely for further opening in the telecommunications sector, improvements of intellectual property rights, improvements in government procurement procedures, strengthening of the supervision and regulation of the banking sector, and speedier privatization," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE LAMENTS PROPOSAL TO RECALL VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Presidential Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung on Wednesday lamented a planned proposal raised by opposition lawmakers to recall Vice President Annette Lu, saying that such a move will affect the stability of the new government.

Stressing that the proposal to remove Lu comes at a time when the new government of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been inaugurated for less then one month, Chang claimed that the move will cast a shadow of political uncertainty over Taiwan that will not benefit the people.
He emphasized that President Chen Shui-bian and Lu "get along very well" and denied rampant speculation that the two are at loggerheads.

Chang's remarks came on the heels of a news conference called by Kuomintang lawmaker Mu Min-chu earlier the same day, in which she said she would put forward a motion in the Legislative Yuan to recall Lu, and that the proposal had been endorsed by 54 legislators -- the required 25 percent of the legislature -- from the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party.
However, Mu added that she might reserve the right to raise the proposal, and that she was still considering allowing Lu's fate to be decided by the Taiwan people through a public plebiscite.

Pointing out that her planned recall motion is aimed at giving Lu a warning, the KMT lawmaker strongly criticized the vice president for violating the spirit of the Constitution by repeatedly making improper comments on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, seriously undermining national security since her inauguration on May 20.

Mu said various of Lu's remarks, such as her description of herself as "devil's advocate" and her claim that Taiwan's status remains undetermined, have provoked fear among the Taiwan people, and that she must be warned immediately as part of efforts to ward off military conflict in the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, DPP legislative whip Cheng Pao-ching said the DPP caucus had instructed DPP lawmakers not to endorse the proposal and was seeking to negotiate the matter with its KMT counterparts in a bid to persuade them not to pursue the idea of recalling Lu.
Lu refused to comment on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE SAID TO BE BIGGEST CHALLENGE TO ASIAN PEACE

TEXT.P: Authoritarian China's determination to gain control over democratic Taiwan is the biggest challenge to long-term peace and stability in Asia, apart from the danger of all-out war on the Korean peninsula, according to an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald.

In a commentary on Wednesday, the daily's foreign affairs and defense correspondent David Lague said there are forces at work on both sides of the Taiwan Strait that make "conflict almost inevitable unless political and economic collapse on the mainland derails the Communist Party's plan to absorb Taiwan. This could have catastrophic consequences."

He said any serious conflict between China and Taiwan would draw in the United States. "Despite the ambiguity of the defense relationship between Washington and Taipei, it is widely understood that the leader of the free world would have no choice but to help one of Asia's most vibrant democracies," he said.
"Quite simply, no US administration could let Taiwan be overrun. Once the US got involved, it would demand that Australia assist," he said.
"Canberra would have little choice, no matter how unpalatable this would be to the powerful pro-China lobby in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade," he noted.

He quoted some analysts as believing that rational thinkers in Beijing understand that China could not win a war in the Taiwan Strait and will exercise restraint. They believe Taiwan can be persuaded to negotiate with the mainland and that a compromise for unity can be reached over time. Lague said bluntly that this is fantasy.

He said China's determination to absorb Taiwan can be seen by the fact that recovering Taiwan is at the top of President Jiang Zemin's political agenda and by the fact that Beijing has sown it into the public's mind that the recovery of Taiwan is an urgent task central to national unity and worth heavy sacrifices. To back down would be unthinkable, he added.
Meanwhile, he said, "the strength of Taiwanese nationalism grows by the day. No Taiwanese government could agree to surrender real power to Beijing and expect to survive."
"It is a grim outlook shared by some of Australia's defense planners. The best hope for peace would seem to be dramatic political change on the mainland," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CONSERVATION OF ENDANGERED BIRD

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office issued a press statement on Wednesday urging the general public to make concerted efforts to save the Indian pitta, an endangered bird.
The statement said President Chen Shui-bian is concerned about the fate of the bird, which has been listed as an endangered species worldwide.

As Taiwan is home to possibly the world's largest number of surviving Indian pittas and is widely believed to be the most important natural habitat for the bird, local conservation groups have recently launched a publicity campaign to protect the species.
In response to an appeal by local conservationists, Chen urged relevant government authorities to take immediate action to protect the Indian pitta, also known as the blue-winged pitta.

"If Taiwan loses this rare bird, it seems to me that the island will have been deprived of one of its most beautiful colors," Chen said, adding that the loss for Taiwan would also be a loss for the whole world.
The president further said he believes that Taiwan will deserve its reputation as a beautiful island only when it can strike a balance between nature conservation and industrial development.
"We will be able to enjoy sustainable development only when we can maintain an environment suitable for harmonious co-existence between humankind and nature," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS NICARAGUAN VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday received Nicaraguan Vice President Enrique Bolanos Geyer, who was in Taipei to attend the ongoing World Congress 2000 on Information Technology.
Chen asked Bolanos to convey his thanks to Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman for his attending his inauguration ceremony on May 20.

He said the fact that the Nicaraguan president and vice president have visited the ROC less than a month apart reflects the friendship between the two countries, and added that the ROC should have more appreciation of this friendship.
Chen praised Bolanos for his courage in overcoming difficulties in his political career and added that he is a good example for the ROC.
Bolanos was once a successful entrepreneur, but was jailed for six months by the Sandinista government after he entered politics.
"We saw hope and inspiration from Bolanos. The Republic of China is mired in a difficult international environment, and we should stand up and have hope like Bolanos," Chen said.

Bolanos for his part said the election of Chen and Annette Lu as president and vice president of the ROC represents not only a victory for the Taiwan people, but also for the world's democracy fighters.

He noted that the ROC and Nicaragua have maintained close relations since the two countries reestablished diplomatic ties in 1990, and added that Nicaragua will continue its firm support for the ROC in its fight for justice in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINLAND TO BUILD VIRTUAL HELSINKI, HIGH-TECH INFORMATION SOCIETY

TEXT.P: Finnish information technology expert Risto Linturi on Wednesday sketched a vision of life in the information society on the final day of the 12th World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT).

Speaking to some 1,800 industry experts from 86 countries around the world, Linturi said that he envisions a society where a citizen can broadcast self-made programs from the living room, use a mobile phone connected to the Internet to evade GPS-radio-collared bears in the wild, and control the radio, the lock, and the VCR from that same phone.
He said that his "Helsinki Arena 2000" project will be a catalyst for many other projects and companies, and that the scope is comparable to Kennedy's vision of putting a man on the moon.
He went on to say that the project aims to eventually build the Finnish capital into a cybercity with ubiquitous Internet connections in homes and offices.

Linturi described an ongoing project to create an interactive virtual replica of the city of Helsinki. He said that a user would be able to dial a phone number by going to the receiver's virtual door and ringing a virtual doorbell. If he wanted a taxi, he could simply jump higher in the virtual landscape, look for the closest free taxi, and wave it down with a click of the mouse -- or the phone.
In Linturi's vision, which he said is already reality in some areas of Finland, even bears, wolves and reindeer are fitted with radio tracking devices.

Electronic windshields will allow drivers to see a virtual road and virtual traffic signs, and when everyone in Finland carries a mobile phone, Linturi envisions streetlights that turn off automatically when there are no mobile phones nearby. Finland has a 70 percent mobile phone penetration rate and is widely expected to be one of the first countries to reach 100 percent.

Linturi said that his vision is now embraced by many telecommunication companies and organizations in Finland, and that the advances in technology in recent years have helped them to take many concepts into commercial usage on accelerated schedules.

He added that perhaps fixed wires will not even be necessary in the future, citing as an example Taiwan's own Helios solar aircraft project that is designed to fly 20 kilometers above a city, with each unmanned aircraft supplying 20 gigabits of local capacity.

WCIT 2000 marks the first time that the biennial conference has been held in Asia outside of Japan. The theme of the three-day event is "IT for a Better World: A New Millennium." WCIT 2002 will be held in Adelaide, Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE DISABLED STILL CAN ACHIEVE PERFECTION: PRESIDENT CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, June 14 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Wednesday that disabled people can achieve perfection with undaunted spirit and redoubled efforts.
Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at a graduation ceremony for about 100 mentally retarded students at a special school in the southern Taiwan city of Chiayi.
Chen said he was very pleased to attend the ceremony and to be able to share in the joy and pride of the children who have endured more hardship and adversity than many of their peers.
Noting that physical and mental disabilities cannot prohibit people from achieving perfection, President Chen said deficiencies can help test humankind's understanding of the true meanings of lives.
Chen said he believes that the disabled people still can achieve their life goals with confidence, courage and hope.

Chen arrived at the Chiayi School for Mentally Disabled Children early in the morning to a warm welcome from teachers, schoolchildren and their parents. Chen shook hands with parents and received flowers and kisses from their children.

In an unexpected turn of events, Chen was trapped in a malfunctioning elevator for three minutes on his way to the school's auditorium where the commencement was held. Chen remained calm during the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CANCELS PARTY VISIT TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) on Wednesday decided to halt a visit by its lawmakers to mainland China slated for mid-July, saying that the cancellation was made out of consideration of the delicate relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

The announcement was made public after PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi met with Liu Sung-pan, former legislative speaker and party stalwart, Liu Wen-hsiung, legislative PFP caucus spokesman, and Chen Chao-jung, legislative party whip.

According to sources close to the pro-unification opposition party, PFP lawmakers are worried about a visit to the mainland at a time when Taiwan-mainland ties are very sensitive. They added that the chances of realizing the planned trip are slim, unless mainland China would permit similar visits by legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Kuomintang (KMT).
Beijing has rejected planned visits of subgroups of both the DPP and KMT.

Although the trip by PFP lawmakers was aimed at providing services and boosting communication with Taiwan businesspeople based in mainland China, Liu Sung-pan expressed his suspicion that such a goal could not be achieved in any event.

Liu, who recently returned from a visit to the mainland, said that the PFP and the New Party could not afford to run the risk of assuming responsibility for relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should they make a turn for the worse at this sensitive time.

The former legislative speaker also denied speculation that his recent mainland visit was aimed at paving the way for a trip by PFP Chairman James Soong. He explained that he is opposed to a Soong visit to mainland China if the PFP leader still wants to pursue broader horizons in Taiwan politics.

In addition, recent Hong Kong newspaper reports have said that mainland China is seeking to abandon its insistence on the "one China" principle and set up new cross-strait communication channels, possibly talking directly to the PFP. These reports have reportedly cast a shadow of fear over the party, and forced it to make a final decision to cancel its visit to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-USA & US-ROC BUSINESS COUNCIL JOINT CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: More than 500 business leaders from the Republic of China and the United States gathered in Taipei on Wednesday to take part in the three-day 24th Joint Conference ROC-USA & US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils which opened that day.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of the conference titled: "Taiwan's New Landscape: Business Opportunities in the 21st Century," President Chen Shui-bian noted that trade between the United States and the ROC has thrived over the years, increasing from less than US$4 billion in the mid-1970s to US$50.6 billion in 1999.

The president pointed out that the United States is Taiwan's "largest export market and second-largest import source," while "Taiwan is the seventh-largest trading partner of the United States and America's fifth-largest export market for agricultural products."

He reaffirmed that the next four years will be "critical for Taiwan to thoroughly transform itself," and vowed to improve conditions for industrial development, government efficiency and privatization, thus providing innumerable opportunities for trade and business in Taiwan.
US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater, who arrived here on Wednesday to attend the joint conference, read a greeting from US President Bill Clinton to the participants.

Slater, the highest-ranking US official to visit the ROC since the May 20 inauguration of the new administration, said later that his participation continues a long-standing tradition, noting that his predecessors -- Sam Skinner and Federico Pena -- took part in 1991 and 1994, respectively.
Slater, who like Clinton is an Arkansas native, also said his participation reflects the importance the United States places on its economic and commercial relations with Taiwan.

He said that he is "extremely interested in the e-commerce wave hitting Asia," and added that he was planning to discuss e-commerce as well as other economic and transportation issues with business leaders during his visit.

Speakers at the plenary session of the conference also included C.Y. Wang, chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council; Frank Carlucci, chairman of the US-ROC Business Council; ROC Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi; John Rockefeller, honorary co-chairman of the US-ROC Business Council; and Jeffrey Koo, honorary chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council.

Wang, who is also the chairman of China Steel Corp., noted that two major recent IT events in Taipei -- Computex and the World Congress on Information Technology -- have aroused keen interest and attracted a large number of business leaders to Taiwan.

Over the next two days, participants in the conference will examine international developments and discuss a number of key topics, including the influence that changing US/China/Taiwan relations will have on US business here. Also, workshops will be held on information technology, banking & finance, power & energy, transportation, defense & aerospace projects, and biotechnology.

Delegates to the conference will deliver papers on "broadband's impact on Asia and Taiwan's wireless revolution," "financial market consolidation: promises & pitfalls," "the importance of venture capitalists & strategic investors," and "what Taiwan & China's WTO accession means to ports & carriers."
The conference will also host its first "investors' forum" Thursday and introduce attending firms to facilitate the formation of partnerships and strategic investment alliances.

US delegates also included Deputy Assistant Secretary for Aviation and International Affairs A. Bradley Mims, Department of Transportation Chief of Staff Jerry lee Malone, State Department Adviser David Keegan, Former Assistant Defense Secretary and Vice-Chairman of the Center for Strategic & International Studies Kurt Campbell, and Director of the Office of Korea and Southeast Asia in the US Department of Commerce Philip Agress.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SECRETARY OF TRANSPORTATION TO CALL ON LOCAL IT LEADERS

TEXT.P: United States Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater, is expected to meet with local information technology leaders during his stay in Taiwan.

Slater, who arrived here on Wednesday to attend the 24th joint conference of ROC-USA & US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils running from June 14-16, said in the opening meeting that he is "extremely interested in the e-commerce wave hitting Asia," and added that he was planning to discuss e-commerce and other economic issues here before leaving on Friday.

The American Institute in Taiwan, the de facto US embassy in Taiwan in the absence of official relations between the two nations, has arranged Slater's schedule. AIT said that the secretary will call on local IT leaders during his short stay in Taiwan.

Although AIT officials would not reveal with whom Slater will meet, they said that he would have discussions with world-class IT leaders such as Stan Shih, chairman of Acer group and Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Manufacturing Semiconductor Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS INVESTMENT OPPORTUNITIES IN TAIWAN FOR US BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: In the next four years, Taiwan will provide innumerable trade and business opportunities for the United States, said President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday.

Speaking at the opening of the joint conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils, Chen said he believes that it is critical for Taiwan to thoroughly transform itself and emerge with a new look in the next four years.

Recalling his May 20 inaugural speech, wherein he proposed a vision of national growth centered transforming Taiwan into a "green silicon island," Chen promised to gradually introduce the environmentally-friendly approach of science-based industrial parks to every corner of Taiwan, and transform the nation into a "green silicon island" with a knowledge-based economy.

Chen told the conference that his administration will initiate a series of plans for infrastructure modernization. Meanwhile, improved conditions for industrial development, better government efficiency, privatization, and incentives for private participation in public construction projects will lead to increased investment and foster Taiwan's capacity for long-term economic growth.

Urging US enterprises to seize the opportunities of Taiwan's transformation, Chen said he hoped investment by US firms in Taiwan, which stood at US$1.1 billion at the end of 1999, will continue to grow. He said that increased US investment would enhance the opportunities for hi-tech industrial interchange, to the mutual benefit of both the ROC and the USA.

The ROC-USA and US-ROC(Taiwan) Business Councils are private non-profit organizations of American and Taiwan business executives. It alternates every year between Washington and Taipei. Wednesday's conference is the 24th of its kind and will last for three days, ending on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI NOT TO ATTEND KMT CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui will not take part in the party's coming extraordinary national congress scheduled for June 17-18 in Taipei, KMT spokesman Jason Hu said on Wednesday.
Lee, however, gave his blessing to the congress, and he called on all party members to stand firmly behind acting Chairman Lien Chan as he attempts to implement party reform.
Lee stepped down as KMT head in late March in the wake of the party's humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election, which saw the end of five decades of KMT rule in Taiwan.
Lien had invited Lee to attend the congress as a VIP. Whether Lee would accept the offer had been of great concern to party members.
Lee hadn't given his answer until KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-chen phoned him Tuesday night. During the conversation, Lee clearly said that he will not attend the congress.

Since his term as Republic of China president came to an end on May 20, Lee has devoted himself to Christian preaching, charity activities and taking care of unprivileged groups. He also has become honorary chairman of the Taiwan Research institute, a private think tank.
Meanwhile the KMT's Central Standing Committee earlier in the day approved draft amendments to the party's charter to tighten the qualifications of candidates for party chairman.

Under the revised charter, any party member who has a criminal records, or who has had his or her party membership revoked or suspended for more than a year will not be allowed to run for party chairman.

The latter part of the measures was seen by a non-mainstream faction of the party as move to block James Soong -- a former KMT secretary general who was kicked out of the party for running against Lien in the last presidential election -- from conducting a comeback. Mainstream KMT stalwarts have repeatedly denied that accusation.
Soong, who is founder and chairman the People First Party (PFP) , has been called on by many KMT members to return to his former party and vie for its chairmanship.
In the future, party members will engage in direct secret balloting to choose party chairmen. The next chairman will be the last KMT head to be chosen during the party congress.
The party's Central Committee will also be transformed with all existing departments being merged into four, dealing with party policy, elections, publicity and administration.
The draft amendments are pending approval by the upcoming party congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO SUPPORTIVE OF CABINET MOVE FOR 44-HOUR WORKWEEK

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, on Wednesday expressed his support of the Cabinet's move to shorten the legal number of weekly working hours from 48 to 44.
The Executive Yuan adopted an amendment on Wednesday that cuts the maximum legal number of weekly working hours from 48 to 44, starting Jan. 1, 2001.

Koo said although the shortening of work hours will result in a decrease in the nation's total production, he would support the practice of the shortened workweek once both capital and labor reach a consensus on the issue.
The amendment allows workers to either have one-and-a-half days off each week, two days off every other week, or three days off at one time each month.

Before passing the amendment, Chen Chu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said in a special report that the CLA favors the implementation of a shortened workweek on a step-by-step basis with the ultimate goal of shortening the number of weekly work hours to 40.

Chen noted that advanced nations such as the United States, Canada and Japan have long practiced the 40-hour workweek, while France this year further shortened the number of weekly working hours to 35.
The legal number of weekly work hours in both South Korea and Singapore is 44, while Vietnam and mainland China already practice a five-day workweek, the CLA chairman added.
Chen said that the gradual shortening of number of weekly work hours from 48 to 40 is one of the new government's most important labor policy goals.
The proposed shortened workweek legislation is subject to approval by the Legislative Yuan on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN PRESIDENT TO ATTEND WORLD FORUM IN US

TEXT.P: Republic of China Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien left on Wednesday for the United States to attend the World Forum to be held in Colorado from June 15-18. He is expected to exchange views with world leaders about international relations.

The yearly World Forum, organized by the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), attracts world elites from all spheres, public and private. Former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt were frequent attendants in past years.

This year's World Forum, to be presided over by former US President Gerald Ford, will focus on Asian security. It is expected that the Korean summit and the cross-Taiwan Strait problem will be the main points of the agenda.

ROC legislator Parris Chang has also been invited by Ford to attend the three-day forum. Other prominent expected participants are former South African President F.W. de Klerk, US Defense Secretary William Cohen, US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, and many US congressmen and business leaders.
AEI, an influential US think tank, was established in 1943 to do research on economic, political and social policies, as well as regional problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CONGRESS ON INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY WRAPS UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 12th World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT) greatly boosted Taiwan's international prominence and brought over NT$1 trillion's worth of business opportunities to local companies, WCIT chairman Richard Yin said on Wednesday.

Yin said at a press conference that WCIT 2000, a three-day industry event that ended here on Wednesday, successfully showed Taiwan's ability to host a world-class technology congress. He added that "technology diplomacy" is far more beneficial to Taiwan than "money diplomacy."

James Wong, chairman of the WCIT's host organization Information Service Industry Association of China, Taipei (CISA), said that many people had misgivings three years ago about a small country like the Republic of China's capability to host the biennial world congress, but that the past few days had proved Taiwan's ability.

At the WCIT, several global information technology (IT) industry leaders announced their plans to continue to invest in Taiwan companies. Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina promised to purchase US$4.5 billion worth of IT products from Taiwan this year, and Cisco Systems CEO John Chambers also said that his company will invest a total of US$1 billion in Taiwan's IT industry by 2003.

Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates also spoke at the event on Tuesday. He praised Taiwan companies for having "made things happen" in the global computer industry over the past 25 years. Gates went on to predict that wireless technology and the speech interface will play critical roles in the home and business environments of the future.

Red Hat Chairman Robert F. Young spoke out for the virtues of the "open source" model of software development. He said on Tuesday that as people rely more and more on technology, they should be allowed to use software freely. Young added that Red Hat, which publishes the Linux operating system, earns its profits from maintenance and services -- rather than from royalties, like Microsoft's proprietary Windows system.

Other high-powered speakers outlined their visions of life in the information society. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said on Wednesday that his city aims to provide universal access to the Internet and break away from the physical limitations of traffic congestion to become a competitive international metropolis. Patricia Hewitt, the United Kingdom's Minister for Small Business and e-Commerce, also described the UK's IT developments on Wednesday.

Finland's Risto Linturi, who initiated the Helsinki Arena 2000 project, sketched a vision of a high-tech wireless nation where the mobile phone takes on the functions of a remote control, electronic key, global positioning system, and reindeer tracker. Finland, where 70 percent of the population carries a mobile phone, is widely expected to be one of the first countries to reach a 100 percent wireless market penetration rate.

WCIT 2000, with its theme of "IT for a Better World -- A New Millennium," was attended by some 1,800 industry experts, academics, and government officials from 86 countries. This marked the first time that the congress was held in an Asian country other than Japan. The 13th WCIT will be held in Adelaide, Australia, in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KOREAS' SUMMIT AN INSPIRATION FOR TAIWAN AND MAINLAND: CAMPBELL

TEXT.P: The historic Pyongyang meeting between the leaders of South and North Korea should be an inspiration for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Kurt Campbell, former Assistant Defense Secretary, said here on Wednesday.

Campbell, who played a crucial role in the US cross-strait policy when he was in charged of East Asian Affairs in the US Defense Department, made the remarks when he called on Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council.
Campbell exchanged views with Tsai on a wide range of issues, including cross-strait relations, the internal situation in mainland China, and the current status of the Asia and Pacific region.

Tsai said that the first-ever meeting of leaders of South Korea and North Korea will be positive for the establishment of permanent peace on the Korean peninsula, and for security and stability in all of East Asia.

Campbell said that the two Koreas' summit should be an inspiration for the disputants across the Taiwan Strait, since even though both sides still harbor hostility toward each other, the two leaders are taking an innovative approach and are sitting down to talk.

Campbell, currently vice chairman of the Center for Strategic & International Studies, further suggested that Taiwan strengthen its relations with Asian and Pacific countries under the framework of regional security.

Since Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has had close relations with South Korean President Kim Dae Jung, he suggested that Taiwan consider strengthening bilateral relations with South Korea in the future.

He also said that the US and international community have a new perception of Taiwan's democracy after the island's March 18 presidential election, which saw the Kuomintang's defeat by the DPP after a five-decade rule. But mainland China is now more worried than ever about the island's democracy, he added.
He also expressed concern about the cross-strait stalemate, saying that though cross-strait tensions have eased, both sides should avoid moving in a negative direction.

President Chen's handling of cross-strait relations have showed skill, rationality and sincerity, which has won the support of the international community, Campbell said, adding that if Chen can further forge a domestic consensus, cross-strait relations will benefit.

Campbell suggested Taiwan learn more about mainland China's mindset through an alternative mechanism of communications, commonly known as the "track II" dialogue channel. He added that official dialogue channels are often too rigid to work well.
Campbell again expressed support for the "track II" communications channel after a closed-door meeting with scholars on the cross-strait situation Wednesday afternoon.
He said that the "track II" dialogue channel is important in that it will create space and inspire dynamic thinking, as well as foster a spirit that would be conducive to solving problems.

He also said that Taiwan will face grave challenges from the mainland in the next few months, or even next few years, so he had cautioned Taiwan leaders to handle cross-strait relations in wise and meticulous manner.

He also said that he is worried that military exercises in mainland China are actually a method to gather momentum to use armed force against Taiwan, and thus should not be treated as "routine" military exercises.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD TO SPEND US$ 3 TRILLION ON ICT PRODUCTS AND SERVICES IN 2000

TEXT.P: A survey released by a technology research center has found that the world will spend US$3 trillion on information and communication technology (ICT) in 2000.

The top ten ICT countries make up 80 percent of the world's market, and North America leads the other continents in terms of ICT spending, according to the World Information Technology and Services Alliance (WITSA).

The figures are the result of a WITSA survey, and were released by WITSA Chairman Robert B. Laurance and WITSA President Harris N. Miller at a press conference. The officials were here to attend the World Congress on Information Technology in Taipei.

According to the survey, the world's top 55 ICT countries are responsible for 98 percent of total worldwide ICT spending, including expenditures on computer hardware, software, and services; communication hardware and services; office equipment, and the establishment of inner-corporation computer-systems.
The survey, which WITSA began in 1998, showed that ICT development in the world is imbalanced, with the top 10 ICT countries holding an 80 percent share of the world market.

Worldwide, there were 260 million computers with Internet access at the end of 1999, an addition of 90 million units compared to the previous year. In total, about 400 million computers were sold in 1999.

North America is still the ICT powerhouse, having spent US$796 billion on ICT in 1999. Meanwhile ICT spending in the Middle East and Africa expanded by 26 percent between 1997 and 1999. In Asia, the figure increased 18 percent in the same period.
By country, Sweden is the world's leading ICT spender. Swedes spent an average of US$3,200 per capita on ICT in 1999, a growth rate of 9.6 percent.
The United States, the world's ICT giant, was third in terms of per-capita ICT spending. Americans spent US$2,700 per capita on ICT in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 TAIPEI CITY ARTISTIC ENVOYS TO ARRIVE IN PARIS FOR ARTISTIC TOUR

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan artists were authorized on Wednesday to represent Taipei City in a two-month cultural exchange in Paris, part of an international city artists exchange program sponsored by the Culture Bureau of Taipei City Hall.

At present, Taipei City has an agreement with the cities of Paris, Jerusalem, and Seoul on the exchange of artists. In addition to Paris, Taiwan artists will be sent to Jerusalem and Seoul for cultural exchanges in the two cities.

After a strict selection, Hung Chung-kun, Wu Yao-tung and Liu Chao-tseh were chosen to represent Taipei City. They will travel to Paris on July 3 for a two-month art exhibition in the world-famous city. They will be the first batch of Taipei artists to be stationed in Paris under the city government exchange program, and will bring their works back to Taipei when they return.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said in a ceremony marking the announcement that he hoped that artists in Paris would also come to Taiwan and exhibit their artwork for local citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS BEIJING TO FOLLOW KOREA'S EXAMPLE

TEXT.P: If South and North Korea can sit down and negotiate with each other, Taiwan and mainland China should be able to do so as well, President Chen Shui-bian said on Wednesday.

Encouraged by the first-ever summit between North and South Korea currently being held in Pyongyang, President Chen Shui-bian told a group of overseas Taiwanese business executives on Wednesday that Taiwan and mainland China should follow the example of the Koreas and reach out to each other.

Noting that his mandate is to maintain security and permanent peace across the Taiwan Strait, the president cautioned that any improvements in relations with Beijing should be made on a basis of "dignity, democracy and good will," and should be implemented gradually.
The president also aired his principle of "confronting obstinacy with flexibility" in coping with the mainland.

Characterizing his approach as gentle but firm, Chen said he would use good sense and wisdom in dealing with Beijing, adding that this policy should not be mistaken for weakness or a willingness to surrender.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 90.26 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 90.26 points to close at 8,844.97.
Market turnover amounted to NT$84.29 billion (US$2.74 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 15, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer, and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1846: The 49th parallel is proclaimed as the border between the United States and Canada.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1904: The paddle steamer "General Slocum" catches fire in New York Harbor, killing 693 people.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down in Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1929: The Kuomintang announces that the government plans to end by 1935 the Period of Political Tutelage, a pre-constitutional form of government which started in 1928.
1933: China and Tibet end a two-year war with a treaty that mutually respects the pre-war border.
1944: US forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the US envoy to China notifies the Chinese government on the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the US, UK and the USSR agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The People's Daily, a Chinese Communist Party newspaper, publishes its first issue.
1949: Taiwan adopts a new currency.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastic raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1969: Georges Pompidou is elected president of France.
1975: The Chinese track and field team returns from Seoul with five gold medals and a third place finish overall in the Asian Championships.
1975: Chang Pao-shu, secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, and four other members leave for Tokyo to attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Eikaku Sato.
1976: Maj. Gen. Kin Sang Tao, chief of the South Korean Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1977: The first democratic election in 41 years is held in Spain and won by Adolfo Suarez and his Democratic Centre coalition.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1981: Juan Rafael Peralta Perez, president of the Senate of the Dominican Republic; Manuel de Jesus Gomez, chairman of two Senate committees; and Senator Manuel Feliu arrive in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1981: Sun I-suan, chairman of the Taipei Bankers Association, announces an increase in the highest deposit interest rate to 15 percent and in the top loan rate to 18 percent.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1992: The Japanese Diet approves an act authorizing the Japanese troops to join United Nations peace-keeping missions.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries: Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
1999: South Korea sinks one North Korean gunboat and heavily damages others in the Yellow Sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 90.26 points to close at 8,844.97.
Due to a strong wait-and-see attitude of investors, the bourse opened at 8,932.59 and fluctuated between 8,968.99 and 8,826.69 during trading.

A total of 1.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$84.29 billion (US$2.74 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.81 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$117.79 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only foodstuff shares gained ground, moving up 0.6 percent.

All the other major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, construction stocks at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 358 to 154, with 96 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 82 points to finish at 8,910, with 405 contract transactions, while September futures plunged 131 points to close at 8,935, with 31 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 8,965 for June; 8,992 for July; 9,066 for September; 9,164 for December; and 9,212 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported negative results.
June TE futures moved down 7 points to close at 496, with 771 contract transactions, while July TE futures decreased 6.75 points to finish at 496.95, with 162 contract transactions.
September TE futures lost 3.3 points to finish at 504.1, with one contract transaction, while next March TE futures decreased 7 points to close at 527.9, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were reported for December TE futures.
June TF futures moved down 7 points to close at 886, with 147 contract transactions, while July TF futures lost 6.2 points to finish at 895.8, with 27 contract transactions.
September TF futures moved down 3 points to finish at 898, with 14 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 3 points to close at 905, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST DPP LAWMAKERS OPPOSE REPEAL OF INDEPENDENCE PLANK

TEXT.P: Most Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators and party heavyweights are opposed to the repealing of the pro-independence plank contained within the party's charter, sources from Legislative Yuan said on Thursday.
DPP Legislator Chen Chao-nan is planning to file a proposal to scrap the pro-independence plank to be discussed during the DPP's national congress in July.

Chen has said that the DPP, which has emerged as the ruling party following Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration as the Republic of China's new president, no longer requires the pro-independence plank as Taiwan is already a sovereign nation.
Chen said scrapping the pro-independence plank would serve two purposes, namely showing goodwill to Beijing and testing Beijing's attitude toward today's Taiwan.

DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung discounted Chen's words, saying Beijing's ambition and hostility towards Taiwan is obvious and cannot be redressed simply by the DPP's scrapping of its pro-independence charter.
Shen said he also does not think that Beijing will appreciate or recognize the DPP's goodwill if the party repeals the pro-independence plank, a move which would be difficult to accomplish.

According to DPP charter regulations, initiating the process of repealing any article in the party charter requires an endorsement by at least 20 national congress delegates, and actually repealing an article requires a yes vote by at least two-thirds of all the party members.
Chen has said that he has, through certain channels, informed President Chen Shui-bian about his plans to propose a repeal of the pro-independence plank during the upcoming national congress.
"The president did not offer any response to my plan, and I assume `no response' means `tacit consent'," Chen noted.

Later in the morning, the Presidential Office made a statement discounting Chen's remarks, saying that Chen's reading of the lack of a response from the president as meaning tacit consent was completely wrong.
The Presidential Office's stance on not intervening in party affairs is patently clear, officials at the office said.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is almost certain to be the next chairman of the DPP, said whether or not to revise, shelve, or scrap the pro-independence plank should be discussed at the national congress, adding that party members should not shy away from related discussions.

Hsieh said President Chen Shui-bian clearly made known his position on cross-strait relations during his inaugural speech, in which he spelled out his "five nos" overture, one of which is that as long as Beijing shows no intention of attacking Taiwan militarily, Taiwan will not hold a plebiscite on independence -- a move tantamount to a freezing of the pro-independence plank.

Hsieh suggested that the DPP further promote bilateral exchanges with mainland China as the DPP only has a limited understanding of Beijing and vice versa. He said he himself would like to visit the mainland in his future capacity as the DPP chairman to further bolster ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO DROP 'ONE CHINA' SHACKLES FOR RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan lawmaker urged mainland China on Thursday to free itself from the shackles of its cherished "one China" principle and deal with cross-Taiwan Strait issues in a pragmatic manner.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the pro-unification People First Party (PFP) said mainland Chinese leaders should draw inspiration from the just-concluded summit meeting between North Korea and South Korea to foster a thaw in the long-deadlocked cross-strait relations.

Chou pointed out that the two Koreas are similar in size, with their territories closely connected. Moreover, the governments of the two Koreas ban bilateral civilian, economic and cultural exchanges. They even had serious military conflicts in the past. "But now their leaders get down to talks without setting any preconditions. The development on the Korean peninsula is an inspiration to both sides of the Taiwan Strait," he noted.

Noting that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin has said Beijing consistently supports the reunification of the two Koreas through negotiations, Chou said he simply couldn't understand why mainland China refuses dialogue with Taiwan and rejected the two Koreas' summit diplomacy as a model for cross-strait rapprochement.

Beijing declines to resume cross-strait dialogue until the Republic of China government explicitly agrees to its "one China" principle that recognizes mainland China's sovereignty over Taiwan, a term that Taipei cannot accept.
Chou said mainland China should free itself from the "one China" shackles and adopt a more realistic, pragmatic and generous attitude in dealing with cross-strait relations.
Another PFP legislator, Liu Wen-hsiung, also urged mainland China not to reject mainland travel plans proposed by lawmakers of other major Taiwan political parties.

Beijing authorities have consistently declined engagement with the ROC's new ruling party -- the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party. Earlier this month, Beijing also turned down a prospective mainland visit organized by the Kuomintang's subgroup e-Generation Alliance in the Legislative Yuan.

On the other hand, Beijing has agreed to a PFP plan to send a delegation to visit the mainland in mid-July. However, the island's newly formed opposition party has canceled the plan for fears that the PFP might be labeled as "Beijing's mouthpiece" in Taiwan.

Liu said if Beijing accepts the PFP's advice and opens its doors to Taiwan lawmakers of different political stripes, the PFP will revive its plan to organize a delegation to visit the mainland for talks with Taiwan investors there and with mainland officials in charge of Taiwan affairs.
