DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD UPGRADE RELATIONS WITH TAIWAN: OPINION LEADER

TEXT.P: The US Congress should pass the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act and the next administration should upgrade US relations with Taiwan by at least allowing high-ranking executive branch officials to visit the island republic, said an American conservative leader Wednesday.

David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, wrote in the latest issue of The Hill, a weekly newspaper, that Democratic Progressive Party leader Chen Shui-bian's victory in the March 18 Republic of China presidential election came amidst mainland Chinese threats of military action against Taiwan if it elected a candidate that refused to accept that there is only one China and Taiwan is a part of it.

The threat may or may not have been real, Keene pointed out, but Chen has softened his line on independence considerably since winning the election. He pledged that, as long as Beijing resists the temptation to use military force against Taiwan, his government will not declare independence or promote a national referendum on the question.

"His problem, however, is that the question of whether the 22 million citizens of the Republic of China on Taiwan will remain free, quasi-independent, and in control of one of the world's strongest economies won't be decided in Taiwan's capital, but instead in Beijing and, to a lesser extent, in Washington," noted the conservative leader.

Keene told his readers that mainland China has never wavered in its stated desire to take Taiwan. Moreover, Beijing's leaders have consistently charged that anyone who questions their right to take Taiwan by whatever means they ultimately deem appropriate "is a threat to peace in Asia."

The Communist Chinese regime has never controlled Taiwan, and few on the island are prepared to let them do so. Those on Taiwan who support reunification "support it contingent on a change of regime in Beijing. They are not more willing to voluntarily surrender what they have spent generations building than are the most radical leaders of the DPP," emphasized Keene.

He said the United States should feel proud of what the Taiwanese have built in Taiwan. "After all, the Republic of China exists today only because of the protection we extended to it over the years. Just as importantly, it is one of the few nations anywhere that has done what our founders hoped many nations would do -- emulate the example of the United States by creating free institutions of their own."

But many in the United States are not proud of what Americans helped create. "They see Taiwan instead as a stumbling block, a nuisance that stands in the way of hopefully better relations with China. A lot of folks here would, in fact, like to see Taiwan vanish," he wrote, adding that this is just what Beijing is counting on.

Of course, Keene said, "if it becomes clear to the Chinese that our commitment to our ally on Taiwan isn't very deep, the likelihood that Beijing will resort to force against the island will increase exponentially. We cannot let that happen, for moral as well as strategic and historic reasons."

He said the mainland Chinese might like to seize Taiwan, but they are not fools. They'll only unleash the People's Liberation Army if they think they can get away with it. Many in Congress understand this and are prepared to pass legislation underscoring US commitment to Taiwan and giving it access to the defensive military technology it needs to guarantee its own security.

He concluded that the legislation should be passed, adding that "we should do more. The next administration should upgrade our relations with Taiwan by at least allowing high-ranking executive branch officials to visit the place."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES US-BOUND MILITARY ACADEMY STUDENTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday received three military academy students who will soon leave for the United States to seek higher education at US military academies, sources from the Presidential Office said.

Chen met with Lee Wu-lin, Tan Tzu-wei, and Chang Chih-jung at the Presidential Office and congratulated them, all male students, for having passed a series of tests with high scores enabling them to receive more advanced military education abroad.

The president also gave high praise to the parents of the three students, saying they have provided their children with a successful education at home, helping the young men excel academically and physically.
The Ministry of National Defense, meanwhile, kept secret the names of the US military academies that the trio will attend in an effort to avoid causing any unnecessary troubles for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLONOSCOPY FOUND EFFECTIVE IN DETECTING COLON CANCER

TEXT.P: Doctors are more likely to detect colon cancer if they use the colonoscopy method instead of a barium enema test, according to a new study published in Thursday's "New England Journal of Medicine."
Some scientists have questioned the effectiveness of the enema technique in comparison to the newer method of colonoscopy.

The researchers found that barium enema examinations missed 79 percent of the small polyps found by a colonoscopy and 61 percent of still-benign tumors. Also, in 14 percent of the cases, the enema test diagnosed a problem where there actually was none.
But the colonoscopies are not entirely foolproof, missing 20 percent of the still-benign tumors, according to the study.

The findings cast new doubt on the value of barium enemas. In this older technique, the inner surface of a patient's colon is dyed with barium and then X-rayed. In a colonoscopy, a lit tube is threaded through the large intestine to search for cancerous cells or potentially cancerous growths.
A colonoscopy is more expensive and a bit riskier, but the researchers found that it is more likely to detect cancer cells.
The US National Polyp Study looked at 580 volunteers who needed to have their colons re-examined after an initial examination revealed at least one polyp that appeared ready to develop into a tumor.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FIRST QUARTER MINERAL EXPORTS INCREASE

TEXT.P: Australia's mineral exports increased by 7 percent in the first quarter of 2000 over the same period last year, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resources Economics (ABARE).

"This is the third successive quarter in which export earnings have increased. The result mainly reflected higher export prices for a range of minerals and energy commodities as well as increased export volumes for petroleum products," said Roger Rose, the research director of the ABARE.

A spokesman for ABARE said on Thursday that Taiwan's imports of steaming coal from Australia in the first quarter of this year surged by about 29 percent to 2.55 million tones from a year earlier, while it's iron ore imports from Australian increased by 6 percent.
Other Australian exports recording increases included crude oil, refinery feed stock, liquefied natural gas, refined gold, nickel, aluminum, zinc and refined silver, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, NORWAY WAGING PR WAR TO LIFT BAN ON COMMERCIAL WHALING

TEXT.P: Japan and Norway are waging a public relations war in Australia and New Zealand in an attempt to have the moratorium on commercial whale hunting lifted, reported the Australian on Thursday.

Australia will be the host of the annual International Whaling Commission (IWC) meeting in Adelaide next month, and Japan has already employed the Melbourne-based public relations firm Shandwick International to spearhead their efforts, reported the daily.
Both the Australian and New Zealand governments strongly oppose the lifting of the global moratorium on commercial whaling.
The daily reported the PR campaign comes in the form of leaflets sent to Australian homes comparing the ban on whaling to the idea of "foreigners telling Australians they couldn't eat meat pies."

Japan has continued to hunt whales despite the global moratorium under the guise of scientific research, although it has continued to argue its case for commercial whaling on the basis of cultural tradition, the daily reported.

In 1999, Japan killed more than 500 minke whales in the Antarctic and North Pacific and is extending its research program to include Sperm and Bryde's whales. While Japan continues to oppose whale sanctuaries, Australia and New Zealand have been the champions of the cause. Whale-watching is an important element of the two countries' tourist industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ANNOUNCES TOUGH NEW MEASURES ON HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Australia's Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Thursday announced tough measures designed to discourage human smugglers and illegal entry and escape from detention centers.

The announcement followed a massive breakout of more than 750 detained refugees, mainly from the Middle East and Afghanistan, from three different detention centers in West and South Australia last week.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, Ruddock said he wanted to send a warning message to human smugglers in mainland China, Indonesia and other countries that Australia is determined to fight against their smuggling operations.
Canberra has sent more immigration officials to mainland China, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia, including Indonesia, to intercept any prospective boat people from entering Australia.
Between early 1999 and early this year, thousands of boat people from the Middle East, Afghanistan, and mainland China were caught entering Australia illegally.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.013 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 30.828.
The local currency opened Thursday at 30.820 and was traded between 30.808 and 30.850.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$291 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COMPANIES URGE TAIWAN TO FURTHER OPEN MARKETS

TEXT.P: Several US business executives attending a US-Taiwan business conference in Taipei urged Taiwan on Thursday to expedite the opening of its capital and telecommunications markets.

David Hoffman, director of accounting firm Pricewaterhouse Coopers, said that the Republic of China's regulations governing telecommunications and related industries seem to be disordered and unpredictable, a phenomenon which has resulted in chaotic development of the market.

He noted that Taiwan opened its cellular phone market in 1996, and in the short period since then, almost everyone on the island has begun using mobile telecommunications devices. But despite the increase in the number of mobile phone subscriptions, Taiwan's quality of service has actually diminished, he added.

Noting that opening the market either too quickly or too slowly would adversely affect the normal development of the industry, Hoffman urged authorities in Taiwan to reassess related policies and regulations on opening the island's telecommunications market.

Hoffman made the remarks during the Taipei American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) Breakfast & Briefing, which is part of the ongoing 24th Joint Conference of the ROC-USA & US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils.

Also speaking at the breakfast briefing, AmCham President Paul J. Cassingham said most US companies and individuals in Taiwan feel that the liberalization of Taiwan's telecommunications market has been moving at a snail's pace.
Peter Kurz, director of US firm Xlinux, said Taiwan has been too slow not only in opening its telecommunications market, but also in liberalizing its capital market.
Kurz urged Taipei to expedite the liberalization of its capital and finance systems, and adopt a global perspective.

Meanwhile, other American delegates at the meeting ridiculed Taiwan's Legislative Yuan as unpredictably wild in adopting legislation. They added that the legislature has failed to come up with any commendable plans on infrastructure development, and hasn't made any progress on the high-speed railway development plan or Taipei's serious parking problem.

US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater, who was also invited to attend the breakfast briefing, said despite the fact that Taiwan's government is now in a transitional phase, the island is still a valuable trading partner for the US. He added that US executives should take advantage of the many business and trade opportunities that are available here.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 INTERNATIONAL TAIPEI FOOD SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Exhibition opened at the Taipei World Trade Center on Thursday, with exhibitors from more than 10 countries participating.
Trying to carve a bigger slice of Taiwan's food market before the island's entry into the World Trade Organization, several foreign countries set up pavilions to display their products.
These countries include Australia, France, Canada, the United States, Austria, South Korea, Chile and several other Central and South American countries.
The Taiwan pavilion is jointly sponsored by 145 local agricultural and fishing industry associations as well as sales and marketing groups.
According to the organizer of the three-day event, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), exhibitors have set up a total of 1,196 booths, an increase of 13.9 percent over last year.
CETRA Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng, Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang and representatives from foreign trade offices stationed in Taiwan were present at the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN PURCHASES OF TAIWAN SHARES CONTINUE TO GROW IN FIRST HALF YEAR

TEXT.P: Foreign purchases of Taiwan stocks exceeded foreign selling by NT$152.5 billion (US$4.92 billion) from January 1 to June 14 this year, according to government statistics released on Thursday.
Of the total net purchases, NT$126.8 billion were from transactions of listed stocks and NT$25.7 billion from over-the-counter transactions.
Meanwhile, capital remitted into Taiwan by foreign special investment institutions and individual foreign and overseas Chinese investors as of June 10 totaled US$27.91 billion.
That represented an increase of US$230 million over the same figure at the end of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC GOVERNMENT WANTS CLOSER COOPERATION WITH US: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said on Thursday that the Republic of China's new government looks forward to further expanding cooperation with the United States in various fields.

The four-star-general-turned-premier made the statement during a meeting with visiting US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater, who arrived in Taipei on Wednesday to attend the annual joint conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils.
Slater is the first US Cabinet minister to visit Taiwan since the ROC completed its first democratic transition of power from the Kuomintang to the Democratic Progressive Party on May 20.

Tang extended a warm welcome to Slater, saying his visit symbolizes close substantive ties between the two countries. For his part, Slater conveyed US President Bill Clinton's concern about Tang's health. Tang is still recuperating from surgical wounds caused by an April surgery to remove a chest tumor.

Tang told Slater that the ROC government is studying the feasibility of opening direct trade, postal and transport links between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China's coastal cities, commonly known as direct cross-Taiwan Strait "mini three links." "We expect to finalize the evaluation and planning work in six months," he said, adding that the opening of "mini three links" will pave the way for eventual opening of direct "three links" between Taiwan and mainland China.

Tang, who had been air force commander-in-chief, chief of the General Staff and minister of national defense before assuming the premiership, said in the past, the ROC regarded the triangular waters surrounding Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China's Shanghai area mainly from military viewpoints.

In the future, Tang said, the ROC will gradually adjust this strategy and strengthen planning for opening commercial shipping services in the area as part of its efforts to promote the cross-strait "three links" policy and to build Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific operations center.

Slater said the United States believes that the opening of direct cross-strait trade, transport and mail links will certainly bring many new business opportunities to US companies, particularly those in maritime and air transport services.
Hopefully, Slater said, Taiwan can offer fair business opportunities to US firms in carrying out its ambitious Asia-Pacific business hub project.

Noting that a large number of Taiwan students have done advanced studies in the United States, Tang said the US assistance in training high-caliber manpower has provided a solid basis for close economic and technological cooperation between the two countries.

He further said the just-concluded World Congress on Informational Technology 2000 has brought many business opportunities to Taiwan companies and signified Taiwan's development potential in the promising information technology (IT) field.
"We also believe that there will be ample room for ROC-US cooperation in the IT field in the future," Tang said.
In response, Slater said he shares Tang's views. "Information technology will be an important realm for US-Taiwan cooperation in the future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, ROC EXPERTS DISCUSS IMPACT OF BROADBAND, WIRELESS REVOLUTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry is poised to take off with the advent of wireless and fixed-line broadband technology, said IT experts at an annual conference between ROC and US business councils on Thursday.

Joseph J. Fan, president of industry heavyweight Taiwan Cellular Corp., predicted that in the future, more subscribers will access the Internet by using wireless access protocol (WAP) technology and the upcoming third generation (3G) wireless technology.

Speaking at the 24th Joint Conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils on Thursday, Fan and other industry leaders said that Taiwan's existing mobile phone and cable television infrastructure will allow for the rapid development of broadband technology throughout the island.

According to Fan, Taiwan's mobile phone market penetration rate reached 52.5 percent by the end of 1999, ranking the island ninth in the world. South Korea has since overtaken Taiwan, and now boasts a 57 percent market penetration rate.

In 77 percent of local homes, cable is already in place, making it the best broadband technology format for Taiwan, according to Raymond Chang, Senior Vice President of Giga Media. In comparison, only 65% of homes in the US are equipped with cable service.
The development of personalized and interactive broadband content will be essential to bolster consumer acceptance of the new technology, he added.

US Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, honorary co-chairman of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, concurred with the other experts on the significance of broadband technology. However, he highlighted the possible social issues that may emerge as a result of the disparity between infrastructure-rich metropolitan areas and infrastructure-poor rural areas.

Rockefeller said that businesses with easier access to greater bandwidth will be more competitive than firms that lack such access. He added that the result will be "disastrous" for the less-wired regions, where unemployment will add to a collective feeling of being left out of the information revolution. He went on to urge countries to find ways to promote the development of broadband infrastructure in all areas.
Herbert Chang, Vice Chairman of KG Telecommunications, said that Taiwan is ready for broadband, but only if issues regarding regulation, technology, and content are resolved in a timely manner.
Nelson Chang, deputy chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council, said that the new economy in Taiwan will be fueled by business opportunities that increased bandwidth will provide.

JD Howard, managing director of Taiwan Nortel CHT, a strategic partnership between Chunghwa Telecom and Nortel Networks, said that the wireless revolution will benefit Taiwan's IT industry by increasing demand for exports of components, end user devices, services, and software.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAY OF HOPE SEEN IN RESUMPTION OF ROC-ROK AIRLINKS

TEXT.P: The upcoming first tourist ministers meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum may provide an opportunity for Taipei and Seoul to discuss resumption of direct airlinks, sources said on Thursday.
ROC Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan has decided to personally attend the first-ever APEC tourist ministers meeting scheduled for July 5-8 in South Korea.
Sources said Yeh's South Korean coutnerpart is expected to raise the airlinks issue during bilateral talks with Yeh under the APEC framework.

While the Republic of China is unlikely to take the initiative to bring up the airlinks issue during an APEC event, it will not shun the topic if South Korea puts the problem on the agenda for bilateral talks.

Sources close to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said the ROC will initially discuss only resumption of flyover, technical landing and passenger flight services with South Korea, and will not consider airborne cargo transport and fifth freedom issues for the moment.

The ROC cut diplomatic ties with South Korea on Aug. 24, 1992 after Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, and direct flight services between the two countries were also suspended from Sept. 15 that year.
South Korea has been eager to resume direct airlinks with Taiwan but is reluctant to upgrade its substantive ties with the ROC for fears of offending Beijing.

MOTC sources said the ROC is willing to negotiate the airlinks issue with Seoul based on the principles of equality, reciprocity and mutual respect. Moreover, MOTC sources said, the ROC is hopeful that the annual bilateral ministerial-level economic cooperation conference can be resumed along with the resumption of direct airlinks.

The ROC also hopes that South Korea can send an official delegation, to be headed by its civil aeronautics administration chief, to Taipei to negotiate airlinks resumption issues with parallel Taiwan officials. Meanwhile, MOTC sources said, a formal agreement on the airlinks resumption should be signed by civil aviation chiefs of the two countries.

The first APEC tourist ministers meeting will focus on four themes -- removing barriers to investment in the tourist industry; expanding the travel market; ensuring sustainable development in tourist management; and promoting tourism to boost economic and social development.
In addition to multilateral discussion, bilateral talks between APEC members on matters of mutual concern will also be arrranged during the upcoming APEC meeting.
APEC is a 21-member regional economic cooperation forum dedicated to promoting free trade and capital flow. Both Taipei and Beijing are its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STAGING LIVE FIRE DRILL OFF FUJIAN PROVINCE: MND

TEXT.P: The People's Liberation Army (PLA) is staging a live fire artillery drill off the coast of Fujian Province but there are no unusual military movements otherwise, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Thursday.
The MND said that the drill being conducted off the coast of Quanzhou, in southern Fujian Province, began on Thursday morning and will last through Saturday.
In an attempt to preempt the public panic that was caused by Beijing's previous military exercises, the MND said the drill is a follow-up to a PLA drill begun earlier this month in the same area.
During the drill, described by the MND as routine, the PLA will test-fire artillery of various calibers from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

The MND announcement assured the people of Taiwan that the exercises are not being accompanied by unusual movements by the mainland navy or air force, and promised to keep the public informed of Beijing's military movements.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAS OFFICIAL URGES COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN IN HI-TECH INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: A visiting Honduran senior official called on Thursday for closer cooperation between the Latin American state and the Republic of China in developing the hi-tech industry.

In an interview with CNA, Gerardo Zepada, director of the National Commission of Science and Technology, said his country is seeking Taiwan's experience in information technology (IT) development to speed up the development of Hondura's IT industry.

Zepada, who also visited Taiwan in 1980 and 1993, said he was impressed by the progress of the island's hi-tech industry since his last trip, and added that there are many lessons that the Honduras could learn from.

Noting that telephone penetration is only 10 percent of the population in Honduras at present, Zepada said wireless telephones rather than the landline system would help his country to catch up with developed countries in accessing the Internet.

Zepada also noted that human capital is at least as essential to the IT industry as the infrastructure, and said Honduras is launching programs in schools to teach Internet skills and train skilled workers for the country's IT industry.

He said a laboratory jointly financed by Taiwan and Central American states in Central America has helped many states in the region to upgrade their products, and added that the work of the laboratory will now be expanded to the IT industry.
Zepada said his country is also trying to beef up contacts with Taiwan's IT firms in the hope that they will help their Honduran counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER PROPOSES REMOVING INDEPENDENCE CLAUSE FROM PARTY PLATFORM

TEXT.P: Legislator Chen Chao-nan of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday formally proposed the removal from the party's platform of the clause that promotes Taiwan independence.
The First Article of the DPP platform and its appendix stipulate that the party aims to establish a sovereign and independent Taiwan Republic.

Chen said that the independence clause is no longer justifiable now that the DPP has become Taiwan's ruling party, because Taiwan is in fact a sovereign country. In order to secure cross-Taiwan Strait peace, the clause should therefore be removed, he added.

Chen denied news reports that his decision to initiate the proposal was prompted by Beijing officials who he met late last month and who said that mainland China would renounce the use of force against Taiwan as long as the DPP agreed to ditch its Taiwan independence platform.
Chen said that he will definitely push ahead with the proposal, despite the difficulties lying ahead, although the chances of his proposal being adopted by the party's heavyweights are slim.

Under DPP regulations, a change in the party platform requires endorsement from at least two-thirds of the delegates to its national congress. The party is to hold its national congress in the middle of next month.

Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said Beijing would not drop its hostility toward Taiwan simply because the DPP agrees to abandon its independence plank, while Legislator Lin Chuo-shui said that Chen's move resulted from his "misunderstanding" of the existing cross-strait situation.
Lin said that ever since Chen Shui-bian's inauguration as president on May 20, Beijing has been making "rational adjustments" in many areas which it would not have tolerated in the past.

In other words, he went on, both Taiwan and Beijing are now trying to adapt themselves to each other, and Chen should not rush to push his proposal because it is in contradiction to the development trends of cross-strait relations.
Lawmaker Chou Po-lun, who is a member of Chen Chao-nan's "New Century Congress Office" faction in the party, also lamented the suggestion, saying it would simply be "troublesome" to President Chen.

However, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is almost certain to be the next DPP chairman, said that scrapping or keeping the independence guideline will be key to the DPP's development direction, and that the party should not attempt to escape the issue. He also said he favored discussion of the proposal in next month's party congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO PLAY MORE ACTIVE ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday urged the United States to play a more active role in helping to maintain balance and stability in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the appeal while meeting with visiting US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater, who arrived in Taipei on Wednesday to attend the 24th Joint Conference of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils.

Chen said he was encouraged by US President Bill Clinton's decision to send Slater, one of Clinton's best friends and colleagues, to attend the annual joint business conference in Taipei to signify the US government support for the new Taiwan administration.

Noting that the Republic of China and the United States share a very close and cordial relationship, Chen said he believes that maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait is not only in the interests of the ROC but also complies with US interests in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen said that although the United States pledged in its 1982 "six assurances" not to serve as a mediator in cross-strait relations, it should play a more active role in helping to maintain Taiwan Strait peace and Asia-Pacific stability and security, as well as to improve and normalize cross-strait ties.
"I believe that my appeal exactly reflects a common hope and expectation of the people of our two countries," Chen said.
The president further said he is convinced that the just-concluded summit meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea is inspirational to future cross-strait relations.

"So long as our national security is not at stake, we are willing to promote direct trade, mail and transport links with mainland China," Chen said, adding that he is hopeful the United States will play a positive role in pushing for resumption of cross-strait dialogue to smooth the way for opening the "three direct links."
Chen also said the ROC supports the US granting of permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) to mainland China with a view to making it abide by international regulations and norms.

"By so doing, mainland China is also expected to gradually move toward democratization, thus helping to maintain peace, stability and security in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region," Chen noted.
While granting PNTR status to mainland China, Chen said, the United States should also push for Taipei's and Beijing's essentially simultaneous accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The president also expressed his expectation that more ministerial-level US officials from various fields can make frequent visits to Taiwan to further upgrade bilateral ties and cooperation.

For his part, Slater acknowledged that cross-strait ties are a great challenge to the new ROC government. "With your wisdom, pragmatic attitude and constructive strategy, I believe you will be able to overcome all difficulties and reach the goal of improving relations with the mainland," Slater said, adding that the United States, as a reliable friend, will continue to support cross-strait dialogue.
Slater also assured Chen that the US government is now working to help both sides of the Taiwan Strait to enter the WTO by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY OVERSEAS CHINESE, FOREIGN INVESTMENTS IN TAIWAN STILL BOOM

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign investments in Taiwan in May topped US$788 million, up 100 percent from the previous month, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Investment Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The statistics also show that overseas Chinese and foreign investments in Taiwan in the first five months of this year topped US$2.68 billion, surpassing the total amount of such investments for the first nine months of last year.

The figures reveal that there were 123 overseas Chinese and foreign investment projects in May, with a total value of US$788.92 million. There have been 558 such investment projects in the first five months of this year, with a total value of US$2.688 billion, an increase of 122.85 percent compared with the same period of last year.
The Investment Commission attributed the sharp increase to the liberalization of the island's telecommunications industry.

Meanwhile, Taiwan businessmen's investment in mainland China in the first five months of this years grew by 141.96 percent, with the increase attributed to the continued recovery of the world economy and Beijing's imminent admission to the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUA SOLICITS TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN TEXTILE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan Vice President Enrique Bolanos Geyer led a mission to Taipei on Thursday to seek Taiwan's investment in his country's textile industry.

Because the US Congress recently passed additional preferential measures on textile products from Nicaragua and some Caribbean countries, the mission is expected to receive a favorable response from Taiwan's textile manufacturers.
Under the newly approved measures, which become effective on Oct. 1 this year, the United States will not levy customs tariffs on garments, handbags and shoes made in the countries in question.

Taiwan Textile Federation Chairman Huang Yao-tang told the media that Nicaragua is a good place for textile investment because it is a diplomatic ally of Taiwan with inexpensive, but well-trained workers.

Nicaragua has provided many incentives for foreign investors. Taiwan's official statistics show that in the past 10 years, the island's investment in that country has amounted to more than US$100 million.

Business cooperation between the two countries is also growing steadily. For instance, Taiwan's textile exports to Nicaragua rose from US$51 million in 1997 to US$57 million in 1998 and to US$58 million last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTED US$163 MILLION OVERSEAS IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen funneled US$163.59 million into 70 overseas projects in May, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and released on Thursday.
A remittance of US$20 million by the China Development Industrial Bank to a firm in the British Cayman Islands was the biggest single such investment project in May.

The figures brought the island's total overseas investment in the first five months of this year to US$1.45 billion, or 1.98 percent more than the figure recorded for the corresponding period of last year.
Meanwhile, the number of investment projects increased by 14 to 345. (By Maubo Chang) ENDITEM/J ZCZC CEP029 06-15-00 `EARTHQUAKE ORPHANS' HONORED AT COMMENCEMENT CEREMONY

Taichung, central Taiwan, June 15 (CNA) President Chen Shui-bian personally presented special awards on Thursday to seven graduating students who were orphaned in the devastating 921 earthquake last year.

Chen lauded the seven as "brave warriors of life" because they have not been daunted by the loss of their parents and have managed to complete their studies with good academic records at either elementary or junior high schools.

Chen tapped each student on the shoulder and shook hands with them before presenting the awards. "I would like to express my greatest respect and admiration for all of you," the president said emotionally.
The seven "earthquake orphans" were cited at a joint commencement ceremony of 100-plus elementary and junior high schools in nine townships and villages in central Taichung County's coastal region.
In a speech delivered following the citation ceremony, Chen encouraged all the graduating students not to be frustrated by adversity.
"Success does not mean defeating others. It means continuous learning, progress and surpassing your past achievements," he explained.

Chen further said he himself has endured many setbacks and hardships during his 20-year political career. "I believe that so long as we have confidence and hope, we will be able to reach our life goals," he added.

Meanwhile, he promised to personally present special President's Awards next year at the Presidential Office to graduating students from around the island with good academic, sporting, or artistic records, as well as to those who have done good deeds or made special achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US DEFENSE SECRETARY ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Secretary William Perry arrived in Taipei on Thursday for a two-day private visit at the invitation of Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao.
As Perry has been pushing for a "second-track" dialogue channel between Taiwan and mainland China, his visit has attracted much attention from political analysts and observers.

During his stay in Taipei, Perry will confer with Tien, President Chen Shui-bian, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
Their topics are expected to be centered on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and the triangular relationship between Washington, Beijing and Taipei.
Perry was greeted upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by Liu Chih-kung, director of the North American Affairs Department under the Foreign Ministry, and other officials.
He is scheduled to leave Taipei on June 17 and proceed to Shanghai, Tokyo and Seoul.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES SUCCESSFUL END TO KOREAN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Foreign Affairs Ministry on Thursday welcomed the successful conclusion of the summit meeting between South Korean President Kim Dae-jung and North Korean leader Kim Jong Il.

Foreign Ministry officials described as significant the fact that the two leaders opened their historic dialogue without any preconditions set, and they said it should serve as a good sample for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The meeting drew to an end late on Wednesday with agreements signed that aimed at reducing tension and enhancing economic cooperation on the divided Korean peninsula.

However, the officials, who asked not to be named, said that Taipei would be more interested in the consensus Kim Jong Il reached during a May 29-31 trip to mainland China, and how he persuaded the Beijing leaders not to oppose, and even perhaps to encourage, the summit.
The officials said that it remains to be seen whether Beijing gave its blessing to the summit in the hope that it would result in the withdrawal of US troops from South Korea.
On Taiwan's ties with North Korea, the officials said that bilateral trade and economic relations will improve should North Korea adopt an open-door policy in the wake of the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES FORMER PENTAGON OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday received Kurt Campbell, a former US defense assistant secretary for Asia-Pacific affairs.
Chen expressed his appreciation for Campbell's past efforts to support and strengthen military exchanges between the United States and Taiwan.

He said that during his tenure in office, Campbell contributed a great deal to the maintenance of peace across the Taiwan Strait and to exchange visits of top-level military personnel of the two countries.

Chen also lauded Campbell for his efforts on the sale of defensive weapons to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, and for speaking up for Taiwan in the US Congress and at various symposia.
Campbell for his part praised Chen for his "golden performance" since his March 18 presidential election victory.
He said that he is glad to share his experience with Taiwan and to work together for Asia-Pacific regional stability and security, as well as world peace.
Meanwhile, Campbell also visited acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to exchange views on the international and domestic situation.

Lien, who was roundly defeated by Chen in the election, told Campbell that he is not optimistic about the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations because Chen's political stance and national policy "remains unclear."

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOW PACE OF TAIWAN'S LIBERALIZATION OF ENERGY MARKET COMES UNDER FIRE

TEXT.P: The alleged slow pace of the Republic of China government in deregulating the energy market came under fire from businessmen in a conference on Thursday.

In the second day of the Annual Joint Conference of the ROC-USA and the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils, both US and ROC business representatives criticized the Taiwan authorities for not opening up the island's energy market faster.
Citing a report by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the attendees said Taiwan is lagging behind in privatizing its petroleum and power industries and opening them to foreign competition.

Noting that there currently are nine bidders for licenses to generate power in Taiwan, Hsu Chih-yi, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, said the private sector is clearly interested in entering the energy field.
He urged the government to accommodate the private sector's enthusiasm by opening the power market wider as soon as possible.

However, the poorly conceived opening of Taiwan's telecommunications market has caused chaos and a degeneration of phone services, according to David Hoffman, the general director of the Pricewaterhouse Coopers accounting firm.
In his view, the Taiwan authorities bungled the work of liberalizing the telecommunications market by enacting confusing rules to regulate the new market.

Paul Cassinghan, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham Taipei) said the Taiwan authorities' slowness in opening the telecommunications market was the focus of criticism of the AmCham members last year.
Lin Hsing-shan, chairman of the Evergreen Marine Corp. Ltd, blamed the government for what he called "dragging it feet" on opening direct maritime links with mainland China.
Likening shipping and trade to two wheels on a car, Lin said bilateral trade between Taiwan and mainland China cannot thrive without direct maritime links.
The three-day conference, the 24th of its kind, will continue its discussion on biotechnology and information technology on Friday before coming to a close later that afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 12.82 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 12.82 points to close at 8,832.15.
Market turnover amounted to NT$82.18 billion (US$2.67 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 12.82 points to close at 8,832.15.
With the continued wait-and-see attitude of both sellers and buyers, the bourse opened at 8,852.32 and fluctuated between 8,893.59 and 8,791.67 during trading.

A total of 1.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.18 billion (US$2.67 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 1.39 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$84.29 billion.
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by cement shares at 0.5 percent, pulp and paper issues and electrical stocks, both at 0.4 percent, textile issues at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 259 to 252, with 88 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK MASS TRANSIT RAILWAY TO SERVE AS CONSULTANT TO TAIPEI COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Taipei Rapid Transit Co., Ltd. on Friday signed a contract with its counterpart in Hong Kong to have the latter serve as its consultant on track maintenance.

Under government procurement law, Taipei Rapid Transit publicly invited bids for providing consultant services, with Hong Kong's Mass Transit Railway Corp. (MTRC) winning the 18 month contract worth NT$9.25 million (US$299,350).

Chen Chuang-liang, president of the Taipei Rapid Transit Co., said that the company made contact with its Hong Kong counterpart during a Taipei-Hong Kong twin city forum in January when both sides exchanged views on the maintenance and operation of rapid transit systems.

Chen noted that there are similarities between the rapid transit systems in Taipei and Hong Kong. He added that since Hong Kong's rapid transit system has been in operation for 21 years longer, Taipei can learn a lot from Hong Kong rapid transit's experience.

Hong Kong's MTRC, established in 1975, now operates three lines, with a total length of 77 kilometers. It is the only rapid transit operator in Asia that turns a profit and one of only a few profitable operators in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 16, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1654: Queen Christina of Sweden abdicates in favor of her cousin, Charles Gustavus.
1858: Gustavus V, the Swedish monarch who reigned for 43 years, is born. He kept Sweden neutral through both world wars.
1869: Charles Sturt, the English explorer who discovered much of Australia, dies at the age of 74.
1890: American comedian Stan Laurel is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of the talking film era. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: China's Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at China's Whampoa Military Academy, presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1928: China's Sinkiang Province pledges allegiance to the Nationalist government after Chiang Kai-shek resumed the Northern Expedition on April 7.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling America's severe economic problems.
1941: Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1948: The first air hijacking occurs when Chinese bandits attempt to take over a Cathay Airways Catalina aircraft. The crew fight back and the aircraft crashes, killing all but the leader of the hijackers.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided to the Republic of China by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad Ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, a British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.
1972: Guatemalan President Carlos Arana Osorio arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Gen. John W. Voge Jr., commander-in-chief of the US Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: China Airlines inaugurates a Boeing 747 jumbo jet service to Los Angeles.
1976: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo inspects cadets of the Military Academy on its 52nd anniversary day.
1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, a German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the US Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.
1982: The 11-member ROC Goodwill Mission of Mayors, led by Mayor Jackson C.T. Yang of Taipei, leaves for a 20-day visit to the United States.
1983: The European rocket Ariane 1 blasts off from the French National Space Center at Kouron, French Guinea.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of regulations governing foreign exchange, authorizing the Executive Yuan to suspend all foreign exchange controls. Resumption of controls would require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
1992: US President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin agree in a summit meeting in Washington to slash their strategic weapons arsenals by about two-thirds by 2003.
1999: Thabo Mbeki becomes president of South Africa, succeeding Nelson Mandela.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Friday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved up 24 points to close at 8,904 points, with 1,930 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July increased 28 points to finish at 8,938, with 443 contract transactions, while September futures gained 50 points to close at 8,985, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 8,880 for June; 8,910 for July; 8,935 for September; 9,079 for December; and 9,127 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

June TE futures edged down 0.05 points to close at 495.95, with 649 contract transactions, while July TE futures lost 0.05 points to finish at 496.9, with 129 contract transactions, and September TE futures decreased 3.1 points to finish at 501, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 7 points to close at 893, with 280 contract transactions, while July TF futures gained 10.2 points to finish at 906, with 85 contract transactions.
September TF futures increased 6 points to close at 904, with 35 contract transactions, while December TF futures moved up 8 points to finish at 913, with 17 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-VERSION SHORTER WORKWEEK PASSED IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A new, shortened workweek program, allowing Taiwan's workers and employers to work 84 hours every two weeks instead of the former 96 hours, was passed overwhelmingly at the Legislature on Friday, sources from the Legislative Yuan said.

Under a first-class mobilization drive, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which holds a majority in the Legislature, successfully overturned the Cabinet-version of a shortened workweek that was passed by the Executive Yuan on Thursday. That version would have reduced the workweek from 48 to 44 hours.

The KMT-version of the shortened workweek, allowing most of the country's laborers to enjoy two days off every two weeks, a privilege that public functionaries are already entitle to, is expected to be brought into force on Jan. 1, 2001, the Legislative Yuan sources said.

Hung Yu-ching, KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said KMT legislators are thrilled at having overridden the Cabinet-version that was passed by the Executive Yuan without the consultation of lawmakers, particularly the KMT legislators.
Noting that the shortening of the workweek is a world trend, Hung said the number of work hours per week is presently 37.4 in Japan and 41.7 in the United States.

The passage of the KMT-version marks the first major setback for the Democratic Progressive Party, which became Taiwan's ruling party when Chen Shui-bian was inaugurated as the new president of the Republic of China on May 20.
The Chinese Federation of Labor, the top labor group in Taiwan, welcomed passage of the KMT-version of the shortened workweek.

Federation Chairman Lin Huei-kuan, however, said he is slightly worried that the 42-hour workweek program may cause some harm to the interests of less-privileged labor groups if the KMT fails to come up with measures to offset the impact of the sudden reduction in weekly working hours.
Meanwhile, the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), the largest group of industrial entrepreneurs in Taiwan, said it accepted the amendment with a feeling of disappointment.

Describing himself as "disappointed and helpless," CNFI Chairman Lin Kun-chung warned that the 42-hour workweek program will undoubtedly deal an "immediate and major" blow to the country's industrial sector. He estimated that it will have a direct impact on about half of the manufacturing industries islandwide when it takes effect.
CNFI Deputy Secretary-General Kuo Yung-hsiung said the 42-hour workweek will deal a major blow to small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly the traditional manufacturing industries.

Kuo said he hopes that the lawmakers listen more to the voice of the people, rather than indulging in political wrestling in the Legislative Yuan as such actions are far from serving the interests of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO PROMOTE YOUNG STARS TO CPC CENTRAL COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: Potential political stars as young as 35 will be promoted to the powerful Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) during its next congress in 2002 as part of Beijing's efforts to rejuvenate the party, reported Hong Kong iMail on Friday.

Rejuvenation of the party will be the main topic on the agenda during the two-week closed-door meeting of senior leaders at the seaside summer resort of Beidaihe late next month, according to the report.

The report quoted mainland sources as saying that the leaders would discuss elevating a group of young cadres, aged between 35 and 45, to the policy-making Central Committee at the 16th party congress to be held in the autumn of 2002.
At the 15th party congress convened three years ago, the average age of members of the 344-strong Central Committee was 60, with only 21 members below the age of 45.

Qualified officials in their thirties could be promoted to departmental posts while talented and competent officials in their forties could be offered higher level jobs at the provincial level, such as the position of governor or vice-governor, the report added.

Top party leaders apparently believe it is essential to increase the number of Central Committee members under the age of 45 at a time when more foreign state leaders are in their late forties or early fifties, said the report.

According to the report, the rejuvenation drive will formally begin after the Beidaihe meeting, and Zeng Qing-hong, a rising star and protege of mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, has been assigned to take charge of the process.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUESTIONS REMAIN ON INTER-KOREAN RELATIONS: EDITORIALS

TEXT.P: Despite a stunning initial breakthrough made by the leaders of North and South Korea in their first summit, questions remain on how the two rival countries can overcome a host of difficulties to forge eventual reunification after 50 years of separation.

An editorial published Friday in the Sydney Morning Herald said that "just as the reunification of Germany depended on changes in the German people, the future of Korea, a nation divided since 1948, is a matter entirely in the hands of the Koreans themselves."

"If the people of North and South Korea make a new destiny for themselves, as they appear ready to do, even the most powerful nations of the world -- including the United States, Japan, China and Russia, all of whose interests converge on the Korean peninsula -- will have to accept that," the editorial added.

"There will be hesitations and prevarications and many obstacles on the way to reunification. But a new course has been set. Wednesday's agreement between the two leaders is mostly very general. Its commitment to reunification, based on proposals already put forward for a federation or confederation as a starting point, will need hard pushing, on many fronts," it pointed out.

Meanwhile, an editorial published in the Australian said that "there is an unfettered sense of optimism surrounding the signing this week of an agreement to push relations between North and South Korea into a new and unprecedented era of cooperation."
It noted that the speed with which the two leaders have agreed to a plan for engagement "is breathtaking" after an often hostile 55-year standoff between the two countries.

Questions, however, remain on the security issue, on the American troops stationed in South Korea, on family reunions, and on nuclear weapons, and it will be a long process tackling these, the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ONLY BRIEFLY MENTIONED IN AMNESTY'S HUMAN RIGHTS REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 15 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was hardly mentioned in Amnesty International's report on human rights violation concerns this year, according to sources from the London-based human rights organization.
In its latest annual report, Amnesty International only said that Taiwan is still being criticized for its continued use of the death penalty.

The human rights watchdog group said that, over the past year, authorities in Taiwan have demonstrated the intention of improving social welfare and human rights protection by passing new laws and amending out-of-date legislation.
Nevertheless, the organization said, Taiwan still uses the death penalty "very often" -- executing at least 24 prisoners in 1999.

Meanwhile, Amnesty International said no region on earth was spared last year as deadly conflicts ignited around the globe and almost two-thirds of the world's nations were accused of human rights abuses.

Mainland China was among the countries accused by the organization, which charged that Beijing conducted its most heavy-handed crackdown on dissent in a decade during the year. The group also noted the thousands of arbitrary arrests, unfair trials, and widespread torture that occurred in that country.

"The year 1999 saw the most serious and wide-ranging crackdown on peaceful dissent in China for a decade," Amnesty said in the report, challenging Beijing's "sincerity in signing key human rights conventions over the previous two years."
"Thousands of people were arbitrarily detained by police and some were sentenced to long prison terms after unfair trials or sent to forced labor camps," the report pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER STRESSES FLIGHT SAFETY

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said the government has made flight safety one of its top priorities and expressed the hope that the rate of aviation incidents could be cut to zero.
Yeh made the remarks while making a round of inspection of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Friday.

CAA Director-General Chang Yu-hern reported that the incident rate for aircraft over 20,000 kilograms in weight was three per 1 million hours of flight over the past decade, with the rate being reduced to 2.32 incidents per 1 million flight hours this year.
The CAA is working toward the goal of a zero incident rate in the next three years, Chang said.

Yeh stressed that the government has made flight safety one of its top priorities, and the goal will require the cooperation of every related government agency, adding that she hoped a zero flight incident rate could be achieved right away.
She asked the CAA not to let its guard down on flight safety at any time, noting that currently three quarters of all flight incidents are due to human factors.
She also instructed the CAA to closely monitor airline operations and point out any major flaws before an incident may occur.
Yeh later toured Eva Airways and China Airlines, where she tried the simulated flight of a Boeing 747 from San Francisco to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FM TO LEAVE FOR MACEDONIA, VATICAN VISIT ON JUNE 20

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao will leave for an eight-day overseas trip on Tuesday, which will take him to the Republic of China's only two allies in Europe -- Macedonia and the Vatican City, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.
This will be the scholar-turned-minister's first overseas visit since assuming office on May 20.

Liu Hsiang-pu, director of the MOFA's European Affairs Department, told a routine news conference that Tien's visit is mainly aimed at cementing the ROC's bilateral relations with Macedonia and the Holy See.

Liu said Tien has received a formal invitation from his Macedonian counterpart for his upcoming visit. During his stay in Macedonia, Tien will hold talks with senior Macedonian officials on matters of mutual concern.

Tien will inspect the 12 ongoing ROC-Macedonian cooperative projects and review progress in construction of an export processing zone (EPZ) in Bunardzik, an industrial city near Macedonian capital Skopje. The EPZ is an ROC-Macedonian join venture designed to attract Taiwan businesspeople to invest in the southeastern Balkan state.

Meanwhile, Tien will sign an agreement with Macedonia on the establishment of a US$10 million development fund to help boost Macedonia's economic development. The ROC will donate the money, and the two countries will form a joint committee to manage the fund. According to the soon-to-be-signed accord, Liu said, Macedonia will only use interest income from the fund to finance various carefully selected development projects.
During his visit, Tien will also donate a batch of computers and relevant equipment to Macedonia.

According to Liu, the ROC is now Macedonia's second largest donor. When former ROC Premier Vincent Siew visited Skopje last year, he also offered US$10.5 million in aid to Macedonia on behalf of the ROC government.
Noting that Macedonia attaches great importance to its ties with the ROC, Liu said relations between the two countries have been growing steadily.
Macedonia forged formal diplomatic ties with the ROC in January 1999, making it the ROC's second ally in Europe after the Vatican City.

Following his Macedonia visit, Tien will travel to the Vatican City on June 24 for a four-day visit. In addition to meeting with his Holy See counterpart, MOFA sources said Tien is likely to meet with even higher-level Vatican officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANANA GROWERS IN HOT WATER
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, June 16 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's banana growers have been caught in an unprecedented dilemma these days as they face cut-throat competition in Japan and disastrously low prices at home because of over-production.

Taiwan-produced bananas have faced fierce competition in Japan since May this year, when the Philippines began dumping its bananas at lower-than-reasonable prices, sources from the Kaohsiung Fruit Growers Association claimed on Friday.

Taiwanese varieties, which used to be the Japanese consumer's banana of choice because of its sweetness, are now exported to Japan at unit price of 1,400 yen per carton, a price even lower than its production cost of about 1,750 yen, the association lamented.

In February, March and April this year, before the Philippines' "mountain banana" had entered the Japanese market in large quantities, Taiwan's bananas enjoyed reasonable export prices there -- at an average price of 2,500 yen per 12-kg carton, the fruit growers noted.
Since early May, however, Philippine banana exports to Japan have increased 37 percent, and the "mountain banana" has reached over 4 million cartons.

Lower-than-reasonable export prices have driven banana growers to shun the Japanese market -- a situation that has pushed down wholesale and retail prices in domestic markets as a result of local over-supply.

Lee Chih-jung, agriculture director of the Kaohsiung County Government, suggested that the central government buy the stockpiled bananas and then have the fresh stocks incinerated in order to avoid turning the fruit into a "bad apple" in the island's fruit market.

Taiwanese bananas are mainly grown in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung and in central Taiwan's Taichung County. Their cultivation is a major source of income for farmers in those three counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US PENTAGON CHIEF STARTS HECTIC VISIT IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Secretary William Perry met with Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao on Friday for wide-ranging talks.

Perry, who has been shuttling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the past couple of years to push for the establishment of an unofficial "Track II" cross-strait dialogue channel, arrived in Taipei on Thursday evening for a three-day visit.
His current visit, Perry's first trip to the island since the new ROC government was inaugurated on May 20, was made at Tien's invitation, and their meeting on Friday took place behind closed doors.

Also present at the meeting were Eugene Chien, deputy secretary-general to the president, Chiou I-jen, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, and Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
The agenda was believed to focus on topics related to the long-deadlocked Taipei-Beijing relations and the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing ties.
Earlier in the day, Perry paid a visit to Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China.

Perry met later in the day with MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen for an exchange of views on cross-strait relations, mainland China's internal situation and the general political and economic climate in the entire Asia-Pacific region.

He will also meet with President Chen Shui-bian, the ROC's first opposition leader-turned-president, and Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen before his departure for Shanghai on Saturday to continue his East Asian tour which will also take him to Seoul and Tokyo.

Meanwhile on Friday, MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said that although the ROC government consistently recognizes the value of "Track II" or "Track III" unofficial dialogue channels to the promotion of cross-strait communications, it believes that the most urgent task for the moment is engineering a resumption of regular dialogue between the SEF and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Noting that "Track II" or "Track III" can only help bridge cross-strait contacts, Chen said substantive issues can be discussed only via officially authorized SEF-ARATS dialogue channels. He added that he does not hope to see the involvement of "Track II" or "Track III" in any substantive talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO HEED IMPACT OF DECREASED FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Legislators on Friday asked the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to pay attention to the impact on Taiwan's industry of cutting the number of foreign laborers.
They made the remarks during a public hearing with the theme of "moving toward a middle way of foreign labor policy" convened by Legislator Lin Feng-hsi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Legislator Lin cited the example of British Prime Minister Tony Blair, saying that Blair, of the Labor Party, himself has said that ensuring the competitiveness of business is the first step toward safeguarding the rights of workers.
Blair said that the "middle way" will create a win-win situation for both labor and business, Lin added as he urged the government to follow suit.

Lin noted that as the government now seems to be moving toward tightening its policy toward foreign laborers, domestic businesses have had difficulty finding laborers to fill labor-intensive and night-shift positions, even though the pay meets the standards requested by the labor unions.
He lamented the fact that the labor shortage has caused a lowering in production capacity and delays in new investment plans.
The record high unemployment rate among aboriginal people has also led CLA Chairman Chen Chu to state that she will work toward controlling the number of foreign laborers, Lin said.
Legislator Hsu Shao-ping of the Kuomintang said to let foreign laborers be entitled to the same minimum wage is detrimental to domestic laborers.

CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen said that the council will still cut the number of foreign laborers by an average of 15,000 per year as instructed by CLA Chairman Chen, but it will also pay attention to the impact of the decreased number of foreign laborers on industry.

Kuo noted that the most affected domestic laborers are mainly aboriginal laborers, and the industries suffering from the decreased number of foreign laborers include the high-tech, traditional, and construction industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TASK FORCE DUE BY LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said on Friday that an inter-party task force to handle cross-Taiwan Strait affairs will be set up late this month.

Lee, who has been appointed by President Chen Shui-bian to head the planned ad hoc task force amid the current sluggish relations between Taiwan and mainland China, said he had yet to work out a list of members that will then have to be sent to a screening committee for final approval.
Lee made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after attending an academic gathering. He also urged the media not to make "groundless" speculation over the issue.

Ever since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's Chen was elected Taiwan's new president on March 18, Lee has repeatedly said he is willing to serve as a special envoy between Taiwan and mainland China to help improve bilateral ties.
But mainland China has rejected Lee's overtures, saying his public stumping for Chen before the vote ruined any possibility of his acting in such a capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.017 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 30.845.
The local currency opened Friday at 30.826 and was traded between 30.826 and 30.865.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$371.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PILGRIMAGE LEADER MEETS OFFICIALS IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 16 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese officials are supportive of the annual pilgrimage to mainland China from central Taiwan, Yen Ching-piao, chairman of Taiwan's popular Chenlan Temple, said here on Friday.

Yen arrived in Beijing on Wednesday on behalf of Taiwanese worshipers of Matsu, the goddess of the sea, to seek official support for a pilgrimage from central Taiwan's Taichung County to Fujian Province's Meizhou Island.
He said the cross-strait voyage will begin as scheduled on July 16, as he obtained a favorable response from mainland Chinese officials.

Yen, who also serves as speaker of Taichung County Council, said he asked Beijing officials to cooperate for the convenience of the approximately 6,000 pilgrims and media representatives from Taiwan when they arrive in Fujian.

According to Yen's spokeswoman Liu Shu-mei, he was entertained with a luncheon on Thursday by officials from the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, including Deputy Director Li Bingcai and Li Yafei, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Also on Thursday, according to Liu, Yen met with mainland vice communications ministers and exchanged views with Hu Hanxiang, director of the Water Transportation Administration under the Ministry of Communications, on details of the informal cross-strait voyage.
Hu told Yen that the mainland authorities will render assistance to the pilgrims whether they proceed to the mainland via air or sea, according to Liu.

Meanwhile, Yen stressed that Chenlan Temple respects the Republic of China government's recent resolution that it will make a decision on "direct religious links with mainland China" in six months, and that until then, all Taiwanese pilgrimages to the mainland should be made through a third country or area.
Yen said the pilgrimage scheduled to set off on July 16 will take a route through a third country or area, but added that the exact course of the voyage had yet to be worked out.
According to legend, Meizhou, located about 72 nautical miles across the Taiwan Strait from Taichung, is Matsu's birthplace.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY LEAVES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater left Taipei for the United States on Friday after a three-day visit.

Speaking before his departure in a news conference held at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Slater stressed that the United States will continue to expand its cooperation with Taiwan in order to lead the country to further open up its market by boosting its policy transparency and industrial competitiveness.
Slater thanked the people of Taiwan for the warm reception accorded to him and said he was deeply impressed by Taiwan's distinguished progress on the political, economic and social fronts.

The US transportation chief, who arrived in Taipei on Wednesday to attend the 24th joint annual conference of the ROC-USA Business Council and the USA-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, said he had relayed US President Bill Clinton's reiteration to ROC President Chen Shui-bian that the United States attaches a great deal of importance to its friendship with Taiwan.
Slater expressed his belief that close trade relations between the two countries will continue into the next century.

According to the US ministerial-level official, the United States will continue seeking to push Taiwan to open its aviation and telecommunication sectors, and he said he strongly believes that foreign capital will remain a key element behind Taiwan's continued growth in the 21st century. He also hailed Taiwan's outstanding role in the world information technology industry.

Describing transportation as the "knot" that links people and societies, Slater went on to say that Taiwan and the United States should enhance their cooperative ties in international transport in order to share common benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ACTING CHAIRMAN ANALYZES PARTY'S DEFEAT, CALLS FOR REJUVENATION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Acting Chairman Lien Chan on Friday attributed his party's defeat in the March 18 presidential election to a combination of factors, including the party's loss of idealism.
Lien, a former vice president and the KMT's standard-bearer in the presidential race, made the remarks at the opening of a meeting of the KMT's old-guard Central Advisory Committee.

Lien said the KMT has left admirable legacies in its 55-year rule of Taiwan, including developing the island from an agricultural backwater to a booming economic powerhouse and completing its democratization.

"Despite this outstanding record, several major reasons have prevented us from winning enough popular support in the hotly contested presidential election," Lien noted, adding that the party should conduct soul-searching, self-examination and self-improvement in order to regain power in time for the next presidential election in four years' time.

Lien pointed out that the most serious problem facing the KMT is its loss of idealism. "Our party's basic concepts have become obsolete and have lost their appeal to young party members and general voters," he said.
He also cited the following other reasons for the KMT's embarrassing election defeat:

-- The KMT's policy-making mechanism lacks democratic spirit, and consequently, its decisions have often failed to comply with mainstream public opinion or have fallen short of public expectations. Moreover, limited participation in the policy-making process by rank-and-file party members has minimized their identification with the party.

-- The party's nomination mechanism for the election of various levels of public functionaries could neither meet the public's high expectations nor satisfy the intraparty demand for fair competition. As a result, the KMT has faced the crisis of splits before nearly every major domestic political election.

-- Because of the party's long grip on power and opposition parties' "ill-motivated" mudslinging, the KMT's image has been "distorted" as a conservative, interest-oriented and gang-linked political group.
-- The KMT's grassroots apparatus has become rigid and almost inactive, and many party activities have been unable to elicit public interest or meet public demand.
To cope with these problems, Lien said, the party has formed a reform committee to work out a comprehensive party re-engineering and rejuvenation plan for sweeping intraparty restructuring.
"We must review and examine our defects and deficiencies sincerely, stop passing the buck and end any meaningless intraparty squabbling," Lien urged.
He also encouraged all KMT members, regardless of seniority and ethnic origin, to stand united and work together for the party's sustainable development and bright future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

The legislature approves shorter workweek.
