President Chen makes first troop review as supreme leader of the armed forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 61.35 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Saturday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 61.35 points to close at 8,770.8.
Market turnover amounted to NT$65.82 billion (US$2.14 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 17, or the 16th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1703: British religious leader John Wesley is born. He founded Methodism in 1738, while his brother, Charles, wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing."
1775: The second battle of the American Revolution commences at Bunker Hill and Breed's Hill, just north of Boston, Massachusetts. The Americans lost around 400 men, the British 1,000.
1900: A joint force from eight nations attack and occupy the fort of Taku Port in China, while Ching government troops and Boxers besiege foreign settlements in Tientsin.
1925: A total of 29 countries sign the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940: Red Army forces occupy Latvia and Estonia and pro-Soviet administrations are installed.
1950: The first kidney transplant is performed by Dr. Richard Lawler in Chicago.
1960: The Chinese communists launch 85,965 shells on the island of Kinmen on the eve of US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's visit to the Republic of China.
1967: Communist China explodes its first hydrogen bomb.
1971: The United States and Japan sign agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: Five men are caught snooping around the Washington apartment-hotel complex known as The Watergate, currently being used by the Democratic Party as their headquarters during the US election campaign.
1974: ROC Economic Affairs Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for Seoul to attend the 9th Sino-Korean Ministerial Level Economic Cooperation Conference.
1976: Hsu Li-teh is appointed vice minister of finance by the ROC Executive Yuan.
1978: More than 4.5 million eligible ROC voters go to the polls to elect 3,786 representatives of townships and villages as well as 6,417 urban and rural district chief.
1979: Charles Cross, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Raymond Perodin, Haiti's new ambassador to the ROC, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1982: Fourteen generals meet at an army base in Buenos Aires and vote unanimously to fire Leopoldo Galtieri, the president who led Argentina into the Falklands War against Britain it could never win.
1982: ROC Foreign Minister Chu Fu-sung, as President Chiang Ching-kuo's special envoy, leaves for Saudi Arabia to offer this nation's condolences for the passing of King Fahd ibn Abdul Aziz.
1986: Nineteen mainland Chinese youths defect across the Yellow Sea aboard a small wooden boat to South Korea to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Some 400,000 Parisians and tourists from all over the world celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower.
1990: President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay arrives in Taipei to sign a joint communique calling for closer bilateral relations with the ROC.
1992: Lin Yang-kang, president of the Judicial Yuan of the ROC, leaves for the United States for a three-week visit.
1996: The United States and mainland China reach a deal to stamp out rampant Chinese copyright piracy.
1999: The ILO (International Labor Organization) adopts a treaty banning the worst forms of child labor, including slavery and forced military recruitment.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I hate the way scarlet dims the perception of vermilion. I hate the way the modern popular airs are liable to spoil the taste for good music. Finally, I hate the way smartness of speech in men is liable to destroy kingdoms and ruin families."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 61.35 points to close at 8,770.8.
With continued selling pressure and a wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors, the bourse opened at 8,827.35 and fluctuated between 8,871.9 and 8,753.67 during trading.

A total of 1.16 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.82 billion (US$2.14 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session, which saw 1.46 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$82.12 billion.
Only one of the eight major categories posted gains, with construction stocks edging up by 0.2 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.8 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, electrical stocks at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 362 to 149, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged. (BY Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Saturday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved down 55 points to close at 8,849, with 1,674 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 48 points to finish at 8,890, with 726 contract transactions; September futures lost 35 points to close at 8,950, with five contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were: 8,904 for June; 8,938 for July; 8,985 for September; 9,103 for December; and 9,151 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

However, September TF futures moved up five points to finish at 909, with three contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN ONLINE SPENDING EXPECTED TO INCREASE THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Online shopping in Canada has increased dramatically from last year, according to a recent poll.
Canadian consumers are expected to spend at least C$4.1 billion (US$2.8 billion) online during 2000, up from the 1999 figure of C$1.65 billion, according to the poll results released on Friday.

The pollsters attributed the increase to the increased availability of Canadian sites offering "e-tail" opportunities, a growing number of online buyers, and increased spending among experienced shoppers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESERTIFICATION INCREASING IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Longbaoshan, a village 70 kilometers north of Beijing, is in the path of an advancing desert, with huge sand dunes creeping a few meters closer every year, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the paper reported that each year, 2,640 square kilometers of once-arable land is turned into desert, but added that what has really made Chinese people sit up and take notice lately is that the sands are now heading towards Beijing at an alarming rate of two kilometers a year.

Beijing has also suffered more than a dozen severe dust storms since April this year. The latest storm dust last week reduced visibility to a few hundreds meters and coated the city in a film of dust, the daily reported.

Longbaoshan's plight has attracted attention because it is so close to Beijing and this has prompted Premier Zhu Rongji to urge people to plant more trees in a bid to slow the pace of desertification, the daily reported.
The daily quoted official figures as revealing that 27 percent of mainland China -- about 2.6 million square kilometers -- is now desert.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FM URGES FIJI TO RETURN TO DEMOCRATIC RULE

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Saturday urged a restoration of democratic rule in Fiji in return for assistance from the Commonwealth countries, including Australia.

In a statement faxed to CNA, Downer said: "We urged all parties in Fiji to make the earliest possible return to normal democratic principles with their inherent protection for all citizens of Fiji, regardless of race."
"We made it clear that the Commonwealth was ready to assist the Fijian authorities to this end through the provision of appropriate technical assistance," he said.

Downer on Friday went to Suva along with other ministers from the Commonwealth countries to hold talks with Fiji's military leaders, who assured them that neither rebel leader George Speight or his henchmen would form part of any interim government.
Speight and his supporters have continued to hold 31 government officials hostage, including Prime Minister Mahendra Chaudhry, since they stormed the Fijian Parliament a few weeks ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONCERNED ABOUT ARREST OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Saturday expressed its concern about the reported arrest of 30-plus Taiwanese businesspeople in mainland China.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, was responding to a report on the alleged arrests "for unknown reasons" by Legislator Chu Hsing-yu of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

According to Chu, two senior executives with Hungqing Plastics Co. in Dongguan, Kuangdong Province, a company owned by Winston Wang, son of Taiwan's business tycoon Wang Yung-ching, were among those detained.

As Winston Wang recently formed a US$6.4 billion joint venture with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's son Jiang Mienheng for a silicon wafer production plant, the arrest of the two Hungqing executives has caused much speculation.
Commenting on Chu's report, Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Economic Affairs Department, said the arrests could be related to mainland China's anti-tax evasion campaign.

"Mainland China has continued investigating the tax records of individual companies. We think that the reported mass arrest of Taiwan businesspeople could be part of mainland China's anti-tax evasion operations," Fu said.

Nevertheless, Fu went on, the MAC will keep a close watch on the development of the event to determine whether mainland China has any other considerations or intentions in detaining so many Taiwan businesspeople.
Fu further said mainland China's ongoing anti-tax evasion campaign will not affect Taiwan's current policy on mainland China-bound investment.

Although Taiwan has adopted a "go slow" mainland investment policy, Taiwan entrepreneurs have poured US$30 billion to US$40 billion into the mainland for various investment projects over the past decade. Mainland China now boasts some 40,000 Taiwan-owned companies, according to mainland tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPENS EXTRAORDINARY SESSION IN SOMBER MOOD

TEXT.P: The vanquished Kuomintang on Saturday held its first party congress since the party's defeat in the March 18 presidential election in a mood of deep sorrow and soul-searching.

Acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan led party delegates in a presentation of flowers to the large statue of KMT founder Dr. Sun Yat-shen at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall before the opening of the KMT's extraordinary session of the 15th National Congress at the hall.

Party heavyweights such as former Legislative Yuan President Liang Su-yung looked downcast, and Wang Tso-yung, former head of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, wept when they sang National Anthem and a song in memory of Sun Yat-sen and pondered the humiliating election loss that saw the KMT ousted by the Democratic Progressive Party after more than five decades in power on Taiwan.
In his opening address to the two-day meeting, Lien urged all party members to work toward the party's victory in the next election.
Lien, the standard-bearer of the KMT in the election debacle, said that the party lost the election because of serious internal problems, including a major party split.
He noted that the "party members could not unify," and that the party failed because "it could not get the backing of the majority."

Lien said the party's reforms will address the following issues: reviving the party members' ideals to fight for the party's goal; bringing democracy to the party's policy-making and its nomination procedures for public functionaries; and finding a mechanism to rejuvenate the party.

He also defined the KMT as a "democratic, just and innovative party for the people," and that its ideals, based on the three principles of Dr. Sun Yat-sen -- nationalism, democracy and social well-being -- aim to build a secure and high-quality Taiwan.

Lien who ran unopposed for the party chairmanship, garnered 94.83 percent, or 1,597 votes out of 1,684 present delegates, to be elected to the post. The figure was slightly lower than the percentage of votes he won when he was nominated as the party's presidential candidate last August.
Former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui stepped down after the presidential election to take responsibility for the defeat.

Lien said that while he felt deeply for losing the presidential election, he decided nonetheless to run for the party chairmanship because of his commitment to the party. He added that he has unshirkable responsibility toward the party, and vowed to revive its past glory.

Lien was expected to ask the party congress to approve his four nominated party vice chairmen -- former Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, former Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung and former Defense Minister Chiang Chung-lin.

In addition to the election of the party chairman, two other major issues on the congress agenda will include the passing of the party reform package and a revision of the party platform, both of which were expected to be discussed on Sunday.

Meanwhile, protesters skirmished with party workers several times outside the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, with KMT diehards demanding the expulsion of Lee Teng-hui from the party, transparency in the party assets, and the popular election of the party chairman.
The protests erupted when Lin Feng-cheng, secretary-general of the KMT Central Committee and KMT Spokesman Jason Hu arrived at the scene.
The old KMT members and party workers scuffled and exchanged punches, and Chien Wei-chang, director of the KMT's Evaluation and Disciplinary Committee, had his jacket torn by the angry protesters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO INMATES BREAK OUT OF MILITARY PRISON

TEXT.P: Two inmates serving jail terms at a military prison in Hsintien, Taipei County, staged a breakout on Friday, according to a press statement released by the Prosecutor's Office of the Northern Martial Court on Saturday.

The press release said the two prisoners, identified as Hsu Cheng-hsiang and Lai Han-wei, climbed the razor-wire wall of the prison after being allowed out of their cells for a smoke and made off on a stolen motorcycle.

The press release said a manhunt has been launched by police and military police, and added that military prosecutors are looking into the incident to see if anyone should be held responsible for the breakout.

According to the United Daily News, the two fugitives stopped a woman and commandeered her motorcycle. She reported the incident and police erected roadblocks on the roads leading out of Hsintien but did not catch the men, described as convicted thieves.
According to the motorcyclist's account, the fugitives might have suffered cuts while climbing the razor-wire fence, and one of them might have broken his foot.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOP ECONOMIC PLANNER URGES INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top economic planning body on Saturday urged innovation in industrial technology, saying successful research and development is the only way to ensure the nation's continued economic competitiveness.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that in the dawn of the "information economy," the government and private sectors have to work hand-in-hand in the research of patents, and stressed that only innovation will ensure a competitive edge and growth potential.

The CEPD's Overall Planning Department said that statistics on patents approved by the United States between 1993 and 1998 show that approved Taiwan applications jumped from 1,510 to 3,805 during the period, averaging an annual growth rate of 21 percent, or fourth-highest in the world.

In terms of the patent approval rate averaged out according to population, the number of patents originating in Taiwan was higher than those of Germany, Canada, France, Britain and Italy, and 1.4-fold and four-fold higher, respectively, compared to the figures recorded in South Korea and Singapore.

The CEPD said that application of information will be the prime mover of societal progress and economic growth in the future, and it urged the government to step up local research and development and encourage people to devote themselves to patent research.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASSETS TOP US$ 2.5 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang's assets totaled more than NT$78 billion (US$2.5 billion) as of the end of April, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said on Saturday.

According to Lin, the assets of the former ruling party include NT$49 million-worth of bank deposits, NT$4.4 billion-worth of stocks, US government bonds worth NT$600 million, NT$1.3 billion dollars in funds for development of party affairs, long-term investment capital of NT$62.7 billion, and NT$8.7 billion-worth of land and real estate.
Lin made the report at a two-day extraordinary session of the party's 15th national congress held at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.

As the KMT's huge assets have long been viewed by the public as a result of its notorious "black gold" -- mobster- and money-linked politics -- Lin said the party authorities decided to make the assets public before registering them with the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office for trusteeship.
After a rule of more than 50 years in Taiwan, the KMT lost its grip on central government power following its defeat in the March 18 presidential election to the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY TOPS CROSS-STRAIT LINKS: MAC

TEXT.P: National security and social stability must take precedence when considerations are being given to setting up cross-Taiwan Strait links with mainland China, an ROC official in charge of mainland affairs said on Saturday.

Fu Dong-cheng, director of the Department of Economic Affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said economic development of the offshore islands belonging to Taiwan should take into consideration the needs of the people living there rather than just resorting to the so-called "mini three links" to achieve the development goal.
Fu made the remarks at a news conference when answering questions from reporters on government regulations on development on offshore islands and the "mini three links."

The "mini three links" refers to direct trade, transport, and postal links between the Republic of China-controlled frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the nearby offshore islets of the mainland's Fujian Province, which lies directly across the Taiwan Strait from Taiwan.
According to Fu, the MAC, in compliance with e ROC laws, will complete an assessment of the "mini three links" as soon as possible.

He noted, however, that satisfying the needs of the local people on the two frontline islands is the core issue, and that the establishment of the "mini three links" is not necessarily the best strategy for obtaining this goal.

Fu added that setting up the "mini three links" should not be equated to the establishment of full "direct three links" between Taiwan proper and mainland China, and noted that the mini links must be implemented before any regular direct links.
He also stressed that establishing the mini links must be made based upon national security and social stability.

With regard to the hotly debated "direct cross-strait religious pilgrimages," Fu said the MAC has made it very clear that such pilgrims must travel through a third country or area aboard foreign-registered vessels.

He was responding to requests that mass pilgrimages be given permission on a case-by-case basis to make direct crossings from central Taiwan's Taichung Harbor to the island of Meizhou, off the Fujian coast. According to legend, the island is the birthplace of Matsu, goddess of the sea, and thousands of local followers of Matsu make the crossing each year as part of a religious ritual.

Fu concluded that while the ROC government of course wishes to allow direct religious cross-strait pilgrimages at the earliest date, many legal issues are involved and the top priority must be that national security and dignity are fully ensured.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO BE DISCHARGED FROM HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei will be discharged from the Taipei Veterans General Hospital on Sunday, ready to begin his normal working schedule.

Tang, who checked into the hospital on April 15 to have a tumor removed from his chest, has been recovering well, according to his doctors, who added that Tang's white blood cell count, blood pressure, breathing and pulse are all normal.

Since being sworn in as Republic of China's new premier on May 20, Tang had been working at the Executive Yuan part-time on the advice of his doctors and of President Chen Shui-bian, who insisted that Tang should make his health his first priority.
Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun stressed nevertheless that Tang had been in full charge of Cabinet affairs during his convalescence.

Yu said that while many might be under the impression that he took over administrative affairs during Tang's hospitalization, the premier had actually been able to issue instructions, read information and receive phone calls in his hospital bed.
Yu said that he had only acted as a communicator and coordinator throughout the period, and that he had been taking instructions from Tang at all times.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD REFORM TO REFURBISH ITS IMAGE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang should refurbish its image through reform, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said on Saturday.

Speaking at an extraordinary session of the party's 15th KMT national congress, Lin urged all party members to commit themselves to the party's cause and put it before personal gains, saying that only commitment can inject enthusiasm into the party bureaucracy and distinguish it from an "ordinary administration."

Noting that the party has lost its attraction for the nation's youth and is graying quickly, the party secretary-general called for the recruitment of new blood into the party and urged that they be offered broad access to the political arena.

Admitting that the party has fallen out of alignment with public opinion because of its undemocratic policy-making mechanism and its undemocratic way of picking up party candidates in races for public office, Lin said this has resulted in a mass exodus of dissidents that has threatened the party's unity.

Now that a new and fully democratic mechanism has been prepared for approval during the meeting, Lin said he hopes the party members will abide by the new democratic system and will respect the results worked out through due process.
As to the work of improving the party's image, Lin lambasted the media for what he called their "pathological interest" in exposing the party's seamier side while ignoring its achievements.
This biased coverage contributed to the party's landslide defeat in the presidential election, said Lin.
He pledged to communicate with the media efficiently in order that the public can be given a "true picture" of the party rather than a "misleading, distorted" one.

Liu Chao-shiuan, the co-convenor of the party's reform panel, urged the candidates vying for membership of the party's central standing committee to run honestly, without wheeling and dealing, wining and dining, or offering bribes, all of which he admitted have been widespread in previous party elections.
"Although we have lost the power to rule, the KMT still holds the majority in the Legislative Yuan and can flex it muscles as long as it can unite its members," he said.

In an effort to convince suspicious members that the party will not transform itself into a party focusing on "Taiwan, rather than the Republic of China," KMT Acting Chairman Lien Chan said at the beginning of the conference that the party's policy of "Taiwanization" is not designed to rid it of its Chinese origins.
However, Lien told his comrades that the KMT will follow the principle that "Taiwan is the top priority, rank-and-file party members enjoy supremacy."

His remarks were interpreted by Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, as referring to the KMT's policy of "standing in Taiwan while setting its gaze on mainland China."
In other words, Chang said, "Taiwanization" is a means for the party to inspire mainland China to step out on the same path as that followed by Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHTS CALL FOR PARTY UNITY

TEXT.P: Kuomintang heavyweights at an extraordinary session of the party's 15th national congress on Saturday called for party unity while protesters outside the session's venue called for the expulsion of former party chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Former KMT Secretary-General John Chang called on his comrades to unite rather than point the finger at former party leaders.

Elections of legislators and magistrates of local governments scheduled for next year are a serious challenge for the party after its humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election, and unity will be more important than ever if the party hopes to remain a major political player in Taiwan, he said.
Chang would not comment on whether the KMT should team up with the opposition People First Party in the upcoming elections, other than to say that the matter needs careful study.

On a separate note, the illegitimate son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo also revealed that he could travel to Chiang's home province of Zhejiang in mainland China as soon as this autumn to visit the graves of Chiang's ancestors.
Meanwhile, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a KMT stalwart, echoed Chang's view that unity is more important than passing the buck for the election defeat.
He called on the protesters gathered outside the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, the venue of the KMT congress, to calm down and direct their energies to party reform.

Later that afternoon, KMT Acting Chairman Lien Chan was formally elected party chairman, whereupon he promised to make the party a driving force for the country's democracy, freedom, stability and prosperity.

He said he considered the chairmanship a great honor and that he was confident he could stand up to the challenges facing the KMT. (By Maubo Chang) EDITEM ZCZC CEP019 06-17-00 PRESIDENT URGES NTU GRADUATES TO MAINTAIN `CREATIVE MINDS'

Taipei, June 17 (CNA) President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday encouraged graduating students at National Taiwan University (NTU) to maintain their creativity and ingenuity after leaving school to start their new lives.
Speaking at an NTU commencement ceremony, Chen said that like himself in his new job, all new NTU graduates will be freshmen in the places where they will work or study following their graduation.

"Although some people may worry that rookies might encounter many problems in a new environment or workplace, I believe that they can inject new blood and vitality into an old organization," said Chen, who assumed the presidency on May 20.
The human rights-lawyer-turned-president further said he is convinced that tenderpads can more easily shed old burdens and carry out sweeping and innovative reforms than can the "old guard."

"I firmly believe that where there are dreams, there are hopes and dynamics to pursue progress," Chen said, adding: "So long as you can keep a creative mind and enterprising spirit, uphold your ideals, bravely face setbacks and carefully examine the reasons behind failures, you will be able to carve out a road to success."

Chen, himself an NTU alumnus, recalled many fond memories of his years at NTU. "I am proud to be an NTU graduate. Many senior officials in my administration, including Vice President Annette Lu, are also NTU alumni. Our school really has cultivated a large number of outstanding talents for our country."
Noting that NTU is considered Taiwan's No. 1 university, Chen said he hopes the school can further develop itself into the island's first globalized top-notch university.
"More important, I hope more NTU graduates can sense Taiwan's mainstream impulses and become the first people to help cast light into the many dark corners in our society," the president said.

Chen, who at 49 is the ROC's youngest president, further said he believes that only by sharing what they have learned at NTU with underprivileged persons will NTU alumni be able to live up to general social expectations and further glorify the school's high reputation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HEARS SUGGESTIONS FROM THREE LOCAL COUNCIL SPEAKERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met on Saturday with the council speakers of Taipei City, Kaohsiung City and Taiwan Province to hear their suggestions on local development.

Praising the speakers for their outstanding contributions to local development, Chen said he invited them to the Presidential Office because as the country's leader, he needs to listen to the grass-roots voices directly from the representatives elected by the people.

During the meeting, Taipei City Council Speaker Wu Pi-chu raised the protection of women's rights to participate in politics, the revision of laws that regulate local political systems, and other issues.

Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Huang Chi-chuan talked about the administrative merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung Harbor, the city's water supply, and plans for an underground railway and international airport.
Taiwan Provincial Advisory Council Chairman Peng Tien-fu asked Chen to implement the proposals made by his advisory council and to provide more financial support.
Chen told the visitors that the central government will do its best to support local development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT HAS NEW IDEA ON WINNING FOREIGN SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said on Saturday that she has a new idea of promoting Taiwan's friendship with foreign countries through a "soft-style diplomacy."
She made the remarks while delivering a speech titled "Go Ahead, Taiwan" at a joint meeting of Taipei Rotary Clubs.
In order to better introduce Taiwan to foreign countries, Lu said that she plans to have beautiful pamphlets introducing Taiwan printed for distribution to foreign friends by Taiwan travelers abroad.
She added that she will also push for the establishment of an "International Society for Friends of Taiwan" and will invite foreigners who have visited Taiwan to join the organization.
Lu said the members of the society could engage in cultural and sporting exchanges and commercial investment, and could even influence foreign politicians and journalists about Taiwan.
The vice president stressed that her intention is to help assure Taiwan's security and dignity in the international community, and that it is in no way designed to "counter any third party."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE REFLECTS `TENSE' CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The ROC Army announced a major personnel reshuffle on Saturday, which military sources said reflects to some extent the tension and uncertainty in the current relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The army reshuffled all three offshore defense commands -- Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu -- as well as the Hualien-Taitung defense command in eastern Taiwan and the Eighth Army command in southern Taiwan.

Military authorities said the personnel reshuffle was mainly made necessary by the retirement of former Political Warfare Department Director Tsao Wen-sheng, who is now a strategy adviser to the president, and the departure of former Combined Service Force Commander-in-Chief Yang Teh-chih to become chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen in the new government.

However, other army sources said the reshuffle reflects the current state of the cross-strait situation, citing the fact that all three of the offshore defense commands underwent personnel reshuffles, a practice rarely seen in the past.

According to a press release issued by the Army General Headquarters (AGH), Hsueh Shih-min, the incumbent commander of the Matsu Defense Command, will be promoted to the post of top commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, while the position made vacant by Hsueh's departure will be filled by Lu Hua-ning, current commander of the Penghu Defense Command. Lai Kuang-tan, director of the AGH's Operations Department and an expert in anti-landing combat strategy, will succeed Lu as head of the Penghu Defense Command.

Military sources said all the new chiefs of the three offshore defense commands are known for their steady, composed and sophisticated personal characters and their rich experience in defense operations on Taiwan's outlying islands, which with the exception of Penghu lie closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.

A recent report prepared by the National Security Bureau for the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee described as "tense" the cross-strait situation around the time of President Chen shui-bian's May 20 inauguration.

Meanwhile, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen also said on May 31 at his first press conference since assuming office that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) on the other side of the Taiwan Strait has continued its pressure on Taiwan.

Moreover, mainland China reshuffled personnel at its Nanjin and Jinan military zones, both of which are in coastal areas close to Taiwan, earlier this year. In that reshuffle, generals with practical combat experience were named as the top commanders of the two military regions.

Military experts said that although there is little likelihood of an eruption of military conflict in the Taiwan Strait for the moment, cross-strait tension still runs high. Moreover, they added, the PLA has maintained its hard-line rhetoric and stance toward Taiwan since Chen's inauguration.

Against this background, military observers said the General Staff Headquarters and the Army General Headquarters have been very prudent in preparing for the latest personnel reshuffle and that the president has fully respected the joint decision of the two headquarters.

Meanwhile, the observers said the offshore defense commands' personnel reshuffle has also taken into account the need for preparations for the future opening of direct "mini three links" -- trade, shipping and mail -- between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China's coastal cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 18, or the 17th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1812: The US Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners executed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, head of the separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly across the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally begins its Manhattan Project, the manufacturing of the first atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan Province, is executed for sedition.
1953: South Korea releases 26,000 North Korean prisoners of war.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200 others.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to militarily defeat the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1973: A four-member delegation headed by Liu Kuo-tsai, vice president of the Legislative Yuan, leaves for Tokyo to attend the 14th council meeting of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1975: Prince Faisal Musaid is beheaded in Riyadh for the assassination of Saudi King Faisal on March 25.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Dr. Robert M. Lumiamsky, president, and Dr. Gordon B. Turner, vice president, of the American Council of Learned Societies.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1980: General Jose Dolores Herrera, El Salvador's ambassador to the ROC, presents his government's Gold Medal of Great Achievements to General Kao Huei-yuan, defense minister, Admiral Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, General Wang Sheng, director of the General Political Warfare Department, and General Wang Yung-shu, director of the National Security Bureau.
1981: The Executive Yuan appoints Dr. Yen Chen-hsing, president of National Taiwan University, as chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
1999: Florencio Marin, Belize minister of sugar industry and local government and Latin American affairs, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNLIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM NEW 'STRAIGHT' ARCTIC AIR ROUTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's airlines are unlikely to benefit from a newly-proposed North Pole air route, which will shorten flight times between cities in the Western and Eastern Hemispheres from three to five hours, because of the island's political situation, sources from China Airlines (CAL) said on Sunday.

Cathay Pacific Airways is currently conducting test flights from Hong Kong to Toronto via the North Pole, a "strait line" route and the shortest possible path, which will use less fuel and shorten flight times for the carrier and its passengers. The new route would be about three hours shorter than current flight paths, which stop over in Anchorage, Alaska.

However, the Arctic "straight line" route is not likely to benefit Taiwan's carriers, CAL officials said, citing the fact that Taiwan does not maintain no air pacts with Russia or mainland China. The new route passes over both of the geographically big countries.

Taiwan is unlikely to formally sign any air pact with Russia or mainland China in the near future, making it almost impossible for the island's carriers to join their counterparts in the rest of the world in taking advantage of the shorter route, CAL officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENCOURAGES GRADUATES TO DISCOVER THEIR ROLES IN LIFE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Sunday urged graduates of Taipei's Tsai Hsin Elementary, Junior and Senior High Schools to figure out their proper roles in life and play them well.
"Life is like a stage play," Chen said, adding that everyone plays an irreplaceable role, even comic characters or supporting actors with no spoken lines.

Chen noted that comic characters not only bring laughter to others, but also convey many hidden messages about life. He added that sometimes such a character's performance may draw even more applause than that of the main actor or actress.

Chen said, "There is no role too big -- or too small." He went on to say that some roles call for no spoken lines at all, but so long as the characters focus on their parts in the play, even silent players can be "best supporting actors."
When the curtain falls, the audience will tally up the score, Chen said, encouraging each student to discover and clarify his or her role and become responsible actors on the stage of life.
This marked the first time that Chen spoke at a high school graduation ceremony in Taipei since his May 20 inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO OPPOSITION PARTIES NOT RULING OUT POSSIBILITY OF COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Ranking officials from two major opposition parties said on Sunday that they are not ruling out cooperating with each other in the next elections.

John Chang, former secretary general of the Kuomintang (KMT), said that next year's legislative election is expected to be a tough contest and that the KMT will have to think about how to develop mutually beneficial relations with the People First Party (PFP).
Chang made the remarks on the second-day of the extraordinary session of the KMT's 15th National Congress at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.
But he said that it is still too early to talk about substantial plans on cooperation, and added that any inter-party cooperation will depend on further developments.

The political map in Taiwan has been re-drawn since the March 18 presidential election, which saw the KMT losing to the Democratic Progressive Party after more than five decades in power, and the emergence of the People First Party (PFP), formed by supporters of James Soong, a former KMT heavyweight who finished second in the presidential election.
PFP Secretary General Chung Jung-chi said that for now, his party will cooperate with others as long as they have the same stance as the PFP on certain issues.

Chung, speaking on the sideline of a Buddhist youth association on Sunday, noted that political parties should compete with each other in a positive way. "It would be impractical if the PFP shuts the door now (to inter-party cooperation)," he added.
Chung said that PFP's willingness to cooperate with other political parties extends to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), if the DPP presents policies that are in the public's interest.

But he cautioned that as there is still some time before the mayoral, magistrate and legislative elections scheduled at the end of 2001, it is still too early to talk about cooperation and strategic alliances.
Chung stressed that the PFP will have a presence in all major elections, including Taipei's mayoral election -- despite popular incumbent Ma Ying-jeou's statement that he will seek reelection.

Chung noted that PFP Chairman James Soong garnered 36.8 percent of the vote in the March election, second only Chen Shui-bian's 39.3=20 percent. He added that the PFP stands a good chance to win the mayoral election if it nominates a candidate with qualifications similar to Soong.

He stressed that the PFP will consider cooperation with other political parties in individual elections, but added that the situation is not yet clear and it is still too early to talk about such cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 19, or the 18th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien Province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and US President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1974: The Chinese national women's basketball team leaves for Seoul to participate in the 5th Asian women's championship tournament.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang Province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."
