DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO BROADCAST LIVE PRESIDENT CHEN'S 1ST PRESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to meet with members of the domestic and foreign press on Tuesday, marking the president's first formal press conference since his May 20 inauguration.

The Republic of China Government Information Office (GIO) will host a live broadcast of President Chen's press conference and has invited news media throughout the world to view live on the World Wide Web the president's first formal press conference since taking office, GIO officials said.
On its foreign-language website, the GIO will feature a special real-time audio-video broadcast of the entire event beginning at 10:30 a.m. Taipei time on June 20, the officials said.

President Chen will make an address lasting approximately half an hour and will then take questions for a further 30 minutes. Chen will be speaking in Chinese, but a simultaneous Chinese-to-English translation will be provided.
The press conference will take place at the government's Taipei Guest House, GIO officials said.

Issues to be discussed by Chen during the press conference will include cross-strait relations, the much-discussed "three direct links" with the mainland, national security, diplomacy, welfare policy and government financial resources, and policies on other domestic affairs, the officials added.

The live coverage will also include reporting and commentary by a native English speaking anchor. The GIO has set up links to all its overseas websites, giving viewers across the globe instant access to the event as it happens, they noted.

To deliver the Internet broadcast, the GIO is working in cooperation with Chinese Television System (CTS) and Chunghwa Telecom-Digital, two companies currently jointly developing Internet audio-visual broadcast technology, which utilizes broadband capabilities to transmit Internet video broadcasts with high visual resolution and audio fidelity, the officials added.
The GIO's foreign-language website is located at http://www.gio.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 19.7 points to close at 8,751.1.
The bourse opened at 8,786.37, and fluctuated between 8,799.68 and 8,653.62 during trading.

A total of 1.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.69 billion (US$2.10 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.16 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$65.82 billion.

Half of the eight major categories posted gains, with construction shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 0.5 percent, and electrical shares and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 302 to 191, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Monday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved down 35 points to close at 8,814, with 2,107 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 30 points to finish at 8,860, with 1,988 contract transactions, while September futures moved down 10 points to close at 8,940, with 23 contract transactions.
December futures plunged 98 points to finish at 8,950, with four contract transactions, while next March futures moved up 44 points to close at 9,140, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 8,849 for June; 8,890 for July; 8,950 for September; 9,048 for December; and 9,096 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures moved down 1.35 points to close at 491.6, with 624 contract transactions, while July TE futures lost 2.3 points to finish at 492, with 579 contract transactions.

September TE futures decreased 5.05 points to close at 492.95, with nine contract transactions, while December TE futures moved down 1.35 points to finish at 503.2, with two contract transactions, and next March TE futures lost 13.65 points to close at 511.2, with three contract transactions.

June TF futures decreased 4.6 points to close at 884.4, with 129 contract transactions, while July TF futures moved down 2.2 points to finish at 898, with 212 contract transactions, and September TF futures lost 7.6 points to close at 901.4, with seven contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN ECONOMIC RECOVERY SEEN AS FRAGILE

TEXT.P: The economic recovery in Asian countries is looking fragile after a year and a half, with the exceptions of Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore, according to a new survey in the Australian Financial Review on Monday.

The daily quoted economists as revealing that among 11 Asian countries, excluding Japan, seven were today as inclined, or even more inclined, to channel good money into bad investments, a practice that triggered the financial crisis in Thailand in 1997 that then spread to other Asian countries.

The daily quoted economic analysts from Goldman Sachs, UBS Warburg, Korea Exchange Bank, the World Bank Milken Institute in California, and the Asian Development Bank Institute in Japan as concluding that these countries still retain the characteristics that resulted in the poor investments of the 1990s.

The remaining four higher-income economies -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore -- are exceptions because they can change or adjust their strategies to improve the health of their economic structures, according to the survey.
Although East Asia, excluding Japan, is again the fastest-growing area in the world, expanding annually by 6 percent, the economists said they believe the growth is very fragile.
"The crisis has left two legacies: heavy debt and greater household insurity. It has also left the region more vulnerable to external shocks," the World Bank said in its assessment.
Experts believe that reforms in East Asia have been inadequate, and this in turn challenges the prospects for continued growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIA SEEN MAINTAINING HI-TECH PRODUCTION DOMINANCE

TEXT.P: East Asia, including Taiwan, Singapore and South Korea, will remain the world's important maker of high-technology products, according to a leading expert.

The Australian Financial Review on Monday quoted Professor Sanjaya Lall of Oxford University as saying the region will retain its position because it does the two things critical to success -- it develops human capital and it uses foreign multinationals' advanced technologies.
He added that India would not be able to displace East Asia and that Latin America and Africa were falling behind in this area.
"World trade is increasingly driven by technological intensity. Five years ago, 10 percent of world trade was in high-tech products and today it is 24 percent," he said.
Lall pointed out that countries, aside from developing their indigenous capabilities, also need to use foreign technology and know-how to remain successful.

He cited Taiwan and South Korea as examples as both are starting to open up to foreign multinationals to take advantage of these companies' high technology in order to maintain their market dominance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALACE MUSEUM WILLING TO PROMOTE EXHIBITION OF TREASURES ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: National Palace Museum (NPM) Director Tu Cheng-sheng said on Monday that the museum will not oppose lending its invaluable collection of Chinese objets d'art for exhibition in mainland China.

"So long as we can ensure the return and impeccability of our priceless art treasures, we'll be pleased to see the exhibition of our art collection on the mainland," Tu said during a report on NPM operations at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Education and Cultural Affairs Committee.

Tu said the proposed mainland presentation of the NPM exhibits can serve as a new ROC government's goodwill gesture to the mainland as well as help promote mutual understanding and trust between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Nevertheless, Tu said the proposal is still on the drawing board. "As the plan is related to the government's overall policy goal, the museum cannot unilaterally make a final decision," he noted.

Commenting on Tu's report, Legislator Lin Cho-shui said he personally supports cross-strait reconciliation and that cross-strait exchanges of exhibitions of their cherished objets d'art are necessary in forging rapprochement.

Lin also reminded Tu that he need not worry about Beijing's possible refusal to return the NPM exhibits on the excuse that the NPM collection was moved from the mainland to Taiwan after the Chinese communists took control of the mainland.
Lin said if Beijing were to do so, it would mean that Beijing no longer recognized Taiwan's links to Chinese culture.
In his report, Tu also cited several problems facing the museum. He said the NPM's current organizational law must be reviewed and revised.

"The museum is now subject to the jurisdiction of the Cabinet. However, the museum is more like a research and educational institute. We hope its organizational mechanism can be adjusted to meet the practical demand and situation," Tu said.
For one thing, Tu said he hopes the NPM can establish a mechanism to facilitate its research work and minimize administrative interferences.

"We are hopeful that the new mechanism will also be conductive to fulfill and even strengthen the museum's educational functions," Tu said, adding that the museum should also be allowed to recruit more professional personnel to promote exchanges of exhibitions with foreign museums and handle increased exhibition of NPM treasures in other major cities around the island.

Tu also called for immediate improvement of traffic conditions in the museum's vicinity. The museum is located in suburban Taipei, but public transportation services to the museum have been limited. As a result, visitors often have to drive their own cars to the museum, resulting in serious traffic congestion in the nearby region on holidays.

"If traffic problems cannot be resolved, the museum will be unable to present world-class art exhibitions even it has one of the world's largest collection of exquisite Chinese objets d'art," Tu said.
Tu, the first native Taiwanese to head the NPM and an expert in history of Taiwan, strongly denied a report that he has initiated a change to the NPM's title.
"The report was sheer speculation," Tu said, adding that opposition lawmakers need not worry about his ethnic and academic backgrounds would affect NPM's policy or operations.

Tu, an academician of Academia Sinica, the Republic of China's highest research body, further said he will improve the way the museum organizes its exhibitions to meet domestic demands and expectations.
He also promised to look into certain alleged NPM-related mismanagement of artwork procurement or other irregularities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN SEEKING JUSTICE IN BEIJING AFTER BEING CONNED
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 19 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese businessmen filed a complaint with Beijing authorities on Monday seeking justice and compensation after he was conned by officials of the Xiamen local government.

Chen Yun-huo, formerly a deputy of the Republic of China's National Assembly and now a businessman who has invested in mainland China's real estate industry since 1996, said he submitted a written report Monday to Beijing's intermediary body with Taiwan, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), complaining about how he was conned and browbeaten by Xiamen officials.
Chen meanwhile appealed for help from the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office in his efforts in seeking justice.

He said he signed a formal contract with a development group run by Xiamen officials in early 1996 to jointly develop a twin, 12-story residential building in Xiamen, a port city in the southern province of Fujian.

During and after the development process, Chen said, the Xiamen officials changed the original design plans after strong sales in order to build two 18-story buildings without even informing him. He added that the Xiamen officials then tampered with the sales records and provided him with fake transaction papers.

After he found that he had been bamboozled, Chen complained to the Xiamen officials and was told that if he wanted to survive the development project, he should foot further "due" bills, including a foreign exchange difference of 3.5 million renminbi suffered by the mainland authorities because of the Asian economic crisis and a refund of 580,000 renminbi after the joint-venture "harvested an unknown additional amount of profit" after the government amended a natural gas utilization regulation, which raised relevant utility fees.

An indignant Chen approached the official Xiamen Credit Investigation Bureau to tell the agency the truth. Unfortunately, he said, he later found out that officials there were of the same feather. Before long, he received threats from gangland figures and was told to shut up or else.

Chen said he may end up like Lin Ti-chuan, a councilwoman from Kaohsiung City who went to northern mainland China several years ago and was kidnapped and murdered. It remains unclear whether Lin's case was ever clearly solved and her kidnappers and murderers actually dealt with.

Chen said all he wants is that his being cheated and maltreated be brought to the attention of the central government, particularly after the Beijing authorities made public measures to "protect" the interests of Taiwanese business people and investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTHIER PREMIER RESUMES FULL TIME WORK

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei, who was discharged from hospital Sunday after more than one month of rehabilitation in the wake of surgery to remove a chest tumor, resumed his work at the Executive Yuan Monday, government spokeswoman Chung Chin said.

Tang, who described the affairs of state as "great in number and complicated in nature" in justifying his eagerness to return to the office on Sunday, met with Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Cabinet Secretary-General Wea Chi-lin, and government spokeswoman Chung Chin for meetings on various administrative affairs and policies.

Tang also exchanged views with them on how government policies on key issues should be formulated as he is preparing to undergo interpellation at the Legislative Yuan beginning July 4, according to Chung.

Later in the morning, Tang went to the Legislative Yuan to meet with Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-ping. Tang expressed appreciation to Wang and his colleagues for allowing him extra time to rehabilitate by postponing the interpellation schedule.

Tang also expressed concerns that the Legislative Yuan, where the Kuomintang (KMT) remains a majority, should soon come up with measures to offset the impact of the sudden reduction in weekly working hours.

The Legislative Yuan last Friday passed overwhelmingly a new, shortened workweek program, allowing Taiwan's employees to work just 84 hours every two weeks instead of the current 96 hours. The program is expected to be brought into force on Jan. 1, 2001.

Tang stressed the importance of measures to help employers and employees adjust to the new program, which is poised to deal a heavy blow to Taiwan's industrial sector, particularly traditional manufacturing and some high-technology industries involving assembly and manual work.

Tang, 68, underwent surgery to remove a tumor form his chest at Veterans General Hospital (VGH) on April 16. He left the hospital on April 29, but was readmitted on May 2 after catching a cold. Since then, doctors have asked him to remain hospitalized for rest and treatment because of a post-surgery infection.

The premier, who temporarily left the hospital on May 20 to attend the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian and the new government, said that VGH physicians have told him that he will be healthy enough to undergo interpellation at the Legislative Yuan between July 4 and Aug. 4.

Although giving him the green light to be discharged from hospital, the VGH authorities suggested that the premier work no more than six hours a day as he has still not fully recovered from the operation.
VGH doctors said that Tang has recovered by 80 percent to 90 percent and that they will give him another thorough examination at the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO REAFFIRM GOODWILL TOWARD BEIJING IN PRESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will reaffirm goodwill and sincerity to mainland China in his first post-inauguration press conference on Tuesday, Presidential Office sources said on Monday.

In his 25-minute speech to be delivered in the press conference, the sources said, President Chen will also again urge mainland China to resume dialogue and consultation with Taiwan based on existing foundations.

The news conference is scheduled to start at 10:30 a.m. Tuesday on the lawn in front of the Taipei Guest House, a government estate. This will be the first time that the Republic of China's head of state has given an open-air press conference.

Presidential aides said Chen will speak on his major policy goals, basic governing principles and his feelings about his one month on new job in a natural, impromptu style. "There will be no prepared text for the president's speech," said a close aide.

Cross-Taiwan Strait relations will certainly be high on the agenda of Chen's speech. Sources said in preparation for Tuesday's press conference, the Presidential Office, the National Security Council and the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, have extensively discussed issues related to cross-strait ties, including the proposed opening of direct "three links" or "mini three links" with the mainland.
Sources said Chen will uphold the context outlined in his May 20 inaugural speech on cross-strait engagement and will reiterate the ROC's sincerity to promote friendly exchanges with the mainland.

Other topics to be addressed in Chen's Tuesday speech are expected to include defense and diplomatic affairs, financial sources for various welfare service programs, the impact of shortened workweek on local industries, interaction among the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the legislature, and the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung reportedly has twice invited officials of various government departments to discuss relevant issues with a view to helping President Chen better understand progress in various administrative plans.
Following his speech, Chen will field questions from local and foreign journalists for 30 minutes and a half-hour tea party will be held after the press conference.

Meanwhile, the Government Information Office (GIO) will host a live broadcast of Chen's press conference and has invited news media throughout the world to view live on the World Wide Web the president's first formal press conference since taking office.
On its foreign-language website, the GIO will feature a special real-time audio-video broadcast of the entire event beginning at 10:30 a.m. Taipei time on June 20.
President Chen will be speaking in Chinese, but a simultaneous Chinese-to-English translation will be provided.

The live coverage will also include reporting and commentary by a native English speaking anchor. The GIO has set up links to all its overseas websites, giving viewers across the globe instant access to the event as it happens, GIO officials said.
The GIO's foreign-language website is located at http://www.gio.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAVYWEIGHT FAVORS A LIEN-SOONG MEETING FOR RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: A former Kuomintang heavyweight on Monday offered his blessing to the just concluded extraordinary meeting of the Kuomintang National Congress which passed a reform package.

David J. C. Chung, secretary-general of the newly formed People First Party (PFP), also said that although he would personally like to see a meeting between former Vice President Lien Chan, who was overwhelmingly elected as KMT chairman over the weekend, and PFP Chairman James Soong for reconciliation, it would be best if the meeting takes place naturally.

In an interview with a local radio station, Chung said he sincerely hopes the KMT can accomplish the reforms aimed at reviving the party after its humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election.

But Chung, former deputy secretary general of the KMT, also cautioned Lien, who was elected as the party chairman by garnering 94.83 percent of the vote on Saturday, against being too complacent, considering the fact that he obtained nearly 97 percent of vote during last year's KMT presidential candidate nomination.
Chung said the KMT has to reflect on "why is there is such a big gap between the party's will and the people's will," a fact demonstrated by Lien's third place finish in the presidential election.

On the future of Soong and the PFP party, Chung said that Soong indeed has galvanized majority support in the party, but added that Soong has expressed the hope that he is not the only one with a halo in the party, which was formed after the March 18 election in response to calls by Soong's supporters.
He said that Soong will continue to reciprocate the support he has received at the grassroots level.

Chung said that the PFP has not formally discussed cooperation with the KMT, saying that it will have to look at timing and other factors when considering such a possibility. He also said that the PFP will respect other political parties, but at the same time will try to solicit support in its bid to win elections, especially the mayoral, magistrate, and legislative elections at the end of next year.

Turning to the topic of the performance of President Chen Shui-bian and the new administration, Chung said it is not fair to make any criticisms at this point as the new administration has barely ruled for a single month.
He noted, however, that there are many new faces serving in major Cabinet posts and that there have been some missteps due to a lack of enough communication.

He also said that the KMT was rejected by voters because of the serious problem of "black gold politics," or the illegal connection between government and organized crime. But despite Chen's campaign promise to root out "black gold politics" and the general public's high expectations, Chung said that he has seen no such determination on the part of Chen judging from some of the senior presidential and national policy advisers he selected.
But to be fair, Chung said the public should still applaud the Chen administration for its efforts and creativity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.005 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$30.843.
The local currency opened at NT$30.831 and was traded between NT$30.831 and NT$30.869.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$298 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CEPD HEAD TOPS KMT CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE ELECTION VOTE

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, the Republic of China's former top economic planner, garnered the most votes in an election on Monday for the 31-member Kuomintang Central Standing Committee.

Chiang, former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), garnered 160 ballots -- the highest number of votes cast for a single member -- to top the hotly contested election.

Some 236 KMT Central Committee members elected the central standing committee members from among their own ranks in the fourth Central Committee session of the KMT's 15th national congress, with each member entitled to select a maximum of 31 names.
Upon learning the results of the election, KMT Chairman Lien Chan expressed satisfaction and noted that 11 women made it onto the list, which he said showed their "high competitive spirit."
Some 12 legislators and 11 former Cabinet-level officials also made it onto the list that will make up the party's policy-making arm.
With 18 seats won by newcomers and 13 incumbent members retaining their seats, the election is significant in that it shows a passing of the baton to the younger generation, analysts said.

Chiang's vote tally was followed by Acting President of the National Assembly Chen Chin-Jang (139), Legislator Huang Chao-shun (135), former Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang (129), Legislator Chen Chien-chih (121), and former Minister Without Portfolio Huang Ta-chou (120).

Popular Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou ranked seventh with 112 votes, although some KMT central committee members who support former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui had said before the election that they would boycott Ma to show their dissatisfaction over his handling of the street protests following the KMT's humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election.
Ma was followed by former Finance Minister Paul Chiu (111), while legislators Lu Hsiu-yen (106) and Ting Shou-chung (105) rounded out the list of the top 10 members.

Former director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics Wei Duan was last on the 31-member list with 78 votes, while local business tycoon Tony Ching-Jing Sheen missed out on inclusion by a single vote and former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih ranked 38th with 67 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER MEETS VISITING SINGAPOREAN DEPUTY PM

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen held a low-profile, closed-door meeting with visiting Singaporean Deputy Prime Minister Tony Tan Keng Yam, who concurrently serves as defense minister, on Monday.

Wu said he had exchanged views with Tan on issues related to bilateral cooperation between the Republic of China and Singapore. However, Wu would not reveal the content of their talks, saying he couldn't disclose any details because of a bilateral accord.
Wu made the remarks in response to questioning by legislators at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.
Wu said this was not Tan's first visit to Taiwan, and added that he himself has no plan to visit Singapore in the near future.
Asked whether the ROC is still helping train Singaporean troops, Wu said the two countries have maintained cooperation in this field.

Wu, a former navy commander-in-chief, said he hopes to see closer ROC-Singaporean cooperation in troops training. Nevertheless, Wu said he doesn't believe this will help confidence-building between the armed forces on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The minister pointed out that the establishment of a cross-strait military mutual trust mechanism is basically a political problem.
"Only after a cross-strait political trust mechanism is forged can confidence-building on military affairs be considered," Wu noted.
The Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed that Singaporean Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Tan paid a courtesy call on Wu on Monday morning.

The ministry said Tan and Wu exchanged views on matters related to the long-standing "Starlight" cooperative project between the two countries. "Both of them agreed that the two sides should further cooperation in this category," said an MND official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Singapore has forged military cooperative ties with the ROC since it declared independence from Malaysia in 1965. The ROC has sent military experts to serve as strategy advisers to the Southeast Asian city state. Hsia Ying-chou, current president of the ROC's National Defense University, had helped Singapore build up its air force. In addition, the ROC army has helped train Singaporean troops on a long-term basis.

During his current visit, military sources said, Tan will discuss bilateral military cooperation with the ROC's first non-Kuomintang government, which was inaugurated on May 20. In addition, military sources said, Tan may assist in mediating confidence-building between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to help defuse cross-strait tension and maintain peace in the entire Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO CONDUCT JOINT REVIEW OF WORK-WEEK PROGRAM, FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will examine the newly promulgated shortened work-week program and tightened foreign labor policy simultaneously, as the two concerns are inextricably linked, Taiwan's top labor official said on Monday.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu reiterated that the shortened work-week initiated by the opposition Kuomintang in the legislature and passed overwhelmingly last Friday, will undoubtedly deal an immediate and major blow to the country's industrial sector. The new work-week mandates that workers must work a maximum of 84 hours in every two-week period.

Chen also said that a continuous reduction of new foreign laborers into the local workforce is the set policy of the government, but added that whether the tightened policy will be put into force on July 1 as originally planned will require a further assessment.

On the shortened work-week, Chen said that the new program is not expected to exert more than a slight impact on the country's high-technology industry, but will definitely deal a heavy blow to traditional manufacturing industries and some high-tech industries that involve assembly and manual work.
Chen said that both the legislature and the administration should try hard and move fast to come up with measures to offset this impact.

She expressed worry that Taiwan's industrial sector will face a rough road once the new shortened work-week goes into effect, pointing out that it took 10 years for industrially strong Japan to make the transition from a 48-hour to a 44-hour work-week, and adding that Taiwan's present economic stability is comparable to Japan's of a decade ago.

On the stricter foreign labor policy, Chen said the qualification threshold for Taiwan's industrial or business companies wishing to employ foreign laborers will be raised from the current NT$200 million (US$6.49 million) to NT$500 million (US$16.23 million) in capitalization, in an effort to further curb the importation of laborers from abroad.

Government screening on the introduction of foreign nationals to work in private homes as domestic helpers or care-givers will also be further tightened so as to reach the goal of capping the number of new foreign laborer arrivals at less than 15,000 a year, she added.

Meanwhile, it was learned that labor brokerage agents in Taiwan are planning to stage a demonstration on June 28 to publicize the plight they will find themselves in as a result of the tightened restrictions.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STEPPING UP DEVELOPMENT OF NUCLEAR ARMS: JAPANESE DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 19 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A Japanese daily reported on Monday that the latest report by "US governmental institutions" indicates that mainland China is secretly continuing to step up its development of nuclear weapons.
The Sankei Shimbun said that the report on the mainland's nuclear arms and its management of military equipment was compiled by two institutions under the Pentagon.
According to the paper, the report noted that mainland China has augmented its military-use nuclear power and is increasing the number of missiles targeting Taiwan and Japan.
The missiles aimed at Taiwan are said to have ranges of less than 600 km, while those targeting Japan have ranges between 1,000 km and 3,000 km, the paper said.

The paper said Beijing has targeted Japan because: Japan provides bases through which US forces can interfere in the Taiwan issue; because Japan might develop nuclear arms; to counter any US-Japan containment of mainland China; and because of the proposed establishment of a theater missile defense system.
The report notes that mainland China now has between six and 24 inter-continental ballistic missiles (ICBMs) with 400-450 nuclear warheads, according to the newspaper.
It added that with last year's test-firing of its Dongfeng 31 ICBM, mainland China plans to deploy Dongfeng 41 ICBMs that could target any location in the United States by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST 2002 `WELCOME CLUBS INTERNATIONAL' CONGRESS
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, June 19 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The 2000 congress of the Washington-based Welcome Clubs International (WCI) closed in Istanbul on Monday, and decided that the 2002 congress will be held in Taipei.

WCI, a women's organization with chapters scattered throughout several countries, was established to promote the friendship of women around the world and to pursue world peace. Its congress is held once every two years.

The just-concluded congress was held in Ankara and Istanbul from June 12, with 150 delegates from the United States, Germany, Britain, Switzerland, South Africa, the Republic of China and Turkey participating.

The major topics under discussion included the role of women in the 21st century, women's educational problems, women's contributions to minority groups, and the promotion of mutual understanding among various ethnic cultures.
Chuan Chung-wen, head of the 17-member Taipei delegation to the congress, welcomed the decision to hold the 2002 congress in Taipei, and said she is confident it will be a success.

She delivered a speech in English to report Taiwan's outstanding economic and political achievements, as well as its rich cultural heritage and progress in advanced science and technology in the past few years.
The Taipei WCI chapter was established in 1986 and now has 250 members. The incumbent president of the Taipei chapter is the wife of new ROC representative to Washington Chen Chien-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MATHEMATICIAN HONORED BY US FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Mathematician Horng-Tzer Yau has been honored with a prestigious award from the US-based John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the Republic of China National Science Council (NSC) announced on Monday.
The honor bestowed on Yau, who is an adviser to the NSC's National Center for Theoretical Sciences (NCTS), provides a much-needed shot-in-the-arm to basic scientific research in Taiwan, the NSC said.

The foundation announced its 2000 list of 25 new fellows in June, and Yau was the sole winner in the mathematics category. He will be eligible to receive a prize of US$500,000 spread over the next five years.
The foundation said Yau won the fellowship because he "applies profound mathematical insights and analysis to the explanation of important physical processes.

"Although the problems that Yau works on are rooted in physical phenomena, he has made important contributions to fundamental mathematics in several areas: probability theory, non-linear partial differential equations, spectral theory, and dynamical systems theory," the foundation added.

The foundation, set up in 1981, has so far named 588 fellows, with each winner chosen by professionals in their respective fields in a secret and anonymous process. The screening process can sometimes take years.
Yau, 40, who has a B.S. from National Taiwan University and a Ph.D. from Princeton University, is a professor of mathematics at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Science, New York University.
He was invited back to Taiwan to serve as NCTS adviser three years ago, and has since devoted himself to the upgrading of the nation's basic scientific research.
He was also commissioned by the NSC to serve as a guest professor at NCTS and National Chiao Tung University.

In an interview with CNA in which he gave his views on upgrading the research in basic science in Taiwan, he noted that the education system in Taiwan does not encourage students to think independently,
Meanwhile, the NSC said it has decided to throw a party on Wednesday for Yau, who is the only person from Taiwan to have received the fellowship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 60.44 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 60.44 points to close at 8,690.66.
Market turnover amounted to NT$81.43 billion (US$2.64 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT HANDSHAKE, RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday he hopes the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can hold a summit meeting without imposing any preconditions.
Chen made the call at his first post-inauguration press conference.
As the president of the Republic of China, Chen said he will abide by the provision of the constitution to safeguard the country's sovereignty, dignity, security and well-being.

On the other hand, Chen said, he is hopeful that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can jointly cultivate an environment conducive for bilateral engagement under the principles of democracy and parity.
Hopefully, Chen said, mainland China can respect the free choice of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and jointly deal with the question of a future "one China."

Chen said he believes that the two sides can keep their differences while seeking a consensus and maximum mutual benefits. "I'm confident our two sides can jointly deal with cross-strait issues based on existing foundations," he said, adding that the existing foundations refer to conclusions and consensus reached in talks, contacts and negotiations between their two formally authorized intermediary bodies in the past.

Touching on Beijing's claim that both sides reached a consensus on its cherished "one China" principle during a 1992 meeting between Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Chen said the two sides did discuss the "one China" issue, but didn't agree on the "one China" definition.
From Taiwan's view, Chen said, if there was a 1992 consensus, it meant that the two sides "agreed to disagree" on the "one China" definition.
Chen further said so long as the two sides have sincerity and goodwill and get down to talks, they will be able to find out mutually acceptable "one China" definition.

Noting that this is an era of reconciliation, Chen said he hopes the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can draw inspiration from the just-concluded Korean summit and pool their wisdom and ingenuity to jointly "re-write and create history."

Chen said he would sincerely invite mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to sit down to talks without setting any premises or restrictions on time, place or form of the meeting. "Let us jointly create the 'moment of historic handshake' and accomplish the 'mission impossible' with wisdom and creativity," he urged.

Turning to domestic issues, Chen also called for reconciliation of major local political parties. The president congratulated his two main rivals in the March 18 presidential election Lien Chan and James Soong for their elections as chairmen of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, respectively.

Chen, a stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said after the DPP formally endorses Frank Hsieh as its new chairman, he will invite Lien, Soong and Hsieh to the Presidential Office for reconciliation and discussion on major domestic affairs and cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 20, or the 19th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1597: Dutch navigator and Arctic explorer William Barents dies at sea at the age of 47. He led several expeditions in search of the Northeast Passage.
1837: Victoria accedes to the British throne at the age of 18 on the death of her uncle, William IV.
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1900: Baron von Ketteler, the German envoy in Beijing, is killed in the street by Boxer rebels.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation between Vietnam and China.
1940: The French government requests an armistice with Italy.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position. But if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GIVES 'BEST WISHES' TO BEIJING'S OLYMPIAD BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday he hopes to see Beijing succeed in its bid to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
"We wish Beijing a success in its Olympiad bid and will not rule out the possibility of supporting its bid in the future," Chen said at his first press conference since his May 20 inauguration.
Chen said the inspiration from the just-concluded summit meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea was that nothing is impossible in the world.

The president further said if Beijing manages to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can also discuss the feasibility of letting Taiwan host certain Olympic sports contests.

"This proposal seems to be very sensitive and unrealistic at the moment, but the event is still eight years away. Nothing is impossible during this era of reconciliation. So long as both sides of the Taiwan Strait have sincerity, we will certainly be able to mend differences and reconcile," Chen said optimistically.

Asked whether the United States should play a more active role in helping resolve cross-strait issues, Chen said he certainly hopes the United States can work even harder to help the two sides of the Taiwan Strait break their current impasse.

Chen pointed out that the United States pledged in its 1982 "six guarantees" to the Republic of China government that it will not pressure Taiwan to negotiate with the mainland nor act as a "mediator" in cross-strait relations.

"I think this US stance remains unchanged. Nevertheless, US President Bill Clinton has repeatedly said in his talks about cross-strait relations that any solution to cross-strait issues must be achieved by peaceful means and has the assent of the people of Taiwan," Chen said, adding that Clinton's call complies with his consistent view that Taiwan's future must respect the choice of the people of Taiwan out of their free will.

Chen further said he thinks that the United States can play an even more active role in cross-strait relations since maintaining lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait is not only in Taiwan's interest but also in the US interest.

As for the "one China" definition, Chen said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should jointly find out a mutually acceptable conclusion. Chen said he thinks that "Agree to disagree" may be the best consensus for the issue at the moment.
The president also said the planned supraparty task force on cross-strait issues, scheduled to be formed at the end of this month, will basically an advisory body.

The panel, to be headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, will forge domestic consensus on sensitive cross-strait issues and provide counseling services to relevant government agencies, Chen explained.

He stressed that the task force will in no way replace the existing government agencies handling cross-strait policy, such as the National Unification Council and the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

Moreover, Chen said the interparty task force will also not replace the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), which is authorized by the ROC government to handle cross-strait negotiations and exchanges in the absence of official ties.

"The SEF will remain our sole formally authorized intermediary body to handle exchanges with the mainland and SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu will continue to be our top negotiator with the mainland," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED NOT TO PRETEND ALL IS QUIET IN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Amid current tensions between Taiwan and mainland China, the government has the responsibility to inform the public about the situation regarding security in the Taiwan Strait, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said on Tuesday.

Lien called on the ruling government of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) not to pretend that "everything is quiet" in the strait, adding that it would be better to give the people a thorough understanding of the real situation in the region.

The future of cross-strait ties seem to remain uncertain, Lien said, adding that tensions between Taiwan and mainland China have effectively escalated. Although many foreign friends of the Republic of China have warned the government of the seriousness of the situation, some people have still failed to act with caution, he said.

"Regardless of whether those people were truly unaware of the situation or just chose to ignore current developments, the government bears the responsibility to let the people understand the real situation across the strait," Lien said. He also urged leaders on both sides to deal with the problems with far-sightedness and wisdom.
Lien, who was overwhelmingly elected by over 2,000 party delegates as chairman of the KMT on Sunday, made the remarks in an interview with a local radio station.
After ruling Taiwan for more than 50 years, the KMT lost its grip on executive power to the DPP in the March 18 presidential vote, with Lien finishing a distant third in the race.

Admitting that many local opinion leaders and business executives have suggested that he visit mainalnd China, and that mainland authorities have publicly encouraged such a visit, Lien made it clear that he currently has no plans to travel to the mainland, due to the delicate situation between the two sides.

However, Lien also stressed that he is willing to pay a visit to the mainland "some day in the future," as long as such a trip would help boost safety, security, peace, and prosperity for Taiwan's 23 million people.

As to the question of party-to-party exchanges with mainland China, Lien said the KMT, as a major political party -- and the oldest in the Republic of China -- is committed to contributing its experience and viewpoints to the nation in any capacity, as long as such cooperation helps bolster a "win-win" situation across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN EXTENDS ANOTHER OLIVE BRANCH TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday extended another olive branch to mainland China in an effort to bring about a breakthrough in stalled cross-strait relations.

Chen, speaking at his first presidential press conference exactly one month after his inauguration, invited Mainland China President Jiang Zemin to meet with him at any time or place, without setting any preconditions.

Taking a cue from last week's historic summit meeting between the rulers of the two Koreas, Chen said he believed that leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait could "rewrite and create history," by exercising wisdom and creativity.
He urged Jiang to forego any preconditions to talks, and start from a "historic handshake," so that the two sides can sit down and reconcile their differences.

He said that a photograph of President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and Kim Jong Il of North Korea stepping forward to shake each other's hands on June 13 is now hanging in his study, adding that the picture has been an inspiration to him.

"If the two Koreans can, why can't we?" he asked, adding that leaders across the Taiwan Strait possess similar wisdom and creativity, and could also rewrite history. He added that he was sincere in extending an invitation to Jiang for such a "historical handshake."

He also said that not setting any preconditions to talks would be in tune with public expectations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, as long as leaders aim to make the utmost contribution to their people.
Stressing that "we are now in an era of reconciliation," he said that he will promote goodwill, mutual cooperation and permanent peace for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He said that as long as both sides of the strait can display goodwill and sincerity in talks, he believed that they could come up with a definition of "one China" that would be acceptable to both sides.

He noted that as long as the two sides are allowed to maintain their different points of view while seeking a consensus, he is "confident that we can jointly deal with the question of a future 'one China' based on the existing foundation," by which he meant conclusions and agreements reached in past negotiations between the two officially-authorized intermediary bodies.

On Beijing's claim that both sides in 1992 reached a consensus on its cherished "one China" principle, Chen said that Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait did discuss the "one China" issue, but didn't agree on its definition.
If there was any agreement, that would be "to agree to disagree" on the issue, Chen said.

He said that throughout the period since the March 18 presidential election to the present, he has conveyed goodwill and sincerity, including in his May 20 inaugural address. He said his gestures were part of an attempt to make a "historic stride" in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen urged Beijing leaders to respect Taiwan's freedom to choose, adding that the two sides should pool their wisdom and creativity to create conditions conducive to cross-strait cooperation under the principle of equality and democracy.
Touching on the possible future path of cross-strait relations, Chen said that he had no preset stance, but that a "confederation" between the two sides is one option for possible consideration.
Chen added that settling the issue is not up to him or any one political party, but rather the 23 million people on Taiwan.

He said that there was no need to have preconditions for talks, citing the Korean summit as an example since the two sides were able to sit down together despite starkly different views on the unification of the Korean peninsula.

Cross-strait relations were strained after former President Lee Teng-hui spoke of a "special state-to-state" basis for talks in July 1999. The election of Chen, who is a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, has further chilled cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT OPERATIONS CRUCIAL FOR WINNING A WAR, SAYS TOP GENERAL

TEXT.P: Gen. Tang Yao-ming, Republic of China (ROC) chief of the General Staff, on Tuesday stressed the importance of joint operations in all sections of the armed forces in order to upgrade the military's overall combat capabilities.

In order to efficiently defend ROC territory and sovereignty and win a possible war across the Taiwan Strait, Tang said the armed forces must not move too slowly in joint operations development and training, as well as combat strategy research.

Tang made the remarks in his keynote address to a symposium hosted by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on guidelines and strategies of joint operations, which were first introduced by the MND on July 1, 1999.

Tuesday's symposium is the third of its kind recently, as part of MND efforts to pool wisdom and opinions of military experts and strategists from the civilian sector -- including academics and lawmakers -- on the development of joint military operations. The MND's two previous symposiums were held in central and southern Taiwan in early June.
Meanwhile, Tang noted that the number of ROC men and women in uniform has been gradually decreased to 380,000 recently, under the military's "slim and mean" plan.

Under the framework of the National Defense Law and the MND Organization Law, the military will continue to strive toward further downsizing in its rank and file, upgrading combat capabilities, and improving the military's mobilization readiness, Tang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ISRAELI DEFENSE FIRMS IMPOSE OWN BAN ON SALES TO CHINA

TEXT.P: While US and Israeli government officials continue to wrestle over controversial Israeli arms sales to Communist China, at least two major Israeli defense firms are imposing their own bans on future dealings with Beijing, according to a report in the latest issue of Defense News.

The weekly newspaper reported that executives from Israel's Rafael Armament Development Authority and Elbit Systems Ltd. say they will not sell arms to China as a matter of corporate policy. US sales represent a significant and expanding portion business base for both Israeli companies.

"We are not selling to China. We don't see the political or technological advantage of doing business there," Elbit President Joseph Ackerman told Defense News. He noted that the US market comprises 25 percent of Elbit's business and he expects to expand the company's business base in the United States through additional joint ventures and teaming arrangements.
Rafael was more direct in linking its self-imposed ban on sales to China with Washington's repeated appeals to Israel to halt the sale of sensitive, potentially destabilizing weaponry to Beijing.

Referring to the ongoing diplomatic quarrel over Israel Aircraft Industries' sale of Phalcon early warning aircraft to China, Rafael President Giora Shalgi said that "we need to learn lessons from this current controversy and draw our own conclusions. For us, the bottom line is that the US market is critically important."

Shalgi noted that US legislators and government officials often are concerned about Israeli exports to so-called sensitive states because of competitive, rather than political reasons. "But when it reaches the highest political levels and the United States insists it is a matter for their national security, then we need to behave differently," Shalgi told Defense News.

However, the weekly newspaper said, US and Israeli officials were quick to point out that Rafael remains an arm of Israel's Ministry of Defense, and therefore could be directed to override corporate policy if the ministry considered exports sufficiently important for Israeli national security.

Further, US officials remain concerned about the sale of Israel's Python-4 and other Rafael missiles to China, while Rafael officials declined to provide details regarding previous missile deals with Beijing. As for future dealings, however, Rafael officials said they will adhere to their corporate policy restricting such sales to Beijing.

But other Israeli industry executives told Defense News that Rafael's deferential attitude toward Washington sets a dangerous precedent by effectively accepting a US veto over Israeli military exports. They argued that Rafael's policy with regard to China could boomerang in the not-too-distant future, when the US government may want to limit sales to other countries it deems sensitive, such as India or countries in Latin America.

A US official said Washington has no intention of imposing a veto over Israeli exports. However, he said the US government expects Israel to notify and coordinate sensitive sales based on a voluntary formula determined through the 1996 Wassenaar Agreement covering transfers of conventional weaponry and dual-use technologies among supplier countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY FINDS YOUNG IMMIGRANTS FACE RACISM IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Young immigrants in Canada face racism and bigotry in schools and communities that are often unprepared to deal with the challenges that this growing segment of the population poses, a new study released Monday suggests.

The Canadian Council on Social Development study indicates that the majority of youths surveyed found it tough to feel totally accepted because of their accents and looks. They also found going to school a traumatic experience.

The problem is that young immigrants continue to be taunted and ostracized by their fellow students for being different, according to the findings of the survey, which looked at focus groups comprised of 50 individuals.

"The trials and tribulations of high school were magnified for immigrant youth," said Jean Kunz, one of the researchers. "Most of them said they had experienced ostracism and bullying at school. Most of the focus group participants also reported experiencing racism and bigotry, especially those who were members of visible-minority groups," he added.
Even more significant were reports that students felt teachers could also be racist, becoming part of the problem rather than the solution, the study says.
Universities and colleges must also prepare future teachers to be sensitive to the diverse needs of students of different backgrounds, Kunz added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN ALSO EXPERIENCE MORNING SICKNESS, SAY RESEARCHERS

TEXT.P: The answer to the question: Does becoming a father affect a man's hormones? is apparently yes, according to Canadian researchers who claim children give their dads something even before they are born -- morning sickness.
Over the centuries, some men have claimed that they experience "sympathy pains" when their wives get pregnant.
Now endocrinologists are studying whether fathers-to-be undergo physical changes before little junior arrives.
"We are for the first time asking men: Does becoming a father affect your hormones?" said Dr. Katherine Wynne-Edwards of Queen's University.
Besides affirmative answers, she tried to collect physical evidence. She took saliva samples from men in the months leading up to and after their children were born.
The findings revealed a significant increase in an estrogen-like hormone, as well as a decrease in testosterone.
According to her research, the physical changes were significant enough to cause morning sickness, weight gain, joint pain, bloating, and even cravings for different food.
The research is expected to be discussed by experts from around the world at the 82nd annual meeting of the Endocrine Society, which gets under way in Toronto on June 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 21, or the 20th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1527: Italian political theorist Niccolo Machiavelli dies at the age of 58. His book "The Prince" describes the achievement and maintenance of power by a determined ruler indifferent to moral considerations.
1788: The US Constitution comes into force.
1791: An escape plan for Louis XVI of France and his family is foiled as members of the National Guard catch the fugitive king at Varennes and bring him back to Paris.
1852: Friedrich W.A. Froebel, the German educator who established the first kindergarten in 1837 at Blankenburg, dies at the age of 70.
1900: Battles rage in both Beijing and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: A suffragette demonstration in London attracts 20,000 supporters.
1908: Russian composer Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in Scotland's Orkney Islands are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's Gen. Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He had accepted on June 6 Gen. Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1976: A 36-member Republic of China delegation to the 22nd Asian Film Festival returns to Taipei from South Korea after winning nine awards.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan calls on free nations to assume moral responsibility for Indo-Chinese and mainland Chinese refugees and to take effective action immediately.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.

1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The ROC Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 53.06 points to close at 8,637.6.
Despite a rebound in US stock prices, the bourse opened at 8,733.2, and fluctuated between 8,742.23 and 8,631.64 during trading.

A total of 1.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$69.74 billion (US$2.26 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.4 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$81.43 billion.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.7 percent, foodstuff shares and bank and insurance stocks, both at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks and construction shares, both at 0.7 percent, electrical stocks at 0.3 percent, and textile issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 403 to 125, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Wednesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for June moved down 30 points to close at 8,670, with 1,552 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for July decreased 11 points to finish at 8,739, with 2,868 contract transactions, while September futures lost 36 points to close at 8,820, with 13 contract transactions.
However, December futures moved up 74 points to close at 8,910, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

June TE futures edged up 0.4 points to close at 485.5 , with 425 contract transactions, while July TE futures increased 1.8 points to finish at 488.75, with 936 contract transactions, and September TE futures moved down 4.1 points to close at 489.5, with 10 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

June TF futures decreased 28 points to close at 860, with 264 contract transactions, while July TF futures moved down 18.2 points to finish at 883, with 392 contract transactions, and September TF futures lost 13 points to close at 890.2, with 20 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT EXPECTED TO ATTACK TAIWAN WITH NUCLEAR ARMS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is not expected to use nuclear weapons to attack Taiwan, Defense Minister Wu shih-wen said on Wednesday.

Wu made the remarks in response to an interpellation by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lee Ching-hua who asked Wu about media reports that mainland China has deployed a large number of missiles targeting Taiwan and Japan.
Wu said the missiles deployed by the People's Liberation Army in southeastern China, which lies opposite Taiwan, are mainly Dongfeng 11 short-range and Dongfeng 15 medium-range ballistic missiles.

"Although these two kinds of missiles can carry nuclear warheads, mainland China is not likely to use them to attack Taiwan as the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait share common ancestral and cultural links," Wu said, adding that using nuclear arms to hit Taiwan also seriously violates mainland China's strategic thinking.

Asked how many mainland missiles have been deployed against Taiwan and whether Taiwan's missiles can hit mainland China's Shanghai and Hong Kong, Wu said he couldn't answer the questions because they are related to Taiwan's combat strategy.
Liu Tai-ying, former chairman of the Kuomintang's Business Management Committee, once said Taiwan's missiles can reach Shanghai and Hong Kong.
PFP Legislator Lee asked Wu whether Liu's saying is true. "You should ask Liu to answer this question," Wu replied.
Meanwhile, Wu said President Chen Shui-bian's remarks on cross-Taiwan Strait relations at Tuesday's press conference were mainly aimed at helping defuse tension in the region.
As for whether Chen's goodwill message could help reach that goal, Wu said it will depend on mainland China's reaction.

In his first press conference since his May 20 inauguration, President Chen held out an olive branch to Beijing, inviting mainland President Jiang Zemin to hold a historic summit for reconciliation and promising that Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of supporting Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
