DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S INAUGURATION SPEECH TO BE INSERTED IN US CONGRESSIONAL RECORD

TEXT.P: US Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, has submitted Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address for insertion in the congressional record, saying the ROC president "has laid out a solid vision of Taiwan's future and his speech deserves wide dissemination."

"The United States is pleased with the flourishing on Taiwan of a fully-fledged, multi-party democracy which respects human rights and civil liberties. It is hoped that Taiwan will serve as an example to the PRC and others in the region in this regard and will encourage progress in the furthering of democratic principles and practices, respect for human rights, and the rule of law," said Gilman on the House floor Monday.

Gilman pointed out that "Congress looks forward to a broadening and deepening of friendship and cooperation with Taiwan in the years ahead for the mutual benefit of the peoples of the United States and Taiwan."

In closing, the congressman wished President Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, and the people of Taiwan the very best in the future. He then submitted Chen's inaugural address for insertion in the Congressional Record.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REITIRATES SUPPORT FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: In response to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's call for a summit meeting with his Communist Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin, the United States reiterated Tuesday its strong support for a resumption of cross-strait dialogue, but said it is up to Beijing and Taipei to decide the basis for the talks.

White House spokesman Joe Lockhart told a routine press briefing that "we have long supported a resumption of cross-strait dialogue. And that is something that we view as the mechanism for the two sides to resolve their differences."

But the press secretary said he does not know whether the summit proposal will influence the Senate's vote on the legislation that would grant China permanent normal trade relations status. "I think at this point, there is solid support for the vote in the Senate; it's just a matter of when it will get scheduled."

State Department spokesman Richard Boucher also emphasized that "we strongly support a resumption of the cross-strait dialogue. We are committed to promoting peace, stability and prosperity in the region. It is up to Beijing and Taipei to determine the basis for the dialogue and the modalities for the dialogue. Our abiding interest is in the peaceful resolution of the differences between the two sides."

When asked whether Washington was advised in advance that President Chen was going to make this summit proposal, Boucher said that "I don't have anything that would indicate that. I'd just say that we have consistently encouraged the idea of resumption of a cross-strait dialogue."

On whether Secretary of State Madeleine Albright will encourage such a summit when she goes to Beijing, the spokesman replied, "she will certainly discuss cross-strait developments, and also reiterate our view that both sides should resume direct dialogue."

DOC.HEADLINE: POVERTY DRIVES PEOPLE OF FUJIAN PROVINCE TO SEEK BETTER LIFE OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: Poverty and the lack of freedom are the main reasons forcing people in China's coastal Fujian province to seek a better life abroad, according to a Canadian Broadcasting Corp. report Tuesday night.

During the report, three of the migrants from China who came to Canada on leaky, rusting boats last summer spoke publicly of their experiences for the first time. They are among a small group of the 600 mainlanders on the four ships who have been successful in claiming refugee status. Almost all of the migrants have been or will be sent back to China.

In an interview with CBC News, the three women, sitting with an interpreter, asked that their faces be shielded because they fear reprisals from the people smugglers who brought them to Canada's shores.
When asked why they left China, all three spoke of the desperate poverty in Fujian province. "I heard Canada is a good country, a democratic country. I thought about a better life."
"I also brought my children with me. I don't care about myself, I care about my children. I want them to have a good life in the future," said another.

Escaping poverty, however, no matter how dire, is still not enough of a reason to get refugee status in Canada. The three women interviewed were allowed to stay because of the repression they faced due to China's one child policy.
One woman told the refugee board how she was forced to have an abortion. Eight months pregnant, she was given an injection and saw the baby die. She was eventually sterilized against her will.
A refugee board member concluded that "the past persecution of this claimant was so atrocious and appalling that it would be unreasonable to expect her to return to China."

The refugees said they had no idea that the smuggling ships were so dangerous and that they would be detained in Canada for months. But they said life in Fujian province is so harsh that they doubt there's anything the Chinese or Canadian governments could do to dissuade others from embarking on the same desperate journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCOG RECEIVES BAILOUT FUNDS FROM NSW GOV'T

TEXT.P: Faced with fewer sponsors due to a series of scandals and lackluster ticket sales, Olympic organizers received a new infusion of cash when the government of New South Wales allocated nearly US$90 million to help bail them out of their budget disaster.

After a year of budget cuts and revenue black holes, the Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) has to be propped up by NSW taxpayers only 86 days before the opening ceremony of the world's biggest sports event.
The bailout comes only four weeks after NSW Treasurer Michael Egan pledged that "every single last cent" of the Games was paid for.
Olympics Minister Michael Knight sought the payout amid fears that the quality of the 2000 Olympic Games would be eroded if further spending cuts were enforced.
Egan told reporters on Tuesday that "clearly the Olympics has cost the taxpayers of NSW money, I have never denied that."
The bailout money, taken from the NSW government's budget surplus for 1999-2000, leaves the SOCOG with an emergency fund of about US$44 million to cover any further blowouts.
The overall cost of the Olympics is now nearing US$3.8 billion, including federal government contributions and private sector construction costs.

The SOCOG has been hit by a series of financial shortages in the past two years as several major sponsors, including Reebok, withdrew their financial support following public anger over several scandals involving the organizing committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.016 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 30.817.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 30.845 and was traded between 30.797 and 30.845.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$346.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS RESUME MAINLAND TRAVEL PLAN

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, the Legislative Yuan caucus of the newly formed opposition People First Party (PFP) finally decided on Wednesday to resume its plan to organize a delegation to visit mainland China in mid-July.

The PFP parliamentary caucus said the delegation, to be composed of only PFP lawmakers, will mainly meet with Taiwan businesspeople to understand their problems and solicit their suggestions on improvement of services for them.
A spokesman for the caucus said the delegation has no plans to meet with mainland politicians nor will it act as a go-between to convey any messages between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"The delegation will adopt a low-profile approach toward its planned mainland visit," the spokesman said, adding that PFP heavyweights, such as chairman James Soong, vice chairman Chang Chao-hsiung and secretary-general Chung Jung-chi, will not join the delegation on its mainland visit.

Following the inauguration of the ROC's first non-Kuomintang government, legislative caucuses of major domestic political parties have been active in planning mainland visits in attempts to help defuse tension in the Taiwan Strait and push for resumption of semi-official cross-strait dialogue.

In addition to the PFP, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Mainstream Alliance, the KMT's e-Generation Alliance and the pro-unification New Party have all planned to organize trips to the mainland.

However, Beijing has said it will reject visits by delegations organized by either the DPP legislative caucus or its subgroups because of the DPP's pro-independence stance. Beijing already turned down the KMT e-Generation Alliance's visit plan.

Beijing's discriminatory attitude against some Taiwan political parties or groups have made the PFP to take a second thought on its mainland travel plan for fears of being labeled as Beijing's mouthpiece in Taiwan. As a result, the PFP legislative caucus last week announced cancellation of its mainland travel plan.

Nevertheless, some PFP legislators doubted the party's wisdom in canceling the mainland travel plan. They said since major local political groups have been endeavoring to help promote cross-strait exchanges, the PFP need not impose self-restraint. Moreover, they said, the PFP's travel plan is mainly aimed at strengthening services to Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China and has nothing to do with cross-strait politics.
Against this backdrop, the PFP legislative caucus made an about-face on Wednesday and decided to uphold its original mainland travel plan.

Meanwhile, PFP Legislator Liu Sung-fan, also a former Legislative Yuan speaker, who just returned from an undisclosed visit to mainland China, denied that his mainland trip was designed to pave the way for PFP Chairman James Soong, a former Taiwan governor and KMT power broker, to visit the mainland.

In fact, Liu said he personally opposes any proposal that Soong make a visit to the mainland in the near future. "My opinion is that if Soong will continue his political career, he should not visit the mainland at the moment," he added.

Soong, who was ousted from the KMT earlier this year for his decision to run for the presidency as an independent, lost the March 18 presidential election to DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian with a narrow margin. Soong garnered 36.8 percent of the vote, higher than KMT candidate Lien Chan's 23 percent.
While Beijing rejects visits by DPP-organized delegations, it still opens its doors to selected DPP politicians for visits in their private capacity.
For instance, DPP Legislator Lee Ying-yuan, a member of the party's Mainstream Alliance subgroup, is scheduled to visit the mainland later this month.

Meanwhile, Elmer Feng, New Party legislative whip, will travel to the mainland later this week to arrange for a visit by a delegation organized by the tiny right-wing opposition party's legislative caucus, scheduled for early July. Feng claimed that the New Party has become an important "window" for cross-strait contact as Beijing still declines to resume dialogue between the two semi-official intermediary bodies --Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S SUGGESTIONS FRIENDLY, BUT NOT FEASIBLE: KMT AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's remarks on Taiwan-mainland ties were full of good will, but chances are slim that they can be carried out, a Kuomintang official commented on Wednesday.

Chang Jong-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Research Department, said the prospects outlined by Chen on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations may raise the public's expectations for an improvement in Taiwan's dealings with mainland China, but that they represented a far cry from reality.
Chang said that Chen's major aim is to garner international publicity through his remarks. "Such an act will only try the patience of the people of Taiwan," he added.

Speaking at a June 20 news conference to mark his first month in office following inauguration as the Republic of China's 10th president, Chen said on Tuesday that he is willing to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin for a "historical handshake," in any location or time, and without any preconditions. Chen had cited the recent Korean summit as an example for Taipei and Beijing.

Turning to the so-called "one China" principle, Chen denied that Taiwan and mainland China had ever agreed upon the definition of the term. If any consensus really exists between the two sides, it was to "agree to disagree" about "one China," which leaves unfinished the task of working out a single definition that would be acceptable to both sides, the president said.

Stressing that South and North Korea had as early as 1972 signed a joint statement agreeing to eventually achieve a peaceful unification, Chang said that Chen's suggestion that the two Koreas be used as a model was inappropriate.

According to Chang, the basic stance of the two Koreas is to "achieve equality through unification and to push for unification based on equality." Despite the fact that Chen has soft-pedaled his position toward mainland China, the president has so far failed to pursue "China's unification," he pointed out.

Although mainland China still refuses to recognize Taiwan as an equal government, Chang said it is true that past bilateral talks between the two semi-official cross-strait intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- were held on an equal footing.

With Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party serving as Taiwan's new leader, the chances of resuming bilateral unofficial talks -- let alone a cross-strait summit -- seem remote, because Beijing fears that Chen may try to promote "peaceful Taiwan independence," the KMT official analyzed.

In addition, Chang contended that Chen's stated ambition to discuss the "one China" issue with mainland China will mark a setback in bilateral ties, and that the topic is effectively the hardest issue to solve between the two sides.

As to Chen's failure to make a concrete statement about the establishment of the direct trade, transport and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China, Chang asserted that Chen's ambiguity on the issue is due to his understanding that there will be no such links without prior negotiations, and that he knows negotiations on the issue will take time.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY POSTPONES VISIT TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party has postponed its planned visit to promote friendship in mainland China from late June to early July, party spokesman Elmer Feng said on Wednesday.

As mainland China needs more time to assess remarks on cross-Taiwan Strait ties made by President Chen Shui-bian at a Tuesday news conference marking his month-long inauguration as the Republic of China's 10th president, Feng said that the mainland requested that the New Party reschedule its trip to July 9.

According to Feng, mainland China wants to come up with an appropriate way to deal with Taiwan during the visit of the New Party mission. The pro-unification New Party has always been a major conduit between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST ASIAN COUNTRIES LACKING IN PROPER CORPORATE GOVERNANCE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The regional economic crisis has revealed many of Asia's weak points, and none more so than the poor quality of corporate governance, both in the public and private sectors, endemic in most Asian countries, according to a report.
The report was released by the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy, and is based on the findings of a survey the company conducted in May.
During the survey, the company asked foreign expatriates working in the Asian region to rate the quality of corporate governance in the countries in which they reside.

Included in the report's definition of "governance" were whether or not nations were willing to make concrete steps to reduce corruption and improve corporate governance. For example, the report noted the importance of appointing independent outside directors, as well as the employment of professional disinterested auditors and the application of international accounting standards.

On a scale of zero to ten, with zero being the best grade possible and ten the worst, only three systems in Asia got a higher rating than five. Singapore was ranked highest at two points, with Hong Kong and Japan rated at 3.59 and four points, respectively. Expatriate perceptions for the rest of Asia were quite negative. For example, mainland China received 8.22 points.
The report said that most Asian countries fall short of the requirements of good corporate governance.

The report also noted that in most cases, listed companies are still dominated by family owners that often disregard the views and interests of non-family shareholders. In other counties, major listed companies are either partially-owned by the government directly, or by friends and relatives of people holding political power who then use their relationships to their own advantage.

In the same survey, the foreign business executives also lambasted the poor quality of most Asian stock markets. Only three stock market regulatory authorities in Asia were rated better than five points. Japan was the most highly-rated at 2.33 points, followed by Hong Kong and Singapore, at 3.43 and 4.71 points, respectively.

The report said that since this is a structural rather than a cyclical issue, it is likely to remain a nagging problem even though most Asian economies seem to be recovering from the financial crisis.

"Since our survey was made after most economies were on the road to recovery, the implication is that the corporate and financial sector reforms that have been implemented to date have not been sufficient to really impress foreigners working in these systems," the report commented.
"That could have important implications for both the volume and type of foreign investment that flows into Asia in the near future," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA RANKS FIRST IN TAIWAN, SOON TO ISSUE 16 MILLIONTH CARD

TEXT.P: VISA has issued a record-breaking total of 15.9 million cards in Taiwan up to the end of May, ranking it first among all credit card companies in Taiwan.
According to VISA International, the firm issued 4.1 million cards in Taiwan in the past year alone.

Taiwan shoppers racked up a total of NT$41.2 billion (US$1.3 billion) in May using their VISA cards, the third highest single-month figure in history. The amount is more than twice that of Visa's closest competitor in Taiwan, the firm said.

VISA International has issued over 1 billion cards that are accepted by a total of 19 million stores around the world, and nearly 200,000 stores in Taiwan alone. VISA cards can also be used in 620,000 automatic teller machines (ATM) worldwide.

According to VISA Taiwan, approximately 10 percent of all consumer spending in Taiwan are paid by using credit cards, far less than the United States' figure of 23 percent, leaving plenty of room for the future development of Taiwan's credit card market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO-WAY TAIWAN-US TRADE SETS NEW HIGH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 20 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two-way trade between Taiwan and the United States set a record high of US$19.54 billion in the first four months of this year, up nearly 20 percent compared to the same period of a year ago, according to the newest tallies released by the US Department of Commerce.

In the period between January 1 and April 30, Taiwan exports to the United States grew by 13.9 percent to US$12.24 billion on a year-to-year basis, while US exports to Taiwan rose by 30 percent to US$7.3 billion, the US figures show.

US outbound shipments to Taiwan registered year-on-year growth of more than 20 percent for the first four consecutive months of the year, according to the statistics, which show that January saw a year-on-year increase of 22 percent, followed by 29.6 percent in February and April, respectively, and 37.5 percent in March.

As a result of a noticeable increase in US exports to Taiwan, Taiwan's trade surplus with the United States has declined since the beginning of this year. The surplus totaled US$4.93 billion as of the end of April, down 3.7 percent from the same month in 1999.
Taiwan ranked as the United States' seventh-largest import source and its seventh-largest export market during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES INDUSTRIAL LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS PRICE DROP

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced on Wednesday that it will lower domestic industrial liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) prices, effective from midnight on Thursday.

According to the CPC, the price for all industrial LPG such as propane and butane will drop from NT$15.61 (US$0.51) per kilogram to NT$15.32 (US$0.50) per kilogram. The reduction mainly reflects summer off-season market prices, CPC said.
Prices for home-use LPG, car-use petroleum gas, and car-use butane will remain unchanged.

The CPC on Wednesday raised prices for gasoline, diesel, industrial natural gas, and electricity generation-use natural gas in reaction to a recent surge in international crude oil prices to US$32 per barrel. It was its seventh price hike of fiscal 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE PREMIER'S REMARKS REFLECT UNFAMILIARITY WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's recent remarks that Taiwan's democratic elections were a joke simply reflect his scant knowledge of the island's democratic experience, a senior mainland affairs official said on Wednesday.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, was responding to Zhu's criticism at a public hearing on last week's summit meeting between North and South Korea.

Chen said he was not particularly surprised by Zhu's criticism, made in a recent interview with a Belgian newspaper, because Zhu has never visited Taiwan and is a stranger to democratic political operations.
Noting that Zhu is unfamiliar with Taiwan's democratic development, Chen said if Zhu were to have visited Taiwan, he would have been able to see for himself the merits of Taiwan's democratization.

Chen pointed out that although mainland China has held grassroots elections in recent years, those elections take place under a one-party, authoritarian system with no competition from opposition political parties.
In contrast, Chen said, Taiwan's multi-party democratic elections have managed to accomplish the first-ever democratic transition of power between different political parties in a Chinese society.

Chen was referring to the election of Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), as the Republic of China's new president on March 18, which marked an end to the Kuomintang's 55-year rule of Taiwan.
He said all the people of Taiwan are proud of this democratic achievement.

"We earnestly hope that Zhu will one day personally experience the merits of party competition and peaceful transfer of executive power among different political parties through open, fair and democratic elections," Chen said, adding: "By then, I think that Zhu would be able to review democratic development with a sober, proud attitude and he would no longer ridicule Taiwan's democratic achievement."
Chen also urged mainland China to make a positive response to President Chen's call for a summit meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to mend their differences.

President Chen said on Tuesday in his first press conference since taking office on May 20 that he would be willing to meet mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin anywhere, under any protocol, to resolve the cross-strait disputes.

"If North and South Korea could hold a summit without any preconditions or premises, why can't the two sides of the Taiwan Strait? We are hopeful that the Beijing leaders will not continue to snub President Chen's olive branch," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRANSPORTATION MINISTER TO ATTEND APEC TOURISM MEETING

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan is expected to visit South Korea in July to attend the first Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting of tourism ministers.

Yeh will arrive in the South Korean capital of Seoul on July 5 for the two-day meeting, which will begin the following day. Yeh is expected to conduct bilaterial discussions with the tourism ministers of Singapore, South Korea, Australia, and Japan on the sideline of the meeting.

According to the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) Bureau of Tourism, Singapore is primarily interested in urging Taiwan to offer Singapore tourists visa-free preferential treatment under the principle of reciprocity. Taiwan tourists currently do not need to apply for entry visas to visit Singapore as long as the duration of stay is less than 14 days.

The MOTC hopes that Australia and Japan will also be willing to offer Taiwan tourists the same treatment, the bureau said, adding that over 800,000 Taiwan tourists visited Japan last year, and that the numbers keep going up.

South Korea is expected to exchange opinions with Yeh regarding the possibility of resuming flights between the two countries. Taiwan already has an agreement with South Korea that sets the duration of stay for visa-free visits to South Korea to 15 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS HEAD WILL VISIT TAIWAN `SOONER OR LATER': BEIJING VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will make a long-awaited trip to Taiwan "sooner or later," mainland Chinese vice premier Qian Qichen was quoted as saying on Wednesday.

Qian, who is in charge of Beijing's policy toward Taiwan, told a group of Taiwan business leaders in Beijing that a meeting between Wang and his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, will still be subject to the cross-strait situation.

A meeting between Wang and Koo in Taiwan has long been deemed a symbol of reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Wang was initially scheduled to visit Taiwan in the fall of 1999, but the trip was put on hold indefinitely after then-Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui asserted the island's statehood earlier that year.

Chen Kuo-ho, board chairman of the ROC Council for Industrial and Commercial Development (CICD), said Qian acknowledged the contribution made by CICD members to the trade between Taiwan and mainland China, and touted the developing potential of western China to his Taiwan guests.

Tsai Cheng-yuan, a deputy director-general of the Kuomintang's Cultural Affairs Department who met with Qian along with the CICD delegation, said the mainland Chinese vice premier was trying to reach out to Taiwan businessmen by sidestepping the thorny political issues at the roots of the Taipei-Beijing dispute.

Citing the idea of setting up direct trade, transportation and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China as an example, Tsai said Qian did not press hard on the issue during the meeting, saying only that the so-called "three direct links" will be realized "when the time is ripe."
Before receiving the CIDC delegation, Qian also met with representatives from Taiwan's Association of Young Business-founders.

Chang Yao-huang, president of the association, told reporters from Taiwan who accompanied the CICD delegation to Beijing that they urged Qian to better protect Taiwan businessmen in mainland China and offer better incentives to woo Taiwan investors.

Later, ARATS Vice Chairman Sun Yafu hosted a luncheon during which he pitched for Beijing's long-standing policies of "one country, two systems" as a model for Beijing rule of Taiwan, and mainland President Jiang Zemin's "eight points for dealing with Taiwan."
Although there have been twists and turns in bilateral ties, Sun said, complementary commercial ties have taken shape between Taiwan and mainland China in the last decade.

Asserting that the principle of "one China" -- that there is only one China, of which Taiwan is a part -- must be the cornerstone of ties between Taiwan and mainland China, Sun claimed that Beijing will work with the Taiwan people who support this principle to carry out the reunification of China.

The CICD, a group consisting of second-generation Taiwan businessmen, regularly visit mainland China to inspect mainland China's investment environment. Its 36-member delegation arrived in Beijing on Tuesday for a four-day visit, the seventh of its kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFIDENCE, PATIENCE KEY TO IMPROVED CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, June 21 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Wednesday he believes that improving the current deadlocked relations across the Taiwan Strait need patience and confidence.

Chen made the remarks in speeches delivered at the graduation ceremonies at two of his alma maters -- Lungtien Elementary School and Matou Junior High School -- in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan.

Chen, the son of a Tainan County tenant farmer, received heroic welcomes at both schools. A diligent, intelligent student, Chen left outstanding academic records during his elementary and junior high school years.
In his speeches to graduating students at both schools, Chen encouraged his young alumni to face the challenges of life with confidence and patience.

"I have encountered many setbacks in my life and political career, but I have never been daunted by any hardship or ordeal. I firmly believe that so long as we have self-confidence and patience, and work diligently, we will be able to overcome difficulties and realize our life goals," Chen said.
The president went on to say he believes that these key elements to achieve success in personal life are also critical principles to resolve public issues.

"For instance, I'm convinced that if Taiwan remains confident and patient in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait issues, relations with mainland China will gradually improve and peace in the region can also be maintained," Chen added.

Chen, who took office on May 20, held a press conference on Tuesday to mark his first month in his new job in which he recounted his hectic new lifestyle. Over the past month, he has traveled extensively around the island and even to Taiwan's outlying islands to "reach out to the people." He also attended graduation ceremonies at many local schools. Wednesday's ceremonies marked an end to his "commencement" tour.
Starting next week, Chen will launch an islandwide grassroots "reaching-out" tour, with oyster farms in Chiayi County in southern Taiwan as the first stop, according to presidential aides.

In order to forge a national consensus on thorny cross-strait issues and major domestic affairs, they went on, the president is also planning to meet with the leaders of the major political parties and might even call a national development conference to chart various reform programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL PAYS RESPECTS TO BRITISH QUEEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Deputy Foreign Minister David Lee on Wednesday paid his respects to Britain's Queen Elizabeth II on the occasion of her birthday.

"On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, I would like to express our felicitations to the royal family as well as to the people and government of the United Kingdom," Lee said in a speech at a reception hosted by David Coates, director-general of the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei, and attended by various guests that included government officials, members of the diplomatic corps and business leaders.

Lee noted that although the ROC and the UK do not have formal diplomatic relations, bilateral relations have grown significantly closer over the years through the common efforts of the Taipei representative office in the UK, and the BTCO.
According to Lee, there are currently more than 13,000 Taiwanese students studying in the UK, making it second only to the United States as a destination for ROC students studying abroad.
He further pointed out that the UK is one of the most important trading partners of the ROC in Europe.

"More than 50 percent of our investments in Europe are in the UK, most of them in the electronics and information technology industries," he said, adding: "In 1999, our bilateral trade volume reached US$5.55 billion and continues to grow."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORT ORDERS IN MAY HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders have been booming since the beginning of this year, with export orders in May hitting a new high of US$13.36 billion, according to statistics released on Wednesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Export orders in the first five months of this year totaled US$59.12 billion, up 18.39 percent compared with the same period of last year, according to the statistics.

Export orders for information and communication products in May amounted to US$2.438 billion, up 36.58 percent from the year-earlier level. Export orders for these products in the first five months of this year reached US$10.894 billion, a growth of 23.56 percent from the same period of last year.

Export orders for electronics products in May stood at US$2.788 billion, an increase of 64.10 percent from the same month of last year, while orders in the first five months of this year totaled US$11.415 billion, up 38.77 percent from the year-earlier level.
The MOEA attributed May's booming export orders mainly to a stronger global economy and rising demand for technology products.
Taiwan's export orders will probably reach the US$14 billion-level during the fourth quarter, to give an overall annual growth rate of 15 percent, the MOEA predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR SURE TO BE ELECTED NEW DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday published a gazette on the election of its ninth party chairman, scheduled to be held on June 25.
With only one candidate and no limitation on the minimum number of votes necessary to win the election, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will be sure to be elected new DPP chairman.
However, incumbent DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung nevertheless urged party members to vote enthusiastically.
Voting time will be 9 a.m. through 4 p.m. on June 25, and fifty vote-casting and vote-counting venues will be set up for the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH ASSEMBLY SPEAKERS FROM CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Wednesday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should sit down to resume negotiations before the opening of direct trade, postal and communication links.
He stressed that this policy should not be affected by a projected pilgrimage to Fujian Province by local worshippers of Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the Sea.
The president made the remarks while meeting with council and assembly speakers from Taichung City and Taichung, Nantou, Changhua and Yunlin counties.
Chen said that he himself is also a Matsu worshipper, but pointed out that national security is important and that Beijing should not be provided with an excuse to divide the people of Taiwan.

Two groups of Matsu worshippers were originally scheduled to make pilgrimages to Fujian in mid-July, but Beijing recently announced a four-point principle governing the pilgrimages, stating that the trips must be made within the "one China principle" and must be a direct voyage between Taiwan's offshore islands and Fujian.

As the Taipei government's assessment on the feasibility of opening direct links and direct religious voyages will not be finished within the next six months, Beijing's four-point principle has become a hot potato for the Taiwan side.

Because of this, Chaotien Temple in Peikang on Wednesday announced its decision to cancel the pilgrimage this year, while Chenlan Temple in Tachia said that its plan to visit Fujian between July 16 and July 21 will go ahead, but that the pilgrims will go by air via Hong Kong, not by sea.
During the meeting at the Presidential Office, Chen also heard suggestions from the speakers on the progress of post-earthquake reconstruction plans and various local development projects.

Nantou Assembly Speaker Cheng Wen-tung suggested that the government should not levy taxes in his county for five years because Nantou was among the hardest-hit areas in last September's devastating temblor which claimed 2,400 lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VISITS FORMER ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his five vice chairmen visited former President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday to solicit his advice on the operation of the party which lost its grip on power to the Democratic Progressive Party last March.
According to KMT spokesman Jason Hu, the meeting, held at Lee's office in Tamsui in suburban Taipei, lasted for more than one hour in a "joyful" atmosphere.
Lee reminded Lien of the importance of cultivating talent for the party, and said that next year's elections for county magistrates and mayors will decide whether or not the party can rise again.
Hu said that Lee urged the new KMT leadership to make more intimate contact with the people and to search for more talent for the party, so as to win more support from the people.

Lee also asked them to pay more attention to the welfare and interests of women, minority groups and aborigines, and raised the need for the new government to resolve the pressing difficulties faced by traditional industries, such as the textile industry.
Lee resigned his post as KMT chairman after the party's loss in the March 18 presidential election, and he did not attend the recent extraordinary session of the party's 15th National Congress.

The five KMT vice chairmen who visited Lee with Lien are former Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng, former Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling, former KMT Secretary-General Wu Poh-hsiung and former Council for Cultural Affairs Chairwoman Lin Cheng-chih.
Earlier in the day, the group paid its respects to late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo at their respective mausoleums in Tzuhu and Touliao, Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES BEIJING NOT TO CORNER ITSELF WITH `ONE CHINA' POLICY

TEXT.P: "One China" is a concept that needs to be clarified through consultations between Taiwan and mainland China, and Beijing should not paint itself into a corner by sticking to its own interpretation, Premier Tang Fei said on Wednesday.

In a meeting with Robert A. Manning, a researcher at the New York-based Council on Foreign Relations, the former air force general told his visitor that President Chen Shui-bian's mainland China policy is quite flexible and that Beijing should capitalize on this and engage in constructive dialogue with Taiwan rather than squandering it by holding on to its rigid "one China principle."
Tang, who served as Minister of National Defense before being appointed premier, admitted that Taiwan is not Beijing's match in either the quantity or the quality of its military.
Beijing is superior to Taiwan in its space technology, nuclear power and missile technology, although Beijing might not use it against the island, according to Tang.

He attributed the mistrust between Beijing and Taipei to Beijing's concerns about Taiwan's shift toward independence and the Taiwan people's reluctance to accept Beijing's dictatorship, saying that a mind-set favorable to dialogue must be adopted before any meaningful dialogue can take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER ARRIVES IN MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Macedonia, June 21 (CNA) (By Ella Lu and Wen-Hung Fang)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao arrived in Macedonia on Wednesday to discuss a possible breakthrough in bilateral affairs with his Macedonian counterpart Alexandra Dimitrov.

Tien arrived in the Macedonian capital of Skopje from Vienna, where he held a two-day meeting with ROC representatives stationed in various European countries. He was greeted upon his arrival by Dimitrov and ranking Macedonian officials, while the airport flew the ROC national flag.

Tien is scheduled to meet with Dimitrov for discussions on bilateral affairs, host a ceremony to mark a Taiwan donation of US$44,000-worth of computers to Macedonia, and conduct a joint press conference with Dimitrov.
He is expected to then travel on to the Vatican, which apart from Macedonia is Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 22, or the 21st day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte of France abdicates for the second and last time after his defeat at the battle of Waterloo.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: US President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won with Elie Metchnikov the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or the Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1936: Chen Chi-tang rebels in Canton, China.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: ROC Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai Islands.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE WASTE HUGE AMOUNT OF WATER AS THEY FACE DROUGHT

TEXT.P: People in mainland China waste a huge amount of water despite the fact they are facing a serious drought in Shandong, Hebei, Tibet, and other provinces, The Australian reported Thursday.
The report from Beijing said pools of water lie all over the capital of China -- on the streets, in the parks, and outside restaurants and cafes.

Water trucks tour the streets of big cities all over the country, pouring water on to the roads for no clearly discernible reason, the daily reported. Women wearing face masks wander through department stores sprinkling water on the floors so the feet of shoppers won't create dust.
In public lavatories, taps are turned on full and water gushes down the drain while women check their make-up and fix their combs beneath the profligate stream, the daily reported.
The daily quoted Xinhua News Agency as reporting that 3.2 million people in eastern Shandong province are plagued by water shortages caused by a drought that has lasted 22 months.

More than 100,000 crows blackened the sky of Hebei province because they were driven in search of food because of drought. On the Tibetan plateau, farmers are worried that a lack of water will kill their herds, the daily reported.

Since 1950, mainland China is estimated to have lost more than 10 billion kilograms of grain per year because of drought and more than 30 cities throughout the country regularly report that the ground is sinking, cracking, and caving in because the underground water resources are being over-used, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 134.17 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 134.17 points to close at 8,771.77.
Market turnover amounted to NT$94.92 billion (US$3.08 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER DEFENDS FORIEGN POLICY

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday defended his foreign policy inside and outside the Asia-Pacific region.

In an article published by the Sydney Morning Herald, Howard pointed out that his government has not retreated from engagement with Asia, but instead has conducted its relations with Asia differently from the previous government of Paul Keating.

"After more than four years of Coalition government, Australia's economic standing and strength is greater than ever before. Our influence and respect have been strengthened in important areas," he said.
Howard said he was aware of the fact that Canberra's relations with Jakarta would take time to heal after Australia's role in the peace-keeping mission in East Timor last year.
He also defended Australia's policy of not sending police or troops to Fiji and the Solomon Islands to help restore law and order, saying such a move requires a UN endorsement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 134.17 points to close at 8,771.77.
Due to a strong rebound by main-stream electrical shares and textile issues after an 11-day downward streak, the bourse opened at 8,623.4 and fluctuated between 8,771.77 and 8,616.85 during trading.

A total of 1.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.92 billion (US$3.08 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.24 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$69.74 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only construction stocks remained unchanged.

All the other major categories gained ground, with electrical shares and textile issues moving up the most, both at 2.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 370 to 135, with 97 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 82% BACK CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people back the convention of a summit meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but less than half of them think it can become a reality, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Thursday.

The telephone survey of 759 randomly selected adult residents, conducted on Wednesday evening by the mass-circulation United Daily News (UDN), found that 82 percent of the respondents threw support behind President Chen's proposal that the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait meet for a historic handshake and reconciliation.

President Chen, inspired by last week's high-profile North-South Korean summit, said at a press conference on Tuesday he is willing to meet mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin anywhere under any protocol with a view to ending cross-strait hostility. UDN poll results show that only 4 percent of those interviewed gave a thumbs-down to Chen's proposal.

Nevertheless, only 37 percent said they believe that a cross-strait summit is likely to take place during President Chen's four-year tenure; 36 percent said they don't think Chen can realize his "dream" over the next four years; 26 percent said they have no opinion about the issue.

The same survey also found that President Chen's approval rating surged 4 percent to reach 79 percent after Tuesday's press conference which marked his first month on his new job. A mere 6 percent said they were dissatisfied with Chen's performance over the past month; 15 percent declined to answer the question.

According to the poll, 69 percent said they think that President Chen has been friendly toward mainland China since he took office on May 20, while only 3 percent said they feel that Chen is hostile toward the Beijing government.
In contrast, 44 percent said they feel that mainland China remains hostile toward Taiwan since Chen's inauguration, and only 18 percent said they think otherwise.

Meanwhile, 53 percent said they support President Chen's proposal that Taipei assist Beijing in winning its bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games; 21 percent said they oppose the proposal; and 27 percent said they have no opinion about the idea.

The survey further found that 33 percent of the respondents are aware of the full content of Chen's talks during his first post-inauguration press conference, and 87 percent of them said they were satisfied with Chen's remarks while 7 percent gave a negative evaluation.
Asked what impressed them most in Chen's press conference speech, 62 percent cited Chen's call for a cross-strait summit and reconciliation.
