DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP PARTY CHAIRMAN WARNS OF PITFALLS FACING COALITION GOV'T

TEXT.P: Taiwan's coalition government will be hard pressed to eradicate corruption even with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the helm because it is still a minority party in the legislature, according to former DPP Chairman Shih Min-teh.

Shih said in a radio interview on Wednesday that the new DPP administration could certainly fill its ranks with honest politicians and call itself "a government of the entire people and a ruling coalition without corruption." However, he went on to say that the DPP's minority status in the nation's lawmaking body will make Taiwan a place ruled by both "the pure and the corrupted."

DPP lawmakers take up less than 30 percent of congressional seats. The KMT retains 51 percent, while the newly formed People First Party (PFP) takes 9 percent, and the New Party (NP) controls 4 percent.

Shih predicted that the existing legislative structure, carried over from the previous Kuomintang (KMT) administration, will force the DPP government to compromise with the lawmakers during September's budget review. He added that "black gold politics," referring to the illegal connections between politicians and organized crime and large financial interests, is here to stay.

Shih noted that the DPP will have "no choice but to surrender in the end" when all of its bills and budgets are slashed. He added that if the opposition parties let the March 18 presidential election bygones be bygones and decide to work together, then the DPP is "doomed."

He went on to say that currently debated issues such as direct trips to mainland China for religious purposes, the number of work hours per week, and the controversies surrounding the construction of a fourth nuclear power plant are "only the beginning." He added that the budget issue will "completely crumble" the new government.

President Chen Shui-bian's invitation to the chairmen of the three major political parties for a meeting is only a "political show" that will not necessarily resolve any problems, Shih said. It all comes back to the need for a sound national system, he added.

Regarding Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, Shih noted that Lee may be well respected by the people, but his political abilities should be left as an open question because he is a Nobel laureate in chemistry, not a politician. Lee is in the process of setting up an interparty task force to focus on cross-strait issues.

Shih said that he disagrees with Lee's recent remark that Chen's election promises don't necessarily have to be carried out if they are unfeasible. Shih noted that if political views don't have to be realized, then any politician can talk through his hat.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Thursday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for July moved up 181 points to close at 8,920, with 4,391 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for August increased 280 points to finish at 8,950, with 47 contract transactions, while September futures gained 156 points to close at 8,976, with 14 contract transactions.
December futures surged 343 points to finish at 9,300, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Indexc Futures trading on Thursday were: 8,739 for July; 8,670 for August; 8,820 for September; 8,957 for December; and 8,917 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
July TE futures moved up 11.05 points to close at 499.8, with 1,394 contract transactions, while August TE futures increased 16.75 points to finish at 504, with 16 contract transactions.
September TE futures gained 16.6 points to close at 508, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved up 9.4 points to finish at 892.4, with 450 contract transactions, while August TF futures decreased 42.4 points to close at 896, with 13 contract transaction.
September TF futures gained 8.8 points to finish at 899, with 19 contract transactions. No transaction were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY OPENS DUTCH-MADE SUBS TO MEDIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, June 22 (CNA) (By K.J. Lo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy opened its only two Dutch-made submarines, acquired in the late 1980s, to the mass media on Thursday.

Twenty journalists boarded the Sworddragon-class Sub "Sea Tiger," one of the two 66.92-meter submarines owned by the ROC Navy modeled after the Netherlands' Zwaardvis-class submarine, for an undersea ride.
This marked the first time ever that the ROC Navy has given media access to the two Dutch-made submarines since the vessels were delivered to Taiwan in 1986 and 1987 respectively.

"Sea Tiger" and "Sea Dragon" represent two of the four submarines that the ROC Navy currently possesses. The two others, commissioned in the early 70s as "Sea Lion" and "Sea Jaguar," are US-made Guppy-class diesel-electric subs that are now restricted to use for training purposes.

The ROC Navy has wanted to acquire at least 10 more submarines to meet it basic coastal defense requirements and ensure naval security but has failed in its attempts since 1987 due primarily to political reasons. Most submarine-producing countries are reluctant to sell the hardware to Taiwan for fear of offending Beijing.
The Zwaardvis-class "Sea Dragon" and "Sea Tiger" are currently the backbone of the ROC Navy's underwater defense force responsible for anti-submarine and coastal surveillance missions.

The "Sea Dragon" and "Sea Tiger" each stands 66.92 meters long and 8.4 meters wide and are equipped with six 21-inch torpedo launchers and advanced navigation and combat systems. Each submarine has the capacity to carry 11 officers and 66 soldiers.

Each submarine is equipped with three 4,050 horsepower Brons/Stork-Werkspoor 120RUB215 diesel engines, two 922KW Holec generators, and 196 batteries in two settings. With a single-shaft, a five-leave propeller, the vessels have a maximum surface horsepower of 1,400 and a maximum underwater horsepower of 5,100.

The subs are capable of traveling at a maximum speed of 12 knots on the water's surface and at a speed of 20 knots underwater. They have a maximum diving capacity of 240 meters and a maximum mileage of 12,000 nautical miles.

The underwater media event was hosted by Admiral Fei Hung-po of the Navy Fleet Command. All the 20 journalists participating received high-pressure tests before boarding the vessel to ensure that they were physically fit for the submarine ride.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY ASKED TO HELP CONSUME OVER-PRODUCED BANANAS

TEXT.P: The ROC Armed Forces were asked on Thursday to consume more bananas to help digest the produce which has been over-stocked since May this year, sources from the Legislative Yuan said.

Legislator Lee Hsien-jen, a member of the Legislature Committee of Defense Affairs, appealed to the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to purchase more bananas and encourage the men and women in uniform to eat "as many as they could" so as to help banana farmers survive their difficulties.

Hsueh Ying, director of the MND General Welfare Department, who was accompanied by Vice Defense Minister Fang Shou-lu at the Legislature interpellation session, said the armed forces have already "eaten many bananas" and will continue to consume more.

Hsueh said the General Welfare Department has always been supportive of the government's agricultural and economic policies. The military's consumption patterns have constantly changed to help the private sector whenever it needed it, he added.
To help consume the back stocks of bananas islandwide, Hsueh said the military purchased over 60,000 kg in April, increasing its purchases of bananas to 138,000 kg in early June.
The MND formally notified all military units on Wednesday to further increase banana purchases, Hsueh added.
Taiwan's banana growers have been caught in an unprecedented dilemma recently as they face cut-throat competition in Japan and disastrously low prices at home because of over-production.
Taiwan-produced bananas have faced fierce competition in Japan since May this year, when the Philippines began dumping its bananas in that market.

Taiwan varieties, which used to be the Japanese consumers' bananas of choice because of their sweetness, are now exported to Japan at a unit price of 1,400 yen per carton, a price even lower than the production cost of about 1,750 yen.

Lower-than-reasonable export prices have driven banana growers to shun the Japanese market -- a situation that has pushed down wholesale and retail prices in domestic markets as a result of local over-supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: BALL IS IN BEIJING'S COURT: TAIWAN NEGOTIATOR
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 22 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan negotiator with mainland China said here on Thursday that Beijing is obliged to realize the proposal of holding a summit meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Yen Wan-chin, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the remarks in an interview with Sankei Shimbun, an influential Japanese business daily.
SEF, headed by veteran business tycoon Koo Chen-fu, is an intermediary body authorized by the Republic of China government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Yen, who arrived in Tokyo on Wednesday for a visit, said the most important reason behind ROC President Chen Shui-bian's call for a cross-strait summit lies in Chen's wish to defuse misunderstanding and normalize bilateral relations.

Chen, inspired by last week's historic North-South Korean summit, said in his first post-inauguration press conference on Tuesday that he is willing to meet mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin anywhere under any protocol for talks on bilateral issues.

Noting that Taiwan is wide open to cross-strait engagement, Yen said the ball is now in Beijing's court. "We are hopeful that Beijing can make a goodwill response to Chen's olive branch to help realize the goal of cross-strait reconciliation," he added.

Asked about the long-stalled quasi-official dialogue between SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, Yen said as Beijing is scheduled to review its policy toward Taiwan and work out new strategy in August, cross-strait dialogue is expected to resume this autumn at the earliest.

Yen said he is optimistic about the prospects for resumption of cross-strait dialogue because the two sides must discuss some practical trade and economic issues following their entry to the World Trade Organization later this year.

Yen, also director of the China Affairs Department of the ROC's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, also said Taiwan hopes the United States can play the role of "facilitator" to help push for early resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRIES TO SURVEY MAINLAND CHINESE INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: A Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) delegation will begin an eight-day survey of mainland China's investment environment on Sunday.

CNFI Chairman Lin Kuen-chung will lead the delegation, whose members cited increasing difficulties in the operation of labor-intensive industries and small- and medium-sized businesses in Taiwan as the primary reason for their interest in mainland China's current state of investments and industry operations.

According to CNFI, the trip was planned before the Legislative Yuan recently passed a controversial bill shortening work week hours to 84 hours per two-week period. Local industries are widely known to be resentful of the bill, and many business leaders have urged the government to keep their interests in mind, adding that an exodus of industries to more ideal investment environments would otherwise inevitably occur.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DELEGATION SURVEYS TAIWAN TOURISM INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: A delegation of mainland Chinese tourism industry professionals arrived in Taiwan on Wednesday to begin a 10-day survey of the local tourism industry.

Led by Qiu Yanming, deputy director of the Tourism Bureau of Guanxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, the delegation is scheduled to study local theme parks, management of hotels and scenic areas, and travel agency services.

Regarding a local ban on mainland Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, Qiu said that he feels "very positive" about recent efforts by the local tourism industry to promote its removal. He said that he hopes the restriction will be lifted soon, noting that mutual understanding and friendship can only be improved through further cross-strait contacts between people from both sides.

According to Qiu, a total of 1.6 million Taiwan tourists have visited Guangxi's Guilin region since 1987. Last year alone, 240,000 Taiwan tourists visited the area, primarily attracted by Guilin's scenic views and colorful culture, he said.
Qiu added that Guilin is currently renovating its transportation and tourism facilities to accomodate more tourists.
The delegation is scheduled to call on the Taipei Association of Travel Agents on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.039 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$30.778.
The local currency opened at NT$30.796 and was traded between NT$30.776 and NT$30.818.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$435.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OFFICIAL POSITIVE ON NEW ROC GOVERNMENT'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Stephen Dunn, director of the Kaohsiung Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), on Thursday gave a thumbs-up to the new ROC government's performance over the past month.

Dunn, the head of the US representative office in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, offered his praise during visits to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) offices in Chiayi City and Chiayi County.

This was Dunn's first visits to the DPP's offices in the Chiayi area since DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian's stunning victory in the March 18 presidential election, which marked an end to the Kuomintang's 55-year rule of Taiwan.
Dunn said his Chiayi trip was mainly aimed at acquiring first-hand information about the DPP's development plan after its grip on power and possible post-election changes in Chiayi's political map.

Asked about his view on Chen's administration, Dunn said the Republic of China's first non-KMT government has performed well since its inauguration on May 20, and that the US government is generally satisfied with the new ROC government's performance.

Dunn also lauded President Chen's handling of relations across the Taiwan Strait over the past month as very reasonable and prudent. "I think we should give Chen more time to adapt himself to cross-strait issues," he added.

Dunn said he believes that if the new ROC government can completely eradicate "black gold" politics, which refers to connections between organized crime and the government, Taiwan will fare even better.
AIT is a semi-official organization authorized by the US government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Following the DPP's election victory, the "political ecology" in the Chiayi area has changed significantly. The local political arena has been dominated by several large local factions. In the past, the KMT controlled all local "political resources." In the March 18 presidential election, Chen managed to emerged as the top vote-getter in Chiayi County. Since the end of the presidential election, the number of DPP members in the county has increased from 3,000 to more than 7,000, according to party sources. (b Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTERIZED LOTTERY SPECIFICS TO BE WORKED OUT: MOF OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Senior officials at the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Bank of Taiwan confirmed on Thursday that the bank is preparing a report on a national computer lottery, widely expected to be introduced at the end of this year.
According to Tsai Ming-teh, deputy director of the Bank of Taiwan's Lottery Department, the lottery is only in its planning stages, and a date of introduction has not been set.

A senior official at the MOF said that his ministry had indeed asked the bank to present a thorough report on the lottery, but denied media reports that the ministry had set a deadline of just three days.

According to the MOF, the computerized lottery was originally to be introduced in June but was postponed until the end of the year to allow for more planning time, and to prevent adverse effects on sales of the ministry's "Two-in-one" charity lotto.
It was widely reported that lackluster sales of the charity lotto had prompted the MOF to pick up the pace for the introduction of the computerized lottery.

An MOF official said that the ministry will utilize an open selection system to find a company with experience in running computerized lotteries. Complicated details may make it difficult for the lottery to be introduced by the end of the year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER GROUP JOINS MIT'S 'OXYGEN ALLIANCE' PROJECT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the US.

MIT's Oxygen Alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive. The research group is developing technologies to replace desktop computers and keyboards with smaller, portable electronic devices as well as voice-controlled IT devices that can be hidden in walls and ceilings of structures of all kinds.
The project, which was initiated by the US Department of Defense, foresees an almost invisible electronic network serving people in their homes, workplaces, and even automobiles.
Stan Shih, chairman of Acer Group, said on Thursday that the technology the project is developing will allow people to easily enjoy the networked lifestyle of the future.

As a participant in the Oxygen Alliance, Shih said that Acer Group will offer all of its abundant resources and talent in cooperating with the world's top researchers to make technology products that can improve people's lives.
The Oxygen Alliance is also supported by the US Federal Government and five other high-tech companies from all over the world.
The five other firms are Delta Electronics Inc., Nokia Research Center, Philips Research, Hewlett-Packard Corp., and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Co.
The six companies will each offer US$1 million yearly as research funding for this project, in which at least 250 MIT researchers will be involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO ATTEND WORLD FORUM ON DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China delegation to attend the first World Forum on Democracy will leave for Poland on Friday, the Government Information Office (GIO) reported on Thursday.
GIO Deputy Director-General Frederic P.N. Chang said at a press conference that organizers of the world forum has invited four ROC representatives to attend the meeting on behalf of Taiwan.

Those invited were two former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairmen Shih Ming-teh and Hsu Hsin-liang, as well as writer Po Yang and Chang King-yuh, a former GIO chief and chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Chang said.

Po Yang, a former political prisoner whose real name is Kuo Yi-tung, however, has politely rejected the invitation on health reasons. Po Yang, now in his 70s, said he is not suitable for long flight because of his age.

Nevertheless, Po Yang, who currently heads a human rights educational fund, has produced a documentary detailing human rights development in Taiwan for distribution to delegates from other countries as a gift.
The documentary, titled "Mothers Don't Cry Any More," will also be shown at seminars to be hosted by the ROC delegation during the world forum.
The forum, to be held in Warsaw from June 25-27, is jointly organized by the noted US human rights promotional group Freedom House and Poland's Stefan Batory Foundation.

Organizers have invited those who have contributed to the development of democracy and human rights from various countries around the world to attend the forum to discuss effective ways to further promote global democratization.

Former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh, who was jailed for a total of about a quarter of a century during Taiwan's martial law era for his pro-democracy stand, said in the past Taiwan was a target of concern or criticism of world human rights organizations and activists.

"Nowadays, Taiwan has emerged as a mature democracy and greatly improved its human rights conditions. We must now begin to show concern about human rights issues in other countries and help them improve the situation," said Shih, an incumbent lawmaker.
Noting that human rights concern is based on humanitarianism, Shih said it should not be used as a tool or "card" for diplomatic purposes.

Another former DPP chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said Poland and Taiwan share similar political development experience. "Both of them have evolved from a long-term one-party autocracy to a democracy. We should be grateful for contribution made by our democracy activists like Po Yang and Shih. Without their efforts and sacrifice, we can't enjoy democratic lifestyles now," he noted.
This was Hsu's first public appearance since he lost his presidential bid in the March 18 election.
Hsu, who quit the DPP last year to run for the presidency as an independent, said he has accepted the new ROC government's offer to serve as a senior adviser to the president.
"I must accept the offer to show my support for the new government now that I have been defeated in the presidential race," Hsu said.

He further said the new government, also the ROC's first DPP-led administration, faces two arduous tasks -- breaking the logjam in relations across the Taiwan Strait and establishing a workable, efficient constitutional system.

Hsu said cross-strait tension has not eased following the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian, the DPP's standard-bearer in the presidential election. "For the common benefits of all of the 23 million Taiwan residents, President Chen must tackle cross-strait issues in a sober, prudent manner," he urged.

Moreover, Hsu said, the new government, which was inaugurated on May 20, should make efforts to develop a sound, healthy, workable and efficient constitutional system to ensure smooth operation of the administration in the next four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IOC MEMBER `SUPPORTED BEIJING'S BID FOR 2000 OLYMPICS'

TEXT.P: Wu Ching-kuo, the Republic of China member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) said on Thursday that he voted in 1993 for Beijing to host the 2000 Olympics.

In an interview with a local radio station, Wu, who was widely believed to have cast the pivotal vote against Beijing in Monte Carlo that led to Beijing's losing to Sydney, said he did not follow the Taipei authorities' instruction to vote against Beijing in the secret ballot.

In the IOC meeting in Monte Carlo, Sydney was chosen to host the 2000 Olympics over Beijing with a two-vote margin. If Beijing had managed to get just one more vote from a pro-Sydney members, it would have tied with Sydney and led to a runoff vote.

Wu said in Thursday's interview that he has come under heavy fire for the mistaken perception of him as the man who blocked Beijing's bid, but said he was reluctant to set the record straight publicly because of the Taipei authorities' secret order and the IOC rules that its members are not allowed to accept instructions on voting from any government or other group or individual.

Wu said it was Kenya and Uganda IOC members who reneged on earlier promises to vote for Beijing, because Sydney offered aid to their national Olympic committees. He did not offer any evidence or proof to back his claim.
He further claimed that in fact, He Zhenliang, who was President of Beijing's Chinese Olympic Committee at the time, wrote him a letter after the Monte Carlo meeting to thank him for his support.

He also said he backs a proposal put forward by President Chen Shui-bian to bid to co-host the 2008 Olympics with Beijing, and added that he would like to travel to Beijing to discuss the matter with sports officials there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MACEDONIA SIGN ACCORD ON US$10 MILLION DEVELOPMENT FUND
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, June 22 (CNA) (By Lu Yi-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Macedonia signed an agreement on Thursday for the establishment of a special fund to help boost the Balkan state's economic development.
The agreement was signed by visiting ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and Macedonia's Development Minister Trajko Slaveski on behalf their governments.

Under the accord, the ROC will contribute US$2.5 million annually to the fund over the next four years to help finance Macedonia's infrastructure construction projects related to people's daily lives. The Macedonian government will also invest a certain amount of money to the fund annually based on its financial capabilities.

The two countries will set up a five-member management board to administer the fund, with Tien serving as board chairman. Taiwan and Macedonia will each name two board members to assist in screening long-term investment projects.

The fund's bank account will be set up in Taipei and the ROC will deposit the first installment of the promised money on Aug. 1. According to the accord, only the interest income from the fund will be used to finance Macedonia's various development plans.
Macedonian officials said Macedonia will first use the fund to improve its tap water supply system, environmental protection programs and small- and medium-sized enterprises development plans.
Tien arrived in Skopje on Wednesday for a three-day visit. Macedonia is the first country he visited since taking office on May 20.

Shortly after his arrival, Tien and Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov gave a joint press conference in which they reaffirmed the two countries' determination to further strengthen cooperation based on the current basis.
Tien said despite rumors that diplomatic relations between Macedonia and the ROC may change, the two countries will continue economic and political cooperation.
Tien stressed that ROC-Macedonian diplomatic ties are based on their mutual respect of human rights and the fact that they are both democratic countries.
Macedonia established diplomatic relations with Taiwan in January 1999, prompting mainland China to immediately cut off diplomatic ties with Skopje and close its embassy here.
Beijing, which views Taiwan as a breakaway province, enforces a diplomatic embargo against the ROC and refuses to maintain diplomatic ties with countries that recognize Taipei.
Tien said on Wednesday that Taiwan was prepared to share with Macedonia some of its economic experience and, in the future, share some of its fruits of economic development with its friends.
He also expressed his hope that Macedonia will continue supporting the ROC's bid to join major international organizations and activities.

Fielding questions on relations with Beijing, Tien said: "Our president during his inauguration speech has already indicated that the Republic of China will not declare independence, unless we are under threat from external forces."
The minister went on: "President Chen also made it clear that he has no plan to abolish the National Unification Council under the Presidential Office and the National Unification Guidelines."

Furthermore, Tien said, President Chen indicated that on the basis of the current foundations of cross-Taiwan Strait relations he hopes that the leaders of both sides will be able to jointly deal with the issue of a future "one China."
In short, Tien said: "We believe that President Chen has made major concessions in order to promote efforts of reconciliation and peace across the Taiwan Strait.

After the press conference, Tien presided over a ceremony in which he, on behalf of the ROC government, donated US$4 million worth of information technology products, including 28 personal computers, five notebook computers and laser printers, to Macedonia.
The ROC has only two diplomatic allies in Europe. Following his Macedonia visit, Tien will travel to the Vatican City, the ROC's other European ally, for a three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INSPECTS MUDSLIDE-STRICKEN ZONE
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, June 22 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour a mudslide-stricken zone in Hsinyi village in the central Taiwan county of Nantou on Thursday.

Chen and several senior government officials and lawmakers arrived at the disaster zone early in the morning. The president expressed his concern about the rehabilitation work for residents affected by heavy mudflows triggered by recent torrential rains.

Chen and his entourage then inspected an anti-mudslide dam construction project at Fengchiu in Hsinyi village. The president said he hopes the dam can be completed as scheduled to prevent flooding of mudslides in nearby regions.
Later in the day, Chen attended graduation ceremonies in Nantou County, which took the brunt of damage caused by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999.

Chen encouraged students at Chengcheng Elementary School in Shuili township not to be daunted by the disaster caused by the Sept. 21 earthquake and continued to stand up and work diligently to realize their life goals.

Before returning to Taipei, Chen also attended the graduation ceremony at Tannan Elementary School. Tannan is home to indigenous Bunun tribesmen. The school only had nine graduating students this year, but all students and faculty members at the school and residents in the Tannan community turned out to greet the president with traditional Bunun folk songs.
Chen said aborigines are the most beautiful group in Taiwan's multiracial society. He encouraged the new Bunun graduates to continue their study in preparation for future services to society.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH PROGRAM BEGUN TO IMPROVE ABORIGINAL HEALTH

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) on Thursday started a far-reaching program aimed at improving the health of Taiwan's aborigines and offshore island residents.

The program included the signing of contracts between the DOH and 17 local hospitals, local government health bureaus, voluntary service organizations and charitable foundations that will carry out the health improvement program.

The DOH said it would provide funding over a three-year period to the contracted hospitals and organizations to pay for health improvement measures for the 57 aboriginal tribes and the residents of Taiwan-controlled offshore islands.

Alcohol abuse and mental illness are two of the more serious problems facing Taiwan's aborigines, and the DOH has also set up an alcohol abuse and psychological care center at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei, as well as setting up a center at National Yang Ming University, also in Taipei, for the promotion of the health of offshore island residents.

A DOH official noted that the average life expectancy of aborigines and offshore island residents is 10 years less than that of the rest of the nation, while mortality among aborigines and offshore island residents is three to five times that of the rest of Taiwan, with main causes of death listed as accidents, chronic liver disease, gout and alcoholism.
The official said that the goals of the health improvement program are to prolong life expectancy, and decrease the mortality caused by accidents and chronic diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELIGIOUS ACTIVITY SHOULD NOT JEOPARDIZE NATIONAL SECURITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday that religious activity should not be conducted without taking national security into account.

Receiving a group of local Taoists, Chen said the government fully respects religious beliefs, but does not wish to see religion being used by Beijing as a means of alienating religious followers from the Taiwan government.

With regard to demands by local followers of Chinese folk goddess Matsu for permission to make direct cross-Taiwan Strait pilgrimages to Matsu's "home town" of Meizhou, Fujian Province, Chen said he does not believe that Matsu -- who is enshrined as a guardian of fishermen -- "would dictate to her followers the specific day on which to make a trip to mainland China without considering national security."

Matsu's followers at the Chenglan Temple in Taichung County had earlier announced that the goddess had instructed them to travel directly to Meizhou by sea on July 16, a move that would challenge the government's ban on direct shipping links with mainland China.

Noting that the government should not limit pilgrimages, but adding that security should take precedence over religious activity, Chen said he hoped the public will rally behind the government's policy where national security is at stake.

Although the government has promised to give favorable consideration to direct pilgrimages to mainland China, it will require Beijing's cooperation to thrash out the details for such links, just as the "three direct links" -- postal, trade and transportation -- between Taiwan and mainland China cannot be implemented unilaterally, said Chen.

Before direct shipping is approved, Chen said pilgrimages to the mainland should be made via a third country or area, the same travel rules that apply to ordinary visitors to the mainland from Taiwan.

In an attempt to turn the screw on Taipei to open direct pilgrimages to the mainland, Beijing required Taiwan pilgrims either to sail Taiwan-registered boats directly to Meizhou or travel as ordinary visitors.
Caught on the horns of the dilemma, the Chenglan followers have given up their plan to sail directly to Meizhou, and will instead travel by air via Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND: BEIJING TO CONDUCT LIVE FIRE DRILL IN QUANZHOU GULF

TEXT.P: Mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) is to conduct a live ammunition firing drill in Quanzhou Gulf off Fujian Province, opposite Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Thursday.
An MND spokesman said it will be the third live-fire exercise to be staged by the PLA in Quanzhou Gulf since late May.
The spokesman said the ministry will keep a close watch on PLA movements, and will keep issuing warnings in advance, as long the warnings do not compromise national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION IN TOKYO TO EXPLAIN PRESIDENT'S MAINLAND CHINA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China official delegation currently visiting Tokyo met Japanese reporters on Thursday to explain President Chen Shui-bian's mainland China policy.

The delegation, led by Presidential Adviser Tseng Yung-hsien, included ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan, Deputy Secretary-General of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Yen Wan-chin and National Security Council Adviser Yeh Kuo-hsin.
It arrived in Tokyo on June 20, the day of Chen's first post-inauguration press conference, in which he made a goodwill proposal to Beijing.
In the meeting on Thursday, Tseng said Chen's new administration has demonstrated bona fide sincerity to Beijing and that it is now time to see how mainland China responds.
However, he added that the "one China" principle espoused by Beijing means the People's Republic of China, which will not be accepted by Taipei.
Yeh also said he welcomed the recent Korean summit and that he was optimistic about the effects the Korean leaders' talks will have on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The SEF's Yen indicated that the smooth development of economic and trade relations is the first step in normalizing cross-strait links and that politics should not interfere with economic affairs. He added that economic affairs should be resolved through economic means and that if Beijing defuses its hostility toward Taiwan, Taipei would be more willing to open the "three direct links" -- trade, postal and transport -- with mainland China.

As for a proposal that the Democratic Progressive Party should repeal its pro-independence plank, Yen said the president has already declared that he will not participate in DPP affairs, so the issue is not his problem, nor is it a problem for the new government.
He said that instead, it is the problem of a political organization, and added that according to the DPP charter, the plank can be revised with the consent of two-thirds of the party's members.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN ENVOYS ENTERTAINED BY ROC LEGISLATIVE YUAN HEAD

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on Thursday hosted a cocktail party in honor of the foreign ambassadors and envoys stationed in the Republic of China.
Wang told his visitors that the March 18 presidential election saw the turning of a new page in the ROC's democratic development.

He added his belief that the new administration under President Chen Shui-bian will continue to seek to expand Taiwan's role in international organizations and activities, in spite of certain policy changes in other fields.

Wang said that as a member of the global village and international community, the ROC is very willing to shoulder its responsibilities in maintaining peace and in cooperating with other countries in the protection of the environment and intellectual property and human rights, as well as in trade, fishing industry and oceanic development.

He said that the legislature will stand firmly behind the government in its efforts to expand foreign relations and he called for stronger support from the rest of the world for Taiwan's international space.

Speaking on behalf of the foreign envoys present, Burkina Faso Ambassador Tacques Sawadogo, who is also head of the foreign diplomatic corps in Taiwan, praised the Legislative Yuan for its contributions to Taiwan's democratic and economic development.

More than 200 people, including the ambassadors of the ROC's diplomatic allies, representatives of the countries with which the ROC has no official ties, legislators and ranking officials, attended the gathering.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT MEETS US FIRST LADY'S BROTHERS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu met with US first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton's two brothers in Taipei on Thursday at noon for a low-profile lunch.

Legislator Parris Chang, former Democratic Progressive Party representative in Washington, who was instrumental in arranging the Rodhams' secret visit to Taipei, declined to disclose whether the first lady's brothers brought along any message from President Clinton.
Chang, however, said the visit by Hugh and Tony Rodham was useful in bolstering understanding and increasing interaction between Taiwan and the United States.
During the lunch, Vice President Lu exchanged views with the Rodhams on Taipei-Beijing relations and on the impact of the Korean summit on the cross-strait situation, according to Chang.
The Rodhams expressed the hope that Taiwan will further bolster its publicity in the United States so as to enable the American public to better know Taiwan and its people, Chang said.

According to Chang, others present at the secret lunch included National Security Council Secretary-General Chuang Ming-yao, Mainland Affairs Council Chair Tsai Ing-wen, and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chair Chang Fu-mei.
Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), meanwhile, declined to comment on the lunch, only saying that the MOFA knew nothing of the Rodham visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 23, or the 22nd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Pedro de Mendoza, Spanish explorer, dies at sea on his way back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia, in a bid to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent for the saxophone, a woodwind instrument with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube, including soprano, alto, tenor and baritone sizes.
1894: Edward VIII, British monarch, is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title the Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, American zoologist and sociologist best known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1911: Thousands turn out to celebrate the coronation of Britain's King George V in London. The coronation ceremony is attended by 8,000 people, including representatives from all over the world.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chung-hua ke-ming tang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected director-general.
1922: Foreign Minister Wu Ting-fang, who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of an illness in Canton at the age of 81. He was reportedly angered by Chen Chiung-ming, who revolted against Dr. Sun Yat-sen on June 16.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan in Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching to be governor of Taiwan.
1971: The European Economic Community (EEC) concludes negotiations in Luxembourg for Britain's entry into the EEC.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait , Australia, and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The US Supreme Court rules that the US Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: Jonas Edward Salk, American microbiologist, dies in California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The Republic of China and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive, is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 86.84 points to close at 8,684.93.
The bourse opened at 8,786.37 and fluctuated between 8,861.03 and 8,616.85 during trading.

A total of 1.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.31 billion (US$2.45 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.55 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$94.92 billion.
Three of the eight major categories posted gains, with plastics and chemical shares and pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 0.2 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares and bank and insurance stocks moving down the most, both at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent, textile issues at 0.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent
Losers outnumbered gainers 286 to 203, with 112 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Friday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for July moved down 100 points to close at 8,820, with 2,820 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for August decreased 97 points to finish at 8,853, with 72 contract transactions, while September futures lost 106 points to close at 8,870, with nine contract transactions.
December futures plunged 340 points to finish at 8,960, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 8,920 for July; 8,950 for August; 8,976 for September; 9,300 for December; and 9,098 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
July TE futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 493, with 833 contract transactions, while August TE futures decreased 6.8 points to finish at 497.2, with seven contract transactions.
September TE futures lost 13.9 points to close at 494.1, with four contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.

July TF futures lost 13.4 points to close at 879, with 280 contract transactions, while August TF futures moved down 13 points to close at 883, with 13 contract transactions, and September TF futures decreased 12 points to finish at 887, with 23 contract transactions.
However, December TF futures edged up 1.8 points to close at 890.2, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSING ARMY PRIVATE FOUND

TEXT.P: An ROC Army private stationed in Kinmen who went missing Monday was found by military police on Friday morning, ending what might turn out to be another wrestling episode between the military and families of servicemen.
Private Wu Tsung-lin, who was found lingering within an empty house in a residential complex located in a Kinmen suburb, said he left his post because he didn't know how to deal with the pressure.

After dispatching some 3,500 men over the past four days to search for Wu without finding a trace of his whereabouts, the Kinmen Defense Command launched Operation Thunder early Friday morning. Soon after the blanket search operation of all areas in Kinmen was begun, Wu was found at around 9:10 a.m.

Wu, who was serving as a supply aide in a transportation battalion, is now in military police custody. He will face a military trial for overstaying his leave or worse, for desertion, the defense command sources said.

Wu told his inquirers that he went on an errand Monday morning but afterwards did not feel like returning to the office. He then headed to a karaoke parlor to pass some time before hiding with some food supplies in the empty house by the beach .

Wu, 20, from a farming family in Yunlin County, left Taiwan for Kinmen in mid-April to begin a nearly three-year term of military service. His family had not heard from him since then, said his father. Feeling worried, his parents called his unit in early June. Wu talked with them over the telephone, but "sounded weird," the father said. That was the last time they heard from him.

Wu's mother and older sister flew to Kinmen on June 20 after they were told that Wu was declared missing. The relatives returned to Taiwan the next day without receiving any news about Wu's whereabouts.
Back in there hometown, Wu's family took his picture to a Yunlin temple to pray for his safe return and simultaneously appealed to Yunlin-based Legislator Hou Hui-shien for help.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S BEHAVIOUR TOWARD US SAID NOT RESULT OF FACTIONALISM

TEXT.P: Policymakers in Washington share a misguided and even dangerous assumption that Beijing's behavior toward Washington is driven by factional politics within the Communist Chinese leadership, according to an analysis published in the latest issue of Foreign Affairs bimonthly.

Paul Heer, a visiting fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, wrote that Chinese leaders today, in fact, are all moderates, and they are all hardliners. On domestic economic policy, they are all reformers in the sense that they are all openly committed to the reform program Deng Xiaoping launched more than 20 years ago. At the same time, they are hardliners in the sense that they retain a commitment to socialism and to Communist Party rule.

On foreign policy, he pointed out, the common denominator is a genuine commitment to Chinese nationalism. Public and private statements by President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji show that even they are hardliners in that they are unwilling to compromise on core sovereignty issues, especially Taiwan. And they are fundamentally suspicious of US intentions, suspecting that Washington wants to contain China internationally and see the demise of the Communist Party.

At the same time, Heer said, leaders in Beijing recognize the global importance, in military and economic terms, of the United States and the benefits of good relations with Washington -- and thus remain, in another sense, moderates.

"It is, consequently, a mistake to ascribe nationalistic, uncompromising, or suspicious statements or actions by Beijing to an intractable minority within the Chinese leadership. Perhaps more important, it is misguided to presume that the occasional, harshly nationalist rhetoric of Jiang and Zhu and other supposed moderates is the product of political pressure and not genuine," he stressed.

Heer emphasized that "the view on sovereignty issues in Beijing generally characterized as hardline is in fact mainstream. Suspicion and resentment of the United States is not a source of division within the Chinese leadership -- it is one of the common denominators."

The statements and writings of a wide variety of Communist Chinese officials suggest that, although Beijing leaders may argue about how best to respond to the challenge of Washington, they all agree on the nature of that challenge: that the United States is trying to Westernize and divide China through a process of "peaceful evolution" -- policies aimed at undermining the Communist Party's authority -- and support for Taiwan's separatist agenda, he wrote.

Consequently, Heer said, "neither a strengthening of supposed moderates nor a change in leadership will make Beijing more compromising to US interests. Even a change in the nature of the regime would not necessarily produce such a result. A democratic and capitalist China would remain strongly nationalistic, retain mixed feelings about the United States, and insist on doing things its own way."

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTH COULD BE HIT BY ANY OF 900 `NEARBY' ASTEROIDS: STUDY

TEXT.P: A new study has portrayed the paths of asteroids in the inner solar system as a vast Los Angeles-style traffic system crisscrossed with superhighways with planet Earth located in the middle of the network.

The study estimated that an armada of asteroids, 900 strong, all a kilometer in diameter or larger, present a potential hazard to life on Earth. Some pass within a few moon distances of Earth every year.
"Sometime in the future, one of these objects could conceivably run into Earth," warned astronomy researcher William Bottke of Cornell University.
"One kilometer in size is thought to be a magic number, because it has been estimated that these asteroids are capable of wreaking global devastation if they hit the Earth," he added.

Bottke is the lead researcher of a US-French team that discovered the spatial and size distribution of a large group of asteroids called NEAs (near-Earth asteroids), a vast system of orbiting rocks in inner space, ranging in size from mere specks to more than 64 kilometers (40 miles) in diameter.
The astronomers believe the results of their observational and computer-based study will better quantify the likelihood of future catastrophic collisions with Earth.
The team's report appears in the June 23 edition of the journal Science.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM FLIES TO SOLOMON ISLANDS IN LAST DITCH PEACE EFFORT

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer will fly into Honiara on Saturday in a last-ditch effort to seek an agreement between rival guerrilla factions ahead of peace talks.
Downer told reporters on Thursday that he would meet leaders of the warring militias in a bid to resolve the dispute that led to the armed takeover of the capital on June 5.
In addition, Downer will also meet government leaders, members of parliament, and representatives of provincial communities during his stay in Honiara.
He told reporters that there had been "some developments" since his first visit to Honiara on June 11-12 as part of a Commonwealth ministerial delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES ALBRIGHT'S PITCH FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government welcomes US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's appeal to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin for early resumption of peaceful dialogue across the Taiwan Strait, a mainland affairs official said on Friday.

Foreign wire service reports said Albright made a fervent pitch to Jiang during their meeting in Beijing on Thursday to resume dialogue with Taiwan without intimidation in an effort to defuse cross-strait tensions.

"We welcome Albright's call for an early resumption of cross-strait dialogue without any precondition," said Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

Albright was quoted as having told Jiang that the recent election of a new president in Taiwan provided a fresh opportunity for new progress in cross-strait relations and certainly more will be gained through flexibility and appeals to shared interests than could possibly be achieved through efforts of intimidate.

Albright reportedly also urged Jiang to "seize the moment" and take advantage of the apparent new atmosphere in Taipei where new ROC President Chen Shui-bian has suggested a cross-strait leadership meeting similar to the recent North-South Korean summit.

Responding to Albright's pitch, Chen said the ROC government shares similar views with the US secretary of state. "We hope that the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can draw inspiration from the spirit of their North and South Korean counterparts and get down to talks for mending their disputes."

Chen went on to say that the ROC also looks forward to seeing an early resumption of systematic dialogue between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

"We believe that resumption of SEF-ARATS talks will help pave the way for a cross-strait summit," Chen said, adding that he sees no contradiction between promoting resumption of SEF-ARATS dialogue and holding of a cross-strait summit.

According to foreign wire service reports, Jiang continued to snub Albright's suggestion and insisted as a precondition for resumption of cross-strait dialogue that Taiwan's president first acknowledge Beijing's cherished "one China" principle.

Commenting on Beijing's recalcitrant attitude, Chen said he thinks that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should take the North and South Korean leaders as an example and refrain from setting any preconditions or premises for cross-strait dialogue.

"We are willing to discuss any cross-strait issue with Beijing," Chen said, adding that national unification is an "effective option" for the new ROC government in dealing with cross-strait relations and also a "direction" of its efforts in the years ahead.

Chen said he was not particularly surprised by Beijing leaders' claim that they do not understand President Chen's personal character and basic stance. The 49-year-old, lawyer-turned-politician is the ROC's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.
"A lack of mutual understanding signifies the need for top leaders on both sides to talk and communicate," Chen noted.

As for the new ROC government's attitude toward the so-called "one China" principle, Chen said President Chen already clearly stated in his May 20 inaugural speech and June 20 press conference that he hopes top leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait can sit down to talk and jointly deal with the question of a future "one China."

Asked about the possibility of President Chen's proposal mentioned in his June 20 press conference that Taipei and Beijing co-host the 2008 Olympic Games, Chen said it's premature to talk about an event that is still eight years away.
Nevertheless, Chen said the two sides can get down to talk right now on how to make "mission impossible" become a possibility or a reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CABINET TO STUDY CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY MUTUAL-TRUST MECHANISM

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Executive Yuan, or Cabinet, is planning to set up a task force to study the feasibility of establishing a cross-Taiwan Strait military mutual-trust mechanism, a Cabinet official said on Friday.

Lin Wen-shan, director of the Executive Yuan's Third Department, which deals with all administrative work related to the military, said the Cabinet will pool the wisdom and expertise from the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and other Cabinet sections on efforts to assess whether or not the task force should be established and how to effect it.
Lin said, however, that the Executive Yuan will wait until after a July MND symposium that will first assess the feasibility of such a task force being established under the MND.
He made the remarks during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan hosted by People First Party Legislator Chin Huei-chu.

At the hearing, Vice Defense Minister Sun Tao-yu said the MND will not be hasty in setting up a cross-strait military mutual-trust mechanism, adding that until the political standoff across the strait is eased, the establishment of any such group will only lead Taiwan into greater risk.

Yang Chih-heng, deputy director of the Strategic and International Studies Division under the Taiwan Research Institute, who also spoke at the hearing, said such a mechanism would need to be controlled by a higher level in the administrative hierarchy. He also said it should be done through non-military agencies such as the National Security Council, in order to secure more objective and impartial studies and assessments on related issues.

Su Chin-chiang, director of Nanhua University's Peace and Strategy Research Center, said that whether the mechanism is established under the MND or the Executive Yuan, the cross-strait military mutual-trust group would have a positive strategic significance which would help give Taiwan more room to maneuver in cross-strait negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.011 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 30.767.
The local currency opened Friday at 30.760 and was traded between 30.754 and 30.775.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$339.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO PUSH FOR PRESIDENT CHEN'S PRESENCE AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday it will make a pitch for ROC President Chen Shui-bian's participation in this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Andrew L. Y. Hsia, director of the MOFA's International Organizations Affairs Department, said President Chen has publicly expressed his desire to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin for reconciliation.

"We believe that the annual APEC summit is the most suitable and natural setting for a Chen-Jiang meeting," Hsia said, adding that the MOFA will do its best to clear the way for Chen to attend the 2000 APEC leadership meeting scheduled for November in Brunei.
Nevertheless, Hsia admitted that it is no easy task to arrange a Chen-Jiang meeting under the APEC framework.

Because of Beijing's opposition, former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui had been barred from attending the APEC summit in person since the annual event began in 1993. In the past, Lee had to appoint a proxy to attend the annual APEC summit on his behalf.

Under the current international climate, Hsia said, great obstacles still stand in President Chen's way to the APEC summit. "But anyway, the MOFA will make continued efforts to realize this goal," he added.

Taking a cue from last week's high-profile North-South Korean summit, President Chen told a Tuesday press conference, which marked his first month on his new job, that he is willing to meet his mainland counterpart anywhere under any protocol.

Hsia said he believes that so long as mainland China does not set any preconditions or premises, there will be many opportunities or occasions for top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet.

APEC, a 21-member regional economic cooperation forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations where both Taiwan and mainland China are full members.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN CITIZENS FAVOR `KOREAN FORMULA' TO SOLVE IMPASSE: POLL

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan citizens think that the "Korean formula" that helped thaw Seoul-Pyongyang relations can be borrowed to ease the cross-Taiwan Strait impasse, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll.

The poll, conducted by the Kuomintang's Policy Research Committee, found that 70.07 percent of the respondents hope that the "Korean formula" of reconciliation can be applied to cross-strait relations, while nearly 50 percent think that Beijing should bear the full responsibility for causing the cross-strait standoff and aggravation of relations.

According to the poll, 17.15 percent of the respondents think Taiwan should be blamed for the political deadlock across the Taiwan Strait and 8.12 percent think the United States should take the blame.

Analyzing the results of the poll, which focused mainly on the impact of the Korean summit on cross-strait relations, KMT Policy Research Committee Deputy Executive Director Hung Chao-nan said neither the mainland nor Taiwan is blameless in aggravating cross-strait tension, and added that both sides should use more wisdom and tolerance to ease the deadlock.

On the prospects of developing cross-strait relations in the future, the poll found that 9.49 percent of the respondents feel the chances of conflict developing are bigger than the likelihood of peace, while 27.19 percent said they were unable to decide one way or the other. Some 59.12 percent said the chances of a peaceful resolution are bigger than the likelihood of war.

When asked about the chances of the United States actually "participating in military operations" should the Chinese communists attack Taiwan, 67.33 percent of the respondents said US participation would be "very likely," or "probable," while some 25.09 percent said it would be "unlikely."

The results show that most of those polled believe that the United States will not sit idly by on the cross-strait conflict, Hung noted, pointing out that deeper studies by the government will be needed to decide whether this is a good or bad sign.

From the poll results, Hung said, it can be seen that the respondents understand that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait lack benign interaction, and that while Taiwan presently does not expect a leadership summit across the strait any time soon, it is keenly hoped that cross-strait dialogue will be resumed, the earlier the better.
The telephone poll was conducted between June 17 and 18 among adults islandwide. The committee acquired 1,096 valid responses with an error margin of under 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRY MISSION TO MEET WITH MAINLAND CHINESE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A delegation from Taiwan's Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) will call on mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing next week, CNFI President Lin Kun-chung told reporters on Friday.

Lin said the delegation will not touch on political issues during the meeting with Jiang, but might take up the issue of direct cross-Taiwan Strait trade, postal and communication links from the economic point of view.
The 36-member mission will leave Taipei on June 25 for the eight-day trip to the mainland. They will stay in Beijing for the first three days and then proceed to Shanghai.
Meanwhile, another CNFI official said that Jiang plans to meet with some members of the Taiwan mission on June 26, but added that the reception might be a closed-door affair.

The official further said that the mission will also meet with Beijing Mayor Liu Qi and several ranking mainland Chinese officials in charge of trade and economic affairs, as well as visiting special economic development zones in Pudong, Wuxi and Kunshan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT AD HOC GROUP TO CALL MEETING NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: A supra-party task force on Taiwan-mainland China relations to be led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh is expected to call its first meeting next week, sources said on Friday.

According to the sources, Lee, as a "relevant figure," will be able to take part in meetings of the National Security Council (NSC) and pass on the findings of the informal ad hoc group to President Chen Shui-bian so that they can be taken into consideration when forming national policy.

As Chen has high expectations that the task force will be effective in forging national consensus on major cross-Taiwan strait issues, its lineup, status and role will have a great impact on the government mechanism in charge of drawing up Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, the sources said.
The planned unofficial ad hoc group, to be composed of 20 members from various political camps, will act as an advisory body that will provide Chen with consultation on major cross-strait affairs.

Once the task force is set up, the National Unification Council (NUC) may also convene a meeting in August at the earliest, at a time when the Beijing leadership has its annual policy-making meeting at Beidaihe during which it is expected to draw up an official response to Chen's stance toward mainland China, the sources said.
The convening of an NUC meeting by that time will be a major benchmark that will indicate the development of cross-strait ties, they added.

When Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, won Taiwan's March 18 presidential election, Beijing said that it would "listen to Chen's words and watch his deeds" before deciding how to respond to him.
Meanwhile, Lee said in the eastern city of Hualien that he will announce the list of members of his ad hoc group in the coming days once a final decision has been made.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS, EMPLOYERS MAKE OPPOSING APPEALS ON FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: Legislators and senior business executives made completely opposing appeals to the government on Friday concerning its policy regarding foreign laborers.

While lawmakers demanded that the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) uphold a promise to cut the annual quota for foreign laborers by 15,000 from next year, many senior business executives urged the government to allow them to hire even more foreign laborers to help tide them over the difficulties that will be caused by the shortened workweek scheduled for implementation from the beginning of 2001.

Legislators Cheng Lung-shui of the tiny right-wing opposition New Party (NP), Chou Ching-yu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Kuo Su-chun of the powerful opposition Kuomintang held a joint news conference to remind the CLA to uphold its "trimming the quota of foreign laborers" promise.

Chou said CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu, also a DPP stalwart, promised in a May 24 report to the Legislative Yuan's Health, Environment and Welfare Services Committee that the labor council will push for an annual reduction of the foreign workers quota by 15,000.

However, Chou said since the legislature passed a KMT-initiated bill on a much-shortened workweek system earlier this month, Chen has softened her stance by saying last week that the "foreign labor quota reduction" policy is still pending evaluation.

Chou said Taiwan now boasts Asia's highest wage levels for foreign laborers, doubling that offered in Singapore. As the domestic unemployment rate has continued rising, Chou said, lowering the number of foreign laborers has become an urgent problem.

Speaking on the same occasion, NP Legislator Cheng Lung-shui said the government's current foreign labor policy has been "abused" by local employers as an excuse to cut production costs at the expense of local blue-collar workers' job opportunities.

Cheng initiated a draft bill on Friday, demanding the Cabinet to trim the quota of foreign laborers by 15,000 annually from 2001 until the ratio of foreign labor in Taiwan's job market drops to 1.6 percent.
Cheng said many of his legislative colleagues have endorsed the draft bill which he said will be referred to the legislature for discussion next week.
Government tallies show that Taiwan had 294,000 legal foreign workers at the end of last year, and that in May this year, about 120,000 grassroots laborers were out of work.

According to statistical officials, the unemployment rate among grassroots blue-collar workers was 1.2 times higher that Taiwan's average jobless rate. They said the import of foreign laborers apparently has affected local blue-collar workers' job openings.

The CLA becomes hesitant to gradually reduce the quota of foreign workers after the legislature overturned a Cabinet plan to shorten the weekly work time from current 48 hours to 44 hours starting next year.

Led by the KMT, Taiwan's ruling party until May 20 which still controls majority seats in the Legislative Yuan, the legislature has passed a bill which trims biweekly work time to 84 hours from 2001. The KMT-initiated version also stipulates that the weekly workweek should not exceed 44 hours under the new system.
The passage of the KMT-proposed bill has triggered strong backlash from local employers, particularly those in battered traditional labor-intensive industries.

Owners of many small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have complained that the shortened work hours would further blunt their competitiveness or even threaten their very survival due to largely increased labor costs. They urged the government to take effective measures to offset the adverse impact to be caused by the new workweek system, including halting the planned cut in the number of foreign laborers.

At a senior business executives meeting called by the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Friday, they unanimously urged the government to increase the import quota of foreign laborers to help them cope with the problems that will arise from shortened workweek.

At present, only manufacturing and construction industries can hire foreign laborers. At Friday's meeting, many service industry operators also urged the government to allow them to employ foreign workers to cut labor costs and to slash national holidays to 10 days from current 19 days.
Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, who chaired the meeting, said representatives of employers and the employees should sit down to talk and mend their differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA CALL ON WEST TO WRITE OFF AFRICAN DEBT

TEXT.P: South African Financial Minister Trevor Manuel has called on Western countries to write off Africa's debt burden because the continent has no means of sustaining itself.
Speaking at the World Economic Forum's Southern Africa summit in Durban, Manuel said: "Even the money spent by consumers in Africa lines the pockets of shareholders in the first world."

Manuel said the future of the continent is at stake, and he called for the developed world to emulate the assistance which was given to Europe and Japan in the rebuilding of their economies after the Second World War.
He pointed out that since the end of the Cold War there has been little interest shown in winning the hearts and minds of Africans, as they are of little strategic importance.

Anti-apartheid activist Dennis Brutus, who is on the steering committee of the Washington-based Alliance for Global Justice, echoed Manuel's opinion at the summit, saying: "We denounce an economic system that continues to shift opportunities, resources and power away from those most in need to those already well provided for."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE CENTER TO BE INAUGURATED IN SKOPJE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Trade Center in Skopje is expected to be inaugurated by the end of June, said the facility's Taiwanese management firm, Koo's Group, on Friday.

The five-story building will serve as a center for Taiwan businessmen who are interested in exploring the Balkan market, said Wu Kuan-hsiung, vice chairman of the Overseas Investment and Development Corp. (OIDC), a subsidiary of Koo's Group, which was contracted to refurbish and manage the facility.

The center will be modeled on Taipei's World Trade Center, with an exhibition area on the ground floor, offices for the OIDC and other Taiwan firms doing business in Macedonia on the second and third floors, and a full-service hotel on the fourth and fifth floors, said Wu.
Wu noted that Taiwan businessmen staying in the facility will be able to do business without stepping out of the building.

Wu added that many local companies as well as foreign firms are exploring the possibility of moving into the new office building, because of its attractive central location in downtown Skopje, said Wu.
Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, who is in the Balkan state on his first overseas visit after taking office on May 20, visited the center on Friday and was briefed by Wu.
He later visited an industrial zone developed by Taiwan's China Development Corporation (CDC).

A CDC executive told Tien that the industrial zone, with an initial size of 30 hectares, is intended to attract firms from Taiwan in hopes that they will use it as a springboard for making forays into the European market.
Macedonia established diplomatic ties with the Republic of China in 1999, in the hope that the island state would assist it develop economically.

DOC.HEADLINE: BACKING BEIJING'S OLYMPIAD BID TO HELP MAINTAIN PEACE: IOC MEMBER

TEXT.P: An International Olympic Committee (IOC) member said on Friday he believes that Taipei's support for Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games will help maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait for at least 10 years.
Wu Ching-kuo, the Republic of China's only IOC member, made the remarks at a public hearing on the proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait co-host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Wu, who is also the sole Chinese IOC member, praised President Chen Shui-bian's announcement in his June 20 press conference that Taiwan would support Beijing's Olympiad bid.

"It's a wise decision which signifies Presdient Chen's goodwill and sincerity toward improving relations with Beijing," Wu said, adding that if Beijing manages to win the bid, the possibility of eruption of a cross-strait conflict in the next 10 years will be slim.

Wu recalled that he already told IOC Chairman Juan Antonio Samaranch during a meeting in April that Taipei may throw support behind Beijing's 2008 Olympiad bid. "Samaranch praised it as an 'excellent idea,'" he added.

In line with the IOC rules, Wu said, Taipei must in the first stage unconditionally backs Beijing's Olympiad bid. Once Beijing wins the bid, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can then discuss the possibility of letting Taipei host some sports competitions.

A total of 10 cities around the world have applied to host the 2008 Olympic Games, and the IOC is scheduled to select three to five cities in August for a second-stage screening. A final vote on the host city will be held next year. According to Wu, Beijing stands a good chance to win this time.

Seven years ago, Beijing lost to Sydney to host the 2000 Olympic Games with a two-vote margin. Wu said he voted for Beijing out of his free will in the 1993 vote for the host city of the upcoming sports extravaganza.

Speaking on the same occasion, Hsu I-hsiung, chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS), said the council will form a sports policy advisory task force to study how to implement President Chen's proposal of supporting Beijing's Olympiad bid.

The task force will comprise officials from the NCPFS, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council and other relevant government agencies, Hsu said, adding that if all goes well, the panel may hold its first meeting next week to discuss the issue.

Hsu also said he is willing to meet with mainland China's Olympic Committee Chairman and Director of the State Administration of Physical Culture and Sports Yuan Weimin to exchange views on the issue under current government regulations if the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee would invite Yuan to visit Taiwan before August.
Meanwhile, reports from Beijing said mainland China's sports officials welcome Taiwan's willingness to support Beijing's Olympiad bid without any conditions.

As for whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can co-host the event or form a joint team to take part in future Olympic Games, the mainland officials said it is premature to talk about those issues as it remains uncertain whether Beijing can win its bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS ON PARTY ELDER STATESMEN

TEXT.P: Newly-elected Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan called on several KMT elder statesmen on Friday in a bid to reinforce his leadership with the endorsements of the prominent former party officials.
