Lien had on Thursday met with former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who was also the nation's president. Lien was Lee's political protege and served under him as the nation's vice president.
Lien on Friday called on former Vice President Hsieh Tung-min, former Economics Minister Lee Kuo-ting, former KMT Vice Chairman Chiu Chuang-huan and former Premier Sun Yun-hsuan.

In the meeting with Chiu, Lien declined to answer questions about the possibility of cooperating with former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, who was expelled by the KMT for running against Lien in the presidential race earlier this year.
He called on Sun in the evening and apologized to the former premier for his loss in the presidential election.
Sun interrupted Lien's apology, and encouraged him to give badly-needed strong leadership to the KMT, and to guide the party to a recovery.
They also talked about Sun's recent trip to his ancestral homeland in northeastern China.
Recalling that his mother came from Shenyang in northeastern China, Lien said that he hopes that he will be able to visit his mother's native land someday.
In all of the meetings, Lien expressed thanks for the party elders' contributions to the KMT, and also consulted their views on party reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS MACEDONIAN PRIME MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, June 23 (CNA) (By Lu Yi-ching and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao met with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski on Friday. The two agreed to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries.

Georgievski told reporters following their 20-minute meeting that he is highly supportive of increased exchanges of ranking government officials to boost two-way activities in all fields, and also voiced the hope that bilateral economic cooperation ventures will be carried out as projected.

As to the question of whether the ROC foreign minister would be able to call on Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski as hoped for, Georgievski declined to comment, saying that he has no knowledge about the matter.
Tien, accompanied by ROC envoy to Macedonia Peter Cheng, paid the visit to Georgievski after touring the National Martyr's Shrine of this Balkan state.
Georgievski also said that he does not know when Cheng will be able to submit his credentials to Trajkovski, and Tien was also reserved in his comments on the matter.

Taipei and Skopje set up formal diplomatic ties in January 1999, making Macedonia the Republic of China's second diplomatic stronghold in Europe, in addition to the Vatican. But Cheng has not been able to present his credentials to the Macedonian president because of internal political struggles in this former-Yugoslavian country.
Tien arrived in Skopje on Wednesday for a three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: G8 MINISTERIAL MEETING NOT TO TOUCH ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 23 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The ministerial-level meeting of the Group of Eight (G8) powerful nations slated for mid-July will not touch on issues regarding the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the English-language Japan Times reported on Friday.

Quoting Japanese government officials, the newspaper said the upcoming meeting of foreign ministers of the world's seven major industrial powers as well as Russia will not involve discussion of cross-strait issues in order to maintain the relatively placid atmosphere between the two sides that exists at present.

The officials were cited as saying that the G8 member states originally thought that they might have to discuss the cross-strait crisis along with other major regional issues in the ministerial meeting slated for July 12-13, which will pave the way for a G8 summit in Okinawa scheduled for July 21 to 23.

But as both Taiwan and mainland China have exercised restraint, their bilateral relations appear to be moving toward peace, an official with the Japanese Foreign Ministry reportedly said. The official reportedly stressed that member nations of the G8 Group will continue to closely monitor developments in cross-strait relations.
Cross-strait relations have been in limbo since Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party was elected as Taiwan's new president on March 18.

Taipei has called on the G8 Group to include a statement in their summit declaring that Beijing should forswear military threats against Taiwan, while mainland China has repeatedly warned the eight member countries not to meddle in its "internal affairs," the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH HEAD OF WORLD VISION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Friday met with World Vision President Dean Hirsch and lauded the organization's contributions to needy people around the world.
Chen also noted that his recent remarks on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations were a display of Taiwan's good will and sincerity toward mainland China.
Similar to World Vision's aim of promoting world peace, he said that his government's top priority is to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait and in the Asia-Pacific region.
The president expressed his appreciation for World Vision's assistance to the people of Taiwan, especially the victims of last September's devastating earthquake.

Hirsch told Chen that Taiwan is a very important member of World Vision because many countries have received assistance from the people of Taiwan, such as Ethiopia, Honduras, Mongolia, Romania and Algeria.
He pointed out that the generous contributions by the people of Taiwan have been acknowledged by the international community.
Hirsch was visiting Taipei at the invitation of World Vision-Taiwan to attend an international exhibition of paintings by young aid recipients and to present awards to the children.
He called on Chen at the Presidential Office, accompanied by World Vision-Taiwan President Chao Ching-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA: BRITISH COUNCIL'S LANGUAGE CENTER IS SUBJECT TO TAIWAN'S RULES

TEXT.P: The language training center operated by the British representative office in Taipei is not a diplomatic agency and should be subject to domestic rules regarding taxes and education, said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Friday.

In response to appeals from the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei that its language training center should be exempted from local rules on language schools and travel agencies, the ministry said that a language training unit is not a necessary part of a diplomatic mission, and therefore is not exempt from domestic rules.

MOFA officials said that with all due respect to BTCO's diplomatic privileges, language training center is not covered by diplomatic immunity, and any foreign embassies or representative offices should follow Taiwan's rules in operating teaching facilities.

The ministry also said that it formerly had no knowledge of BTCO's language training center; and after learning about it, asked BTCO to stop recruiting new students for the school and cease organizing trips for Taiwan students to schools in Britain.
Local English language training schools, or English cram schools, have complained that the BTCO offers its English training program to local students without a license.
The BTCO had argued in its defense that as a diplomatic organization, local rules didn't apply to its language training center.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS EXPRESS CONCERN ABOUT SHARP FALL OF BANANA PRICES

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on Friday offered to buy 60,000 kilograms of Taiwan-produced bananas to distribute to legislators in an effort to prop up the fruit's domestic price, which has dropped sharply as a result of oversupply.

The drastic fall in the price of Taiwan-produced bananas has caused many legislators to express concern. Some lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday asked the new administration to strictly control banana production in the future in order to prevent the situation from recurring.

DPP Legislator He Chia-jung said at a press conference on Friday at the Legislative Yuan that agricultural authorities should encourage the public to eat more bananas as well as buy them at guaranteed minimum prices, and process the fruit to reduce domestic banana growers' losses.

Lee Chien-chuan, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said banana prices have rallied gradually, adding that because the Farmers Association in Taiwan Province and the Farmers Association in Taipei City have offered to buy a total of 900,000 cartons of bananas, the situation is expected to improve soon.

Since Japan raised tariffs on Taiwan bananas from May this year, Taiwan-produced bananas have met with fierce competition from cheaper bananas from the Philippines. Taiwan's banana industry has also been hit by raised standards for imported fruits in Japan, which have caused customs authorities there to reject a large amount of the product.

After being returned from Japan, the rejected bananas have only aggravated the domestic glut, resulting in a sharp fall of wholesale and retail prices in domestic markets, with the wholesale price dropping to NT$0.5 per kg at its lowest.

DOC.HEADLINE: AQUARIUMS IN TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE SIGN EXCHANGE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Underwater World Singapore (UWS), a local aquarium, entered into a fish exchange program with Taiwan's DL Educational Oceanarium (DLEO) in a ceremony on Friday.

Under the agreement, UWS will give one sawfish to DL in exchange for a number of sunfish. The sawfish will arrive in Taiwan on June 25, and the sunfish will be transported to Singapore early next year.

Ouyang Jui-hsiung, head of the Taiwan Representative Office in Singapore, witnessed the signing of the agreement. Also present at the ceremony were representatives of DLEO and journalists from Taiwan and Singapore.
UWS officials said that the agreement represents the first of what they hope are many exchanges with aquariums around the world.
Found in fresh or weak saline waters in river basins around Australia, Indonesia, and New Guinea, the sawfish is a type of ray that resembles a shark and can grow up to seven meters long.

The sunfish can grow up to two meters long, and is found in tropical and temperate waters worldwide. Considered to be one of the most fertile species, a single female can lay more than 300 million eggs at a time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS MOURN DEATH OF MRS. CHANG HSUEH-LIANG

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and other Taiwan political leaders on Friday sent their condolences to Chang Hsueh-liang to express their grieves over the death of his wife, Chao Yi-ti.

Chao had been troubled by lung disease since she suffered from lung cancer years ago. She was admitted into Honolulu's Straub Hospital because of her deteriorating condition about 10 days ago, and died of pneumonia at the hospital on Thursday (local time) at the age of 88.
Chang, who had celebrated his centennial birthday at his Honolulu home early this month, flew back to Honolulu from Los Angeles on June 19 after learning of his wife's critical condition.

Chang engineered the Sian Incident of December 1936, in which he detained then Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and later freed and escorted him to Nanjing after a series of behind-the-scenes negotiations.
He had been under virtual house arrest until he was allowed to leave Taiwan for Hawaii in the early 1990s.

Upon learning of Chao's death, Wang Lo-sheng, director of the ROC Foreign Ministry's representative office in Honolulu, visited Chang's family to extend condolences on behalf of the ROC government. He also offered to provide necessary assistance.

Other Taiwan leaders also sent messages of condolence to Chang, including Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang Fei, Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE MILITARY GAINING ON TAIWAN: US REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese military superiority over Taiwan is expected to widen in the next two decades, said a report released by the US Department of Defense on Friday.

The Pentagon report to the US Congress said disrupting or reversing the trend depends very much on whether or not Taiwan can acquire advanced equipment and weaponry, as well as its ability to integrate its existing weapons systems and improve the quality of its personnel training.
Beijing's submarines are a major threat to Taiwan, which the island should counter by upgrading its anti-submarine technology, the report suggested.
However, Taiwan's navy could hardly break a mainland maritime blockade with the resources currently at its disposal, the report said.
Without the intervention of a third party, Taiwan's aged fleet of World War II vessels wouldn't stand a chance against Beijing's superior navy both on and under the sea, said the Pentagon report.
The Pentagon predicted that Taiwan will be able to hold its own in a possible war with Beijing for the next five years, given Beijing's limitations in integrating its newly-acquired weaponry.

Noting that air superiority is vital to any military attack against Taiwan, the report said Beijing's current numerical superiority in aircraft will continue to be balanced by the superior technology of Taiwan's jet fighters at least until 2005.

In order to stymie a military attack by mainland China, Taiwan should maintain a superior military by continuously acquiring modern weaponry, technology and equipment, and effectively integrating these systems and improving the quality of its personnel, the report suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Pentagon report says the United States is mulling whether to sell Taiwan state-of-the-art weapons.
The China Times:
Pentagon says mainland China will acquire military supremacy by 2010.
The United Daily News:
The Investigation Bureau will give more emphasis on criminal investigation, with anti-espionage work as second priority.
The Liberty Times:
The Cabinet has reached consensus on revisions to the Election and Recall Law to prevent convicted criminal ring members from running in elections until 10 years after ending their jail terms.
The China Post:
Premier Tang says two-day weekends is only a matter of time.
The Taiwan News:
US troops to stay in South Korea, says Albright.
The Taipei Times:
KMT wants to supervise President Chen Shui-bian's task force on cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 24, or the 23rd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1314: Led by Robert the Bruce, the Scots defeat the English army at the Battle of Bannockburn.
1340: The British fleet destroys the French at Sluys in the Hundred Years' War.
1497: John Cabot, originally Giovanni Caboto, an Italian-born navigator and explorer in the service of the English crown, discovers the North American mainland just 35 days after leaving Bristol in his ship, the Matthew.
1812: Napoleon Bonaparte, leading his Grand Armee, begins his invasion of Russia.
1821: Simon Bolivar, known as "the Liberator," leads 8,000 South American patriots to victory against 4,000 Spanish Royalists at the Battle of Carabobo in Venezuela, virtually freeing Venezuela from Spanish control.
1940: Japan formally asks Britain to close the Burma Road.
1948: The Berlin airlift begins as the Allies delivery food and essential supplies by air to Berliners after the Soviets blockade the city.
1953: Jacqueline Bouvier announces her engagement to Senator John F. Kennedy.
1964: Fu Jen Catholic University, founded in Beijing in 1926 and taken over by the Chinese communists in 1950 after the ROC government moved to Taiwan, is reopened in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
1973: Eamon de Valera resigns as president of Ireland at the age of 90.
1974: Robert E. Page, and Frank W. Beatty, vice presidents of United Press International, arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the banking law.
1975: The China External Trade Development Council and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, sign an agreement to promote trade and other economic relations.
1976: A 1,000,000-ton dry dock at Kaohsiung shipyard is christened.
1976: The Executive Yuan appoints Fan Kwei-shu as political vice minister of the Ministry of Justice and Chen Min-ching as commissioner of the Department of Reconstruction, Taiwan Province.
1978: Lieutenant-Colonel Ahmed Hussein al-Ghashni, president of the Yemen Arab Republic, is killed by a bomb carried by a South Yemen special envoy, who also dies in the explosion.
1981: The opening ceremony of the 30th Council Meeting of the Asian Pacific Parliamentarians' Union is held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
1983: President Assad of Syria orders Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to leave Damascus.
1983: Sally Ride becomes the first American woman in space when she blasts off in Challenger with four male astronauts.
1987: Kim Dae-jung and 300 other dissidents are released after two weeks of unrest in South Korea.
1989: Zhao Ziyang, who expressed sympathy with pro-democracy students in mainland China, is replaced by Jiang Zemin as general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party.
1993: A Xiamen Airlines passenger plane is hijacked and diverted to Taiwan by Chang Wenlung, a mainland Chinese youth.
1994: Russia and the European Union sign a friendship accord in Corfu, Greece, designed to help stabilize Russia and bring it closer to its former rivals.
1998: The UNSC agrees to maintain sanctions against Iraq for 60 more days.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government there are five good principles to be kept in mind and respected. First, to benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country; secondly, to encourage labor without giving cause for complaint; thirdly, to desire for the enjoyments of life without being covetous; fourthly, to be dignified without being supercilious; fifthly, to inspire awe without being severe."

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORIAL ON ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN RECEIVES ATTENTION

TEXT.P: US Rep. Bob Barr (R-Ga.) on Tuesday submitted for the congressional record a newspaper editorial that called on Congress to press the administration to provide Taiwan with the defensive weapons it requires to deter a Communist Chinese invasion.

The editorial, published in the Augusta Chronicle on June 12, said the Clinton administration did "next to nothing" after the story broke in the Taiwan press on May 25 that the Chinese military started live-fire artillery exercises for six days near the closest outpost of the Republic of China, which recently inaugurated a new president.

That same week, an unnamed top Clinton official with the National Security Council even said it was a mistake for the United States to issue a visa to former president Lee Teng-hui so he could attend a reunion at his US alma mater, according to the newspaper report.
"Just before that insulting declaration, the Clinton administration decided against selling four Aegis destroyers to Taiwan," said the report.

According to a recent classified Pentagon report leaked to The Washington Post, Taiwan is far more vulnerable to invasion from the Communist regime than was previously known. The level of Taiwan's military technology has fallen behind Beijing's, particularly in the area of defending against air and missile attacks.

Since the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian and his appointment of a hardline anti-Communist from the previous ruling party as defense minister, the editorial continued, the mainland Chinese military has been saber rattling even more frequently. Yet President Bill Clinton is still reluctant to sell military equipment to Taiwan.

This reluctance and the administration's pro-Beijing slant "is thankfully drawing the attention of Congress, which is naturally concerned that the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act is being ignored. That legislation requires that all arms-sale decisions must be based solely on Taiwan's defense needs," said the paper.

In light of the Pentagon report and current mainland Chinese military provocations, the editorial added, those needs have never been greater. A bipartisan block in Congress has drawn up new legislation, the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act. Among other things, this legislation would order the executive branch to explain whenever it rejects, postpones, or changes a military request from Taiwan.

The editorial emphasized that "this bill was introduced because key lawmakers of both parties value the island as a loyal ally and key trading partner. Taiwan deserves entry into the World Trade Organization, as does China, especially since Taiwan is free, open, and democratic."

"How can Americans who live in a country that is a self-proclaimed leader of free world ever abandon a free country to dictatorship? At the very least, the people's representatives in the legislative branch of our government can hold the executive branch to account when it comes to defensive armaments in Taiwan," concluded the editorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE CANADIAN STUDENTS WIN TOP SCIENCE AWARD

TEXT.P: Two Canadians of Chinese origin have won one of the biggest high school student science competitions in the world.
Andrew Lam and Jamy Li of Don Mills Collegiate Institute in Toronto won the senior category at the Toshib/NSTA Explora Vision Awards with their "flower power" entry.
The two high school students studied photosynthesis to come up with an artificial means of harnessing that process to create energy.
Their project beat out 13,000 other entries at the event, which was organized in part by the National Science Teachers Association in the United States.
For their efforts, they each received a savings bond worth US$10,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD RESPOND TO TAIWAN'S OLIVE BRANCH: DAILY

TEXT.P: As Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian has already offered quite a few olive branches to Communist China, the next move "can only come from mainland China," a major Canadian newspaper said Wednesday.

An editorial published by the National Post pointed out that one week after the historic meeting between the leaders of South and North Korea, Chen proposed a similar summit between his country and China.
Beijing, however, wasted no time in snubbing Taiwan and repeating its demand that Chen unambiguously accept that Taiwan is an inseparable part of China, noted the editorial.

It pointed out that Chen has held out an olive branch to the Communists on several occasions, calling for open trade ties and other direct links with the mainland. He has also said Taiwan might support Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympics and even to co-host some sporting events.

"Yet Beijing continues to insist that Taiwan must first submit to the mainland's terms. What the Communists fail to understand is that the Taiwanese are prepared to accept a prolonged stalemate, and even isolation, if the only alternative means they must give up their hard-won political and economic freedoms to appease Beijing," said the editorial.
It noted that Taipei already governs itself independently -- without ever having had to declare its independence -- and is both prosperous and democratic.
Beijing "should accept President Chen's invitation and talk with Taiwan," it concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAGES FOR DISABLED WORKERS FALL BELOW OFFICIALLY-SANCTIONED LEVEL

TEXT.P: One-third of local physically or mentally disabled workers fail to earn the government-sanctioned minimum monthly wage, according to a long-term study of 204 handicapped people's career lives released on Saturday.

Chen Ching-chiang, an associate professor at National Kaohsiung Normal University, unveiled the study result at a seminar on promotion of job openings for the disabled amid calls by some industry and business executives for cancellation of current government requirement of minimum wage at NT$14,000 (US$454.55) per month on grounds that local workers' monthly pays have far exceeded the minimum level.
In fact, Chen said, wages for many handicapped workers still fall below the officially-sanctioned level.
According to her long-term track of the career records of 204 selected disabled workers, 33.4 percent of them failed to earn NT$14,000 a month.
The study also shows that monthly earnings of another 33.3 percent range between NT$14,000 and NT$18,000; and 22.5 percent of those studied have been unable to secure stable income.
According to Chiang's study, the top three jobs for the disabled are factory assembly line work (25 percent), cleaning work (23.1 percent) and convenience store work (13.5 percent).
The study found that nearly all of those who suffer medium- or severe-grade physical or mental disabilities have taken either "non-skilled or semi-skilled" jobs.

Major reasons cited by those surveyed for their departure from their jobs were a lack of interest in their work (30.8 percent), factory closures, removal or layoffs (18.8 percent), and emotional or spiritual problems (10.9 percent.)

Speaking on the same occasion, Hsu Hsiang-liang, a special education professor at National Changhua Normal University, said his study shows that a quarter of disabled people cannot land jobs even after they have received vocational training.

According to Hsu's research, all government-run vocational training centers for the disabled have many "return" students who already completed training courses but still failed to secure suitable jobs. Some of them said they have chosen to return to the training centers simply because government subsidies for trainees are even higher than what they could earn on the job market.

Hsu also singled out several defects in the government's current vocational training programs for the handicapped, including failure to accurately evaluate each student's vocational potential; gaps between existing vocational skill training programs and demands of local industries; limited capacity of nearly all vocational training centers; inadequate training facilities; shortages of competent training instructors; and incompleteness of training courses.

After listening to the scholars' suggestions, Kuo Chi-jen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, said the council will first improve cultivation of qualified instructors, prepare science- and technology-oriented training courses, and set up more special factories for the seriously disabled as the initial steps to improve the employment climate for the handicapped.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PUSH FOR EXPANSION OF OFFSHORE TRANSSHIPMENT CENTER

TEXT.P: Before the opening of direct transport between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Republic of China government will push for the expansion of the existing offshore transshipment center, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said.
Minister Yeh Chu-lan is expected to put the idea forward when she reports to Premier Tang Fei next week on the ministry's operations.

In May 1995, the government announced the regulations regarding the offshore transshipment center. According to the rules, foreign ships or foreign-registered Taiwanese ships are allowed to ship cargoes from or to a third country between appointed ports in Taiwan and mainland China under the condition that the goods not pass through Taiwan customs or enter Taiwan's territory.

The port appointed by Taiwan was Kaohsiung, while the mainland appointed Xiamen and Fuzhou for offshore transshipment purposes. Cargo shipped in this manner has increased every year, with the total amount of cargo shipped reaching 360,000 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) last year and expected to reach 500,000 TEUs this year.
The ministry said that before the opening of cross-strait direct transport, the offshore transport center will expand to other export processing zones and to sea-air transport networks.

The ministry is mulling over whether to open the ports of Keelung and Taichung for such a purpose and to request that the mainland open the ports of Guangzhou, Talian, Shanghai, Qingdao, and Tianjin as well.

The ministry will stress that direct cross-strait transport will only be possible after national security has been safeguarded as the problems related to direct cross-strait transport will involve quarantine and customs clearance and will have to wait to be solved through consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER CLARIFIES `MONEY DIPLOMACY'
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, June 23 (CNA) (By Lu Yi-ching and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China, as a developed nation, has the responsibility of contributing to the international community by providing loans or technical assistance to other less fortunate countries, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Friday.

Tien, who arrived in Skopje on Wednesday for a three-day visit, made the remarks while answering questions on the so-called "money diplomacy" and issues related to bilateral ROC-Macedonia ties during an interview with the British Broadcasting Company.

Dismissing the term "money diplomacy" as being created by a "certain country" seeking to smash the ROC's efforts at building formal diplomatic links with other countries, Tien said it is very normal that the ROC, as a developed country, extends its concern to the international community.
Although the ROC's financial and technical assistance is delivered mainly to countries with which it has formal diplomatic ties, Tien said the ROC's foreign assistance policy is quite transparent.

Turning to the purpose of his current visit to Macedonia, Tien said his trip to this Balkan state is aimed at explaining the continuity of the new ROC government's foreign policy to the Macedonian government.

As Macedonia is the first foreign country which he has visited since the May 20 inauguration of the new ROC government, Tien said it is a clear indication that the present administration of President Chen Shui-bian views its ties with Macedonia as very important.

Brushing aside widespread rumors that diplomatic relations between the two countries are "at stake," Tien claimed that there is no such "crisis" in their bilateral ties because both the ROC and Macedonia are free and democratic countries which share the same values and aspirations for democracy and human rights.
Tien went on to say that he hopes his current visit to Macedonia will help clarify the groundless speculation regarding the relationship between the two countries.
The ROC and Macedonia set up formal diplomatic ties in January 1999, making this former-Yugoslavia republic Taipei's second diplomatic stronghold in Europe after Vatican.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERCURY-LACED SLUDGE SENT BACK TO FPG'S PLANT

TEXT.P: The mercury-contaminated industrial waste created by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) and initially sent to Cambodia in 1998 has been shipped back to company's plant in an overnight operation that lasted for nearly 10 hours.

Kaohsiung Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien carefully sealed the sludge, which was put into 325 containers at a pier in Kaohsiung Harbor prior to the transshipment operation on Friday night. The containers were then put in container trailers for shipment to the FPG's plant in Jenwu, Kaohsiung. The FPG mobilized 60 trailers for the operation.
The last of the sludge containers arrived at Jenwu at about 5:20 a.m. on Saturday to the great relief of the government and local environmental officials who were monitoring the whole process.
Environmental officials from Kaohsiung County are now commissioning experts to review the FPG's plan to burn the toxic waste under a trial basis.

The FPG has imported a vacuum heat processor from the United States and will assemble it by July 3. When its "burn-on-trial-basis" plan passes, it will begin burning the sludge on a trial basis. If the results of the trial are approved by government experts, the FPG will then begin to handle all the sludge.

The sludge, produced by the Jenwu plant, was first shipped to the southern coastal town of Sihanoukville, Cambodia in late 1998, causing panic among the local people and great deal concern among environmentalists.

The outcry forced the FPG to later apologize to Cambodia and ship the industrial toxic waste back to Kaohsiung Harbor in April, 1999. The sludge was allowed to be stored at the Kaohsiung pier on the condition that it would later be shipped to a third destination.
But as the FPG's consultations with other nations concerning storage of the sludge were unsuccessful, the FPG applied to send the waste back to the original plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONCERNED ABOUT PENTAGON REPORT: MND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is very concerned about a US Pentagon report on Beijing's military power and strategy released on Friday, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Saturday.
The MND, however, refrained from making any comments on the latest Pentagon assessment on mainland China's military build-up required by the US Congress.
"The ROC is not in a position to comment on the report because it is the US government's internal evaluation," said an MND official who preferred anonymity.
The official further said the MND attaches great importance to the Pentagon report and will carefully study it after obtaining a full original copy.

"We'll then re-evaluate and forecast the possible development in the Taiwan Strait and adjust our defense policy as well as military build-up and deployment plans to cope with the new situation," the official said.

According to the Pentagon report, the mainland Chinese military is increasing the number of short-range missiles aimed at Taiwan as it focuses military preparations on a possible clash with Taiwan involving the United States.

The report neither predicts a mainland attempt to win control of Taiwan by force nor dismisses the possibility. But it says mainland China's army is buying the kinds of weapons that could be used in a pre-emptive strike. These include cruise missiles and ballistic missiles of longer ranges and greater accuracy.
"The warning time for missile launches most likely will decrease as (mainland) China expands its missile force opposite Taiwan," the Pentagon report said.

The report further says mainland China is strengthening its military on a broad front but, despite having a far larger armed force, would still face "significant shortcomings" in a conflict with Taiwan, even a decade from now.

Over the coming five years, the report says, the 2.4 million-strong mainland Chinese army will have "only a limited capability" to conduct offensive operations against Taiwan in a way that effectively combines air, sea and land forces, adding that mainland China's naval, air and ground troops are not fully integrated into a cohesive combat force.

In the longer term -- in the 2010-to-2020 period, the report says, mainland China could gain a greater edge over Taiwan in both the quality and quantity of its military forces. At that point, the report notes, Taiwan's success in deterring Beijing's aggression will depend on its ability to acquire and operate modern arms and technology.

Commenting on the Pentagon report, a senior military officer, who demanded anonymity, said the ROC has long singled out 2005 as a critical period for military balance between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"We have long planned to realize the goal of building up a new-generation, high-tech defense force, completing sweeping military organizational and administrative reforms and cultivating competent military personnel before 2005," the officer said.
He pointed out that Premier Tang Fei, a four-star-general-turned-politician, already drafted a forward-looking military development plan during his stint as defense minister.

"The plan was based on the prediction that if mainland China maintains its current pace in military build-up while Taiwan drags its foot on military modernization and defense technology development, then mainland China would gradually win supremacy in the Taiwan Strait from 2005," the officer noted.

In an interview with CNA during his stint as defense minister, Tang said cross-strait military balance is a dynamic development. If Taiwan fails to upgrade defense capabilities, overhaul military structure and step up personnel training, Tang warned, mainland China would gain military supremacy even before 2005.

Tang also stressed the importance of military "software" upgrading, namely upgrading troop training and overall defense system and mechanism. "For instance, establishing an efficient command, control, communications , intelligence, surveillance and search mechanism is far more important than acquiring advanced hardware," he noted.
He further said Taiwan must seek continued progress in defense capabilities in order to maintain military balance in the Taiwan Strait and to ensure parity in cross-strait exchanges and negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN SHOULD MAINTAIN STRATEGIC STATUS IN CROSS-STRAIT INTERACTION

TEXT.P: The frontline island of Kinmen should take advantage of the planned opening of direct "mini three links" to establish an environment conducive to its sustainable development, a senior economic planning official said on Saturday.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the call at a seminar on Kinmen's capability to cope with the planned opening of direct "mini three links" between Kinmen and mainland China's southeastern coastal cities.

Ho led a delegation of officials from the CEPD, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and other relevant government agencies to this frontline island early in the morning to meet with Kinmen County government officials and elected representatives on the island's development prospects.

Ho said the planned opening of direct "mini three links" on an experimental basis in line with the newly passed Offshore Islands Development Act is mainly aimed at offering more development opportunities for Taiwan's outlying islands, such as Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu. Both Kinmen and Matsu are Taiwan's defense outposts and lie closer to southeastern mainland coast than Taiwan.

Ho pointed out that the Kinmen County Government should not regard the planned opening of direct "mini three links" between the island and mainland China's coastal cities as an ultimate policy goal, but should rather treat it as one of the strategies to help boost the island's overall development and to maintain its strategic status in cross-strait interaction.

Ho said the new ROC government will honor its promise to complete a comprehensive evaluation of the feasibility of opening direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China's coastal cities, commonly known as "mini three links," within three months and to finalize a blueprint for implementing the new "open doors" policy in another three months.
In the process, Ho said, the Cabinet's inter-ministerial planning task force will maintain close contact with Kinmen authorities to ensure that its proposals meet local demands.
Ho suggested that the Kinmen County Government prepare a priority list of software and hardware construction projects needed for implementing the "mini three links" policy.

According to a list drafted by the Kinmen County Government, a number of infrastructure construction projects must be launched in preparation for the opening of direct "mini three links" with the mainland.

Those projects include improving Kinmen's airport facilities, expanding existing ports, building a new commercial port, adjusting the island's urban development plan, easing restrictions on construction in some military regions, expanding power generation capacity, building new oil storage tanks, establishing firefighting, medical service, anti-crime, as well as fauna and flora quarantine and inspection systems.

Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai said the county government will form a special task force, composed of officials, scholars and industry executives, to work out a detailed list of needed infrastructure construction projects. "We will come up with a comprehensive report on various development projects in one-and-a-half months," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFI MISSION VISITS MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A 36-member delegation of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) will leave for mainland China on Sunday for an eight-day visit.
The trade-promotion mission, led by CNFI Chairman K. C. Lin, will first travel to Beijing via Hong Kong, and then proceed to Shanghai and Wuxi.
In addition to visiting ranking mainland Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs, Lin said the delegation members will also hold investment seminars with mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen.

Lin stressed that they will not touch on political issues while meeting relevant mainland Chinese authorities, but added that talks on the establishment of the long-awaited direct trade, transport, and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China will be unavoidable.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC CHAIRWOMAN ASKS FOR FORGIVENESS FROM OVERSEAS CHINESE
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 23 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Vice Chairman J. C. Chen, along with a legislative delegation led by Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, flew into San Francisco on Friday for a visit to local Chinese communities.

Speaking upon arrival at the airport, Chen said he had brought a letter from OCAC chairwoman Chang Fu-mei and would deliver it to the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association in San Francisco, inviting local Chinese community leaders to visit Taiwan and asking for their forgiveness for some remarks made by Chang early last month.

Chang, the new OCAC chairwoman in the Democratic Progressive Party-led government inaugurated on May 20, said in early May that traditional overseas Chinese communities rank third on her list when she works out plans for offering assistance to Chinese people living abroad.

Chang's comments stirred up strong protests and grave concerns among century-old Chinese communities in San Francisco over the new ROC government's approach to cross-Taiwan Strait issues. In a protest against Chang's remarks, the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association recently turned down the OCAC's invitation to visit Taiwan.

Chen, who is scheduled to meet with local Chinese community leaders on Saturday, said he will personally deliver Chang's letter to those representatives and expressed his hope that all misunderstandings would be cleared up.

While condemning the OCAC chairwoman's "inappropriate" and "misguided" remarks that classified overseas Chinese people into various categories, Yao said that Chang should be forgiven now that she has apologized for the improper comments.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FM SAYS MACEDONIA BACKS TAIPEI EFFORTS TO JOIN WORLD BODIES
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, June 24 (CNA) (By Lu Yi-ching and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Macedonia is a very important diplomatic partner of the Republic of China, and Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski backs Taipei's efforts to join world bodies, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said here on Saturday.
Georgievski's support for the ROC to take part in international organizations will have a far-reaching impact on bilateral ties between Taipei and Skopje, Tien said.

Stressing that his current visit to Macedonia is not just a superficial trip, Tien said the ROC's formal diplomatic relationship with Macedonia carries a great deal of strategic importance that will help the ROC explore its relations with other countries in the Balkans.
The ROC government will therefore undoubtedly do its best to protect its ties with Macedonia and become familiar with the major political figures in the country, Tien commented.

Tien said he has met with all the pro-ROC Macedonian officials during this trip and has discussed issues of mutual concern with them. He said he hopes that his talks with these Macedonian officials will help them understand the benefits of maintaining diplomatic links with the ROC.

The foreign minister, however, did not disclose whether he had been able to meet Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski, saying only that he had met with those whom he had wished to meet. He also failed to confirm media reports on whether he had been able to deliver a letter from President Chen Shui-bian to his Macedonian counterpart.
ROC envoy Peter Cheng has so far not been able to submit his credentials to Trajkovski due to an internal political struggle that reportedly continues in the Balkan state.
Tien arrived in Skopje on Wednesday for a three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 25, or the 24th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th US state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Company turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia in World War II, last viceroy of India, then commander-in-chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende and other minerals, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration.
1942: Major General Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of US forces in Europe, and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the UN Charter. The ROC, the US, the USSR, France and Britain are made members of the UN Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1974: Dr. Wang Ching-mow takes over as director-general of the National Health Administration.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second-place victory.
1975: Mozambique becomes independent, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos, and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as US secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news-gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua-lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS VATICAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and his wife arrived in Rome on Saturday for an official visit to the Vatican.

Branding Tien's visit as one aimed at promoting peace, a statement issued by the ROC Embassy to the Holy See said he will meet with Secretary of State Cardinal Angelo Sodano and Secretary for Relations with States Archbishop Jean-Louis Tauran during his four-day stopover in Rome.
The statement said Tien will exchange views with Vatican leaders on issues of common interest, but didn't mention whether Tien will meet with Pope John Paul II.

The Vatican is the only European state other than the Balkan nation of Macedonia that recognizes Taipei, but bilateral ties have been dogged by persistent reports that the Holy See is flirting with the idea of striking diplomatic relations with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
US TOP LIAISON OFFICIAL WITH ROC LOOKS FORWARD TO WORKING WITH CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 24 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Richard Bush, the highest-ranking US liaison official with the Republic of China, said over the weekend that he looks forward to working with the ROC's new Representative to the US Chen Chien-jen.
Chen, who was approved by the US State Department last week to serve as the new ROC representative to the US, will arrive in Washington D.C. soon to assume his new post.

Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, said on Saturday that he has known the new representative for over two decades, and noted that Chen was first appointed as a third secretary in charge of liaison affairs with the US Congress at the ROC's former Embassy in the US.
Bush added that the new representative had served in the ROC's Washington office for a span of 16 years, establishing wide connections and a good reputation in the US capital.
Bush said that he looks forward to working with Chen to continue strengthening bilateral relations between the US and Taiwan.

He also noted that when he served as the aide of former US Congressman Stephen Solarz 20 years ago, he had become acquainted with new ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, and both are old friends.

Bush made the remarks when he saw off outgoing ROC Representative to the US Stephen Chen and his wife at the airport. More than 100 people bid farewell to Chen, who left here for Europe via New York for tourism before returning to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRY DELEGATION VISITS MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Northern Taiwan, June 25 (CNA) (By Wen-Hung Fang)

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) left Taiwan on Sunday for an eight-day visit to mainland China, where it may meet with mainland President Jiang Zemin, according to CNFI Chairman K.C. Lin.

Lin and his 36-member delegation first flew to Hong Kong, where they will then travel on to Beijing. The ROC trade mission will be greeted by Taiwan Affairs Office Economic Bureau Director He Shizhong upon arrival in the mainland's capital.

Prior to departure, Lin confirmed that his team will visit high-level mainland Chinese officials, including Beijing Mayor Liu Qi, Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin, Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng, and Minister of Science and Technology Zhu Lilan.

Lin said that his delegation will urge mainland authorities to pay greater heed to protecting the lives and property of Taiwan business executives operating in mainland China. He added that the delegation, which is the first group from his organization to visit the mainland in three years, will also survey the mainland's investment environment.

In addition to visiting ranking mainland Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs, Lin said on Saturday that the delegation members will also hold investment seminars with mainland-based Taiwanese business officials.
The delegation members will stay in Beijing for three days and then proceed to Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL STRATEGIC FRAMEWORK SHOULD DICTATE STRAIT ISSUES: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The global strategic framework should dictate how Taiwan Strait issues are considered and resolved, according to Chiou I-Jen, Deputy Secretary General of the ROC National Security Council.
Chiou told industry leaders, officials, and scholars at a local summit on the outlook of cross-strait relations on Sunday that relations between Beijing and Taipei clearly influence the entire world.

Chiou noted that Chien Fu, president of the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body in this country, once declared during his term as foreign minister that "the relations between Taiwan and mainland China should dictate Taiwan's relations with other foreign countries."

However, Chiou went on to say that Taiwan's domestic and diplomatic situations are different now, and that it should turn to the global strategic framework for guidelines to resolve cross-strait issues.
Chiou cited military, foreign affairs, economic, social, and political reasons to back up his claim.
Militarily, Chiou said that Beijing's arms build-up is clearly aimed at the United States, because Beijing's military preparations have surpassed what is required to settle the "Taiwan issue."

Chiou noted that Beijing regards the United States as a strategic target and a major factor in the resolution of the Taiwan issue. He said that this shows Beijing looks at cross-strait issues from the broader perspective of the global strategic framework.

In foreign affairs, Chiou said that Beijing's diplomatic breakthroughs have not been entirely aimed at limiting Taiwan's space in the international community. For example, he said that mainland China's efforts to develop better relations with Russia was meant to counter the strength of the United States -- not Taiwan.

Chiou claimed that Beijing's proactive involvement in the historic summit between the two Korean leaders suggests a different kind of strategic thinking from the past, because unification of the Koreas could prompt US forces to withdraw from the Korean Peninsula. He added that US forces may even withdraw from the Ryukyus as well, decreasing the need for a theater missile defense system in the region.

From the economic and social perspectives, Chiou said that allowing mainland China to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the US government decision to grant permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status to the mainland are both ways to bring Beijing into the international norm.

The possibility of mainland China peacefully embracing democracy can be realized only through its participation in the globalization of trade, which is good for both Beijing and cross-strait relations, Chiou added.

Chiou said that mainland China is inconsistent in its definition of the "one China principle," citing that the mainland stresses the possibility of equality when negotiating with Taiwan, but then insists on one China being the "People's Republic of China" on the international stage. Taiwan cannot begin a new round of negotiations with mainland China until Beijing's definition of "one China" is clear, he said.

Chiou summed up by noting that if cross-strait negotiations cannot rely on "package deals," then a breakthrough must come from a single issue, which he said should be trade. However, he repeated that the breakthrough can only happen when cross-strait issues are considered under the global strategic framework.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG RETURNS FROM US

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the newly-formed People First Party (PFP), said on Sunday that he would not rule out the possibility of meeting with President Chen Shui-bian and leaders of other political parties to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.
Soong made the remarks upon his arrival at CKS International Airport from the United States early Sunday morning.

On Tuesday's proposal by President Chen Shui-bian to invite the leaders of major political parties to the Presidential Office for consultation, Soong said he would meet with President Chen as long as it helps solve the major problems of the nation.
But as the president has had a hectic schedule since his inauguration on May 20, Soong said he is not certain that Chen will have time for such a meeting.

Soong also said that many PFP members used to be members of the Kuomintang (KMT), but left the KMT because past leaders of the centenarian party had turned their backs on the will of the people. If the KMT can utilize new thinking and a new approach, he is not ruling out the possibility of a meeting with KMT Chairman Lien Chan, he added.

Soong was a KMT heavyweight before splitting from the party to run on his own in the March 18 presidential election, which saw the end of the KMT's 50-year rule over Taiwan and the election of the Democratic Progressive Party. Soong finished with 36.8 percent of the vote, second to Chen Shui-bian's tally of 39.3 percent, but far ahead of Lien's 23.1 percent.
Soong and his supporters formed the PFP only after the presidential election.

Soong also criticized the six constitutional reforms that have been implemented over the years, which he said were orchestrated by only a few people. He said that the constitution has to be amended to strengthen the division of political party operations from those of the central government.

The PFP will "stick to its ideals," Soong stressed, adding that the PFP will present the best available candidates in the major legislative elections next year. He said that he has no plans to run in the election himself.

Soong said that because he had been overseas for some time, he will need to learn more about the current domestic situation. "Many things are not my own decision now," he said, adding that he will have to consult with other officials within his party on various issues.

The PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan is planning to invite Soong to attend a caucus meeting on Tuesday. Observers have noted that there are divisions within the party itself over whether Soong should meet with Lien, or cooperate with the KMT in elections.

Soong, who departed for the US on May 18, said the trip was to receive an honorary doctoral degree from the University of Maryland and that he had used the chance to meet with overseas Chinese, US officials and scholars to exchange views on current events in Taiwan and cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP LEGISLATOR WILL LEAVE FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta of the New Party will leave for the mainland on Monday.

Hsieh said that she has long been concerned with the interests of Taiwan businessmen in the mainland, and decided to accept the invitation from Taiwan firms operating in Shenzhen and Tongguan of Guangdong province to attend a meeting there.

Company officials had also asked her to invite other legislators, Hsieh said. She therefore invited Hsu Jung-shu and Chou Ching-yu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, but she is not sure if they will be able to make the trip.
She said that her main concern during the trip will be the interests of Taiwan firms with mainland operations, and that she will stay only around Shenzhen and Tongguan.
Although she has not prepared to meet with high-ranking officials from the mainland, she expects high-ranking officials will attend the meeting, she said.
Meanwhile, a delegation of NP legislators is scheduled to visit the mainland next month to promote a reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Elmer Feng, NP legislative whip, said that the delegation originally planned to visit the mainland in late June, but delayed the trip till July 9 because mainland China needed more time to sort out its response to the goodwill gestures of President Chen Shui-bian in his recent press conference.
Feng said that the delegation had therefore delayed its trip until July 9, and that he will first go to the mainland to hammer out a schedule for the trip.

High-ranking cross-strait exchanges were disrupted after former President Lee Teng-hui's July 1999 statement on "special state-to-state" cross-strait relations. Bilateral relations were further chilled by the March 18 election of President Chen of the pro-Taiwan independence Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY MAYOR ELECTED DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh was elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Sunday.
In a press conference at the DPP headquarters in Taipei, DPP outgoing chairman Lin Yi-hsiung announced Hsieh's victory.
Lin praised Hsieh's performance during career as a public servant, and urged party members to rally behind Hsieh.

Since Hsieh was the only candidate in the race and there is no minimum requirement for votes under the party's "first past the post" election system, his victory was assured before the vote actually took place. Under the party's election rules, the candidate with the most votes wins the election, regardless of the percentage of votes that he or she garners.

As a result, not very many of the party's 143,000 members bothered to show up at the 50 ballot booths around the island. Today's turnout was about 16,000, or 11 percent of the party's 143,000 members. Hsieh garnered 98 percent of Sunday's votes.
Even President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu -- both DPP members -- were absent from the voting, not to mention other prominent party officials.

Hsieh expressed understanding for Chen's absence, noting that Chen has publicly declared that he will not engage in party business, in order to keep his distance from party politics after his victory in the March 18 presidential election.
He took pains to quell speculation that Chen didn't favor his candidacy, saying that Chen's endorsement for his bid is quiet but certain.

Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun is one of the few DPP heavyweights to cast a vote in Taipei on Sunday. He played down the significance of Taipei's turnout of less than 5 percent, saying that Hsieh is the perfect choice for the job. He added that the Kaohsiung mayor's unmatched qualifications for party leadership can partly explain the absence of other contestants in the race and the low turnout in the vote.

Hsieh expressed confidence in his leadership despite the low turnout in the election, saying that he would lead the party behind President Chen's administration. He expressed his hope that the popularity of Chen's administration will rub off on the party in turn, and broaden the DPP's grassroots power base.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PREMIER URGES OPEN THINKING TO RESOLVE STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Sunday said that Taiwan Strait issues should be viewed from an international perspective and that cross-strait relations should be handled through an open approach that does not limit possible developments.

Yu told industry leaders, government officials, and scholars at a local summit on cross-strait relations that Beijing's "zero sum" approach can not win the approval of the public in Taiwan, and the most important factor in the development of cross-strait relations is the support of the people.
Yu said that cross-strait relations should be resolved through new thinking and a practical attitude in the face of the situation facing Taiwan after the inauguration of a new administration.

Yu urged leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to look at cross-strait affairs from an international perspective. He said that the gradual acceptance of the concept of a global village makes it necessary for any country's relations with another country to be developed under an equal and mutually beneficial foundation.

Yu went on to say that freedom, democracy, human rights, peace, and environmental protection are not contained by national boundaries, but rather are universal values. He added that it would be impractical and against global trends if the leaders from both sides of the strait ignore the importance of peace, the development of democracy, the differences in their political systems, and the protection of human rights.

Before the two Germanies were unified, 122 countries recognized both countries, Yu said. The fact that over a hundred countries currently recognize both North and South Korea has not adversely affected the two nations' pursuit of unification, he added, again urging leaders to think and act under the mainstream framework of international politics.

Yu also advocated an open approach to cross-strait relations where the leaders should avoid being trapped by predetermined conditions. The only way to breakthrough the impasse is to adopt an open attitude, he said.

Yu added that from now on, Taiwan will not shun any positive trend in cross-strait relations, will not eschew any manner of bilateral contacts, will not insist on any prerequisites or preconditions to a cross-strait dialogue, and will not limit itself to any single framework.

Yu said that this open approach shows the greatest flexibility in the development of cross-strait relations and leaves the most room for future bilateral interactions. He added that the people of the Republic of China will judge and decide.

Yu said that economic cooperation can open up possibilities for cross-strait relations, and noted that economic exchanges have already yielded fruitful results, despite the fact that many political differences still cannot be resolved on the current stage.

Yu summed up by saying that as long as both sides have the sincerity to work together under a mutually beneficial foundation, they will join the rule-setting World Trade Organization (WTO), and create even more opportunities and interactions to help ease or dilute their political entanglements and confrontations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY'S PUBLIC INTEREST TV AD MAKES DEBUT ON 3 CABLE STATIONS

TEXT.P: The first public interest advertisement shot by the Republic of China's first lady Wu Shu-chen made its debut Sunday on three cable TV stations.
The public inrest ad was sponsored by the ROC Alliance of the Handicapped.

In commemoration of the 10th anniversary of its founding, the alliance held a press conference on Sunday morning to introduce the ad, which was first aired Sunday on the Formosa, SET, and TVBS cable TV stations.
The public-spirited TV ad demonstrated the hardship of handicapped children studying at schools.
In the ad, the first lady stressed that what the handicapped strive for is equal opportunity in various fields of life and society.
Explaining why she decided to shoot the ad for the alliance, the first lady affirmed the alliance's 10 years of contributing to maintaining and advocating the rights of the handicapped.
Additionally, the first lady will attend a dinner party on July 6 to raise funds for the handicapped. She will also preside over a charity sale on the occasion.

At present, there are 670,000 mentally and physically handicapped people in Taiwan, a number that increases by an average of 10,000 every three months. The ROC Alliance of the Handicapped urged the public to have understanding toward the handicapped and allow them to live in an atmosphere of equality.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEW WITH LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT (1)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng talked about the management of legislative affairs in the ROC's parliament, where the Kuomintang (KMT) continues to maintain a majority, in an interview with CNA.

Wang, who was recently appointed as one of the five KMT vice chairmen, also voiced his views on future cooperation between the KMT and the People First Party (PFP), which is headed by former KMT Secretary-General James Soong. The following is the full text of the interview:
Q 1: Congratulations on your election as a KMT vice chairman.

A: I assumed the post thanks to KMT Chairman Lien Chan's support. This also reflects the increase in the KMT Legislative Yuan caucus' influence on party policy-making as more legislators have joined the Central Standing Committee.
Q 2: There is a worry that the newly-formed DPP government will turn out to be a weak government as the KMT maintains a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

A: The DPP has won the presidency, but it controls less than one-third of the seats in the Legislative Yuan, with two-thirds of the seats in the hands of the KMT, the PFP, the New Party and non-partisans. As a result, the power of the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) is weakened.

But the Cabinet will not become weak if it works well with the DPP caucus in the parliament to handle relevant matters soundly because the parliament has established the principle of handling important matters through negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties.

In other words, all bills, procedural matters, and important issues will be decided through negotiations chaired by the Legislative Yuan president before they are submitted to the plenary session for deliberation. Over more than the past year, this method has greatly increased the passage rate of bills.

The only case so far that has indicated that the Cabinet's power is weak and has demonstrated that the DPP is a minority ruling party was the parliament's passage of a KMT-engineered bill on June 16 over an amendment to the Labor Standards Law. This reversed a DPP-led Cabinet bill on cutting the working hours per week for the private sector.

It was not the KMT that had no intention of negotiating with the DPP over the bill, but in fact the Cabinet which seemed to be unaware of the established procedural interaction between the Executive Yuan and Legislative Yuan. It therefore announced beforehand that the Cabinet version would be the final version without negotiating with the opposition or submitting a revision before the plenary session. As a result, the KMT bill was passed with almost no opposition.
Q: What will be the future mechanism for negotiations between the minority ruling government and the majority opposition?

A: The government must coordinate with the DPP's legislative members during the policy-making process and should communicate with the opposition parties to exchange views after bills are sent to the parliament.

The government should act to seek support through negotiations with the opposition. The DPP caucus should also ask the president or vice president of the Legislative Yuan to call for negotiations with the opposition.

Negotiations are the best method for the Cabinet and the minority DPP in the Legislative Yuan because they are participated in by an equal number of representatives from each party, usually two to three. During the negotiations, the views of the minor parties are respected and they can influence the final outcome. This is the most precious merit of the present mechanism of negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEW WITH LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT (2)

TEXT.P: Q: Will deliberations on the government budget be conducted using this formula?

A: When the KMT was the ruling party and had a majority in the Legislative Yuan in the past, it respected the opposition parties. Now the DPP is a minority ruling party and therefore should further respect the opposition and cooperate with it.

In the past, no matter how the committees made cuts in the budget, the Legislative Yuan president would always call a meeting of the caucuses of all the parties to review the whole budget situation before the plenary session, so as to negotiate the amount to be slashed and to decide the items to be affected. That proved to be an effective way to complete deliberations on the budget and also the way that was most advantageous to the ruling party.
Like the past practice, the ruling and opposition parties may conduct negotiations this year to decide the total amount to be cut from the budget proposal.

Then the caucuses of all the parties will conduct further negotiations under the chairmanship of the Legislative Yuan president to decide the details of budget cuts or increases for the various ministries and agencies.
Such a traditional practice of budget deliberations is the most favorable way for the Cabinet. Otherwise, it will be a disastrous situation for various ministries and agencies.

Q: Some fear that under the present situation, the parliament will be influenced by both clean and unclean forces, and there is a move to push for the formation of a supra-party majority alliance in the parliament.
A: Is it possible to push for such a move? President Chen Shui-bian of the DPP knows well that it is impossible. Such a move would only bring about a greater boycott.

So far, the only case that led to some calls for a boycott was the bill on cutting working hours, but even the DPP admitted that it was the government's fault for failing to respect legislative power.

All other matters have been handled smoothly, such as the issue of Premier Tang Fei's health, the postponement of the interpellation session, and the matter of direct cross-Taiwan Strait trade, postal, and communication links. In fact, there is no need to form a so-called majority alliance. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEW WITH LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT (3)

TEXT.P: Q: How do you draw a neutral distinction between being a vice chairman of the Kuomintang and the Legislative Yuan's president?

A: Although I am a vice chairman of the Kuomintang and have taken part in the party's policy-making for some time, the borderline is quite clear: I am the Legislative Yuan's president for the nation and for all its people, not just for the Kuomintang.

As a parliament president, I do not allow my status to be limited to only a KMT leader. In order to get the job done smoothly in the Legislative Yuan, I must play the role of coordinator, because no matter who is in charge of ruling the country, we must operate through coordination between ruling and opposition parties to work toward the direction which best serves and benefits the nation.
Q. Concerning President Chen Shui-bian's promised "3-3-3" welfare project, will there be any changes due to the current political situation in the Legislative Yuan?

A: The contents of the "3-3-3" project still remain to be decided by both the ruling and opposition parties themselves. However, because of the fierce inter-party competition for scarce national finance resources, we should consider whether it is really necessary to carry out the project at all. I believe this is the basic issue that we should discuss now, to find out whether it is necessary or justified.

As for interaction between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan, due to lack of experience on the part of both the Executive Yuan and the Democratic Progressive Party as a new ruling party, as well as the health condition of Premier Tang Fei, I consider this to be a period of adaptation and searching for new approaches.
A few days before, I communicated with Premier Tang. They now know where the problem lies, and I believe they are sparing no efforts to improve themselves.
Q: Under the present national framework and political environment, how would you characterize the interaction between the president and the Legislative Yuan?

A: President Chen has described the present political system as "a dual-leadership system, with control exercised by the president and the premier, but somewhat leaning toward the presidential system." I believe there are still many people in the legislature with different views on the issue.
Under our current system, the premier is named by the president but is under the supervision of the Legislative Yuan. Therefore, the president is also indirectly supervised by the Legislative Yuan.

In addition, the Legislative Yuan may propose to remove the president or vice president from their offices. On the other hand, the president may dissolve the Legislative Yuan under certain conditions. Therefore, the relations between the president and the Legislative Yuan can be described as indirect and mutually supervisory.

The only direct interaction between the two sides is the president's state of the nation report, but whether to listen to the report or not is still the decision of the Legislative Yuan. Recently a member of the Legislative Yuan had considered a proposal to remove the vice president from her office, proving that the legislature is in a stronger position in interacting with the president. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEW WITH LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT (4)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) (By Fang Hsu, Ben Wu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Q: As a vice chairman of the Kuomintang, what do you expect of the party's reforms and future development?

A: The extraordinary session of the KMT's 15th National Congress passed a party reform package, including changes to the KMT's organizational structure and operations as well as measures to improve its image among voters. Therefore, quick action must be taken to deal with the KMT's assets in a transparent, efficient and trustworthy manner. In that way, I believe the party structure will be changed for the better, which will also improve its image in society.

Of course, the most important thing is to understand popular opinion and to maintain contact with the people. The establishment of a think tank, improving methods by which the party conducts public opinion surveys, and the use of more experienced professionals will allow the KMT to best realize and serve the needs of the people, and to enjoy a dominant position in the formulation of public policy.
I have stressed earlier that the KMT should be dominant in policy formulation and should take the initiative in making laws. Otherwise, the KMT's superior numbers in the legislature will be wasted.
Q: How do you assess the possibility of cooperation between the KMT and the newly-formed People First Party (PFP)?
A: Cooperation between the KMT and PFP is quite natural and an inevitable trend for the future, but when will be the right time for cooperation still remains to be seen.

Naturally, this is my personal feeling. But after all, many PFP members used to be members of the KMT, and some level of friendship must still exist. Both the KMT and PFP are opposition parties now, and they must work together in order to survive.
Q: How do you assess the voice of some party members that expect party chairman Lien Chan to run for legislator?
A: I think it would be proper for Lien Chan to run for a seat in the legislature that is reserved for a national constituency.

I don't think it would be proper for Lien to run in regional elections. After all, the party chairman is a former vice president and an important political figure who may run in the next presidential election.
