Therefore, if Lien enters the local elections, it would be far from ideal for him to win by a slim margin. On the other hand, too many votes for him would affect the chances of other KMT candidates in the same constituency.
But developments will depend upon his own wishes and his personal assessments. If he wishes to come to the Legislative Yuan, it is suitable, and I look forward to his success.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN LAUDS TAIWAN'S POLITICAL PROGRESS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: US Representative David Wu (D-Oregon) on Saturday praised Taiwan for its outstanding political transformation and progress over the past few decades.

He reserved his highest praise for the peaceful and smooth power transition after last March's presidential election, saying that the whole process displayed common human values, such as democracy, human rights and the rule of law.

The Taiwan-born Chinese-American congressman made the remarks while delivering a speech at the 12th annual congress of the Federation of Taiwan Business Associations in North America in San Francisco.
He said that he strongly backed the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in Congress and also supports simultaneous entry into the World Trade Organization for Taiwan and mainland China.
On the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Wu expressed the hope that both sides of the strait will be able to make mutual concessions to calmly resolve their differences.

Several Taipei leaders sent cables to the business congress, including Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairperson Chang Fu-mei.
ROC Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi and some ROC officials stationed in Washington and San Francisco were invited to speak at a dinner party following the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALK OF COOPERATION BETWEEN TWO OPPOSITION PARTIES SURFACES AGAIN

TEXT.P: The issue of cooperation between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the newly-formed People First Party (PFP) has again surfaced in Taipei amid the return PFP Chairman James Soong from the United States on Sunday.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng predicted on Sunday that the two parties will join hands in county and city elections next year.

Wang, who is one of five KMT vice chairmen, said in an interview with CNA that the two parties have no choice but to work together because maintaining their division would mean defeat for both of them, as in the March 18 presidential election.

The traditional support base of the KMT was split between KMT candidate Lien Chan and PFP head James Soong in the presidential election. As a result, President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party won the election with 39 percent of the vote, with Lien and Soong splitting a combined tally of almost 60 percent.
Noting that the PFP is a splinter party of the KMT and there are common views among senior officials of both parties, Wang asserted that political reality will force the two parties to collaborate.

Although there are voices among KMT rank-and-file opposed to cooperating with Soong, the interests of the party should take precedence over personal feuds and will leave the KMT with no other option, the KMT official said.
Meanwhile, both KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Soong have played down the prospects of cooperation between their parties.
In a courtesy meeting with KMT elder statesman Chiu Chuan-huan on Friday, Lien was evasive on the question of whether he and Soong could heal the rift between them and work together again.

Soong, a former KMT secretary general, was kicked out by the party because of his bid for president without party approval. Election rhetoric between the two former comrades was even more bitter than their competition with the DPP's Chen, with both Lien and Soong reserving their strongest attacks for each other.

Soong's answer to the same question was more subtle. Speaking with reporters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, where he arrived earlier Sunday morning, the PFP chairman said that the issue is up to the PFP members to decide, and not just himself.
PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi has said the PFP will await developments before deciding whether it will be able to work with the KMT in next year's election.

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a KMT heavyweight, greeted the question cautiously, saying that it is too early to predict that the two parties will be able to unite in any election or present an united front on political issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 26, or the 25th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The US Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the UN founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter became effective on Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to US President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Students leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the ROC.
1992: A peoples court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: US forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton opens a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 155.37 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 155.37 points to close at 8,529.56.
Market turnover amounted to NT$67.94 billion (US$2.21 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Monday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for July plunged 160 points to close at 8,660, with 3,392 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for August decreased 140 points to finish at 8,713, with 59 contract transactions, while September futures moved down 148 points to close at 8,722, with 15 contract transactions.
December futures lost 150 points to finish at 8,810, with 11 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 8,820 for July; 8,853 for August; 8,870 for September; 8,960 for December; and 8,998 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
July TE futures moved down 12.55 points to close at 480.45, with 1,089 contract transactions, while August TE futures lost 12.55 points to finish at 484.65, with 18 contract transactions.
September TE futures decreased 4.1 points to close at 490, with four contract transactions, while next March TE futures moved down 12.55 points to finish at 496.8, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were reported for December TE futures.
July TF futures decreased 7 points to close at 872, with 287 contract transactions, while August TF futures lost 7 points to finish at 876, with 10 contract transactions.
September TF futures edged down 1 point to close at 886, with 24 contract transactions, while December TF futures moved up 8.8 points to finish at 899, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULES ON MAINLAND VISITS NEED TO BE REVIEWED: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Existing regulations governing visits to mainland China by former Republic of China officials who were in charge of affairs related to intelligence or national security need to be reviewed, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chair Tsai Ing-wen on Sunday.
Tsai said there is certainly a "gap" between the regulations and actual execution which has led to irregularities and improper behavior.
She added that the MAC, the highest government agency responsible for formulating mainland China policy and related policies, will work to "seal the gap up."

Tsai made the remarks in response to reports regarding a visit to mainland China by Maj. Gen. Pan Shi-hsien, director of the Personnel Department of National Security Bureau (NSB), who retired recently.
According to the reports, Pan retired from the NSB post on June 1 and went to Guangdong Province in mainland China with his wife on June 4.

His visit apparently violated amended laws promulgated in March governing Taiwanese residents' visits to the mainland and related affairs, said Kuomintang Legislator Chen Jung-sheng, who disclosed Pan's mainland visit at the Legislative session last Tuesday.

According to the newly promulgated laws, retired and former intelligence officials and those who were in charge of affairs related to national security are prohibited from traveling to mainland China in the first three years after their retirement or leave. If there is a precise need for them to go to the mainland during the first three years of retirement, they have to file for formal approval from their former authorities.
The laws also state that once the intelligence or national security official retires, the Bureau of Entry and Exit must be notified of the official's retirement within two weeks.

According to the reports, Pan left Taiwan for Guangdong before the Bureau of Entry and Exit received notification about his retirement from the NSB. Pan was probably allowed to exit the country to Hong Kong in his capacity as an ordinary tourist.
NSB Director Ting Yu-chou said he feels regret over the incident and, as Pan's former boss, urged Pan to return to Taiwan as quickly as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 155.37 points to close at 8,529.56.
Affected by a drop in prices in the United States and the poor performance of electronics shares, the bourse opened at 8,672.8 and fluctuated between 8,675.47 and 8,507.42 during trading.

A total of 1.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.94 billion (US$2.21 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.44 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$75.31 billion.
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.5 percent, construction shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.6 percent, and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 420 to 102, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CALLED ONE OF FASTEST-GROWING ECONOMIES IN OECD

TEXT.P: Australia was among the top six countries within the Organization for Economic Cooperation Development in terms of economic growth in the 1990s, according to Federal Treasurer Peter Costello.
The Sydney Morning Herald on Monday quoted Costello as saying that Australia, the United States, Denmark, Ireland, the Netherlands, and Norway performed much better than other OECD countries.

"The (OECD) report's preliminary findings ... note that while some features of a new economy are evident, old economy relationships remain important in shaping growth everywhere," he told the Sydney Morning Herald.

Costello, who is in Paris to chair the OECD ministerial council meeting, said "identifying the keys to strong growth, the OECD report endorses the priority the Australian government has given to pursuing sound macro-economic policies and a comprehensive structural reform agenda."

He said the OECD noted that countries which improved growth over the 1990s not only pursued sound structural policies, but generally experienced buoyant cyclical conditions, low inflation and improving public budgets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINATRUST WORKING ON BIG MEDIA LINK IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chinatrust Bank is working on a communications deal to form a media giant link in Australia, reported the Australian on Monday.

The daily quoted Jeffrey Koo Jr., president of the Koo Group, the flagship of Chinatrust Bank, as saying that the potential deal covered "everything" from content to distribution with what he described as an Australian "media giant."
The daily reported that Telstra, the government-owned telecommunications giant, is among the most likely Australian partners.
The Koo family's business assets cover banking, cable television, tourism, sports, property, and manufacturing, said the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: QANTAS WINS RIGHT TO FLY OVER TIBETAN PLATEAU

TEXT.P: Australia's flag carrier Qantas Airways has won the right to fly from Asian destinations to Europe via the Tibetan plateau, cutting flight times and saving the company millions of dollars per year, reported the Australian on Monday.

The daily reported the new route will lop 20 to 30 minutes off the flight time between London and Bangkok and is being hailed as a breakthrough because it solves complex safety and technical problems posed by flights over the high and remote Tibetan plateau.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-THIRD OF MANUFACTURERS FEEL GOOD ABOUT PROSPECTS: TIER

TEXT.P: Nearly one-third of Taiwan's manufacturers expect that the economy will take a turn for the better over the next six months, while about half of them believe the economy will remain at the present level, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) reported on Monday.

In its monthly report on the country's business trend in May, the private economics think-tank's latest survey of manufacturers islandwide showed that 32.2 percent of the respondents expect the economy to take a turn for the better and 50 percent expect the economy to at least remain at the present level, while only 17 percent foresee a possible slowdown over the next six months.

The survey found that precision instrument manufacturing, property insurance, and transportation and warehousing experienced better business in May and expect business to continue to boom over the next half year.

Industries whose business remained the same in May but which expect turnover to increase over the next six months include food processing, synthetic fiber, weaving and fabric, garments, basic steel processing, telecommunications materials, import-export trade, retailing, wholesaling, restaurants and travel, and life insurance, the TIER survey found.

However, the TIER researchers said, in a similar survey of local manufacturers conducted in April, 35.4 percent of respondents said they expected the economy to improve, compared with 32.2 percent in May. The number of respondents who think the economy's performance will remain unchanged was 51 percent in April, compared with 50 percent in May.
The number of respondents who feel the economy will take a turn for the worse over the next six months was 17.7 percent in May, while only 13.6 percent in April, according to the TIER.
Meanwhile, TIER researchers said, the Central Bank of China (CBC) is presently under clear pressure from home and abroad to hike interest levels.

Pressed by rising interests rates in international markets and increasingly higher commodity prices at home, the CBC is widely expected to have no choice but to raise interests rates in the months ahead. But the increases are not expected to be too sharp, the researchers estimated.
TIER said neither higher interest rates nor the Taiwan currency's exchange rate would adversely affect the local economy or two-way trade in the months ahead.

What the think-tank said it is really worried about is that the recently-passed shortened workweek and rising domestic oil prices will have an affect on manufacturers' costs and a consequential impact on overall economic growth.

Meanwhile, the researchers noted that the mainland Chinese summit meeting scheduled to be held in Beidaihe in August will probably trigger some changes in cross-strait relations and eventually affect Taiwan's political and economic situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHLIGHTS OF INTERPARTY TASK FORCE RULES UNVEILED

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office unveiled key points concerning the formation of an interparty committee on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait on Monday.

Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general to the President, told a routine press conference that the new interparty committee will pattern after the existing National Unification Council (NUC) and enjoys a similar status.

"The interparty committee will mainly act as an advisory task force," Chang explained, adding: "Hopefully, the task force will help President Chen Shui-bian integrate public opinion, forge national consensus and formulate policy on the development of cross-strait relations and safeguarding Taiwan Strait peace, as well as help promote harmony among major ethnic groups."

Chang said the Presidential Office has worked out regulations governing the formation of the interparty committee, adding that Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic body, will serve as the group's convener.
Chang said the convener can take part in meetings of the National Security Council.

Except for its convener, the interparty committee will comprise 21 to 29 members, including 11 to 13 representatives of major domestic political parties, four to six academic representatives, two to four industry representatives and three to five social celebrities.
According to the panel's organizational rules, its convener is obliged to come up with a roster for President Chen to make formal appointment. All members are expected to serve a two-year tenure.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry, is scheduled to unveil the committee's roster and operational formula on Tuesday.

Under the organizational rules, the committee will meet once every three months, but it can also hold extraordinary meetings if the convener thinks that extra meetings are needed. The committee can also hold extra meetings at the request of half of all members.

Asked whether the inauguration of the new interparty committee will mark the demise of the NUC, Chang said President Chen already vowed in his May 20 inaugural speech that so long as Beijing has no intention of using force against Taiwan, there will not be the issue of abolishing the NUC and the National Unification Guidelines.

As for when the NUC will hold a plenary session again, Chang said he hopes local society will give more time for the new government, which was inaugurated slightly more than a month ago, to make all necessary preparations.

The NUC was inaugurated on Sept. 12, 1990 by then President Lee Teng-hui to promote "phased" development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations in line with the National Unification Guidelines, also unveiled during Lee's tenure.

Chang said former President Lee formed the NUC in accordance with the organizational law of the Presidential Office. "President Chen follows the same example in setting up the interparty committee on cross-strait affairs," he noted.

Asked how the new government will respond if the new interparty committee's suggestions contradict with the existing unification guidelines, Chang said since the committee is basically an advisory group, President Chen can make a final decision on whether the committee's policy recommendations will be adopted or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING MULTIPLE CHANNELS TO IMPROVE TIES WITH JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to improve exchanges with Japan through "multiple channels," Lo Fu-chen, Taipei's top representative in Japan, said in Tokyo on Monday.

Seeking "multiple-channel exchanges" and promoting substantive relations with Japan are the primary goals of his mission in the East Asian country, said Lo, who assumed his post in Tokyo nearly one month ago.

Commenting on results of Sunday's election of the 480-member Lower House, Lo said the election reflects a passing of the torch between generations in Japan's politics, as many old timers were ousted while new faces emerged.
Lo noted that the "single-seat small constituency" election formula in Japan provides political novices with a fast track to the stage of politics, a method that better reflects the people's will.

Meanwhile, Lo gave a thumbs-up to the supra-party Japan-ROC Parliamentarian's Council for its invaluable and long-lasting contributions to cementing bilateral relations between Japan and the Republic of China.

Lo noted that Taiwan also greatly appreciates the Democratic Party of Japan, which won a sizable 95 seats in Sunday's election, for establishing the Japan-Taiwan Parliamentarian's Council right after President's Chen Shui-bian's inauguration on May 20, to better bolster bilateral relations between Japan and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NOT LIKELY TO IMPLEMENT NATIONAL PENSION NEXT YEAR: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said on Monday that the government has no policy on implementing the national pension scheme next year, and the chances of carrying out such a scheme in 2001 are slim.
The premier made the remarks on the sidelines of a ceremony to award medals in honor of people who have contributed to the anti-drug campaign.

Tang urged the public to pay attention to the issue of care for the elderly in Taiwan, noting that because of advances in medical care, the average life span of Taiwanese citizens has lately been increasing every year.
He said that by 2020, 20 percent of Taiwan's population will be over 65, and by 2025, it is estimated that one in every 3.8 people in the work force will have to support someone over the age of 65.

He said that there are currently more than 1.6 million people over 65 in Taiwan, half of whom are supported by their children. But he added that there are problems resulting from a changing society, noting that around 600 elderly citizens commit suicide each year.

Tang said that the Executive Yuan pays great attention to the issue of care for the elderly, pointing out that it proposed the welfare subsidy in order to provide elderly citizens with a minimum source of income so that they do not have to depend entirely on their children.

Meanwhile, Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya said that although she is not sure when the government will begin implementation of the national pension plan, she is confident that it will be "a fulfillment of the expectation of the nation."
Chang made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRY DELEGATION CALLS ON MAINLAND PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The head of a visiting delegation of Taipei industry officials said here on Monday that he will convey to mainland China President Jiang Zemin the hope of Taiwan businesses that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can have "three direct links" soon.
K.C. Lin, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), made the remarks prior to his meeting with Jiang in the afternoon.

Lin noted that after both sides of the Taiwan Strait join the World Trade Organization, they will face steep competition in the world. If there is no direct cross-strait trade, postal and transport links, Taiwan businesses will run into difficulties that will be detrimental to cross-strait relations.

He stressed that people on both sides of the Taiwan strait are Chinese, adding that President Chen Shui-bian has consistently displayed the sincerity needed to solve cross-strait problems since his inauguration on May 20. Lin expressed confidence that both sides can resume high-level talks soon.

Lin also said that he would inform Jiang of the difficulties and problems faced by Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland, and added that he would convey their wish to be able to invest in the mainland without fearing for their lives and property.
He will also make suggestions to the new Republic of China government on cross-strait trade exchanges after he returns to Taiwan, Lin said.
Lin said that cross-strait talks should be handled by the respective governments, and that from the CNFI's point of view, its responsibility will be to handle cross-strait trade exchanges.
But he also said that for the sake of protecting Taiwanese investors doing business in the mainland, the CNFI hopes that the respective governments will resume talks as soon as possible.

He also said cross-strait relations will enter a new stage in the next decade, and that the changes will depend on politics. Nevertheless, he said that the CNFI is confident that trade across the strait will only increase.
Meanwhile, Beijing Mayor Liu Qi gave an introduction of the investment environment in Beijing during his meeting with the CNFI delegation Monday morning.

Liu noted that his city excels in its biochemical and medical technology. He said that Taiwanese businesses are welcome to invest in Beijing's high-tech industries and that the city is willing to provide additional incentives to investors.

The CNFI delegation left Taiwan for the mainland on Sunday for an eight-day visit. In addition to meeting with ranking mainalnd Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs, the delegates will also hold investment seminars with mainalnd-based Taiwanese business officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY POLLS FIND SERVICEMEN VERY WILLING TO ACCEPT NEW GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's military servicemen are very willing to accept the country's new government, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said on Monday.
Wu made the remarks while fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.

During the meeting, opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao asked how the ROC's military servicemen reacted after Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), won the March 18 presidential election.
In response, Wu said, the military conducted five to six internal surveys between March 18 and May 20 with a view to understanding armed forces' attitude toward Chen's administration.
"The results of the series of poll show that nearly all officers and men display a high degree of willingness to accept our new government," Wu said.
The minister also for the first time expressed the military's anti-independence stance, saying the military firmly upholds the country's constitution.

According to the constitution, Wu said, the armed forces must serve and safeguard the Republic of China. Moreover, he said, the existing National Security Law also stipulates that all ROC nationals are banned from forming groups or holding rallies to promote secession of one part of the country from the rest.

Asked whether the DPP should revise its pro-independence party charter to make it easier for the ROC's servicemen to pledge loyalty to the new president, also the top leader of the armed forces, Wu said although the military should try to understand political operations, it should not get involved in politics.

Wu stressed whether the DPP would amend its party charter or not is none of the military's business, adding that even if the DPP does not revise its charter, the military servicemen will not suffer "any spiritual disorder" or confusion simply because of the inauguration of a DPP president.
Moreover, Wu said that judging from Chen's words and deeds since winning the presidency, the president truly respects the ROC and will defend the ROC's sovereignty, dignity and security.

Chen said in his May 20 inaugural speech that so long as Beijing has no intention to use force against Taiwan, his administration will abide by a "five noes" policy which refers to no declaration of Taiwan independence, no changes to the ROC's national title, no inclusion of the "state-to-state" theory in the conclusion, no holding of a plebiscite on Taiwan's future and no abolishment of the existing National Unification Council and National Unification Guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER FAVORS TEMPORARY HALT TO FOREIGN LABOR FREEZE

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said on Monday that he favors a temporary halt to a freeze on foreign labor as a complementary measure to ease the impact of a shortened workweek.

In face of strong pressure from the Legislative Yuan, which has already approved a mandatory 84-hour two-week work scheme, Lin said he supports a plan to temporarily stop the freeze on hiring foreign workers and adjust days off for national holidays as part of government efforts to reduce the impact of a shortened workweek on local industries.

As a shorter workweek will noticeably increase production costs for Taiwan's small businesses and traditional industries, Lin said the above-mentioned two ideas are feasible ways to make up for the shortened work scheme, especially when most of Taiwan's major rival countries still maintain a 44-hour workweek.

Otherwise, local labor-intensive sectors will be forced to shut down or relocate overseas as a result of rising production costs, he noted, adding that under the current circumstances, the government will not consider lifting the minimum wage for workers to help ease the burden for business owners.

In a written report to the Legislative Yuan, the economic affairs minister pointed out that the new 84-hour two-week work scheme, if implemented in the beginning of next year, will add seven days off for workers, bringing the total days off up to 110 days annually.

According to Lin, the new work scheme will add some NT$689 million in personnel management fees for the 12 state-run enterprises and increase wage costs in the private sector 12 to 18 percent. This will further squeeze profit margins for private-sector firms, possibly forcing them to relocate to other countries, at a time when Taiwan is to open up to foreign competition following its imminent admission to the World Trade Organization, he added.

Meanwhile, lawmaker Cheng Lung-shui of the opposition New Party has also submitted a proposal to the Executive Yuan demanding that the government, starting early next year, reduce the number of foreign workers in Taiwan by 15,000 each year until the ratio of foreigners in the local labor market reaches 1.6 percent.

A shortened workweek coupled with a cap of 1.6 percent on foreign labor would mean that the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan must be reduced from the current level of 290,000 to 160,000, Lin elaborated, warning that labor-intensive private firms may not be able to take the blow.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA PLANS TO VISIT TAIWAN THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, June 25 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, said that he plans to visit Taiwan again this year. He made the remark during a fund-raising luncheon in Los Angeles on Sunday.

Delivering a speech on "love , mercy and responsibility," the Nobel Peace Prize laureate spoke highly of Taiwan's democracy, noting that the March 18 presidential election will have far-reaching effects.

The Dalai Lama said that the world has witnessed the remarkable achievements of Taiwan in its economy, education and democracy, while preserving and maintaining many aspects of traditional culture that have been destroyed in the mainland.
The Dalai Lama refuted the claim that many so-called western values can not be applied to oriental societies, saying that democracy in Taiwan will serve as the best example.
The Dalai Lama also said that the urgent task for Tibet is to prevent its culture, natural environment and mental values from continuing to be destroyed by the mainland.

He also said that if Beijing is willing to help Tibet to improve its material civilization and help solve its urgent problems, then Tibet is willing to remain within the People's Republic of China. But he added that Tibet would also need some level of real autonomy within the framework.
More than 700 officials from Taiwanese groups in southern California took part in the luncheon, which raised US$300,000 for a Tibet fund.
The Dalai Lama visited Taiwan three years ago, attracting a great following during his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD ENCOURAGES EX-OFFICIALS TO RUN IN 2001 ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan on Monday presented party medals to retired senior officials of the KMT-led government, and encouraged them to run in next year's elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors.
Nearly 80 former officials, who relinquished their duties to the Democratic Progressive Party government on May 20, received the medals at the KMT headquarters.
Former Premier Vincent Siew was awarded the Shihchien First-Class Medal, the highest honor of the party. The former vice premier and former cabinet ministers were given Huahsia First-Class Medals.
Lien affirmed that the officials had made outstanding contributions to the country and the party during their tenures of office.

He noted that the KMT has since become an opposition party and is encountering waves of new challenges, and therefore he hopes that the former officials will continue disseminating the party's ideals by running in next year's elections.
The KMT lost its 55-year grip on power in Taiwan to the DPP in last March's presidential election. But it continues to enjoy a majority in the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan's parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.03 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at 30.797.
The local currency opened at 30.765 and was traded between 30.762 and 30.814.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$353 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COAST PATROL OFFICER ASSAULTED, WARNING SHOT FIRED

TEXT.P: A fleeing suspect assaulted and injured an officer of the Kinmen General Coast Patrol Team on Monday during an early morning operation to enforce the ban on illegal "small sum" trading between mainland Chinese fishermen and Kinmen residents.

Captain Wang Yu-chung suffered a fracture to his left shoulder blade. Chuang Shui-sheng, 38, was detained for questioning and charged with assault and interfering with official law enforcement duties. Team members Chen Hung-wen and Chang Hung-chi also were assaulted but suffered no major injuries.

Wang and Captain Huang Teh-nan were on a routine patrol in the Northern Kinmen coastal area when they discovered some 60 Kinmen residents trading with fishermen from more than 10 beached mainland Chinese fishing vessels.

When Wang and Huang led their team to move in on the illegal activity with the intention of investigating and seizing any contraband goods, Chuang attacked Wang with a bamboo bench and allegedly attempted to ram the patrol officers with a car.

Huang fired a warning shot into the air with his 65K2 rifle and brought the scene under temporary control. However, onlooking residents shouted that patrol officers were firing at people and began to verbally assault the team.
Deputy team leader Jen Chien-hua arrived at the scene with 20 support personnel to re-establish order. The team transported Wang to Kinmen County Hospital and arrested Chuang.

Jen said that Huang's decision to fire a warning shot was an effort to regain control of the situation, in which the team's safety was threatened. He added that Huang followed regulations in firing the shot, and the timing was not inappropriate.
The bullets inside Huang's rifle were blanks, so Huang did not fire at people, Jen said.

Sources said that illegal "small sum" trading activities between mainland Chinese and Kinmen residents have become more rampant recently, and even tourist groups have been brought to the northern Kinmen coastal area for "shopping." The conflict between coast patrol officers and the public has become more severe, sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EASE REGULATIONS ON TAIWANESE MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Acting on the instruction of the Executive Yuan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) revise regulations on Taiwanese mainland Chinese spouses.

Under the new rules, which still has to be approved by the Executive Yuan before taking effects, mainland Chinese spouses will be allowed to stay in Taiwan for 60 days in two years rather than 30 days and those who stay ten days beyond this limitation because of "irresistible force", might be exempted from the punishment of one-year postponement in granting them permissions for permanent residence.
Taiwan limited the number of mainalnd Chinese spouses immigrating to Taiwan to 3,600, there are tens of thousands applicants waiting their turns.

The new regulations also relax requirements for the entry of mainland Chinese who married with Taiwanese, such as allowing their close relatives to act as their guarantees vouching for their behaviors in Taiwan.

Meanwhile MAC Vice Chair Chen Ming-tung denied that the MAC has decided to review within three months the government long-standing policy of curtailing trade with mainland China, or so-called "No Haste, be patient".

A local evening newspaper the China Times Express said on Monday that MAC will revise the current restrictions on trade with and investment in mainland China and replace it with "Keeping root in Taiwan". Chen said the MAC has no plan to revise the current policy toward mainland China, and there is no point in substituting one term with another.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SECURITY NET' IS AIMED AT GAINING BALANCE WITH MAINLAND CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: The idea of a "safety net" proposed by Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is aimed at working out a mechanism to obtain an economic balance with mainland China, said MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung on Monday.

According to Chen, Tsai hopes to achieve a policy that is balanced and coordinated with the "no haste, be patient" policy on Taiwan investment in the mainland and a bold "go west" proposal. Chen said that balance could be achieved by setting up such a management mechanism to deal with cross-strait trade after Taiwan and mainland China join the World Trade Organization.

The reserved "no haste, be patient" policy governing Taiwan investment in the mainland was imposed by the former Kuomintang government in 1996 to limit political risks for Taiwan businesses wishing to invest there.

Chen also denied media reports that the MAC, in conjunction with the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, will stop using the "go haste, be patient" policy within three months as part of the present government's efforts to eliminate negative factors in Taiwan's economic exchanges with mainland China.

The vice chairman of the Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said he has no knowledge of the source of the reports, adding that no such issue was discussed in an MAC meeting earlier the same day, as had been reported.

According to Chen, Taiwan needs a comprehensive economic development strategy to boost the country's economic structure and safeguard its security which should go beyond the options provided by the "no haste" or "go west" policies.

If a comprehensive "security net" which "does not block the possibility of interaction and can protect our national security" can be established in five years, Taiwan people would become "very happy," Tsai was reported as saying in a seminar on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EASE REGULATIONS ON MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Acting on the instructions of the Republic of China Executive Yuan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has revised regulations governing mainland Chinese spouses of ROC nationals.

Under the new rules, which still have to be approved by the Executive Yuan, mainland Chinese spouses of ROC nationals awaiting permanent residence status will be allowed to stay in Taiwan for 60 days in every two-year period rather than the current 30 non-transferable days per year. In addition, those who overstay by up to ten days beyond the limit because of "irresistible force" might be exempted from the punishment of a one-year postponement in granting them permanent residence.

Taiwan limits the number of mainland Chinese spouses granted permanent residency to 3,600 per year, and tens of thousands of applicants must wait, sometimes for several years, for the right to live with their spouses.

The new regulations also relax the requirements for the entry of mainland Chinese married to Taiwanese, such as requiring their spouse's close relatives to act as their guarantors to vouch for their behavior in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung denied that the MAC has decided to review within three months the government's long-standing policy of curtailing trade with mainland China -- the so-called "no haste, be patient" policy.

He was responding to a report in Monday's edition of local evening newspaper, the China Times Express, that the MAC will revise the current restrictions on trade with and investment in mainland China and replace it with a policy called "stay rooted in Taiwan."
Chen said the MAC has no plans to revise the current policy, and added that there would be no point in merely substituting one term with another.

DOC.HEADLINE: `I HAVE NOT ADVOCATED INDEPENDENCE,' SAYS FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 26 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said in a recent interview that his opposition to the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification formula should not be interpreted as "support for Taiwan independence."
In an interview with Japanese non-fiction writer Takashi Kakuma, Lee said he opposed the "one country, two systems" scheme mainly because mainland China is still not a democratic country.
Once mainland China becomes a free, democratic country like Taiwan, Lee said he would be very pleased to see Taipei and Beijing discuss the "unification" issue.
The interview was published in the latest issue of Japanese weekly "Post" which hit newsstands on Monday.

Commenting on mainland China's continued acceleration of naval and missile deployment, Lee described himself as a peace-loving man. "I have consistently thought that Taiwan and mainland China should co-exist peacefully," he added.

Nevertheless, the former head of state said that if Taiwan is invaded, he will never lose his determination to resist aggression. "I believe that many Taiwan people share my point of view," he noted, adding that if mainland China really attacks Taiwan, it will certainly encounter a "destructive strike."

Touching on an incident during his first public appearance after stepping down when he was splashed with red ink by a retired military prosecutor, Lee said there are still a few people in Taiwan who identify themselves as "mainland Chinese" and who deem the Kuomintang's defeat in the March 18 presidential election as the "demise" of the ROC.

"I think it's a flawed concept," Lee said. The retired military prosecutor, Shih Li-hsing, blamed Lee, also a former KMT chairman, for the party's embarrassing loss of its 55-year grip on power on Taiwan.
Lee said that although he was born in Taiwan, his ancestors came from mainland China 300 years ago. "I think all the residents of the island of Taiwan are Taiwanese and that all residents are equal."
He explained that the main reason behind his snub of Beijing's "one country, two systems" proposal is that mainland China is still a repressive regime.

Noting that Taiwan is very pragmatic in handling relations with mainland China, Lee said that Taiwan, while recognizing the existence of the PRC, has never denied the existence of the ROC. Lee said he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can co-exist under the current situation and gradually pursue future unification.
He also pointed out that maintaining Taiwan's survival, security and sustainable development is the most important task for the ROC's new government at the moment.
Lee also said he advocates the concept of "new Taiwan persons" which refer to all residents of Taiwan, regardless of their ethnic origin.

He lauded his successor, President Chen Shui-bian, as a representative of "new Taiwan persons" who, while recognizing the existence of the Beijing government, always stand ready to defend Taiwan's survival, freedom and democracy.

The Japanese weekly also carried a five-page color photographic report on Lee's family life. In addition to introducing Lee's extensive library, the report also featured his collection of 60-plus golf clubs. According to the weekly, Lee's retirement centers around reading, preaching the Christian faith and playing golf.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIPPLED ILLEGAL CHINESE IMMIGRANT ARRESTED IN MACAO

TEXT.P: Police Monday arrested at a border checkpoint a crippled mainland Chinese who attempted to sneak into Macao by hiding under a truck from Zhuhai in southeastern Guangdong province.
The crippled man, who is about 30 years old, told the police that he wanted to make a living in Macao by begging on the streets.
Another crippled man, who attempted to sneak into Macao in the same way, was arrested at the border checkpoint earlier this month.
Macao became a special administration region of China last December. The two illegal immigrants could soon be deported back to the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,200 FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS ARRESTED IN RECENT DAYS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese police arrested more than 1,200 members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual group in recent days, a human rights group said here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said they were arrested between June 18 and 25 when they practiced Falun Gong in groups or when they staged demonstrations in protest against government crackdown on the group in the provinces of Hebei, Heilongjiang, Liaoning, Jilin, Guangdong, Shandong, Sichuan, and Hunan and the capital city of Beijing.

The information center said the arrests indicate that more members of the spiritual group have gathered together to practice Falun Gong and stage public protests in recent weeks. Police have been making great efforts to prevent members of the group from getting together.
Large numbers of them were arrested on Tiananmen Square in Beijing, and in public parks in Harbin, Guangzhou, and other major cities in China, the information center said.
At least 22 Falun Gong mmembers have died in police custody since the government began to crack down on the group as an "evil cult" in last July.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER MILITARY MEETING

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian presided over a military conference on Monday with a view to gaining a better understanding the country's current military and security situation.
It was the first time that Chen had called a military meeting in his capacity as the supreme leader of the ROC's armed forces since taking office on May 20.

The meeting was attended by Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Tang Fei, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming, National Security Bureau Director Ting Yu-chou, Defense University President Hsia Ying-chou, the commanders-in-chief of the navy, army and air force, and other senior officers.
Most noteworthy was the presence of Lu, as in the past, the country's vice president has seldom attended similar military meetings.

During the 90-minute meeting, senior military and intelligence officials briefed the president on the military's defense capability, defense budget and the military's perception of the current situation across the Taiwan Strait.
Relevant military officers also analyzed the key points of a newly released US Defense Department assessment of the respective military strengths of Taiwan and mainland China.
According to the practice of the previous Kuomintang government, the president called a meeting of military chiefs once every month or two.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT STRESSES CONCERN FOR ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian told visiting environmental experts on Monday that environmental protection -- just like pollution -- has no boundaries and is even more of an universal value than freedom, democracy, and human rights.

Chen received the foreign guests just before Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh gave a speech on the issue of "finite earth and infinite exploitation" at a monthly Presidential Office assembly. Chen said that the crisis brought about by the depletion of the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect deserves study and attention.

He went on to say that a recent suggestion to establish a ministry of environment and energy is "a good direction" for the government to follow as part of its re-engineering efforts. He added that projects on environmental protection, energy, and desalination on Taiwan's outlying islands to counter a lack of fresh water resources there will be "very helpful" for Taiwan.

He further pointed out that there is only one earth, so the environment must be cherished, and added that this generation has no right to destroy the natural ecology. He urged the protection and nurturing of the environment while pursuing economic growth.

Chen reiterated an earlier call to build Taiwan into a "green silicon island" that is not only an innovator in the world's information applications and a leader in digital economy, but also a "wise island" that continues to base its developments on the humanities, the "green revolution," and eternal growth.

The visiting environmental experts included Wim Van Vierssen, director of Holland's International Water Conservancy and Environmental Protection Institute; Masahiro Murakami, trustee of the International Water Resource Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on July 1 for a five-day official visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian, the Republic of China Foreign Ministry announced on Monday.
This will be Moscoso's second visit to Taiwan and her first since being elected president in May last year.
During her stay in Taiwan, the Panamanian president will hold talks with Chen to exchange views on the international situation and matters related to bilateral cooperation.
She is also expected to meet with ROC Premier Tang Fei, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, former President Lee Teng-hui, and to receive an honorary doctorate from National Taiwan Oceanic University.
Moscoso was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan last July at the invitation of the island's Evergreen Group, but she postponed the trip, citing a busy domestic schedule.

Last October, a senior advisor to Moscoso visited Beijing and touched off speculation that Panama's relations with Taipei might be affected, but some political watchers in Taipei have said that Moscoso's forthcoming Taipei visit indicates that the Panamanian government is determined to consolidate its relations with Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WILL NOT JOIN `SHOW' AD HOC GROUP: PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said on Monday that the PFP will not join the supra-party task force on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations if the task force is formed "only for show."
Soong made the remarks at his first press conference since returning from a month-long visit to the United States.
Soong said that it is normal in democratic nations for political party leaders to meet on major national affairs and that he is duty-bound to attend such talks.
However, he added that if the new government fails to stand by its policy, the supra-party task force will be a mere formality and the PFP will not be a part of such a group.

Soong cited the National Unification Council (NUC) as an example of a "show" organization, pointing out that it was set up during the tenure of former President Lee Teng-hui, who also made the "special state-to-state relationship" statement that caused heightened tension between Taipei and Beijing and led to the suspension of cross-strait talks.
The Presidential Office on Monday unveiled key points concerning the establishment of a supra-party task force on the development of ties across the Taiwan Strait.
The task force will comprise between 21 and 29 members, including between 11 and 13 representatives of major political parties.

Asked if there is a possibility of his cooperating with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Soong replied that he did not intend to give others an impression of machiavellian trickery, or to bargain with high-ranking KMT cadres on official positions. He added his hope that he and Lien will respect one another.
Soong also congratulated Lien and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh on their respective elections as party chairman of the KMT and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
He also said he has no plans to visit mainland China at present, and suggested that both Taiwan and mainland China should take steps to further understand each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VATICAN TIES SOLID: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 26 (CNA) (By Lu Yi-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the Vatican are firm and solid, visiting ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Monday.
Tien made the statement after paying separate visits to Holy See Secretary of State Cardinal Angelo Sodano and Foreign Minister Archbishop Jean-Louis Tauran.
Tien, who arrived here from Macedonia on Sunday for a three-day visit, was accompanied by ROC Ambassador to Vatican City Raymond Tai during his meetings with the two senior Holy See officials.
Tien said his meetings with both Sodano and Tauran proceeded in an amicable atmosphere. "All of us see firm relations between the ROC and the Holy See," he added.
Moreover, Tien said, Tauran especially expressed his hope that the ROC will not be affected by rumors or false reports about relations between the two countries.
"Tauran has assured me that if the Vatican were to adjust its ties with the ROC, it would certainly inform us of its decision in advance," Tien said.
Touching on the Vatican's relations with mainland China, Tien said the two sides remain far divided on certain key issues and that their differences are not expected to be mended in the near future.

During his meetings with the two senior Vatican officials, Tien said he briefed them on the peaceful democratic transition of power in Taiwan and the new ROC government's foreign policy and direction.

"I told them that our new government will strengthen the protection of human rights and will promote exchanges and cooperation with international organizations, as well as extensively taking part in humanitarian relief and charity activities," Tien expounded, adding he had also asked the Vatican to assist the ROC in realizing these goals.

Meanwhile, Tien said he had briefed his hosts on the new ROC government's policy toward mainland China. "I told them that reconciliation is the basic tone of our mainland policy and that we hope to co-exist with the mainland under a peaceful framework."

The Vatican is the second leg of Tien's current overseas trip, also his first since taking office on May 20. Before coming to the Vatican, he already visited Macedonia. Macedonia and the Holy See are the ROC's only two diplomatic allies in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC RAISES INTEREST RATES BY 0.125% TO HELD OFF INFLATION

TEXT.P: In order to preempt the threat of inflation and to maintain the stability of Taiwan's financial market, the Central Bank of China decided to raise its two vital interest rates by 0.125 percent from Tuesday.

CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said after a meeting of the CBC directors and supervisors that the bank's rediscount interest rate and its interest rate on secured loans will be raised by 0.125 percent each, from 4.625 percent and 5 percent to 4.75 percent and 5.125 percent, respectively.

He said the hikes, the second this year, were necessary because of the widening gap between local interest rates and those in Europe and North America, which resulted in an increase in May's domestic consumer price growth, and signs in the leading index of core consumer prices that inflation is looming.

However, Perng said the CBC will fully accommodate local banks' need to extend credit to industry by continuing to keep the money supplies within its target range of 6 percent to 11 percent through open market intervention.

The CBC foresees rosy prospects for the island's economy this year, estimating a growth of 6.7 percent, given the tame international price of raw materials and booming internal and external demand, said Perng
Immediately after the announcement, the average overnight rate charged by local banks on loans between themselves increased by by 0.25 percent to 4.785 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE PRESIDENT MEETS WITH TAIWAN INDUSTRY MISSION

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin met on Monday with a delegation from Taiwan's Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) in Beijing.

Delegation member Chen Wu-hsiung said in a telephone interview that Jiang stated that mainland China insists on a "peaceful unification" with Taiwan and does not wish to see a war break out across the Taiwan Strait, but reiterated that Beijing will not renounce the use of force against a declaration of Taiwan independence.
Jiang was quoted as expressing his hope that Taiwan's industrial sector will be able to play a more important role in the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
He also indicated his hope that Taiwan investors will show interest in the development of western China.

CNFI President Lin Kun-chung, leader of the mission, told Jiang that the current visit was purely designed to inspect the mainland's economic and trade situation and see the areas in which Taiwan businessmen can render their assistance.
He also said that the CNFI has decided to organize groups to visit coastal and inland areas of the mainland each year to assess the investment environment in various mainland locations.
The meeting lasted one hour and 20 minutes and took place in a cordial atmosphere, and little time was spent on political issues.
The 30-member mission arrived in Beijing on Sunday but only 14 members were allowed to meet with Jiang. The mission was scheduled to proceed to Shanghai on June 28 and return to Taipei on July 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN CRITICIZES NEW GOVERNMENT'S MAINLAND POLICY

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on Monday criticized the new Republic of China government's policy toward mainland China as "very flexible but lacking a vision."

Soong, who just returned from a one-and-half-month-long visit to the United States, said he is pleased to see President Chen Shui-bian refrain from making any hardline rhetoric to provoke mainland China.

Nevertheless, Soong said Chen has yet to work out feasible concrete measures to break the current cross-strait logjam, adding that Chen's administration should forsake several "negative elements" in the old government's thinking or policy toward mainland China.

Soong, a former Taiwan governor and Kuomintang power broker, left the KMT to run for the presidency as an independent. He lost to Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the March 18 presidential election with a narrow margin. Shortly after his defeat, he founded the PFP to continue his political career.

Soong said during his stay in the United States, he met with many US officials, scholars and experts. "Many of them worry about the prospects for cross-strait relations," he warned, adding that the United States now thinks that a crisis is more likely to erupt between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait than between North and South Korea or between India and Pakistan.

Noting that the new ROC government cannot afford to make any big blunder in handling cross-strait relations, Soong said the new government should use new thinking to achieve a breakthrough in the long-deadlocked cross-strait ties. "People's well-being and national security should always be top concern in formulating mainland policy," he urged.

Soong said he currently has no plan to visit mainland China. Nevertheless, he said he would be pleased to see more local people and PFP lawmakers to visit the mainland to help boost mutual understanding.

Touching on the PFP's future development plans, Soong said the party has no intention to give the priority to wooing KMT legislators to join the PFP's legislative caucus. Nearly all current PFP lawmakers were previously KMT members.
Soong said the PFP's current priority is to work out the party's overall development plan, build up a nationwide service network and draft comprehensive platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S TOP NEGOTIATOR HAS CHANCE TO VISIT TAIWAN: PRC LEADER

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin said in Beijing on Monday that his top negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, has the chance to visit the island.
Lin Kun-chung, president of Taiwan's Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), told the media in Beijing that Jiang made the remarks during a meeting with a CNFI delegation.
According to Lin, the Taiwan side suggested at the meeting that Beijing send Wang, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, on a visit to Taiwan as soon as possible.
Jiang reportedly replied that "he will have such a chance."
Wang was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan last fall at the invitation of his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
But Beijing postponed the trip indefinitely after then-President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" in July last year.
Lin's delegation arrived in Beijing on Monday for an eight-day trip to inspect the mainland's economic development.

He said that during the meeting with Jiang, both sides were very happy when they talked about economic issues, and added that he believes the current trip will help reduce the problems for Taiwan investors on the mainland.
Later, Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under Beijing's State Council, hosted a dinner in honor of the Taiwan visitors at the Great Hall of the People on Monday.
Li remarked at the dinner that only under the "one China" principle can the two sides of the Taiwan Strait enjoy smooth economic exchanges and cooperation.
He also called for early realization of direct trade, postal and communication links between the mainland and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED CHINA POLICY PANEL DRAWS FIRE FROM OPPOSITION, SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A proposal by President Chen Shui-bian's administration to set up a supra-party panel to advise the government on policy toward mainland China came under fire on Monday from the opposition and scholars.

Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng cold-shouldered the idea as unnecessary because there is already a National Unification Council (NUC) under the president to provide consultation on mainland China policy.
Lin said he saw no point in setting up another panel to play the same role as the NUC.
Lin, who was reportedly earmarked to be a member of the supra-party panel, also said he had not been asked to serve on the proposed panel.
Meanwhile, Su Chi, the head of the Mainland Affairs Council under former President Lee Teng-hui, said that Chen was "barking up the wrong tree" by setting up the panel.
The former mainland policy architect attributed the Chen administration's lack of leadership in its engagement with Beijing to the absence of consensus among his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
"Chen's party should first struggle to present a united front on this issue before seek other parties' support for it," said Su.
He also questioned the legal basis of forming a non-governmental panel with the power to dictate policy to the administration.
Chen Pi-chao, a former NUC executive secretary, also criticized the new administration for lacking vision in terms of its approach toward Beijing, despite its adequate flexibility.

He dismissed Chen's idea of co-hosting the 2008 Olympic Games with Beijing as an ill-conceived proposal, and asked what good it would do for Taiwan to host the Olympics "as part of mainland China's territory."
He added that he suspected Chen's proposed non-governmental panel to be the president's way of trying to evade the legislature's supervision by sidestepping the NUC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Scientists announced Monday they have completed the first rough map of the human genetic code, an achievement President Bill Clinton called "a day for the ages."
The China Times:
The International Human Genome Project consortium announced a milestone in scientific history on Monday with news they have completed and made publicly available the first working draft of the human genome.
The United Daily News:
Revolution in medical science launched with virtual mapping of 'the complexity, the beauty, the wonder' of the genetic code.
The Liberty Times:
Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui and his wife leave for Britain on Tuesday for a weeklong visit.
The China Post:
Human 'book of life' unveiled.
The Taiwan News:
'Human book of life' roughly decoded.
The Taipei Times:
Democracies turn up the heat as the first-ever international conference on the promotion of democracy opens in Warsaw; Taiwan joined 100 other democratic nations in calling for increased pressure on undemocratic states and societies that ignore human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 27, or the 26th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1871: A new system of currency based on the yen is introduced in Japan.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads went out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government Spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR BRITAIN FOR 6-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and his wife left for Britain on Tuesday for a six-day private visit.
Lee's entourage included Lin Pi-chao, a former deputy secretary-general to the President, and 10-plus security personnel and Lee's close aides.
Sources said Lin's British friends and the new ROC government have assisted in arranging Lee's first overseas trip since stepping down from the presidency on May 20.

During his visit, Lee will be granted honorary membership of the Schumpeter Joseph A academic forum in Manchester in northwestern England and will deliver a speech there on June 29 on Taiwan's political and economic development after World War II.
Lee and his wife will also attend their granddaughter's commencement from a British senior high school.
In addition, Lee will meet Chinese community leaders, visit prestigious British think tanks and tour cultural relics and tourist attractions.

Although Lee does not hold any public office now, mainland China still spares no effort to block his overseas visit as part of its diplomatic embargo against Taiwan. Against this background, Lee adopted a low-profile approach toward his Britain visit to avoid bringing troubles to the British government.
Lee is scheduled to return to Taipei on July 2. It remains unclear whether Lee will travel to other countries after his Britain visit.
During his 12-year stint as the ROC president, Lee pushed for Taiwan's democratization and endeavored to upgrade Taiwan's international profile.

Lee visited many countries during his presidential tenure, including several countries which recognize Beijing. His landmark visit to the United States in 1995 angered Beijing as mainland leaders viewed the trip as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

Beijing then launched saber-rattling against Taiwan. It even lobbed missiles and conducted live-fire war games at Taiwan's doorsteps in the run-up to Taiwan's first-ever direct presidential election in 1996 with an aim to sway Taiwan voters from Lee. Undaunted by Beijing's intimidation, Lee won a landslide in the vote.

Tension in the Taiwan Strait escalated again after Lee defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" last July. In retaliation, Beijing announced indefinite postponement of its top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan, originally scheduled for last autumn, and suspended cross-strait dialogue.

Lee stepped down from the chairmanship of the Kuomintang after the party suffered an embarrassing defeat in the March 18 presidential election, which marked an end to the KMT's 55-year grip on power in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 105.39 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 105.39 points to close at 8,424.17.
Market turnover amounted to NT$63.39 billion (US$2.06 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR CHANG CLARIFIES REPORT ON RODHAM BROTHERS' VISIT

TEXT.P: Dr. Parris H. Chang, a member of the Legislative Yuan, Monday denied reports that he had been instrumental in arranging the visit to Taipei by US first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton's two brothers last week.

In a letter faxed to the Central News Agency, Chang, who attended a lunch hosted by Vice President Annette Lu on June 22 in honor of the Rodham brothers, said, "I can't take the credit for what I did not do."
The Democratic Progressive Party legislator also pointed out that unlike what the media had reported, the Rodhams' trip to Taipei was "not a secret trip but a private business trip."

He deplored that the media had cited him as the source of their information on what was discussed at the lunch, including such topics as the Taipei-Beijing relations and the impact of the Korean summit on the cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Actually, Chang stressed, he never told the press anything about the lunch conversation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 105.39 points to close at 8,424.17.

Affected by the Central Bank of China's announcement on Monday of an increase in its two vital interest rates by 0.125 percent from Tuesday, the bourse opened at 8,569.35 and fluctuated between 8,587.4 and 8,412.01 during trading.

A total of 1.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.39 billion (US$2.06 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.32 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$67.94 billion.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.4 percent, textile issues and electrical stocks, both at 1.3 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 396 to 108, with 88 stocks remaining unchanged.
