DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN LEGION URGES SENATE TO VOTE AGAINST PNTR FOR CHINA

TEXT.P: The American Legion on Monday urged all Americans to tell their senators to vote against the legislation that would grant Communist China permanent normal trade relations status unless Beijing recognizes Taiwan's right to determine its own future and abandons policies aimed at military dominance in Asia.

Al Lance, national commander of the 2.8-million member American Legion, the largest veterans organization in the United States, called the PNTR bill "wrong -- an abandonment of principles, and shortsighted submission to avarice."

This free trade pact with Communist China, he pointed out, "sells our national security short. That is why the American Legion is lobbying the Senate to reject this proposal. Certain of our elected officials have apparently forgotten that China continues to antagonize Taiwan, has stolen US nuclear and military secrets and attempted to influence US elections by making allegedly illegal campaign contributions."

Those congressmen, who called the PNTR bill "landmark trade legislation, also have conveniently forgotten that the Chinese government tramples on the human rights of its own people and refuses to cooperate in accounting for missing American servicemen from the Korean and Vietnam Wars, and from the Cold War era," said Lance.
"I realize President Clinton is looking to bolster his legacy, but this is not the way to do it," he added.

The Senate's plans for a closed debate stand in stark contrast to the American Legion's National Executive Committee's action on the PNTR bill. After extended discussions, the NEC unanimously passed a resolution that details the Legion's opposition to the PNTR legislation as it now stands.

Lance emphasized that "the American Legion believes China should be required to comply with four conditions before such favored trade status is awarded." These include recognizing Taiwan's right to self-determination, extending full cooperation on accounting for missing American serviceman, abandoning policies aimed at military dominance in Asia, and encouraging human rights and religious freedom among the Chinese people.

To do otherwise, Lance said, "is merely gambling, perhaps with the lives of American troops, that China will comply with the four fundamentals listed above and will not finance an arms buildup with the economic benefits of membership in the World Trade Organization. The American Legion and other responsible organizations strongly discourage such a foolhardy wagering."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTS AGAINST CHINESE CRACKDOWN ON INTERNET USERS URGED

TEXT.P: Human Rights Watch on Monday called on foreign companies involved in developing the Internet in Communist China to strongly protest the detention of Huang Qi, who has been held since June 3 for maintaining a website exposing human rights abuses on the mainland.
Because Huang Qi has not yet been put on trial, the human rights organization pointed out that "foreign companies have a rare opportunity to help bring about his release."

"The Internet is supposed to help bring freedom to China," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of Human Rights Watch's Asia Division, adding that "that's more likely to happen if foreign companies object to the punishment of Internet users trying to advance freedom."

The New York-based organization emphasized that China's attempts to control access to the Internet through politically-motivated regulations and detentions "blatantly violates users' free expression rights."

Beijing has blocked the websites of foreign newspapers and dissident websites based abroad. Companies that fail to screen messages and to prevent users from posting certain kinds of information on the web could also be blocked. Internet users in mainland China, including companies intending to use the Internet, are required by law to register with the police.
While Internet and mobile technology are merging, foreign telecommunications and software companies are investing heavily in the development of mainland China's Internet.

"Internet companies are helping to provide Chinese people with an important new means of communication, enhancing their access to the free flow of information, and this is to be welcomed. But they should not turn a blind eye to users who are being censored, harassed, and arrested," said Jendrzejczyk.

On June 3, Human Rights Watch said, Chengdu police detained Huang Qi and his wife, Zeng Li. She was released after three days, but said police told her that Huang was being charged with subversion, a charge which could result in life imprisonment.

Huang's website (www.6-4tianwang.com), which grew out of an electronic billboard for missing persons, existed for one year. The website developed into a discussion forum where people reported human rights abuses neglected or ignored by the official Communist Chinese press. On the eve of the 11th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, users posted increasingly critical messages, including an account by a mother who accused police of having beaten her son to death during the crackdown.

Visitors to Huang Qi's web page were able to follow the developments leading to his arrest as they took place. At 5:05 p.m. on June 3, Huang posted a message saying: "Good-bye everyone. The Public Security Department summoned me for interrogation."

Two minutes later, he reported: "Four people of the Chengdu Public Security (Bureau) came to summon me for interrogation. I told them to produce a written summons. I estimate that they will bring it in ten minutes."
At 5:15 p.m., Huang posted his last message: "The road is still long. Thank you everybody. Thanks to all who have made an effort on behalf of democracy in China. They have come. Good-bye."

DOC.HEADLINE: PORTS STEP UP HI-TECH OPERATIONS TO NAB ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Ports around the world are stepping up high-tech anti-smuggling operations to deal with the growing problem of human smuggling, reported The Business Times today.

In the wake of the Dover port tragedy, where 58 Chinese mainland migrants died in a sealed container, the British government has pledged two million British pounds (US$3.05 million) to tackle the problem, with security organizations MI5 and MI6 taking the lead. A one and half British pound x-ray scanner is to be purchased for the Dover port, which has seen its share of illegal entries rise by more than 25 per cent over the last year.

Similarly, the French port of Calais is currently studying the use of drive-through X-ray units - similar to those used on the US-Mexican border - that can scan a single truck in less than 20 seconds.
Calais, along with Hong Kong, is already using carbon-dioxide detectors which can detect the carbon dioxide exhaled by people within a container within a few seconds.

Currently, law enforcement officials from Belgium, Holland, France, Germany, and Britain are attending an emergency Europol meeting in the Hague aimed at strengthening their intelligence gathering and cooperation in tackling the problem of human smuggling.
Human smuggling is now the fastest growing criminal business in the world, according to the head of the UN Office for Drug Control and Crime Prevention, undersecretary-general Pino Arlacchi.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO INVITE MAYORS OF MAINLAND COASTAL CITIES TO VISIT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Hall announced on Tuesday it will formally invite mayors of major mainland Chinese coastal cities to visit the southern Taiwan port city to help forge rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait.
Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh said if the plan can be realized, it will mark a breakthrough to the long-deadlocked cross-strait relations.

Hsieh, who was elected chairman of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Sunday, said the city government also plans to invite mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan to visit Kaohsiung.

Wang, president of the Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), originally planned to visit Taiwan last autumn to reciprocate a 1998 landmark visit to mainland China by his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu. However, Beijing announced an indefinite postponement of Wang's visit after former ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" last July. Beijing interpreted the definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Hsieh, a human rights lawyer-turned-politician, said he thinks that Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest commercial port and second largest city after Taipei, can be an ideal venue for new rounds of Koo-Wang talks.
Elaborating on his plan to host visits by mayors of major mainland port cities, Hsieh said he is hopeful that inter-city exchanges can help break the current cross-strait logjam.

Among major mainland coastal cities, Hsieh said he most likes to invite Xiamen city mayor to visit Kaohsiung because the two port cities play important roles in the current cross-strait transshipment business.
Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait transportation links, but has allowed Kaohsiung Harbor to handle direct offshore cross-strait transshipment services since May 1995.

According to the rules, foreign vessels or foreign-registered Taiwanese freighters are allowed to ship cargoes from or to a third country between appointed ports in Taiwan and mainland China under the condition that the merchandise not pass through Taiwan customs or enter Taiwan.

The port appointed by Taiwan for such offshore cross-strait transshipment services is Kaohsiung, while mainland China appointed Xiamen and Fuzhou in its southeastern Fujian province, which lies opposite Taiwan, to handle similar services.

Hsieh said he hopes that Xiamen mayor and top administrators of other mainland port cities can make official visits to Kaohsiung in the near future to help pave the way for mainland China to open even more ports for offshore cross-strait transshipment services to meet the demand of Taiwan investors on the mainland.

"Hopefully, cross-strait inter-city exchanges can take place before mainland China holds a high-level military meeting at Bedaihe, a summer resort on the outskirts of Beijing, in late July," he noted.
Hsieh, known for his resourcefulness and eloquence, further said he looks forward to visiting the mainland before assuming the DPP chairmanship on July 22.

Beijing leaders have refused contact with the DPP due to the party's pro-independence stance. However, the party has soft-pedaled its pro-independence stand since Chen Shui-bian, a DPP stalwart, won the March 18 presidential election.

Commenting on Hsieh's plans to invite mayors of major mainland port cities to visit Kaohsiung, Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general to the President, said the Presidential Office will be pleased to see mainland China make a positive response to Hsieh's goodwill gesture and sincere invitation.
Chang said the new ROC government welcomes increased cross-strait engagement on a parity, dignity and reciprocal basis to help defuse cross-strait tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO UTILIZE FORMER PRESIDENT AS PEACE ENVOY

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers on Tuesday suggested that the government appoint former President Lee Teng-hui as a special peace envoy to mainland China.

Speaking at a national affairs forum in the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Parris Chang proposed that the current DPP-led government assign Lee to serve as a peace envoy between Taiwan and the mainland because of his deep understanding of the Chinese Communist Party.

Brushing aside the view that Lee is a "trouble maker," Chang said that Lee had made many outstanding contributions to Taiwan's democratization that have resulted in the former president being nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize several times.
Lee can also represent the new government in introducing Taiwan's democratic achievements to the international community, he suggested, noting that Lee has been allowed to visit Britain.
Accompanied by his wife, Lee departed for Britain on Tuesday for a week-long private visit.
Chang said he hopes that Lee would be able to visit more foreign countries on the same basis.

Echoing Chang's remarks, lawmaker Wang Hsing-nan contended that President Chang Shui-bian should appoint Lee as a special envoy to negotiate with mainland China on behalf of the government to resolve bilateral disputes resulting from the long-time separation of the two sides.
Lawmaker Cheng Chao-ming said that Beijing should drop its "one China" principle and renounce its threat of military force against Taiwan as a token of goodwill toward the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY LIFT BAN ON PHILIPPINE WORKERS EARLIER

TEXT.P: Taipei may consider lifting the ban on new hires of Filipino workers at an earlier date if Manila takes concrete measures to ease the worries of local employers, said an ROC official on Tuesday.

C. J. Kuo, vice chairman of the cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), told visiting Philippine Labor Affairs Minister Bienvenido Laguesma that a lift on the ban "is not impossible" as long as the Philippine government is able to put forward a solution within a month, although the ROC government has not yet decided to lift its ban any earlier than the original three months.
But Kuo said he hopes that the three-month freeze on Filipino workers will not be extended after the period expires, and added that he is optimistic about that feasibility.

The CLA vice chairman also thanked Laguesma for the contributions of Philippine workers to Taiwan society, while Laguesma promised to find solutions to the problems with Filipino workers here, which prompted the ROC government to temporarily freeze new hires of laborers from that country.

The CLA decided to impose a three-month ban on the importation of Philippine workers less than one month ago, after numerous cases of runaway Philippine workers and labor disputes with local employers were reported to police.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL FOREIGN DOMESTIC HELPERS URGED TO BE INCLUDED IN HEALTH PLAN

TEXT.P: Around 18,000 foreign domestic helpers in Taiwan have still not been registered in the national health insurance plan, the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) said on Tuesday.
BNHI officials noted that there are more than 80,000 foreign domestic helpers in Taiwan, and they should all be included in the national health insurance plan.

But there are around 18,000 foreign domestic workers who are still not included in the plan, either because the employers do not know the rules or the brokerage agencies have deliberately overlooked the regulations and failed to notify the employers.

The officials said that the basic wage of foreign domestic helpers is NT$15,840 (US$514.3). According to the regulations, the monthly health insurance premium should be split between an employer and foreign domestic helper at NT$759 and NT$210, respectively.

The officials said that any employer who fails to register his or her helper in the plan is not only liable for all unpaid premiums, but also subject to a fine equal to the total premiums that are in arrears.
The bureau has now taken the initiative to notify local employers to register their domestic helpers in the national health plan as soon as possible, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND DISSIDENT URGES ROC TO EVADE 'ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE

TEXT.P: Exiled prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng said on Tuesday that the Republic of China's new government should evade Beijing's cherished "one China" principle, which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the PRC.

Wei, who is currently in Warsaw to the attend the first World Forum on Democracy, offered the suggestion in an interview with CNA. The US-based mainland dissident attracted much media attention upon his appearance at the forum.

Wei held a closed-door meeting with US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on Monday evening. According to Wei, their talks focused on mainland China's current human rights conditions and his views on Taiwan's present political situation. Albright delivered a keynote speech at the democracy forum earlier in the day.

Noting that Beijing's "one China" definition does not carry any legal significance, Wei said "one China" can have many definitions. He further said Beijing is indulging in a wordplay by pressuring Taipei to accept its "one China" definition.

"It's an unfair and flawed strategy to force Taiwan to accept Beijing's 'one China' principle as a precondition for resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue," Wei remarked, adding that Beijing intends to hold Taiwan responsible for the failure to resume cross-strait dialogue by insisting on such a tactic. "Against this backdrop, Taiwan should reject negotiations with the mainland," he explained.

Touching on Taiwan's political situation following the democratic transition of power from the Kuomintang to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on May 20, Wei said it seems to him that the KMT is still overshadowed by its embarrassing election defeat while the DPP is indulging itself in its "election jubilee."

Wei reminded the DPP-led new ROC government that it should brace up to cope with the many challenges that lie ahead. He said the new ROC government should first work out new foreign policy and new defense policy.

On the diplomatic front, Wei said, the new ROC government should help the international community gain a better understanding of the substance of cross-Taiwan Strait issues in order to win support and pressure Beijing to resume dialogue with Taiwan in a pragmatic and realistic manner.
In addition, Wei said, Taiwan should increase exchanges with non-governmental international organizations to help upgrade Taiwan's international profile.

Wei further said the KMT and the DPP should cooperate to safeguard Taiwan's security and democratic lifestyle, adding he believes that no democrats around the world would like to see democratic Taiwan be swallowed by communist China. (by Tony Fang and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFLICT OF INTEREST LAW PASSED IN LEGISLATIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Legislators on Tuesday hailed the passing of a bill that would prohibit public functionaries and anyone closely related to them to have financial dealings with government agencies that they serve or oversee.

Under the bill, which cleared the required third reading in the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday, all public functionaries, their spouses, their family relations to the distance of second cousin, and any relatives living with them will be barred from lobbying for or conducting any transactions with the government agencies served or overseen by the same public functionary.
Public office holders found violating such regulations will be subject to a fine between NT$1.5 million and NT$7.5 million (US$48,700 and US$243,500).

Legislators Chao Yung-ching of the opposition Kuomintang and Wung Chin-chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said the passing of the bill after seven years of effort will mark a major improvement in countering nepotism in political circles.

The bill also states that publicly elected representatives who are aware of any conflict of interest between their official duties and private interests, should refrain from screening relevant bills or voting on any related legislation. Violators will be subject to a fine of between NT$1 million and NT$5 million (US$32,467 and US$162,330).

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE RULES TO REDUCE FOREIGN LABOR IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday adopted a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.

In compliance with the terms of the resolution, which was raised by a group of 46 lawmakers, the government must, from the start of next year, begin to reduce the number of foreign workers by 15,000 annually until the ratio of foreign laborers in the local labor market drops from the current 2.87 percent to 1.6 percent.
New Party Legislator Cheng Lung-shui said Taiwan's jobless rate has continually risen from 2 percent in 1991, when the government decided to allow the importation of foreign workers.

Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Tai Chen-yao also stressed that he supports the passage of the resolution to help protect the interests of local workers, including aborigines, women and elderly job seekers.

Meanwhile, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Vice Chairman C. J. Kuo said the government will first lower the number of foreign family nursemaids, as well as foreign workers in domestic major construction projects and the high-technology sector, in a bid to ease the impact of the recently-enacted shortened workweek on labor-intensive traditional industries.

Kuo pointed out that the government will increase hires of aboriginal workers in public construction projects, adding that aborigines used to form the bulk of laborers in the local construction industry.

In addition, the CLA will also provide subsidies to jobless and elderly Taiwan workers and take measures to help them find work in traditional local industries as part of government efforts to reduce unemployment among local workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.007 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 30.790.
The local currency opened at 30.835 and was traded between 30.765 and 30.840.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$353 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,000 MERCHANTS STAGE DEMONSTRATION IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Some 2,000 Chinese merchants at a herb medicine market in Chengdu city in southwestern Sichuan province Monday staged a demonstration in protest against a new financial burden imposed on them by the city government.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Tuesday that the city government sent more than 200 anti-riot police to disperse the demonstrators, who blocked a section of a street for several hours. Five demonstrators were injured and seven others arrested by police.
The police confiscated the films and video recording tapes of news reporters who covered the event, it added. Chengdu is one of the two biggest cities in the province.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI VISITING BRITAIN

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and his wife departed for London on Tuesday for a six-day private visit, his first overseas trip since leaving office on May 20.

During his visit, Lee will be granted honorary membership in the Joseph A. Schumpeter Academic Forum in Manchester, which is in northwestern England. He will deliver a speech at the private foundation on June 29 on Taiwan's political and economic development since World War II.
Lee and his wife will also attend the commencement ceremony of their granddaughter, Lee Kun-yi, at a British senior high school near Birmingham in central England.

Reportedly, Lee also may meet with Chinese community leaders, exchange opinions with prestigious British think tanks and political scholars, tour Oxford and Cambridge Universities, and visit tourist attractions such as Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace.

Cheng Wen-hua, the ROC representative to Britain, would not comment on the significance of Lee's visit. In a telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Cheng also said that he cannot predict mainland China's possible reaction to Lee's trip.

Although Lee does not currently hold any public office, mainland China continues to spare no effort to block any overseas visits by Lee as part of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan. Lee has maintained a low profile regarding his visit to Britain, his first trip abroad in over two years.
Lee is the most prominent ROC political figure to visit Britain in recent years.

According to Cheng, Lee's visit has been arranged "for some time," and Lee received his entry visa in Taipei with the assistance of the new ROC government and the British Trade and Cultural Office, the de facto British embassy in Taipei due to a lack of formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Lee's entourage includes Lin Bih-jaw, a former deputy secretary-general to the president, security personnel, and Lee's close aides. Lin received his doctoral degree from Wales University and his master's from Manchester University.

Lee left Taiwan on an EVA Airways flight bound for London via Bangkok, Thailand. He is scheduled to return to Taipei on July 2. It remains unclear whether Lee will travel to other countries after his visit to the United Kingdom.

During his presidential tenure, Lee visited several countries, some of which recognize Beijing. His landmark visit to the United States in 1995 angered Beijing, as mainland leaders viewed the trip as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

Beijing lobbed missiles and conducted live-fire war games at Taiwan's doorstep in the run-up to Taiwan's first-ever direct presidential election in 1996, aiming to sway Taiwan voters away from Lee. Undaunted by Beijing's intimidation, Taiwan voters re-elected Lee by a landslide.

Tension in the Taiwan Strait escalated again after Lee defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" last July. In retaliation, Beijing announced the indefinite postponement of a scheduled visit by Wang Daohan, its top negotiator with Taiwan, and suspended cross-strait dialogue.

Lee stepped down from his post as Kuomintang chairman after the party suffered an embarrassing defeat in the March 18 presidential election, which marked the end to the KMT's 55-year grip on power in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH FIRM TO BUILD FIVE-STAR HOTEL ON PENGHU

TEXT.P: Britain's MaiDor international investment group is to build a five-star tourist hotel in Taiwan's offshore island county of Penghu, the Penghu County Government announced on Tuesday.

It will be the first foreign investment project on Penghu (also known as the Pescadores), an archipelago of 64 islets situated in the Taiwan Strait midway between the Chinese mainland and Taiwan proper.
MaiDor's subsidiary, Amazing Co., will invest about NT$2.2 billion (US$32.47 million) in the construction of a world-class tourist hotel in Makung, Penghu County's largest city.
Amazing Co. already signed a land purchase contract with representatives of landlords in May last year. The piece of land to accommodate the new hotel originally belonged to several landlords.
On Tuesday, the Penghu County Government signed a land deal authorization contract with Amazing Co. to finalize the company's land acquisition plan.
The authorization contract was inked by Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei and MaiDor Group Chairman Ian Irvine at the county government's headquarters.

Lai said the MaiDor investment project marks a milestone in Penghu's development because it will help bring the island county's rich tourist resources into the international limelight for the first time.
"We believe the project will also help attract other foreign and domestic business groups to invest in Penghu," Lai added.
Speaking on the same occasion, Irvine, a Scotsman, said he was very happy when he unexpectedly sighted thistles, Scotland's national flower, in Penghu.
Irvine said he is convinced that while MaiDor is the first company to launch a massive investment project in Penghu, it will not be the last.

"We stand a chance of developing Penghu into a world-class vacation resort. Nevertheless, we will need the assistance of the Penghu County Government and all of its residents," Irvine said, adding that he believes June 27, 2000 will be remembered in the future as the beginning of Penghu's globalization.

MeiDor Group's Asia region chief, Tim Potter, and Amazing senior executives, as well as Penghu County Council Speaker Su Kun-hsiung and many other local political heavyweights, were also present at the signing ceremony.

Penghu is Taiwan's only county that is an archipelago. Only 20 of the islands are inhabited. Penghu proper, Yuweng and Paisha are the main islands. They are connected by two causeways and the Cross-sea Bridge which is the longest inter-island bridge in the Far East.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT SUGGESTS ALTERNATIVE TERM TO `ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu on Tuesday suggested the coining of a new term to replace Beijing's "one China" policy, or the establishment of an "Asia Pacific league," to prevent Taiwan from being swallowed up by mainland China.

Speaking at a seminar on the prospects of national policy, Lu said that a term such as "one Chunghwa" -- which can be loosely translated as "one Chinese race" -- could allow the 23 million people of Taiwan to break free from the "politically binding spell" of "one China."
She added that "one Chunghwa" is only an example she brought up as food for thought, because "spending all day going in circles under the spell of `one China' is wasting too much time."
New thinking, such as the formulation of an "Asia Pacific league" with mainland China, would be mutually beneficial and would begin a new era, she said.

Lu concluded that the common challenge for the people of Taiwan is to find ways to increase the number of the country's diplomatic allies from the current 29 countries and to foray further onto the international stage.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen later remarked on Lu's "one Chunghwa" concept, saying: "These are all possibilities."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT LAUNCHES GRASSROOTS `REACH-OUT' TOUR
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, June 27 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian began a nationwide grassroots "reach-out" tour on Tuesday, with a sandbar off the coast of Chiayi County in southern Taiwan as his first stop.

Accompanied by Chiayi County Magistrate Lee Ya-ching and several other local political heavyweights, Chen arrived at the Waishan Tingchou sandbar via an air force helicopter early in the morning, becoming the first Republic of China ever to land on the sandbar that forms a natural barrier to help protect the Yunlin-Chiayi coastline in southwestern Taiwan.

The sandbar is Chiayi County's aquaculture industry stronghold and the surrounding area is rich in maritime resources. However, the sandbar is shrinking continuously due to natural weather changes and human pollution, and the feature which boasted an area of more than 3,000 hectares during its heyday has now shrunk to only about 300 hectares.
Chiayi County Magistrate Lee presented Chen with a plan to fortify the sandbar and prevent it from completely disappearing in the near future.
Chen said the central government will form a special task force to study the problem and assess whether the county government-proposed development plan is feasible.
Chen and his entourage then traveled to Putai, a Chiayi County fishing port which boasts a booming oyster cultivation industry.
They also toured several other coastal cities in the county, including a bitter gourd farm in Putzu township, before returning to Taipei.

Chen, the ROC's first non-Kuomintang head of state, who won just 39.3 percent of the vote in the March 18 presidential election, has vowed to make extensive grassroots community tours during his four-year tenure with an aim of exploring public opinion and expanding his support base.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT ANNOUNCES NAMES OF SUPRA-PARTY PANELISTS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh on Tuesday announced the names of the five-member selection panel of a new supra-party task force that will advise Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on policies toward mainland China.

The panel, which will be responsible for selecting members of the task force, includes Academia Sinica Vice President Yang Kuo-shu, Chung Hua Institute for Economic Research President Mai Chao-cheng, Attorney Lai Hao-min, Vice Chairman of I-Mei Foods Kao Chih-shang, and Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Lee said.

Lee, who serves as convenor of the supra-party committee, said despite its unofficial nature, the task force will be supervised by the people and society. He explained his statement by pointing out that Chen, to whom the committee will offer consultations on formulating policies on cross-strait relations and other issues, is supervised by the people and society.
Upon announcing the five-member selection panel, Lee said the panel will finalize its selection of between 21 and 29 task force members within two weeks.

Lee said the members will include between 11 and 13 representatives of major domestic political parties, four to six academic representatives, two to four industry representatives and between three and five local celebrities. Recommendations from all walks of life will be welcomed over the next two weeks to help the five-member panel finalize its selection, he added.
He added that although the selection panel is obliged to come up with a roster, it will be Chen who makes the formal appointments. All members will be expected to serve a two-year tenure.

The supra-party committee is expected to convene its inaugural conference in mid-July, slightly behind the originally scheduled timetable, as it will take longer than previously estimated for the panel to select the members, he said.

The committee will meet once every three months, but can also hold extraordinary meetings if the convenor thinks that extra meetings are needed. The committee can also hold extra meetings at the request of at least half of the members.
Meanwhile, MAC Chairwoman Tsai said Beijing "worries too much" by saying through the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Po daily newspaper that it will not recognize the proposed supra-party committee.
Tsai noted that Taiwan is a multi-faceted society with many different points of view and that the government should listen to opinions from all sectors of society before formulating its policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING INDEX OF ECONOMIC PROSPECTS DECLINED IN MAY

TEXT.P: A major barometer for Taiwan's future economic activity declined in May for the fifth consecutive month, according to a report released on Tuesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The government's leading index of economic prospects, which heralds the economic activity for the following three months, has maintained a downward tendency since February, with the pace of decline widening from 0.5 percent in February to 0.6 percent in March, 0.9 percent in April and 1.1 percent in May.

However, at 105.2 points in May, the leading indicator was still quite high, according to CEPD official Hu Chung-yin, who said he believed the economic development is slowing down rather than reversing.

In step with the leading index, the CEPD said that a survey conducted in May shows that fewer firms feel optimistic about the economic prospects for the next three months, with only 21 percent of the firms polled expressing optimism compared to 30 percent one month earlier.
On the other hand, the number of those who said they expect an economic downturn increased from 11 percent in April to 17 percent in May, according to the CEPD survey.
The remaining 62 percent said they expect the economy to remain unchanged, compared to 59 percent who thought so in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND EXPLAINS NEW DEFENSE STRATEGY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China military has decided to adopt a more active defense strategy since last year's Hankuan No. 15 combined services military exercise, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday.

The ministry made the statement in an attempt to clarify speculation that President Chen Shui-bian's "launching a decisive offshore strike against invasion" concept runs counter to the ROC military's traditional defense strategy.

Chen mentioned the "offshore defense" concept while making his first-ever military review as the supreme leader of the ROC's armed forces at the Chinese Military Academy in southern Taiwan earlier this month.

The MND said the ultimate goal of the "offshore defense" strategy is to avoid bringing war to a country's own territory. "This is a common military goal pursued by nearly all countries around the world," said an MND official.
He pointed out that the ROC military's current combat guidelines are centered around "foiling invading troops at sea or thwarting them on beachheads."

In the future, the official said, the military will establish a strong deterrent force to effectively dissuade enemy troops (referring mainly to mainland Chinese armed forces) from launching an attack on Taiwan.

"This is an active defense strategy with a view to discouraging enemy forces from leaving the other side of the Taiwan Strait or foiling them once they cross over the center line of the strait," the official said, adding that this is also the gist of the "offshore defense" strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR SIGNS PURCHASE CONTRACT WITH BOEING

TEXT.P: EVA Airways Corp. (EVA Air) signed a contract with Boeing Co. on Tuesday to procure 15 B777-series passenger planes for a total price tag of US$3 billion, according to an EVA source.
The source said the 15 jets include three B777-200Xs, four B777-300Xs and eight other B777-series models.

B777-200Xs and B777-300Xs are Boeing's most advanced planes and EVA Air is only the second airline in the world after Japan Airlines to introduce the new type of aircraft to its fleet, said the source.
The B777-series are equipped with powerful single engines that generate twice the thrust of those of the B747-400s.
The B777-200X has a maximum capacity of 250 passengers and a range of 15,000 km, which will allow them to make non-stop flights from Taipei to New York, Paris or London.
The B777-300X, meanwhile, has a maximum passenger load of 310 and a range of 10,000 km, making them suitable for use on EVA Air's Taipei-Vienna and Taipei-Rotterdam routes.

At present, EVA Air owns 35 planes, with a further three B747-400 cargo planes scheduled for delivery from July this year. These, plus the 15 B777s scheduled for delivery in 2005, will increase the fleet strength to 53.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JAPANESE LOWER HOUSE SPEAKER DESIGNATED
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Tamisuke Watanuki, head of the political faction belonging to late Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, was designated as Japan's new Lower House speaker on Tuesday.
He is scheduled to be formally elected at a special session of the Diet (parliament) on July 4.
In a general election last Sunday, the ruling coalition of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), the Komeito Party and the Conservative Party gained a controlling majority of 271 seats.
As a result, Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori is expected to continue to hold on to the premiership in the July 4 election of the premier.
Watanuki, 73, has served as LDP secretary-general, construction minister and Land Development Agency director-general.

The Obuchi faction which he headed garnered 57 seats in the general election and continued to be the largest faction in the LDP, followed by the Kato faction with 43 seats and the Mori faction with 39 seats.
It was also reported that former Science and Technology Development Agency Director-General Hidenao Nakagawa of the Mori faction will be named as chief Cabinet secretary.

Of the 18 Cabinet posts, 16 will be occupied by LDP parliamentarians, and one each will be allocated to the Komeito Party and the Conservative Party. Foreign Minister Yohei Kono and Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa will be retained.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO SET UP TASK FORCE ON MAINLAND CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday decided to set up a task force on mainland China policy and cross-strait affairs in the parliament to deal with the development of cross-strait relations.
The decision was reached by the caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties, and details of the function and obligation of the task force were expected to be discussed on Thursday.
Lin Chien-jung, head of the Kuomintang legislative caucus, told reporters that the task force will be an ad hoc group and not a permanent organ.
He said that it will be convened by the Legislative Yuan president and composed of 21 members, to be represented by all parties in accordance with the number of seats each holds in the legislature.

According to the KMT draft, the Legislative Yuan president will convene the task force when necessary, and invite the National Security Council secretary-general and related Cabinet ministers to make reports.
The Cabinet will also be asked to consult with the task force before working out any new policy on cross-strait relations, and to present a report after the new policy is formulated.

Meanwhile, the Legislative Yuan also decided to start general interpellation on administrative affairs of the Cabinet on July 4, and to close the current legislative session on July 28 instead of the originally scheduled Aug. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT BUYS BANANAS TO DRAW ATTENTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng bought 36,000 kg of bananas to treat all legislators on Tuesday, an act aimed at calling government and public attention to the plight of Taiwan's banana farmers.

Domestic banana prices have plummeted recently and banana farmers have been strongly affected. Apart from dishing out the bananas, Wang also led legislators in a rallying cry of "help banana planters by eating bananas."
In response to a question as to how eating bananas can help farmers, Wang said that although it only helps a little, it is still of some help. In addition, eating bananas aids digestion, he added.

People First Party Legislator Chou Hsi-wei (Taipei County) attributed the banana problem to the production and marketing system. Banana prices differ from region to region, and while prices may remain relatively stable in some parts of the island, prices in some banana-producing areas cannot even meet production costs.
Therefore, the Legislative Yuan has to urge the government and the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) to come up with feasible policy and take responsibility for the problem.

New Party Legislator Cheng Long-shuei (legislator-at-large) echoed Chou, saying that production and marketing is not balanced, and that the COA has to come up with concrete policy to solve the problem.

However, Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Cheng Pao-ching (Taoyuan County) rebutted their ideas, pointing out that the imbalance between production and marketing has long existed, and adding that in a free economy, if there is no serious defect, the government should not intervene in the market mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ACCEPTS `ONE CHINA, RESPECTIVE INTERPRETATIONS'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday for the first time that his government is willing to accept a 1992 consensus reached with Beijing on "one China, respective interpretations."

Accepting the previous consensus that each side of the Taiwan Strait can adhere to its own interpretations of the meaning of "one China," he chided mainland China for its current insistence on its cherished "one China" principle, which downgrades the Republic of China to a local-level government under the People's Republic of China -- something that is unacceptable to the people of Taiwan.

Receiving US-based Asia Foundation Chairman William Fuller at the Presidential Office, Chen also said that Taiwan hopes to resume negotiations with mainland China soon and to "seek common ground while preserving our differences."
Chen said that Beijing's insistence on its own interpretation of "one China" is the reason that negotiations cannot be resumed at present, a situation which he described as "regrettable."
He added that negotiations can also help both sides to discover a mutually acceptable interpretation of "one China."

Chen reiterated what he said in his first post-inauguration press conference on June 20 -- that he is willing to sit down anywhere and shake hands with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and discuss any topic without any predetermined stance.
The foremost job of the new government is to improve cross-strait relations and ensure eternal peace in the Taiwan Strait, he added.

He noted that Taiwan is a democratic, pluralistic society where different opinions abound. However, he cited an 80 percent public approval rate for his May 20 inauguration speech and his June 20 press conference as proof that his thinking in regard to cross-strait affairs follows mainstream opinion and consensus in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL REFUTES BEIJING PROTEST OVER EX-PRESIDENT'S BRITISH VISIT

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said on Tuesday that Beijing should not politicize former President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Britain, as it is a purely private visit by a private individual.
Noting that the former president has every right to travel, Lin said Beijing's protest over Lee's visit is "just too much."

Lin, who has just returned from the United States where he was introducing Taiwan's mainland China policies under the leadership of President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks in response to a protest from mainland China's Foreign Ministry over Lee's visit that labeled the visit an activity designed to create "two Chinas" in the international community.

Lin also noted that the people of Taiwan are greatly disappointed by confirmation from representatives of Taiwan's industrial federation who recently visited the mainland and met with high-ranking officials that Beijing has been suppressing Taiwanese businessmen who maintain operations in the mainland since President Chen's inauguration.
Meanwhile, Lin said most American opinion leaders have high regard for President Chen and attach great importance to the cross-strait situation.

After talking with think-tank scholars, China hands, retired officials and the media in the United States, Lin said he had an impression that the Americans also agree that Beijing should give Taiwan a goodwill response with regard to the cross-strait impasse rather than expecting Taiwan to shoulder the responsibility.

Lin also conveyed messages to Beijing via the United States, including Taipei's hope that Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait Chairman Wang Daohan will visit Taiwan soon, that mainland China will take back the 1,400-odd illegal mainland Chinese immigrants currently languishing in Taiwan's three detention centers, and that the PLA's constant live-fire war games on Taiwan's doorstep have seriously hurt the feelings of the Taiwanese people.

On the much-discussed but never agreed upon "one China" issue, Lin suggested that negotiators from both sides of the strait should "meet and talk" to work out consensus rather than exchanging empty rhetoric.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANK OPENS BRANCH OFFICE IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Gearing up for a launch of direct trade links between Taiwan and mainland China, a Taiwan-based bank opened a branch office in Hong Kong on Tuesday.
The Medium Business Bank of Taiwan is the seventh Taiwan-based bank to open a Hong Kong branch.

At a reception to mark the opening of the branch, General Manager Lu Ho-yi said that the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan will now be able to offer better services to customers operating in Hong Kong and mainalnd China.

In an additional move to brace for the establishment of direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China, Lu said his bank is also mulling the possibility of representative offices in Shenzhen as a first step toward opening branch offices there.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL HOSPITALS PLANNING OSTRICH CORNEA TRANSPLANT PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Several domestic medical institutions are preparing to embark on a program that will see humans receiving ostrich cornea transplants, a local ostrich expert said on Tuesday.

Speaking at a ceremony at National Chungshing University to mark the establishment of an ostrich-breeders association, Feng Cheng-wan, secretary-general of the Republic of China Chicken Breeding Association said that because the structure of the ostrich cornea is almost the same as that of humans, foreign medical institutions have started experimental programs to transplant ostrich corneas into humans.
He added that Taiwan's Chang Gung Memorial Hospital and some other medical institutions have already contacted domestic ostrich farmers to seek the possibility of cooperation.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) gave a greenlight to ostrich breeding and the import of eggs in 1998, and at present, there are over 10,000 ostriches on the island in 100 ostrich farms.
Feng, who is also an expert in ostrich breeding, said that the ostrich is a high economic-value animal prized for its feathers, meat and skin, all of which can be utilized by humans.

A kilogram of top-grade ostrich meat sells for about NT$1,000, while a kilo of regular-grade ostrich meat costs around NT$500. Ostrich feathers can be used to produce static electricity-free brushes and ostrich hides can be used to make handbags and shoes, Feng said.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 28, or the 27th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1491: Henry VIII, king of England famed for having six wives and rebelling against the Roman Catholic Church, is born.
1776: British forces are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: A peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Versailles Treaty because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against Chinese communists.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from COMINFORM at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the American government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the navy and air force.
1950: General Douglas McArthur, commander of the Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of the 17-year-old soccer player Pele, whose real name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.
1970: US troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1976: Fifty-one American scholars, researchers, teachers and students arrive in Taipei for a five-week Seminar on China Studies.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives H.A.E. Scheels, permanent honorary vice president of the International Badminton Federation.
1976: Chao Shou-po is named director of the Department of Information in the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1977: Ma Chi-chuang, board chairman of the China Steel Corporation, puts a torch to the blast furnace of the company's new Kaohsiung steel plant to signify the start of steel making.
1979: The ROC government approves two new appointments proposed by the Kuomintang's Central Committee, naming H.K. Yang, political vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Africa, and Ding Mou-shih, administrative vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Korea.
1981: To promote cultural communication and economic relations, the Sino-Nigerian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: Russian troops begin their withdrawal from Chechnya.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
1999: The 1999 International Seminar on the Protection of Clean Coasts opens in Kaohsiung with more than 100 experts from home and abroad attending.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention -- that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 58.54 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 58.54 points to close at 8,365.63.
Market turnover amounted to NT$78.69 billion (US$2.55 billion)

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT OFF TO VISIT MEXICO, TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 27 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on July 1 for a five-day state visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.

Before heading to Taiwan, Moscoso will visit Mexico where she will witness the signing of a free trade agreement on June 29 among Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, diplomatic sources here said on Tuesday.

Mexico's President Ernesto Zedillo, Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo, El Salvadoran President Francisco Flores, and Honduran President Carlos Flores will participate in the signing ceremony, while Panamanian President Moscoso will attend as a special guest, said the sources.
After the visit to Mexico City, Moscoso and her entourage will board an EVA Airway chartered flight in Los Angeles headed to Taiwan.
This will be Moscoso's second visit to Taiwan and her first since being elected president in May last year.
During her stay in Taiwan, the Panamanian president will hold talks with Chen to exchange views on the international situation and matters related to bilateral cooperation.

She is also expected to meet with ROC Premier Tang Fei, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, and former President Lee Teng-hui. She is also scheduled to receive an honorary doctorate from National Taiwan Oceanic University.

Moscoso's forthcoming Taipei visit is concrete proof of the solid relationship between Panama and the Republic of China and helps lay to rest speculation that Panama's relationship with Taipei might have been affected after a senior adviser to Moscoso visited Beijing last October.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 58.54 points to close at 8,365.63.
The bourse opened at 8,429.05, and fluctuated between 8,476.89 and 8,248.95 during trading.

A total of 1.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.69 billion (US$2.55 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.26 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$63.39 billion.
Only one of the eight major categories posted gains, with electrical shares edging up by 0.1 percent.

All the other major categories lost ground, with textile issues moving down the most at 3.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.2 percent, construction shares at 2.5 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 442 to 106, with 49 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Wednesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for July moved down 56 points to close at 8,539, with 5,110 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for August decreased 60 points to finish at 8,560, with 74 contract transactions, while September futures lost 100 points to close at 8,580, with 20 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 33 points to finish at 8,670, with 19 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 8,595 for July; 8,620 for August; 8,680 for September; 8,703 for December; and 8,773 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
July TE futures moved up 3.2 points to close at 479.5, with 1,227 contract transactions, while August TE futures increased 3 points to finish at 481, with 23 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 0.35 points to close at 485.5, with seven contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.
July TF futures decreased 8.2 points to close at 859.8, with 362 contract transactions, while August TF futures lost 13.2 points to finish at 859, with 43 contract transactions.
September TF futures moved down 14.6 points to close at 860.4, with 29 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER RETURNS FROM EUROPE VISIT

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao returned to Taipei on Wednesday after wrapping up his first overseas visit since taking office on May 20.
Tien, a political scientist-turned-politician, visited the Republic of China's only two diplomatic allies in Europe -- Macedonia and the Vatican -- during his trip.

Tien said he made extensive contacts with senior officials of the two countries during his visit. "I have made friends with many of them and I believe this will be helpful to the development of our relations with these two countries," he added.

Touching on the ROC's ties with the Holy See, Tien said relations between the two countries are firm and solid. During his talks with his Vatican counterpart, Tien said Archbishop Jean-Louis Tauran assured him that if Taipei-Vatican diplomatic ties will have any changes, the Holy See will certainly inform the ROC in advance.

The Vatican reportedly has been negotiating with mainland China for establishing formal ties. However, their talks have been hindered by some serious problems, including Beijing's insistence on its rights to ordain Catholic clergy and its resistance to offer its people religious freedom.

During his visit to the southeastern Balkan state of Macedonia, Tien held an undisclosed meeting with Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski. Tien said the meeting was kept secret mainly because of Macedonia's domestic political situation.
Tien also signed an agreement with Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov on the establishment of a US$10 million fund to help Macedonia develop its battered economy.

Turning to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's ongoing visit to Britain, Tien said Lee's itinerary was arranged by the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank of which Lee is an honorary chairman.
Tien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has only provided Lee with necessary assistance and convenience based on protocol for a retired head of state.
The soft-spoken minister denied a newspaper report that he was instrumental in arranging Lee's Britain visit. "I can't take the credit for what I did not do," he said.

As for Beijing's furious response to Lee's Britain visit, Tien said since Lee no longer holds any public office, he has rights to go abroad as an ordinary ROC citizen. Lee, an outspoken critic of communist China, left for London on Tuesday for his first post-retirement overseas trip. During his six-day visit, Lee will attend his granddaughter's graduation from a British senior high school, receive an honorary membership of the Schumpeter Joseph A forum, attend a seminar and meet with British academics and politicians. Lee is scheduled to return on July 2.
