DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GENE RESEARCH CENTER TO BE ESTABLISHED IN ONE YEAR: LEE

TEXT.P: Just as scientists from around the world have finished the first big step toward mapping the human genetic code, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announced on Wednesday that Taiwan will establish its own genetic research center within one year.

Noting that if the Republic of China begins to lag further behind other advanced countries in genetic research, it risks falling into the ranks of the second-class countries, Lee said that Academia Sinica, the top research institute in Taiwan, is actively preparing for the establishment of a gene center.

Lee said that although Taiwan is fast catching up in genetic research, particularly in rice genome sequence studies, with some foreign institutes having tried to recruit researchers from the island, Taiwan must keep progressing in genetic research and related sciences, which will be the signature industry in the new century.

Lee, the 1986 Nobel laureate in chemistry who in 1994 assumed the helm of Academia Sinica, said his institute will sign an agreement for research cooperation with Scripps Institute in San Diego, California in three months. Related costs, expected to be at least NT$15 million (US$0.49 million), however, may have to come from private sector donations as the government's finances are strained, he noted.
The topic of establishing a world-class genetic research center in Taiwan was first sounded in late May when the 2000 International Symposium on the Future of Biodiversity was held in Taipei.

During the opening of the symposium, Lee said that as biodiversity and genetic research are inextricably linked, it is Taiwan's responsibility as a member of the international community to develop itself into a genetic research hub so as to provide efficient protection to the island's diverse and abundant biological resources.

Dr. Peter H. Raven, a top science adviser to US President Bill Clinton taking part in the two-day symposium, said Taiwan is indeed a "formosa" -- Portuguese for beautiful island -- because about one-quarter of the species found on and around the island are exclusively endemic to Taiwan, while the remaining three-quarters have unique genetic characteristics.

Raven said the island of Taiwan, which is a closed biological system with rich and diverse biological resources that rival those of Europe, shows promising signs of becoming a global example of biodiversity protection.

Meanwhile, also commenting on the genetic research center plan, Academia Sinica Vice President Chen Chang-chien said that in addition to rice and mice genome sequence studies, the Academia Sinica may expand its research in this area to papaya, sweet beans, and bacterium in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD SINOLOGY CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN TAIPEI FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The Third World Sinology Conference is scheduled to kick off Friday at the Academia Sinica with the participation of more than 250 scholars of sinology from around the world, sources from the Academia Sinica said on Wednesday.

During the conference, the third of its kind, being held 14 years after the second, 46 workshops and panels will be held for the sinologists to exchange views on new trends, concepts, and theories on sinology which have been developed over the past decade, the sources said.
The sinologists, including 125 from Taiwan, 18 from mainland China, and 108 from overseas, will split into seven groups for discussions on 15 subjects each during the three days of the conference.
They are also expected to bring up topics such as the digitalized preservation of, and search for, Chinese literature and language archives to be debated during the conference.
Prof. Yu Ying-sheh from Princeton University and Prof. William Skinner from the University of California will each give a keynote speech to the conference on Friday and Saturday respectively.

Also, for the first time, nearly 400 domestic educators and researchers will be invited to attend the conference as observers in an effort to upgrade the local level of sinology research and studies, the sources noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO FRAMEWORK CAN SERVE TO HANDLE CROSS-STRAIT TRADE: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait trade issues can be handled under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) once both Taiwan and mainland China are admitted, Economic Affairs Vice Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Wednesday.
Lin told CNA that it will be "normal" to deal with cross-strait trade practices through the WTO mechanism once both sides are members of the world trade regulatory body.

His remarks came after local media reported that mainland Chinese Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Minister Shi Guangsheng claimed that mainland China, in compliance with WTO regulations, will file a complaint with the WTO for arbitration should Taiwan remain reluctant to establish direct trade, transport and postal links with the mainland after both sides are allowed to enter the organization.

Responding to a statement by Shi that mainland China is fully prepared to set up such links across the strait while Taiwan is unwilling to do so, Lin said the issue will also require approval from the Mainland Affairs Council.

After both sides enter the WTO, Taiwan will be willing to see mainland China handle cross-strait trade practices under the WTO framework, by which time the ROC government will have worked out a comprehensive package to tackle the issue, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IOC MEMBER HEADS FOR BEIJING TO PROBE JOINT OLYMPICS FEASIBILITY

TEXT.P: Wu Ching-kuo, the Republic of China's International Olympic Committee (IOC) representative left Taipei for mainland China on Wednesday to meet mainland sports officials on matters concerning the Olympics.

Wu, who voted in 1993 for Beijing to host the 2000 Olympics against the wishes of the ROC government, said he will first meet with He Zhenliang, former President of Beijing's Chinese Olympic Committee, in the scenic southern city of Gueilin for "a chat between old friends."

Wu said he will then travel to Beijing on July 3 for a meeting with Yuan Weimin, president of the All-China Sports Federation and Chinese Olympic Committee to discuss the feasibility of Taipei co-sponsoring the 2008 Olympics with Beijing and to see the progress of Beijing's preparations to bid for the right to host the Games.

Wu, who was widely believed to have cast the pivotal vote against Beijing in Monte Carlo that led to Beijing's losing its 2000 Olympic to Sydney, said in a recent interview with a local radio station that he did not follow the Taipei authorities' instruction to vote against Beijing in the secret ballot.

He said in the interview that he has come under heavy fire for the mistaken perception that it was his vote that blocked Beijing's bid, but said he was reluctant to admit publicly that he had ignored the Taipei authorities' secret order, even though the order showed a blatant disregard for the IOC rule that its members are not allowed to accept instructions on voting from any government or other group or individual.
Wu further claimed that in fact, He Zhenliang, who was president of the Chinese Olympic Committee at the time, wrote him a letter after the Monte Carlo meeting to thank him for his support.

He said he fully backs a proposal put forward by President Chen Shui-bian in his first press conference after his inauguration that Beijing should consider allowing a portion of the Olympic events to be held in Taiwan in 2008.

According to Wu, although IOC Chairman Juan Antonio Samaranch has explicitly supported the idea of Beijing hosting the 2008 Olympics and there is a precedent of some Olympic events being held in cities other than the host city, it remains to be seen whether the IOC authorities or Beijing would agree to the proposal that Taipei and Beijing co-sponsor some of the 2008 Olympic events.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.02 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at 30.810.
The local currency opened at 30.783 and was traded between 30.775 and 30.819.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$457 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MULLING WAYS TO PROMOTE TAIWAN BANANAS

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said on Wednesday that the KMT Central Standing Committee will form a task force to hammer out a policy to promote the export of Taiwan bananas.
Lien made the statement at a regular meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, the first following last week's election of the party's new central standing committee.
KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng promised at the meeting that he will solicit the assistance of a Japanese parliamentary group to cut Japanese tariffs on Taiwan bananas to 12.5 percent.

Ling Hsiang-nung, former Chairman of the Council of Agriculture, presented a report at the meeting on the price collapse of bananas following a slowdown in exports, and offered his suggestions for alleviating the problem.

Ling noted that due to weather conditions, this year's banana harvest was later but more plentiful than usual. However, Japan, the main importer of Taiwan bananas, scrapped its premium tariff on Taiwan bananas on the grounds that Taiwan's economic development has reached the level of developed nations. This meant that the tariff jumped to 27 percent, making Taiwan bananas much less competitive.
He suggested that KMT-run enterprises could help distribute bananas and that Hong Kong could be targeted as another potential market.

Lin expressed the hope that high-ranking KMT officials, especially KMT Central Standing Committee member P.K. Chiang, could try to contact Japan to increase the quota for Taiwan bananas, adding that it should be considered as an urgent matter for the KMT to use its clout to win back the support of banana farmers.

He also proposed that Wang Jing-pyng, KMT vice chairman and president of the Legislative Yuan, use his communication channel with the Japanese Diet to solicit the cutting of tariffs. Wang responded by promising to solicit the support of the Japan-ROC Parliamentarians Council to cut the tariff on Taiwan bananas to 12.5 percent.

He also urged the KMT to appeal to the public to consume more bananas to help bolster prices, and, noting that in addition to bananas, bumper crops of papaya, mango and lichi have also resulted in low prices, suggested that the KMT sponsor promotions for these fruits also.
The KMT Central Standing Committee also sponsored a banana promotion activity to underscore its concern for the plight of banana farmers.

Lin said in the promotion that Taiwan's location in a subtropical region ensures that its bananas are especially delicious, and noted that they sell in Japan for up to three times the price of Philippine bananas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEAM WINS 2ND PRIZE IN WORLD COMPUTER DESIGN COMPETITION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 27 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A team of students from National Taiwan University (NTU) won second prize on Tuesday in the First IEEE Computer Society International Design Competition.
The NTU team, composed of five students from the school's Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, won the award with a "Family Health Guard" program.

The team received US$18,000 in prize money, US$10,000 of which will be shared among the team members while the remainder will be presented to NTU's Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering to set up an educational fund to promote the application of computer technology in cultural or humanistic fields.
The contest, sponsored by the 54-year-old IEEE Computer Society, was held in Arlington, Virginia from June 26-27.
A total of 180 universities from around the world sent teams to compete in the competition, and after several heats, 10 teams were left to compete in the final.
In the final, the NTU team first explained the details of its "Family Health Guard" program and the team members then fielded impromptu questions from an 11-member international panel of judges.

According to the competition rules, the theme of the competition focused on health and medical services. Computer equipment used in the contest by each team was not permitted to exceed a value of US$200, and the ranking was mainly based on the ingenuity and quality of design of the entries.
A Canadian team took first prize, while a team from Poland came third.

During the award-presentation ceremony, however, members of the Boston University team expressed doubt about the impartiality of the panel of judges, claiming that the NTU team should have won because its program was the most sophisticated and the most likely to be upgraded for other functions.

Professor Feipei Lai, mentor of the NTU team, told CNA that he was also surprised by the Canadian team's victory because its program was "not very innovative." Nevertheless, Lai said he was still very happy to see the NTU team emerge as the first runner-up.
This was the first time that a Taiwan university team has managed to win a prize in an international computer design competition.
"The competition indicates that the world has entered a post-PC (personal computer) era and that Taiwan has 3C (computer, communications and consumer electronics) integration capability," Lai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN BEGINS INSPECTION TOURS OF VARIOUS MILITARY UNITS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) on Wednesday as part of his efforts to get familiar with the Republic of China's overall defense affairs.
Accompanied by Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming and other senior military officers, President Chen arrived at the intelligence bureau early in the morning.
MIB Director Hsu Chu-sheng briefed Chen on the bureau's main functions and mainland China's current situation.

The president's undisclosed visit to the bureau drew much attention as it came at a time when Pan Hsi-hsien, a former personnel department director of the National Security Bureau (NSB), the ROC's top intelligence agency, is now making a controversial visit to mainland China. Pan just retired from his NSB post, and under current government rules, senior government officials are banned from visiting the mainland within specified periods of time after retirement.
Following his MIB visit, Chen went to the Navy General Headquarters (NGH) in suburban Taipei to continue his "military units" inapection tour.

In addition to listening to Navy Commander-in-Chief Lee Chieh's briefing on the NGH work plans, Chen also inspected the NGH's command-control-communications-intelligence system, also known as the Tacheng system.
Chen, who is known for his good rapport with ordinary people, then lunched together with all NGH staff members at the headquarters.

Sources said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and the General Staff Headquarters (GSH) have arranged a series of military units inspection tours for Chen with a view to consolidating his position as the ROC armed forces' supreme leader.

Over the next three months, President Chen will make extensive visits to headquarters of various military branches and combat units to help the president's gain a better understanding of progress in the country's military build-up plans and combat preparedness.
Chen is scheduled to inspect the Army General Headquarters in Taoyuan, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, on July 4, and the Air Force General Headquarters in downtown Taipei in mid-July.

Chen presided a military review in his capacity as the ROC armed forces' top leader for the first time at the Chinese Military Academy in southern Taiwan on June 16. During the review, cadets from major military academies pledged loyalty to their supreme leader.
The president is scheduled to chair a commissioning ceremony for an IDF (indigenous defense fighters) jet fighter wing at a southern Taiwan air force base in Tainan.
On July 27, Chen will preside over the commissioning ceremony for the Anchorage-class "Hsuhai" dock landing ship, which the Navy recently leased from the United States.
In mid-August, Chen will oversee a computer-simulated drill, code-named the Hankuan No. 16 combined services military exercise, at the maximum-security Hengshan Command Center in Taipei.
Meanwhile, Chen will review a retired servicemen mobilization drill in late August.

The MND and the GSH will also arrange detailed defense reports at the Presidential Office's monthly closed-door military conference. On Monday, Chen presided over such a meeting at the Presidential Office in his capacity as the ROC's top military leader for the first time.

Military brass said all the programs are aimed at helping Chen become familiar with the ROC military's defense capability and military strength on either side of the Taiwan Strait in order to help him cope with a possible surprise attack from outside or contingencies within the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OPPOSITION WELCOMES PRESIDENT'S RETURN TO 1992 CONSENSUS (I)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition New Party (NP) and the People First Party (PFP) on Wednesday welcomed President Chen Shui-bian's claim that he will embrace the "one China" consensus agreed upon by Taiwan and mainland China in 1992.

Speaking at a news conference held in the Legislative Yuan, NP legislative caucus leader Elmer Feng hailed Chen's flip-flop from a Taiwan independence advocate before the March 18 presidential election to his current stance which recognizes the Republic of China.
Feng said the NP gave high marks to Chen's return to the 1992 "one China, separate interpretations" consensus reached by the former Kuomintang (KMT) government with mainland China.

However, he suggested that Chen further clarify the term to "one China principle, separate interpretations as to its meaning" in order to avoid the dispute provoked by the "special state-to-state relationship" theory. That proposed change, he said, would be acceptable to both Taiwan and mainland China and would also be in line with the spirit of the National Unification Guidelines.

If Chen is hesitant about doing so, or should mainland China be skeptical of Chen's attitude, the NP stalwart said that he would be willing to travel to mainland China to help boost conciliation between the two sides through face-to-face communication with mainland officials.
PFP Legislative Caucus Whip Chiu Chuang-liang also said he was happy to hear Chen's remarks on "one China."

Nevertheless, he voiced suspicion about the formation of a supra-party task force to provide the president with advise on cross-strait ties, saying it is worth pondering whether the establishment of such an ad hoc group is contradictory to the existing National Unification Council.
Chiu vowed that PFP lawmakers will continue to monitor government operations and that no PFP legislators will take part in the supra-party cross-strait task force.

The remarks were prompted by a discussion on Tuesday between Chen and William Fuller, chairman of the US think tank Asia Foundation, in which the president said for the first time that Taiwan would accept the "one China, separate interpretations" consensus agreed upon in 1992 by the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

But Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), also told Fuller that the people of Taiwan cannot accept Beijing's rhetoric that the so-called "one China" refers to the People's Republic of China.
He also accused mainland China of withdrawing from the 1992 consensus by reaffirming that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China.

Chang Jong-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Research Department, said Chen had no choice but to make such an about-face to the position upheld earlier by the KMT if he hoped to see the resumption of cross-strait talks.

Because of Chen's previous ambiguous attitude toward "one China" and a lack of lateral thinking to tackle cross-strait issues, Chang predicted that the prospects of any reopening of two-way negotiations are slim and that the Chinese communists will continue to watch Chen's deeds to judge whether Taiwan's new president really identifies himself as a "Chinese."
Although he admitted that cross-strait tensions have temporarily eased at present, Chang warned that a cloud of uncertainty still casts a shadow over Taiwan-mainland ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OPPOSITION WELCOMES PRESIDENT'S RETURN TO 1992 CONSENSUS (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 28 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Meanwhile, ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shu-bei reiterated that Taiwan and mainland China can discuss any issue, as long as the discussions take place under the "one China" principle.

Delivering a speech at the opening of a Guangdong-Taiwan trade exchange fair held in the mainland city of Dongwan, the mainland's No. 2 negotiator with Taiwan called on Taiwan businessmen to seize the opportunities presented at a time when both Taiwan and mainland China are set to enter the World Trade Organization. He also urged them to further bolster trade and commercial relations between Taiwan and Guangdong Province.

More than 2,000 businessmen from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, as well as over 1,000 businessmen from Taiwan, took part in the event, which was also attended by DPP lawmaker Chou Ching-yu, KMT lawmaker Liao Feng-te and NP lawmaker Hsieh Chi-ta.

Tang said that the large number of Taiwan businessmen at the gathering was seen as an indication that complementary economic cooperation between Taiwan and mainland China will be a mainstream trend across the strait, and added that he hoped to see an improvement in cross-strait political relations at a time when bilateral economic links have become closer and more plentiful.

At the same time, mainland Chinese experts commented that Chen has become more pragmatic with his remarks on the consensus of "one China, separate interpretations." But they pointed out that the statement alone is not enough to indicate that Taiwan's head of state is likely to make a major change in his policy toward the mainland.

According to Fan Xizhou, head of the Institute of Taiwan Studies under Ximan University, Chen's remarks sounded very vague and seemed to be more an attempt to gauge opinion than a policy statement. He claimed that the remarks should not be viewed as a change in Chen's stance toward the mainland.

He backed his claim by referring to the supra-party task force to be led by Academia Sinica Lee Yuan-tseh, saying that the lineup of the advisory body and its functions mark a noticeable departure from Chen's words.

Fan suggested that Chen indicate a clear and overall recognition of past two-way exchanges, including the 1992 "one China" consensus, and make clear his willingness to follow the policy outlined by the National Unification Guidelines if he truly wants to clarify his position toward the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNG, LIVER CANCERS TOP CANCER DEATHS IN TAIWAN LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Lung and liver cancers topped the list of fatal malignant tumors last year, the Department of Health (DOH) said on Wednesday.
The DOH made the revelation in a report that also stated that deaths caused by malignant tumors last year stood at 29,784, accounting for 23.8 percent of all deaths in Taiwan in the period.

Among them, breast and colon cancer deaths in women grew by 7 percent over the previous year, according to the report. Among the island's men, meanwhile, oral cancer deaths increased by nearly 10 percent, showing the health dangers posed by chewing betel nuts, smoking and drinking, the report said.
DOH officials noted that liver and lung cancers have always been the top two causes of cancer death in Taiwan, with liver cancer fatalities topping lung cancer deaths every year except 1994.

The officials noted that although liver cancer ranked second last year in terms of cancer fatalities, liver disease is still more threatening to society than lung cancer, as it tends to strike middle-aged people who are still breadwinners, while lung cancer deaths most often occur in older people.

Sheu Jin-chuan, executive director of Taiwan's Liver Disease Prevention Foundation, said that liver cancer is often described as "the silent killer," as victims can often live normally for many years without knowing that they have the deadly disease.
He pointed out that at least 3 million people in Taiwan are unknowing carriers of hepatitis B or C, both of which very often lead to liver cancer if left untreated.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian's father died of liver disease, Sheu urged the government to take the lead in promoting liver disease screening and hepatitis immunization for people over the age of 20, in order to cut the number of deaths from liver disease.
In 1999, lung cancer was the top fatal cancer in Taiwan, accounting for 27.07 percent of cancer deaths, followed by liver cancer, which accounted for 26.18 percent.
Rounding out the top 10 cancer deaths were colon cancer, stomach cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, oral cancer, prostate cancer, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and pancreatic cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NT$ 1,000 BILL TO BE ISSUED ON JULY 3

TEXT.P: A new version of the NT$1,000 bill will be issued on July 3, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Wednesday.
CBC officials said that the new version of the NT$1,000 note will use blue as its basic color, and that its design style will focus on the indigenous landscape and wildlife preservation.

The officials noted that the new NT$1,000 bill will have many anti-counterfeiting features such as stealth words and safety marks in the wake of reports that counterfeit money has been circulated at freeway toll collection stations recently.
The officials also said that the CBC will issue a new version of Taiwan dollar every six months, with NT$500, NT$100 , NT$200 and NT$2,000 notes being issued, in that order.

The CBC will reportedly limit the printing of the new NT$1000 note to the tens of thousands. The bills will only be available at Land Bank of Taiwan, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank and Cooperative Bank of Taiwan, with each person eligible to buy just five notes.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM SAYS GOV'T WILL BOOST DEFENSE SPENDING

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard said his government will boost spending on defense in the face of instability on the Korean Peninsula, in the Taiwan Strait, and in South Asia.

The Australian government is expected to spend between US$50 and US$70 billion over the next 20 years to replace all of the country's 71 F/A-18 Hornet jet fighters, its P-3C transport aircraft, amphibious support ships, six guided missile frigates, and its wheeled vehicles and small arms.
Howard on Tuesday told Parliament that after last year's successful peacekeeping mission in East Timor, the public interest in defense is at its highest level in more than two decades.

He said he believes the Australian community would back bigger defense budgets and mentioned that the introduction of a 10 percent goods and services tax would allow higher spending on Australian defense.

"I don't think those reforms are going to damage our capacity to spend more on essential public provisions, of which defense is obviously one. I simply make the point that defense has to assume a larger place in our spending and our national priorities," he said.

Potential flash points in the Taiwan Strait, on the Korean Peninsula, and in South Asia, along with the current political chaos in Fiji and the Solomon Islands and the instability in Papua New Guinea and Indonesia, are expected to prompt Canberra to spend more on defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO GRANT REFUGEE STATUS TO 1700 DETAINED BOAT PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Australia is set to release about 1700 boat people from detention centers after they are classified as genuine refugees, said Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Tuesday.
Ruddock said the release is unprecedented since the Australian government set an annual intake quota of 12,000 immigrants on a humanitarian basis several decades ago.
The 1700 to be released account for more than 50 percent of the 3100 boat people still being held at various detention centers around Australia since the middle of 1999.
At the height of the influx of illegal migrants into Australia, the number of detainees stood at around 4,000.

Ruddock said the 1700 boat people would be released gradually over the next six weeks beginning next Monday, adding that they will be resettled to Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia, Canberra, Northern Territory, and Tasmania.

About 400 of the remaining 1,400 detainees will be deported because they were unable to prove they are in genuine danger of persecution in their home country or they failed health or character assessments. The fate of the remaining detainees is still up in the air, said immigration officials.
The government moved to accelerate the processing of the detainees' refugee claims after massive breakouts at several detention centers recently, said critics of the government's decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA SPEEDING UP PLANS TO OPEN STOCKMARKETS TO FOREIGNERS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is speeding up plans to open its stock markets to foreign investors with an approach similar to that carried out by Taiwan and India when they made a similar move, reported The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the daily reported that new rules being prepared by the China Securities Regulatory Commission will allow foreign investors to buy Chinese shares through a qualified foreign institutional investor scheme.

During the first phase of the opening of its stock market to foreign investment, Taiwan also allowed foreign investors to buy stocks through qualified institutional investors in order to regulate the local market and prevent volatility due to large-scale speculation as a result of a possible large-scale influx of foreign investment.
Taiwan has opened its stock market successfully with that step-by-step approach and has so far limited speculation, analysts said.
India also took a similar path when opening its stock market to foreign investors.

The daily reported foreign investors would be allowed access to more than 900 A-class listed companies on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges, which together have a market capitalization of US$240 billion.

The daily reported this massive influx of overseas capital into the equity markets might be overshadowed by record levels of foreign direct investment in local firms as a result of China's entry into the World Trade Organization.

The daily quoted Stephen Roach, chief economist of Morgan Stanley Witter in Hong Kong, as saying that he "wouldn't be surprised if foreign direct investment easily surpassed the US$42 billion record hit in 1997."

"With China now beginning to implement a broad range of market-opening reforms negotiated as part of its WTO deal, foreign investors simply do not want to miss gaining a toehold in a market containing 20 percent of the world's population," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SPEAKER OF CHIAYI COUNTY COUNCIL SENTENCED TO JAIL

TEXT.P: A former speaker of Chiayi County Council was sentence to separate jail terms of two years and four months on Wednesday for rigging an election of a local farmers association and obtaining fraudulent loans from that association.
However, to the great surprise of the prosecutor, a three-judge panel in Chiayi District Court acquitted Hsiao of the more serious charges of racketeering and extortion.

The court sentenced Hsiao six months imprisonment for rigging the election of the Taipao City Farmers' Association in Chiayi County by offering bribes. Additionally, it sentenced him to two years imprisonment for getting loans from the same association through phantom members.
According to the court's verdict, Hsiao should serve only two years and four months.

A total of 49 representatives and staff of the Taipao City Farmers' Association were convicted as Hsiao's accomplices in the case, and were given jail terms varying from three months to six months, and can be converted into fines.
The court's verdict capped a trial of nearly seven months duration. Hsiao, who was detained during the trial, was ordered to remain in custody because of the risk of his fleeing.

The former council speaker was originally accused of being engaged in organized crime, including kidnapping for ransom and acting as a bookie for professional baseball games. But he went into hiding on Dec. 20, 1996, before police could arrest him.

Displaying blatant contempt for the law, he subsequently reappeared in Chiayi Council to preside over an extraordinary session during which the council members were entitled to immunity from prosecution. He then vanished into thin air after the 12-day session.

He successful eluded arrest some four times, including a large-scale manhunt led by Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa. He was the first council speaker in Taiwan to be described by law enforcement authorities as "cruel and dangerous" in their "wanted" posters.

He surrendered to prosecutors on September 17, 1999, and was spared the humiliation of being sent to the maximum security prison on Green Island, a common place of detainment for other leading mobsters.
Hsiao was absent from Wednesday's sentencing session. Both he and the prosecutor can appeal the sentence within ten days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US SHARE COMMON INTERESTS IN TAIWAN STRAIT PEACE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Wednesday that the Republic of China and the United States share common interests in safeguarding Taiwan's security and maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with visiting American Legion President Alan G. Lance, who arrived in Taipei earlier this week at the head of a delegation of senior executives of the noted US veterans organization.
During their talks, Chen expressed his gratitude for Lance's loud support for the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA), which is still pending approval of US Congress.

"No matter whether the bill can pass Congress or not, I believe that all the concern and support expressed in the process of congressional discussion will be the best guarantee to our national security," Chen said.
Noting that improving relations across the Taiwan Strait is his administration's moral obligation, Chen said he has been handling cross-strait issues with great prudence.

"I'm convinced that mending cross-strait difference and maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait are common expecations of all of civilian Taiwan residents, military servicemen and their families," Chen said.

The president expressed his admiration for the extensive care offered by the US government to its retired soldiers, adding that the new ROC government will continue improving vocational assistance and welfare services for military retirees.
Chen further said he hopes the traditional cordial ties between Taiwan and the American Legion can be further strengthened in the future.

In response, Lance lauded Chen for his efforts to promote cross-strait dialogue. "We hope peaceful cross-strait dialogue can be resumed in the near future through concerted efforts from various quarters," he added.
Lance also assured Chen that the American Legion will continue boosting cooperation with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: US THINK TANK PRAISES ROC PRESIDENT'S ACCEPTANCE OF 1992 CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's acceptance of the "one China, respective interpretations" consensus with Beijing marks a positive step toward the resumption of cross-strait interactions, said a US think tank expert on Wednesday.

Edwin J. Feulner Jr., chairman of The Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington-based think tank that retains friendly ties with Taiwan, told ROC Deputy Foreign Minister David Lee during a courtesy call that he hopes mainland Chinese leaders can sense Chen's good will.

However, Feulner added that cross-strait issues can only be resolved by Taipei and Beijing without the interference of a third party, no matter how much the international community hopes that the two sides will soon resume talks.
Chen said on Tuesday that his government is willing to accept a 1992 consensus with Beijing that each side of the Taiwan Strait can adhere to its own interpretation of the meaning of "one China."

Chen also chided Beijing for its current insistence on the "one China" principle, which downgrades the Republic of China to a local-level government under the People's Republic of China. Chen said that the people of Taiwan would never accept such an arrangement.

Feulner, who witnessed the historic summit between the two Korean leaders on June 13, said that he hopes the summit will serve as a good example for Taiwan and mainland China and that it will encourage both sides to resume a constructive dialogue.

Feulner added that during a meeting with senior government officials in Beijing, he had urged the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to reciprocate a 1998 visit by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF). ARATS and SEF are semi-official agencies that serve as channels of communication between Taipei and Beijing in the absence of formal ties.

Feulner concluded that a resumption of cross-strait interaction must be based on a foundation of mutual good will. Closer relations and more binding mutual interests from years of trade and cultural exchanges between the two sides should allow for more discussions and interactions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TUNA ASSOCIATION TO STEP UP COOPERATION WITH SENEGAL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tuna Association will step up fishery cooperation efforts with Senegal, one of the Republic of China's allies in West Africa, association officials said on Wednesday.
They made the remarks after receiving Senegal Ambassador Ahmed Tijane Kane at the association in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

The ambassador noted that Senegal's major fishing base at Dakar Harbor can provide multiple services for fishing boats, and he welcomes Taiwan's deep-seafaring vessels to enter the harbor for repairs and supply, which will boost bilateral relations between the two nations at the same time.

Association Secretary General Fu Hsin-fu said that most of Taiwan's large deep-water fishing ships have used Cape Town, South Africa, as their supply base. But he noted that Dakar has several advantages, including its proximity to rich fishing grounds, cheaper oil prices , and secure social order. He added that the port will be very accommodating to the needs of Taiwan fishing vessels.
Currently, more than 20 Taiwan large deep-sea fishing vessels stop regularly in Dakar for repairs and supply.

Kane said that as Senegal steps up its campaign to boost cooperation with other countries, it especially welcomes Taiwan deep-sea fishing vessels to call in Dakar for refueling, purchasing fish bait, and recruiting local workers to serve as crew members.

There are around 200 Taiwan large deep-sea tuna ships operating in the Atlantic. Among them, around 100 are operating in the Atlantic sea area near Senegal. The association is hoping that 50 of them will use Dakar as a base of supply and repairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TASK FORCE TO STIMULATE TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF), the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), and the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (COLA) will jointly establish an ad hoc task force to assist in the development of traditional, labor-intensive industries.

According to the Executive Yuan, Premier Tang Fei on Wednesday agreed to the project in principle, but he asked the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to track and evaluate its progress after the plans are formally appraised and approved.
Three sections will be established under the task force, for the purposes of "tax and financial assistance," "competitiveness boosting," and "human resource promotion."

The MOF will be responsible for guiding medium- and long-term capital investment into traditional industries, including insurance capital, post office savings, and retirement funds. The MOF is also tasked with providing traditional industries with preferential loans to upgrade their technology and increase their competitiveness.

The MOEA is charged with assisting traditional industries with research and development of new products and new production techniques as well as the expansion of industrial export processing zones to focus on storage, transshipment, and related industries.

The COLA is responsible for encouraging unemployed workers to find jobs in traditional industries, giving priority to providing foreign labor for traditional industries and small- and medium-sized industries, and carefully considering the adjustment of the basic wage through reviews and council meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTELLIGENCE STAFF URGED TO HELP BOOST MAINLAND'S DEMOCRATIZATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday encouraged the Republic of china's intelligence staff to help push for mainland China's democratization.
Chen made the call during an inspection tour of the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB).

The president pointed out that mainland China's military build-up and its resistance to renounce the use of force against Taiwan are the biggest threat to the ROC's national security and sustainable development.

Noting that the MIB is the ROC's sole officially authorized agency to operate mainland China-related intelligence work, Chen said he hopes that the MIB can learn from the prevailing world trend of promoting peaceful evolution in repressive countries.
Chen suggested that the MIB staff take advantage of pro-democracy force within mainland China to spread democratic ideas and advocate democratic political reforms.

"I believe that pushing for mainland China's democratization and denouncement of one-party dictatorship and military expansionism is the most effective way to narrow the ideological gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," he noted.
Chen also promised to promote the legislation of an intelligence staff protection law as soon as possible to better protect their rights and interests.

The MIB was the first stop of Chen's new military units inspection tour designed by the Ministry of National Defense and the General Staff Headquarters with a view to helping Chen become familiar with the country's overall defense affairs and consolidating his position as the ROC armed force's top leader.
Later in the day, Chen made a similar inspection tour of the Navy General Headquarters in suburban Taipei.
Chen said mainland China has apparently changed its naval force development goal from "offshore defense" to building up a deep-sea naval fleet.

Noting that the adjustment in Beijing's naval force build-up strategy is mainly aimed at beefing up its capability to take Taiwan by force and developing itself into a naval power, Chen urged all ROC naval officers to brace up to cope with the new challenges ahead.
"In addition to completing renovation of our naval fleet as scheduled, we should also work out medium- and long-range naval force development plans," he added.
Over the next three months, Chen is expected to continue inspection tours of other military units around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE FROM MAINLAND CHINA IMPOSSIBLE: DALAI LAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 27 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: It is impossible for Taiwan to be fully independent from mainland China, the Dalai Lama said on Monday.

In light of Taiwan's close cultural and economic affinity with mainland China, it is unimaginable that the island could be separated from mainland China and become fully independent, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader said.

Noting that he had visited Taiwan in 1997 and was favorably impressed by its well-entrenched democracy, booming economy and highly-developed education system, the Dalai Lama urged Taiwan to "look before you leap" and define the meaning of "one China" before resuming a dialogue with Beijing.
He also called on leaders of both sides of the Taiwan Strait to cast aside their personal feelings and deal with each other sensibly.
The Dalai Lama expressed interest in visiting the island this year and said that he looks forward to meeting with President Chen Shui-bian.
The Tibetan religious leader is presiding over a three-day meeting to promote Buddhism in Los Angeles from June 28-30.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS AGREE TO ENFORCE FIVE-DAY WORK WEEK FROM 2001

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition caucuses in the Legislative Yuan (parliament) on Wednesday agreed that a five-day workweek system be enforced from Jan. 1, 2001.
At present, the five-day workweek is implemented only for the second and fourth weeks of each month.
The lawmakers decided to amend the Public Employee Service Law to introduce the new system, under which annual holidays for public servants will be increased to 115-116 days.
The second and third readings of the amendment to the law will take place on June 30.
At the same time, Premier Tang Fei instructed the Central Personnel Administration to work out complementary measures to comply with the implementation of the five-day workweek next year.

The government was originally scheduled to enforce the new system from 2002, but lawmakers recently decided to implement it one year ahead of schedule following their success in cutting the weekly working hours for private sector employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN SCIENTISTS MAKE BREAKTHROUGH IN ORGAN TRANSPLANT RESEARCH

TEXT.P: A team of Canadian scientists may be on the verge of a breakthrough that could eliminate the body's urge to reject organ transplants.

Their findings, which will be published in the July issue of the US monthly journal Nature Medicine, could also eventually help scientists cure auto immune diseases, such as lupus and rheumatoid arthritis, said Dr. Gary Levy, director of the multi-organ transplant program at Toronto General Hospital.

Finding a way to stop the body's rejection of transplanted organs has been regarded as the holy grail of transplantation research. The body's immune system detects and attacks any foreign tissue, so people who have received a donor organ have to take powerful and costly drugs to suppress that immune reaction for the rest of their lives.
Suppressing the immune system leaves patients far more susceptible to viruses, bacteria or whatever ailment is making the rounds.

The Toronto team, led by Dr. Li Zhang, has identified a particular type of white blood cell that can regulate the killer white blood cells which attack and destroy foreign tissue. The newly identified T-cells were found in the spleens of mice, which were the subject of her research.

These newly identified T-cells trick killer T-cells into attacking them rather than the transplanted tissue. In the process, the killer T-cells are destroyed, leaving the transplanted organ unaffected and the body's ability to protect itself against other threats intact.
Using their findings, the team has been able to successfully transplant skin -- the toughest organ to transplant -- in mice.

"There is a great potential for using this method in transplant patients in future," said Zhang, a senior scientist at Toronto General Hospital Research Institute. She is also an assistant professor in the department of laboratory medicine and pathobiology at the University of Toronto.
Kevin Young, a Ph.D. student working on Zhang's team, cautioned that while the findings are promising, it is too soon to say whether this process will work in humans.
"What we've discovered works in mice, but we have to try it with different organs in mice, and then there's been no work done in humans," he noted.

Still, Levy predicted applications leading from Zhang's research could be ready for use within a few years. He also said the findings could help unlock the secret to turning off auto immune diseases -- conditions like inflammatory bowel disease or lupus where the body attacks itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT MEET WITH MARGARET THATCHER
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 28 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met with Lady Margaret Thatcher, former prime minister of the United Kingdom, on Wednesday to exchange views on world affairs.

A spokesman of the Lady Thatcher Foundation in downtown London said that the two former leaders have known each other for some time. They reminisced about their past experiences, and also discussed current world events, the official added.
Thatcher visited Taiwan in 1992 and 1996, after stepping down as British prime minister in 1990.
However, the spokesman insisted that the two did not discuss Taiwan politics in the wake of March 18 presidential election during their 40-minute meeting.

Lee and his wife Tseng Wen-hui, their granddaughter Lee Kun-yi, former Deputy Secretary General to the President Lin Bih-jaw, and the ROC's Representative to Britain Cheng Wen-hua, arrived at the foundation at around 10 a.m.
Lee had kept a low profile throughout his visit to the foundation. He only smiled before and after his meeting with Thatcher, and did not make any remarks to the press.
After the visit, the Lees drove past Buckingham Palace and Westminster Abbey for a visit to the British Parliament, where they had lunch with British legislators.
Lee is scheduled to visit the British Museum in the afternoon, and tour Oxford and Cambridge Universities on Thursday, if his schedule permits.
Lee departed for London on Tuesday for a six-day private visit, his first overseas trip after leaving office on May 20.

During his visit, Lee will be granted a honorary membership in the Joseph A. Schumpeter Academic Forum in Manchester, which is in northwestern England. He will deliver a speech at the private foundation on June 29 on Taiwan's political and economic development since World War II.
He and his wife will also attend the commencement ceremony of their granddaughter Lee Kun-yi at a British senior high school near Birmingham in central England.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAJOR OPPOSITION SPURN SPECIAL PANEL ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang, the major Republic of China opposition party, joined forces with another opposition party on Wednesday in declining to take part in a panel designed to build a consensus on policy toward mainland China.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said on Wednesday that the so-called supra-party panel aimed at advising the president on mainalnd China policy is a non-government organization without any legal basis, and would usurp the authority of the government's National Unification Council.

He said that the KMT has neither been consulted about the new panel's functions nor been invited to take part in it. Lin said that the party's opinion is that would be better to work out the government's policy by authorized government agencies.
Asked if that means the KMT will not join the panel chaired by Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Academia Sinica, Lin said, "You can interpret it in that way."

Lin made the remarks after the People's First Party (PFP), another opposition party, ruled out the possibility of joining a non-government panel that has no legal authority to turn out a binding decision.

Branding the controversial claims by former president Lee Teng-hui for a "special state-to-state" basis for cross-strait relations as the brainchild of non-government organizations, PFP head James Soong said that the new panel could degenerate into an opportunity for political horse-trading rather than a forum for policy discussion.
Soong added that his party will not extend any legitimacy to the panel by joining it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF: ROC PRESIDENT'S STAND TOWARD PRC IS CONSISTENT

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Eng-wen said on Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian's basic stance toward mainland China has been consistent and remains unchanged.
Tsai called a press conference to clarify speculation that Chen might have softened his stand on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Chen told an American visitor on Tuesday that Taipei is ready to accept a 1992 consensus allowing each side of the Taiwan Strait for "respective interpretations" on "one China."
His statement received favorable comments from the Kuomintang and the People First Party, but drew criticism from Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Tsai said that Chen's statement on Tuesday was consistent with remarks he made on the issue on May 20 and June 20. The MAC head pointed out that Beijing's goal of downgrading Taiwan to the level of a local province belonging to the People's Republic of China is unacceptable to Taipei.
Meanwhile, DPP Chairman-elect Frank Hsieh said on Wednesday that Chen's statement is not contradictory to the DPP's policy on mainland China affairs, although it is still some distance away.

He said that as long as Chen does not actually retreat from the party's policy, the DPP welcomes him to adjust his stance on the issue. Hsieh added that Chen's statement might be interpreted as a goodwill gesture toward Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 29, or the 28th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1801: The first census is carried out in Britain.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thais revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai-shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by the Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1974: The ROC government announces the suspension of diplomatic relations with Venezuela, which recognized the Chinese communist regime.
1974: The 6th National Little League Baseball Tournament ends with the Li Teh team from Kaohsiung City designated to represent the ROC in the Asian playoffs.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship-carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates the new Commissioned and Noncommissioned Statute of the Armed Forces and the new Entertainment Tax Law.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1982: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives Richard Allen, senior counselor for foreign policy to the Republican National Committee of the United States.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law, or Eugenics Bill, after a third reading.
1986: Argentina wins the World Cup soccer title again in Mexico, thanks to Diego Maradona, 25, who was directly or indirectly responsible for all the goals in the championship game.
1992: Mohamed Boudiaf, president of Algeria, is assassinated as he opens a cultural center in Annaba.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former US Vice President Dan Quayle.
1994: Japan's Parliament chooses Tomiichi Murayama as the new prime minister.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
1999: The ROC wins the right to host the annual global Information Technology conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER MAY MAKE GOODWILL JOURNEY TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Mainland China has tentatively agreed to a possible visit by Taiwan's Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to promote "Track II" interaction across the Taiwan Strait, an opposition lawmaker said on Thursday.

Legislator Chen Horng-chi of the Kuomintang, the Republic of China's ruling party until May 20, said he broached the idea to a well-placed mainland official during his just-concluded visit to mainland China.

"I told the mainland official that Taiwan's Legislative Yuan can now serve as an effective channel for unofficial 'Track II' cross-strait dialogue," Chen said, adding that the mainland official gave a warm response to his proposal.

Although the KMT lost to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the March 18 presidential election, it still enjoys a comfortable majority in the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan's parliament. The KMT favors an eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under freedom and democracy.

Chen said interaction between the two officially authorized intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- has long been stalled.

"I'm convinced that the Legislative Yuan can now serve as a conduit for cross-strait communications," Chen said, adding that Beijing authorities have shown keen interest in the Taiwan legislature's possible role in future cross-strait interaction.

Chen said he had suggested that Legislative Yuan Presdient Wang, also a KMT vice chairman, make a goodwill journey to mainland China as a representative of the Taiwan public to help break the current cross-strait logjam.
According to Chen, the well-placed mainland official gave a thumbs-up to the proposal, describing the idea as "feasible."
Chen, however, would not identify the mainland official with a view to avoiding any unnecessary troubles.

Commenting on Chen's recommendation, Wang said whether he would represent the legislature to make a visit to the mainland cannot be mulled until after the chamber's planned mainland policy task force is formally inaugurated.

"If the proposed task force agrees to Chen's proposal, I will make a decision on whether to make a journey to the mainland," Wang said, adding that in making a final decision, he will take into account the state of cross-strait relations at the time.

ARATS President Wang Daohan, also mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, originally planned to visit Taiwan last autumn to reciprocate a landmark visit to the mainland in October 1998 by his Taiwan counterpart, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu.

However, Beijing announced an indefinite postponement of Wang's visit after former ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" last July as mainland leaders interpreted the definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 244.74 points to close at 8,120.89.
Despite an increase in US stock prices, the bourse opened at 8,433.9 due to a lack of confidence on the part of investors and fluctuated between 8,440.84 and 8,112.08 during trading.

A total of 1.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.87 billion (US$2.66 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.52 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$78.69 billion.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 5.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 4.6 percent, textile issues at 3.8 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 3 percent, electrical shares at 2.9 percent, cement stocks at 2.4 percent, construction shares at 1.6 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 1.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 473 to 61, with 533 stocks remaining unchanged.

TAIEX Index Futures for August decreased 347 points to finish at 8,213, with 120 contract transactions, while September futures lost 267 points to close at 8,313, with 12 contract transactions.
