DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATE CALLS ON CHINA TO RELEASE UIGHUR BUSINESSWOMAN

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives International Relations Committee on Wednesday marked up Senate Concurrent Resolution 81, urging Communist China to immediately release Rabiya Kadeer, a prominent ethnic Uighur businesswoman, and to allow her, her secretary, and her son to leave mainland China.
The resolution can now move forward and be scheduled to be voted on by the full House of Representatives. The Senate passed the resolution on May 2.

Rabiya Kadeer, her secretary, and her son were arrested last August outside a hotel in the city of Urumqi as she was attempting to meet a group of US congressional staff staying there. Her husband Sidik Rouzi, who has lived in the United States since 1996 and works for Radio Free Asia, has been critical of Communist China's policies toward the Uighurs in Xinjiang, pointed out the resolution.

The Uighur businesswoman was sentenced on March 10 to eight years in prison for the crime of "illegally giving state information across the border." Reports indicate that her son was sent to a labor camp last November for two years without trial for "supporting Uighur separatism," and her secretary was recently sentenced to three years in a labor camp. Reports also indicate that Kadeer's health may be at risk.

Since Communist China has signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which forbids arbitrary arrest and detention, the resolution said, the US Congress calls on the government of the People's Republic of China to immediately release Kadeer, her secretary, and her son, and to permit them to move to the United States, if they so desire.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DONATE TIGERS TO AUSTRALIAN ZOO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is set to donate at least 10 tigers to Australia for the first time in a bid to write off its image as a place where the widespread killing of animals occurs.

In an interview with the CNA on Thursday, Dr. Kurtis Pei, associate professor of the Department of Wildlife Conservation at the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, said the Mogo Zoological Garden in Canberra had asked for more than 20 tigers from his school so that it could help protect the animals on the one hand and attract more people to see them on the other hand.
But the university presently only has a total of 31 tigers under its care and can only afford to donate 10 tigers to the Australian zoo, Pei said.
"This will be the biggest donation from Taiwan to a foreign country since we started our animal conservation and management program in Pingtung," Pei said.

In 1993, the university installed facilities to reproduce, protect, and breed animals, including orangutans, gibbons, and tigers, in order to showcase Taiwan efforts at caring for the island's animals. The university now has more than 420 animals under its care.
Pei on Wednesday went to see the facilities and holding grounds of the Mogo Zoo in Canberra.
Pingtung University, aside from breeding animals, has provided temporary loans of its animals, to other countries for educational purposes.

So far it has loaned out tigers, gibbons, and orangutans to Pakistan, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. And it will also loan animals to Britain, Australia, and New Zealand in the coming weeks and months, Pei said.
"I hope this donation will be a good start for the long-term cooperation between Taiwan and Australia in conserving, breeding and reproducing animals," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY TO HOLD 'HANKUANG NO. 16' EXERCISE IN MID-AUGUST

TEXT.P: The Republic of China military is scheduled to conduct a combined services exercise in northern Taiwan in mid-August, Vice Chief of the General Staff Wang Han-ning said on Thursday.
Wang made the report during a closed-door meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.
Wang was quoted as having told lawmakers that the planned combined services drill, code-named Hankuang (Chinese Glory) No. 16 military exercise, is a routine annual event.
Lawmakers quoted Wang as saying at the meeting that this year's Hankuang series of exercise will focus on correcting defects exposed in the 1999 drill.

According to legislators, Wang said the Hankuang No. 16 exercise will place emphasis on minimizing malfunction of any weaponry system, improving communications among various participating military units and practicing electronic warfare, anti-guided missile and other moder combat skills and tactics.

President Chen Shui-bian will personally review and oversee the combined services maneuvering in his capacity as the ROC armed forces' top leader. The drill will be conducted in the Taoyuan-Hsinchu-Miaoli area in northern Taiwan.

Wang also said the routine exercise is not expected to have any adverse impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait, adding that the disclosure of information about the drill is part of the Taiwan's efforts to foster a good atmosphere for cross-strait interaction.
Meanwhile, Wang said a series of civil air drills, code-named Wan-An No. 23 exercise, will be held in various parts of the island between July and August.
During the meeting, some lawmakers expressed doubts about President Chen's "offshore defense" concept.
In response, Wang said the "offshore defense" strategy is an active defense strategy aimed at avoiding bringing war to a country's own territory.

President Chen mentioned the "offshore defense" concept while making his first-ever military review as the supreme leader of the ROC's armed forces at the Chinese Military Academy in southern Taiwan on June 16.
According to Wang, the "offshore defense" strategy is a common military goal pursued by nearly all countries around the world.
On Tuesday, a Ministry of National Defense also pointed out that the ROC military's current combat guidelines are centered around "foiling invading troops at sea or thwarting them on beachheads."

In the future, the official said, the military will establish a strong deterrent force to effectively dissuade enemy troops (referring mainly to mainland Chinese armed forces) from launching an attack on Taiwan.

"This is an active defense strategy with a view to discouraging enemy forces from leaving the other side of the Taiwan Strait or foiling them once they cross over the center line of the strait," the official said, adding that this is also the gist of the "offshore defense" strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.002 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 30.808.
The local currency opened at 30.790 and was traded between 30.790 and 30.817.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$394 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS EUROPE VISIT 'VERY FRUITFUL'

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Thursday that his just-concluded visits to the Republic of China's only two diplomatic allies in Europe -- Macedonia and the Vatican -- were very fruitful.

Tien said he met with many people whom he desired to see. "I'm satisfied with the results of my first overseas trip since taking office," the scholar-turned-minister said, adding that the results were even beyond his original expectations.
During his 10-day, two-leg visit, Tien met with senior Macedonian and Vatican officials for extensive talks on matters of mutual concern.

Tien pointed out that cementing ties with Macedonia is very important. "Our relationship with Macedonia can serve as a showcase to other neighboring Balkan countries," Tien noted, adding that it can also help upgrade the ROC's international image.
Touching on relations with the Vatican, Tien said the ROC should make every possible efforts to maintain close ties with the Holy See.
Noting that the world has more than 1 billion Catholics, Tien said the Vatican has enormous influence not only on European countries but also on many Central and South American nations.

The Vatican is known to have been negotiating with mainland China for establishing diplomatic ties. Tien said although the Beijing-Vatican talks have been hindered by their great differences about religious freedom and rights to ordain Catholic clergy, the ROC should keep wary of mainland China's possible sabotage of Taipei-Vatican ties.

During his talks with his Vatican counterpart, Tien said Archbishop Jean-Louis Tauran assured him that if Taipei-Diplomatic ties will have any adjustments, the Holy See will certainly inform the ROC in advance.
While in Macedonia, Tien held an undisclosed meeting with Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski. Tien said the meeting was kept secret mainly because of Macedonia's domestic political situation.
Tien also signed an agreement with Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov on the establishment of a US$10 million fund to help Macedonia develop its battered economy.
As for former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's current visit to Britain, Tien said he was not particularly surprised by Beijing's outrageous reaction to Lee's first post-retirement overseas trip.

Tien said British authorities' handling of Lee's visit and Beijing's strong protests are "satisfactory." The minister also stressed that Lee's itinerary was arranged by the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank of which Lee is an honorary chairman. According to Tien, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has only provided Lee with necessary assistance and convenience.

Britain recognizes Beijing, but maintains close substantive ties with the ROC. "We hope countries that maintain diplomatic ties with mainland China can resist its pressure and continue forging close cooperative relations with us," he added.
Accompanied by his wife and several close aides, Lee left for London on Tuesday for a six-day private visit, his first overseas visit since stepping down from the presidency on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET SLUMP IS ONLY TEMPORARY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Wei Chi-lin, secretary general of the Executive Yuan, said Thursday that the current poor performance of Taiwan's stock market is only temporary, because the economic fundamentals are pretty good.
He made the remarks after top officials of the Ministry of Finance, the Central Bank of China, and the Ministry of Economic Affairs met in an emergency meeting on the stock market situations.
The benchmark weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchanges has dropped about 20 percent in the past two months to close at 8,120.89 Thursday.
He told the press that the officials who attended the meeting were optimistic about the stock market and that they attributed the market slump to investors' lack of confidence.
Wei said the market performance will soon return to normal, because the fundamentals of the economy are good.
He pointed out that the economy grew 7.93 percent in the first quarter of this year, the best performance in nine years. The economy is expected to grow 6.73 per cent this year.

Wei also pointed out that the business revenues of listed companies increased 15.06 percent in the first five months of this year over the same period of last year, and that their net profits before tax grew 152.85 percent in the first quarter of this year over a year earlier.

According to the statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the investment made by the private sector in the first three months of this year was 15 percent more than a year earlier, he said. Total private sector investment is expected to grow 13 percent in 2000, he added.
Exports from Taiwan in the first five months of this year hiked 22 percent over the same period of last year, Wei said, adding that commercial banks are making much more money than a year earlier.
He quoted the officials as saying in the meeting that investors have clear reasons to be confident in the stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CONTINUES GRASSROOTS 'REACH-OUT' TOUR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung on Thursday as part of his nationwide grassroots "reach-out" travel program.

Accompanied by Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan and several other local political heavyweights, Chen first arrived on the county's offshore township of Hsiaoliuchiou by a ferry boat early in the morning.
This was Chen's second visit to the small isle off the southern Taiwan coast in three months to show his concern about local residents' living conditions.
The president pointed out that Hsiaoliuchiou is a "jewel on the sea," not an isolated isle. "You are not alone. I'm always with you," he added emotionally.

Chen attended a special sailboat worshiping rite at the Taoist Sanlung Temple in Hsiaoliuchiou to pray for the nation's well-being. He said his administration is a government for all people and will take care of the benefits of all ROC nationals.

Chen said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has set aside budget in its budget plan for the coming fiscal year for purchasing a second ferry boat for Hsiaoliuchiou residents. At present, the offshore fishing township has only a ferry boat for links with Taiwan.
Chen also promised to urge relevant government agencies to improve drinking water supply for Hsiaoliuchiou residents.
Later in the day, Chen toured eel cultivation ranches and dairy farms in Pingtung County's Hsinyuan and Wantan villages before returning to Taipei.
Chen, who assumed office on May 20, began his nationwide grassroots "reach-out" tour on Tuesday, with a sandbar off the coast of Chiayi County in southwestern Taiwan as his first stop.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP VICE CHIEF `OUGHT TO BE ASHAMED': ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The head of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic body, said on Thursday that People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung should feel ashamed of his "improper remarks" about the institute.

Chang, a noted cardiologist who had just returned from a six-week visit to the United States, told a news conference that some US-based Academia Sinica academicians have alleged that Academia Sinica's research level fails even to meet the standard of a second-class American university.
Commenting on Chang's remarks, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said it was wrong for Chang to recount such criticism, since he has "never set foot in the institute."

Lee, a Taiwan-born co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry, said the US-based Science Magazine published two in-depth reports in recent issues on Academia Sinica's overall development, based on interviews with him and some researchers.

"I advise Chang to read these articles first before making any criticism of Academia Sinica," said Taiwan's foremost scholar. "Science Magazine has given a positive evaluation of the institute's progress in recent years."

Lee, who ended an enviable research career in the United States and returned to Taiwan to assume his current post about six years ago, said Academia Sinica's research in dynamic chemistry has reached the highest international level.

"Its research in astronomy has drawn world attention and its Institute of Molecular Biology's outstanding research results in life sciences have attracted many foreign universities to send executives to Taiwan with a view to recruiting the institute's research fellows to join their faculty rosters," Lee went on.
He stressed that while Academia Sinica probably has not yet achieved the level of the world's top-rate universities, it truly has made remarkable progress in the past five or six years.

Touching on Chang's criticism of the slow progress in Taiwan's educational reform, Lee, a member of a Cabinet-level educational reform advisory panel, said all 30 of its panelists have worked very hard over the past couple of years.

According to Lee, all the panelists, including himself, have often traveled around the island to promote educational reform. "In fact, we have made significant progress in educational reform, particularly in elementary education," he added.

Chang, a former Chang Gung University president, served as independent presidential candidate James Soong's running mate in the March 18 election. The Soong-Chang team lost to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidates, Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu, by a narrow margin. Encouraged by their supporters, Soong and Chang then formed the PFP in late March.

Chang said that during his just-concluded US visit, he met with many academics, including some Academia Sinica members. "I was surprised to find that many of those scholars were more critical of Lee than of Chen," he added.

Lee threw his support behind Chen in the final stage of the hotly contested election, and his endorsement was widely believed to have helped Chen to win the presidency. Both Soong and Chang left for the United States on the eve of Chen's May 20 inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH EAST EUROPEAN NATION POSSIBLE: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Legislator Chen Shei-saint disclosed on Thursday that Taipei is likely to set up formal diplomatic ties with an East European country in the near future.
While Chen said that he is not in a position to disclose the nation in question, he added that the country may be a neighbor of Macedonia, which forged formal ties with Taipei in January 1999.

Chen, head of the Foreign Affairs Committee under the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks following a breakfast gathering with Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, who on Wednesday returned from a ten-day visit to Macedonia and the Vatican, the only two European countries which maintain diplomatic links with the ROC.

Chen quoted Tien as saying that bilateral ties between Taipei and the Vatican remain stable at present, and that the Holy See has promised to notify Taipei if there is to be any change in two-way diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADER TALKS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, chairman-elect of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said here Thursday that the differences between China and Taiwan may be resolved by goodwill and interactions, not by rhetoric.

He made the remarks when talking about the definition of "one China." China has long insisted that there is only one China and that Taiwan is part of China, while Taiwan has said that it is willing to talk with China on the question of "one China," but the two sides should be free to make their own definitions.
Hsieh said that the differences between the two sides were made in history, and that such differences can only be resolved by goodwill and interactions.

He said President Chen Shui-bian was making overtures of goodwill to Beijing, when he said recently that Taiwan could accept the formula that would allow the two sides to have their own definitions of "one China."
Hsieh said what is important to the people of Taiwan is their security and well-being.
He said Taiwan's formal name is the Republic of China, which is a sovereign state.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHIPMAKERS EMBRACE MASK ROM CHIP MARKING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: On July 1, Taiwan chipmakers will be the first in the world to enforce a mask ROM chip marking system intended to prevent counterfeiting.

According to Taiwan's Intellectual Property Office (IPO), US officials during negotiations initially demanded that Taiwan extend the marking system to cover microprocessors, but Taiwan officials refused because too many companies would be affected.

Under the accepted policy, all mask ROM (read-only memory) chips must be stamped with identification numbers to help law enforcement agencies and intellectual property rights owners trace fake products.

Approximately 60 local semiconductor manufacturing companies and an estimated annual US$240 million worth of products are to be affected by the new regulation, which states that by September, any unmarked mask ROM chips will not be cleared for export.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN AIRLINES TO JOINTLY ESTABLISH TRAVEL WEBSITE

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) on Thursday signed an agreement with eight other regional airlines to establish a Pan-Asia Travel Portal website by the end of this year.

The independently managed portal website will provide full spectrum business-to-business and business-to-consumer travel services such as booking, ticketing, car rentals, hotel reservations, and package tours.

According to CAL, the website will initially be aimed at the Australian and Southeast Asian markets and may later expand into other Asian regions and mainland China by inviting other airlines and travel industry companies to collaborate.
CAL signed the online venture deal with Air New Zealand, Ansett Australia, Asiana Airlines, Cathay Pacific Airways, Singapore Airlines, Quantas Airways, Malaysia Air, and Royal Brunei Airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD INTERNATIONAL SINOLOGY CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel Prize winner for chemistry, on Thursday pointed out the importance of integrating the results of sinology studies.

Delivering a speech at the opening of the Third International Sinology Conference at Academia Sinica, he said that sinology is "an important asset of human civilization," and added that finding ways to integrate and preserve the wisdom of the ancestors is an important task at a time when some rare species and natural resources are rapidly vanishing from the earth.
The three-day conference is being attended by 251 scholars from Taiwan, mainland China and around the world.
The participants will split into seven groups -- history, literature, ideology, philology, linguistics, ethnic relations, belief and life -- to engage in discussions in 46 panels under 15 topics.

Professor Li Yi-yuan, secretary-general of the conference organizing committee, expressed hope that the conference can be held once every three to five years. The previous conference was held in 1986.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL CRITICIZES GOVERNMENT'S MAINLAND CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The government should return to the path set under the Guidelines for National Unification by the Kuomintang (KMT) if it is unable to break the current impasse with mainland China, a KMT official said on Thursday.

Should the present government led by the pro-unification Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) be unable to find a way to deal with the "one China, separate interpretations" consensus agreed upon by the former KMT government with mainland China in 1992, President Chen Shui-bian should consider adopting the policy set under the Guidelines for National Unification, according to Chang Jong-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Research Department.

Chang also criticized Chen for lacking a consistent policy toward mainland China, claiming that this uncertainty will not help stabilize the situation across the Taiwan Strait and benefit the people of Taiwan.
Much to the surprise of observers, Chen told visiting Asia Foundation Chairman William Fuller on Tuesday that he would embrace the 1992 "one China, separate interpretations" consensus.

But Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen called an emergency news conference later that day in which she pointed out that Taiwan and mainland China have never reached any consensus on the "one China" principle, and stressed that the people of Taiwan cannot accept Beijing's position that "there is only one China, and `one China' refers to the People's Republic of China."

According to Chang, the now-ruling DPP government's refusal to accept the "one China, separate interpretations" as a basis for negotiations and its attempts to discuss the meaning of "one China" with the mainland will directly touch on the hardest and most sensitive issue for both sides, provoking further cross-strait tension.

The KMT official suggested that Chen follow in the footsteps of the KMT, temporarily put aside the discussion of the "one China" dispute, and immediately reopen talks on technical issues with mainland China as a means of helping forge peace in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE US STATES TO OPEN OFFICES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US states of Delaware, Maryland and Kansas are to open representative offices in Taiwan, the American State Offices Association (ASOA) announced on Thursday.
The three states will jointly announce the grand opening of their representative offices at a news conference on Monday at the Taipei World Trade Center, the ASOA said in a press release.

In addition to bringing the total number of US state representative offices in Taiwan to 22, the opening of the three offices also represents a giant step toward a closer trade relationship between Taiwan and the United States, according to the ASOA.

Two-way Taiwan-US trade reached US$50 billion in 1999, with the United States being Taiwan's largest trade partner and Taiwan the US' seventh-largest trade partner. Taiwan is also the fifth-biggest market for US agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO IMPLEMENT NATIONAL PENSION SYSTEM NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition caucuses in the Republic of China Legislative Yuan decided on Thursday to introduce a national pension system from Jan. 1 next year.
The Executive Yuan agreed to accept the proposal by the lawmakers, and consequently withdrew its own draft of a "provisional statute for welfare allowances for the elderly" from the legislature.
President Chen Shui-bian promised during his election campaign that if he won the election, he would provide NT$3,000 (US$97) per month for every man and woman aged 65 or over from July 1.
However, the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party opposed the provisional statue, and decided to submit their own proposals regarding welfare allowances.
Anticipating a heated clash on the issue in Friday's legislative session, the legislators from both the ruling and opposition parties put their heads together to find a better solution.

They agreed that if the Cabinet would withdraw its provisional statute, the bills submitted by other parties would also be withdrawn, and the lawmakers would push for implementation of a national pension system from Jan. 1.

Premier Tang Fei said that it will be possible for the government to enforce the national pension system from Jan. 1, and he instructed related agencies to resolve two problems -- the source of funding and the model to be applied to the new system.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party stressed that the cancellation of the NT$3,000 welfare allowance for the aged should not be interpreted as a breach of Chen's election promise, and claimed that the national pension system, once implemented, will actually provide more benefits for the aged.

The Executive Yuan is required to present the draft of the national pension system to the legislature by Sept. 15. Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih estimated that NT$20-30 billion will be enough to cover the national pension system for the first year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-AMERICAN ACCUSED OF EXTORTION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Chinese-American who was convicted in the United States of illegally donating campaign funds to US President Bill Clinton was charged with extortion in Taiwan on Thursday.
Charlie Trie, 52, was booked by the Criminal Investigation Bureau after being accused by the local Hui Hsing Century Foundation of trying to obtain money by intimidation.
Trie was caught on Wednesday night by police at a restaurant in the Taipei suburb of Peitou where he was reportedly to have received NT$5 million (US$166,000) from the Hui Hsing Foundation.

Also arrested were four of his accomplices, including a man named Lin Hsing-pang who publicly charged foundation head Lin Cheng-tsai with cheating his actress wife out of money and having an affair with her.

The foundation claimed that Trie and his accomplices threatened to go public with the foundation's dirty laundry, including Lin's alleged antics with women, unless they were paid NT$8 million, a figure that was later cut to NT$5 million.
Trie denied the charge, saying that the money was the foundation's "compensation" for the death of his wife.

He claimed that his wife, who died in September 1998, joined the foundation as a voluntary worker earlier that year after being convinced by Lin that practicing what he preached could cure her of her colon cancer.
Trie, who arrived in Taiwan in May, said he demanded damages from the foundation for his mental suffering caused by the death of his wife, and that Lin agreed to pay him NT$5 million.

Trie is no stranger to falling foul of the law. The Taiwan immigrant struck up an acquaintance with US President Bill Clinton while operating a restaurant in Little Rock, Arkansas in the 1960s, and became one of Clinton's avid supporters. He later solicited campaign funds among Asian-Americans to help finance Clinton's numerous campaigns for public office.

Although Trie's business never made much of a profit, he was able to funnel US$220,000 to the Democratic National Committee between 1994 and 1996, and delivered nearly US$800,000 to a legal defense fund for Clinton when the president and his wife were being investigated for their controversial business venture in Whitewater, Arkansas.

He fled to Asia for more than a year when his role as a conduit for illegal political contributions to Clinton came under scrutiny, eventually surrendered, and was sentenced in the United States to community service.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SNAFU DRAWS FIRE FROM OPPOSITION LEADER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's latest statement on Taiwan's stance toward mainland China and the immediate denial by his chief mainland policy adviser drew fire from opposition People's First Party (PFP) official Chang Chao-hsiung on Thursday.

Chang, who was PFP Chairman James Soong's vice presidential running mate in the March 18 election and had just returned from a trip to the United States, aired his concerns over Chen's rapidly changing stance on mainland China, saying it cast doubt on the president's seriousness.

Chen told a group of US visitors on Tuesday that he would agree on the principle of "one China, with separate interpretations," but just a day later, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Chen's administration has never accepted the policy.
Chang described Chen as a political chameleon who shifts his political position so rapidly that no one can understand what he really thinks.

Judging from Chen's statement, he went on, a proposed supra-party panel designed to build consensus among various political parties is nothing but a rubber-stamp which will implement Chen's ideas rather than advise him on policy.
Claiming that statesmen tend to stick to their vision while politicians chase votes without respect to their stances, Chang said Chen should prove that he is a statesman rather than a politician.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CRITICIZES DPP ADMINISTRATION'S MAINLAND CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan on Thursday criticized the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's mainland China policy for being "inconsistent and worrisome."
Lien likened the government's mainland policy to "issuing an order in the morning and rescinding it in the evening."

He told visiting delegates of the US National Foreign Policy Committee that the DPP government's rapid sway from one policy to another not only makes attaining public consensus difficult, but also sets back cross-strait relations because the inconsistency makes it unlikely that Taipei will be able to rebuild communication channels with Beijing based on a foundation of mutual trust.

The issues facing both sides of the strait today cannot be resolved by "merely saying words that are delightful to the ear," Lien added as he urged the government to make substantial adjustments in both concept and stance to resolve the crisis.

Lien said that the KMT followed the "comprehensive designs" set forth in the National Unification Guidelines to come up with its "clear concept" on cross-strait policy, which is "one China, but not yet."

He added that the KMT does not identify with nor accept Beijing's "one China" principle, which states that Taiwan is a part of mainland China, and said: "The `one China' that we insist on refers to the Republic of China, and Taiwan is definitely not a part of the People's Republic of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST COMMERCIAL BANK SETS UP NEW OFFICE IN JAKARTA

TEXT.P: A representative office of the Taipei-based First Commercial Bank will start operations on Friday in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta to provide financial data and consultation services for its clients.
According to official Republic of China statistics, Taiwan's investment in Indonesia as of 1998 had reached US$13.6 billion, making it Indonesia's sixth-largest source of foreign investment.
Most of the Taiwan investment in Indonesia is wrapped up in pulp manufacturing, textiles, and the mineral and chemical sectors.

The First Commercial Bank has so far set up 19 offices abroad, in countries and areas such as the United States, Singapore, Britain, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, Palau, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, Burma and Malaysia.
A bank official said that preparations for opening additional branch offices in El Salvador and Canada are also under way.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taiwan tentatively decides to launch a national pension system from next year.
The China Times:
Lawmakers from across the political spectrum agree to opening of a national pension system from Jan. 1, 2001.
The United Daily News:
Taiwan may begin to implement a national pension system from 2001.
The Liberty Times:
The legislature will push for implementation of a national pension system from next year.
The China Post:
The Ministry of Finance takes action as TAIEX slumps.
The Taiwan News:
President Chen calls aides after stocks dive again.
The Taipei Times:
Government acts to boost ailing stocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SIGNS THAT MURDER-SUICIDE CASE CAME FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 29 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Sources at Taipei's representative office in Seattle said that the Chinese resident physician at the University of Washington Medical Center who killed his supervisor before committing suicide probably did not come from Taiwan as university authorities and police have been unable to prove this to be the case.

Instead, Jian Chen, a resident physician who fatally shot Dr. Rodger Haggitt, director of the UW Medical Center's Pathology Division, because he was about to lose his job, probably came from mainland China, the sources said.

They said campus police have been unable to find any documents or items that would indicate Chen came from Taiwan. Instead, all they have found is a single telephone number with a mainland China area code.

According to the university, Chen, in his 30s, graduated from Shanghai Medical University. He had studied at Mississippi University before entering the Medical Center of the University of Washington. Chen apparently had no relatives living in the Seattle area.

The police believe that Chen, who apparently had been experiencing language difficulties and other personal problems, was angry with Haggitt, his supervisor, because he was not going to renew Chen's contract. For a resident, this would mean an end to their professional training and would harm their prospects for employment in the future.

Officials from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle contacted university authorities in order to find out how they should contact Chen's family, but were told that so far there were no signs indicating that Chen came from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 144.2 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 144.2 points to close at 8,265.09.
Market turnover amounted to NT$79.43 billion (US$2.58 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 30, or the 29th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1918: Susan Hayward, the American actress who won an Oscar for "I Want to Live," is born.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: American general Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of the Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: US President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian astronauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record-breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.
1983: Hsu Shih-hsien, mayor of Chiayi and Taiwan's first female mayor, dies of liver cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Sten A. Akestam, president of the International Association of Lions Clubs, and six other top-ranking Lions officials.
1987: The construction of Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County, with a price-tag of NT$14 billion, is completed.
1989: ROC Interior Minister Hsu Shui-teh and Vice Defense Minister Kuo Tsung-chin jointly preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a national boundary stone tablet inscribed with the words "Shield of the South China Sea" on Tungsha Chuntao (the Pratas Islands) in the South China Sea.
1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the Deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The US government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: More than 200 civic leaders, foreign diplomats, Catholic and government officials, attend a reception given by the Rev. Thomas White, charge d'affaires of interim of the Apostolic Nunciature, to celebrate the 13th anniversary of the coronation of His Holiness Pope Paul VI.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1997: Britain hands Hong Kong back to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
1999: The US ratings agency Standard and Poor's gives the Republic of China's long-term foreign currency credit a rating of "AA+", indicating its belief that the country has a high level of capability in fulfilling its financial commitments.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer moving up 144.2 points to close at 8,265.09.
Encouraged by a series of favorable measures taken by the Republic of China government, the bourse opened at 8,159.41, and fluctuated between 8,290.63 and 8,050.02 during trading.

A total of 1.58 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.43 billion (US$2.58 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 1.57 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$81.87 billion.

All the eight major categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up the most at 4.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares and pulp and paper issues, both at 3.1 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.7 percent, cement shares at 2.5 percent, foodstuff stocks and construction shares, both at 1.6 percent, and electrical stocks at 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 407 to 115, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DECLINES COMMENTS ON CHEN'S REMARKS, BUT ENCOURAGES DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 30 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Department of State on Thursday declined to explain whether ROC President Chen Shui-bian's recent statement would help improve prospects for resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.

The State Department instead reiterated the Clinton administration's strong support for early resumption of cross-strait dialogue and its commitment to promoting peace, stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region.

"The United States strongly supports resumption of cross-strait dialogue and is committed to promoting peace, stability and prosperity of the region," said a State Department official, who preferred anonymity.
The official went on to say that it's up to Taipei and Beijing to determine the basis for dialogue and the modalities for dialogue.

"Our abiding interest is peaceful resolution of differences between the two sides," the US official said, adding: "To that end, we welcome steps that foster dialogue, reduce tensions, emphasize peaceful resolution and promote mutual understanding."
The official further said the Clinton administration urges both sides of the Taiwan Strait to refrain from actions or statements that increase tensions or make dialogue more difficult to achieve.

President Chen said in Taipei on Tuesday that his administration is willing to accept a 1992 consensus reached with Beijing on "one China, respective interpretations," but Beijing disagrees with that.

Chen, the Republic of China's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, made the statement while receiving visiting US-based Asia Foundation Chairman William Fuller at the Presidential Office.
Chen's statement drew different interpretations, and some news media claimed that it marked a major concession from Chen with an aim of facilitating resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

Chen himself and the ROC's mainland policy planner, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, however, have stressed that the spirit and content of Chen's Tuesday statement were consistent with his remarks made during his June 20 press conference, which marked Chen's first month in office.
