DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER VICE PRESIDENT LEADS KMT THINK-TANK

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who was also the former vice president of the Republic of China, was elected on Friday as the chairman of the newly-established KMT think-tank, the National Policy Research Foundation.

Addressing a ceremony marking the establishment of the think-tank, Lien said the Kuomintang is the sole financier of the foundation, and the party hierarchy will be responsible for choosing the 23-member board of directors.

As chairman of the foundation, Lien appointed former Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan and former Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chiang Pin-kun as two vice chairmen of the think-tank.

The National Policy Research Foundation, a non-profit organization, was first established by the Lien Chen-tung Cultural and Educational Foundation in 1984, with part of its NT$11 million fund coming from industrial business sector donations, according to Lien.

Recently, the Lien family transferred control of the National Policy Research Foundation to the Kuomintang. The KMT then enlarged the foundation's fund to NT$1 billion and made it a signature foundation of the party.
Board directors of the foundation are expected to be mostly ex-Cabinet officials of the former Kuomintang-controlled government under the premiership of Vincent Siew, according to think-tank sources.

In his speech, Lien said the immediate goal of the think-tank will be to study current political and economic circumstances at home and abroad in order to provide advice to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and President Chen Shui-bian's administration.

The think-tank's mid-range goal, said Lien, will be to help KMT members win mayoral races in Taipei and Kaohsiung, city council seats, as well as national-level legislative elections beginning in 2001.

As for its long-term goal, the think-tank will provide the government with plans and research results so as to help secure sustainable development and long-lasting prosperity for the nation, Lien added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Friday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for July moved up 60 points to close at 8,250, with 5,048 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for August increased 132 points to finish at 8,345, with 79 contract transactions, while September futures gained 70 points to close at 8,370, with 31 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 98 points to finish at 8,497, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 8,190 for July; 8,213 for August; 8,300 for September; 8,399 for December; and 8,368 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
July TE futures moved up 3.05 points to close at 465.15, with 1,151 contract transactions, while August TE futures lost 1 point to finish at 465, with nine contract transactions.
September TE futures moved up 3.05 points to close at 472.45, with four contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.
July TF futures increased 16 points to close at 836, with 464 contract transactions, while August TF futures moved up 11 points to finish at 843, with 21 contract transactions.
September TF futures gained 12 points to close at 847, with seven contract transactions, while December TF futures decreased 2.4 points to finish at 848, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for next March TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT TO ARRIVE ON SATURDAY FOR STATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Saturday for a five-day state visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Friday.
Moscoso will be the first foreign head of state to visit the Republic of China since the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian's administration was inaugurated on May 20.

Kuo Yung-liang, deputy director of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs Department, said Moscoso's visit is of great significance. "We believe that her visit will help cement the longstanding diplomatic relations between our two countries," he explained.

Moscoso assumed office on Sept. 12, 1999 as Panama's first popularly elected female head of state. She will be accompanied by Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman and other senior Panamanian officials, particularly those in economic and financial fields, on her ROC visit.

During her stay, Moscoso will meet with President Chen, Premier Tang Fei, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high-ranking ROC officials for exchanges of views on matters of mutual concern, including measures to further boost bilateral cooperation.

Commenting on press reports that the ROC will offer a US$30 million loan to Panama during Moscoso's state visit, Kuo said Moscoso's administration has devoted much energy to infrastructure construction and living quality upgrading projects.
As for the reported US$30 million lending program, Kuo said the plan is still on the drawing board and has not yet entered an "enforcement stage."

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL WARMING MAY OPEN NORTHWEST PASSAGE

TEXT.P: Due to the effects of global warming, Arctic icecaps are expected to have melted enough within a few decades to open the Northwest Passage for at least part of the year, cutting the voyage between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans by a third.

Right now, the fastest route between Europe and the Far East is via the Panama Canal, about 12,600 nautical miles. A gateway through the Canadian Arctic would cut the trip to about 7,900 nautical miles.
Temperatures continue to rise in the polar regions of the northern hemisphere where the thickness of the permanent ice cap has already diminished by 40 percent, according to a Canadian news report.

Scientists are predicting that, within the next few decades, ships will be able to traverse the cold waters in the north unassisted for one to three months a year. There likely will also be a couple extra months when ships can make the trip escorted by an icebreaker, the report said.

But some experts say the fabled Northwest Passage will remain a fantasy. They say the effects of global warming are exaggerated and things have to really heat up before the passageway receives any sort of large-scale consideration.

If the Northwest Passage becomes a dream-come-true for ship captains, icebergs would still continue to be a real threat. Even small icebergs that only rise a few feet above the water's surface can sink a ship.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA RUNNING OUT OF CASH TO PAY UNEMPLOYED

TEXT.P: Mainland China is running out of cash needed to pay the unemployed as its state firms continue to lay off more workers due to reforms being implemented to make the enterprises more efficient and profitable, reported The Australian Financial Review on Friday.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the daily reported many state firms in mainland China are now finding difficulties paying the welfare benefits they are responsible for providing to redundant workers. The Ministry of Labor and Social Security this week conceded that delayed payments now totaled more than 1.45 billion yuan.
The ministry also stated that mainland China still has a long way to go in upgrading its social welfare system, the daily reported.

Mainland China last month was forced to seek a US$500 million loan from the Asian Development Bank to help establish a new national fund to recapitalize the country's social welfare system, the daily reported.

Between January and April this year, China's state firms laid off about 6 million workers, bringing the total number of people laid off to 25 million since Premier Zhu Rongji announced sweeping reforms to over 320,000 state firms across mainland China over two years ago, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERTS OPPOSE SALE OF AEGIS-EQUIPPED SHIPS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: In an apparent blow to Taiwan's hopes of acquiring advanced US-made warships, a group of US experts have concluded that the transfer of sea-based Theater Missile Defense platforms is "unwise at this time".

The group of 14 prominent experts said they believe that the sale of lower-tier TMD systems "clearly falls within the guidelines of the Taiwan Relations Act", the basis for US military assistance to Taiwan.
The experts, however, argued in a new report that sea-based TMD for Taiwan "makes less political and military sense than the procurement of land-based systems".
In a Henry L. Stimson Center working group report, the experts noted that the Republic of China Navy is "not prepared to introduce the sophisticated Aegis-equipped destroyers into its fleet".
This type of vessel has the potential to become a platform for a sea-based TMD, which is still under development. The Clinton administration turned down Taiwan's request for such vessels in April.

Also, the report said the experts "recognized that Aegis-equipped ships operated by the US Navy--working in conjunction with other US military assets--would have far more utility (in protecting Taiwan) than Aegis-equipped ships operated by the ROC Navy."

Taiwan is interested in upgrading the units of its Modified Air Defense System, a Patriot Advanced Capability 2 derivative, to a fully capable PAC-3 system. The experts recommended that the United States support such requests from Taiwan.
Citing the likely averse reaction from Beijing, they also cautioned against inter-operability between TMD systems under the respective control of the United States and Taiwan.

Other recommendations made in the report were that the US continue utilizing the existing arms sales process to evaluate TMD transfers to Taiwan on a case-by-case basis, that Beijing and Taipei pursue confidence-building measures to defuse cross-strait tensions, that the US refrain from participating in military exercises with Taiwan, and that the next US administration issue a white paper connecting all the key elements of US policy toward Beijing and Taiwan.
The working group report, called Theater Missile Defenses in the Asia-Pacific Region, also discussed possible TMD transfers to Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS SENT TO CAMBODIA TO HELP FAMILY OF DEAD ROC MERCHANT

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said on Friday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has dispatched officials to Cambodia to help investigate the death of Taiwanese merchant Lee Chih-shin.

Tien said the Republic of China maintains no liaison or representative offices in certain countries, and he called on Taiwanese citizens and businessmen to be extra careful when traveling to those countries, particularly nations that are politically and socially unstable -- such as Cambodia.

According to MOFA spokesman Henry Chen, Wang Ping, a trade official with MOFA's representative office in Vietnam, and Wu Kuang-tin, a secretary with the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), were on their way to Phnom Penh via Vietnam on Friday to assist Lee's family.

Sources from Cambodia reported that Lee, president of the Taiwanese Business Association in Cambodia and owner of a construction company, was shot dead on Thursday in front of his Phnom Penh residence while sitting in the back of his car.

Another man in the car, identified as Liu Hsin-yi, also from Taiwan, who runs a concrete and gravel processing company, was shot in the left arm but survived the short-range shots described by police as a contract killing.

Witnesses said Lee and Liu were assaulted by two unidentified gunmen who wore military uniform. The Taiwanese business circle in Phnom Penh believes that Lee, a warm-hearted man who liked to be "big brother" to his fellow countrymen, was killed over a business disagreement between Liu and Cambodian businessmen.

Lee, who was in his 40s, arrived in Cambodia some four years ago. Although having been involved in many trades, including the travel, farming and construction businesses, Lee did not have much money, probably because of his "chivalrous nature," according to his friends.
Wu will accompany Lee's wife, who lives in their hometown in Tainan County, to Phnom Penh and provide her with assistance in filing a lawsuit and handling her husband's remains.

Commenting on the assassination, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu said the incident will undoubtedly hinder Cambodia in its efforts to woo Taiwanese capital and investors. Taiwan is currently Cambodia's third-largest source of foreign investment, primarily in the garment sector.

The number of Taiwanese businessmen who still have manufacturing operations in Cambodia has fallen to some 1,000 from around 4,000 four years ago, mainly as a result of Cambodia's political and social instability.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 80 PERCENT OF MACAU AIRPORT ARRIVALS ARE TAIWAN RESIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, June 30 (CNA) (By Ren Zhong-hong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Nearly 85 percent of the people who entered Macau through its international airport between January and May this year were visitors from Taiwan, Macau government sources said on Friday.

Figures compiled by the Macau Statistics and Census Bureau show that 325,401 visitors arrived at Macau International Airport in the first five months of this year, up 26.8 percent over the year-earlier figure.
Of these visitors, 84.8 percent came from Taiwan and 8.3 percent came from mainland China, according to the bureau statistics.
During the same period, some 3 million other visitors entered Macau via sea and land routes, most of whom were from Hong Kong, bureau officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO US TO ASSUME OFFICE

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen will leave for Washington, D.C. next Wednesday to assume his new post.
Chen, a seasoned career diplomat, said at a swearing-in ceremony that he will do his utmost to strengthen substantive ROC-US relations based on the current foundation.
In addition, Chen said, he will also continue improving and expanding services to ROC nationals residing in the United States.
Chen has previously served as deputy representative to the United States, director-general of the Government Information Office and foreign minister.
His swearing-in ceremony was presided over by Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, who succeeded Chen as the ROC's diplomatic chief on May 20.
Tien praised Chen as an outstanding diplomat and said he hopes Chen's new job will go smoothly.
After the ceremony, Tien said it is still uncertain whether President Chen Shui-bian will make his first post-inauguration overseas visit in August, and that the trip is still in the planning stages.
Previous reports had said Chen might attend the Aug. 16 presidential inauguration of the Dominican Republic, an ROC diplomatic ally.

The topic has drawn increasing attention after Tien made "fruitful" visits to the ROC's only two European allies -- Macedonia and the Vatican -- earlier this month, and former ROC President Lee Teng-hui arrived in Britain on Wednesday for a visit, despite furious protests from Beijing.
Tien pointed out that the timing of a country's head of state's overseas visits needs prudent consideration.

Kuo Yung-liang, deputy director of the Central and South American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, told a routine news conference on Friday that the ROC will certainly send a special delegation to attend the Dominican Republic's presidential inauguration.
"As for who will lead the delegation, the government is still mulling the issue. Anyway, we'll designate a well-placed official to serve as the special envoy," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES US DELEGATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Friday that he has been consistent in seeking improved relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The president said that his basic tone remains unchanged from what he said in his inaugural speech on May 20, when he said that through building upon the existing foundation and constructing conditions for cooperation through goodwill, the leaders across the Taiwan Strait can jointly handle the problem of a future "one China."

Chen said his remarks on cross-strait relations have been consistent in spirit and content, whether on June 20, when he expressed hope that he could shake hands with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and sit down to talk with him as did the two Korean leaders earlier in June, or on June 27, when he said that he accepted the consensus reached in cross-strait talks in 1992 on "one China, different interpretations."
Chen made his latest remarks as he received an 11-member delegation led by William Flynn, chairman of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP), a US think tank.

Chen noted that since 1997, the NCAFP has held round table meetings and has conducted study and research on issues related to cross-strait relations, which has contributed greatly to a stable and secure Asia-Pacific region.

Chen said that he was positive about the "track II" dialogue channel -- unofficial Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue channels to reduce cross-strait tensions -- adding that he welcomes any activities or proposals that help improve cross-strait relations and contribute to the regional peace and stability.

Dr. Donald Zagoria, a delegation member, lauded Chen's wisdom in dealing with cross-strait relations since his inauguration, but he also asked Chen to elaborate on his remarks on Tuesday regarding "one China, respectively interpretations."

Chen said that as a democratic and pluralistic society, Taiwan has various different views on the handling, interpretation and future direction of cross-strait relations, which is the reason why he asked Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh to head a supra-party ad hoc team to forge national consensus on the issue.

He said that the ultimate resolution of the cross-strait problem will have to be decided by the Taiwan people, and noted that US President Bill Clinton said that any solution should be acceptable to the Taiwan people following a mainland Chinese white paper in February warning Taiwan not to postpone unification talks indefinitely.
Chen said that the Taiwan people cannot accept that "`one China' means "the People's of Republic of China," and that they cannot identify with the idea that "Taiwan is a part of the PRC."

Saying that the Taiwan people insist on upholding the sovereignty, dignity and safety of the Republic of China, Chen said the true voice of the Taiwan people must be heard by the United States and the international community.
He said that the mainland has insisted on Taiwan accepting its "one China" principle, and that it believes both sides reached consensus on that principle in 1992, which he said is far from truth.
He said that if the Taiwan people were to accept such a principle, then the "principle would turn into a conclusion," and added that "we will not fall into such a framework or pitfall."

He said that if Taiwan were to become a part of the People's Republic of China, then the two sides would have no need for dialogue. As the president of a free and democratic ROC, Chen said he will follow the will of the people and safeguard the sovereignty and dignity of the nation.

The US delegation arrived in Taipei on Wednesday and was scheduled to leave on Saturday. During its stay in Taiwan, the delegation also met with Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Premier Tang Fei and Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP VICE CHAIRMAN TO STAY IN POLITICS FOR 4 MORE YEARS

TEXT.P: Chang Chao-hsiung, vice chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), said on Friday that he had made up his mind to stay in politics for "four more years."

Chang is a noted surgeon who was serving as president of the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital when he was invited by former Kuomintang stalwart James Soong, who ran as an independent in the March 18 election, to serve as his running mate.
The Soong-Chang ticket finished second in the election, garnering 36.8 percent of the vote behind President Chen Shui-bian's 39.1 percent.
The PFP was formed after the election at the urging of Soong's supporters.
Chang also said that while he will not run for public office, he will go around the nation to campaign for others as a way to reciprocate the support he received during the election campaign.

Saying that the reason he decided against staying in politics is because "there are patients in Chang Gung who are waiting for me to perform surgery," he added that he will report to Y.C. Wang, head of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) -- Chang Gung Memorial Hospital is an affiliate of FPG -- to inform him about his decision.

Speaking of reasons behind his election defeat, Chang said that Soong's handling of a financial scandal was flawed, which dealt a blow to the campaign, but he also criticized the "demonization" campaign against Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: University of Minnesota President Mark G. Yudof is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Saturday at the head of a nine-member delegation for a three-day visit.
While here, Yudof will call on Republic of China Minister of Education Ovid J.L. Tzeng and visit the National Palace Museum.
University of Minnesota alumni in Taiwan will host a dinner in his honor on July 3, when Yudof will confer an outstanding alumnus award on Perng Fai-nan, governor of Taiwan's Central Bank of China.

Yudof took the post as the university's 14th president on July 1, 1997. He had previously served as dean of the Law Department and vice president of the University of Texas. A law professor, Yudof mainly teaches the Constitution of the United States, education law and contract law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT LAUDS MILITARY NEUTRALITY IN ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Friday that the Republic of China's armed forces provided a good model by maintaining strict political neutrality around the time of the March 18 presidential election.

Chen lauded the military's adherence to a neutral stance during the hotly contested presidential race as he presided over a promotion ceremony for senior officers at the Armed Forces Officer's Club in downtown Taipei.

Chen, the ROC's first head of state from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said the military deserves praise for abiding by the Constitution and upholding constitutional democracy during the presidential race.

"The military's performance helped maintain domestic stability during the island's first democratic transition of power between different political parties," Chen said, adding that it also signifies the military's achievements in "democratization and nationalization."
Article 138 of the ROC Constitution stipulates that the armed forces shall be above personal, regional or party affiliations, shall be loyal to the state, and shall protect the people.

Chen's stunning victory in the March 18 presidential election marked an end to the Kuomintang's 55-year grip on power in Taiwan. Shortly after the end of the voting, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming, on behalf of all branches of the armed forces, pledged loyalty to the ROC's new president.

At Friday's ceremony, a total of 61 military officers in land, sea and air forces were promoted to the rank of either major-general, lieutenant-general, rear-admiral or vice admiral. The promotions were to take effect from Saturday.

In his speech, Chen encouraged the new crop of military brass to apply new information technology and management concepts to troop training, education, leadership, administration and combat preparedness in order to build up a truly high-quality, professional and modern defense force.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RECOGNIZES ROC PRESIDENT'S APPROACH TO CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES: MAC

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China official said on Friday that the United States recognizes ROC President Chen Shui-bian's "soft but firm" approach in dealing with issues related to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks at a press conference after his return from an 11-day visit to the United States.

Lin said the United States has become more attentive to Taiwan's public opinion and attaches even greater importance to Taiwan's strategic, political and economic status following the island's first democratic transition of power between different political parties in May.

Lin, an expert on mainland China's military development, headed a delegation of government officials, academics and representatives of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on its visit to the United States from June 13-23.

During the visit, Lin said, the delegation attended more than 20 seminars, met with 45 influential US scholars and experts, visited 10 universities and think tanks, five newspapers, and held talks with 13 media executives.

Lin said that since Chen delivered his inaugural speech on May 20 and held his first post-inauguration press conference on June 20, "various US quarters 100 percent" recognized his "prudent, soft yet firm" approach in handling cross-strait issues.
"Even some Americans who used to be critical of Taiwan gave a thumbs-up to Chen's performance, and, as a result, the atmosphere throughout the visit was good and amicable," Lin explained.

During the visit, Lin recalled, many of the people he met with repeatedly mentioned US President Bill Clinton's statements that any resolution of cross-strait issues must respect the opinion of the people of Taiwan and must have their assent.

"This indicates that the United States now attaches greater importance to our public opinion, our strategic position and our political and economic clout, particularly our achievements in political democratization," Lin added.
In addition, Lin went on, many other major countries, including Japan and Britain, are also paying increasing attention to Taiwan.

Quoting an unidentified Englishman, Lin said the British government will become even more attentive to Taiwan and that its interest in Taiwan is also rising steadily, citing as evidence former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's current visit to Britain.

Lee, an outspoken critic of Beijing's hegemonic attitude toward Taiwan and its diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, left for London on Tuesday for his first post-retirement overseas visit. Although Lee stepped down from the presidency on May 20 and does not now hold any public office, Beijing has lodged strong protests to the British government over its granting of a visa to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC GOVERNMENT URGED TO TAKE PART IN MORE NGO ACTIVITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 29 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting former Taiwan official suggested on Thursday that the new Republic of China government play a more active role in activities sponsored by international non-government organizations (NGOs).

Tsai Cheng-wen, a minister-without-portfolio during the Kuomintang government era, made the call at a seminar being held in Paris on the possible impact of the ROC's recent transition of power from the KMT to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Tsai pointed out that although Taiwan's peaceful democratic transition of power has drawn global attention, its diplomatic plight is not expected to improve at least in the foreseeable future due to Beijing's rigid diplomatic embargo against Taiwan.

Tsai said unless Beijing softens its diplomatic isolation strategy against Taiwan, new ROC President Chen Shui-bian's administration faces a diplomatic situation similar to that in the period of KMT rule.
"Taiwan's democratization alone cannot fundamentally change the general international situation," Tsai noted.

Nevertheless, Tsai said after both sides of the Taiwan Strait are admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the near future, Taiwan will have a better chance of forging economic and trade ties with more countries around the world under the WTO framework.

Moreover, Tsai said he believes that there is still ample room for the ROC to expand its role in NGO activities. According to Tsai, the world currently has more than 20,000 international and regional non-government organizations (NGOs).

At the moment, Tsai said, Taiwan has taken part in less than 1,000 NGOs. "The new ROC government should devote more efforts to NGO activities to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TANG FEI INSPECTS POST-QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION PROGRESS

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei on Friday inspected the progress of post-quake reconstruction in Taichung and Nantou counties for the first time since taking office on May 20.

Tang, who spent a large portion of his first weeks in office recovering from surgery in a hospital until his release on June 18, arrived at the seat of the provincial government in Nantou County -- where the post-disaster reconstruction committee meets -- to listen to reports on the progress of reconstruction efforts.

Tang told local county magistrates and legislators that he could not immediately come up with solutions to all reconstruction problems, bit that his committee will handle them in order of priority and try to complete all reconstruction work within four years.

The preliminary allotment of the Executive Yuan's 2001 fiscal budget did not leave room for the reconstruction plans, Tang said, adding that the government will have to raise the necessary funds through other means.

Tang said that the government will begin raising the money by practicing thrift in government expenditures. Failing that, the money could come from special budgets or business tax increases, he added.

He later visited areas in Taichung and Nantou County to observe actual work in progress and to speak with people living in the disaster areas. The two central Taiwan counties were hardest hit by last year's Sept. 21 earthquake, which measured 7.3 on the Richter scale and killed 2,400 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS QUESTION PREMIER-PRESIDENT RELATIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Legislators of the opposition People First Party (PFP) on Friday questioned Premier Tang Fei's absence from an emergency financial meeting held by President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday.
The PFP lawmakers said that Tang's absence begged the question of whether Tang is being treated as a figurehead, and whether a serious rift has opened up between Chen and Tang.
Legislator Chin Hui-chu said that unless a rift really exists, Tang would not have spoken of quitting his post after less than two months in office.

Chin was referring to an announcement by Tang on Thursday that he will tender his resignation at the end of August -- after just three months in office -- if the public continues to believe he is not fit for the job.

Questions have been asked about Tang's ability to promote his policies after the Cabinet's versions of a reduced work-week bill and a pension bill were voted out in the Legislative Yuan, where the opposition Kuomintang holds a majority.
Chang Chun-hsiung, Presidential Office secretary-general and spokesman, said on Friday that the president looks highly upon Tang's sense of duty and determination to promote government policies.

He urged the public to give Tang and his Cabinet more support and encouragement, and to give the new government some time. He assured the public that the results of the new government's policies will withstand the test of time.

PFP legislator Lee Ching-hua, on the other hand, urged Chen to give Tang some time and space to lead his Cabinet instead of taking national defense, foreign policy, cross-strait relations, and finance into his own hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'A-BIAN' ELECTION SUPPORTERS PROTEST HIS REMARKS ON 'ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: A group of President Chen Shiu-bian's electoral supporters in southern Taiwan released a statement on Friday accusing Chen of betraying them by saying he would accept the "one China, separate interpretations" basis for reopening negotiations with mainland China.

The declaration, signed by more than 20 major supporters of Chen's presidential campaign from the southern Taiwan counties of Kaohsiung and Tainan, charged that Chen has made too many concessions to mainland China since his inauguration on May 20.

Chen had told visiting Asian Foundation Chairman William Fuller on Tuesday that he would embrace the "one China, separate interpretations" consensus agreed upon by the two sides in 1992 as a basis for reopening negotiations with mainland China.

According to the declaration, Chen's concessions have deeply hurt the feelings of his long-time backers, represent a withdrawal from hard-won precedents set by former President Lee Teng-hui, and are a political betrayal of Chen's pro-Taiwan independence allies.

Stressing that Taiwan and mainland China are independent sovereignties, the statement said that mainland China has no right to claim Taiwan as a part of it, and there is no need for Taiwan to concede political ground in the face of China's military threats.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S REMARKS ON 'ONE CHINA' ARE CONSISTENT: MAC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's remarks on "one China" have been consistent in both spirit and content, Lin Chong-pin, spokesman and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said here Friday.

President Chen told Chairman William Fuller of the US-based Asia Foundation on June 27 that his government is willing to accept a 1992 consensus, which would allow both sides of the Taiwan Straits to have their own definitions of "one China." The consensus was reached orally by negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China in a meeting.
The remarks made by Chen on June 27 are consistent with those made in his May 20 inaugural speech and June 20 press conference in both spirit and content, Lin said.

MAC chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen clarified Chen's June 27 remarks at a press conference on the next day, Lin said. In the press conference, Tsai stressed that the government is willing to accept the way of making the definitions. It does not mean that Taiwan is willing to accept China's definition, Tsai said. enditem/eh

DOC.HEADLINE: TERRITORY DISPUTE CASTS SHADOW OVER PHILIPPINE-MAINLAND CHINESE TIES

TEXT.P: The dispute over the South China Sea casts a long shadow over relations between the Philippines and the People's Republic of China, despite closer ties between the two countries over the past 25 years, Philippine Foreign Affairs Undersecretary for Policy Lauro Baja Jr. said on Friday.

Speaking at a celebration of the 25th anniversary of official relations between the two nations at the University of the Philippines, Baja said some areas of the South China sea -- particularly Mischief Reef in the Spratly Islands and Scarborough Shoal -- are the subjects of a protracted territorial and maritime row between the two countries.
"Neither side is willing to burn all its bridges on the South China Sea," he said, but added that the issues would not be easy to solve.
The DFA official noted that bilateral and regional mechanisms have been put in place to diffuse tensions in the area and build confidence among concerned parties.

"The ASEAN-mainland China working group on the regional code of conduct in the South China sea has just come out with a consolidated text for the formulation of the code. The eventual adoption (of the code) in the immediate future will hopefully also contribute to a new phase of mutual trust and confidence on security concerns of both countries," Baja said.
The Philippines and mainland China achieved only minimum progress during their first 15 years of bilateral relations, which took a more dynamic turn only in the 1990s, Baja noted.

Incidents in the South China Sea involving the respective naval forces of the two countries and their fishermen always caused wars of words between the two countries and exchanges of diplomatic protests.

"I am convinced that renewed confidence in the political and security aspects of our relations could be found in the years that lie ahead. I am optimistic that in the immediate future, we may see the transition towards better and closer political ties and a good understanding of mutual security concerns," Baja said.
He added this would be achieved by intensified parallel exchanges of officials in all levels of government, military, defense and security departments from the two countries.

Both the Philippines and mainland China have worked to develop a more harmonious relationship, resulting a state visit by President Estrada to mainland China last month. The two sides have also released a joint statement on a framework for bilateral relations in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HONG KONG TIES NEED IMPROVEMENT: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Two-way ties between Taiwan and Hong Kong should be further improved now that the former British colony has been under Beijing rule for almost three years, said an ROC official on Friday.

C. C. Tsai, head of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department under the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said bilateral Taiwan-Hong Kong relations need to be further improved, although the current situation in Hong Kong remains stable under Beijing's "one country, two systems" scheme.

According to Tsai, mainland China has not explicitly interfered in Hong Kong affairs, but a lack of confidence among the people of Hong Kong has cast a shadow of uncertainty over the free-wheeling capitalism and freedom of the press in the territory.

Tsai said that the MAC will continue to seek ways to break the deadlock over Chang Liang-jen, the newly-appointed director for the Hong Kong Affairs Bureau who is expected to serve as the de facto representative of the Republic of China in the former British colony.
Chang has been denied a visa in Hong Kong since the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: B747-400 CARGO PLANES TO JOIN CAL, EVA AIR CARGO FLEETS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 29 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) and Eva Air will each receive Boeing 747-400 cargo planes in July, adding to their respective cargo fleets, sources with Boeing Co. said Thursday.
CAL has ordered 13 B747-400 cargo planes for a total price tag of US$2.5 billion and retains an option to purchase four more of this type of cargo plane.

Boeing said the 13 cargo planes will be delivered one at a time between 2000 and 2007, with the first of them being handed to CAL next month. Previously, CAL has never owned any B747-400 cargo planes.
Eva Air ordered three B747-400 cargo planes last year and the first of them will also be delivered next month, Boeing announced.

Eva Air and CAL have spared no efforts in recent years to raise their cargo transportation capacities. Eva Air and CAL reportedly rank first and second in the world in terms of cargo transportation growth among the world's major airlines.
Boeing also revealed on Friday that Eva Air recently signed a contract with Boeing to procure 15 B777-200X and B777-300X passenger planes for a total price tag of US$3 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PROMOTES DIGITIZED PRESERVATION OF CHINESE LITERATURE

TEXT.P: Sinologists from around the world met at Taiwan's Academia Sinica on Friday to discuss the digital preservation of traditional Chinese literature and language archives.

A total of 251 scholars from Taiwan, mainland China, and overseas are in attendance at the Third International Sinology Conference, a three-day meeting that began Thursday. The scholars are engaged in various discussions among 46 separate workshops and panels.

During the conference, held 14 years after the most recent of its kind, Academia Sinica researchers unveiled the volumes of searchable digitized Chinese text that they have encoded over the past 15 years.

According to Academia Sinica researcher Huang Kuang-chung, the digital archive currently boasts a total of 330 million characters -- 120 million of which have been completely proofread, 50 million of which have gone through the first round of proofreading, and 160 million of which still await proofreading.
Researchers have completed searchable indices on several ancient texts as well, Huang added.

The scholars presented over ten papers on the next stage of digitization in the field of sinology. Among them, National Taiwan University's Huang Pei-jong presented a paper on "the benefits of ancient text font archive development for the study of written Chinese characters." Others offered research on the design and application of ancient text databases and search systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN DECIDES TO PROMOTE NATIONAL PENSION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: After intense negotiations among various parties, the Legislative Yuan decided on Friday to ask the Executive Yuan to launch a national pension program, preferably beginning from January 1, 2001.

As to the administration's bill on a pension for senior citizens, which will be preempted by the national pension program, the Legislative Yuan said they will allow the Executive Yuan to withdraw on the grounds of budget restrictions.

In what was seen as another setback to Executive Yuan, Premier Tang Fei agreed on Wednesday to replace the senior citizen pension, one of President Chen Shui-bian's major campaign promises, with a broader national pension program.
Noting that a national pension system is the ultimate goal of his administration, Tang said he would like to incorporate the senior citizen pension into the national pension program.

The Legislative Yuan dealt a blow to the administration on June 16 by rejecting its bill to cut the minimum working hours from 48 hours per week to 44 hours per week. Instead, the Executive Yuan voted to reduce the workweek to 84 hours every two weeks.
However, the premier warned that the current government budget would not be able to pay for the program, and the government is mulling a tax hike to finance it.
But his Cabinet members seem to have different opinions on what tax should be increased.
Chen Po-chih, chair of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Friday that he favoured raising the sales tax by one percent next year.
The tax hike will increase the government's coffers by NT$40 billion (US$1.33 billion) a year, enough to cope with the startup costs of the program without seriously affect local industries.

Meanwhile, Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong opposed Chen's idea, arguing that an increase in sales tax would further dampen already-weakened non-tech industries, which have seen stock prices dip to record lows recently.

Although a tax increase is inevitable in light of the government's dwindling revenue and increasing expenditure in social welfare, Shea said the time could not be worse for a tax increase, since it would undermine current government efforts to rejuvenate traditional, labor-intensive industries.
Tang's statement about a tax hike has drawn fire from the Kuomintang (KMT), the major opposition party in the Legislative Yuan.
KMT Legislator Chen Hung-chi said Tang's administration is pulling the rug out from under President Chen Shui-bian, who promised not to raise taxes both before and after the presidential elections.

Chen of the KMT noted that President Chen said after being sworn-in that his government would differentiate itself from the former administration by being efficient and thrifty concerning expenditures, rather than resorting to tax increases.

Chiang Pin-kung, a former CEPD chair and now head of a KMT think tank, said the national pension program should be launched as a kind of compulsory insurance financed mainly by premiums, rather than social welfare funded by tax.

Chiang said that according to the program crafted by the CEPD under the former administration, the government would bear no more than 40 percent of all premiums, and beneficiaries would get a pension of about NT$8,700 per month.

The program, if solely funded with tax, will drain the government's resources, due to the expanding population of senior citizens, which now stands at 1.8 million, and is expected to surge to 5 million by 2010, said Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES TO WORK FIVE DAYS PER WEEK STARTING NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: A bill shortening the workweek of government employees to five days passed its last hurdle at the Legislative Yuan on Friday.

Under the revised Government Functionaries Service Law, which was approved upon its third reading on Friday, the government will cut down on the number of existing national holidays to adjust to the five-day workweek, which is to take effect at the beginning of next year.

Under a proposal put forward by the Executive Yuan, most current national holidays designed to mark political events will be observed without a day off from work, while traditional folk festivals will remain holidays.
The new workweek system will bring government employees' total days off duty to 115 or 116 a year.
